name: Anneli JÄÄTTEENMÄKI
text: The first item is the report by Heidi Hautala, on behalf of the Committee on Legal Affairs, on monitoring the application of Union law: Annual Report 2014 (2015/2326(INI) (A8-0262/2016).

name: Heidi HAUTALA
text: rapporteur. – Madam President, every year the Commission reports to Parliament and to the Council on the application of Union legislation. The current report is already the thirty-second of its kind. I had the honour to be the rapporteur for the 2014 report. We can soon discuss the key findings and conclusions, but before that let us think for a moment why these reports are made.  The European Union was founded to promote peace, democracy and the rule of law. Its purpose is to establish an internal market with a highly competitive social market economy and a high level of environmental protection. This all contributes to the well-being of all Europeans. If we want to meet these objectives, the EU and its Member States must not only make laws, but also implement and apply them. In 2014, environment, health, consumer protection, mobility and transport were again the policy areas with the highest number of new infringement cases. These are policy areas directly linked to the well-being of citizens and to the functioning of the internal market.  When it comes to monitoring the application of Union law, different institutions have different tasks. First and foremost, the responsibility for the correct application of EU law belongs to the Member States. The Commission is responsible for the monitoring and, if needed, the enforcement. Finally, this Parliament has a crucial role in exercising the political oversight of the Commission’s enforcement actions.  What are the key findings, then, of our political oversight this year? Firstly, the enforcement of EU law is not sufficiently transparent. The structured dialogue with Member States via the so-called ‘EU pilot system’ seems to have promoted the more efficient enforcement of EU law but, if Parliament and if other interested parties are kept in the dark, it will certainly generate problems in the future. We must ensure the utmost transparency.  Secondly, the EU legal system and its fundamental values, such as the rule of law and respect for human rights, can be a vital tool in tackling many of the problems the accession countries and the countries with association agreements are facing. Therefore, in order to provide suitable assistance to carry out necessary legal and judicial reforms, we need more systematic tools to assess the current state of compliance with the relevant EU acquis in these countries.  Thirdly, we could benefit from a more systematic approach here in the EU, too. This year, the Committee on Legal Affairs received opinions from three other committees – and I want to thank all these committees: Economic and Monetary Affairs, Employment and Social Affairs, and Petitions, for their contributions – but perhaps we could further improve our internal procedures so that in future the relevant committees could make even more precise act- and country-specific observations from their field of competence. All in all, the credibility of the EU institutions does not lie only in the quality of our legislation, but also in its correct implementation and application. Therefore, I ask the Commission and the Council to pay close attention both to this report and to the speeches and comments of my colleagues.

name: Heidi HAUTALA
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, honourable Members, the European Union is founded on law and relies on law to ensure that its policies and priorities are realised in the Member States. The effective application, implementation and enforcement of the law is hence a high political priority for this Commission. Often, it is not the lack of EU legislation that is the source of problems; it is rather the lack of its effective application and redress for citizens. That is why the European Commission takes its role as Guardian of the Treaties so seriously. If Member States are breaching EU law, then we need to take steps to address this weakness and, where necessary, we may need to launch formal infringement proceedings before the European Court of Justice. This unique and essential role of the Commission, overseeing the effective and efficient application of Union law in the Member States, is an integral part of the Better Regulation agenda. Through the annual reports on monitoring the application of EU law, the Commission reports on its work and explains how it exercises its powers as Guardian of the Treaties. I want to thank Members for the preparatory work on the 2014 Annual Report. The Commission very much appreciates Parliament’s increased interest in implementation issues. The Annual Report reviews the Member States’ performance on key aspects of the application of Union law from the point of detection of a possible infringement to the pursuit of the case before the Court. We detect problems in the application of law ourselves, but we also rely on petitions and complaints from citizens and business. Hence your Petitions Committee plays an important role. Once we have identified a problem we can work with Member States to solve it through a system called the EU Pilot. If the problem cannot be solved we indicate infringement procedures. The Treaty allows us to request financial fines if Member States are late in transposition and we have not hesitated to do so.  Let me summarise the main findings of the 2014 Report. Citizens and businesses remain active in detecting and bringing forward violations of EU law. More than 3 500 complaints were received from citizens and businesses during the year 2014. We are determined to work with the Member States in improving compliance at an early stage and resolving potential infringements quickly, to the benefit of citizens and businesses. About 75% of alleged infringements were resolved at an early stage. As a result, the overall number of formal infringement procedures has continued to decrease. However, there is still a significant gap between what is in the EU rulebook and the rules applied on the ground.  How can we improve the implementation of EU law more generally? I strongly believe that we should strengthen our partnership with the Member States and support them in their task of timely transposition and correct application of the law. As part of our better regulation efforts, we deploy a wide array of tools, ranging from preventive measures and early problem solving to proactive monitoring and targeted enforcement.  You have raised a number of other issues in the Hautala report, to which I would like to respond. I note your increased interest as regards Parliament’s role in monitoring the implementation of EU law. Without prejudice to democratic control by Parliament, the Commission oversees the application of EU law under the control of the Court of Justice of the European Union. The infringement procedure has a specific bilateral nature. It is conducted solely between the Commission and the concerned Member State. This being said, the Commission will continue to provide Parliament with information on infringement proceedings in accordance with its commitments in the current Framework Agreement. This includes more detailed information, if requested, on specific infringement cases. As regards Parliament’s proactive contribution in monitoring the compliance with EU law of accession countries and countries with association agreements, I want to emphasise that the Commission will continue its regular reporting on the progress made by these countries.  I note your call for a legislative proposal on administrative procedures under Article 298 of the Treaty. I would like to stress that the Commission has already created a strong framework to protect complainants. Its Code of Good Administrative Behaviour and the Communication on relations with the complainant offer a number of guarantees that safeguard complainants’ rights throughout the entire procedure. These include the right to be informed about any decision on his or her complaint, the right to be heard, prior notice before closing a case, and a timeframe for a final decision on complaints. Against this background, the Commission does not find it necessary to regulate this matter in a legislative act based on Article 298 of the Treaty.  Concerning the transparency of infringement procedures, and especially that of EU Pilot, the Commission is fully dedicated to delivering on the commitments stipulated in the Framework Agreement. I wish to underline that from the initial phase of infringement procedures, the Commission must also respect confidentiality vis-à-vis the Member States, as recognised by the Court of Justice. This means that transparency and access to a specific file has to be limited while the Commission conducts its initial investigation in order to clarify the often complex legal and factual background of the cases. I also note your increased interest in better regulation. Our aim is to legislate in an open, transparent way, using the best evidence available and valuable stakeholder inputs. We also focus on ways to support implementation and are pleased to see that Parliament supports all these efforts.

name: Ramon TREMOSA i BALCELLS
text: rapporteur for the opinion of the Committee on Economic and Monetary Affairs. – Madam President, every year the Commission launches 1 000 new infringement procedures against EU Member States due to the bad transposition of EU law. Since 2009 there have been 1 000 procedures per year. This is the real sickness of the EU project. This is what is killing the EU and creating political disaffection everywhere: the inability of the EU to maintain the rule of law within its Member States. Poland and Hungary do not want to accept refugees, Italy does not want to apply European rules to solve the banking crisis, France is allowed not to comply with the public deficit rules because it is France – as President Juncker, incredibly, stated publicly – and Spain does not comply with the Late Payment Directive. Spain is unwilling to force the big Spanish multinationals to pay SMEs’ bills at 30 days and allows them to pay at 250 days without sanction. In Spain one million workers of sovereign SMEs lost their jobs during the crisis due to these bad practices on the part of big multinationals allowed by the central government. So, in my opinion, bad transposition of EU law, is the silent crisis of the European project. Countries in the south of Europe, which are the worst offenders regarding EU law, are the countries which most need to implement it to modernise their economy. So, finally, if Europe is not able to oblige Member States to comply with EU law, citizens will abandon all hope in the European project.

name: Agnieszka KOZŁOWSKA
text: author of the draft opinion of the Committee on Employment and Social Affairs. – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by The opinion of the Committee on Employment and Social Affairs on this report has been drafted in full agreement, with a high convergence of positions, and draws attention to the fact that delays and irregularities in transposition constitute a barrier to the internal market and are contrary to the interests of citizens: both employers and workers. Therefore, work should be made to reduce these delays. This reduction and improvement can be achieved by analysing the causes of delays, as well as by working with countries and social partners, exchanging information and good practices. In this context, the Committee welcomes the effectiveness of EU Pilot action, as well as the introduction of websites informing it, with the entire database of infringements, and informing on the application of Union law.  The Commission draws attention to the need to constantly review existing legislation with regard to the principle of subsidiarity, as over-regulation can harm employers and the labour market. And in the context of these previous paragraphs, the EMPL Committee draws attention to the fact that the appointment of the First Vice-President of the European Commission responsible for the application of the law, the rule of law and fundamental rights is very much in line with the objectives set out here.

name: Cecilia WIKSTRÖM
text: rapporteur on the opinion of the Committee on Petitions. Madam President, I would like to begin by thanking Theresa May for As chairman of the Committee on Petitions, I am constantly reminded that the legislation we are working on here is not always properly implemented in the Member States. I am reminded of how important it is that it is also properly implemented, implemented, out there and notwithstanding what policy area we are talking about, because it is actually about our credibility as institutions; it is a question of citizens' right, regardless of where they live, in which Member State, actually benefit from the legislation that we are implementing. Unfortunately, the Member States leave a great deal to be desired, and that applies to all policy areas. We receive petitions relating to migration policy, consumer affairs, environmental issues and all sorts of more. We see, through the stream of petitions that we receive, that there is actually a gap between the intention of the legislation and the implementation out there. As chairman of this committee, I will continue to highlight these shortcomings and point out that proper implementation is required, and that citizens throughout europe have the right to consult the legislation we are working on in an equal way, everywhere.

name: Tadeusz ZWIEFKA
text: On behalf of the PPE Group. – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab Honourable Commissioner, I would like to thank you for your excellent work. It would seem that, after so many years of Community existence, the process of monitoring the implementation of Community law in the legal systems of the Member States is a routine issue, that this is just something that we must do for the sake of order. The reality, however, is that it is completely different. There are several reasons, but the most important one is that the Member States are still so mistrustful of what we, together with the European Council, are creating at Community level. This mistrust of whether this approach linked to such a system of additional control results in completely unnecessary national rules being imposed on those created at European Union level. Informing citizens, on the other hand, is that it is these bad officials and this Parliament with the Council somewhere in Brussels that are creating the law that we have to deal with now, and you are, unfortunately, the people who are most affected by this.  I am strongly protesting on this issue. We are trying, together with the Council, to make it transparent and, above all, necessary and effective for our citizens and for businesses, because it is intended to make their lives easier. That is why we are implementing national parliaments in the legislative process at an early stage of the legislative process, in order to avoid confusion or a desire for such or other approaches to established Community law. I am therefore very pleased that the European Commission is serious about monitoring the law and pointing out those shortcomings that are being flagled by both citizens and businesses.  I would also like to thank our rapporteur, Heidi Hautala, very warmly, who has once again prepared an excellent report, pointing out the main directions with which we have the greatest problems today.

name: Sylvia-Yvonne KAUFMANN
text: Mr President, I would like to make a mifful son, mr President, I would like to make a ido to the S&D Group. Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her Two figures are particularly interesting: in 2014, the Commission received 3715 complaints about potential breaches of EU law. And the second figure: in the same year, the Commission opened 893 new infringement proceedings against the Member States. The late and incorrect transposition of European laws undoubtedly has a negative impact on general legal certainty and, of course, on the conditions of competition in the internal market. If we then find that most complaints have been received in the field of employment about the violation of EU law, then we do not need to be surprised why citizens perceive that their social and workers' rights are not improving. Unfortunately, we see time and again that, in the event of problems, the finger is being pointed at those in Brussels. Yes, it is quite simple and incredibly popular to make Brussels a scapegoat. But it must not go on like this. It is high time that when we talk about the European Union and its problems, we were specifically called Ross and Reiter, that it was clearly stated who is responsible for what and who bears political responsibility. The Commission is responsible for legislative proposals and it is the guardian of the Treaties. And it is the responsibility of the Member States to implement and properly apply once European laws have been adopted on time. They must not shirk this responsibility, they must take their duties seriously. Only through the efficient and effective application of EU law can citizens, workers and businesses benefit from the benefits of European legislation.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. Madam President, the application of European Union law often faces legitimate objections from both Member States and citizens, especially because the states of the European South are usually confronted with the exploitative policy pursued against them by the states of the rich North. On the other hand, the citizens of the Union are experiencing unemployment and poverty as a result of mercelious austerity and are resisting the imposition of callous Brussels legislation.  As the European Union itself transforms itself from a Union of States and Peoples into a German Europe, into a Union of Lenders, where states are divided into lenders and debtors, the ECB and the Commission, which is supposed to be the guardian of Union law, are transformed, through the troika, into institutions of the lenders themselves who, through their action, as members of the troika , infringe Union law and fundamental rights. As an MEP, but also as a professor of European Union institutions at the University of Crete, I consider it important that recently the Court of Justice of the European Union, on the occasion of the Cyprus Memorandum, stressed that the Union institutions, when acting as members of the troika, are bound by the Treaties and the Charter of Fundamental Rights. We expect this judgment of the Court of Justice and the spirit of the Court's decision to be fully implemented. The Commission, as a member of the troika, must not violate fundamental rights in Greece and other countries.

name: António MARINHO E PINTO
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Madam President, Commissioner, this report deals with the implementation of EU law by the Member States. A number of things that need to be addressed here are involved. We cannot talk about EU law, but rather European Union law.  In a rule of law it is the courts that carry out the law and the law is only one of the sources of law. It is imperative, in this area, to intensify cooperation, on the one hand, between the different bodies of the Union - namely the Commission, Parliament and the Council - and, on the other hand, between these bodies and each of the Member States.  Realising the law through the application of laws means fairly resolving social life disputes, especially those affecting the lives of people, businesses and other associations between them and between them and the EU and the Member States.  The rule of law is precisely the State which is limited in its concrete actions by the rules and principles of law. It is therefore urgent to create reserves of jurisdiction for the European Union, especially in matters relating to the single market and human rights, as well as the establishment of Union courts in each Member State. European integration will be nothing more than a mirage until concrete steps are taken in standardising the different laws and jurisdictions in Europe. There is therefore an urgent need for greater integration in the area of justice, even as a factor in overcoming many of the current blockades and even deepening European cohesion itself. Without democratic reforms in the justice systems of the Union and the Member States there will be no real European integration. (The speaker agrees to answer a question under the blue card procedure in accordance with Article 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure)

name: Tibor SZANYI
text: Blue card question. - Mr President, I would like to thank you for your support. You have repeatedly said in your speech that judicial solutions should be given some kind of priority. Let me ask you, however, how satisfied you are with the current court practice, when you can have a dispute for four to five years?

name: António MARINHO E PINTO
text: Response according to the "blue card" procedure. I'm not happy. I am very unhappy with the delays in the Courts of the Union. But these delays are infinitely shorter than the delays in the justice of the different Member States.  Delays in justice are overcome with new magistrates, with truly prepared magistrates and not with appointments of political commissioners rather than judges. To expedite justice is to hand over its administration to judges, to judges and not to lawyers and not to politicians who will momentarily play the role of magistrates.  The problem of backwardness in justice in the Union, in the courts of the Union and in the courts of the Member States is one of the problems that threatens democracy itself and the essence of the rule of law itself. It must therefore be a priority of the Union, in particular the Commission, which has powers in this area which Parliament does not have.

name: Kostas CHRYSOGONOS
text: on behalf of the GUE/NGL Group. Madam President, the report on the application of European law in 2014 contains good findings, such as that the Institutions of the Union must respect primary law and in particular the Charter of Fundamental Rights when adopting secondary Union law or that the Member States must also respect fundamental rights. However, the same report aptly points out that the environment and health, as well as consumer protection, have once again stood in those policy areas where the most infringements occurred, and that the application of Union law is not sufficiently transparent but is not subject to effective scrutiny by the applicants and stakeholders. It turns out, therefore, that there is a lack of respect, both for the Member States and for the Union itself, for its founding principles, such as respect for fundamental rights and the rule of law. This is a dead end and must be changed, because otherwise the Union will be in danger of disintegration in the foreseeable future.

name: Laura FERRARA
text: Mr President, president, ladies and gentlemen, i.e. the european Union, the European Union and its Member States are Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, the report on monitoring the application of European Union law, which we feel we can support as a whole, shows that the reduction in infringement procedures would not be so much linked to the Monitoring and Prevention work carried out by the Commission, but above all to the fact that in recent years there has been a drastic reduction in regulatory proposals by the Commission.  All this gives us the opportunity to reflect, which should, of course, affect all the institutions of the European Union, on the reasons for this behaviour. Perhaps the Commission has regulated most aspects of the lives of European citizens. On the contrary, it is preferred not to intervene on issues that are likely to lead to the emergence and, in some cases, to further aggravate the differences between the Member States. I believe that there are still many questions on which the citizens of Europe are waiting for answers. I am thinking in particular of legislation to combat corruption and organised crime, but also of whistleblower protection or transparency legislation.  Finally, I have some misgivings about the fact that financial penalties could be a real deterrent to the fight against infringements, as they would ultimately fall on the taxpayers' shoulders. It could probably be wiser and more effective to introduce dissuasive mechanisms such as the suspension of the voting rights of states that commit infringements.

name: Marie-Christine BOUTONNET
text: on behalf of the ENF group. Madam President, this report on the monitoring of the application of EU law follows the canon of precedents: always the same rengaines. It calls on the Commission to make compliance with EU law a real political priority. This Parliament and the Commission are always quick to establish themselves as whipping fathers to the Member States who would behave as bad pupils in the face of the Brussels doxa. I call on the Commission to lead by example and to make the compliance of its actions with the treaties a real priority, starting with the application and respect of the principle of subsidiarity provided for by Article 5 of the Treaty on European Union. The Commission ignores this and does not respect the obligation to motivate draft legislation under Protocol 2. However, the Member States, in their Edinburgh Declaration in 1992, affirmed that the European Union is based on subsidiarity, and have even enshrined it as a fundamental principle.  On the other hand, this report dares to assert that unjustified Euroscepticism is due to unnecessary measures "taken by Member States during the application of EU legislation". So you wouldn't be responsible for anything? Irresponsible mass unemployment and job destruction across Europe. Irresponsible of the migration submersion, which you have organised, and whose distribution you impose on peoples who can no longer and do not want it, as the Hungarian referendum showed us.  Your policies are irresponsible. You do not need anyone to provoke the discontent and anger of the peoples, but to give moral lessons, you are always the first, like the Luxembourg Foreign Minister, who called for the exclusion of Hungary because it would not respect the values of the Union. I said, "What about the LuxLeaks?" There is a principle here, which is the principle of fair cooperation, which also means that one should not rip off one's little comrades.  You dare everything and that's what you're recognized for.

name: Diane DODDS
text: – Madam President, the prime minister, Theresa May, has confirmed in no uncertain terms that Brexit is happening. The British people will get what they voted for: control of their money, control of their borders and the right to make their own laws. Article 50 is to be invoked by the spring and, after 45 years of surrendering control to Brussels, British law will again rest supreme across the United Kingdom. So in this debate on the application and monitoring of EU law, I am glad to say that the great repeal bill will give our national parliament its say. The sole right to make laws on behalf of the British people will rest with the British parliament and its devolved assemblies.  So in this negotiation that is coming up I would urge all those people, on all sides, to be forward-thinking and outward-looking in defining a new and positive trading relationship with our neighbours in Europe, and outward-looking in embracing new opportunities with the rest of the world. Let us step up, not step back, and create a positive atmosphere for a new relationship within Europe.

name: Pavel SVOBODA
text: – Madam President, when we talk today about the regular report on the application of European Union law, we can recall the words of the first President of the European Commission, Walter Hallstein, who said: 'The Community is a creation of law, it is the decisive novelty that sets them apart from previous attempts to unite Europe, not violence, not subjugation being used as a tool, but a spiritual cultural force, a right'. These words may remind us that we cannot see the law as just a technical matter.  In this context, I would like to support the Commission in its role as guardian of the Treaties, because I believe that this specific role of the Commission is essential at the moment, and it is only good if the Commission speaks out in defence not only of the letter but also of the spirit of European legislation. If we agree together on certain rules, we must also demonstrate the will to respect them together and find the will to enforce them. As a result, even this moment can contribute to a positive perception of the European Union in its citizens. Here I would also like to draw attention to the related issues, and that is the quality of the rules adopted. In this respect, I hope that, together with the Commission and the Council, we will continue to improve and find common ground, even with regard to European Union administrative law.

name: Sergio Gaetano COFFERATI
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, Commissioner, the report highlights the existence of two serious problems which, in my opinion, should be resolved quickly. The first relates to indicators. The report is based on purely quantitative indicators, while we also need qualitative evaluation elements to understand the reasons and characteristics of the non-application of European standards in some Member States. We need to make a political judgment that can only be made if we have all the elements of assessment that are unfortunately lacking today. European integration cannot be measured only by aseptical parameters as quantitative ones. The second issue is transparency. Parliament, as you know, has difficult access to both knowledge of the pilot system and knowledge of pending cases. We are not in a position to assess whether the reduction in the number of formal procedures really reflects the increased implementation of European Union law, or whether it is not the compromise between the Commission and the Member States. So having elements of transparency here too would make your work, but above all our intervention, much more effective and precise.

name: Ulrike TREBESIUS
text: Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her We often talk here in Parliament about European ideals and great civilisational achievements such as the rule of law. In this sense, the implementation of EU law, which is being discussed here today, is very important, and I am pleased to see how so many details are being looked at closely. Unfortunately, the EU is much less precise on the big things. In 2014, the so-called euro bailout also massively broke laws. For example, €8.3 billion of European ESFS funds were transferred to Greece in 2014.  The ESFS is one of the instruments of the European Union. The allocation of these funds was linked by the Eurogroup at that time to the promise of Greece's debt sustainability. Today, we know that the IMF is officially denying this debt sustainability and is demanding a debt cut. We found before 2014 that Greek debt was unsustainable, and the Eurogroup must also have been aware of this. In my opinion, there is a clear breach of the law of the Maastricht Treaty, and it is always astonishing how little the rule of law counts here when there are only enough politicians who are interested in such breaches of the law.

name: Paloma LÓPEZ BERMEJO
text: – Madam President, the application of European legislation is not a technical debate, it is a political debate. We all know that European regulations are applied and controlled when it favours large capitals, but it is forgotten when it tries to protect European workers. It is sufficient to note how the Commission and the European Union strive to enforce every measure of austerity, cuts, loss of rights, and deliberately forget to act in the social field. I give two examples: social dumping. We have directives to require control of cabotage and mailbox companies in road transport, but the European Union does not control its implementation; on the other hand, when you try to apply a minimum wage to carriers, you are in charge of relying on European legislation and preventing the recognition of a right as fundamental as 'equal employment, equal pay'. Another example: labour regulations. You are cheerfully involved in the framework of work, for example in Spanish; two reforms have been imposed, but while you are making cuts and others implement them, you forget that European legislation is also based on the principle of non-discrimination, and it has to be the Court of Justice of the European Union that intervenes to recognise rights to temporary and interim workers. But for a law to be fair, what needs to be done is above all to apply it for the benefit of all parties, and not as it is being done.

name: Gilles LEBRETON
text: Madam President, the 2014 report on the monitoring of the application of EU law is written in diplomatic terms. However, it is harsh for the Brussels Commission. It points, for example, to the Favouritism or cowardice of the Commission towards Germany. It rarely opens infringement proceedings against Merkel's country, even though it is one of the three EU states that attracts the most complaints. For the rest, the Commission's record of action is frightening: unrealistic deadlines imposed on states to implement European directives and regulations; lack of transparency in all areas, not just in the TAFTA negotiations; indexing the draft code of administrative procedure, which would have provided greater protection for the citizens; and, alas, a violation of the treaties, when she is officially the guardian. One word sums up the Commission's attitude: 'disrespectful' - contempt for the law, contempt for the European Parliament, contempt for states and, finally, contempt for the citizens, who will remember it when voting.

name: Georgios EPITIDEIOS
text: NI). Madam President, it is a fact that the correct and timely transposition of EU law into the laws of the Member States must be one of the priorities of the Member States. This will contribute both to increasing the credibility of the institutions and to addressing some of the side effects that are occurring. However, in order for this objective to succeed, this effort must not be made either under pressure of time, nor should it be pursued to be applied uniformly in all States, because each State has its own specificities which must be taken into account. For example, a southern country is differently affected by a northern country by a directive on agricultural and livestock products.  No one can blame Greece, whose economy has been destroyed by the memorandums, for delaying business-to-business transactions. So if we want the smooth transposition of the law, we must approach the matter in a pragmatic way. Otherwise, brussels chair men who tend to regard states as vassals who must apply directly and undeniably the instructions of their superiors will have a problem.

name: Rosa ESTARÀS FERRAGUT
text: – Madam President, today we are analysing the thirty-second report on the application of European Union law in 2014. Indeed, ensuring the application of that European Union law is essential and must be one of the Commission's priorities. It will mean that the European Union operates under conditions.  There are three actors. On the one hand, the Commission: it is its responsibility to play an active role in improving the implementation, enforcement and monitoring of compliance with these rules; but also the role of Parliament, in particular with the Committee on Petitions, in being able to control that this functioning is real — citizens report cases of malfunction in the Committee on Petitions and is therefore very useful information for the Commission; and finally, the role of the Member States.  There is no doubt that conflicts and infringement procedures have diminished , as we have seen in this report, because the structured dialogue between the Member States and the Commission itself has paid off. In fact, the pilot project of that dialogue has made many procedures not reach the infringement dossier, and we think that is good news.  It is true that almost all infringements concern services, the environment, transport and everything that would be development, but it is no less true that, if we put all efforts on the part of all actors — the Member States too, making the transpositions of the directives in a timely and form, and we also put in time for transpositions that are really objective— , we will get citizens to truly trust in the European institutions, and that distance between what we do in the institutions and what citizens receive is shortened, and they believe much more in us.

name: Lidia Joanna GERINGER DE OEDENBERG
text: – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab In 2014, the European Commission received 3 715 complaints of alleged infringements of EU law and launched 893 new infringement procedures. Between 2010 and 2014, 3 550 cases were opened due to the late transposition of 439 directives by Member States. The environment, transport, the internal market and services were the most ing the subject-matter of infringement proceedings. The annual report also highlights the fact that the number of formal proceedings has decreased over the last five years. According to the Commission, this is a result reflecting the effectiveness of structured dialogue with Member States through the EU Pilot procedure. Nevertheless, the European Parliament still has relatively limited access to this procedure and pending proceedings. The enforcement of Union law itself remains insufficiently transparent. The European Parliament should also play a greater role in analysing compliance by countries applying to the Community and those with which the European Union has already signed association agreements. Finally, I would like to thank the rapporteur for a very good document.

name: Ruža TOMAŠIĆ
text: – Madam President, as an MP from Croatia, I can testify firsthand in favor of the thesis that at the state level there is an additional burden on European legislation with a whole range of procedures that waste time and money for citizens and companies. But I cannot agree with the rapporteur that this is the main cause of the rise of Euroscepticism. We should not close our eyes to the fact that the Union in many spheres is not functioning and shift the blame to the Member States. They carry some responsibility, but let's not forget that citizens' expectations of a supranational level are different and if the Union does not justify them, they will lose more and more popularity. The Union must be of added value, otherwise we do not need it. For European legislation to be widely accepted and well prepared, we need to return to true subsidiarity. The Union must regulate only where necessary in order to achieve the best results. Further interference in the affairs of the state and lower levels of governance will bring us only more disorder and dissatisfaction among citizens. (The Speaker agreed to answer the question by raising the blue card on the basis of Article 162(8) of the Code of Health. Rules of procedure.)

name: Evelyn REGNER
text: Question about the procedure of the "blue card". Madam President, the Member States do not live on Mars or anywhere else, but are also involved in legislation as co-legislators. Your speech now more or less makes the Member States look as if they are surprised or as if it has nothing to do with their own obligations. How do you see that?

name: Ruža TOMAŠIĆ
text: answer to the question posed by raising the blue card. - Mrs Regner, when we became members of the EU, we expected the EU to be an umbrella state, a country to help us, not a country that would tell us exactly what to do, when to do it and where it should be. Just talk, not be there to help us on our way.  So it's one thing to order, it's another to participate with us and guide us. There are a lot of Member States, especially post-communist countries that have been told all along what and how they are going to work, and now all of a sudden they are just being ordered without instructions on how to do it.

name: Merja KYLLÖNEN
text: – Mr President, one of the big problems facing this European Community in Europe is the implementation of what we have agreed together. This has been reflected, among other things, in the resolution of the refugee crisis. Together, we agreed on minimal quotas, and then in our own countries we will not be able to keep to that minimum. This is constantly eating away at the credibility of our common system. However, even if our decisions are not always to the public's ability to take decisions and also to implement them.   It is, of course, up to the Commission to monitor the implementation of the legislation and, if necessary, the Commission will also intervene in the member states. But what are the Commission's priorities? In 2014, the number of new infringement procedures was highest in the environmental, health, consumer protection, mobility and transport sectors.   The implementation of economic discipline policy by the Member States is, of the way, required and its implementation is watched by the Commission as a hawk. We would also like to see a similar passion in commonly agreed environmental, health, consumer and transport matters.

name: Emil RADEV
text: – I thank Mrs Hautala for the comprehensive report. The application of European Union law by the Member States is a prerequisite for the proper functioning of the Union legal order. In this way, we will strengthen trust and confidence in the Union's objectives to our citizens.  And in 2014, the environment and transport continued to be one of the areas where the most new infringement proceedings were initiated. As one of the reasons for non-compliance, we can point to unrealistic deadlines for the implementation of the legislation. They have an impact on the timely implementation of European legislation. In this regard, I believe that the European institutions need to agree on more appropriate deadlines for the implementation of regulations and directives, taking due account of the necessary monitoring and consultation periods.  Clearer and more understandable legislation will also help to better and efficiently implement the provisions. In this regard, the Interinstitutional Agreement on Better Law-Making is a step in the right direction.  We see that the EU Pilot system is also established as useful and has a positive impact in promoting a more efficient implementation of European Union law. However, the European Commission must improve transparency and provide sufficient information to the European Parliament on pending files.  Finally, I would like to draw attention to the fact that, once again, we call on the European Commission to present a legislative proposal on Administrative Procedural Law of the European Union, taking into account the measures taken so far in this area by the European Parliament and the document we have produced in the Working Party on Administrative Law.

name: Victor NEGRESCU
text: – Madam President, two thirds of national legislation is influenced by decisions taken at European level. This is essential for the construction of a united and coherent European Union. However, European legislation is very often blamed for its density and for generating too much bureaucracy. Interestingly, however, citizens are calling for the Union's intervention in areas where there are no competences, and the Member States are seeking the support of united Europe in difficult situations. We see this in the large number of requests and petitions that come to us, either from citizens, but also from states or local authorities. It is clear that we need to increase transparency on European decision-making. We need to involve citizens more directly, communicate with civil society and ensure that European legislation is known and especially understood before it is implemented. The legal action of the European Union must once again be perceived as the result of a broad consultation and an expression of the general interest, and that is why together with colleagues in the European Parliament we come up with a number of recommendations such as: increasing online interaction, developing advisory councils or establishing a more transparent institutional dialogue with Member States and groups covered by European measures.

name: Monika BEŇOVÁ
text: – The Commission's annual report on monitoring the application of European Union law finds that most cases where Member States have failed to fulfil their obligations fall within the fields of the environment, transport, the internal market and services. I welcome the fact that the number of formal non-compliance procedures has decreased in the last five years, which may point to the progress made in the work of the in pilot project. However, the European Parliament still has significantly limited access to the information processed under the project in question, and it is therefore difficult to determine to what extent the reduction in the number of formal infringement procedures actually reflects better compliance with Union law by the Member States and not compromise solutions between the Commission and the Member States. Despite a number of positive results, we must therefore continue to take further measures in order to achieve an even higher level of transparency. We must show citizens that we are better able to control and analyse how individual Member States handle money.

name: Evelyn REGNER
text: Madam President, Commissioner, I would like to thank the Commissioner for her excellent work and for the work she has done. Before I come to the subject, I would like to congratulate you on your moving speech yesterday in the debate on women's rights in Poland. It was really moving.  Now to monitoring: the European Union was founded on the rule of law and the predictability of legislation. Every citizen has the right to be informed at an early stage whether and what legislation is being adopted at European level and which national body is responsible for its enforcement.  Member States will not be surprised at their obligation to implement. They are involved from the outset as co-legislators, and accordingly they must know exactly that it will, of course, be possible to implement the rules as quickly as possible. This makes it all the more problematic when there are repeated delays, particularly in labour law and social law. This is because the citizens suffer more or less very much here. Hence their great task in monitoring. Finally, i.e. please: make sure that these are often minimum standards! Not everything is over-regulation, it is often minimum standards that can be exceeded.

name: Stanislav POLČÁK
text: – Madam President, In my minute's contribution, I would like to focus only on the issue of those transposition periods, because, in my opinion, if the state's commitment to comply with the adoption of a standard of European law in its national law is not fulfilled in the long term, there are often violations of citizens' rights in the EU. And we should face this more effectively.  I do not know whether to design a new legal instrument that would better respond to such a situation in the field of European law, but I think unequivocally that it is the long-term violations of the transposition period by the Member States that are completely unacceptable.  I can also illustrate this on the problem of the Czech Republic, where a European Union directive is currently being incorporated into copyright law with a delay, and this delay results in citizens not being able to purchase, for example, copyright from some other collecting societies registered in EU Member States. The directive was supposed to bring more competition to this matter, and this has not yet happened in the Czech Republic. I think we should focus on that.

name: Maria GRAPINI
text: – Madam President, Commissioner, I would first like to congratulate the rapporteur and say that I agree with what was said in the report. Different forms of implementation in the Member States ultimately create discrimination between citizens. As you said, Commissioner, it is not the lack of European legislation that is the main problem. A lot of times, I get the impression that there is overregulation. The problem is to monitor the implementation of Union law and the measures taken in the event of infringement severing in European rights. I want to convey the perception of the citizens of my country, it is my duty to do so, as a person chosen to represent them. The perception of many citizens is that, on the one hand, solving their problems is cumbersome and often the same petition is resolved differently, on the other hand citizens want greater transparency, simplified procedures and clear measures on those who violate European citizens' law. Examples have also been given here, and I would like to add another one, which I have also encountered in my country, namely: the right to appeal is not respected, that time limit for resolving the appeal. Member States shall take decisions before that period expires. That is why, Commissioner, the emphasis must be, in my view, on monitoring and taking immediate action in the event of a breach of European law.

name: Maria GRAPINI
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, honourable Members, I think that this is an extremely important debate which we have here because this is about something essential. Our goal is to ensure the timely – and I want to emphasise also what Mr Polčák has just said –application of EU law in the Member States. Not only that, this is also about the way we work, the methods we use, and about the cooperation of the Commission with the European Parliament and the Member States.  Although I would say the rules are very rigid, the message must be flexible, because we need to take the relevant approach to the cases which we work with. I can share with you one example: I am responsible for the integration of people in societies, for the very sensitive issue of the integration of Roma children into normal basic education, and we have three countries where we already have EU Pilot. For me, this is absolutely essential that I see the results in concrete time. The procedure itself, for me, is important and it exists, but I prefer to start EU Pilot and continuous dialogue and push the Member States. And I would emphasise the dialogue more than the push, because it is also in the interests of the Member States to change the situation. For me, reaching the next stage of the procedure is not as important as achieving the necessary results, which means that more people from Roma communities will have good quality education.  This debate is also very much connected to the Better Regulation system, which the Commission now has, meaning less new legislation, but more stress on the real application of EU law, and also more understanding of how the application of EU law works in practice. This has not been debated here at all, this effect, which gives us a chance to see better how it works in practice, and what should be corrected – because not everything which was adopted in the past is still valid and relevant for current problems. You know that we have review clauses in the EU legislation, so we must use this interaction to take the proper measures to adopt and to modify the legislation so that it better meets the needs of the 21st Century. In the digital agenda this is typical. We need to be able to have this interaction, and to understand what works, what poses big burdens on businesses and people. We must not only say that we want to cut red tape; we must do it. We must deregulate things which people across the EU are saying is making their lives more difficult and, of course, continue to check how it is with the gold-plating in the Member States. In many cases, the Member States say that Brussels gave us the legislation but in the end we see that it was the Member State which made it more difficult for the people. So this is about a method, it is about our contact with reality and the full understanding that we are here to improve the legislation and to improve the lives of people, to increase legal certainty and to contribute to increased trust.  Believe me, Mr Lebreton, who accused us of disregarding the interests of people (he is not here anymore but I would like to address him), when I became the Commissioner responsible for Justice I received hundreds of mails from people who complained about their situation and they shared with me their frustration that there is no justice for them in the EU and in their State. Maybe among the people sitting here watching us there is also such a frustration, perhaps they are not satisfied with the situation, that perhaps justice is here only for the rich or the young, and I can tell you that I read all the mails and I responded to all of them. The majority were individual cases where people were frustrated about the result of some poor decision, but many mails reflected the mistakes of the system and also the lack of application of EU law in their Member State. I found these mails alarming and we worked with them. For me this was a very important hint and impulse for the beginning of my work here, and I am sure all my colleagues experienced the same thing and we tried to work with all the complaints, be it from the European Parliament, from the Committee on Petitions, or be it directly from the citizens of the EU and of the Member States. This must be done on a continuous basis and I think this is our common goal. Thank you for this debate. I can assure you on behalf of the Commission that we have very high interest in continuing good cooperation with Parliament on better regulation and the better application of EU law.

name: Heidi HAUTALA
text: rapporteur. – Madam President, I think that this debate shows that we are dealing with a very multifaceted, rich area where there are lots of angles that we can focus on. I would like to address a couple of them that were raised in the discussion and also in in your words, Commissioner Jourová. First, I must say that I am – and I believe my colleagues are as well – disappointed that the Commission continues to dismiss the demand by Parliament to introduce a more open, efficient and independent EU administration on the grounds of Article 298 in the Treaties, because it seems that the Commission believes that this is an attack against it. It is not. It is also a reminder that the Commission is responsible for how the EU administration works in the bodies, offices and agencies of the Union, of which there are so many. How can you be so sure that the administration is open, efficient and independent in all those tens of different institutions? Secondly, I would like to say that it is very important that we continue to open up what better regulation means. I would like to touch on the aspect of prevention. Last Friday, I organised a seminar in my home city of Helsinki with experts from consumer law authorities, consumer associations, trade associations and others. I must say that, when the subject is the digital agenda, under new proposals by the Commission on contracts on the purchase of digital content and tangible goods, many of these stakeholders and authorities complained about the complexity and the way in which these new proposals add to complexity. This means that it will be very difficult to apply this type of legislation properly.  I think there is no easy way out, but we need to work together and I hope that that in the next year the Parliament, when giving the answer to the Commission’s next report, will have a more structured cooperation. We also missed opinions from the Committee on the Environment, Public Health and Food Safety and the Committee on Transport and Tourism, having seen that these are the areas where most of the infringements actually occur.

name: Vilija BLINKEVIČIŪTĖ
text: Writing. – The Commission's annual report on monitoring the application of European Union law again provides interesting information on the current implementation of EU law and its practical application. The report shows that the environment, transport and the internal market and services were the policy areas where the largest number of infringement procedures were initiated in 2014. The report also highlights the decrease in the number of formal infringement procedures over the last five years. It should be stressed that the correct implementation and application of EU law are primarily the responsibility of the Member States and that the Member States must also respect all fundamental values and rights enshrined in the Treaties and in the EU Charter of Fundamental Rights when implementing EU law. At the same time, Parliament recalls that the Commission has a responsibility to monitor and evaluate the implementation of EU law and therefore constantly encourages Member States to use correlation tables on a regular basis, but notes that this does not relieve the EU institutions of their obligation to respect EU primary law when drafting secondary EU legislation. Parliament also has a crucial role to play in the political control of the Commission's enforcement actions, in checking the annual reports on monitoring the implementation of EU law and adopting relevant parliamentary resolutions.

name: Dubravka ŠUICA
text: in writing. – I applaud the 2014 Report on Monitoring the Application of EU Law, which gives an overview of the actual implementation and practical application of EU law and which is useful because it shows the policy areas which had the most infringement cases. However, the enforcement of EU law is still not sufficiently transparent and thus, perhaps the Commission should consider the proposals made by the new Working Group on Administrative Law, as they could lead to greater efficiency within the EU's own administrative procedures. I support this Report because it is important that we closely monitor the application of EU laws. As Vice-Chair of the Delegation for relations with Bosnia and Herzegovina, and Kosovo, I firmly believe that the Parliament should play a more important role in the analysis of how accession countries and countries with association agreements comply with EU laws and that the Parliament can play a larger role in developing appropriate support for implementation of EU laws in these countries. Therefore, I support the suggestion that Parliament draft proper reports on all candidate countries in response to the annual progress reports released by the Commission, with the aim to give relevant committees the chance to deliver opinions.

name: Anneli JÄÄTTEENMÄKI
text: The next item is the debate on six motions for resolutions on Rwanda and victoire Ingabire.

name: Ignazio CORRAO
text: author. – Madam President, Victoire Ingabire, the leader of the opposition Unified Democratic Forces party, was arrested in 2010 and is being held in prison for allegedly posing a terrorist threat to the country. However, the sentence was based on unreliable evidence, while of course we would want her to be judged on the basis of a fair trial. Like Victoire Ingabire, other political activists and government opponents have gone missing or are currently in prison. Effectively, the Rwandan government, despite calling itself democratic, is severely limiting political pluralism and obstructing freedom of expression and association throughout the country. Therefore, it is fundamental to establish a true democratic process, even in the light of the economic agreement signed at the beginning of September. The protection and freedom of its citizens must be ensured by the Rwandese government. It is necessary to allow a European delegation to attend and give evidence when this process will be seriously started.

name: Mark DEMESMAEKER
text: Author. – Only by listening to the opposition can a governing majority learn to be critical themselves, not by locking up opposition leaders. It is a principle that every democratic society should celebrate.  It is therefore unacceptable that Victoire Ingabire was convicted by a Rwandan court in October 2012. The leader of the Rwandan opposition had committed two crimes: conspiracy against the authorities and minimizing the genocide. However, independent international reports show that the process was anything but fair and impartial.  It is therefore good that we should follow her case and put her in the spotlight, because we must condemn politically inspired trials anytime, anywhere. Rwanda can play an important stabilising role in the Great Lakes region. The country has made remarkable economic and social progress. If it is now also in the direction of a genuine rule of law, a genuine inclusive democracy, then much is possible in the region. This requires pressure from the international community. The EU must therefore review its assistance to the Rwandan institutions and make it subject to real progress in the areas of human rights and free expression.

name: Rosa ESTARÀS FERRAGUT
text: Author. – Madam President, human dignity, freedom, democracy, equality, the rule of law, human rights, are the priority values of the Union. Those values are now violent in Rwanda. The regime is a regime where every word of the president is itself a law. Victoire Ingabire is a courageous and committed African policy, with solid technical and intellectual training, which wanted to install a rule of law in Rwanda and was arrested, arrested and imprisoned in a process without guarantees and a process, as collected by many observers and oenegés, full of irregularities. Fifteen years in prison for having been able to claim more freedom, more democracy and more equality in Rwanda. He is in prison for the will of a regime that does not tolerate action contrary to his view of things. I end with a few words from Victoire in his 1930 book: "My convictions have not been altered by my stay in prison; the peace and solidarity of the Rwandans is the only way to succeed. Whether Kigali's power decides to keep me in captivity or not, nothing will stop the wind of change." We have, ladies and gentlemen, an opportunity to give hope back to Victoire and an entire people.

name: Pier Antonio PANZERI
text: Author. Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, it was 2013 when this Parliament passed a resolution on the eight-year prison sentence handed down to Victoire Ingabire, who was guilty of trying to run for the leadership of Rwanda by challenging President Kagame, in a process that was purely political in nature. Three years later, we have to note the increase in the sentence, extended to fifteen years, and the deterioration of the health of the Rwandan leader, while the political climate in preparation for the 2017 elections is in danger of being damaged by pressure on journalists and the media, and changes in the Constitution are even being called for in the country to allow the president to run for a third term. With this resolution, we want to keep this alive and we call on the Rwandan Government to guarantee the right to a fair trial and to ensure sufficient space for the opposition forces, so that freedom of expression is guaranteed and there is a greater pluralist climate at the next elections.

name: Jordi Vicent SEBASTIA TALAVERA
text: Author. – Madam President, in 2013 this Parliament adopted a resolution denouncing the case of political prisoner Victoire Ingabire, imprisoned in Rwanda after a political trial without any international guarantee and in breach of all the basic norms of justice.  And in 2016 things are going to get worse. Her health worsens, she is prevented from being visited and legally assisted by her lawyers and a delegation from this Parliament, who was in Kigali a few weeks ago, is also prevented from being able to talk to her.  It is important that, from this Parliament, a very clear and very forceful message comes out. It is important that we tell Mr Kagame's government that we do not forget the case of Victoire Ingabire; that we ask for his release and a fair trial; and that we are not forgetting either and that we will denounce the imprisonment of journalists, the violation of freedom of expression and the persecution of their political opponents.  It is also important that we send a very clear message to the European Union: to monitor where those funds we send to Rwanda are going, not to take advantage of to give more glory to Mr Kagame and to prevent the real democracy that his people need.

name: Ángela VALLINA
text: Author. – Madam President, we recently visited Rwanda and had the opportunity to know a society deeply marked twenty-two years later by a terrible genocide against the Tutsis. It is true that colonial powers during the colonization of Rwanda fostered ethnic divisions between Hutus and Tutsis, which was the breeding ground that led to genocide, in the face of the passivity of the international community. From GUE/NGL we support this second Parliament Resolution for this courageous Rwandan woman, wrongly imprisoned since 2010, and we call for the European Union to act and condition its financing of around EUR 40 million per year to respect for human rights. Victoire Ingabire's conviction has very clear political motivations, and we regret that the Rwandan authorities have banned us from visiting it. From this Parliament today we urgently call on the Rwandan authorities to release immediately, not only Victoire, but all those who, like her, are detained, condemned or disappeared, solely because they wished to exercise their right to freedom of expression.

name: Tomáš ZDECHOVSKÝ
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. – Madam President, this resolution has the main task of reminding the Government of Rwanda that democracy is based on a pluralistic government, a functioning opposition, independent media and courts, and respect for human rights. Unfortunately, we have seen on the Victoire Ingabire case that Rwanda is lagging far behind in this regard, and that the authorities there, including President Kagame, must ensure that the fundamental principles of a democratic society are respected.  As the European Union has repeatedly pointed out, rwanda must, above all, focus on respect for human rights and the right to a fair trial. In this context, the whole process must be reopened and revised according to the standards of both Rwandan and international law. We cannot continue to tolerate the decisions of the courts in Rwanda being politically motivated or opposition politicians being prosecuted for their views and activities.

name: Maria ARENA
text: On behalf of the Group of President, the resolution before us today, in my view, is more about the importance of respecting the rule of law than about a particular case. According to several Amnesty International reports, journalists, human rights defenders and members of opposition political parties are working in extremely difficult conditions in Rwanda today. That is why I would have preferred a more comprehensive resolution, at the end of our mission of the Committee on Women's Rights and Gender Equality in Rwanda. Rwanda is a strategic player in the Great Lakes region and, although seen as a model for women's participation in political life, the challenges that Rwanda faces are still significant, particularly with regard to: freedom of expression, the rule of law, political diversity, social protection of the most vulnerable populations, traceability of minerals and its role in the International Conference on the Great Lakes Region. , with the corollary of funding for armed groups. So I think it would be important to have a comprehensive resolution on Rwanda rather than a specific resolution.

name: Ryszard CZARNECKI
text: On behalf of the ECR Group. – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab Commissioner, i would like to thank you very much for I have been to Rwanda, not just me in our Parliament, and I must say that one of the most poignant experiences of my political career was the presence, a tour of the genocide museum in the Rwandan capital, Kigali. A country with such a tragic history – we have talked here about the genocide that resulted from the war between the Hutu and Tutsi tribes – must, at least, in my and probably my opinion, respect human rights, including the rights of the opposition, in a special way. And I think it is good that there is this debate today, it is good that we are defending people who have been wrongly imprisoned, and that is, in a sense, our moral duty, but also to show Rwanda that our long-standing humanitarian aid to this country should result in the expectation of respect for certain standards.

name: Louis MICHEL
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, as in 2013, the ALDE Group has decided not to co-signed the emergency resolution on Mrs Victoire Ingabire, President of the FDU-Inkingi. I quite agree with Mrs Arena when she says that we should have worked on a resolution directly affecting the functioning of democracy in Rwanda, rather than isolating a case that is indisputably ambiguous.  That is why we are not going to follow this resolution. The resolution is too ambiguous, confusing, expresses unverifiable accusations, claiming that Ms. Victoire Ingabire was convicted without evidence and, therefore, for political reasons.  I took the trouble to meet with the D.A. who handled this matter. I, of course, asked all the questions that related to the statements I had heard and that had been expressed. Not a single one of these questions can be answered by the prosecutor. I would also like to point out that, 22 years after an abominable genocide, it is understandable that the authorities are afraid of allowing ethnic quarrels to spread again. However, everyone knows that Ms. Ingabire has contacts with the Interahamwe FDLR, which are the genocidals of 1994. That has to be said, too.  Together with Guy Verhofstadt, I witnessed the immense courage of the Rwandan people in a drama that appears in the most sordid gallery of abominations in history. Rwanda is recovering thanks to the will of the Rwandan authorities and, above all, the Rwandan people to pull their country up. I just want to point out that the Rwandan parliament has 51 women out of 80 in the Chamber of Deputies, or 63.8%, 10 out of 26 women in the senate, or 30.5%. It is ranked at this level in the world leading position. The Women in Parliaments Global Forum, chaired by Silvana Koch-Mehrin, our former colleague, will open an office in Kigali soon.  Rwanda has 11 out of 28 women in government, or 40%. The death penalty is abolished there. Sexual orientation is respected. This too must be said! I know, of course, that human rights must be better respected, that we must work on them, that we must push the authorities to do so, of course. But, in the particular case, to make this resolution a resolution concerning a personal case, I think that is a mistake.  (The speaker agrees to answer a "blue card" question (Article 162, paragraph 8, of the regulation))

name: Rosa ESTARÀS FERRAGUT
text: "blue card" question. – I was in Rwanda two weeks ago. There is a presence in Parliament because Mr Kagame chooses them by finger; they are not democratic systems. You talk about development, but there is no development when democracy is forgotten.  Mrs. Ingabire, it has never been shown that she had any belonging to a terrorist gang. The trial was riddled with irregularities, and has been acknowledged by Amnesty International and a multitude of oenegés. It's the only one: even you don't have the backing of your group. The person who came on behalf of your group to our delegation signed this Resolution and you had him withdraw his signature. He is the only, or probably of the few in this Parliament, who is not supporting peace, democracy and equality in the person of Victoire Ingabire.

name: Louis MICHEL
text: "blue card" answer. "It is a value judgment that I leave to you, ma'am. I know Ms. Ingabire has contact with the FDLR. What's the problem? Do you want me to tell you? Because, this Rwanda file, I know perhaps a little better than some. I've been following him from the beginning. What is the problem in Rwanda? The FDLR, which is the genocidal, wants to become an honourable political party in Rwanda, and the authorities are obviously reluctant to do so. Indeed, they fear that making this genocidal group a party will reignite the ethnic quarrel. And it is true that the authorities do not want it! You know, in some European countries, there was a time when parties, which had played a serious role during the war, were also banned. But I don't hear anyone talking about it and referring to it, it has to be said as well.

name: Nicola CAPUTO
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, Victoire Ingabire is an icon of the struggle for freedom and democracy in Rwanda. Returning to the country in January 2010, after sixteen years in exile, to participate in the presidential elections, she was arrested in October 2011 and is now in prison on charges of terrorism and threats to national security. For you, the European Parliament had called for a fair trial, in accordance with international legal standards. Unfortunately, recently a delegation from Parliament and the European Union, who came to Rwanda to find out about the situation in Ingabire in prison, was denied to see it. The country has changed a lot since the massacres of 1994. Nevertheless, the human rights watch organisation has documented numerous disappearances and numerous arrests for political reasons and illegal detentions, particularly of opponents of the government. The detention of Victoire Ingabire, it is now clear, responds only to the political logic of the current government. The European Union and the international community must demand the immediate release of Ingabire and all political prisoners.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: ECR). Madam President, the case of Victoire Ingabire shows how the Rwandan regime has been treating its political opponents for two decades: with gagging and imprisonment. Victoire Ingabire is serving a third year in prison for claiming the obvious: truth and justice. However, the regime does not seem willing to accept another different narrative about the events of 1994, apart from the official one on which it also supports its legitimacy. The refusal of the Rwandan authorities to hold the long-planned meeting of the European Parliament's mission with the activist Victoire Ingabire must not go unnoticed. It is yet another act in the regime's long-running effort to put a brake on investigations into the responsibilities of the current rulers for the 1994 massacres that led hundreds of thousands of people to death, on both sides, and to a complete disintegration of the country. In the case of Victoire Ingabire, we must condemn the many other persecutions suffered by lesser-known activists and dissidents who are currently in the dungeons of Kigali, many of whom are missing.

name: Cecilia MALMSTRÖM
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, honourable Members, I am grateful to you for raising the case of Victoire Ingabire. As you are aware, and many of you have said so, Ms Victoire Ingabire was sentenced in October 2012 to eight years in prison, having been arrested and detained on several charges, and her sentence was then extended to 15 years by the Supreme Court of Rwanda in December 2013, following appeals by both prosecution and defence. We in the Commission, and the High Representative, are of course very much aware of the fact that the European Parliament has already passed a resolution on the case of Victoire Ingabire and that members of the Committee on Women’s Rights (FEMM) requested a prison visit during your visit to Kigali and that request was rejected by the Rwandan authorities.  The European Union, both the EEAS and individual EU Member States, have followed closely the situation of Ms Ingabire since her arrival in Rwanda in 2010 to run for president, and this period has included her detention, her hearings and her imprisonment since then. The court cases where observed by members of the EU diplomatic community, as well as a lawyer commissioned by the Netherlands to analyse the trial.  As you know, Ms Ingabire has filed an appeal with the African Union Court of Human and People’s Rights where her case is pending, despite the recent decision of Rwanda to withdraw from a special declaration that allows for the deposition of individual cases against the Rwandan authorities. The EU will continue to follow closely the process and the outcome of this appeal, which we hope will be allowed to run its course, and here I do note the concern of the House and the resolution that the appeal should be prompt and fair. Conditions of detention are a matter of concern. We insist that Ms Ingabire receive fair treatment in a prison facility, and that she continues to be regularly visited by members of her political party, as well as representatives of the EU diplomatic community. This is not only an issue of comfort; it is important that she should feel safe in prison and that she has access to the medicines she needs and access to legal advice.  In the Ingabire case, the EU insists that due legal process be followed, that international obligations are respected and that all the rights of the defendant, including in appeals, are fully ensured. Overall, we maintain a continuous political dialogue with Rwanda on a number of issues, including justice.  Rwanda has a managed a remarkable transformation, not only in economic reforms, but also in the area of representation of women in parliament and also in the governance of the country. These are important achievements. Let there be no mistake, we have a lot to learn here, but this should not stop us from speaking frankly with our partners on the issues that are of concern. The link between justice and political space is especially sensitive and we do have concerns which we have expressed to our Rwandan partners on the judicial treatment of some opposition actors.  At the same time, we also note that several international bodies have concluded that trials in the country are generally consistent with internationally recognised fair trial standards, and I am glad that in the draft resolution here you have expressed your respect for the independence of Rwanda’s judicial system.  We will from the EU and the Member States continue to engage with the Rwandan authorities over the rule of law and further reform of the justice system in the country, as well as reform of the legal framework as to encourage widening of political space, development of a legitimate political opposition, and full exercise of political rights in the country, including freedom of speech and association. And we do so, of course, in the context of our desire to support the relevant principles in the African Charter of Democracy, elections and governments.

name: Maurice PONGA
text: In writing. The issue of respect for human rights and democratic principles in Rwanda is fundamental not only for Rwanda but also for the countries of the region. It should be noted that Rwanda has made considerable progress in recent years in terms of good governance, economic development and women's participation in politics.
