Nevertheless, the European Union must continue to support Rwanda in its efforts, including by ensuring the promotion and respect of the rule of law. The case of Ms. Victoire INGABIRE is complex and the legal proceedings are still ongoing. We must therefore ensure that procedures are respected and human rights are respected.

name: Bogdan Brunon WENTA
text: I would like to write to the Commission. – Until March 2016 Rwanda was one of the countries that recognised the right of citizens to lodge a complaint directly with the African Court of Human and Peoples' Rights. The Rwandan authorities withdrew from the ranks of countries respecting this principle after a complaint was lodged by Victoire Ingabire, an activist and opposition figure. The withdrawal of this power from individuals is a worrying sign for the international community. The intentions of the authorities of this country are clear and aim to limit human rights, civil liberties and media freedom. President Paul Kagame's attempts to change the constitutional order to take power for the third time are pushing the country towards authoritarianism. This is manifested in the removal of political prisoners such as Victoire Ingabire from a fair trial, as well as the refusal of the right of contact, as was the case in September when a European Parliament delegation wanted to visit the opposition. The disappearance of social activist Illuminée Iragena in March 2016 and journalist John Ndabarasa in August 2016 also require a firm response from international opinion. Decisive steps must be taken to stop the Rwandan authorities from taking further action that could lead to increased internal tensions and even another civil war.

name: Ignazio CORRAO
text: author. – Madam President, the current issue of Sudan is taking on increasingly alarming dimensions, especially with regard to the Darfur region, where government forces have launched about thirty chemical attacks against the civilian population since the beginning of this year. The last two of these took place on 9 September, with dramatic and devastating effects; they have spared no-one.  We must immediately take measures to stop any type of attack. The Sudanese Government must ensure strict respect for human rights and freedoms of its citizens. To make this possible, it is necessary to reinforce the United Nations arms embargo and extend it to include all Sudan – not just the region of Darfur. For this purpose, we urge the Sudanese Government, this Parliament and all stakeholders to act urgently to put an end to these atrocities, allowing the necessary provision of humanitarian assistance.

name: Cristian Dan PREDA
text: Author. – Mr President, on the day that our Parliament decided to discuss the situation in Sudan, Amnesty International published a report on that country. We can learn, by reading the text, that Sudanese government forces have repeatedly used chemical weapons against civilians; I saw that colleague Corrao also referred to this fact.  These are horrible acts, which we condemn very strongly. They are in addition to other serious violations of human rights and international humanitarian law. I recall here the excessive use of force against civilians, out-of-court abductions and executions, acts of sexual violence, the closure of non-governmental organisations, the intimidation of religious minorities. That is why our text is very harsh and proposes more sanctions.  Omar al-Bashir, also indicted for genocide and crimes against humanity by the International Criminal Court, needs to know very clearly how we see how they treat their citizens.

name: Pier Antonio PANZERI
text: Author. Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, even today Sudan presents a dramatic scenario, dominated by conflicts, episodes of violence and a lack of protection of human rights. The case involving some traffic-involved members of the TRACKS Centre, one of the few still independent organisations operating in the field of Sudanese civil society, is an example of this. These activists, accused of inciting a war against the state, a crime involving the death penalty, went on trial last September. The judicial process and the condemnations suffered by human rights activists are a worrying sign against all those working in Sudanese civil society in the defence of human rights and civil liberties. With this resolution, once again, we want to draw attention to the worrying situation of conflict in Sudan and call on the government authorities to ensure that activists and collaborators working in civil society can play their full role as defenders of human rights, without being prosecuted, without being condemned in contravenously under international law.

name: Judith SARGENTINI
text: Author. – President al-Bashir is wanted by the International Criminal Court in The Hague for crimes against humanity. But the man travels freely through Africa and sits at the front of parties and parties. South Africa, Chad, Uganda, Congo, Djibouti –countries that endorse the Icc – let him run again and again. You can't do that. This is where we need to be firmly addressed by our diplomatic services. Or do our diplomatic services speak with flour in their mouths? Is the European asylum crisis already leading the way in Khartoum?  At the end of 2015, the project for better migration management was launched, providing assistance and training for countries in the Horn of Africa to better monitor their external borders and deal with migrants. Dealing with migrants, do you mean that constructive cooperation between Sudan and Eritrea? People who are sent back to Eritrea are in incredible danger. Or perhaps we mean that pleasant cooperation between Italy and Sudan, in which 48 potential refugees were sent back to Sudan in August? You are not going to tell me that after Turkey, Sudan has also become a safe country.  It remains a traving that cooperation between the European Union and African countries to stop migration has been named after the capital of Sudan: the Khartoum process. I would like to take the European delegation in Khartoum at their word when they say that, of course, the Sudanese Rapid Support Forces are not guarding the northern border at the behest of the European Union to stop refugees. But I can vividly imagine that the commander of those Rapid Forces, trained by us in migration management, may not have that quite sharp anymore.  Let us be clear: this week's Afghanistan summit also shows that it is difficult to keep migration management and development cooperation apart. Ms Mogherini said: "There is never a conditional link between development aid and what we do in the area of migration." I'll hold her to that. This resolution therefore also calls for clarity on the use of the funds in 'better migration management' in Sudan. Then we'll get that idea out of the world.

name: Bas BELDER
text: Author. – Islamic law, Sharia law, adopted by Sudan five years ago – October 2011 – appears to be severely affecting the Christian minority.  I am pleased to see former Colleague Commissioner Malmström in front of me, I know her as a committed former member of the Committee on Foreign Affairs and the Subcommittee on Human Rights.  I would like to receive a detailed overview from the Council and the Commission of the impact of Sharia law on Christians in Sudan. There is an extremely active EU delegation, so could you tell us – because I understand that you cannot give it now – that I would like an answer to that? How does this come about for the Christian minority?  To take an advance on the questions that live with me, because I have been going through documentation for this debate this week. For example, the destruction of churches has become a normal pattern in Sudan in recent years. Is this image correct? Can you inform me about that, please write? The Sudanese regime has a downright criminal policy of ethnic and religious cleansing against Christians in South Kordofan and Blue Nile. I would also appreciate and be particularly pleased with detailed information on paper.  Mrs. Malmström, I know you, a woman of her word. I would like to see documentation from your side, especially now that there is a special person – Mr Figel – who deals with religious freedom. I'd like to be informed. What do we see and what do we do?

name: Marie-Christine VERGIAT
text: Author. Mr President, we are once again talking about the dramatic situation in Sudan. The resolution addresses a wide range of human rights violations in that country: permanent bombing of civilians, including with chemical weapons; permanent repression of all opponents; violations of freedom of thought, conscience and religion, regardless of religion; Violence against women; threats to migrants, such as those unfortunate Eritreans arrested and sent back directly to their country, at the risk of their lives, on behalf of the European Union; and the fact that the mandate of the International Criminal Court against Mr. Al-Bashir is constantly flouted.  So I wonder what fly could have stung the European Union to decide to hold a conference in Khartoum in October 2014 on migration routes and the States of the Horn of Africa with representatives of all the Member States? The Council, all the Member States and the Commission have thus given Mr Al-Bashir the international recognition to which he aspires, rendering obsolete any support, or even showing a certain contempt, for the difficult work of the International Criminal Court.

name: Pavel TELIČKA
text: author. – Madam President, ever since February 2003 and well before, we have seen in the Darfur region nothing but violence and ethnic cleansing, all done or conducted by government forces, the secret service and pro-government militia. The United Nations calls this one of the worst humanitarian crises ever, with 2.3 million displaced and 300 000 casualties. The dictatorship in Khartoum is abusing human rights on a daily basis and is preventing aid workers, NGOs, peacekeepers and others access to aid those in need. By the way, I am grateful to my colleagues that they have accepted a proposal to name concretely the aid workers concerned, including one countryman of mine. Moreover, as has been said, Amnesty International has investigated the fact that in the last eight months there has been repeated use of chemical weapons. This Sudanese situation must end. Enough is really enough.  That is why today we call on all stakeholders involved to act quickly and to put an end to this situation. Omar al-Bashir is a war criminal and, if the rest of the world does not want to act, the EU has to move and impose targeted punitive sanctions against those responsible for continued war crimes and non-cooperation with the International Court of Justice.

name: Pavel SVOBODA
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. – Madam President, Unfortunately, Sudan is one of those states that we are not talking about here for the first time in the context of human rights. 15 months ago, the European Parliament stood up for Marjam Ibrahím, a victim of Sudanese religious intolerance who was subsequently released.  However, we are constantly witnessing human rights violations. I would therefore like to draw attention once again to the European Parliament's recommendation to the Council of June 2013 that development aid must be provided only where freedom of religion is respected. I have emphasised my conviction here several times about the universality of human rights, but let me emphasise from the whole resolution the right to freedom of religion, in relation to the Czech citizen Petr Yašek, who has been imprisoned in Sudan for several months, and I call on the Sudanese Government here to release him immediately.

name: Julie WARD
text: on behalf of the S&D Group. – Mr President, how sad it is to be standing here again talking about appalling atrocities being committed in Sudan. The use of gas, cluster bombs and rape as a weapon of war have no place in our world. These are crimes against our common humanity. I would like to pay tribute to all of the brave human rights defenders and activists, and civil society organisations and networks, who risk their lives on the ground in order to let the world know what is happening. We want to stand here in solidarity with you and give you a voice. I am eternally grateful to the British organisation ‘Waging Peace’ with whom I am in regular contact. What we must do as MEPs is to make sure that no EU aid money is funnelled to actors committing these terrible crimes, and also that the EU does not compromise on human rights protections when doing deals on migration in the region, including the Khartoum Agreement. We continue to work to hold the Commission, the EEAS and the Council to account on this, day and night.

name: Mark DEMESMAEKER
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. – We have a moral obligation to condemn, condemn loud and clear the use of weapons of mass destruction. Anytime, anywhere, and in particular the use of chemical weapons. It is a war crime, a crime against humanity, a violation of international law.  Amnesty International has a well-documented report with testimonies and photo evidence of the use of chemical weapons in Sudan, targeting civilians, in a remote area of Darfur. With hundreds of victims, many of them children.  In Sudan, as in the rest of the world, citizens have the right to protection. The international community must use all its levers to do so. Also to provide access to humanitarian aid, to ensure disarmament.  Today, the same war crimes are taking place in Darfur as in 2004. Then the world woke up to human rights violations. The only thing that has changed since then is that the world is no longer watching. That's the real drama. It is up to us and you, Commissioner, to change that.

name: Hilde VAUTMANS
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Sudan is plagued by many plagues. I think everyone here has already listed them today. In addition, since 1989, the country has been held hostage by a head of government who oppresses and terrorises his people. There is no freedom of the press and internet traffic is severely curtailed.  It is the same government that dropped chemical weapons in Darfur last week, killing many people, many children.  Europe has given EUR 196 million to Sudan since 2010 and a further EUR 100 million has been allocated through the Africa Emergency Trustfronds from 2016. It is a disgrace that we continue to support a government financially while women are raped and chemical weapons are used. I therefore call on you today: send a strong European signal, stop the financial flows towards a government that is so flot out on human rights. It is time for a strong European signal.

name: Maria Lidia SENRA RODRÍGUEZ
text: GUE/NGL Group. – Mr President, first of all, our condemnation of violence, massacres and repression of the population in Sudan. Secondly, to ask the European Union for a real effort to stop the looting of Africa. Because we know that behind these conflicts, there are usually always interests of large corporations and Western powers, whether it's land separation, whether oil, whether minerals and, also, logically, behind it's the arms sales business. That is why, Commissioner, we ask you to put all measures at your disposal to stop the looting of Africa, to stop the sale of arms, and to enable the peoples of Africa to develop, improve the quality of life of their inhabitants and achieve peace.

name: James CARVER
text: on behalf of the EFDD Group. – Mr President, Sudan’s partition into two states was supposed to end decades of conflict blighting that country. However, this has unfortunately not proved to be the case with both countries still suffering the acrimony from internal conflict and persisting border disputes. The international community must do more to support the two countries working with both Sudan and South Sudan, and, of course, the regional institutions, to help resolve the border dispute and improve human rights in terms of security and personal dignity in both countries.  The immediate humanitarian and security situation must be addressed and combined with genuine longer—term solutions. Most pressing is the issue of the removal of punitive tariffs placed on trade. The liberalisation of these rules will not only do far more to support development and the chronic needs and daily lives of people in Sudan, South Sudan, and indeed Africa as a whole, but will also help our own citizens through cheaper food and freeing up money which would otherwise go on foreign aid, which is not always ending up where it aims to be sent. The Horn of Africa is a tragedy, but there are some good parts of it not – not least Somaliland and I, as you know, am a long-time advocate of support of international re-recognition of Somaliland. I do not think that the issue of Sudan and South Sudan needs to be a precursor or a hurdle to the genuine aspirations of people in a different part of the Horn of Africa who have led a far different, and a far more peaceful and dignified, example.

name: Edouard FERRAND
text: on behalf of the ENF group. Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, a new tragedy threatens the world. Recent suspicions of the use of chemical weapons by the Khartoum regime show that the Sudanese regime is a veritable rogue state, a leading fodest of radical Islamism. I am pleased to see the unanimity of my colleagues here. From Al-Tourabi to Al-Bashir, this regime has been marked by its genocidal conduct against the Christian and animist populations, as well as against the minorities of Darfur.  Whatever happens to the chemical weapons investigations, we must banish civilized nations from this regime which was, it must be remembered, one of bin Laden's refuges and one of the most radical Islamist groups.

name: Krzysztof HETMAN
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by The situation in Sudan has been particularly severe for many years. Three million people have been forced to flee their homes due to the conflict, hundreds of thousands have lost their lives, malnutrition levels are below alert and more than 6.5 million people are in need of various forms of humanitarian aid. In April, the European Commission decided to provide additional assistance of EUR 100 million to improve the living conditions of Sudanese people. I agree that this assistance is well-needed and very necessary. Unfortunately, however, the question of reaching out to those in need itself, given that access to the most affected regions is deliberately blocked, remains a huge problem. I therefore believe that the European Union should strongly condemn such activities and strongly oppose violations of international humanitarian law, as well as demand that those guilty of crimes against civilians be punished.

name: Monica MACOVEI
text: – Mr President, the Darfur region of Sudan is in the worst humanitarian crisis in the world. More than three million people need humanitarian aid, they are sick, they have no food and most are internally displaced. In addition, the Government of Sudan has used chemical weapons to kill people - more than 200 people in 2016 alone - and most of them are children.  We all know that the use of chemical weapons is a war crime. According to Amnesty International there were more than 300 chemical weapons attacks in 2016 alone, the last on September 9, 2016. In addition, human rights activists are closed, representatives of the Christian church in Sudan are closed, and all this makes the Darfur region of Sudan and Sudan practically a dictatorship and an area where people starve, die attacked with chemical weapons.  They urgently call for the stopping of criminal attacks and the release of those who are being released for political reasons.

name: Urmas PAET
text: – Mr President, reports on the use of chemical weapons are extremely disturbing. The use of such weapons must be investigated by the United Nations and perpetrators must be brought to justice. The situation in Darfur, in South Kordofan and Blue Nile, is deplorable. The innocent killings must stop immediately. The UN-African Union mission must be given access to these areas and humanitarian aid made accessible in this humanitarian disaster. President al-Bashir must be arrested, as foreseen by the International Criminal Court. Those States that gladly greet al-Bashir in their countries, despite the fact that he is wanted by the ICC, must keep in mind that they bear part of the responsibility for the atrocities that are going on in Sudan, by greeting al—Bashir and not allowing for his arrest.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: ECR). Mr President, since 1989, when Omar al-Bashir seized power in Sudan in a coup d'état, the country has been placed under authoritarian rule and conflicts within it have multiplied, resulting in thousands of deaths and millions of displaced persons and refugees. At the same time, since 2003, the conflict in Darfur has resulted in more than 300,000 deaths and, according to Amnesty International data, hundreds of children have died from the chemicals with which the Sudanese government is bombing the region. Moreover, the freedom of the press and the media is deteriorating and criminal charges against journalists are frequent.  It is therefore necessary to put an end to all forms of violence, repression and violation of human rights in Sudan, as well as to the bombing of the civilian population using chemical weapons. At the same time, there should be financial support for all humanitarian organisations from the European Union in order to provide food and healthcare to the population and armed conflicts taking place in the region should also be condemned.

name: Michaela ŠOJDROVÁ
text: – Mr President, I support the resolution on human rights violations and the government of Sudan's law. I think it is very important that we present specific cases of detention of local priests and aid workers. Among them is petr jašek, a citizen of the Czech Republic. In Sudan, these individuals assisted locals in areas plagued by military dictatorships, military conflicts, and were subsequently accused by the intolerant Sudanese regime of anti-state activities. They are now awaiting trial and their lives are in danger. These people helped the local population daily in dangerous areas of humanitarian work, giving them hope for a better life.  It is now up to us to stand up not only for their efforts, but also for themselves, and to appeal to the Sudanese authorities that the fate of these volunteers should be better, and to appeal in the sense that we are not indifferent. We want them released. And I also ask you, Commissioner, to push for their release.

name: Nicola CAPUTO
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the situation in Sudan is very difficult. The country is appalled by the recent violence between supporters of President Salva Kiir and those of former Vice-President Riek Machar. Amnesty International has complained that this year the Sudanese Government has even carried out chemical weapons attacks against the civilian population. In addition to the violence, there is a dramatic famine. There would be at least five million people starving. The political crisis leaves the whole country in a state of great instability and violence. A very painful and very complex situation that has distant roots: war, the interweaving of international interests and tribal struggles for local power and so on. All this at the expense of the civilian population. It is time for the European Union and the international community to exert all their pressure to also initiate a political transition or to open up the country to democratic standards, the only way to help the Sudanese people and also the people of Darfur to emerge from the current state of underdevelopment and suffering.

name: Stanislav POLČÁK
text: – Mr President, I would also like to express my support for the citizens who are being detained in Sudan, including, of course, the Czech citizen mentioned by my colleague Šojdrová. Commissioner, please take the aim of releasing these people.  However, if we look at the situation in Sudan in a kind of greater perspective, we see here not only a humanitarian disaster, not only a violation of fundamental human rights, but we also see here, of course, the abuse of the aid that is being delivered. And this is, to some extent, a political clash, because, on the one hand, we want to help those extremely poor citizens whose lives depend on this very assistance, and besides, we see this abuse.  I think that we should try to support specific projects that, for example, lead to greater innovation in agriculture in this area, if at least a little bit possible, because they will help to address the situation on the ground itself.

name: Cecilia MALMSTRÖM
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, this is not the first time we are discussing Sudan in this plenary, and of course we see with very much concern that the human rights situation in Sudan has shown no sign of improvement and is, in fact, deteriorating. Serious human rights violations have been perpetrated by state actors, government—supported militia and rebel forces in impunity. These happened with serious disregard for Sudan’s interim constitutions of 2005, international commitments or recommendations presented by the Human Rights Council. International and local civil society organisations in Sudan face severe obstructions in their work, in particular those working on human rights issues and in conflict-affected areas. One of these organisations is the one you referred to, TRACKs, a human rights organisation which provides and facilitates training on a variety of topics, ranging from human rights to information technology. Currently ten members or affiliates of the TRACKs staff, including its Director, Khalafalla Alafif Mukhtar, who has been in detention since May, are facing trial in two separate cases under Sudan’s criminal court and these carry – as you also mentioned – the death penalty.  The EU considers that the repeated official raids and summoning of staff on judicial charges are in violation of freedom of expression and association and appear to be a clear attempt to intimidate the members of the organisations due to their work on human rights or democratisation. Accordingly, we have closely followed developments on the TRACKs case and we have observed several court sessions. It is coordinating with the different EU Member States and other Western embassies on the ground to ensure a continuous international presence throughout the trials on a rotation basis. This case is, of course, also continuously raised in meetings with Sudanese officials. Overall, promoting a conducive environment for civil society and the protection of human right defenders are key issues in EU relations with Sudan. We have the EU country map for engagement of civil society and the human rights and democracy strategy for Sudan. However, UN agencies and humanitarian partners keep being denied access to so many areas in Darfur, in South Kordofan and Blue Nile by government authorities, preventing the delivery of assistance which is so needed to the vulnerable population. We have, in the EU, been at the forefront of calling for a speedy agreement on cessation of hostilities, humanitarian taxes and an inclusive, comprehensive and transparent national dialogue process in a conducive environment. Efforts towards peace and human rights remain a priority for the EU. The EU, in particular through our Special Representative for the Horn of Africa, Mr Alexander Rondos, supports efforts towards a holistic and inclusive political solution. Political and financial support was provided to the mediation efforts led by President Mbeki, in the framework of the African Union High-Level Implementation Panel for Sudan and South Sudan. We consider that the gravity of the human rights situation requires continued attention from the UNHCR and therefore we have supported the extension of the mandate of the independent experts on Sudan, while pushing strongly for his full access to all areas of the country.  Our commitments to enhance cooperation with African countries on migration is firmly anchored within international humanitarian law and international human rights law, and EU assistance to Sudan is delivered at bilateral and regional levels through international organisations and NGOs, not through that Sudanese Government. No support has ever been given to the rapid support forces, and we are aware of the specific situation of the Christian minorities and are looking into that. There have recently been some arrests of pastors and we are following those cases on the ground as well. The EU will continue to call for the government to respect freedom of expression, peaceful assembly and the media, to release the detainees and to give them an opportunity for fair trial and to conduct credible investigations into human rights violations that led to killing, injuries and material damage. I am sure this is not going to be the last time we discuss the terrible situation in Sudan.

name: David Maria SASSOLI
text: The debate is closed. The vote will take place at the end of the debate. Written declarations (Rule 162)

name: Isabella ADINOLFI
text: in writing. Today, we denounce the sudanese Government's use of chemical weapons against civilians in the Jebel Marra region of Darfur and stress that this is a serious violation of international standards and a war crime; we also condemn any other form of violation of fundamental human rights perpetrated by the Sudanese Government and opposition forces against activists, journalists and civil society spokesmen.  The EU and its Member States must continue their commitment to support the African Union's efforts to bring peace to Sudan and to the Sudanese people in the transition to a reformed democracy from within.

name: David Maria SASSOLI
text: The next item is the debate on seven motions for resolutions on Thailand, in particular the case of Andy Hall.

name: Ignazio CORRAO
text: author. – Mr President, in October 2015 we highlighted the difficult political situation in Thailand, where a military junta took power after the coup of May 2014. At present there is no way to foresee a full transition back to a civilian government. On the contrary, the Thai military junta has adopted arbitrary and even more restrictive measures to disrupt the lives of everyone opposing the regime. Arrests and intimidation are frequent in order to control the population and reduce or eliminate citizens’ freedom of expression. Among them, Andy Hall, who has always been a defender of workers’ rights and a committed activist, has been falsely accused of defamation and now faces a three-year prison sentence. We ask for immediate withdrawal of this allegation, and stress the regime should change its attitude to its citizens and to fundamental freedoms. For these reasons, we think it is essential for the Commission and the European External Action Service to take action on the issue.

name: Jeroen LENAERS
text: author. – Mr President, this debate and this resolution are the result of our commitment and our friendship with the Thai people and it is because of this commitment and friendship that we share some of our concerns here today: concerns about the labour rights for migrants in Thailand, concerns about the disproportionate use of criminal defamation laws, and concerns about the climate and the legal framework in which human rights defenders like Andy Hall have to do their work to speak for those who cannot speak for themselves. But it is not only about concerns today; it is also about acknowledging the steps that the Thai Government has taken in recent times and about encouraging Thailand to continue and to accelerate those developments. Yesterday, many of us had the opportunity to meet with Andy Hall. He is here in Parliament today, so let us also take this opportunity to welcome him here and from this Chamber applaud his determination and his passion to bring about real change in people’s lives. Workers have rights. Whether they are migrants or not, they have the right to safety and dignity at work. Andy Hall has the right to protect and to defend them, and we have a duty to help and support them.

name: Pier Antonio PANZERI
text: Author. Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, Andy Hall is one of many activists who has exposed the daily violations of human rights and labour rights suffered by migrant workers in Thailand. The reporting activity of Andy Hall and other rights defenders has been prosecuted as a libel offence and this represents a narrowing of the area of freedom and freedom of expression available to civil society. In our opinion, the Government of Bangkok must be aware that denouncing the abuses and bad practices of companies will not affect the country's reputation or access to the global product market, but will help to improve the quality of the world of work for the benefit of workers of all nationalities. I hope that Thailand will continue its progress on the protection of labour rights and, in particular, that it will continue with the implementation of the memorandum for cooperation with neighbouring countries on the employment of foreign workers, a regulatory system that is still too little used. We hope that there will be positive responses to our resolution from the Thai authorities.

name: Lola SÁNCHEZ CALDENTEY
text: Author. – Mr President, andy Hall's case seems like a joke. How is it possible for a workers' rights defender, a citizen of the European Union, to be sentenced to three years in prison and a significant fine only for collaborating on a report by an oenegé exposing human rights violations at the Thai Natural Fruit Company plant? Gentlemen, this is a disgrace. As is the human rights situation in Thailand. In this regard, Human Rights Watch notes that the human rights and labour rights of migrant workers, especially from Myanmar, Cambodia and Laos, are violated with impunity on a regular and permitted basis.  The European Union needs to promote binding systems to ensure respect for human rights companies. An essential step in this is to support the creation of a binding treaty on transnationals and human rights within the United Nations. Last year our representative tried to block the process: I was there and I saw it. We hope this year won't happen again. In the meantime, what you can do is support our amendments to this resolution.

name: Dita CHARANZOVÁ
text: author. – Mr President, Madam Commissioner, reporting human rights violations is not a crime. Andy Hall has been unjustly punished by Thailand for reporting violations by Thailand of its own laws and international commitments. People should not be punished for bringing injustices to light. This verdict sends an alarming message to all defenders of rights in Thailand. The Thai Government has taken measures to improve working conditions. It should confirm this commitment by pardoning Andy Hall and amending the laws under which he was convicted, including the Computer Crime Act, to make clear that these laws should not be abused to suppress individuals’ fundamental rights.

name: Heidi HAUTALA
text: author. – Mr President, it is very unusual that a person whom an urgent resolution of the European Parliament concerns can be present, as many of them have disappeared or have been imprisoned. Today, however, this is not so. Mr Andy Hall is present and has been in Parliament as my guest, meeting many colleagues and other EU actors. He was deemed guilty of criminal defamation under Article 328 of the Thai Criminal Code and crimes under Article 14(1) of the Computer Crimes Act. The charges were brought against him by Natural Food Company Limited, a Thai pineapple producer, because of a report called ‘Cheap has a high price’, which was published by a Finnish NGO, Finnwatch. Mr Hall had done research for the report which revealed serious violations of workers’ rights in Natural Food’s operations. The report’s aim was to investigate possible problems in Finnish retail companies’ supply chains and these violations were found. To respect the court’s decision does not mean that we should agree with it. Today the European Parliament will show that we disagree with the Bangkok criminal court.  I have been following Andy Hall’s case for several years now and I will continue to express my support for him, among many other colleagues who are deeply touched by what happened to him. Instead of being prosecuted and convicted, Andy Hall should be given an award for his work as a human rights defender. The use of criminal defamation laws, carrying penalties of imprisonment against human rights defenders, constitutes a violation of Thailand’s obligations under the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights, to which it is a state party.  Thailand has recently made some progress in the work against labour exploitation. It has, for example, ratified ILO Convention 187 on Promotional Framework for Occupational Safety and Health. Still, Thailand should abolish the crime of defamation and it needs to revise the Computer Crime Act, which is very broadly worded. I am very concerned about what implications Mr Hall’s sentence will have on people and organisations working to improve the human rights situation in Thailand. The court decision is a clear step back on freedom of expression that might lead to further silencing of human rights defenders in Thailand.  Corporate social responsibility is the cornerstone for improving the human rights situation all over the world. Transparency and responsible business conduct is today’s thinking. Companies should be thankful for research and civil society that looks at their supply chains and this is exactly what the Finnish retail company S Group did by looking into the findings and remedying its supply chains.

name: Charles TANNOCK
text: author. – Mr President, since the military coup in Thailand of 2014, we have all been waiting for the promised return to democracy. We are told that following the introduction of the new constitution, democratic elections will go ahead next year, but we must question the degree of democracy on offer, in spite of the so-called democratic mandate required by the outcome of the referendum. An upper house entirely appointed by the military junta with powers to dissolve the government and appoint the prime minister is enough for me to question the democratic credentials of the new settlement for Thailand.  As for the case of my compatriot, Andy Hall, it is extremely concerning that the author of a report into migrant labour rights should end up with a criminal conviction and a three—year prison term. Regardless of the underlying intent, this case will act as a deterrent to whistleblowers and human rights activists. So I am pleased that our resolution today calls for the Thai authorities to decriminalise defamation laws, and I believe that this will go a long way to proving their commitment to improving working conditions for migrant labourers and supporting the efforts of those that seek to uncover such abuses.

name: Eduard KUKAN
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. – Mr President, the work of human right defenders faces many challenges in the countries of South-East Asia. It is important, therefore, that the EU stand behind them, especially in cases when they come under attack and harassment from governments or local authorities, such as the case with Andy Hall in Thailand. Our delegation should be ready to provide them with the necessary help and assistance.  The problem of migrant workers in Thailand is well known in the region. It is important that the countries have a framework for the protection of migrant workers in place. Thailand is one of the most developed countries in the region and I hope it will remain open for workers from other countries. It should, however, respect their rights as required by international conventions. At the same time, I also appeal to the Thai Government to lift restrictions on civil rights, support democratisation of the country and protect human rights organisation and human rights defenders to work unrestricted.

name: David MARTIN
text: on behalf of the S&D Group. – Mr President, the court verdict against Andy Hall is not, in reality, about offences that he committed. This was a verdict against freedom of expression and human rights defenders in general. The danger of it is that it will embolden other companies to file suits against activists and workers, and indeed this is already the case in relation to 14 chicken farmers in Thailand.  It is clear, as other colleagues have said, that there are significant loopholes in the defamation and cybercrime laws in Thailand. It is these that have allowed the Natural Fruit Company to bring this unjust case against Mr Hall. Whilst we recognise that companies do have the right to sue on legitimate grounds of defamation, imprisonment is never an appropriate sentence in such cases. We encourage all governments to ensure their penal code contains effective guards against efforts aimed at silencing human rights activists and, in my last few seconds, I want to join Heidi Hautala in praising the S Group in Finland for their responsible approach to the supply chain and the actions that they have taken.

name: Merja KYLLÖNEN
text: On behalf of the GUE/NGL Group. – Mr President, improving the position of workers, protecting the environment, human rights and democracy are certainly important values for all of us. The EU must always defend, in all situations, those courageous people who dare to put themselves on the line for these values.   It is equally important for the EU to act consistently for these values, including in foreign and trade policy. If, in the interests of economic interests, we turn a blind eye to people's needs, we will have no credibility in acting and condemning individual events that cross the news threshold. The treatment of Andy Hall and his revelations say much more about Thai society and the global economy than the surface that we Europeans often see on our holidays.   Europe must demand that Thailand and other partners strengthen the rule of law and democracy. People must be allowed to show their opinions freely without fear of the consequences, be they EU citizens, guest workers or trade union activists in their own country.

name: Seán KELLY
text: – Mr President, the fact that Andy Hall is here, and I welcome him and commend him on his courage, is I suppose indicative that this is a rather unusual resolution. Most of the people we have resolutions about are locked up and tortured, etc., but at the same time, the issue is very important because, as has been said, it is not really about Andy Hall at all, it is about the broader implications of his case and the attempt to discourage people from defending human rights when they are abused, and from defending the rights of migrant workers.  So I think we have to put extra pressure on the Thai authorities to amend the Computer Crimes Act and also the law on defamation. This is not right or proper and, because of our relationship with Thailand, the EEAS here should be in a position to put greater pressure on them to ensure that there is fair play for everybody, especially migrant workers, and also to ensure the conviction of Andy Hall is overturned.

name: Richard HOWITT
text: – Mr President, on behalf of Andy’s constituency MEP, Glenis Willmott, who has championed his case, and on behalf of Andy himself, who told us this yesterday, this debate and resolution is not about Andy personally. It is about an attempt to cover up abuses, low wages and child labour in the production of fruit juice that we go to Carrefour, to Morrison’s, and to other supermarkets to buy and to drink. To Thailand I say: do not criminalise those who uncover the abuses, criminalise those who perpetrate them. To Commissioner Malmstrom I say: you and I went together to the Dutch Presidency Conference on global supply chains. As CSR rapporteur I say: the Commission and Parliament together have championed the UN Guiding Principles on Business and Human Rights. EU trade policy is supposed to support core labour standards and decent work. Commissioner, in your reply tell us what these words mean in Andy's case. What action have you taken and will you take so that the responsibility of European companies is fully upheld in the policies we say we follow and so that we are not as complicit as anyone in Thailand for the abuses that Andy has uncovered?

name: Marc TARABELLA
text: Mr President, the conviction of Human Rights Defender Andy Hall, and particularly here the rights of migrant workers, is a catastrophic signal to all human rights defenders in Thailand. Indeed, while it was already difficult for them to do their job properly, this judgment will cause victims of abuse to hesitate before confiding about working and living conditions in Thailand.  Instead of respecting its obligation to protect human rights activists, Thailand allowed itself to embark on a trial that was only there to establish the omnipotence of companies that want to stifle information about their abuses against workers. Unfortunately, Mr. Hall's case is not the only one, and many human rights defenders are being sued for defamation. It is high time that Thailand understood the need to look at its judicial system and stop preventing human rights defenders from doing their jobs.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: ECR). Mr President, on 20 September 2016, a Bangkok criminal court found Andy Hall guilty of alleged slander, imposing a four-year prison sentence on him. Andy Hall has been fighting for human rights protection in Southeast Asia for the past ten years and has taken part in investigations into the mistreatment of migrant workers in Thailand, providing evidence of the violation of basic rights during their work, as well as the lack of protection under the country's labour laws.  However, the case of Andy Hall is not unique in Thailand. On the contrary, there is an increase in prosecutions against human rights defenders in the country. According to the UN Human Rights Office, ten people have already been prosecuted in the country this year for reporting incidents of rights violations. It is therefore necessary to restore democracy in Thailand immediately and to protect human rights, in particular workers' rights. The Thai authorities must finally stop bringing criminal charges against human rights defenders as well as against Andy Hall.

name: Nicola CAPUTO
text: – Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, we can only express our concern at the four-year prison sentence for defamation and cybercrime imposed on 20 September in Bangkok on Andy Hall, a British citizen and migrant rights activist, who three years ago denounced the exploitation of labour in the fruit processing industry, largely intended for export to Europe. Hall had denounced, on behalf of an NGO, the use of forced child labour, lower wages than legal wages and out-of-order hours in a factory of the Thai giant National Fruit.  The European Union must condemn a measure which once again affects those who denounce the child labour of the workforce engaged in these large multinationals. We must strongly call for a review of the trial of Andy Hall and at the same time ask ourselves about the ethical quality of the products entering our market. Consumers must be informed about the quality of the products, but also about the primary guarantees offered to every worker employed in production. In short, we must prevent products manufactured by minors from being introduced into our market.

name: Stanislav POLČÁK
text: – Mr President, if someone publishes an injustice, if he asks for an investigation into infringements and is actually condemned on the basis of a certain 'rubber' law, that undoubtedly indicates the nature of such a regime.  I am convinced that we cannot call Thailand a democratic state, I am sorry, it is a beautiful country, but the military now has power in it, and this army is applying it in a way that is truly at the heart of the fundamental demands we place on democracy. For this reason, I would very much like both the Commissioner and the Commission, of course, to always think very clearly about what kind of assistance they will provide to such a state, so that it actually gets to those in need and that it does not only strengthen the regime.

name: Liisa JAAKONSAARI
text: – Mr President, fortunately there are many good things about this sad issue. The way in which NGOs work is fine. We are not talking in general terms, but have targeted the company. In addition, this company, the Finnish S-chain, has already corrected its practices.  I believe that one of the purposes of our debate is to have a direct influence on the Commission. Commissioner Malmström, for example, you could give a little hardness to the international labour organisation, the ILO, to take more account of workers' rights. We must also support NGOs in this day-to-day practical work to defend workers' rights and to defend the rights that are very little defended, that is to say, the guest workers. Andy Hall certainly deserves a trophy and no punishment.

name: Cecilia MALMSTRÖM
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, a Thai court has sentenced the British social rights campaigner, Andy Hall, to a three—year suspended prison sentence. Mr Hall is present with us today and I welcome his presence.  The case was brought against him by a Thai food processing company for his contribution to a report by the European NGO, Finnwatch, which alleged serious labour rights abuses by the company concerned. This verdict sends shivers through Thailand’s already nervous human rights and social rights community. Criminal defamation laws are often used improperly by various actors to silence analysis and debate. Mr Hall’s reaction, that he was grateful for the international attention the case has brought to migrant rights in Thailand, testifies to his character in a way that the verdict does not because this is, of course, a much bigger question than one person. It is not my role to criticise a court, but let me mention what the ILO country director said, and I quote, ‘Labour rights abuses suffered by migrants in Thailand have been well documented in various ILO reports. The treatment alleged in the Finnwatch report is not unique to any one employer or industry’. This verdict casts a deep shadow over the real progress in Thailand in recent months regarding labour conditions. Let me mention, for instance, the prohibition of child labour in the seafood sector, the reinforcement of the labour inspection, the new legislation for labour agencies, measures to prevent debt bondage and trafficking in human beings, more deterrent sanctions schemes on labour abuses and the decision to ratify several ILO conventions. This would, of course, not have been possible without political will and dedicated Thai officials, without our dialogue with them, and without the cooperation of the ILO. The EU has several projects in Thailand, together with the ILO, on the issue of migrant workers and labour conditions. The progress made is good and we expect it to continue. We hope that the abuses and the type of abuses which Mr Hall has documented will soon no longer be found in Thai factories. Respecting human rights is important, but it is also good business. Companies in Thailand and everywhere in the world who want to send to the EU need to understand that European consumers demand products free of labour abuse. I say to them that they should not underestimate the fundamental decency of the European consumer during her or his daily shopping. Do not underestimate the EU’s – and the increasingly global –determination in ensuring decent work in global supply chains and more transparency. This is indeed an issue we are working on with companies to see if we can formulate a more coherent corporate social responsibility strategy that we are working on within the Commission. Mr Hall, Finnwatch, Thai workers, migrant workers in Thailand and Thai officials working on labour rights all deserve our continued support and the closest possible cooperation to accelerate the process which is still so necessary.

name: David Maria SASSOLI
text: The debate is closed. The vote will take place at the end of the debate. (The sitting was suspended at 11.35 a.m. and resumed at 12.00 p.m.)

name: Pavel SVOBODA
text: – Mr President, I propose that we amend paragraph 6 of the resolution, so that at the end of the paragraph we add the words: ‘and especially concerning’ and then we add the four names you have in the voting lists.  I have three reasons for this amendment. Firstly, among the four there is a European citizen, a Czech national, Petr Jašek. We simply should stand behind our people and, at the same time, not forget the other three. Secondly, we are voting on urgent cases, urgent individual cases and not country-by-country reports. Concrete names make a difference.  Lastly, these four people are threatened by a death sentence; to be or not to be mentioned in this resolution can make the difference between life and death. I therefore beg you, colleagues, to kindly accept this amendment.

name: Malin BJÖRK
text: – Mr President, of course, it is Rule 135 on breaches of human rights and international law. I want to say to this House that we have no news from the peaceful Women’s Boat to Gaza; they are being held in Israel. (The President cut off the speaker)

name: Alexander Graf LAMBSDORFF
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for his excellent report, which We have all the issues that are particularly burning on our nails. But they are not suitable as points of order. I had spoken to my colleague about this in the run-up to this plenary session. I would therefore ask you to understand that I am doing this a little more rigorously. We should have these discussions in the committees and meetings that are designated for that purpose. (Applause)

name: Krisztina MORVAI
text: - Mr President, I would like to thank the European When voting on the report on international financial reporting standards, voters who know me can rightly ask me on what basis I dare to vote on such an issue, because I am not an economist, I am not a financial professional. Every day, however, I meet, as a lawyer and representative, with people who suffer from the effects of bank speculation. So I ask the economic and financial professional who helps me to prepare the voting lists to give professional advice that ultimately leads to a reduction in speculative possibilities. We are therefore talking about a systemic problem, international financial speculation. As long as the neoliberal financial economic system that is now in place in the world is in place, it will not cease to exist, but since I and my expert thought that these standards could reduce speculation, I voted in favour of the report.

name: Paloma LÓPEZ BERMEJO
text: – Mr President, we believe that moving from a model in which bank losses are not accounted for until they erupte to a model in which banks must account, at all times, for their actual exposure to financial risks is a positive step, because it will allow a clearer picture of the health of banks and help to avoid over-risk , or what that means, that it is the people who pay the dismantling of finance. If I abstained from Parliament's proposal, it is because it is trying to dilute, in some way, the effectiveness of these new standards, IFRS 9, avoiding references to possible regulatory capture and generally paying a negative view of the new rules, as if financial speculation were to be paid for to promote economic growth. We cannot comprehend the enormous instability of the current economic system, the power of large capital over States and on workers themselves, not to mention the growing expansion of financial services and speculative motive.

name: Seán KELLY
text: – Go raibh maith agat a Uachtaráin. Vótáil mé le mo ghrúpa sna vótaí seo agus tá áthas orm é sin a dhéanamh. Freisin, bhí sé de phribhléid agam labhairt ar son mo ghrúpa ar an ábhar seo go déanach oíche Dé Máirt, timpeall leath uair tar éis a haon déag. Ach ní gá dom mórán eile a rá ach tá seo ana thábhacht: go dtabharfaimid gach seans do na bainc airgead a thabhairt do na custaiméirí agus ag an am gcéanna má tá fadhbanna ann, go bhfeicfear na fadhbanna sin chomh luath agus is féidir, agus gur féidir leo bearta a dhéanamh dá réir. Dá bhrí sin táimid ag iarraidh cothromaíocht a chur isteach anseo agus is dóigh liom go bhfuil a fhios ag an gcoimisinéir mar dúirt sí é dhá oíche ó shin go bhfuil fadhbanna agus go bhfuil saghas, na bainc, go bhfuil eagla orthu go ndéanfaidh sé an-difríocht dóibh maidir le hairgead a chur ar fáil do dhaoine ach is dóigh liom gur féidir é sin a cheartú. Go raibh maith agat.

name: Clara AGUILERA
text: in writing. I supported the decision not to object to the updating of international standards for financial reporting (IFRS 9), with the aim of increasing transparency in the after-financial crisis. I also agree that the Commission should be asked to take steps to apply standards to the long-term investment insurance sector.

name: Tim AKER
text: in writing. – This non-legislative resolution calls on the Commission to act, and in particular to ‘make sure that IFRS 9 serves the EU’s long-term investment strategy’. This would be putting the cart before the horse. Accordingly, UKIP voted against.

name: Marina ALBIOL GUZMÁN
text: in writing. I consider, as the report says, that IFRS 9 is an important accounting step forward, moving from a 'loss incurred' model to an 'expected loss' model, that is, by forcing the financial system to immediately provision the risks incurred, rather than keeping them under the carpet until the bubble bursts. If I have abstained, it is because this motion is intended to postpone its entry into force and to dilute some of its proposals, in order to protect European finances above the general interest.

name: Eric ANDRIEU
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report promoting accounting standards that ensure financial stability, sustainable growth and long-term investment. A major overhaul of the process for developing and approving accounting standards is fundamental to ensuring transparency and accountability.

name: Laima Liucija ANDRIKIENĖ
text: in writing. ‒ I have voted in favour of the resolution on International Financial Reporting Standards: IFRS 9. The global financial crisis brought onto the EU agenda the role played by international financial reporting standards (IFRS) in financial stability and growth, in particular the rules regarding the recognition of losses incurred in the banking system. IFRS 9 – Financial Instruments were issued by the International Accounting Standards Board (IASB) as a key response to the financial crisis and its impact on the banking sector. I supported this motion for a resolution as it thoroughly notes the absence of a proper quantitative impact assessment for IFRS 9, which is due in part to a lack of reliable data. Also, it underlines the need to gain a better understanding of the impact of IFRS 9 on the banking sector, the insurance sector and the financial markets in general. I also welcome this resolution’ call on the European Commission, together with the European Supervisory Agencies (ESAs), the European Central Bank and the European Systemic Risk Board (ESRB), to closely monitor the implementation of IFRS 9 in the European Union.

name: Nikos ANDROULAKIS
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the motion for a resolution on International Financial Reporting Standards (IFRS 9) because it concerns accounting standards that ensure financial stability, sustainable growth and long-term investment.

name: Marie-Christine ARNAUTU
text: In writing. IFRS 9 applies to financial instruments and must address the difficulties associated with IAS 39 (International Accounting Standards), which is the current standard. The big change comes mainly from the notion of "fair value", which allows the assets and liabilities of large companies to be valued according to their market value or, failing that, according to their value calculated by the present sum of the expected revenue streams from their use. The draft resolution drafted by the ECON Committee calls on European and international financial regulators to produce studies on the impact of IFRS 9 standards on the banking, financial and insurance sectors. The proposal highlights concerns about the lag in the effective dates of IFRS 9 and the new accounting standards for insurance products, IFRS 17. This could lead to serious inconsistencies for companies that use both types of products. I voted in favour of this essentially technical proposal, which follows the very small feedback that the European Parliament receives from the regulatory bodies and the European Commission on the requests for impact assessments of IFRS 9.

name: Jonathan ARNOTT
text: in writing. ‒ I voted against due to the calls for Commission action in this regard.

name: Jean ARTHUIS
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this resolution because I believe that IFRS 9 is one of the necessary responses of the IASB to the financial crisis.

name: Zoltán BALCZÓ
text: Writing. \u2012 The global financial crisis that began in 2008 has put the G20 and the EU on the agenda to examine the role of international financial reporting standards in financial stability and growth, in particular the accounting of losses in the banking system. Indeed, the pre-crisis accounting standards did not function properly, for example, they resulted in pro-cyclicality in the accounting of profit or loss, i.e. risk accumulation was underestimated during the recovery phase of the cycle, and there was no common and transparent methodology for the valuation of non-liquid and impaired assets. The motion for a resolution is about putting international financial reporting standards on a new footing. In my view, this regulation does not eliminate the possibility of financial crises, because it is essentially related to the liberalisation of the financial sphere and the subsequent concentration, but it can, to some extent, curb speculation and I therefore supported its adoption, despite my reservations.

name: Gerard BATTEN
text: in writing. ‒ This non-legislative resolution calls on the Commission to act, and in particular to ‘make sure that IFRS 9 serves the EU’s long-term investment strategy’. This would be putting the cart before the horse. Accordingly UKIP voted against.

name: Nicolas BAY
text: In writing. The International Accounting Standards Board (IASB) aims to develop a set of accounting standards applicable around the world, and thus to create a common language for global financial reporting. These standards are called the International Financial Reporting Standards (IFRS). Since 2005, the IAS Regulation has required publicly traded EU companies to prepare their consolidated financial statements in accordance with these standards. I am in favour of this proposal for a technical resolution, which mainly calls on international financial and banking regulators to make available studies on the impact of IFRS9 accounting standards (for financial products) on the banking, financial and insurance sectors.

name: Hugues BAYET
text: In writing. The standard on financial instruments, launched in 2008 in response to the economic crisis, will be approved and will apply in 2018. A real big bang for financial institutions, which will have to adopt a new risk management framework. In practice, this means reviewing in their consolidated accounts the way in which all their financial assets are classified and assessed, but also the methods of depreciating their receivables. Clearly, the number of cases where they will have to use the fair value method, rather than the historical cost, will increase very sharply. Not only will be the proven losses related to the deterioration of a credit, but also the expected losses (which requires forecasting provisions for loan portfolios based on different risk factors).

name: Brando BENIFEI
text: in writing. \u2012 The global financial crisis has led the European Union, together with the G20, to address the role played by international financial reporting principles on financial stability and growth, in particular as regards the rules on the detection of losses incurred in the banking system. The motion for a resolution on international financial reporting standards, which I supported today, deals with the IFRS 9 standard, which is one of the main responses to the financial crisis of the International Accounting Standards Board (IASB). Thanks to the new instrument, it will be possible to improve the problems arising from the accounting methods by introducing a new model for the classification and measurement of financial instruments, the adoption of a new criterion for assessing expected losses and the definition of new rules for the detection of hedging instruments. However, some concerns remain about the impact of the IFRS 9 standard on the banking, insurance and financial markets in general, which is why the IASB needs to strengthen its impact analysis capacity, paying particular attention to the macroeconomic dimension.

name: Xabier BENITO ZILUAGA
text: in writing. I voted abstention in this report, although it contains a number of positive elements that I have supported. However, it does not call into question the process of establishing rules as such, which has a number of flaws, especially in relation to democratic control and supervision. In addition, the new IFRS 9 standard has not fully solved problems related to the procyclical nature and could have some negative consequences, especially for smaller financial institutions (e.g. cooperative banks) that use the standard method for access to credit risks. While the report raises some of these concerns, I fundamentally question the adequacy of the new standard, as well as the process with which it has been drafted.

name: Dominique BILDE
text: In writing. Since 2005, IAS Regulations have required publicly traded EU companies to prepare their consolidated financial statements in accordance with these standards. IFRS 9 is the standard that applies to financial instruments and must address the difficulties associated with IAS 39 (International Accounting Standards), which is the current standard. IFRS9 therefore makes changes in the methods of calculating "fair value" but there are very few impact analyses of these new standards.  The resolution here calls on financial regulators to produce studies of the impact of IFRS9 standards on the banking, financial and insurance sectors. In addition, the proposal addresses concerns about the lag in the effective dates of IFRS9 and the new standards for insurance products (IFRS17). It is therefore a very technical dossier that follows the lack of feedback received from regulators and the European Commission on requests for impact assessments. So I voted for it.

name: Mara BIZZOTTO
text: in writing. \u2012 The resolution on ifrs 9 international financial reporting principles presents critical issues that could create future problems for companies in our territories. That is why I preferred not to support the text with my vote.

name: Vilija BLINKEVIČIŪTĖ
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this resolution, in which the European Parliament discusses international financial reporting standard (IFRS) published by the International Accounting Standards Board. As a result of the global financial crisis, the importance of international financial reporting standards for financial stability and economic growth has been on the G20 and EU agendas, in particular the rules on the recognition of losses incurred in the banking system. Parliament therefore notes the importance of a full understanding of the interaction of IFRS 9 with other regulatory requirements and welcomes the European Banking Authority's assessment of the impact of IFRS 9 on EU banks to better understand the impact of this Standard on regulated own funds, its interaction with other prudential requirements and how institutions prepare for the application of IFRS 9. Parliament also notes that banks using the Standardised Approach are likely to be most affected by the reduction of their Common Equity Tier 1 capital, and therefore calls on the Commission to propose appropriate prudential framework measures by the end of 2017, such as the phasing-in procedure in the Capital Requirements Regulation, which mitigates the impact of a new impairment model over a three-year period (or until an appropriate international solution to this problem is established) and avoids unjustified sudden impacts on banks' capital ratios and lending.

name: Franc BOGOVIČ
text: Writing. -u2012 Resolution on International Financial Reporting Standards: I supported IFRS 9. IFRS 9 will enter into force on 1 January 2018 and will replace IAS 39, a set of financial instruments that will be able to respond to certain aspects of the financial crisis and its impact on the banking sector. IFRS 9 brings improvements compared to IAS 39, as the loss-based impairment model is turned into an impairment model based on expected losses, thus addressing the problem of "too little and too late" in the loan loss recognition process. While the views of auditors in this area vary widely, the ESAs, the Commission and the European Financial Reporting Advisory Group must work together on developing guidelines to prevent abuses of management discretion.

name: Simona BONAFÈ
text: in writing. \u2012 I support Parliament's report on the adoption of international financial reporting standards (IFRS 9) and share the concerns raised about aspects not yet sufficiently clarified by the Commission. In particular, the theme of ifrs9's potential negative impact on long-term investments in the absence of a quantitative impact assessment remains open. In this sense, Parliament stresses the need for such an impact analysis and requires it by December 2017. The path to recovery from the crisis and a return to economic growth require clarity on the priority to be given to increasing investment. In this respect, we must emphasise that we need coherence between EU actions, such as the European Fund for Strategic Investments, and more technical provisions that risk inhibiting rather than stimulating investment itself.

name: Biljana BORZAN
text: Written. \u2012 I support this Report on International Financial Reporting Standards. As a social democrat, I am committed to accounting standards that ensure financial stability, sustainable growth and long-term investment. I also support a profound overhaul of the process of drafting and certifiing accounting standards to ensure transparency and accountability.

name: Renata BRIANO
text: in writing. \u2012 IFRS 9 is one of the IASB's main responses to the financial crisis. It represents an improvement over IAS 39, as the shift from a "sustained loss" model to a "expected loss" model is a response to the problem of "too little, too late" in the credit loss detection process. It should be borne in mind that, in the case of IFRS 9, there is no adequate quantitative assessment of the impact on financial markets and financial stability.  It is therefore necessary to develop a gradual introduction mechanism aimed at mitigating the impact of the new impairment model, avoiding sudden repercussions on capital ratios and bank loans. It is also worrying that IFRS 9 provides accounting treatment for certain financial instruments held directly or indirectly, which could run counter to the overall objective of promoting long-term investments; it is therefore necessary to ensure that IFRS 9 is functional to the EU strategy. IFRS 9 must comply with the Capital Integrity Directive and the Accounting Directive.  The IASB will need to carry out a post-implementation review of IFRS 9 to identify and assess the side effects of this principle, in particular on long-term investments.

name: Steeve BRIOIS
text: In writing. The International Accounting Standards Board aims to develop a set of accounting standards applicable around the world, and thus to create a common language for global financial reporting. These standards are called the International Financial Reporting Standards. The Committee on Economics and Monetary Affairs is asking European and international financial regulators to produce studies on the impact of IFRS 9 standards on the banking, financial and insurance sectors. The report calls for a detailed study on the impact of capital threshold standards for long-term investment positions. I voted for this report.

name: Nicola CAPUTO
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted today in favour of the resolution on the IFRS 9 standard, which is one of the main responses of the International Accounting Standards Board (IASB), the body responsible for issuing international accounting standards, to the financial crisis. The IFRS 9 standard will make it possible to improve the problems arising from the way financial instruments are accounted for by the introduction of a new model for the classification and measurement of financial instruments, the adoption of a new criterion for assessing expected losses and the definition of new rules for the detection of hedging instruments. However, I think we need to better understand the impact of the IFRS 9 standard on the banking sector, the insurance sector and financial markets in general, but also on the financial sector as a whole. I therefore call on the IASB to strengthen its impact analysis capacity, particularly in the macroeconomic field.

name: David CASA
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this resolution as I believe that IFRS 9 – Financial Instruments constitutes one of the major responses of the IASB to the financial crisis. In order to be effective, I believe that the Commission, together with the European Supervisory Agencies, the ECB, the European Systemic Risk Board and the European Financial Reporting Advisory Group, should closely monitor the implementation of IFRS 9 in the EU, to prepare an ex—post impact assessment no later than June 2019 and to present this assessment to the European Parliament and act in accordance with its views. I also call on the IASB to conduct a post-implementation review of IFRS 9 in order to identify and assess unintended effects of the standard, in particular on long-term investment.

name: Lefteris CHRISTOFOROU
text: Writing. \u2012 We support the proposal as IFRS 9 "Financial Instruments" is one of the most important responses of the IASB to the financial crisis.

name: Kostas CHRYSOGONOS
text: Writing. \u2012 The motion for a resolution on International Financial Reporting Standards is a technical effort, but with very important implications both in the everyday life of European citizens and in areas directly relevant to the course of Europe. The revision and strengthening of specific structures will allow us, inter alia, to avoid crises such as the recent financial crisis of 2008. That is why I voted in favour.

name: Alberto CIRIO
text: in writing. \u2012 In my belief that accounting rules that are often too mearmish or unreas harmonised have contributed to the expansion of the global financial crisis, especially as regards the excessive use of fair value (as a reference value for the accounting of financial instruments), I am voting in favour of the motion so that more European international accounting standards can be achieved through which financial stability can be achieved.  Moreover, the G20 and the de Larosière report had already highlighted before the crisis some specific concerns about accounting standards, including: accounting for profits and losses, underestimating the accumulation of risks and lack of a common and transparent methodology for assessing unfulwarded assets. During the crisis, the delayed detection of losses on receivables and other financial assets was recognised as one of the main sources of weakness of the current principles.  On January 1, 2018, from IAS 39 to IFRS 9, therefore, the transition from a loss-based loss reduction model to one on expected loss as a method of recording credit losses will take place. However, a proper assessment of the implications is necessary, and I therefore call on the Commission and the other supervisory authorities to monitor implementation and prepare an ex-post impact assessment.

name: Deirdre CLUNE
text: in writing. ‒ I supported the motion for resolution on International Financial Reporting Standards and noted no objections.

name: Jane COLLINS
text: in writing. – This non-legislative resolution calls on the Commission to act, and in particular to ‘make sure that IFRS 9 serves the EU’s long-term investment strategy’. This would be putting the cart before the horse. Accordingly UKIP voted against.

name: Lara COMI
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the resolution because, given the general situation of economic uncertainty, the continuous change of markets and the need to use appropriate instruments to detect and evaluate new financial instruments, the Commission needs to assess the potential effects of IFRS 9 on long-term investments and European rules already enacted in this area, deepening better the impact of IFRS 9 in particular on the banking sector , on the insurance sector and on the financial markets in general.

name: Javier COUSO PERMUY
text: in writing. I consider, as the report says, that IFRS 9 is an important accounting step forward, moving from a 'loss incurred' model to an 'expected loss' model, that is, by forcing the financial system to immediately provision the risks incurred, rather than keeping them under the carpet until the bubble bursts. If I have abstained, it is because this motion is intended to postpone its entry into force and to dilute some of its proposals, in order to protect European finances above the general interest.

name: Andrea COZZOLINO
text: in writing. \u2012 The role of international financial reporting standards (IFRS), in relation to financial stability and economic growth, multiplied in the light of the global financial crisis, which highlighted the weaknesses and weaknesses of the system. That is why we welcomed the reform and the introduction of new rules limiting the risks to the future. The new accounting standards were drawn up, precisely following the financial crisis, in order to ensure greater transparency in the first place.  However, there are still a number of open questions on which it will be necessary for the Commission and the other financial authorities to take action to submit proposals, in particular on the insurance sector and the impact on long-term investments, ensuring a proper ex-ante impact assessment on the effects of the new rules.  The season of uncertainty of the rules, which has had so many negative consequences for small savers, is now behind us. It is now a question of going all the way to ensure that the system is properly transparencies and resilience.

name: Edward CZESAK
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 I voted in favour of the resolution on international financial reporting standards: IFRS 9, as this standard covers aspects related to the accounting of financial instruments such as classification and valuation, downgrading of financial assets and accounting for collateral.
