It is very important to ensure that the implementation of IFRS 9, the creation of which is aimed at preventing a crisis, which is undoubtedly crucial for ensuring economic stability, is monitored on a permanent basis. For these reasons, I voted in favour.

name: Miriam DALLI
text: in writing. ‒ Following the financial crises, the EU is working towards ensuring greater transparency. This resolution highlights the remaining open issues on which the Commission and the European Financial Reporting Advisory Group (EFRAG) should make proposals, notably regarding the insurance sector and the impact on long-term investment. I voted in favour of this resolution because I believe that new accounting standards and long-term investment are needed for financial stability in the EU. Through our vote, the Parliament will be asking the Commission to ensure proper impact assessment of the effect of the new rules laid down in this report.

name: Michel DANTIN
text: In writing. This resolution deals with the establishment of international financial reporting standards (IFRS 9). IFRS 9 defines the accounting treatment of financial instruments and covers a very large part of the balance sheet of banks. This resolution proposes the approval of the European Parliament for the adoption of the new IFRS 9 standards but underlines the remaining flaws in the transposition of these standards. Considering that this resolution is balanced, I voted in favour.

name: Rachida DATI
text: In writing. This resolution on international financial reporting standards IFRS 9 allows the European Parliament to express its concerns about the uncertainty about the impact of the entry into force of these new international accounting standards. There is a need to support the transition from the old IAS 39 standards, which were seen as responsible for the acceleration of the 2008 financial crisis to better standards. According to European auditors, including the European Commission's Financial Reporting Advisory Group (EFRAG), set up specifically to assess IFRS standards, IFRS 9 standards are the best standards we need to adopt. Without questioning the application of IFRS 9 standards from 1 January 2018 I supported this resolution which mainly calls on the Commission and EFRAG to carry out impact assessments of the entry into force of these new accounting standards, in order to be able to take the necessary measures to ensure a fair and effective transition as well as conducive to financial stability and growth.

name: Gérard DEPREZ
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this resolution, which aims to question the Commission on the international financial reporting standard IFRS 9 (financial instruments). Indeed, the three-month period available to the European Parliament for the monitoring of the Commission's draft enforcement measures on this standard expires on 7 October 2016. Parliament is asking itself several points: How does the Commission plan to take into account concerns about the potential negative effects of IFRS 9 on long-term investment? How does the Commission intend to address concerns about the delay between the effective date of IFRS 9 and the date of the new future standard on insurance contracts (IFRS 17)?  Does the Commission consider that the provisions published by the Council on International Accounting Standards are appropriate and satisfactory for the European Union? How does the Commission intend to counter the potentially negative effects of IFRS 9 on financial stability, in particular a potential decline in banks' capital? What is the Commission's view on the links of IFRS 9 to other types of financial regulation, such as prudential requirements?

name: Angel DZHAMBAZKI
text: in writing. ‒ I have supported the resolution despite the fact that I disagreed with some of the proposed additions. The motion for resolution and OQ are designed to ensure continued monitoring of the implementation and implications of IFRS 9 which will come into force in January 2018. I support the continued scrutiny of IFRS 9 and its implementation and therefore I have supported the resolution.

name: Georgios EPITIDEIOS
text: Writing. \u2012 International Financial Reporting Standards as part of EU law must impose a level playing field on a single market that is structured for the benefit of the strong economies of the EU Member States and does not allow the development of the corresponding weak.

name: José Manuel FERNANDES
text: in writing. The global financial crisis has put the role played by international financial reporting standards (IFRS) on the G20 and EU agenda in financial stability and growth, in particular the rules on the recognition of losses in the banking system. The issue of IFRS 9 – Financial instruments has emerged as a key response to some aspects of the financial crisis and its impact on the banking sector. This financial instrument moves from an impairment model based on "losses incurred" to a model based on "estimated losses" responding to the problem "too little, too late" in the process of recognition of losses from lending. However, the European Supervisory Authorities, in cooperation with the Commission and EFRAG, should set guidelines on the matter in order to avoid any abuse of the discretionary margin of management.

name: Edouard FERRAND
text: In writing. Vote for: this is essentially a technical proposal that follows the very small feedback that the European Parliament receives from regulators and the European Commission on requests for IFRS9 impact assessments.

name: João FERREIRA
text: in writing. \u2012 In 2014, the Council for International Accounting Standards adopted IFRS 9 as an international accounting standard for financial instruments. IFRS 9 replaces the existing IAS 39 standard. IFRS 9 represents a major change in the process of measuring impairment losses of institutions and emerges as a response of the Council of International Accounting Standards to the late recognition of losses in the ias 39 loss model. IFRS 9 is based on a foresight view through an expected loss model, which makes institutions able to recognize losses before they occur.  The change of approach forces financial institutions to model future market trends, which will require an important set of macroeconomic data that historically have not been required for accounting purposes. Although it contains some concerns, the resolution does not call into question the process of setting the standard. In addition, the new IFRS 9 standard has not been fully effective in solving the pro-cyclicality problem, and may even have some negative implications, especially for smaller financial institutions (e.g. cooperative banks), which use the standard method to assess credit risks.

name: Monika BEŇOVÁ
text: Writing. \u2012 The resolution in question is part of the European Parliament's consent to the support and approval of international financial reporting standards – IFR9, which will enter into force on 1 January 2018. These measures were taken after the financial and economic crisis to ensure greater transparency for the new accounting standards. The new accounting standards should ensure long-term investment and financial stability. The European Commission must ensure a proper assessment of the impact and effect of the new rules on these two areas. The European Parliament must support a profound reform of the process of preparing and approving accounting standards in order to ensure transparency and accountability.

name: Lampros FOUNTOULIS
text: Writing. \u2012 I am voting in favour of this motion for a resolution because the International Financial Reporting Standards, as part of EU law, must impose a level playing field on a single market which is structured for the benefit of the strong economies of the EU Member States and does not allow the development of the weak.

name: Francisco de Paula GAMBUS MILLET
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the motion for a resolution, considering that the global financial crisis put on the table the importance for financial stability and growth of international financial reporting standards, in particular those relating to the recognition of losses in the banking system. The Commission, together with the European Supervisory Authorities, the ECB, esRB and EFRAG, must therefore closely monitor the implementation of IFRS 9 in the Union, as well as prepare an ex post impact assessment, which must be presented to the European Parliament in order for it to participate in its control and decisions.

name: Iratxe GARCÍA PÉREZ
text: in writing. I supported the decision to give no objection to updating international standards for financial reporting (IFRS 9) in order to increase transparency in the after-financial crisis. I also agree that the Commission should be asked to take steps to apply standards to the long-term investment insurance sector.

name: Eider GARDIAZABAL RUBIAL
text: in writing. I supported the decision not to object to the updating of international standards for financial reporting (IFRS 9), with the aim of increasing transparency in the after-financial crisis. I also agree that the Commission should be asked to take steps to apply standards to the long-term investment insurance sector.

name: Elena GENTILE
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the EP resolution on international financial reporting standards IFRS 9 because I strongly supported the call from the ECON Committee for greater transparency in the implementation of international accounting standards because of their importance with regard to financial stability and growth and specifically with regard to the rules on the detection of losses incurred in the banking system.  Ifrs 9, which is due to enter into force on 1 January 2018, has as its fundamental objective to ensure greater transparency in relation to credit risk, opting for an asset depreciation approach that should be more responsive to developments in the credit cycle. In other words, it is the main response of the International Accounting Standardisation Body (IASB) to specific aspects of the financial crisis and its impact in the banking system, reducing the level of complexity that the previous accounting standard, IAS 39, presented. There is currently a lack of an impact assessment and there is considerable concern about the potential effects of applying these investment rules as it could lead to some volatility. Long-term investment must be regarded as a 'public good', due to its positive effects on growth.

name: Nathan GILL
text: in writing. ‒ This non-legislative resolution calls on the Commission to act, and in particular to ‘make sure that IFRS 9 serves the EU’s long-term investment strategy’. This would be putting the cart before the horse. Accordingly I voted against it.

name: Tania GONZÁLEZ PEÑAS
text: in writing. I voted abstention in this report, although it contains a number of positive elements that I have supported. However, it does not call into question the process of establishing rules as such, which has a number of flaws, especially in relation to democratic control and supervision. In addition, the new IFRS 9 standard has not fully solved problems related to the procyclical nature and could have some negative consequences, especially for smaller financial institutions (e.g. cooperative banks) that use the standard method for access to credit risks. While the report raises some of these concerns, I fundamentally question the adequacy of the new standard, as well as the process with which it has been drafted.

name: Theresa GRIFFIN
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this motion, as I support reform of the process of elaboration and endorsement of accounting standards to ensure transparency and accountability.

name: Sergio GUTIÉRREZ PRIETO
text: in writing. I supported the decision not to object to the updating of international standards for financial reporting (IFRS 9), with the aim of increasing transparency in the after-financial crisis. I also agree that the Commission should be asked to take steps to apply standards to the long-term investment insurance sector.

name: Marian HARKIN
text: in writing. ‒ IFRS 9 is a financial instrument that constitutes one of the major responses of the IASB to the financial crisis. I voted in favour of this resolution, which calls on the Commission, together with the European Supervisory Agencies (ESAs), the ECB, the European Systemic Risk Board (ESRB) and EFRAG, closely to monitor the implementation of IFRS 9 in the EU and to prepare an ex-post impact assessment. This assessment is to be produced no later than June 2019 and presented to the European Parliament for action in accordance with our views.

name: Cătălin Sorin IVAN
text: in writing. ‒ I fully support reform of accounting standards in the interests of better accountability and transparency. The new standards should promote financial stability, sustainable growth, and long-term investment.

name: Ivan JAKOVČIĆ
text: Written. \u2012 I voted for the IFRS 9 International Financial Reporting Standards Report (2016/2898(RSP)) as IFRS 9 represents one of the main responses of the IASB (International Accounting Standards Board) to the financial crisis, where efforts to apply it are already under way. Definitely IFRS 9 is a significant improvement compared to previous standards, especially in terms of predicting possible lending losses.  However, a better assessment of the potential impacts of IFRS 9 on the banking sector and other financial services should be carried out. There is also the problem of the possible negative impact of IFRS 9 on certain financial instruments and directly or indirectly on long-term investments. The issue of non-compliance between IFRS 9 and the forthcoming insurance standard (IFRS 17) is also essential. Furthermore, the interaction of this standard with other regulatory requirements, and the impact on financial stability and the level of equity of banks, is not entirely clear.

name: Jean-François JALKH
text: In writing. This proposal has the merit of making a mainly technical contribution to the harmonization of financial information standards, and especially their impact in the sectors concerned. There is a need to bring consistency to the financial practices of companies making use of these new standards, particularly on the subject of "fair value", and to avoid as much as possible any lag in the replacement process. I voted for it.

name: Diane JAMES
text: in writing. – This non-legislative resolution calls on the Commission to act, and in particular to ‘make sure that IFRS 9 serves the EU’s long-term investment strategy’. This would be putting the cart before the horse. Accordingly UKIP voted against it.

name: Marc JOULAUD
text: In writing. I voted in favour of my colleague Roberto Gualtieri's report on the replacement of the current accounting standard, IAS 39, with IFRS 9. The objective of this change in standards is to take a new approach to assessing bank accounting rules. In practical terms, this will lead financial institutions and businesses to take more account of the economic reality and the obligation to provide the fairest financial information possible.  This report was adopted by a large majority, which I welcome.

name: Philippe JUVIN
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this resolution both to welcome the objective of creating this standard in response to the financial crisis and its impact on the banking sector and to call on the Commission to closely monitor its deployment in the Union.

name: Barbara KAPPEL
text: Writing. The objections to the new accounting standards raised in the resolution are entirely justified and could pose problems as to what funds could be used for bank resolution. I am therefore voting in favour of the motion for a resolution.

name: Afzal KHAN
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report, as I support a reform of the process of elaboration and endorsement of Accounting standards to ensure transparency and accountability.

name: Stelios KOULOGLOU
text: in writing. ‒ In July 2014, the International Accounting Standards Board adopted a new accounting standard for financial instruments, which replaces the existing standard. The resolution aims to address the main concerns prior to its adoption by the Commission. The resolution entails several good elements that GUE/NGL supports. I therefore voted in favour of it.

name: Gilles LEBRETON
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this technical resolution because it mainly calls on international financial and banking regulators to provide impact studies of IFRS9 accounting standards (for financial products) on the banking, financial and insurance sectors.

name: Philippe LOISEAU
text: In writing. The draft resolution drafted by the ECON Committee calls on European and international financial regulators to produce studies on the impact of IFRS 9 standards on the banking, financial and insurance sectors. Specifically, a study is requested on the impact on banks' capital requirements and on long-term investment positions. Finally, the proposal highlights concerns about the lag in the effective dates of IFRS 9 and the new accounting standards for insurance products, IFRS 17. This could lead to serious inconsistencies for companies that use both types of products. It is therefore essentially a technical proposal which follows the very small feedback that the European Parliament receives from the regulatory bodies and the European Commission on the requests for impact assessments of IFRS9. So I supported that proposal.

name: Javi LÓPEZ
text: in writing. I supported the decision not to object to the updating of international standards for financial reporting (IFRS 9), with the aim of increasing transparency in the after-financial crisis. I also agree that the Commission should be asked to take steps to apply standards to the long-term investment insurance sector.

name: Petr MACH
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted against. I do not agree with the attempt to make accounting standards subject to EU objectives ("EP calls on the Commission to ensure that IFRS 9 serve a long-term EU investment strategy"). Accounting standards are supposed to be business neutral, and trying to make them subject to EU investment plans could lead to overly risky business behaviour.

name: Andrejs MAMIKINS
text: in writing. ‒  The global financial crisis brought to light the role played by international financial reporting standards (IFRS) in financial stability and growth, in particular the rules regarding the recognition of losses incurred in the banking system. We need further progress in this field.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: Writing. \u2012 I am voting against the motion for a resolution on International Financial Reporting Standards: IFRS 9 for the reasons I mentioned in detail in my speech to the plenary of the European Parliament in Strasbourg on 4/10/2016, and because I believe that this motion for a resolution is not complete and substantiated.

name: Dominique MARTIN
text: In writing. I voted for this text. It follows the development of a set of accounting standards applicable around the world, the International Financial Reporting Standards (IFRS). The standard referred to, IFRS 9, applies to financial instruments and changes the concept of "fair value." The voted text calls on European and international financial regulators to produce studies on the impact of IFRS 9 standards on the banking, financial and insurance sectors, which we agree with. In the same vein, it denounces the lag in the effective dates of IFRS 9 and IFRS 17 (on insurance products). This discrepancy could indeed create serious inconsistencies.

name: Georg MAYER
text: Writing. I take a positive view of the impact of IFRS 9 on the banking, insurance and financial markets in general, but also on the financial sector as a whole.

name: Valentinas MAZURONIS
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the European Parliament resolution on International Financial Reporting Standard (IFRS) 9 of the International Accounting Standards Board. This standard is important because it helps to shape national accounting systems so that they are understood in different countries.  Parliament's resolution discusses the impact of these standards on EU banks and aims to provide for measures to ensure financial stability and economic growth.

name: Jean-Luc MÉLENCHON
text: In writing. In July 2014, the International Accounting Standards Board (IASB) published the final version of the International Financial Reporting Standards (IFRS) 9 - Financial Instruments. IFRS standards are international financial reporting standards designed to standardize the presentation of internationally traded accounting data. This is intended to enable investors to determine a company's financial situation. This new standard replaces the standard "IAS 39 - Financial Instruments: Accounting and Valuation" in order to avoid further financial crises, such as the one in 2008. The report criticizes the complexity of this new standard and the lag between the effective date of IFRS 9 and the future standard on insurance contracts (IFRS 17). I, for one, fear that these new financial standards, dominated by the Anglo-Saxon accounting model and established without democratic control, will not change the harmful financialisation of the economy. To think that crises depend on an accounting standard is the height of ridicule. However, I abstain on this text in order to interfere with some additional information requirements that will now be imposed on the banks.

name: Joëlle MÉLIN
text: In writing. The draft resolution drafted by the ECON Committee calls on European and international financial regulators to produce studies on the impact of IFRS 9 standards on the banking, financial and insurance sectors. Specifically, a study is requested on the impact on banks' capital requirements and on long-term investment positions. Finally, the proposal highlights concerns about the lag in the effective dates of IFRS 9 and the new accounting standards for insurance products, IFRS 17. This could lead to serious inconsistencies for companies that use both types of products. It is therefore essentially a technical proposal which follows the very small feedback that the European Parliament receives from the regulatory bodies and the European Commission on the requests for impact assessments of IFRS9. I therefore voted in favour of this proposal.

name: Nuno MELO
text: in writing. \u2012 IFRS 9 will enter into force on January 1, 2018 and replace IAS 39. IFRS 9 is an improvement over IAS 39, as the transition from an impairment model based on "losses incurred" to a model based on "estimated losses" is a response to the problem in the process of recognition of losses from lending. This standard will be very important to prevent future crises in the financial sector. Hence my vote in favour.

name: Roberta METSOLA
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this resolution as it stresses the importance of long-term investment for economic growth. It also calls on the Commission to ensure that IFRS 9 measures do not limit the Union’s long-term investment goals, whilst also continuing to discourage excessive risk taking.

name: Marlene MIZZI
text: in writing. ‒ I have voted in favour of the report, which promotes accounting standards that ensure financial stability, sustainable growth, and long-term investment. I also support a deep reform of the process of elaboration and endorsement of Accounting standards to ensure transparency and accountability.

name: Csaba MOLNÁR
text: Writing. \u2012 The European Commission intends to adopt a Regulation amending Regulation (EC) No 1126/2008 adopting certain international accounting standards with regard to IFRS 9 international financial reporting standard. On 26 September 2016, Representative Roberto Gualtieri, on behalf of the Committee on Economic and Monetary Affairs, submitted to the Commission a question requiring an oral reply on the possible negative effects of IFRS 9 on long-term investments and financial stability. The draft resolution of the Committee on Economic and Monetary Affairs points out that, partly due to a lack of reliable data, there is insufficient impact assessment for IFRS 9, and therefore calls for a better understanding of the impact of IFRS 9 on the banking sector, the insurance sector and financial markets in general, as well as on the financial sector as a whole. It is also concerned that the accounting treatment under IFRS 9 of certain financial instruments held directly or indirectly as long-term investments may be contrary to the objective of promoting long-term investments. For this reason, it considers it necessary to carry out further examinations, analyses and ex-post evaluations. I voted in favour of the draft resolution.

name: Cláudia MONTEIRO DE AGUIAR
text: in writing. \u2012 IFRS 9 was issued by the International Accounting Standards Council as a key response to some aspects of the financial crisis and its impact on the banking sector. I advocate an ex post review of IFRS 9 in order to identify and assess the unforeseen effects of the standard, in particular on long-term investment. As well as attentive supervision of the implementation of IFRS 9 in the EU. I support the need to better understand the impact of IFRS 9 on the banking sector, the insurance sector and financial markets in general, but also in the financial sector as a whole.

name: Sophie MONTEL
text: In writing. This is essentially a technical proposal that follows the very small feedback that the European Parliament receives from regulators and the European Commission on requests for IFRS9 impact assessments. I'm voting for.

name: Nadine MORANO
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this resolution on the European transposition of IFRS 9, which is an international standard for financial reporting. This new standard will replace the current standard, IAS 39. It will be used to define the accounting treatment of financial instruments and will therefore cover a large part of the balance sheet of banks that will have to review the way all their financial assets are classified and assessed, and their information systems will evolve.

name: Victor NEGRESCU
text: in writing. ‒ The International Accounting Standards Board (IASB) was set up on 1 April 2001 and is responsible for developing International Financial Reporting Standards (IFRS). IFRS 9, promulgated by the IASB, addresses three main topics: classification and measurement of financial instruments, impairments of financial assets and hedge accounting. I voted against this motion for a resolution regarding the IFRS 9.

name: Luděk NIEDERMAYER
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported the resolution because IFRS 9 represents an improvement by abandoning the loss-based model and adopting a impairment model based on expected losses that addresses the problem of late adoption of overly weak measures under the credit loss recognition procedure. On the other hand, I note that no appropriate quantitative impact assessment has been carried out for IFRS 9, which is partly due to the absence of reliable data. However, in order to assess the impact of IFRS 9 on the banking and insurance sectors, on financial markets in general and on the financial sector as a whole, it is necessary for the competent institutions to strengthen their capacity to carry out impact analyses, in particular in the macroeconomic field.

name: Franz OBERMAYR
text: Writing. Although this report contains very good approaches, there are some areas on which I cannot agree. An example of this would be my doubts about private experts.

name: Urmas PAET
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported. IFRS help stabilise markets, make them more transparent and strengthen supervision, ensure investment protection and legal certainty.

name: Demetris PAPADAKIS
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the resolution on International Financial Reporting Standards, since IFRS 9 "Financial Instruments" is one of the most important responses of the International Accounting Standards Board (IASB) to the financial crisis and implementation efforts are already being made. In addition, IFRS 9 is an improved standard compared to IAS 39. This resolution refers significantly to the Commission in order to ensure that IFRS 9 serves the EU's long-term investment strategy and limits pro-circularity and incentives to take excessive risks. It is also important that the Commission, in cooperation with the European supervisory authorities, the ECB, the European Systemic Risk Board and EFRAG, monitor the implementation of IFRS 9 in the EU in order to draw up an ex post impact assessment, which is very important for the smooth implementation of IFRS 9.

name: Margot PARKER
text: in writing. – This non-legislative resolution calls on the Commission to act, and in particular to ‘make sure that IFRS 9 serves the EU’s long-term investment strategy’. This would be putting the cart before the horse. Accordingly UKIP voted against it.

name: Alojz PETERLE
text: in writing. ‒ If we would like to achieve a more industrialised Europe, with high potential for generating jobs and growth, it is essential to support that aim with a properly functioning and efficient capital market. Standardising companies’ financial reporting is one more building block towards that goal.

name: Marijana PETIR
text: Written. ‒International Accounting Standards (IFRS) are one of the key components needed for the efficient functioning of the internal market and capital markets.  Their use must not jeopardise financial stability and should serve the common good, not just the interests of investors, lenders and creditors. The importance and comprehensiveness of these standards requires maximum preparation, which will not only focus on the desired consequences of their application, but will also pay necessary attention to assessments of other possible impacts on various aspects of the financial system. In this process, crucial cooperation between the European Commission and other bodies dealing with these standards, which have already introduced us to estimates of possible negative impacts of IFRS 9, as may be the one on long-term investments. I consider that the level of involvement of the European Parliament in the standard setting process is insufficient and I support this resolution which formally raises concerns about certain shortcomings of ifRS 9 International Accounting Standards.

name: João PIMENTA LOPES
text: in writing. \u2012 In 2014, the Council for International Accounting Standards adopted IFRS 9 as an international accounting standard for financial instruments. IFRS 9 replaces the existing IAS 39 standard. IFRS 9 represents a major change in the process of measuring impairment losses of institutions and emerges as a response of the Council of International Accounting Standards to the late recognition of losses in the ias 39 loss model. IFRS 9 is based on a foresight view through an expected loss model, which makes institutions able to recognize losses before they occur. The change of approach forces financial institutions to model future market trends, which will require an important set of macroeconomic data that historically have not been required for accounting purposes. Although it contains some concerns, the resolution does not call into question the process of setting the standard. In addition, the new IFRS 9 standard has not been fully effective in solving the pro-cyclicality problem, and may even have some negative implications, especially for smaller financial institutions (e.g. cooperative banks), which use the standard method to assess credit risks.

name: Franck PROUST
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this technical resolution, which follows the publication in July 2014 by the International Accounting Standards Institution of a new standard to simplify the accounting of financial instruments.

name: Julia REID
text: in writing. – This non-legislative resolution calls on the Commission to act, and in particular to ‘make sure that IFRS 9 serves the EU’s long-term investment strategy’. This would be putting the cart before the horse. Accordingly UKIP voted against it.

name: Sofia RIBEIRO
text: in writing. The global financial crisis has put the role played by international financial reporting standards (IFRS) on the G20 and EU agenda in financial stability and growth, in particular the rules on the recognition of losses in the banking system. I voted in favour, considering that IFRS 9 is an improvement over IAS 39, since the transition from an impairment model based on 'losses incurred' to a model based on 'estimated losses' is a response to the problem "too little, too late" in the process of recognition of losses from lending. However, IFRS 9 requires a considerable level of discernment in the accounting process and there are considerable differences of opinion and few concrete guidance from the auditors in this regard. In this way, the European Supervisory Authorities, in cooperation with the Commission and EFRAG, should set guidelines on this matter in order to avoid any abuse of the discretionary margin of management.

name: Inma RODRÍGUEZ-PIÑERO
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the motion for a Resolution on International Financial Reporting Standards asking the Commission an oral question relating to not raising objections to updating international standards for financial reporting, in order to increase transparency after the financial crisis. In addition, the Commission is requested to take appropriate action with respect to the long-term investment insurance sector for standards to be applied.

name: Claude ROLIN
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the European Parliament's motion for a resolution on international financial reporting standards IFRS 9. IFRS 9 is a standard on financial instruments that will come into effect on January 1, 2018 and replace IAS 39. However, it has not been the subject of a quantitative impact analysis. That is why this motion for a resolution calls on the Commission and the European supervisory authorities (ECB, CERS, EFRAG) to closely monitor the roll-out of this standard and submit an assessment to the European Parliament for June 2019.

name: Bronis ROPĖ
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the resolution "International Financial Reporting Standards: IFRS 9". As a result of the global financial crisis, the importance of international financial reporting standards for financial stability and economic growth has been on the G20 and EU agendas. The new standard developed (IFRS 9) will enter into force on 1 January 2018 and will replace International Accounting Standard (IAS) 39. The new standard is much more advanced as it moves from a value reduction model based on a 'loss incurred' based on 'expected loss'. This solves the problem where the actions taken too little and too late in the procedure for the recognition of loan losses. In its resolution, Parliament calls on the Commission, together with the European Supervisory Authorities, to closely monitor the eu's implementation of IFRS 9 and, by June 2019, to monitor the implementation of IFRS 9. to prepare an impact assessment and submit this assessment to the European Parliament.

name: Fernando RUAS
text: in writing. \u2012 International financial reporting standards have played a key role since the beginning of the global financial crisis, as a guarantee of financial stability and growth, especially when we talk about the standards alusive to the recognition of losses in the banking system. The Council for International Accounting Standards issued IFRS 9 - Financial instruments as a key response to some aspects of the crisis and its impact on the banking sector - which will replace IAS 39 from 1 January 2018.  This is an equally complex standard, but which is already improving over IAS 39, adopting a model based on "estimated losses", as opposed to "losses incurred" and which will lack an impact assessment on the banking, insurance and financial markets in general in macroeconomic terms.  Overall I agree with the measures suggested in this motion for a resolution, with the aim of identifying and assessing the effects and implications of the implementation of this IFRS 9 standard in the EU, in particular with regard to long-term investment, and I therefore voted in favour.

name: Tokia SAÏFI
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this resolution on IFRS 9, which defines the accounting treatment of financial instruments. These international financial reporting standards have a direct impact on European banking institutions.  Implementation of the new model will likely require a review of the process of organising, collecting information and feeding systems for many European banking institutions. In this sense, the resolution reiterates the need to better understand and study the effects of this standard on the financial sector as a whole, and calls on the Commission and the ECB, in particular, to develop an assessment of the impact of the implementation of this standard before the end of 2019.  I have supported this report which urges the Commission to ensure that this international standard is at the service of long-term investment in the Union.

name: Lola SÁNCHEZ CALDENTEY
text: in writing. I voted abstention in this report, although it contains a number of positive elements that I have supported. However, it does not call into question the process of establishing rules as such, which has a number of flaws, especially in relation to democratic control and supervision. In addition, the new IFRS 9 standard has not fully solved problems related to the procyclical nature and could have some negative consequences, especially for smaller financial institutions (e.g. cooperative banks) that use the standard method for access to credit risks. While the report raises some of these concerns, I fundamentally question the adequacy of the new standard, as well as the process with which it has been drafted.

name: Maria Lidia SENRA RODRÍGUEZ
text: in writing. I consider, as the report says, that IFRS 9 is an important accounting step forward, moving from a 'loss incurred' model to an 'expected loss' model, that is, by forcing the financial system to immediately provision the risks incurred, rather than keeping them under the carpet until the bubble bursts. If I have abstained, it is because this motion is intended to postpone its entry into force and to dilute some of its proposals, in order to protect European finances above the general interest.

name: Siôn SIMON
text: in writing. ‒ Today I voted for the motion on the European Parliament resolution on International Financial Reporting Standards: IFRS 9. It stresses the need to gain a better understanding of the impact of IFRS 9 not only on the insurance sector, the banking sector and the financial markets in general, but also on the financial sector as a whole.

name: Igor ŠOLTES
text: Writing. The International Accounting Standards Board has issued International Financial Reporting Standards 9 relating to financial instruments. In doing so, it has responded to certain aspects of the financial crisis and its impact on the banking sector. These standards will replace the elderly and come into force on 1 January 2018. Parliament assessed these accounting standards as an important response by the International Accounting Standards Council to the crisis, while at the same time assessing that these bring improvements, particularly in the case of impairment models. The resolution also calls on the European Commission, in cooperation with the ESAs, to closely monitor the implementation of the new standards in the EU and to prepare an ex-post impact assessment by June 2019 at the latest and to submit it to the European Parliament. A similar call is also made to the International Accounting Standards Council, which should carry out a review after the standards have been implemented in order to identify and assess adverse reactions. I believe that the re-establishment of financial reporting standards is an important measure in the fight against financial crises, which is why I voted in favour of the resolution.

name: Ivan ŠTEFANEC
text: Writing. \u2012 Tax evasion and other financial crimes are currently taking place through complex and sophisticated schemes involving the manipulation of financial statements. International cooperation in the field of compilation of reporting procedures and standards is also the basis for the successful fight against fraud of this nature.

name: Dubravka ŠUICA
text: Written. The International Accounting Standards Board has prescribed the IFRS 9 financial instrument as the main response to certain aspects of the financial crisis and the impact thereof on the banking sector. The Economic and Monetary Policy Committee analysed the IFRS 9 financial instrument in detail and concluded that it contains important responses from the International Accounting Standards Board to the financial crisis and notes that work on application is already under way. IFRS 9 is an improved version of IAS 39.  I support the proposal for a resolution from the Economic and Monetary Policy Committee.

name: Neoklis SYLIKIOTIS
text: Writing. \u2012 The resolution actually expresses Parliament's support for the G20 decisions and stresses that the anti-circular measures proposed are in the right direction. There are some concerns about the complexity of the new standards, but reference is made to a "direct response to the crisis". It is considered that accounting standards played a role in the profitability of banks and investment groups before the crisis. Nevertheless, not only does it not call for an immediate reorganisation of banking operating standards or for the regulation of the work of investment groups, but it also goes into the logic of 'impact assessment'. This is a very general resolution on a very technocratic issue. The real cause of the crisis-bank/investment group relationship, which is the absolute freedom given to these institutes to profit, is not addressed. That's why we chose abstinence.

name: Eleftherios SYNADINOS
text: Writing. \u2012 International Financial Reporting Standards as part of EU law must impose a level playing field on a single market that is structured for the benefit of the strong economies of the EU Member States and does not allow the development of the corresponding weak.

name: Tibor SZANYI
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of your draft motion for a resolution on international financial reporting standards. The new IFRS 9 standards aim to improve financial statements on financial instruments by eliminating problems that emerged during the crisis. The draft motion rightly draws attention to the fact that a commitment to better regulation makes it necessary to carry out an impact assessment. I also agree with the finding that a better look should be given to the practical impact of IFRS 9 international financial reporting standards on the banking and insurance sectors and on the financial sector as a whole in general. Overall, the new standards, as highlighted in the draft motion, should serve the EU's long-term objectives.

name: Claudia ȚAPARDEL
text: in writing. ‒ The global financial crisis brought the role played by international financial reporting standards onto the G20 and EU agendas. It has already been decided that starting with the 1st of January 2018, a new financial instrument, IFRS 9 will replace IAS 39. I agree that IFRS 9 is an improvement to IAS 39 insofar as the move from an ‘incurred loss’ to an ‘expected loss’ impairment model addresses the problem of ‘too little, too late’ in the loan loss recognition procedure. However, on the matter of the banking sector, especially the accounting process, IFRS 9 is highly debatable and there is a lack of consensus in the opinion of experts. Therefore, I support this report, as I believe that the IASB and the EFRAG should strengthen their impact analysis capacity in order to get a better understanding of the IFRS 9 in certain areas, notably in the field of macroeconomics.

name: Marc TARABELLA
text: In writing. In this text, Parliament recognises that IFRS 9 improves the IAS 39 standard in that the evolution of a "loss-making" model towards a "expected loss" depreciation model solves the problem of inadequacy and inefficiency in the loan loss accounting process. We note, however, that IFRS 9 is very subjectivity in this process and note that in this regard, auditors have profound differences of opinion and provide little concrete guidance. We therefore call on the European supervisory authorities to develop such guidelines, in cooperation with the Commission and EFRAG, in order to prevent any abuse of the discretion of management entities.

name: Pavel TELIČKA
text: in writing. ‒ International Financial Reporting Standards (IFRS) reform came about as a result of the global financial crisis: the aim is to boost stability and growth, in particular through the rules regarding the recognition of losses incurred in the banking system, and placing these issues on the G20 and EU agendas. I voted in favour of the resolution because I believe in the importance of long-term investment for economic growth and I believe IFRS 9 serves the EU’s long-term investment strategy and reduces pro-cyclicality as well as lessening incentives for excessive risk taking.

name: Ruža TOMAŠIĆ
text: Written. ‒ The application of the International Financial Reporting Standards (IFRS) in the European Union has contributed to strengthening the single market and has strengthened the competitiveness of the European economy by attracting capital and investment on global capital markets. However, the financial crisis in the Member States of the European Union has highlighted the need to review and improve financial reporting standards. That is why I support a resolution to ensure the continuation of the monitoring and monitoring of the implementation of MFSI 9, which will take effect in January 2018. Its entry into force replaces International Accounting Standard 39, which prescribes the measurement of financial assets and financial liabilities. I believe that the application of the paragraphs in the proposed resolution will be an effective response to the financial crisis and the alleged role of accounting standards in causing the crisis.

name: Romana TOMC
text: Writing. \ u2012 Motion for a European Parliament resolution on international financial reporting standards: I supported IFRS 9. IFRS 9 Financial Instruments is one of the major responses of the IASB (International Accounting Standards Board) to the financial crisis. IFRS 9 brings improvements compared to IAS 39, as the loss-based impairment model is turned into an impairment model based on expected losses, thus addressing the problem of "too little and too late" in the loan loss recognition process. IFRS 9 will enter into force on 1 January 2018 and will replace IAS 39.

name: Estefanía TORRES MARTÍNEZ
text: in writing. I voted abstention in this report, although it contains a number of positive elements that I have supported. However, it does not call into question the process of establishing rules as such, which has a number of flaws, especially in relation to democratic control and supervision. In addition, the new IFRS 9 standard has not fully solved problems related to the procyclical nature and could have some negative consequences, especially for smaller financial institutions (e.g. cooperative banks) that use the standard method for access to credit risks. While the report raises some of these concerns, I fundamentally question the adequacy of the new standard, as well as the process with which it has been drafted.

name: Mylène TROSZCZYNSKI
text: In writing. The International Accounting Standards Board (IASB) aims to develop a set of accounting standards applicable around the world, and thus to create a common language for global financial reporting. Since 2005, the IAS Regulation has required publicly traded EU companies to prepare their consolidated financial statements in accordance with these standards. IFRS 9 applies to financial instruments and must address the difficulties associated with IAS 39, which is the current standard. The big change comes mainly from the notion of "fair value", which allows the assets and liabilities of large companies to be valued according to their market value or, failing that, according to their value calculated by the present sum of the expected revenue streams from their use. This accounting standard is at odds with the "historical cost valuation" standard, which values assets and liabilities on their market date. But this "fair value" has also been accused of having a great deal of responsibility in the 2007 crisis, because of its very powerful pro-cyclical impact on the banking and financial system. I voted for this essentially technical proposal.

name: Kazimierz Michał UJAZDOWSKI
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 Non-compliance with basic accounting standards should be considered one of the many causes that have caused the multi-year financial crisis in Europe. Economic stagnation underlined the need to prepare new international financial reporting standards. The new standards address key accounting elements, including those relating to asset and collateral downgrades. The legislation will enter into force in January 2018. The motion for a resolution will monitor the implementation and impact of these standards. It is to be hoped that the new International Financial Reporting Standards (IFRS 9) will help prevent new economic crises. I voted in favour of the resolution.

name: Miguel URBÁN CRESPO
text: in writing. I voted abstention in this report, although it contains a number of positive elements that I have supported. However, it does not call into question the process of establishing rules as such, which has a number of flaws, especially in relation to democratic control and supervision. In addition, the new IFRS 9 standard has not fully solved problems related to the procyclical nature and could have some negative consequences, especially for smaller financial institutions (e.g. cooperative banks) that use the standard method for access to credit risks. While the report raises some of these concerns, I fundamentally question the adequacy of the new standard, as well as the process with which it has been drafted.

name: Viktor USPASKICH
text: Writing. – I stress the importance of long-term investment in economic growth. I am concerned that accounting for certain financial instruments held directly or indirectly as long-term investments (in particular equity) in accordance with IFRS 9 could undermine the overall objective of promoting long-term investments.

name: Ivo VAJGL
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the motion for a resolution on International Financial Reporting Standards: IFRS 9. The global financial crisis brought the role played by international financial reporting standards (IFRS) in financial stability and growth onto the G20 and EU agendas. The resolution notes that IFRS 9 – Financial Instruments constitutes one of the major responses of the International Accounting Standards Board to the financial crisis. Moreover, the resolution notes the importance of fully understanding the interaction of IFRS 9 with other regulatory requirements. I voted in favour because I believe that the principle of prudence must be the key guiding principle for any accounting standard.

name: Ramón Luis VALCÁRCEL SISO
text: in writing. The global financial crisis placed on the G20 and Union table the importance for financial stability and growth of international financial reporting standards (IFRS), in particular those relating to the recognition of losses in the banking system. In key response to some aspects of the financial crisis and its impact on the banking sector, the International Accounting Standards Council (ICC) adopted IFRS 9 – Financial Instruments. Whereas the principle of prudence should be the fundamental guiding principle of all accounting rules and that IFRS 9 – Financial Instruments is one of the IASC's main responses to the financial crisis, this document recognises that IFRS 9 is an improvement over IAS 39 and notes the importance of fully understanding the interaction between IFRS 9 and other regulatory requirements. It also calls on the Commission to propose appropriate measures in the prudential framework before the end of 2017 and to ensure that IFRS 9 favours the Union's long-term investment strategy. That is why I considered it appropriate to vote in favour of the text.

name: Ángela VALLINA
text: in writing. I consider, as the report says, that IFRS 9 is an important accounting step forward, moving from a 'loss incurred' model to an 'expected loss' model, that is, by forcing the financial system to immediately provision the risks incurred, rather than keeping them under the carpet until the bubble bursts. If I have abstained, it is because this motion is intended to postpone its entry into force and to dilute some of its proposals, in order to protect European finances above the general interest.

name: Miguel VIEGAS
text: in writing. \u2012 In July 2014, the Council for International Accounting Standards adopted IFRS 9 as an international accounting standard for financial instruments. IFRS 9 replaces the existing IAS 39 standard.  IFRS 9 represents a major change in the process of measuring impairment losses of institutions and emerges as a response from the Council of International Accounting Standards on the late recognition of losses in the ias 39 loss model. IFRS 9 is based on a foresight view through an expected loss model, which makes institutions able to recognize losses before they occur. This change comes because the subsequent recognition of credit losses was identified during the financial crisis as a weakness in financial institutions, mainly due to the fact that the current impairment requirements are based on models of loss incarled.  Although it contains some concerns, the resolution does not call into question the process of setting the standard. In addition, the new IFRS 9 standard has not been fully effective in solving the pro-cyclicality problem, and may even have some negative implications, especially for smaller financial institutions (e.g. cooperative banks), which use the standard method to assess credit risks.

name: Harald VILIMSKY
text: Writing. It is noted that a better understanding of the impact of IFRS 9 on the banking, insurance and financial markets in general, but also on the financial sector as a whole, needs to be established. It also calls for an analysis of the impact of the introduction of IFRS 9 on financial stability. That is why I voted in favour of this report.

name: Milan ZVER
text: Writing. I voted in favour of the European Parliament resolution on international financial reporting standards. In the wake of the global financial crisis, the role of international financial reporting standards, in particular the rules on the recognition of losses of the banking system, is crucial in financial stability and growth. I therefore support the call for the Commission, in cooperation with the ESAs, the European Central Bank, the ESRB and EFRAG, to closely monitor the implementation of IFRS 9 in the EU, to prepare an ex-post impact assessment by June 2019 at the latest and to submit it to the European Parliament and act in accordance with its positions.

name: Krisztina MORVAI
text: - Mr President, I would like to thank the European I voted in favour of the report on the unspeakably dramatic situation in Syria, but let me share something here. There would have been a very good amendment, it is a mystery to me why the majority of this Parliament rejected this amendment. Let those interested know, however, that it would have been the European Parliament's condemnation of arms deliveries and any other form of support for ISIS, al-Nusra and other jihadist groups in Syria. He notes that weapons and other equipment supplied to so-called rebel groups often fall into the hands of ISIS and al-Nusra. I would like to ask you nicely, why did the majority of the European Parliament not vote for this? Everyone should think for themselves and draw conclusions.

name: Bronis ROPĖ
text: – I voted in favour because I want to speed up the killing of innocent people, and I would also like to inform you that one of the possible contenders for the Nobel Peace Prize is the 'White Helmets' of Syria, which has rescued about 60,000 people in opposition-controlled territory after the bombings. The White Helmets are one of the lights of hope for the local people, and they have become the target of syrian regime-supporting forces. The deliberate destruction of the headquarters of both Russian and Assad forces is an unforgivable and shameful step that must await a rigorous assessment by the EU institutions. A few weeks ago, the White Helmets reported that most of their equipment had been destroyed. As a result, they cannot arrive in the areas that have just been bombed in time and help people. I therefore invite you to contribute and to call on the Member States to find funds so that these members of the voluntary organisation can continue their noble mission.

name: Stanislav POLČÁK
text: – Mr President, the situation in Syria is really not just a humanitarian disaster, it is a huge tragedy, and I would very much like us to also name the role of Russia, which is undoubtedly clear at the moment. I think she showed up in full white. Russia is, in my opinion, committing war crimes, committing them in the name of its own actions, not in the name of, say, organizing the situation in this country.  We should refine the sanctions lists drawn up by the European Union and, for this reason, include other groups of persons. Tighten the sanctions that go to dual-use items, including, of course, any further tightening of sanctions with regard to agricultural production. These impacts, which go into ordinary businesses, into the lives of companies and entrepreneurs, so of course we should also compensate for them. Nevertheless, I, of course, supported this motion for a resolution.

name: Seán KELLY
text: Go raibh maith agat a Uachtaráin. Arís bhí áthas orm tacaíocht a thabhairt don tuarascáil seo agus vótáil le mo ghrúpa leis na vótaí go léir taobh amuigh de alt 6.1. Vótálamar i bhfabhar an rúin sin agus i gcoinne an ghrúpa. Ach bíodh sin mar a tá, táimid go léir aontaithe faoin tragóid atá ag tárlu sa tSiria agus go háirithe an méid atá á fhulaingt ag muintir na Siria, nil aon dealramh leis. Agus freisin, tá déistin orainn go léir an ról atá á ghlacadh ag an Rúis sa tSiria. Níl sé féaráilte agus is ar mhaithe leo féin atá siad ag obair ansin. Dá bhrí sin tá sé tábhachtach go n-úsáidfimid gach aon seans atá againn chun deireadh a chur leis sin. Freisin, tá bród orm go bhfuil ár dhá mbád, LE Niamh agus LE Samuel Beckett, ag obair sa Mheánmhuir chun daoine a shábháil atá ag teitheadh na Siria chun teacht go dtí an Eoraip.

name: Lars ADAKTUSSON
text: Written. The resolution addresses the humanitarian disaster in Syria, with a particular focus on the situation in Aleppo. I welcome the call on all parties, in particular Russia and the Assad regime, to cease attacks on the civilian population and civilian infrastructure. I therefore chose to vote in favour of the resolution. At the same time, I note that the resolution has been able to go further with regard to the Russian bombing of civilians. What is now happening in eastern Aleppo, with attacks on hospitals, among other things, is, in consistent assessments, nothing less than violations of the laws of war and international law. The European Parliament should underline this.

name: Isabella ADINOLFI
text: in writing. \u2012 In view of the increase in hostilities in Syria, this motion for a resolution, in addition to strongly condemning all attacks on civilians and civilian infrastructure, especially the recent attacks on a convoy of humanitarian aid, which represent serious and worrying violations of international humanitarian law and possible war crimes, urges all parties to the conflict, in particular Russia and the Assad regime. , to put an end to all attacks on civilians and civilian infrastructure and to allow rapid, safe and unrestricted access to humanitarian agencies so that they can reach the populations in need of help.  All members of the International Syria Support Group are also urged to resume negotiations to facilitate the conclusion of a stable truce and to step up work to achieve a lasting political solution in Syria. For these reasons, I voted in favour.

name: Clara AGUILERA
text: in writing. We have promoted and voted on this resolution on Syria because of the worsening humanitarian situation, especially in the Aleppo region. And because of the resounding failure of the U.S.-Russian truce that has been operational for a few days. The latest attacks by Syrian government forces on Aleppo. These operations are taking away hope of a real ceasefire. Allegations of war crimes against Russia in the Security Council focus on the widespread use of anti-bunker bombs and incendiary bombs on the 275,000 civilians living in east Aleppo. Aleppo will enter history through the door of shame like Dresden, Gernika or Sarajevo. We must put an end to this destruction that is already practically total. Nevertheless, the only way out for Syria now is to re-negotiate, lower arms and secure humanitarian corridors for relief to civilians. That's the most important thing right now. The Union must be even more involved in these two priorities.

name: Tim AKER
text: in writing. – This is a non-legislative and non-binding resolution. UKIP remains gravely concerned by the ongoing conflict in Syria and is fully supportive of efforts to create a lasting and peaceful political solution. However, we cannot support EU posturing on foreign policy issues or any calls for EU action. The United Nations, primarily the Security Council, remains the most relevant forum for achieving a lasting solution. Therefore we abstained on this resolution.

name: Marina ALBIOL GUZMÁN
text: in writing. This resolution is another example of the one-way propaganda campaign in which we are immersed, which presents us with a single guilty "side", Russia and the Syrian Government, a rather hypocritical stance when some Member States of the Union, in collaboration with the US, trained and financed terrorist groups operating in the Middle East and Europe. The U.S. strategy of unilateralism and the Union's continuing foreign policy has already seen the consequences it brought in the case of Libya. We have to decide whether we want to take up that path, or position ourselves as a facilitator of dialogue and political resolution of the conflict. The Union must demand that the United States resume dialogue with Russia in the context of the conflict in Syria in order to lead to a ceasefire that gives way to a negotiating table for peace with all non-terrorist political actors. It should not be forgotten that the failure of the last truce was the cause of the U.S. bombing of Syrian Army positions in Deir Azzor. As long as the European Parliament's resolutions continue to present a single culprit of the conflict, and continue to elude their own responsibility in the conflict, my vote will be against it.

name: Martina ANDERSON
text: in writing. – We voted in favour of the resolution. While it has shortcomings, its focus on the de-escalation of violence, the protection of innocents and the need to protect humanitarian aid means we were able to support it. Sinn Féin has an issue with the resolution mentioning the Syrian regime and Russia in isolation. There are several parties to this conflict, all of whom are inflicting casualties on a civilian population. All parties to the conflict should cease operations against civilian targets or infrastructure, and that includes western powers such as the USA and EU Member States such as Britain and France.

name: Eric ANDRIEU
text: In writing. Together with my Socialist colleagues, we demand an immediate cessation of hostilities and indiscriminate bombing of civilians, in order to ensure the unimpeded delivery of humanitarian aid to all those in need and the resumption of political negotiations with the aim of ending the war, in accordance with Security Council Resolution 254.

name: Laima Liucija ANDRIKIENĖ
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the European Parliament resolution on Syria. Despite the efforts of the international community to end hostilities, the situation in Syria is deteriorating. Hostilities, including attacks on hospitals, have intensified throughout Syria, and especially in Aleppo, which Russian military aviation, which supports the Syrian government, has been under intense bombardment. With this resolution, we aim and call on the other EU institutions to play a greater role in the eu's mediation in order to reach a Syrian peace agreement. It is to be welcomed that the resolution calls on all parties to the conflict, in particular Russia and the Assad regime, to put an end to attacks on civilian and civilian infrastructure, to put an end to all sieges and to enable humanitarian organisations to reach people in need without hindrance. It is also commendable that efforts are being renewed to achieve a common EU Strategy for Syria, which aims to facilitate a political agreement in Syria. It is also necessary to monitor and ensure the implementation of the agreements and commitments entered into within the International Syria Support Group. All participants in the International Syria Support Group are invited to resume negotiations in order to facilitate the declaration of a stable ceasefire and to work more actively towards a long-term political solution in Syria.

name: Nikos ANDROULAKIS
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the motion for a resolution on the situation in Syria, because there must be an immediate cessation of hostilities and indiscriminate bombing of civilians, in order to ensure the immediate delivery of humanitarian aid and to reopen political negotiations with a view to a definitive cessation of the war.

name: Pascal ARIMONT
text: Writing. For more than five years, Syria has been in civil war, and the conflict has already claimed more than a quarter of a million lives. It is estimated that up to 14 million people in Syria need humanitarian assistance. Nearly 5 million Syrians are in hard-to-reach or besieged areas of the country.  Despite international efforts to reach a ceasefire, violence has escalated in recent weeks, and the northern Syrian city of Aleppo in particular has been rocked by massive bombardment. I agree with the majority of Parliament, which calls on all parties to the conflict in the war in Syria, and in particular Russia and the Assad regime, to refrain from all attacks on civilians. I also condemn the recent attacks on hospitals and an aid convoy. I also support the call for all members of the International Support Group for Syria to resume negotiations on the establishment of a stable ceasefire, as well as the call for those responsible for war crimes and crimes against humanity to be held accountable.

name: Jonathan ARNOTT
text: in writing. ‒ I am hugely concerned by the situation in Syria. Overall it felt appropriate for me to abstain on this resolution, despite me finding myself in agreement with much of the content, because I am not convinced that this should be considered at a European Union level.

name: Jean ARTHUIS
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this resolution on the situation in Syria, on the initiative of the ALDE, with the support of almost all political groups in Parliament. The current situation in Aleppo demonstrates that diplomacy has failed and that the international community lacks the tools to enforce existing agreements. There is a need to establish a no-fly zone over Aleppo and to allow humanitarian aid and relief to be provided to the wounded.

name: Gerard BATTEN
text: in writing. ‒ This is a non-legislative and non-binding resolution. UKIP remains gravely concerned by the ongoing conflict in Syria and is fully supportive of efforts to create a lasting and peaceful political solution. However, we cannot support EU posturing on foreign policy issues or any calls for EU action. The United Nations, primarily the Security Council, remains the most relevant forum for achieving a lasting solution. Therefore we abstained on this resolution.

name: Nicolas BAY
text: In writing. The resolutions presented amount to half-hearted support to forces opposed to the internationally recognized Syrian government and implicitly support jihadist groups on Syrian soil. I voted against these outrageous motions for a resolution.

name: Hugues BAYET
text: In writing. It was essential that the European Parliament take a position on the situation in Syria. The country has been bombed daily since 2011 and the situation is getting worse. We have denounced these atrocities and put forward solutions.

name: Beatriz BECERRA BASTERRECHEA
text: in writing. In addition to mobilizing funds to meet urgent humanitarian needs, I voted in favour of the resolution celebrating the Union's emergency humanitarian initiative for Aleppo, which, in addition to mobilizing funds to meet urgent humanitarian needs, aims to ensure the evacuation for medical reasons of injured and sick people, in particular women, children and the elderly, in eastern Aleppo.  It is now essential to consolidate the cessation of hostilities agreed in September by the U.S. and Russia. If achieved, it will be possible to allow access to humanitarian aid throughout the country. The international community, represented by the United Nations, must be present in this process. Its role is essential to make it easier for this dialogue to take place. I therefore support the work being done by the UNS SGNU Special Envoy for Syria, Mr. De Mistura. I would like to conclude by highlighting point 3 of the resolution, which calls on all parties to the conflict, and in particular Russia and the Assad regime, to put an end to all attacks on civilians and civilian infrastructure, to take credible and immediate action for the cessation of hostilities, to lift all sieges and to allow unfeased access of humanitarian organizations to people in need

name: Brando BENIFEI
text: in writing. \u2012 The situation in the city of Aleppo has now become a tragic example of the destruction that affects Syria on a daily basis. Heavy air strikes have destroyed hospitals, medical facilities, humanitarian aid convoys and even a Red Crescent warehouse near the city. The resolution adopted today by Parliament, which I supported, strongly condemns all attacks on civilians and infrastructure and the maintenance of sieges that do not allow humanitarian assistance to reach the people in need.  We need credible and immediate measures that will lead to a real cessation of hostilities and that provide for an end to attacks on civilians and basic civilian infrastructure such as water and electricity for all parties involved in the conflict, in particular Russia and the Assad regime. High Representative Mogherini has the task of defining a common EU strategy on Syria in order to facilitate a political solution to the crisis that includes instruments of control and guarantees of the implementation of the agreements and obligations assumed within the framework of the International Syria Support Group.

name: Xabier BENITO ZILUAGA
text: in writing. "U2012 Despite supporting the bulk of the content of this Syria Resolution, which calls on all parties to cease bombing, open humanitarian corridors and reopen negotiations for a ceasefire, since We have voted abstention on the ground that the resolution lacks the purported equidistance, by pointing out greater responsibilities to one of the parties to the conflict and , therefore, to place the debate in the key to a bipolar choice between two powers which we oppose from our conviction that it must be Syrian civil society that will lead the way to peace, democracy and social justice that neither party to the conflict seems to be interested in achieving.

name: Izaskun BILBAO BARANDICA
text: in writing. I have supported this Resolution on the situation in Syria in which all attacks on civilians and civilian infrastructure, the maintenance of all sieges in Syria and the lack of humanitarian access to Syrians in need are strongly condemned. The situation of populations such as Aleppo and other areas of Syria is a total emergency, as they include children and women who do not have access to essential humanitarian goods and desperately need food, clean water and medical supplies.

name: Dominique BILDE
text: In writing. I voted against this totally unfavourable resolution, which in fact implicitly supports jihadist groups on Syrian soil. Worse, several amendments to the text even take sides against the Syrian legal government of Bashar al-Assad and Russia or advocate an international role of the European Union (while diplomacy is a competence of states, not the Union!).

name: Mara BIZZOTTO
text: in writing. \u2012 I found the resolution subject to an unbalanced and non-acceptable vote, so I voted against it.

name: Malin BJÖRK
text: Written. I have voted in favour of the resolution on Syria. My basic view is that there is only one political and diplomatic solution to the conflict in Syria. There is no military solution to the bloody civil war. If the violence is to stop, a political solution is needed that includes a democratic transition, that Assad hand over power and that Syria's various ethnic and religious groups have their rights guaranteed. Arms supplies both to the Syrian regime and to the opposition are countering a peaceful solution to the conflict. A full arms embargo on Syria is needed. The UN urgently needs to deal with the crisis and act to protect the civilian population and cut off the supply of weapons and resources to IS and other terrorist groups. The forces supporting IS must be put under great pressure. A particular responsibility falls to Turkey, which has not consistently opposed IS, but instead focused on its own military violence against the Kurdish population and its fight for its fundamental rights. The war in Syria has created a terrible refugee disaster. If the EU had assumed its responsibilities and shown respect for international conventions and human rights, it would have guaranteed the issuance of humanitarian visas to asylum seekers at EU embassies and consulates, as well as the introduction of mandatory resettlement programmes at EU level instead of the effortless voluntary resettlement programme proposed by the Council.

name: José BLANCO LÓPEZ
text: in writing. – We have promoted and voted on this resolution on Syria in the face of the worsening humanitarian situation, especially in the Aleppo region and the resounding failure of the truce between the United States and Russia, which has been operational for a very few days. The last attacks by Syrian government forces on Aleppo are driving away hope of a real ceasefire. Allegations of war crimes against Russia in the Security Council focus on the widespread use of anti-bunker bombs and incendiary bombs on the 275,000 civilians living in east Aleppo. Aleppo will enter history through the door of shame like Dresden, Gernika or Sarajevo. This destruction must be put to an end. The only way out for Syria now is to re-negotiate, lower arms and secure humanitarian corridors for relief to civilians. That's the most important thing right now. The Union must be even more involved in these two priorities.

name: Vilija BLINKEVIČIŪTĖ
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this resolution, in which the European Parliament condemns all attacks on civilians and civilian infrastructure, the continuation of all sieges in Syria and the lack of humanitarian aid provided to the Syrian people in need. Parliament is particularly concerned about the suffering of people in besieged areas of Aleppo and throughout Syria, many women and children who do not have access to the necessary humanitarian supplies and who desperately need food, clean water and medical supplies. He also deeply regrets the recent attacks on the humanitarian convoy and the Red Crescent warehouse near Aleppo and condemns them as a serious and worrying violation of international humanitarian law and a potential war crime. Parliament pays tribute to the humanitarian workers who died to help the people of Aleppo and syria as a whole, and expresses its sincere condolences to the families and friends of the victims; calls for responsibility for the consequences and for those guilty of war crimes and crimes against humanity to be held accountable. Parliament therefore calls on the VP/HR to resume efforts to achieve a common EU Strategy for Syria, which aims to facilitate a political agreement in Syria, and to include monitoring and enforcement measures in order to further respect the agreements and commitments made by the International Syria Support Group.

name: Andrea BOCSKOR
text: Writing. \u2012 In my opinion, the European Union, like the entire international community, has a duty to save Syria, serving both Syrian citizens and the whole region. The negotiations started by the Syrian parties offer a good opportunity to move towards a solution. However, this option will not always be open, so it is vital that all parties engage constructively in a dialogue that leads to tangible results. The EU and its Member States will continue to provide life-saving assistance, while putting pressure on all the other to ensure that humanitarian aid reaches those in need throughout Syria, to put in place a ceasefire and to ensure the protection of civilians. Humanitarian and diplomatic efforts must take place in a coordinated manner, which can strengthen or weaken each other. I believe that a stronger, more coordinated, effective and proportionate international development policy can contribute to the reconstruction of war-torn countries and to making countries that issue masses of economic migrants more livable. The formula is simple: history has repeatedly shown that there is only one effective solution strategy in these situations: to bring help to those in distress, not to bring trouble to Europe! In view of the above, I voted in favour of the adoption of this report.

name: Franc BOGOVIČ
text: Writing. There have already been so many words about Syria that, in fact, each is superfluous. Actions are essential, but they differ greatly from the words – including international agreements –. In the meantime, children, women and many other innocent civilians are dying, and survivors are heading in large numbers to safety and forward towards Europe. I voted in favour of the resolution because, from a human point of view, I have no reason to oppose it. More than one wonders what the adoption of the resolution will change in the first. Not much, I'm afraid. The recent attacks on hospitals and humanitarian aid convoys are undoubtedly worthy of any condemnation, as this is a grave violation of international humanitarian law and a war crime. Russia and the Assad regime must immediately stop attacks on civilians and infrastructure, and the siege of cities must end.
