The key to resolving the horrific situation in Syria, however, is to renew negotiations to establish a lasting ceasefire and step up efforts to achieve a lasting political solution in the country. The agreements reached by the US and Russia so far have all fallen into the water in turn, so the EU needs to be more actively involved in the rescue. The latter has remained at a disadvantage for all years of the conflict, while the waves of migrants and terrorism make it the most felt consequence of this conflict.

name: Biljana BORZAN
text: Written. I support this Situation Report in Syria. Much concern and outrage is growing over the continuing indiscriminate bombings of civilians in Aleppo and disrupting the delivery of humanitarian aid. There is a need to cease hostilities as the last remaining hope to prevent another brutal escalation of the war.

name: Marie-Christine BOUTONNET
text: In writing. Parliament does not have to interfere in Syria's internal affairs, let alone demonstrate its systematic opposition to Russia's policy through its resolutions. Therefore, I vote against the joint resolution and against that of the GUE/NGL group.

name: Mercedes BRESSO
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the resolution on the situation in Syria because I join with my colleagues in condemning the recent attacks against civilians and we urge the parties in the International Syria Support Group to resume negotiations in order to facilitate the establishment of a stable peace. Furthermore, we call in the resolution upon Russia and the Assad regime to stop attacking civilian infrastructure, including water and electrical infrastructure, and to allow access for humanitarian aid.

name: Renata BRIANO
text: in writing. \u2012 All crimes committed against the civilian population in Syria must be strongly condemned; and in the most absolute way the systematic violations of human rights and international humanitarian law resulting from terrorist acts perpetrated by the so-called Islamic State and other radical armed groups against the Syrian population; acts that can constitute war crimes and crimes against humanity. It is necessary to urge all parties to the conflict to put an end to the attacks on civilians.  Negotiations will have to be resumed in order to facilitate the conclusion of a stable truce and to step up work towards a lasting political solution in Syria. The EU must, as soon as possible, define a common strategy on Syria that facilitates the achievement of a political solution and includes instruments for monitoring and ensuring implementation in order to strengthen compliance with the agreements concluded and the obligations entered into. The EU must ensure greater international support to cope with the increase in the number of refugees.

name: Soledad CABEZÓN RUIZ
text: in writing. We have promoted and voted on this resolution on Syria because of the worsening humanitarian situation especially in the Aleppo region. And because of the resounding failure of the U.S.-Russian truce that has been operational for a few days. The latest attacks by Syrian government forces on Aleppo. These operations are taking away hope of a real ceasefire. Allegations of war crimes against Russia in the Security Council focus on the widespread use of anti-bunker bombs and incendiary bombs on the 275,000 civilians living in east Aleppo. Aleppo will enter history through the door of shame like Dresden, Gernika or Sarajevo. We must put an end to this destruction that is already practically total. Nevertheless, the only way out for Syria now is to re-negotiate, lower arms and secure humanitarian corridors for relief to civilians. That's the most important thing right now. The Union must be even more involved in these two priorities.

name: Nicola CAPUTO
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted today in favour of the motion for a resolution on the situation in Syria because the time has come for Europe to play an incisive role in reopening negotiations to put an end to the huge humanitarian tragedy unfolding in the country. The situation in Syria is very difficult and the treagues, only announced, now hold only a few hours. We continue to shoot, to bomb, without taking into account schools, hospitals and helpless civilians. I voted in favour of the resolution so that Europe does not remain silent in the face of this carnage and exercises its leadership in order to determine the conditions for an immediate ceasefire and to facilitate the opening of humanitarian corridors.

name: Matt CARTHY
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this resolution on the situation in Syria, which focused on the disastrous humanitarian crisis happening there. It called for aid, for the prevention of all acts of violence against citizens and for a peaceful negotiated settlement of the situation.

name: David CASA
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the resolution on the desperate human rights situation in Syria. I strongly believe that, in the light of Russia’s military intervention in the country, the EU needs to work out how to deal with Russia. It is also very worrying to witness the links between the far-right parties in the EP and Russia, which is not acting as an independent party in this conflict.

name: Fabio Massimo CASTALDO
text: in writing. \u2012 As Europe speaks, Syria burns. Syria is our neighbourhood: we were the first to suffer the disastrous consequences of the destabilisation desired by others, paid primarily in terms of refugee flows. The image that Europe gives itself is that of a jammed mechanism, internally torn apart and perpetually waiting for an innovative momentum that never comes. This absence is being paid by 13.5 million Syrians, who need immediate assistance, more than 11 million refugees from outside and inside and entire cities razed to the ground, more than 400,000 dead, an endless humanitarian tragedy. I voted in favour of this resolution, in which all parties to the Syrian conflict were urged to put an end to actions against civilians and civilian infrastructure, including water and electricity.

name: Dita CHARANZOVÁ
text: in writing. ‒ Since hostilities in Syria have escalated recently – particularly in Aleppo, which is currently facing unjustified attacks against medical facilities and has been under heavy aerial bombardment – I voted in favour of the resolution calling for more effort in mediation for a peace deal in Syria. I also welcome the EU emergency humanitarian initiative for Aleppo, which aims to bring much-needed help, and I join in the call to all parties involved to stop attacks on civilians and civilian infrastructure immediately.

name: Lefteris CHRISTOFOROU
text: Writing. \u2012 We support the report and call on all parties involved in the conflict to stop all attacks on civilians and civilian infrastructure, including water and electricity infrastructure, to take credible and immediate action to cease hostilities, to lift all sieges and to enable humanitarian organisations to have rapid, safe and unhindered access to all persons in need.

name: Kostas CHRYSOGONOS
text: Writing. \u2012 The ever-deteriorating situation in Syria should lead us as the European Parliament to a clear message, with the aim of promoting solutions for the benefit of the thousands of people at risk and always in the light of respect for international agreements and international law. However, I do not think that the motion for a resolution was clear enough and at the same time did not cover all aspects of the problems we have to deal with, despite its positive elements. That's why I decided to abstain.

name: Angelo CIOCCA
text: in writing. \u2012 I am voting against a completely balanced resolution that makes no reference to Isis and Turkey's role. The resolution also calls for the introduction of compulsory resettlement programmes for refugees.

name: Alberto CIRIO
text: in writing. \u2012 I support my group's proposal on the Syrian context. We are witnessing a rapid and tragic escalation, made even worse by the lack of unity of purpose and international action. What to do in Syria, how to act and approach it, seems increasingly cumbersome: the Eu ropean Union is currently providing humanitarian aid, where it can reach those in need, and condemns all attacks on civilians and infrastructure, with the greatest concern for those suffering undeserved pain.  However, this is not enough. We are no less guilty than those who assault civilians, so we cannot complain about having to take in refugees if we do not in any way prevent this and eradicate its root cause. The aim of the proposal before us is to define a common strategy for a political solution to the economic situation by including instruments for monitoring and guaranteeing implementation in order to strengthen the agreements concluded and the obligations assumed.  The Union cannot accept the worst parts of humanity and must not show once again that it does not know or does not want to provide effective answers to concrete problems, because if it does, any problem or crisis will pile up, generating a pachydermal accumulation of unresolved issues and an unsolvable future.

name: Deirdre CLUNE
text: in writing. ‒ I supported the motion for resolution on the situation in Syria and noted no objections. I fully support a resolution to the conflict.

name: Carlos COELHO
text: in writing. The civil war that is rife with Syrian territory and the escalation of violence in recent days, especially in the city of Aleppo, put the country in the greatest humanitarian crisis today. I strongly condemn the attacks that have been perpetrated against civilians who have peculiarly affected helpless women and children who are being deprived of food, drinking water, medical supplies being denied to them, due to the siege of the city, for humanitarian aid to arrive. In the last week of September alone, 96 children were killed in bombings, according to Unicef records, with half of the injured arriving at hospitals and other treatment centers in the city's eastern children (according to Save the Children). It is vital that the parties authorise humanitarian corridors, and it is vital to condemn the recent attacks on a humanitarian aid convoy and a Red Crescent warehouse which constitute serious violations of international humanitarian law and constitute possible war crimes.  The EU and all global political actors must make efforts to find a peace solution for Syria and a rapid cessation of hostilities. A final word of support for humanitarian workers on the ground and for the families of the deceased.

name: Birgit COLLIN-LANGEN
text: Writing. I voted in favour of the resolution because we must use all the means at our disposal to work towards a political solution to the syrian war. Five years of war, five years of murder and destruction must come to an end. I deeply regret that the peace process that has been sought has failed. We must make every effort to avoid giving in to the fight against ISIS and, most importantly, we must help the people on the ground!

name: Jane COLLINS
text: in writing. – This is a non-legislative and non-binding resolution. UKIP remains gravely concerned by the ongoing conflict in Syria and is fully supportive of efforts to create a lasting and peaceful political solution. However, we cannot support EU posturing on foreign policy issues or any calls for EU action. The United Nations, primarily the Security Council, remains the most relevant forum for achieving a lasting solution. Therefore we abstained on this resolution.

name: Lara COMI
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the resolution because it is now clear to everyone how the truce in Syria decided by the US and Russia at the beginning of September has not been respected and how the situation has deteriorated, particularly in Aleppo, which has recently been hit by heavy air strikes, some of them targeting medical facilities.  The European Union has always been one of the main providers of humanitarian aid to people fleeing violence and destruction, and it is therefore necessary to allow international humanitarian organisations to reach the Syrian civilian population while also protecting humanitarian convoys from terrorist attacks.  It is necessary for the entire international community to ensure that negotiations resume rapidly in Syria in order to facilitate the conclusion of a stable truce which is an essential prerequisite for a lasting political solution in the country.

name: Javier COUSO PERMUY
text: in writing. This resolution is another example of the one-way propaganda campaign in which we are immersed, which presents us with a single guilty "side", Russia and the Syrian Government, a rather hypocritical stance when some Member States of the Union, in collaboration with the US, trained and financed terrorist groups operating in the Middle East and Europe. The U.S. strategy of unilateralism and the Union's continuing foreign policy has already seen the consequences it brought in the case of Libya. We have to decide whether we want to take up that path, or position ourselves as a facilitator of dialogue and political resolution of the conflict. The Union must demand that the United States resume dialogue with Russia in the context of the conflict in Syria in order to lead to a ceasefire that gives way to a negotiating table for peace with all non-terrorist political actors. It should not be forgotten that the failure of the last truce was the cause of the U.S. bombing of Syrian Army positions in Deir Azzor. As long as the European Parliament's resolutions continue to present a single culprit of the conflict, and continue to elude their own responsibility in the conflict, my vote will be against it.

name: Andrea COZZOLINO
text: in writing. \u2012 The situation in the city of Aleppo is becoming increasingly critical: indiscriminate attacks on civilians and repeated air strikes have not only undermined the success of the Geneva peace negotiations and the truce established by the US and Russia, but seriously worsen the humanitarian crisis in a city that sees its basic infrastructure and civilian population under siege and deprived of basic necessities under attack.  The European Union is one of the main providers of humanitarian aid for Syria and can play a very important role as mediator in the peace and political transition process in the country. In view of this fact, with my vote in favour, I intend to support the efforts to call on all parties to the conflict to put an end to the attacks on civilians and civilian infrastructure, including hospitals, and to work concretely on the cessation of hostilities, the delivery of humanitarian aid and the effective resolution of the conflict.  The EU has already promoted an emergency humanitarian initiative in favour of Aleppo, aimed both at mobilising funds for ongoing emergencies and at facilitating the health evacuation of the injured.

name: Edward CZESAK
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 I support the resolution on the situation in Syria, which In my opinion is tragic. The death toll exceeds 250,000 and 12 million people have had to leave Syria. After a war that has lasted so long and is so tragic, steps must be taken at international level as soon as possible to end the conflict. What I, as an MEP, can do is call for an urgent solution to the conflict at international level and condemn attacks on civilians and aid workers. I voted in favour because every step must be taken to end this conflict.

name: Miriam DALLI
text: in writing. ‒ The situation in Syria is deteriorating and civilians are being killed and injured daily, especially in Aleppo. The ceasefire negotiated 2 weeks ago between the International Syria Support Group, Russia and United States seems to have collapsed. The US, the UK, France, Germany and Italy condemned the gross violations of international humanitarian law. Today, the prospects for a new ceasefire seem very bleak, especially with the American presidential elections coming up. I am greatly concerned and outraged at the bombings of innocent civilians in Aleppo and the disruption of humanitarian aid deliveries. If no new agreement is negotiated between the US and Russia, the situation in Syria will escalate into further violence, destruction and human suffering. I believe that an immediate cessation of hostilities is needed, and that is why I am completely in favour of this report.

name: Nicola DANTI
text: in writing. \u2012 The massacre that took place a few days ago in East Aleppo, the heart of the clash between Assad and the rebel forces, is just the latest drama of an unacceptable conflict that has reduced the whole of Syria to rubble, cost the lives of more than 300 thousand people and forced almost half the population to leave their homes.  A tragedy, to which the European Union, in cooperation with the United Nations, has reacted with a humanitarian initiative aimed at facilitating the delivery of assistance to civilians and ensuring the evacuation of injured or sick people from East Aleppo. An important step to limit the damage, which once again testifies to the EU's commitment to humanitarian assistance in Syria, but which does not change the rules of the game.  The real game to resolve this interminable conflict, in fact, will be all politically and diplomatically. For this reason, I hope that the efforts of the Union and the High Representative Federica Mogherini will lead to a constructive dialogue, including neighbouring countries and the two major superpowers, and that its aim will be to achieve an immediate ceasefire and break this deadlock that is destroying the Syrian people.

name: Michel DANTIN
text: In writing. This resolution sets out the European Parliament's position on the massacres currently taking place in Syria. In this context, MEPs strongly condemn attacks on civilian persons and infrastructure, and denounce the serious and disturbing violations of international humanitarian law in Syria. Considering that war crimes and crimes against humanity committed in Syria are unacceptable and are against the values of the Union, I supported this resolution.

name: Rachida DATI
text: In writing. I supported this resolution in order to condemn in the strongest terms the unacceptable attacks in Syria on civilians and infrastructure such as hospitals. Syria is in a situation of humanitarian tragedy and suffering in which Europe cannot remain unanswered. Too many children are affected by these attacks, especially in the Aleppo region. The European Union's humanitarian initiatives are no longer enough. We must express real political will for a lasting resolution of conflicts in a country in chaos.

name: Isabella DE MONTE
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the motion for a resolution because I believe it is necessary to stop the hostilities and escalation of violence in Syria. I therefore call on the parties involved in the conflict to put an end to all attacks on civilians and infrastructure and to resume negotiations, and for the EU to play a stronger role in brokering a peace agreement.

name: Jean-Paul DENANOT
text: In writing. Syria has become the bloody scene of a civil war whose death toll the United Nations has stopped counting. Faced with a game of contradictory alliances at the regional and international level, faced with a tangle of actors, Syria is a depleted country where, behind closed doors, a humanitarian drama is played out. With this text, the European Union wants to once again alert international public opinion to the intensification of hostilities, outside of respect for all the rules of the law where civilians are targeted, especially the most vulnerable (women, children, the elderly and hospitalized). The city of Aleppo is particularly targeted and affected. It is unsustainable and it must stop.

name: Marielle DE SARNEZ
text: In writing. The bombing of a humanitarian convoy on 20 September put an end to the fragile truce in Syria. The city of Aleppo is now under fire from unprecedentedly violent attacks by the Damascus regime and its Russian ally. Hundreds of thousands of people are currently trapped. The Syrian crisis is a humanitarian tragedy unprecedented since World War II. Since the conflict began in 2011, nearly 250,000 people have lost their lives and some 5 million Syrians have been forced to flee the country, seeking refuge in Lebanon, Jordan and Turkey. The diplomatic confrontation between the United States and Russia does not seem to be possible to reach an attempt at a resolution, quite the contrary. In this deleterious context, Europe must make its voice heard. It must seek the assistance of regional powers such as Turkey, Iran or Saudi Arabia. The Union must act and develop a perspective to try to put an end to the tragedy that is being played out on our doorstep.

name: Angel DZHAMBAZKI
text: in writing. \u2012 I supported the resolution on the situation in Syria, as I believe that the European Union, which is being flooded with hundreds of thousands of illegal refugees, many of whom are not Syrians at all, suffers the most from the conflict in Syria.  There is an interest in continuing the conflict, especially Turkey, which aims, on the one hand, to weaken the Assad regime and seize large swathes of territory from Syria and, on the other hand, to have leverage to blackmail the European Union for even more money and visa-free regimes. The conflict in Syria and the subsequent refugee wave have triggered irreversible geopolitical processes such as the split in the European Union and Britain's departure.  Our only chance to deter this process is to close our external borders tightly, to prevent new refugees and to return all illegally entered and residing in the Union. The European Union must start defending its own interests, not the economic or political interests of individual countries such as Germany, Turkey or Saudi Arabia.

name: Georgios EPITIDEIOS
text: Writing. \u2012 Negative as a whole. Once again and more openly, the EU is following the tactic of indirect support for Islamists and is opposed to the only force that has fought alongside Assad, Russia.

name: Jill EVANS
text: in writing. ‒ I supported this report because I believe that war crimes in Aleppo require urgent action, and my constituents in Wales demand no less. We have all seen the horrific images of attacks on hospitals, homes and even aid convoys. The EU must do everything possible to provide humanitarian aid and also use its influence internationally to bring these attacks to an end. There must be a return to the negotiating table.

name: Fredrick FEDERLEY
text: Written. "It is my strong belief that a resolution is needed that will get to grips with the serious situation in Syria, and in a situation where things are rapidly changing for the worse, a new resolution is also needed to take note of this. I chose to include an amendment from the ENF; in this case, it was important to also show support for the Kurds, who have been affected by the Syrian war and by the political leadership in Turkey.

name: José Manuel FERNANDES
text: in writing. Recent attacks are serious and alarming violations of international humanitarian law and possible war crimes and the EU should take a major role in mediating for a peace agreement in the country. I commend all attacks on civilians and hospitals in Syria and express my deep concern about the suffering of people in the besieged areas of Aleppo. All participants in the International Syria Support Group should resume negotiations, facilitate the establishment of a stable peace and step up efforts to achieve a lasting political solution for Syria.

name: João FERREIRA
text: in writing. \u2012 This resolution consists of a cynical exercise in the instrumentalisation of humanitarian issues. Decontextualizing events on the ground since the ceasefire, omitting some of them – such as the US air strike that first violated the ceasefire – omitting the causes of the conflict in Syria, and in particular the role of external interference by Western powers and their support for armed terrorist groups, what is intended with this resolution is to give political and institutional coverage to the entry into a new stage of the process of external aggression to this sovereign country. Something similar happened a few years ago when it came to preparing the aggression to Libya. At that time too, humanitarian issues came into the spotlight, in a skewed and truncated way. We do not ignore the serious humanitarian situation experienced on the ground. For her attention is drawn in the resolution presented by our group. a situation that requires immediate responses, which must be articulated with the end of economic and diplomatic sanctions; with the end of the supply of weapons and military training to TERRORIST GROUPS supported by the US and EU; and with the commitment to build a political solution that will end the war and bring humanitarian aid where it is needed, while creating conditions for the reconstruction of the country.

name: Luke Ming FLANAGAN
text: in writing. ‒ I voted against, as reasonable amendments were not accepted.

name: Monika BEŇOVÁ
text: Writing. \u2012 The situation in Syria is constantly deteriorating and the suffering of the civilian population, especially in Aleppo, has reached dramatic proportions. The ceasefire agreed two weeks ago appears to have been lost and Russia blames the US for bombing and attacking Syrian army positions. The prospects for an early peaceful resolution of the conflict appear to be in sight in the Russia-US disputes, which is also complicated by the US presidential election, as no major foreign policy decisions are expected from the outgoing administration. It is extremely worrying that world powers, led by the US, Russia and the European Union, are looking at the ongoing bombing of innocent civilians in aleppo, where the locals do not even have access to basic humanitarian aid.

name: Lorenzo FONTANA
text: in writing. \u2012 I am voting against the resolution which contains an attack on Russia and makes no critical and condemning reference to Isis and Turkey's role.

name: Eleonora FORENZA
text: in writing. \u2012 Although I welcome the very high cost in terms of civilian casualties from the Syrian conflict, I voted against the text because it is not possible to think of attributing exclusively to Russia and the forces loyal to Assad the dramatic repercussions on civilians of this war.  The responsibility for what is happening in Syria lies also with the rebel groups , including ISIS and Al Nusra, which are also supported and financed by the USA and European countries, as well as by Saudi Arabia and Turkey. The responsibilities of these armed groups as well as their international sponsors in the violation of human rights and war are in no way mentioned in the resolution.  As a humanitarian reminder, the resolution thus converts into a declaration of the EU's political positioning alongside the US, which I do not believe is helpful in achieving a stable and lasting truce in Syria.

name: Lampros FOUNTOULIS
text: Writing. \u2012 I am voting against the reports on the situation in Syria because, once again clearly, the EU is following the tactic of indirectly supporting the Islamists and is opposed to the only force that has fought alongside al-Assad, Russia.

name: Doru-Claudian FRUNZULICĂ
text: in writing. ‒ The situation in Aleppo is dramatic. In spite of the agreement of the 9 September on the cessation of hostilities, the Assad regime, supported by Russia are continuing to deliberately target civilians, a humanitarian convoy last week, doctors and hospitals. The water supply have also been cut off. Those actions must be strongly condemned, as they are an unacceptable breach of international humanitarian law and could be qualified as war crimes. I would therefore like to express my deepest concern for the human suffering in the besieged areas of Aleppo and throughout Syria, including many women and children, who do not have access to essential humanitarian goods and desperately need food, clean water and medical supplies. I support the call on the HR/VP Federica Mogherini, on the international community and the on the United Nations to use all necessary diplomatic instruments and pressure to end the indiscriminate aerial bombardment of civilians and for the cessation of hostilities to be implemented, respected and prolonged in order to allow full humanitarian access to the besieged areas.

name: Francisco de Paula GAMBUS MILLET
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the motion for a resolution following the finding of the breakdown of the truce and the worsening humanitarian situation in Syria. The Union must continue its efforts at the collective level, to develop greater prominence in mediation for a peace agreement in Syria. We cannot in any way consent to attacks on civilians and civilian infrastructure, the maintenance of all sieges in Syria, and the lack of humanitarian access to Syrians in need of many women and children, who do not have access to essential humanitarian goods and desperately need food, clean water and medical supplies. All parties to the conflict, and in particular Russia and the Assad regime, must end all attacks on civilians. Similarly, we must urge all participants in the International Syria Support Group to resume negotiations to facilitate the establishment of a stable truce and the end of violence.

name: Iratxe GARCÍA PÉREZ
text: in writing. We have promoted and voted on this resolution on Syria because of the worsening humanitarian situation, particularly in the Aleppo region. And also as a result of the resounding failure of the united States-Russian truce, which has been in force for very few days. The last attacks by Syrian government forces on Aleppo are driving away hope of a real ceasefire. Allegations of war crimes against Russia in the Security Council focus on the widespread use of anti-bunker bombs and incendiary bombs on the 275,000 civilians living in east Aleppo. Aleppo will go down history through the door of shame like Dresden, Gernika or Sarajevo. We must put an end to this destruction that is already practically total. Nevertheless, the only way out for Syria now is to re-negotiate, lower arms and secure humanitarian corridors to relieve civilians. That's the most important thing right now. The Union must be even more involved in these two priorities.

name: Eider GARDIAZABAL RUBIAL
text: in writing. U2012 We have promoted and voted on this resolution on Syria because of the worsening humanitarian situation, especially in the Aleppo region and the resounding failure of the us-Russian truce that has been operational for very few days. The last attacks by Syrian government forces on Aleppo are driving away hope of a real ceasefire. Allegations of war crimes against Russia in the Security Council focus on the widespread use of anti-bunker bombs and incendiary bombs on the 275,000 civilians living in east Aleppo. Aleppo will enter history through the door of shame like Dresden, Gernika or Sarajevo. We must put an end to this destruction that is already practically total. Nevertheless, the only way out for Syria now is to re-negotiate, lower arms and secure humanitarian corridors for relief to civilians. That's the most important thing right now. The Union must be even more involved in these two priorities.

name: Enrico GASBARRA
text: in writing. \u2012 The emergency in Syria and particularly in Aleppo is increasingly dramatic. In today's vote, this House has unreservedly expressed its strong condemnation of all attacks on civilians and infrastructure, strongly calling on all parties to the conflict, in particular Russia and the Assad regime, to put an end to all operations. The European Union is one of the main providers of humanitarian aid to people fleeing violence and destruction. That is also why, as Europeans, we must persevere in our joint efforts and collectively assume, through High Representative Mogherini, a stronger role in brokering a peace agreement.

name: Jens GIESEKE
text: Writing. After more than five years of civil war, there is still no end to violence in Syria. The divisions between the parties to the conflict are too deep. The European Union must continue to fulfil its role as peacemaker and press for a diplomatic settlement of the violence. Russia's support for the Assad regime is currently destroying hopes for an early, lasting peace. The parties to the conflict must return to the negotiating table in order to finally stop the suffering of the Syrian people. The ceasefire agreement between the US and Russia is an important first step here.

name: Nathan GILL
text: in writing. ‒ This is a non-legislative and non-binding resolution. UKIP remains gravely concerned by the ongoing conflict in Syria and is fully supportive of efforts to create a lasting and peaceful political solution. However, we cannot support EU posturing on foreign policy issues or any calls for EU action. The United Nations, primarily the Security Council, remains the most relevant forum for achieving a lasting solution. Therefore we abstained on this resolution.

name: Bruno GOLLNISCH
text: In writing. I voted against the resolution on Syria. I would have liked to see in this text a paragraph, a line, which emphasizes that the civilians of East Aleppo are used as human shields. That the forces that occupy this area of the city today prevent them from fleeing. That these forces are not made up of opponents of the Russian-backed regime in Damascus, but by Islamists who have also brought war to the heart of our cities. I would like this Parliament to express so much firmness against Saudi Arabia's actions and abuses in Yemen. But, obviously, the death of Shiite civilians caused by this friendly Gulf democracy, armed among others by the government of my country, does not have the same price as that of the hostages of Daesh in Aleppo. Finally, I would like Parliament to pay attention to the fate of what is left of Mosul's people when the Peshmerga offensive, supported by the bombing of NATO aircraft, has been launched. No doubt, if there is a problem, you will reuse the vile expression of collateral damage. Your Manichaeism is not only stupid but sickening: it amounts to wanting to protect the jihadists. Choose your friends better.

name: Tania GONZÁLEZ PEÑAS
text: in writing. "U2012 Despite supporting the bulk of the content of this Syria Resolution, which calls on all parties to cease bombing, open humanitarian corridors and reopen negotiations for a ceasefire, since We have voted abstention on the ground that the resolution lacks the purported equidistance, by pointing out greater responsibilities to one of the parties to the conflict and , therefore, to place the debate in the key to a bipolar choice between two powers which we oppose from our conviction that it must be Syrian civil society that will lead the way to peace, democracy and social justice that neither party to the conflict seems to be interested in achieving.

name: Theresa GRIFFIN
text: in writing. ‒ I supported the resolution as it demands an immediate cessation of hostilities, including the indiscriminate bombing of the civilians, and calls for the unhindered delivery of humanitarian aid to all those in need as well as the re-launch of political negotiations with the aim of ending the war, in accordance with UN Security Council Resolution 2254.

name: Enrique GUERRERO SALOM
text: in writing. We have promoted and voted on this resolution on Syria because of the worsening humanitarian situation especially in the Aleppo region. And because of the resounding failure of the U.S.-Russian truce that has been operational for a few days. The latest attacks by Syrian government forces on Aleppo. These operations are taking away hope of a real ceasefire. Allegations of war crimes against Russia in the Security Council focus on the widespread use of anti-bunker bombs and incendiary bombs on the 275,000 civilians living in east Aleppo. Aleppo will enter history through the door of shame like Dresden, Gernika or Sarajevo. We must put an end to this destruction that is already practically total. Nevertheless, the only way out for Syria now is to re-negotiate, lower arms and secure humanitarian corridors for relief to civilians. That's the most important thing right now. The Union must be even more involved in these two priorities.

name: Sylvie GUILLAUME
text: In writing. The situation in Syria has been revolting for several years and must be the subject of the strongest condemnation. But the latest abuses, such as repeated bombing of hospitals, humanitarian convoys and targeting of civilians, have shown that neither the Syrian government nor its Russian allies are seriously considering a ceasefire. It is in this context that I voted for this resolution but also because it is essential that the international community continue to unanimously condemn what is increasingly akin to war crimes. Moreover, the fact that this resolution is common to the various political groups in the European Parliament conveys an image of precious unity which shows that speaking out and denouncing barbarism is always useful, in particular to give the sign that we are not abandoning the people of Aleppo.

name: Sergio GUTIÉRREZ PRIETO
text: in writing. We have promoted and voted on this resolution on Syria because of the worsening humanitarian situation especially in the Aleppo region. And because of the resounding failure of the U.S.-Russian truce that has been operational for a few days. The latest attacks by Syrian government forces on Aleppo. These operations are taking away hope of a real ceasefire. Allegations of war crimes against Russia in the Security Council focus on the widespread use of anti-bunker bombs and incendiary bombs on the 275,000 civilians living in east Aleppo. Aleppo will enter history through the door of shame like Dresden, Gernika or Sarajevo. We must put an end to this destruction that is already practically total. Nevertheless, the only way out for Syria now is to re-negotiate, lower arms and secure humanitarian corridors for relief to civilians. That's the most important thing right now. The Union must be even more involved in these two priorities.

name: Cătălin Sorin IVAN
text: in writing. ‒ Hostilities in Syria must come to a stop. Another ceasefire needs to be put into place. However, in order for this solution to work, dialogue must occur with all the political parties involved. Re-launching political negotiations is paramount!

name: Ivan JAKOVČIĆ
text: Written. I voted for the Resolution on the Situation in Syria as soon as possible to find a solution that would calm tensions and continued casualties and new casualties, especially the civilian population. It is now clear that in Syria complete chaos has been caused by the many particular interests of not only the parties to the conflict. It's disgusting to bomb cities, and in them hospitals and settlements where innocent children and civilians are killed. Attacks on public institutions in Damascus and elsewhere are also unacceptable. It is also unacceptable for the EU that it is practically not participating in the peace process, which is again frozen, but that is why EU members are suffering enormous damage from the migrant crisis. Even the entire European project has been called into question due to the migrant crisis. It is necessary to find a peaceful solution as soon as possible and reduce the suffering of the citizens of Syria. Efforts by European diplomacy to secure the humanitarian aid now most needed to save people's lives need to continue. It is necessary to involve the US, Russia, countries in the region and of course the EU in a future solution to the situation in Syria in order to find a political solution to the conflict. The EU needs to continue its peace-making policy and do everything to stop the horrors.

name: Jean-François JALKH
text: In writing. I do not intend to provide any support, direct or indirect, to the so-called rebels fighting an internationally recognized and democratically elected regime. Moreover, the warlike episodes of the Syrian conflict do not seem to me to be analysed in the light of the best objectivity by Parliament. I chose to vote against it.

name: Diane JAMES
text: in writing. – This is a non-legislative and non-binding resolution. UKIP remains gravely concerned by the ongoing conflict in Syria and is fully supportive of efforts to create a lasting and peaceful political solution. However, we cannot support EU posturing on foreign policy issues or any calls for EU action. The United Nations, primarily the Security Council, remains the most relevant forum for achieving a lasting solution. Therefore we abstained on this resolution.

name: Marc JOULAUD
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the resolution on the situation in Syria. With this resolution, Parliament strongly condemned the atrocities committed in Aleppo targeting civilians and civilian infrastructure. There is an urgent need for a ceasefire and the establishment of a humanitarian corridor. The High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs must, on behalf of the Union, play a greater role in mediating a peace agreement in Syria.

name: Philippe JUVIN
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this resolution on Syria, which urges the actors of the Syrian conflict to stop bombing civilians, including those targeting hospitals and humanitarian aid convoys. The resolution also calls for negotiations to resume quickly so that a peace agreement can be reached soon.

name: Barbara KAPPEL
text: Writing. I am abstaining on this resolution. The suffering in Aleppo is inhumane, but this resolution fails to give the reasons for it correctly and in detail, it is indiscriminate. The atrocities committed by the Islamic State or the Al-Nusra Front are completely ignored, while the Assad regime and Russia are blamed for the suffering.

name: Afzal KHAN
text: in writing. ‒ I supported the resolution as it demands an immediate cessation of hostilities and indiscriminate bombings of the civilians, to ensure an unhindered delivery of humanitarian aid to all those in need and re-launch of political negotiations with the aim to put an end to the war in accordance with the UNSC resolution 2254.

name: Jaromír KOHLÍČEK
text: Writing. \u2012 The Syrian and Russian armies have agreed several times since this spring to a ceasefire, but this has not been broken by their fault relatively quickly. Russian officials have repeatedly asked the US administration for clear identification of individual resistance groups. The situation is very cluttered, and it is clear that neither the al-Nusra Front nor IS can be among the negotiating partners. In the case of other groups, the situation is much more complicated.  Of particular warning is the us government's latest statement that it does not want to discuss the matter with Russia. The heavily hyped image of eastern Aleppo is just one of the places where distorted information is trying to convince the world public that both the Russian and Syrian armies are still killing civilians. During late summer, the ceasefire allowed civilians to leave the city. So-called democratic opposition forces have prevented the evacuation militarily and are currently using heavy artillery to try to retake the rest of the city. The situation is certainly not black and white, as the representatives of the US, the United Kingdom and France are trying to tell us during the UN General Assembly. Peace in Syria will not ensure the flow of millions more dollars from the Gulf states, nor will efforts to impose sweeping economic sanctions on the Syrian regime. The position of Western states is incomprehensible and precludes the achievement of a peaceful resolution of conflicts in the region. Preferential admission of refugees in EU countries will also not help bring peace.

name: Ilhan KYUCHYUK
text: in writing. – The situation in Syria continues to deteriorate, and the view of lasting peace is about to disappear. The failure of yet another agreed truce only reinforced the thesis that the peace process in the country is possible only with full consensus between the warring parties, without the involvement of dictator Assad, but also with the unification of the international community. In this complex international environment, the EU must use all its diplomatic and humanitarian resources to prevent human terror in Aleppo, where more than 250,000 people are suffering encirced by the forces of Bashar Al-Assad and Hezbollah. These innocent victims do not have access to drinking water, food and medical assistance, while being subjected to constant artillery fire and military bombardment. In this regard, I welcome the European Commission's decision to create an urgent humanitarian initiative for Aleppo to allow humanitarian organisations to help the thousands of civilians suffering. I believe that all parties to the conflict will support this initiative in the name of humanity, but also peace and the future for Syria and the region.

name: Gilles LEBRETON
text: In writing. I voted against this resolution because it takes sides against Assad and implicitly supports the jihadist groups on Syrian soil. It is all the more reprehensible since the amendments of the ENF group which called 1) the ban on arms deliveries to so-called moderate Islamists and 2) the recognition of Turkey's ambiguous role have been postponed.

name: Philippe LOISEAU
text: In writing. It is a matter for Parliament to interfere in the battle for Aleppo by putting all stakeholders back to back. We can therefore detect the primary Russophobia to which the European institutions are accustomed. Moreover, the resolutions presented amount to supporting forces opposed to armies loyal to the legitimate Syrian government without saying so. I therefore objected to the joint resolution and that of the GUE/NGL group.

name: Javi LÓPEZ
text: in writing. We have promoted and voted on this resolution on Syria because of the worsening humanitarian situation especially in the Aleppo region. And because of the resounding failure of the U.S.-Russian truce that has been operational for a few days. The latest attacks by Syrian government forces on Aleppo. These operations are taking away hope of a real ceasefire. Allegations of war crimes against Russia in the Security Council focus on the widespread use of anti-bunker bombs and incendiary bombs on the 275,000 civilians living in east Aleppo. Aleppo will enter history through the door of shame like Dresden, Gernika or Sarajevo. We must put an end to this destruction that is already practically total. Nevertheless, the only way out for Syria now is to re-negotiate, lower arms and secure humanitarian corridors for relief to civilians. That's the most important thing right now. The Union must be even more involved in these two priorities.

name: Juan Fernando LÓPEZ AGUILAR
text: in writing. We have promoted and voted on this resolution on Syria because of the worsening humanitarian situation especially in the Aleppo region. And because of the resounding failure of the U.S.-Russian truce that has been operational for a few days. The latest attacks by Syrian government forces on Aleppo. These operations are taking away hope of a real ceasefire. Allegations of war crimes against Russia in the Security Council focus on the widespread use of anti-bunker bombs and incendiary bombs on the 275,000 civilians living in east Aleppo. Aleppo will enter history through the door of shame like Dresden, Gernika or Sarajevo. We must put an end to this destruction that is already practically total. Nevertheless, the only way out for Syria now is to re-negotiate, lower arms and secure humanitarian corridors for relief to civilians. That's the most important thing right now. The Union must be even more involved in these two priorities.

name: Paloma LÓPEZ BERMEJO
text: in writing. This resolution is another example of the one-way propaganda campaign in which we are immersed, which presents us with a single guilty "side", Russia and the Syrian Government, a rather hypocritical stance when some Member States of the Union, in collaboration with the US, trained and financed terrorist groups operating in the Middle East and Europe. The U.S. strategy of unilateralism and the Union's continuing foreign policy has already seen the consequences it brought in the case of Libya. We have to decide whether we want to take up that path, or position ourselves as a facilitator of dialogue and political resolution of the conflict. The Union must demand that the United States resume dialogue with Russia in the context of the conflict in Syria in order to lead to a ceasefire that gives way to a negotiating table for peace with all non-terrorist political actors. It should not be forgotten that the failure of the last truce was the cause of the U.S. bombing of Syrian Army positions in Deir Azzor. As long as the European Parliament's resolutions continue to present a single culprit of the conflict, and continue to elude their own responsibility in the conflict, my vote will be against it.

name: Mairead McGUINNESS
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this resolution that seeks to provide solutions to the ongoing conflict in Syria.

name: Petr MACH
text: Writing. \u2012 I abstained. Amendments criticizing the supply of weapons to the Islamic State, as well as criticism of Turkey for fighting Kurdish militias in Syria, have not been pass. The call for all warring parties not to attack civilians is nothing, the warring parties will not make any of it.

name: Ivana MALETIĆ
text: Written. ‒ The EU strongly condemns the escalation of violence in Aleppo, the continuous bombardments and sieges that further endanger the lives of hundreds of thousands of Syrians and hamper the international community's efforts to provide humanitarian aid and support political conflict resolution. All attacks on civilian populations and civilian infrastructure, as well as excessive and disproportionate attacks by the Syrian regime, need to be stopped. The EU will continue to do its um to ensure the full implementation of the Geneva Communiquing and the relevant UN Security Council resolutions. An immediate halt to the conflict in Aleppo is needed to allow medical evacuations, aid deliveries and repairs to basic water and electrical infrastructure. Humanitarian operations in Aleppo must serve humanitarian purposes and comply with international humanitarian principles and standards, not part of any military strategy.  I supported this resolution as I think it is necessary to continue negotiations to achieve a stable ceasefire and to step up actions to reach a lasting political agreement in Syria.

name: Andrejs MAMIKINS
text: in writing. ‒ In my view, this is a resolution of EU weakness. We can only condemn and deplore. What kind of instruments do we have? Our diplomatic possibilities are very small, military possibilities are at zero level. As for refugees from Syria, now the EU has concluded the deal with Turkey not to allow refugees from Syria to EU.  Thus, the only way we can help Syrians is to finance humanitarian programmes, but the amount of money for these purposes is very limited compared with EU countries’ financial possibilities. I think we have to show our attitude with real actions and not just with empty resolutions.

name: Vladimír MAŇKA
text: Writing. \u2012 Attacks on humanitarian aid are a gross violation of international humanitarian law. The war in Syria is primarily a struggle by large states for power over this territory, the consequences of which are borne by the civilian population.  Statements and challenges are ineffective; The propaganda of the superpowers is untrustworthy. Syria is now most in need of a ceasefire that will create room for negotiation. The diplomatic path remains the only way to reach a ceasefire and continue to resolve the conflict through negotiations and negotiations.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: Writing. \u2012 Referring to my speeches from time to time in the plenary of the European Parliament on the situation in Syria, I state very clearly that I am voting against this motion for a resolution because it is neither complete nor substantiated.

name: Dominique MARTIN
text: In writing. I voted against this motion for a resolution. We keep stressing that the European Union has no foreign policy competences and should not meddle in the internal affairs of other countries. This motion for a resolution is yet another example of this imprudence: Parliament wants to interfere in the situation in Syria, especially with regard to the battle for Aleppo. In addition, the resolution aims to support forces opposed to armies loyal to the internationally recognized Syrian government. Finally, it is a perfect example of the Russophobia of the European institutions.

name: Georg MAYER
text: Writing. This resolution does not paint a holistic picture of Syria's situation. While mentioning Russia and the Assad government, which are blamed for attacks on civilians and civilian infrastructure, neither ISIS nor the AL-Nusra Front are mentioned. That is why I had to abstain from voting here.

name: Valentinas MAZURONIS
text: Writing. \u2012 I support the EP resolution on Syria. The resolution on intensified hostilities in Syria, attacks on medical facilities and the drastic deterioration of the situation calls on all parties to the conflict, in particular Russia and the Assad regime, to put an end to attacks on civilians and civilian infrastructure, including water and electricity infrastructure, to take credible and urgent action to end hostilities, to put an end to all sieges and to enable humanitarian organisations to reach all people quickly, safely and without barriers who need it.

name: Jean-Luc MÉLENCHON
text: In writing. This joint resolution is mainly aimed at condemning the massacres of civilians taking place in Aleppo, which I naturally support. But it also uses the pretext to call only "Russia and the regime of Bashar al-Assad to stop all attacks targeting civilians and civilian infrastructure". She forgets to say that behind these civilian targets are mostly hidden, and in this case in Aleppo, jihadist troops, especially from the Al-Nusra Front, the Syrian branch of Al Qaeda. The latter has been responsible for months of thousands of civilian deaths in Syria. A terrorist organization that the United States, the monarchies of the Gulf, Turkey but also France of François Hollande have been sparing for years at the expense of peace in Syria. The resolution also consciously forgets to mention the bombings of the United States and France, which took place at the same time in Mosul, a city of 1.2 million people, the majority of whom were defenceless civilians and no means of fleeing. I also vote against this resolution and support the much more balanced resolution tabled by my group, the GUE/NGL group.

name: Joëlle MÉLIN
text: In writing. It is a matter for Parliament to interfere in the battle for Aleppo by putting all stakeholders back to back. We can therefore detect the primary Russophobia to which the European institutions are accustomed. Moreover, the resolutions presented amount to supporting forces opposed to armies loyal to the legitimate Syrian government without saying so. I therefore objected to the joint resolution and that of the GUE/NGL group.

name: Nuno MELO
text: in writing. \u2012 The European Union makes one of the greatest contributions to humanitarian aid for people fleeing historical violence and destruction in Syria; that the lack of international unity undermines the prospects for a negotiated solution to the war in Syria. The EU must continue its efforts and take a greater role in mediation for a peace agreement in Syria. We must regret everything that is happening in Syria and try to find a peaceful solution to this conflict. Hence my vote in favour.

name: Roberta METSOLA
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this cross-party resolution on the dire situation in Syria, commending the Union’s emergency response to the humanitarian crisis in Aleppo. The resolution also calls for the members of the International Syria Support Group to resume negotiations and reach a lasting truce that will facilitate a political solution to the war.

name: Louis MICHEL
text: Written. – The war and hostilities in Syria continue unabated after 5 years. The city of Aleppo and its people are currently being wiped off the map. Heavy air strikes on the city, including bombings of its own population in hospitals and medical infrastructure, have once again killed many hundreds of innocent people in recent weeks. According to the Syrian Observatory, the death toll from the five-year war would have risen to more than 370,000 by the middle of this year. Assad's regime is blamed for most of the deaths. This madness must stop. The air strikes must stop and an immediate ceasefire should allow access to humanitarian aid for the ailing population. With this resolution, the European Parliament reiterates its call for all parties involved to put an end to this terrible war. It also calls on the EU and its High Representative to come up with a common EU strategy and to step up efforts for a lasting political solution for Syria and to play a more pronounced role in brokering a peace agreement.

name: Miroslav MIKOLÁŠIK
text: Writing. – The humanitarian situation in Syria remains alarming and without a foreseeable solution. Armed conflict, accompanied by violations of human rights and international humanitarian law, continues to cause casualties for innocent civilians and volunteers. World powers, including the European Union, the United States, Russia, Turkey, Iran and surrounding Arab states, must unite to support the UN Special Envoy's call for a break in wartime violence to provide assistance to the affected area in Aleppo and to ensure the necessary evacuation of the injured and sick. I deeply condemn all forms of violence directed and carried out against innocent residents and vulnerable groups such as children, the elderly and the sick. It is unacceptable for these acts of violence to continue, and it is the Union's duty, as a global promoter of human rights standards, to participate actively in limiting these war crimes, as well as to make a strong appeal to other world powers to do so.

name: Marlene MIZZI
text: in writing. ‒ I have voted in favour of the resolution because it is essential to raise strong concern and outrage at the continuing indiscriminate bombings of civilians in Aleppo and disruption of humanitarian aid deliveries. We must stress the necessity to save the cessation of hostilities as the last remaining hope to prevent another brutal escalation of the war.

name: Csaba MOLNÁR
text: Writing. \u2012 The PPE, S&D, ECR, ALDE, Verts/ALE and EFDD Groups jointly tabled a joint motion and the GUE/NGL Group tabled an independent motion. By my vote, I supported the joint motion.

name: Cláudia MONTEIRO DE AGUIAR
text: in writing. The civil war in Syria, which has been perpetuated for more than five years, is already one of the greatest humanitarian disasters and the escalation of violence, especially in the city of Aleppo, shows no signs of truce.   I strongly condemn the abuse and indiscriminate attacks perpetuated on civilians and the infrastructure that enable the arrival of humanitarian aid. It is crucial that respected humanitarian corridors are created.   There is an urgent need to find a golden peace solution and a ceasefire to be reached as soon as possible.

name: Sophie MONTEL
text: In writing. This motion for a resolution defends unacceptable immigrationist options, so I am voting against it.

name: Nadine MORANO
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this resolution on the situation in Syria, which calls for an end to the violent attacks, particularly in Aleppo, which result in the deaths of many people, including civilians. It also calls on the EU High Representative for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy to increase her mediation activities in order to achieve a solution to the Syrian conflict. The international community must be mobilized in a single coalition, including Russia, to end the war in Syria, which includes the mass migration wave facing Europe.

name: Alessia Maria MOSCA
text: in writing. \u2012 We welcome the resolution on the situation in Syria. Today, Parliament is making its voice heard, as uniformly as possible, on the emergencies that so deeply affect the constituent values of the European Union. We must not forget that Parliament, the only European institution directly elected by the citizens, is the guardian of the Charter of Fundamental Rights.  As the representative of the European people, Parliament therefore has the imperative not to remain silent in the face of the tragedies taking place on our borders, and the obligation to express the authority and value of the democratic mandate. As a Group of Socialists and Democrats, we continue to call for a cease-fire on Syria, where the din of bombs continues to dominate the interweaving of formal and informal negotiations that could find a less dead-end solution to this conflict. Five years after the start of the war, it is still difficult to see the minimum conditions for lasting peace. We therefore call, with greater conviction, for an effort by all the forces involved to reach an agreement which will, first and the first and the way, support the Syrian people.

name: József NAGY
text: Writing. \u2012 I welcome the motion for a resolution. We are witnessing the challenges that the migrant crisis poses to Europe. The EU is now learning to deal with this situation: we are looking for solutions, we are setting up agencies, we are trying to protect our borders. However, we must not forget that similar migratory flows can continue to hit Europe in the future, and we must pay more attention to eliminating the root causes. We must therefore pay attention to what is going on in Syria and do everything in our power to put an end to it.

name: Victor NEGRESCU
text: in writing. ‒ I voted for this motion for a resolution, which condemns all attacks against civilians and civilian infrastructure in Syria. The need for humanitarian access to the Syrian people is of the utmost importance.

name: Momchil NEKOV
text: in writing. – Recent events in Syria, and especially in Aleppo, have once again put important international players in a situation of conflict between them. I would like to recall that this situation is also detrimental to Syrians directly affected by the conflict, as well as to countries that will have to deal with increased migrant pressures for which they are not to blame, but because of their geographical proximity are on the front line when it comes to illegal immigrants from conflict regions. One of these countries is my country – Bulgaria. I am convinced that the lasting solution to the conflict in Syria, as well as its derivative refugee crisis, is directly linked to the cooperation of the countries participating in the International Syria Support Group, which include EU countries, Russia, the US, China, Turkey, Egypt, Iran and Saudi Arabia. By supporting this motion for a resolution, I call on these countries to overcome their differences and think about syrians, as well as the full effect this situation has on the whole EU. Instability in Syria means even more uncertainty and problems in general, but especially on countries directly affected by it, such as my country – Bulgaria.

name: Luděk NIEDERMAYER
text: Writing. \u2012 I consider it important that the EP condemned in the resolution all crimes against the civilian population of Syria and systematic violations of human rights and international humanitarian law in connection with terrorist acts committed by the so-called Islamic State and other radical armed groups against the Syrian population. We should have the courage to point out that attacks bordering on war crimes and crimes against humanity are also permissed by the Assad regime and russia, which is helping it. The EU should speak in a more decisive and forceful voice and incite its engagement in Syria on the part of the Kurdish and moderate Arab opposition, and categorically reject Russia's claim that it cannot discern the moderate and radical opposition in Syria, which it has alibiically advocated for massacres of civilians in Aleppo in airstrikes knowingly targeting civilian targets, including hospitals.

name: Franz OBERMAYR
text: Writing. I abstained from voting on this report because the resolution completely excludes radical Islamist tendencies. Not a single word is lost here about the Islamic State, for which Russia and Assad are blamed as the de facto sole culprits for the misery in Aleppo.

name: Urmas PAET
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported. The consistent killing of civilians and the bombing of hospitals in the Syrian city of Aleppo must be stopped immediately. It is deeply regrettable that Russia is not willing to contribute to the ceasefire in Aleppo in order to deliver humanitarian aid to those in need and to allow civilians to leave safely. It is high time for EU foreign ministers to come up with a plan for helping to achieve peace and delivering humanitarian aid to Syria in cooperation with the UN.

name: Maite PAGAZAURTUNDÚA
text: in writing. What's happening in Aleppo is atrocious. It is a catastrophe of enormous dimensions, and the most horrible face of the Syrian war. In the city there are children, wounded and entire families in need of evacuation. Violations of International Humanitarian Law are there. I do not merely support this resolution: I would like to call on the entire international community in general, and the European institutions in particular, to put all technical, financial and diplomatic means to work in order to obtain the opening of humanitarian corridors. We can't just stand by.

name: Demetris PAPADAKIS
text: Writing. \u2012 The suffering suffered indiscriminately by innocent civilians in Syria is an unacceptable violation of international humanitarian law. I am deeply concerned about the ongoing and indiscriminate bombing of civilians in Aleppo and the cessation of humanitarian aid deliveries. I supported the resolution because it stresses the need for a cessation of hostilities, as the last remaining hope to avoid another violent escalation of the war. I underline the special responsibility of the co-chairs of the International Syria Support Group (ISSG), the United States and Russia, as well as the other issg members. High Representative/Vice-President Federica Mogherini, the International Community and the United Nations must use all necessary means and exert diplomatic pressure to end the indiscriminate aerial bombardment of civilians. Finally, with regard to the ceasefire, it must be implemented, respected and extended in order to allow full access for humanitarian aid to the areas under siege.

name: Gilles PARGNEAUX
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the resolution on Syria. In this conflict, Europe has a role to play. We have been the driving forces in the restoration of relations with Iran. We must therefore use this channel of discussions to put pressure on a key player on the Syrian ground. The issue is important, namely whether Europe can provide a credible and tangible response to a conflict in which, among the diplomatic actors, it is the only one to suffer the consequences and yet the only one not sitting at the negotiating table.

name: Margot PARKER
text: in writing. ‒ This is a non-legislative and non-binding resolution. UKIP remains gravely concerned by the ongoing conflict in Syria and is fully supportive of efforts to create a lasting and peaceful political solution. However, we cannot support EU posturing on foreign policy issues or any calls for EU action. The United Nations, primarily the Security Council, remains the most relevant forum for achieving a lasting solution. Therefore we abstained on this resolution.

name: Aldo PATRICIELLO
text: in writing. \u2012 With reference to the motion for a resolution on the situation in Syria, I believe that joint action is needed in the face of increased hostilities in that country. In the Syrian conflict, according to the agencies, not only military targets but also medical facilities have been hit in the last period, causing several civilian casualties.  Since the beginning of the conflict, the European Union has been one of the main providers of humanitarian aid for people fleeing violence and destruction. However, the lack of international agreement makes it increasingly difficult to reach a negotiated solution. It is therefore necessary to take cohesive action by all the members of the International Support Group for Syria, with the aim of facilitating the conclusion of a stable and lasting truce and a political solution.  Given, therefore, the importance of this proposal, I would like to express a positive opinion on the

name: Alojz PETERLE
text: in writing. ‒ The EPP Group Members believe that a lasting solution in Syria requires a political transition through a Syrian-led inclusive process with the support of the international community. All parties in the conflict should ensure the protection of the civilian population and honour their obligations under international humanitarian law and human rights law. Definitely, peace in Syria will not be achieved by an externally lead, non-inclusive approach. It is a matter for Syria, with Syrians.

name: Marijana PETIR
text: Written. ‒ The difficult situation in Syria has deteriorated further despite all efforts to reach a peaceful settlement recently.  Across the country, there are attacks on civilians and civilian infrastructure. Clashes have escalated the most in the city of Aleppo, which suffers heavy bombardments, which single out attacks on health facilities. We cannot tolerate a pre-existing situation that does not give innocent civilians access to basic humanitarian aid and basic healthcare.  I welcome this resolution and the European Union's emergency humanitarian initiative for the Aleppo, as they clearly recognise the importance of normalising the delivery of humanitarian aid, the execution of medical evacuations and the provision of healthcare to those in need. We recognise the fact that the European Union is one of the largest providers of humanitarian aid to people fleeing the protracted war in Syria, but we must also be aware of our responsibility to reach a lasting political agreement on peace in Syria. I believe that the EU must sever all trade and economic relations with countries that fund terrorist groups in Syria to send a message that human lives come first and that it is willing to do everything it can to protect them.

name: Pina PICIERNO
text: in writing. \u2012 The escalating hostilities and the dramatic deterioration of the humanitarian situation in Syria, particularly in Aleppo, is of enormous concern. I strongly condemn all attacks on civilians and civilian infrastructure, including medical facilities, and the continuation of sieges that make it impossible to provide assistance to the population, including many women and children, who desperately need essential humanitarian goods. The recent attacks on an aid convoy and a Red Crescent warehouse near Aleppo represent serious violations of international humanitarian law. All parties to the conflict must immediately cease all attacks on civilians and civilian infrastructure, work towards an effective cessation of hostilities, stop all sieges and allow quick and secure access to humanitarian agencies so that they can reach the populations in need of help.  I welcome the EU's emergency humanitarian initiative for Aleppo, which is intended to provide urgent assistance and ensure the health evacuation of the injured and the sick. I support the call for members of the International Support Group for Syria to reach a stable and lasting truce and for the High Representative to define a common EU strategy on Syria.

name: Tonino PICULA
text: Written. ‒ The situation has deteriorated dramatically and I am concerned about the lack of international unity, making it increasingly difficult for negotiations to reach a solution. Washington and Moscow must find common ground, as must other participants in the International Syria Support Group. The EU should continue its efforts and collectively, through the actions of the Vice-President of the Commission/High Representative of the Union for Foreign and Security Policy, play a more prominent role in mediation. We are one of the largest providers of humanitarian aid for people fleeing prolonged violence and destruction in Syria. I deeply regret the attack on the Humanitarian Convoy and Red Crescent Warehouse and condemn them unconditionally as a grave and troubling violation of international humanitarian law and a possible war crime. The perpetrators must be held accountable. I strongly condemn all attacks on civilians and lack of humanitarian access for the needy Syrian people. I express deep concern about human suffering in besieged areas of the city of Aleppo and across Syria affecting many women and children. I welcome the EU's urgent humanitarian initiative for the Aleppo.  I call on the VP/HIGH REPRESENTATIVE of the Union for Foreign and Security Policy to renew efforts to reach a common EU strategy for Syria aimed at facilitating a political agreement in Syria. It has become an urgent decision to end the conflict as soon as possible, in particular the bombing of civilians, and must ensure the smooth delivery of humanitarian aid to all those in need.

name: João PIMENTA LOPES
text: in writing. \u2012 We are facing another resolution with an unacceptable nature of interference. Presented as a resolution directed only to the humanitarian issue, it appears to be a text of evident partiality, treating equally what is not equal. The ongoing investigation processes into the attack on the humanitarian convoy, or the Us's responsibility for violating the ceasefire with aerial bombardment, are omitted. The reference to concrete facts devoid of context serves the interests of those who, in the name of the humanitarian cause, pursue other objectives. History shows how the call for humanitarian intervention preceded, in various situations, a military escalation of military intervention and occupation. This was the case with the resolution adopted in this Parliament before the military intervention in Libya.  The resolution not only takes sides on one side, but at the same time omits the need to fight terrorist forces on the ground, it does not recognize the Syrian government's right to defend itself in a conflict that has lasted for more than 5 years and has been promoted and financed from abroad, fulfilling the US agenda of destabilization and control of the Middle East , instrumentalizing the legitimate and just aspirations of the Syrian people. Causes that are omitted by obvious complicity. Obviously we voted against it.

name: Franck PROUST
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this resolution, which was jointly shared by several political groups on the situation in Syria. The war in Syria means more than 400,000 dead, 13.5 million people in need of humanitarian assistance and nearly 5 million refugees. The Syrian conflict has become the variable of adjustment of the selfishness of certain powers. To pursue a foreign policy strategy by playing with the lives of innocent civilians is unbearable. The resolution of this unprecedented crisis, of course, goes beyond the role of the European Parliament: it is up to the States, their governments, to finally take action. But citizens should be aware that at a time when Parliament is trying, to the extent of its remit, to contribute, for example, to the humanitarian aid effort for Syria, extremist MPs, such as those of Marine Le Pen's group, voted in 2015 against budget transfers for humanitarian aid. As for us, members of the European People's Party, we fought for almost 450 million euros to be released in 2016 to help the population victims of the atrocities of Bashar al-Assad's regime.

name: Julia REID
text: in writing. ‒ This is a non-legislative and non-binding resolution. UKIP remains gravely concerned by the ongoing conflict in Syria and is fully supportive of efforts to create a lasting and peaceful political solution. However, we cannot support EU posturing on foreign policy issues or any calls for EU action. The United Nations, primarily the Security Council, remains the most relevant forum for achieving a lasting solution. Therefore we abstained on this resolution.

name: Sofia RIBEIRO
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour, taking into account the current situation and the continuing escalation of hostilities in Syria, especially in Aleppo, a city that has been subjected to heavy air bombardment, including attacks on medical infrastructure, and considering that the situation has deteriorated rapidly and dramatically, despite the efforts made by the international community to end hostilities. In this way, the European Union must continue to make one of the greatest contributions to humanitarian aid for people fleeing historical violence and destruction in Syria, although the lack of international unity undermines the prospects for a negotiated solution to the war in Syria.

name: Liliana RODRIGUES
text: in writing. We condemn attacks on civilians and civilian infrastructure, continued sieges and the impossibility of humanitarian aid for the Syrian population in need. We condemn the recent attacks on humanitarian aid convoys near Aleppo, a serious violation of international humanitarian law. We pay tribute to the humanitarian workers who died in the effort for Syrian citizens. We call on the parties to the conflict, especially Russia and the Assad regime, to immediately cease attacks on civilians and civilian infrastructure and to take steps towards a complete cessation of hostilities.

name: Inma RODRÍGUEZ-PIÑERO
text: in writing. There is currently a general worsening of the humanitarian situation in Syria and the US-Russian truce has failed. War crimes are underway, attacking much of Aleppo's population with anti-bunker and incendiary bombs, and there are only thirty operational doctors. It calls for maximum pressure to stop attacks, allow open and continuous humanitarian access to those in need, and resume political negotiations under the auspices of the United Nations in Geneva as quickly as possible. That is why I voted in favour of this motion for a resolution.

name: Claude ROLIN
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the resolution on the situation in Syria, because the heavy aerial bombardment, particularly in Aleppo, caused human and diplomatic damage. The European Union is one of the main providers of humanitarian aid to the people. Without international unity, it will be very difficult to find a negotiated solution to the war in Syria. Attacks targeting civilians are intolerable and also prevent the delivering of much-needed humanitarian aid. Russia and the regime of Bashar al-Assad must allow an end to hostilities and urgently open the way for humanitarian organizations to help the population. The European Union must work to comply with the agreements and obligations of the International Support Group for Syria.

name: Fernando RUAS
text: in writing. \u2012 Materials and objects in contact with food are widely used in everyday life (e.g. food packaging, cooking utensils).
