When put in contact with food and depending on their composition and properties, the materials behave differently, transmitting parts of their constituents to them. However, the chemicals that these objects emanat, can alter the composition of foodstuffs endangering human health. Although these products are subject to Community rules (to which they are legally bound), the existing Regulation lays down only the general safety requirements and also provides for the possibility of specific measures in accordance with the legislation of each Member State.  So far, only common specific measures have been adopted within the EU for four materials/objects.  The specific measures adopted by one Member State may be different from those taken into account by the other, so that the absence of common European measures not only hinders the internal market, but also leads to increased compliance costs (often transferred to consumers) and also result in a loss of competitiveness and innovation/development capacity. Because I consider this uniformity in the area of food security to be important, I voted in favour of this own-initiative report.

name: Tokia SAÏFI
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this resolution, which condemns the intensification of hostilities in Syria, particularly in Aleppo, a city that has suffered heavy aerial bombardment.  The resolution condemns recent attacks on a Red Crescent humanitarian convoy and infrastructure. It is no longer tolerable that civilians, especially children, are the targets of aerial bombardment. These indiscriminate strikes constitute serious violations of international humanitarian law.  There is an urgent need for the Union and its Member States to continue their mediation efforts in favour of a peace agreement in Syria, particularly since the failure of the ceasefire and the escalation of violence.  As such, the Vice-President/High Representative must present a European strategy for Syria as soon as possible.

name: Lola SÁNCHEZ CALDENTEY
text: in writing. "U2012 Despite supporting the bulk of the content of this Syria Resolution, which calls on all parties to cease bombing, open humanitarian corridors and reopen negotiations for a ceasefire, since We have voted abstention on the ground that the resolution lacks the purported equidistance, by pointing out greater responsibilities to one of the parties to the conflict and , therefore, to place the debate in the key to a bipolar choice between two powers which we oppose from our conviction that it must be Syrian civil society that will lead the way to peace, democracy and social justice that neither party to the conflict seems to be interested in achieving.

name: Daciana Octavia SÂRBU
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted for the European Parliament resolution which strongly condemns all attacks against civilians and civilian infrastructure, the continuation of sieges in Syria and the blocking of humanitarian access to Syrians in need of aid.  It is inadmissible to remain silent about human suffering in the besieged areas of Aleppo and across the country, which affects many women and children, who do not have access to essential humanitarian supplies and who are in desperate need of food, drinking water and medical services or medicines.  This slaughter must be stopped, and international society must engage in serious negotiations with the Assad regime and Russia to stop the atrocities on civilians in Aleppo.

name: Maria Lidia SENRA RODRÍGUEZ
text: in writing. This resolution is another example of the one-way propaganda campaign in which we are immersed, which presents us with a single guilty "side", Russia and the Syrian Government, a rather hypocritical stance when some Member States of the Union, in collaboration with the US, trained and financed terrorist groups operating in the Middle East and Europe. The U.S. strategy of unilateralism and the Union's continuing foreign policy has already seen the consequences it brought in the case of Libya. We have to decide whether we want to take up that path, or position ourselves as a facilitator of dialogue and political resolution of the conflict. The Union must demand that the United States resume dialogue with Russia in the context of the conflict in Syria in order to lead to a ceasefire that gives way to a negotiating table for peace with all non-terrorist political actors. It should not be forgotten that the failure of the last truce was the cause of the U.S. bombing of Syrian Army positions in Deir Azzor. As long as the European Parliament's resolutions continue to present a single culprit of the conflict, and continue to elude their own responsibility in the conflict, my vote will be against it.

name: Siôn SIMON
text: in writing. ‒ Today I voted for the European Parliament resolution on Syria. It strongly condemns all crimes committed against the civilian population of Syria, urges all parties to the conflict to stop all attacks on civilians and civilian infrastructure, and calls for the EU to ensure greater international support for the increased numbers of refugees.

name: Davor ŠKRLEC
text: Written. ‒ I voted positively for this report, but this explanation of the vote is a criticism of the existing system of evaluation of the work of MEMBERS of the European Parliament solely on the basis of the statistical number of parliamentary activities potentiated in Croatia, which does not really reflect the actual quality and quantity of work, efficiency and most of all the success of parliamentary action.

name: Monika SMOLKOVÁ
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported the EP resolution on Syria because the EU needs to renew its efforts to develop a common EU strategy for Syria, to resume negotiations in order to facilitate the establishment of a stable ceasefire and to step up action to achieve a lasting political solution in Syria. The European Union is one of the main contributors to humanitarian aid to those fleeing unprecedented violence and destruction in Syria. In the resolution, we condemned all attacks on civilians and civilian infrastructure, the continuation of various sieges in Syria. We have expressed our deep concern at the suffering of people in besieged areas, which also concern many women and children who do not have access to basic humanitarian material and urgently need food, clean water and medical equipment.  All participants in the international Syria support group must resume negotiations in order to facilitate a stable ceasefire and achieve a lasting political solution in Syria.

name: Michaela ŠOJDROVÁ
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported the European Parliament resolution on Syria. The war in Syria is now in its fifth year and has claimed nearly half a million lives, almost three times more than the war in Yugoslavia in the first half of the 1990's. Needless to say, this war is a great source of migration and instability. I am therefore ready to support any initiative that deals with this conflict in good faith in order to contribute to its end. In retro fact, I regret that the West has not been more active in this war, although our engagement has been effectively made difficult by a number of factors, such as the clutter of the conflict, the various interests of regional powers, and the large number of warring parties. In particular, the EP resolution deals with the drastic situation in Aleppo, which has become a symbol of this war. The once exuded and rich city gradually turned into ruins, mostly under the rush of bombing government troops and, more recently, the Russian Federation. The latest events, in which a number of civilians have been killed, have provoked our condemnation. The resolution is therefore primarily an appeal to the Assad regime and Russia to put an end to all attacks on civilians and civilian infrastructure. I support this appeal, as well as the call for EU High Representative Mogherini to take steps towards greater EU involvement in the search for a peaceful solution in Syria.

name: Igor ŠOLTES
text: Writing. Despite the negotiations and the brief ceasefire, the war in Syria has certainly not ended and the situation is getting worse. In light of the recent developments, the European Parliament has therefore strongly condemned, with a resolution, all attacks on civilians and civilian infrastructure, the continuation of sieges and the lack of humanitarian aid. At the same time, he strongly condemned the recent attack on a humanitarian convoy and red cross depot near the city of Aleppo, and called on all parties involved, especially Russia and the Assad regime, to stop attacks on civilians. In its resolution, Parliament calls on all parties involved in the International Syria Support Group to continue negotiations to establish a stable ceasefire and to step up action leading to a lasting political solution. I believe that a peaceful solution to the conflict in Syria is necessary for peace in the wider region and in the world, which is why I voted in favour of the resolution.

name: Ivan ŠTEFANEC
text: Writing. \u2012 Despite promises of a ceasefire, the Syrian civil war, with the hearty contribution of the Armed Forces of the Russian Federation, reaches the dimensions of a humanitarian and security disaster. The result is not only the suffering of the civilian population, but also the threat of new migration waves. We call for an end to the bombing of civilian targets, the creation of humanitarian corridors and the resumption of political negotiations between the opposing parties to the conflict.

name: Dubravka ŠUICA
text: Written. ‒ Hostilities in Syria have escalated again, especially in Aleppo, and the situation is deteriorating at all times. Among other things, hospitals and warehouses are being bombed and humanitarian convoys are being attacked.  The EU can contribute to resolving the situation in Syria – humanitarian aid, encouraging conductive negotiations and overseeing compliance with the ceasefire reached. The lack of international unity makes negotiations more difficult, and human rights violations urgently need to be stopped. That is why I support the European Parliament's resolution on the situation in Syria calling for a re-ceasefire and condemns attacks and atrocities against civilians, the siege of Syrian territory and the lack of humanitarian procedures and assistance to victims, in particular the lack of food, drinking water and medicine.

name: Eleftherios SYNADINOS
text: Writing. \u2012 The EU continues to practice indirect support for Islamists and opposes the only force that fought alongside Assad, Russia.

name: Adam SZEJNFELD
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 Nearly half a million Syrians have been killed and 11 million forced to leave their homes since the syrian conflict began in 2011, almost half of whom have left the country, moving in particular to Turkey, Egypt, Jordan, Iraq and Lebanon. At present, we cannot talk about the situation in Syria solely as a revolution, but as an international conflict in which various world powers and terrorist organisations have been involved. Unfortunately, despite five years of diplomatic efforts by the international community, the chances of a quick resolution of the conflict seem minimal and a political future acceptable to all parties to the conflict is impossible to scratch. Especially as the situation has deteriorated dramatically and rapidly in recent months despite the efforts of the international community to cease hostilities. The European Union has repeatedly accused the Assad regime of fomenting conflict and crimes against civilians, but the resolution rightly points out that president Putin, who cannot be seen as a partner in peace talks, should also be blamed for the deaths of thousands of Syrian citizens. The EU humanitarian initiative for Aleppo, which, in addition to raising funds for humanitarian needs, aims to enable the evacuation of wounded and sick people from eastern Aleppo, especially women, children and the elderly, is to be welcomed.

name: Claudia ȚAPARDEL
text: in writing. \u2012 The dramatic situation in Syria continues to worry the international community and the European institutions. The way in which the various factions involved in the domestic military conflict and supported by certain international actors do not understand to comply with ceasefire agreements negotiated at the highest level is deplorable. The result is a growing number of civilian casualties and refugees, especially in the context of the siege of government troops on Aleppo and the bombing of humanitarian convoys. Instead of a joint offensive against Islamic State and other terrorist groups, Russian-backed government troops and United States-backed rebels choose to confront each other over any peaceful solution. The European Union, as an international actor, neighbouring this conflict zone, condemns the violation of international humanitarian law and urges the warring parties to cease hostilities as soon as possible and to work for a sustainable future of the Syrian state, in accordance with Resolution No. 2254 of the UN Security Council. In this context, the co-chairs of the International Support Group for Syria, the United States and Russia have an important responsibility to resume negotiations. I support the adoption of these resolutions.

name: Marc TARABELLA
text: In writing. As Syrian regime forces advance in eastern Aleppo, Moscow has deployed S-300 air defense systems in the port city of Tartus, where it has a military base. Diplomacy has stalled. The eastern districts of Aleppo have been under a barrage of bombs of unprecedented intensity for more than ten days. Outrage is growing in Western capitals, but diplomacy seems to have stalled: Russians and Americans have broken off dialogue. While Washington said it was considering "diplomatic and military options," Russia deployed S-300 air defense systems to Tartus, a coastal city in northwestern Syria where it has military port facilities. With its S-300s and S-400s, Russia is providing air defense of its two anchor points in Syria, the port of Tartus and the Hmeimim airbase in Latakia province, where the Russian air force has dozens of bombers, ground attack aircraft and helicopters. These batteries are in particular a response to the threat of missiles fired from the Mediterranean Sea. Aleppo has become a real butchery!

name: Pavel TELIČKA
text: in writing. ‒ The civil war in Syria, five years in, represents one of the worst humanitarian disasters of the 21st century. The pro-Assad coalition forces, including Russia, have launched incessant and worsening attacks against civilians and civilian infrastructure. The continuation of sieges and the lack of humanitarian access to the people in Syria have become more alarming with every passing day. The human suffering in the besieged areas of Aleppo and throughout the rest of Syria has affected nearly everyone, including women and children, who lack access to humanitarian goods, food, clean water and medical supplies. I voted in favour of the resolution on Syria, and I deeply deplore and unconditionally condemn the recent attacks on humanitarian relief convoys, which represent a severe violation of international humanitarian law and embody possible war crimes. I urge all military forces, particularly the Assad regime and Russia, to return to the ceasefire agreement of 26 September 2016.

name: Ruža TOMAŠIĆ
text: Written. ‒ The bloody conflicts in Syria have left more than 250,000 dead and 12 million people have fled their homes. What began as another Arab Spring struggle against autocratic rule has over time transformed into a brutal war between regional groups, world powers and the terror of the Islamic State. The exceptional complexity of the situation unfortunately makes it impossible to draw impartial and objective conclusions about the culprits of the conflict, which is one of the reasons why dozens of innocent people are still killed every day six years after the conflict began. The latest sad example occurred after the United States and Russia agreed in September to cease airstrikes, after which at least 248 people, most of them civilians, were killed, many involved in humanitarian actions following an agreed ceasefire. The situation in Syria requires urgent constructive international engagement without a "finger in the pocket". Until the same is realized, thousands of innocents will continue to die in conflicts that have no sign of an end.

name: Romana TOMC
text: Writing. - I supported the motion for a European Parliament resolution on Syria. Violence in Syria is intensifying, particularly in Aleppo, which is the target of heavy air strikes and where medical facilities are also under attack. The situation has become dramatic and is rapidly deteriorating, despite the international community's efforts to dissuad hostilities. It calls on all warring parties to immediately stop attacking civilians and infrastructure, including water and electricity infrastructure, to take measures to end all sieges and to give humanitarian agencies uneasy and secure access. It strongly supports the demands of the UN Special Envoy to end violence and protect civilians and infrastructure, and for a weekly 48-hour ceasefire to at least give humanitarian access to Aleppo and the evacuation of the wounded and sick.

name: Estefanía TORRES MARTÍNEZ
text: in writing. "U2012 Despite supporting the bulk of the content of this Syria Resolution, which calls on all parties to cease bombing, open humanitarian corridors and reopen negotiations for a ceasefire, since We have voted abstention on the ground that the resolution lacks the purported equidistance, by pointing out greater responsibilities to one of the parties to the conflict and , therefore, to place the debate in the key to a bipolar choice between two powers which we oppose from our conviction that it must be Syrian civil society that will lead the way to peace, democracy and social justice that neither party to the conflict seems to be interested in achieving.

name: Ramon TREMOSA i BALCELLS
text: in writing. ‒ The situation in Syria is deplorable and the bombing of hospitals in Aleppo is a war crime. Assad and the Russian forces have to be called to account. The EU together with the US should impose a no—fly zone as soon as possible and a humanitarian corridors to take civilians out of that hellish situation.

name: Mylène TROSZCZYNSKI
text: In writing. It is a matter for Parliament to interfere in the battle of Aleppo by putting all parties back to back. Added to this is the primary Russophobia of the European institutions.  All the resolutions presented amount to supporting forces opposed to armies loyal to the internationally recognized Syrian government. I voted against it.

name: Kazimierz Michał UJAZDOWSKI
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 Six years of war in Syria has killed 250,000 people and forced 12 million people to flee their homes. In the face of a relentless conflict, the majority of syrians do not have access to education, health and social care. In September, a thaat was negotiated to end airstrikes on rebel-held positions and allow the two conflicting parties access to humanitarian aid. Despite these findings, Syrian government forces have recently intensified their attacks and recently bombed the country's second-largest city, Aleppo. The war will not be put to an end without a political agreement at international level. The Countries of the European Union must press with a consistent voice in this direction to resolve the conflict of which civilians are primarily victims. I voted in favour of the resolution.

name: Miguel URBÁN CRESPO
text: in writing. "U2012 Despite supporting the bulk of the content of this Syria Resolution, which calls on all parties to cease bombing, open humanitarian corridors and reopen negotiations for a ceasefire, since We have voted abstention on the ground that the resolution lacks the purported equidistance, by pointing out greater responsibilities to one of the parties to the conflict and , therefore, to place the debate in the key to a bipolar choice between two powers which we oppose from our conviction that it must be Syrian civil society that will lead the way to peace, democracy and social justice that neither party to the conflict seems to be interested in achieving.

name: Viktor USPASKICH
text: Writing. – I strongly condemn all attacks on civilians and civilian infrastructure, the continuation of all sieges in Syria and the lack of humanitarian aid provided to the Syrian people in need. I declare that I am extremely concerned that people are suffering in besieged areas of Aleppo and throughout Syria, many women and children who do not have access to the necessary humanitarian supplies and who desperately need food, clean water and medical supplies.

name: Ivo VAJGL
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the motion for a resolution on Syria. The conflict in Syria is well into its sixth year and has claimed the lives of more than a quarter of a million people. Up to 14 million people are thought to be in need of humanitarian assistance within Syria, while almost five million are in hard-to-reach or besieged areas. Despite international efforts to reach a ceasefire, violence has escalated in recent weeks, with Aleppo in particular facing heavy bombardments. The resolution urges all parties to the conflict immediately to stop all attacks on civilians and civilian infrastructure, including water and electrical infrastructure, to lift all sieges and to grant unhindered and safe access to international aid workers. I voted in favour because I believe that the EU must do everything in its power to work against terrorism in Syria.

name: Ramón Luis VALCÁRCEL SISO
text: in writing. I supported this statement by the High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy because it is urgent to move towards a political solution to the Syrian conflict. The war will soon enter its sixth year and there is a palpable risk that it will continue to continue to continue, with both human and material costs. Resolution 2254 adopted in December 2015 by the United Nations Security Council establishes a roadmap for initiating a political process in Syria – starring the Syrians themselves – that will lead to an end to the contest. In this way, the key to achieving peace is now, more than ever, to promote and strengthen the political will to implement this roadmap on the ground. At a time of estrangement from the positions of the United States and Russia, the Union must play a role that will help to restore dialogue between the parties and ultimately consolidate the cessation of hostilities agreed only a few weeks ago by the United States and Russia.

name: Ángela VALLINA
text: in writing. This resolution is another example of the one-way propaganda campaign in which we are immersed, which presents us with a single guilty "side", Russia and the Syrian Government, a rather hypocritical stance when some Member States of the Union, in collaboration with the US, trained and financed terrorist groups operating in the Middle East and Europe. The U.S. strategy of unilateralism and the Union's continuing foreign policy has already seen the consequences it brought in the case of Libya. We have to decide whether we want to take up that path, or position ourselves as a facilitator of dialogue and political resolution of the conflict. The Union must demand that the United States resume dialogue with Russia in the context of the conflict in Syria in order to lead to a ceasefire that gives way to a negotiating table for peace with all non-terrorist political actors. It should not be forgotten that the failure of the last truce was the cause of the U.S. bombing of Syrian Army positions in Deir Azzor. As long as the European Parliament's resolutions continue to present a single culprit of the conflict, and continue to elude their own responsibility in the conflict, my vote will be against it.

name: Hilde VAUTMANS
text: Written. The situation is dramatic. The images won't let go of me. A mom, dead in a chair, covered in dust, with her two children by her side. Syrian children as many as five have only known war in their lives. They deserve a life without violence. And the need for solutions is also high for Europe. The instability at our external borders, migration, the rise of religious extremism mean that there is no alternative but to act. Europe must finally show its leadership. That is why I voted in favour of this resolution on Syria.

name: Marie-Christine VERGIAT
text: In writing. The European Parliament has adopted a new resolution on the situation in Syria, expressing concern about the situation in Aleppo, which is understandable. But this resolution only means condemning certain belligerents, namely Russia and the regime of Bashar al-Assad, forgetting the others altogether, including Daesh, a group to which the resolution does not once refer, or radical armed groups such as Al-Nusra. As if the conflict in Syria was born yesterday and as if it were born out of nowhere. Not the slightest compassion, or even reference to the thousands of people that this terrible conflict is chasing away from home. Not a word about the solutions to offer them. No humanitarian visas. No mandatory resettlement program. In short, one more resolution that does not care about the causes or the real consequences of a conflict in which impotence is evident and hypocrisy even more so. I abstained out of solidarity with the victims of this war which has lasted too long and because this text calls in particular for humanitarian aid to be able to arrive unhindered.

name: Miguel VIEGAS
text: in writing. The resolution omits that this is a war between a legitimate government in defense of the integrity of its territory and armed armies trained by western powers. Omit that form the United States that violated the ceasefire agreed on September 26. Everyone is certainly recalling a resolution in everything similar to that adopted in this House on Libya. At the time, the Libyan government had ceased to serve the interests of the same Western powers that created and armed the militias that destroyed a country that is now in the run." Let's stop being hypocrisy. We call for an end to economic and diplomatic sanctions against the Syrian government. What matters is that they cease to arm and form the rebels, replacing the weapons with dialogue and helping to build a political solution that will end the war and humanitarian aid and create conditions for the reconstruction of a country that has already suffered too much from this conflict.

name: Harald VILIMSKY
text: Writing. The resolution completely excludes radical Islamist tendencies and Islamism as decisive factors in the civil war. Only Russia and the Assad government, which are blamed for the suffering in Aleppo, are mentioned by name. That is why I abstained from voting.

name: Daniele VIOTTI
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the motion for a resolution on the situation in Syria, which strongly condemns the crimes committed against the civilian population and the systematic violations of human rights and international humanitarian law committed by the so-called Islamic State. The proposal calls on all parties to the conflict to put an immediate end to attacks on civilians and civilian infrastructure and to allow safe access to humanitarian workers; urges all parties to restore the ceasefire agreement of 26 September and calls on the EU to ensure greater international support to cope with the increase in the number of refugees.

name: Udo VOIGT
text: Writing. The motion for a resolution cannot be outdone in its imbalance. It unilaterally criticises Russia and the Syrian government for alleged and in no way proven attacks on civilians and infrastructure, but makes no mention of the US responsibility for the escalation of the situation through direct and indirect support of armed rebel groups, as well as bombingand other hostilities attributable to the United States and its allies, in violation of Syria's state sovereignty. A clear 'no' was required here.

name: Julie WARD
text: in writing. ‒ I condemn and deplore the recent attacks on civilians and humanitarian convoys in Syria, in particular the devastating bombardment of Aleppo. I have been working on the Syria case since 2013, prior to my election, when I was an Oxfam volunteer. The international community must do more to bring all parties to the conflict around the table, in order for ceasefires to be agreed and for more humanitarian aid to be provided to those suffering in the war.

name: Lieve WIERINCK
text: in writing. – I voted in favour of this parliamentary resolution because it is important to recognise the gravity of the situation in Syria. The European Union plays an important role in supporting the refugees who are a result of this conflict. However, it is important that we act collectively and in a unified way through the High Representative of the EU and the administration that supports her. I support the call on some parties involved immediately to stop the bombing of civilians and other forms of attacks on these vulnerable groups. At the same time, I strongly welcome the humanitarian aid and support for Aleppo that is being organised. Finally, I support the call to the parties involved to resume peaceful negotiations and recognise the importance of the UN Special Envoy in facilitating these negotiations.

name: Jana ŽITŇANSKÁ
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported the resolution on the situation in Syria. Unfortunately, the conflict in Syria has been going on for six years and has claimed an incredible number of human lives, as well as over twelve million people, who have been forced to leave their homes and seek refuge, whether in neighbouring countries or in Europe, as a result. Over time, the situation in Syria has been thrown into a huge humanitarian catastrophe, where the education system, health or any infrastructure is not working and neighbouring countries are no longer able to cope with the unprecedented influx of refugees. The highlight of all this is that, although the parties to the conflict have formally committed themselves to allowing humanitarian access, they have ultimately failed to comply with the agreements. The resolution therefore reflects all these facts, condemns the attacks on civilians and infrastructure and urges that they be stopped. Although this resolution is not an instant solution to the disastrous situation in Syria, it is an expression of the European Union's deep condemnation of such behaviour by the parties to the conflict.

name: Milan ZVER
text: Writing. \ I voted in favour of the European Parliament resolution of 6 October 2016 on Syria. Reports say violence in Syria is intensifying, particularly in Aleppo, which is the target of heavy air bombardment and where medical facilities are also under attack. The civilian population in besieged areas in Aleppo and elsewhere in Syria, also the victims of women and children, does not have access to basic humanitarian aid and urgently needs food, clean water and medical supplies. I therefore join the call for all warring parties to stop attacking civilians and infrastructure and to take immediate and convincing measures to end hostilities and sieges, and to give humanitarian agencies quick, safe and uneasy access to all people in need.

name: Jude KIRTON-DARLING
text: – Mr President, this week we have shown that the European Union can act quickly and decisively on climate change. By ratifying the Paris Agreement in less than a year from its negotiation, we have shown that we can unite to take assertive action. With the next round of global climate talks rapidly approaching, this is no time for us to sit on our laurels – the world cannot wait and neither should we. We must put in place policies that limit the rise in global average temperatures to no more than 1.5° Celsius, while allowing a just transition which provides working people and their communities with high-quality jobs and produces sustainable growth for our economies. With today's resolution, which I wholeheartedly support, we have sent out a clear message to the negotiators in the upcoming talks. All economic sectors, all industries and all peoples have their role to play. There can be no more excuses; now is the time for action.

name: Krisztina MORVAI
text: - Mr President, my fellow Members, I would like to thank you for your support. European people are increasingly annoyed and annoyed by the many visible mergers between European decision-makers and various economic lobby groups. Well, it just occurred to me by accident, it has nothing to do with the fact that, once again, in the large-scale report on climate change, this parliament did not vote for an amendment that I think is of great importance, and which would have been about us fighting climate change on one line, right, very much on the other, these transnational corporations and companies that are known to be engaged in activities that are not. , causing enormous damage to the environment and thus to the climate. There would have been an amendment that would have started negotiations on the matter, so that they would be systematically held accountable and that impunity for these companies should end. Miraculously, even the Greens did not vote for this amendment, let alone the largest faction, the People's Party.

name: Paloma LÓPEZ BERMEJO
text: – Mr President, I abstained from the proposals for COP 22 because I do not think they are ambitious enough for the meeting in Marrakesh.  But I would like to address this House to warn of another element that must not go unnoticed, and it is the propaganda use that is being made of this event, of COP 22, by the Moroccan regime, trying to equip itself with an international pedigree and a green halo with which to disguise its occupation of the Saharawi people.  As parliamentarians, we must not forget that the host of COP 22 is responsible for the expulsion of the Minurso, the violation of the Guerguerat ceasefire, the repression of The Saharawi protesters in the occupied territories. May prudence not make us cowards before our hosts. I would like to conclude by reminding Gdeim Izik prisoners, now illegally confined to Rabat after six years of torture, abuse and ill-treatment for requiring a right that Morocco must respect if it is to become a respectable member of the international community. And it is the right of the Saharawi people to their self-determination.

name: Monica MACOVEI
text: – Mr President, the European Union is the global leader in combating climate change. At the Paris Conference we committed to reducing greenhouse gas emissions by 20% compared to 1990. What message do we send to people, politicians, investors, society? That we have no more time to waste, history is no longer waiting for us and let us get on the move because the train has already left, let us get on the go on the train that leads, wanting not to, to a low-carbon economy. Only then can we start a process of reindustrialisation for the 21st century.  I want to make it clear that I do not agree with the introduction of a tax on all financial transactions to finance climate change, and here I voted, therefore, against this paragraph. We need to be creative and find other sources of funding.

name: Eleonora EVI
text: – Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, we have voted in favour of this report, an important report that contains a series of calls and recommendations, but also critical ones, to address what are the next steps in combating climate change at global level. However, it is essential for me to refer to what are the serious dangers contained in this text and which are part of the Pillar of the Union in combating climate change, namely the ETS. The proposal for a global ETS is something that we clearly object to, because the ETS as a market instrument is not a sufficient instrument to deal with environmental problems and climate problems. It is essential for us to make this statement: the ETS is a system that does not work and that simply promotes financial speculation on carbon and certainly not an improvement in the condition of the planet.

name: Michał MARUSIK
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by Dear! Bad law arises not because lawmakers are driven by bad intentions. They are guided by good intentions, but very often come out of completely false, erroneous reasons. And climate law has just that. The display of anthropopression as a reason for establishing certain rights is greatly exaggerated. This anthropopression is very small, while the real reasons are hidden. And the real reasons are in the economic mechanisms. Well, if we set emissions charges, for example, carbon dioxide and emissions at some level set at the moment – for every next emissions you have to pay and trade in these emission rights – that means that poor countries that want to develop will have to pay countries that have long ago developed, so we fund such mechanisms with huge injustices to the world and stop the development of these countries and increase poverty in the world. This is unfair and wrong. This should not be done. I voted against.

name: Stanislav POLČÁK
text: – Mr President, I would like to say that the Paris Conference can certainly be described as a success. The next round is coming up and it is good that we have voted down this motion for a resolution. I myself supported him. I have to agree in part that, of course, the forces of nature have overwhelming power, and man is just a small wheel or certainly a smaller wheel in the climate change that is happening without question, but we would be foolish if we did not really try, at least with the near what we can, to influence climate change. And for this reason too, we should promote a policy of thrift. I myself think it's about how many of us are able to modestize in our own lives, how to deal sparingly with values, with energy. All of this has to do with everything. So, for this reason too, I supported this motion for a resolution.

name: Seán KELLY
text: – Mr President, I was very honoured to attend, on behalf of Parliament, the COP21 in Paris with the historic global agreement. I will be very honoured to attend COP22 in Marrakesh, Morocco, especially after we have ratified the Agreement here in Parliament, signed in the presence of Ban Ki-moon by our President, Mr  Schulz.  There is no doubt that this is the really big challenge because, if we do not save the planet, all other problems will disappear because the planet will not exist and people will not be able to live here. I am glad about the progress we are making and very pleased with the leadership that has been shown by the Commission and by the European Union generally and hope that will continue. I am of course also pleased that in my own country a great deal of research is being undertaken to come up with innovative solutions cognisant of climate change, especially in the area of sustainable agriculture, something which is not often recognised. This is the way to go.

name: Isabella ADINOLFI
text: in writing. \u2012 The resolution touches on all aspects related to climate change, highlighting above all the positive effects, including from an economic and innovation point of view, that have resulted from policies to reduce emissions and promote renewables and putting at the centre the medium and long-term objectives and sectors that will have to be involved in the reduction effort. For these reasons, I voted in favour.

name: Tim AKER
text: in writing. – We in UKIP are against this resolution because we object to the Paris Agreement and the Climate Change alarmism supported by green lobbies. They are the cause of our current damaging and counter-productive energy policy.

name: Marina ALBIOL GUZMÁN
text: in writing. After the Paris Agreement, the purposes of combating climate change are primarily based on voluntary commitments and market mechanisms. This resolution, even more ambitious, continues on the same path, so I abstained.

name: Martina ANDERSON
text: in writing. – I abstained on this report. Whilst the report contained some positive points on the very important issue of climate change, it also sees the much derided concept of emissions trading as an important tool in the future of fighting climate change. In Europe, the EU’s own Emissions Trading Scheme is widely accepted as being a very costly failure for EU climate change policy which has not brought the significant emissions reductions required and indeed promised. The EU ETS has not been cost-effective and has subsidised polluters with taxpayers’ money with its oversupply of allowances to power companies, many of which are being given ‘free’ to these companies.

name: Eric ANDRIEU
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report. It is essential that the Union as a whole ratify the Paris Agreement before COP22 in Marrakech for the agreement to enter into force. It is essential that the Union holds its place around the table in Marrakech.

name: Laima Liucija ANDRIKIENĖ
text: in writing. ‒ I have voted in favour of the motion for a resolution on the implementation of the Paris Agreement and the 2016 UN Climate Change Conference in Marrakesh, Morocco. The 22nd Session of the Conference of Parties to the United Nations Convention on Climate Change (COP 22) will be held in Marrakesh (Morocco) in November 2016. It will focus on actions in order to achieve the priorities of the Paris Agreement, especially related to adaptation, transparency, technology transfer, mitigation, capacity building and loss and damages. To my mind, the motion for a resolution that I have supported is of high relevance due to its effort to welcome the Paris Climate Agreement as a landmark achievement for combating climate change and for multilateralism. What is more, it also aims to define the position of the European Parliament in view of the COP22 Climate Conference in Marrakesh and addresses, among other things, issues such as the urgency to ratify and implement the Paris Agreement, the pre-2020 ambition and the Kyoto Protocol, the priority negotiation points in COP22, the role of non-state actors, the comprehensive effort of all sectors, climate finance, climate resilience through adaptation, and climate diplomacy.

name: Nikos ANDROULAKIS
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the motion for a resolution on the UN climate change conference, because it is vital that the European Union ratifys the Paris Agreement before COP22 takes place in Marrakech, in order to ensure that the agreement enters into force.

name: Marie-Christine ARNAUTU
text: In writing. This resolution is part of COP22, which will take place in Marrakech in November 2016. The European Parliament sends an official delegation there, which is included and does not participate in the negotiations. This resolution must express the wishes to be conveyed to the Commission's negotiators.  Unsurprisingly, the resolution is enthusiastic and calls for urgent ratification of the Paris Agreements. It calls on the Union to make ever more efforts: more budget for green funds, more constraints imposed on businesses (but by supporting economic development with the lips), more circular economy... And more migrants to welcome because of climate change! There is a clear reference to Brexit so that countries that have left the EU or are on their way out of the EU still commit themselves! In the face of the Union's measures which lead to our deindustrialisation in order to produce what we import under more polluting conditions, I voted against the resolution.

name: Jonathan ARNOTT
text: in writing. ‒ Whilst I support appropriate improved environmental standards, and specifically appropriate research and development, I cannot support the totality of this report - and believe that it should be for the UK, not the EU, to decide which international agreements we sign up to.

name: Jean ARTHUIS
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this resolution, because I believe that we need to be aware of the important step in ratifying the Paris Agreement. However, we need to be aware of the consequences for the Member States and to monitor the proper implementation of measures to ensure the success of COP22 in Marrakech.

name: Nicolas BAY
text: In writing. This resolution is part of the COP22, which will take place in Marrakech in November 2016. I am against this resolution because we disagree on many points: immeasurable efforts of the Member States of the Union, climate migrants, modalities and sources of funding for the fight against climate change, etc.

name: Hugues BAYET
text: In writing. We welcome the Paris climate agreement, voted this week by the European Parliament, a historic event in the fight against climate change and for multilateralism. We believe that this is an ambitious, balanced agreement, fair and legally binding, that its adoption, in addition to the announcement by 187 parties before the end of COP21 of planned contributions determined at the national level (CPDN), marks a decisive turning point on the path to global, global and collective action and that, once implemented, this agreement and these contributions will permanently and irreversibly accelerate the transition to a global economy that is resilient to climate change and climate change. Neutral. We intend to work tirelessly, in the same way, for COP22.

name: Brando BENIFEI
text: in writing. \u2012 Global warming is an unequivocal fact and human activities have been the main cause of this phenomenon observed since the mid-20th century. The EU's ratification of the Paris Agreement is an important step in the direction of reducing greenhouse gas emissions, but only its entry into force and subsequent implementation will accelerate, definitively and irreversibly, towards a resilient global economy with zero climate impact.  The resolution voted by Parliament today on COP22 in Marrakesh calls on the EU and its Member States to continue to participate actively in the coalition of high ambition, committing themselves to speeding up the progress of the negotiations and supporting the Moroccan Presidency in promoting renewable energies and adaptation measures to the global fight against climate change.  The Union now has the experience, capacity and global dimension to be a leader in creating the smart, clean and resilient infrastructure that is needed to achieve the global transition fostered by the Paris Agreement; That is why today it must also support the efforts of developing countries in their transition to low-carbon, more inclusive, socially and environmentally sustainable societies.

name: Xabier BENITO ZILUAGA
text: in writing. I have decided to abstain in this vote because, while I believe that the ratification of the Paris Agreement by each Member State is paramount to ensuring the fight against climate change, I understand that this report is only a first step. The Paris Agreement is wholly insufficient to achieve the very long-term objective set: not to exceed 2oC in temperature rise at the end of this century. The report is based on false solutions such as the Emission Trading System (ETS) whose exchange of emissions bonds contributes to the financing of nature and allows the one who pays more to pollute more. The REDD+ system also puts biodiversity at risk and causes land grabbing, endangering indigenous peoples.  This report is only a first step in carrying out this fight as it leaves out important issues such as the modification of the productive and agri-food system. The Paris Agreement does not even remotely mention agriculture. Industrial agriculture is among the main leaders of anthropogenic climate change, while climate change is one of the biggest problems related to food security.

name: Izaskun BILBAO BARANDICA
text: in writing. I would like to thank the rapporteurs for their work on the 2016 United Nations Climate Change Conference in Marrakesh. I support the Resolution as presented, but I voted in favour of an amendment recalling the importance of the work of the Open-ended Intergovernmental Working Group on Transnational Enterprises and Other Enterprises on Human Rights, which is responsible for developing a legally binding international instrument to regulate the activities of transnational corporations. Similarly, I voted in favour of a reference to financial transactions in that resolution.

name: Dominique BILDE
text: In writing. I voted against the resolution because it is contrary to the immediate interests of the Member States, asking them for more and more effort as they de-industrialize at high speed because of the orientations the Union has wanted since the early 2000s and in particular the disastrous theory of 'the knowledge economy'. Moreover, British pragmatists are embarking on a proactive recovery policy, understanding that a large country will never have a successful economy without domestic industry.  COP 22 is too restrictive for EU member states and will not be respected by the majority of developing countries, which pollute much more. We support initiatives that truly make our planet more sustainable and sustainable, without putting a sword of Damocles on our economies.

name: Mara BIZZOTTO
text: in writing. \u2012 The resolution being voted on is unbalanced and contains critical issues that have led me not to support it.

name: Vilija BLINKEVIČIŪTĖ
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this resolution because the fight against climate change cannot be seen as an obstacle to the path to economic growth, even on the contrary: it is a lever that will contribute to and implement new and sustainable economic and employment growth. Climate change will most affect developing countries, especially the least developed countries and small developing countries on the islands, which do not have sufficient resources to prepare for and adapt to the changes that are taking place. According to the Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change (IPCC), Africa is particularly vulnerable to this challenge and therefore suffers greatly from water scarcity, extremely difficult weather conditions and food shortages caused by droughts and desertification. The European Parliament therefore stresses that all countries must inevitably take climate change adaptation action if they want to reduce the negative effects of climate change and make full use of the potential for climate-resilient growth and sustainable development. Parliament also calls on the Commission to review the EU climate change adaptation strategy adopted in 2013 and invites the Commission to submit a proposal for a legally binding instrument if action taken in the Member States is considered insufficient.

name: Andrea BOCSKOR
text: Writing. \u2012 In my opinion, climate change can increase competition for resources such as food, water and pasture, exacerbating economic difficulties and political instability. This applies particularly to developing countries and, in the not too distant future, could become one of the biggest drivers of population displacement within national borders and across borders, a worrying sign that Europe has been feeling in its own skin in recent years. In this context, I think it is important that the issue of climate change migration is high on the international agenda. In view of the above, I voted in favour of the adoption of this report.

name: Franc BOGOVIČ
text: Writing. \u2012 Just as I was happy to support the decision to conclude the Paris Climate Agreement, I also supported that resolution on orientations for the 2016 UN Climate Change Conference, to be held in Marrakesh in November. I hope that the conference will set out a clear path to the operational implementation plan for key parts of the Paris Agreement – a strengthened transparency framework, details of the Global Scoreboard, further guidance on planned, nationally determined contributions, agreement on differentiation, loss and damage, climate finance and support for capacity purposes, etc. As before, the EU should follow a further example to others and should immediately start meeting its climate and energy targets with the agreed international objective of limiting the increase in the global average temperature below 2 °C, while at the same time working to limit the increase to 1.5°C, as also defined in the Paris Agreement. I am convinced that, with the formal entry into force of the agreement during the Marrakesh Conference, the motivation for implementing the objectives of the agreement will be even greater and will also make finding solutions to save our planet easier.

name: Simona BONAFÈ
text: in writing. \u2012 In November, in the wake of the Paris Agreements, COP22 will meet in Marrakech. In this regard, I support the European Parliament resolution and in particular the priority given to energy efficiency and sustainability in the fight against climate change. In order to achieve the emission reduction targets set by the Paris Agreements, increasing energy efficiency and using renewable resources not only have the potential to reduce pressures on the environment in terms of emissions and resource exploitation, but are also able to stimulate the sustainable growth of the world economy.  Furthermore, given the level of emissions from raw material extraction processes and waste management, the transition to a circular economy model, based on reuse and recycling, is very central. I also think it is important that the resolution has highlighted the contribution that can be made by the financial sector. In this field, existing experience to highlight the sustainability characteristics of investments must be strengthened and deepened.

name: David BORRELLI
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the resolution on the implementation of the Paris Agreement and the 2016 United Nations Climate Change Conference (COP22), a report that contains a number of important calls and recommendations to address the next steps to combat climate change globally. Although the text is acceptable in its general approach, the continued existence of the ETS as one of the European Union's main instruments for combating climate change and the adoption of this instrument on a global scale is a matter of great concern to the 5-Star Movement. The ETS mechanism, by giving market logic how to reduce CO2 emissions into the atmosphere in the sectors covered by this system, has proved to be totally ineffective in solving environmental and climate problems. This system has in fact encouraged financial speculation on carbon, and the creation of an international securities market is yet another opportunity for the financial market, to the detriment of the fate of the planet.

name: Biljana BORZAN
text: Written. I support this issue on the UN Climate Change Conference. The draft resolution aims to determine the position of the European Parliament in view of the climate conference, which will be held in November in Marrakech, Morocco. The draft resolution addresses issues such as urgency in ratifying and implementing the Paris agreement, but also a comprehensive effort by all sectors to reduce CO2 emissions, etc. I believe that we must all work together to balance climate change, so that we can leave a better place to live for generations to come.

name: Mercedes BRESSO
text: in writing. ‒ I endorsed the resolution on the implementation of the Paris Agreement and the 2016 UN Climate Change Conference that will take place in Marrakesh with the aim of supporting the Moroccan Presidency in its focus on the contribution of renewable energies. In addition, I believe the EU has the capacity to lead by example and it must start working immediately on aligning its targets with the agreed international goal by limiting the increase in the global temperature.

name: Renata BRIANO
text: in writing. \u2012 Warming of the climate system is unequivocal, climate change is a current reality and human activities are the predominant cause of warming. All countries should accelerate the transition to net greenhouse gas emissions by zero. Developed countries must drastically reduce greenhouse gas emissions beyond the commitments already made to prevent the large-scale occurrence of negative emissions. In this context, the Paris Climate Agreement is an historic achievement in the fight against climate change.  In order to limit the rise in the world average temperature, rapid decarbonisation is needed, giving priority to the phasing out of coal emissions. Negotiations on the key elements of the Paris Agreement should be continued and member states need to deliver on their agreed commitments under this agreement. It is crucial to start discussions on the form that the 2018 'facilitation dialogue' will take, which is important for bridging the existing mitigation gap.  The increase in mitigation actions in the period prior to 2020 is a key element in assessing the effectiveness of the Marrakech COP. The EU has the capacity and responsibility to set an example and start work immediately.

name: Alain CADEC
text: In writing. The 22nd Climate Change Conference (COP 22) will take place in Marrakech from 7 to 18 November 2016. In this resolution, the European Parliament questions the Council and the Commission on the steps they intend to take to ensure that COP 22 makes progress on key elements of the Paris Agreement, to influence the revision of national commitments in 2018 and to strengthen climate finance so as to achieve the target of raising $100 billion. The Paris Agreement plans to take effective and long-term measures to keep global temperatures well below 2 degrees Celsius above pre-industrial levels, while striving to limit this increase to 1.5 degrees Celsius.  I voted in favour of this resolution.

name: Nicola CAPUTO
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted today in favour of this resolution so that the INTERNATIONAL COP22 climate conference, to be held in Marrakech in November, can transpose the Paris Agreement from the adoption plan to the action plan. It is essential that the Commission and the Member States deliver on their agreed commitments under the Paris Agreement, especially with regard to the EU's contribution to climate change mitigation and adaptation, as well as its financial support and the transfer of green technologies to the poorest areas.  In order to make change possible, we need substantial investment. Synergies between public and private funding must therefore be strengthened, as well as between the various European funds. In this regard, the EU must support Member States, regions and cities in the implementation of the Paris Climate Agreement, providing financial support through the European Fund for Strategic Investments, the Cohesion Fund and the Regional Development Fund, but also through specific instruments such as the Natural Capital Financing Instrument and the Private Energy Efficiency Financing Instrument , provided for under the EIB and the LIFE funds. The challenge of climate change will be to translate climate commitments into eligible projects.

name: Matt CARTHY
text: in writing. ‒ I abstained on this report. Whilst the report contained some positive points on the very important issue of climate change, it also sees the much derided concept of emissions trading as an important tool in the future of fighting climate change. In Europe, the EU’s own Emissions Trading Scheme is widely accepted as being a very costly failure for EU climate change policy which has not brought the significant emissions reductions required and indeed promised. The EU ETS has not been cost-effective and has subsidised polluters with taxpayers’ money with its oversupply of allowances to power companies, many of which are being given ‘free’ to these companies

name: David CASA
text: in writing. ‒ I fully recognise the importance of the implementation of the Paris Agreement and the 2016 UN Climate Change Conference in Marrakesh. This resolution aims to define Parliament’s position in view of the upcoming COP22 Climate Conference which will be held in November 2016. It addresses a number of very positive issues, including the reduction of non-CO2 emissions, climate resilience through adaptation, and climate diplomacy, but it also calls for the introduction of a financial transactions tax, which I cannot support. I therefore voted against this resolution.

name: Fabio Massimo CASTALDO
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this resolution, which touches on all the overall aspects related to climate change, recalling the positive effects that have emerged from the policies to reduce emissions and promote renewables by 2020 and putting at the centre the medium and long-term objectives and the sectors that will have to be involved in the reduction effort.

name: Lefteris CHRISTOFOROU
text: Writing. \u2012 We support the motion for a resolution and urge developed countries and the EU to drastically reduce the same greenhouse gas emissions, even beyond current commitments, in order to avoid, as far as possible, the large-scale dissemination of negative emission technologies because these technologies have not yet proved successful, socially acceptable, cost-effective or safe.

name: Kostas CHRYSOGONOS
text: Writing. \u2012 The motion for a resolution on the UN Climate Change Conference was a positive move that demonstrates our attitude towards the need to take initiatives on the problems and risks that threaten the environment. As I believe that we must remain vigilant about environmental protection, I agree with this proposal and voted in favour.

name: Alberto CIRIO
text: in writing. \u2012 External my support for the resolution, as COP22 in Marrakech is a focal point of the confrontation between international actors on climate change. This is a time to reflect after the recent ratification of the Paris Agreements and to set new targets for what is happening to our planet because it reflects our behaviour. In this respect, EU action must focus not only on reducing emissions but also on efficient production of resources.  In fact, through research and innovation we will be able to achieve sustainable and competitive production, since a reduction in environmental pressures would be accompanied by one of the wastes, contributing to an increase in productivity. It will therefore be essential to make concrete commitments with regard to climate finance.  In this regard, I express my dismay at the proposal to introduce a tax on financial transactions as a source of funding and therefore, I repeat my call on the Commission to plan other sources in terms of capacity, governance and implementation mechanisms with timing. In fact, climate change is a current reality with which confrontation is inevitable, so it is necessary to give it a direction that will provide growth and stability for all mankind.

name: Deirdre CLUNE
text: in writing. ‒ I supported the motion for a resolution on the 2016 UN Climate Change Conference in Marrakesh, Morocco (COP22) and noted no objections.

name: Carlos COELHO
text: in writing. \u2012 The European Union's leadership in combating climate change dignifies the Union and the Member States. The ratification of the Paris Agreement, which will allow its rapid entry into force, and the commitment to reduce greenhouse gas emissions by 40% by 2030 are generational contributions that we should be proud of. I believe that the EU should preserve its leading role at COP22 in Marrakesh by accompanying the Moroccan presidency in defining renewable energy as a priority. I follow the concern with the deepening of the emissions allowance market, reiterating the need to coordinate the principles of the Paris Agreement and even the Kyoto Protocol with other international legal instruments in this area. This is the only way to meet the 2020 and 2030 targets. I share the view that the conditions need to be created for industrial adaptations to meet environmental objectives to promote employment, competitiveness and economic growth. In this respect, it is essential to concert environmental policy with energy policy, promote scientific research and technological innovation and integrate objectives into external action, with environmental diplomacy, especially with regard to development support. I support the motion for a resolution.

name: Birgit COLLIN-LANGEN
text: Writing. I voted in favour of the resolution because, unfortunately, the efforts made so far by the countries are not sufficient to achieve the safe CO2 limits. We must all step up our efforts and commit ourselves to further emission reductions by 2030. The ratification of the Paris UN Framework Convention is a great success, and we must now make further progress on the key points of the Paris Agreement in the forthcoming negotiations.

name: Jane COLLINS
text: in writing. – We in UKIP are against this resolution because we object to the Paris Agreement and the climate change alarmism supported by green lobbies. They are the cause of our current damaging and counter-productive energy policy.

name: Lara COMI
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the resolution because, in addition to calling for the ratification of the Paris Agreement, important issues are addressed for the daily lives of all European citizens, such as the reduction of harmful emissions and the commitment of all countries to monitor the rise in global average temperature. The resolution also highlights the important role played by research and innovation in climate change, adaptation policies and efficient technologies.

name: Therese COMODINI CACHIA
text: in writing. ‒ I support measures aimed to mitigate global warming and agree with the motion which states clearly that this should not be seen as an obstacle to striving for economic growth but should, on the contrary, be seen as a driving force in the realisation of new and sustainable economic growth and employment. I also welcomes the commitment of all countries to limit the increase in the global average temperature to well below 2°C above pre-industrial levels and to pursue efforts to limit the temperature increase to 1.5°C; as much as I welcome therefore the preparation in 2018 of an IPCC special report for this purpose. By now it is clear that current efforts by countries are not enough to reach these safe limits for the most vulnerable countries. Climate-related developments in parts of Africa and the Middle East could contribute to political instability, economic hardship and an escalation of the refugee crisis in the Mediterranean. I have however voted against the inclusion of a financial transaction tax as this is prejudicial to economies which already face disadvantages and challenges which are already crippling for these countries. This is a key vote for me and consequently while I agree with all the remaining of the report, I cannot agree with this call.

name: Javier COUSO PERMUY
text: in writing. After the Paris Agreement, the purposes of combating climate change are primarily based on voluntary commitments and market mechanisms. This resolution, even more ambitious, continues on the same path, so I abstained.

name: Andrea COZZOLINO
text: in writing. \u2012 With the entry into force of the Paris Agreement on climate change, it was necessary to establish a concrete roadmap to accelerate and amplify the immediate response to the challenges recognised by the Paris Agreement. The UN climate change conference in Marrakesh identifies some key actions to achieve the goals outlined in the Paris Agreement. For example, to keep global temperature rise within an average of 1.5 °C, a decarbonization path and the transition to low-carbon investments is required.  The resolution calls on the EU to put pressure on the Parties following a path that does not comply with the Paris Agreement. In particular, the Commission and the Member States are responsible for timely ratification of the agreement so as not to delay its effects. Their role will be crucial in maintaining the EU's commitment to mitigation and adaptation, as well as technology transfer and capacity building. In addition, all producers of greenhouse gas emissions, including the EU, are committed to reducing emissions in their NPCs every five years and to taking this objective into account in national development planning. These are the main reasons why I voted in favour of this resolution.

name: Edward CZESAK
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 I voted against the motion for a resolution on the UN Climate Conference 2016 - COP 22 in Marrakesh. The content of the project covers very important environmental issues such as the reduction of non-CO2 emissions, the need to reduce aviation and marine emissions, the role of climate diplomacy and the reduction of carbon leakage. Of course, I support the fight against climate change, but I do not think it is appropriate to increase funding to combat climate change.  In my view, the resources allocated to this objective are sufficient. The EU is currently facing more serious problems (which we also discussed in plenary sessions) for which it should allocate funding. I therefore voted against.

name: Miriam DALLI
text: in writing. ‒ Less than a year after the success of COP21, we will in Marrakesh celebrate the world's commitment to climate action. Parliament will push for a solid review while closing loopholes for industries and Member States. In Marrakesh, the European Commission and EU Member States will have to specify their long-term strategies on decarbonising the economy and clarify their financial commitments to reduce the negative effects of climate change. The draft resolution addresses issues such as the urgency to ratify and implement the Paris Agreement, pre-2020 ambition, negotiation points, the role of non-state actors, climate finance and the reduction of non-CO2 emissions among others. I have voted in favour of this resolution because it is imperative that climate change is addressed immediately, particularly for vulnerable regions such as the Mediterranean region.

name: Viorica DĂNCILĂ
text: in writing. \u2012 Given that the fight against climate change is a global priority, ensuring energy security, sustainable economic growth and the creation of sustainable jobs, I consider it important to adopt a holistic and systemic approach to developing and implementing policies to reduce greenhouse gas emissions on the one hand, and on the other, I believe that research and innovation in the context of climate change policies and adaptations to them , as well as low-emission and resource-efficient technologies are fundamental to combating climate change in a cost-effective way, reducing dependence on fossil fuels and promoting the use of secondary raw materials.

name: Michel DANTIN
text: In writing. This resolution aims to provide an overview of the situation in the climate change negotiations. The resolution welcomes the results of the Paris Climate Agreement (COP 21), recalling that it is an ambitious, balanced, fair and legally binding agreement. Considering that the European Union is the originator of the Paris Agreement and that it must contribute to global efforts to reduce global warming, I voted in favour of this resolution.

name: Rachida DATI
text: In writing. I supported the resolution on the implementation of the Paris Agreement and the conference of the parties to the 2016 United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change (COP 22), to be held from 7 to 18 November 2016, in Marrakech. The Paris Agreement is a historic success in protecting the environment. It is important to capitalize on this success for COP 22. It is therefore essential that this conference be used as a driving force for the implementation of the Paris Agreement so that our objectives can be achieved. Funding for the fight against climate change will the thus have to be an important issue to be addressed during COP 22.

name: Angélique DELAHAYE
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this resolution, which sets out Parliament's positions for the 22nd Conference of the Parties to be held in November 2016 in Marrakech. This resolution particularly underlines the urgency of implementing the measures provided for by the Paris Agreements and the Kyoto Protocol. The fight against climate change is indeed everyone's business and each state must engage quickly. This resolution stresses the need for strict compliance with the rules when it comes to international activities in the aviation and navigation sector in particular.

name: Mark DEMESMAEKER
text: Written. \u2012 The COP 22 resolution sets out the Priorities of the European Parliament for the next UN climate conference to be held in Marrakech in November. The resolution contains many positive elements. In this way, the importance of ratifying and implementing the Paris Climate Agreement is rightly emphasised. The N-VA delegation approved this agreement with conviction earlier this week. After all, we can only effectively fight climate change with full and concerted efforts. The EU cannot solve the problem alone, we need allies.  In addition, the resolution stresses, among other things, the need to reduce emissions from shipping and aviation, to reduce the impact of carbon leakage and to exploit the potential of climate diplomacy.  The N-VA wants to combine economic growth and prosperity with a low-carbon economy. This implies that we make sustainable, efficient and effective choices that we can sustain for years and that we link ambition to realism. The explicit demand for a tax on climate financial transactions and the call to earmark proceeds from the emissions trading system are problematic in that context. That is why the N-VA delegation abstained in the final vote.

name: Isabella DE MONTE
text: in writing. \u2012 I believe that the resolution is a further step towards achieving the objectives of the Paris Agreement. In fact, it marks a turning point towards global and collective action to limit the rise in temperature to a maximum of 1.5°C.  For these reasons, I voted in favour of the resolution.

name: Marielle DE SARNEZ
text: In writing. By ratifying the Paris climate agreement, the first universal and legally binding global climate agreement ever concluded, the European Union and its Member States sent a strong signal just weeks before the opening of COP22 in Marrakech. This choice was all the more necessary because in order for the EU to have ratified the agreement in order for it to participate in the first decisions as a stakeholder. The EU must take this opportunity to continue to exercise its leadership in the fight against climate change at the global level. This implies a more ambitious medium- and long-term strategy to achieve the zero-emissions target by 2050. The EU needs to promote green finance more and more strictly regulate emissions related to the international civil aviation and maritime transport sectors. The European Union must also continue its efforts within it and with partners in third countries on the creation of financial transaction taxes, some of which could support developing countries' adaptation to climate change.

name: Angel DZHAMBAZKI
text: in writing. ‒ I have voted against this resolution. Overall, I support some of the points it addresses, such as the need to ratify the Paris Accord, the emerging role of international ETS and the limiting of the harmful effects of carbon leakage. However, through the adoption of additional text, it is also calling for increased EU 2030 ambition and setting targets even higher, earmarking ETS revenues and an FTT. These goals are not in line with market realities and Member States’ capacity to fulfil the requirements. Therefore, such unrealistic targets will only result in the continued sanctioning of Member States, instead of setting achievable goals as incentives. I believe that a lot more work needs to be done before I can support this resolution.

name: Jill EVANS
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the resolution on the 2016 UN Climate Change Conference in Marrakesh, Morocco, COP22. The resolution puts forward the European Parliament’s position for the COP22 conference this November. It is ambitious, but does not go as far as to call for specific numbers on emissions to make the EP’s position even more progressive. Climate change is the greatest threat facing us today, and we in Wales need to do all we can to protect the planet and ensure the well-being of future generations.

name: Fredrick FEDERLEY
text: Written. \u2012 COP22 will be an important next step after the success of COP21. The resolution as a whole is both acceptable and well-balanced. However, I am opposed to the point of the financial transaction tax because it has a counterproductive impact on the movement of capital in the internal market. That is why I voted in agreement with ALDE to delete this paragraph.

name: José Manuel FERNANDES
text: in writing. \u2012 The EU and its Member States have submitted their planned nationally determined contributions requiring a binding target of at least 40 % internal reduction in greenhouse gas emissions by 2030. Efforts to mitigate global warming should not be considered an obstacle to the fight for economic growth, but should instead be considered a driving force for the creation of new sustainable jobs and the achievement of sustainable economic growth. The EU should drastically reduce its greenhouse gas emissions beyond current commitments in order to avoid, as far as possible, large-scale negative emissions, as technologies have not yet proven to be successful, socially acceptable, cost-efficient and safe.

name: Edouard FERRAND
text: In writing. Vote against: in the face of the excessive efforts of the European Union which lead to our deindustrialization to produce in more polluting conditions what we will import, we remain on our usual line.

name: João FERREIRA
text: in writing. \u2012 This resolution addresses the preparation of the 22nd UN Conference of the Parties on Climate Change, to be held later this year in Marrakesh. Inevitably, the Conference will take place under the sign of the Paris Conference and the agreement reached there. This resolution also reflects that. We do not follow the laudatory tone regarding the Paris Agreement. In fact, there are several problems with this agreement. In addition to not having agreed concrete limits on GHG emissions, the agreement maintains and legitimises a market approach to the problem of climate change, of which carbon trading is the main (but not only) instrument. The Agreement abandoned the principle of "common but differentiated responsibility", between developing and industrialised countries, opting for a single system that could deepen injustices between the countries that have contributed the most to the accumulation of carbon in the atmosphere and developing countries. The Agreement also includes a funding dimension of projects by large transnational groups in developing countries, enhancing the imperialist domination of the resources of these countries. These are views and options which are also shaped and defended in this resolution, which we are of course opposed to and to which we oppose an alternative vision, based on a normative approach and a common but necessarily differentiated responsibility.

name: Christofer FJELLNER
text: Written. "Tackling climate change is one of the biggest challenges we face and it is of great importance that all the countries of the world bear their share of the burden.
