Climate finance and technology transfer are important for reducing emissions in less developed countries. However, introducing an EU tax on financial transactions is the wrong way to go. Giving the EU the right to tax would be a massive transfer of power from the Member States to the EU and would erode the Swedish tax base. We will continue to decide on tax policy on our own in Sweden. Therefore, the Moderates have chosen to vote against the introduction of one.

name: Monika BEŇOVÁ
text: Writing. \u2012 The aim of the resolution in question is to define the position of the European Parliament ahead of the forthcoming COP22 conference in Marrakesh in November. Among other things, the resolution focuses on the need to ratify the Paris Agreement, the European Union's climate ambitions before 2020, as well as the need to reduce CO2 emissions. The motion for a resolution welcomes the Paris Climate Agreement as a successful milestone for combating climate change. It represents an ambitious, balanced, fair and legally binding agreement.

name: Lorenzo FONTANA
text: in writing. \u2012 I am voting against the resolution which does not make the necessary changes.

name: Lampros FOUNTOULIS
text: Writing. \u2012 I am voting in favour of the motion for a resolution on the 2016 UN Climate Change Conference held in Marrakech, Morocco (COP22), although it contains issues that do not concern environmental protection, an environment that the rulers themselves have destroyed now and are simply now trying to save what is left.

name: Francisco de Paula GAMBUS MILLET
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the motion for a resolution, considering that the fight against global warming cannot be seen as an obstacle to economic growth but, on the contrary, should be seen as a stimulus to generate new economic growth and new sustainable jobs. The ratification and entry into force of the Paris Agreements represents a very important step in this direction, but we must continue to work towards the objectives set to mitigate the effects of climate change, so the preparation of the ONE conference in Marrakech is of great importance. We must move forward in the negotiations and respect the commitments made under the Paris Agreement, in particular those relating to the Union's contribution to mitigation and adaptation, as well as its support in the form of financing, technology transfer and capacity building.

name: Enrico GASBARRA
text: in writing. \u2012 With great satisfaction we supported with our vote the ratification of the COP21 climate agreement, allowing the entry into force of the Paris Agreement in time for COP22 scheduled for next November in Marrakech. This is an historic achievement and one that parliament has pursued everything and in particular that the Progressive Group wants. With the green light for EU ratification, Europe has reaffirmed its leading role in protecting the planet and its capacity for concrete leadership in global socio-economic and environmental strategies.  Europe is there, therefore, and in passages such as today's, it shows how determined and decisive it is for our future. The commitment will now be to meet the ambitious targets set for 2030: to reduce greenhouse gas emissions by 40 % compared to 1990 and to invest to significantly increase renewables and energy efficiency. Therefore, continue with the common commitment to global action, aimed at giving new opportunities to the planet: a future that is supportive and sustainable, healthier and safer.

name: Elena GENTILE
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the EP resolution on the implementation of the Paris Agreement and the UN Conference on Climate Change in Marrakech (COP22) because I shared the EP's call for developed countries, in particular the EU, to drastically reduce greenhouse gas emissions beyond the commitments already made to avoid, as far as possible, the large-scale occurrence of negative emissions , as the technologies have not yet proved effective, socially acceptable, economic and safe. I therefore hope that other countries will follow the EP's example and ratify as soon as possible and commit themselves to implementing the Paris Climate Agreement, as it is an historic achievement in the fight against climate change achieved thanks to the multilateral methodology. This is an ambitious, balanced and legally binding agreement, and its adoption and cumulative announcements by 187 parties at the end of COP21 of planned contributions established at national level marked a decisive turning point towards global and collective action at world level. When implemented, it will definitively and irreversibly accelerate the transition to a global economy resilient to climate change and climate-neutral. I hope that all countries will commit a great commitment to this.

name: Nathan GILL
text: in writing. ‒ I am against this resolution because I object to the Paris Agreement and the climate change alarmism supported by green lobbies. I believe they are the cause of our current damaging and counter-productive energy policy.

name: Tania GONZÁLEZ PEÑAS
text: in writing. I have decided to abstain in this vote because, while I believe that the ratification of the Paris Agreement by each Member State is paramount to ensuring the fight against climate change, I understand that this report is only a first step. The Paris Agreement is wholly insufficient to achieve the very long-term objective set: not to exceed 2oC in temperature rise at the end of this century. The report is based on false solutions such as the Emission Trading System (ETS) whose exchange of emissions bonds contributes to the financing of nature and allows the one who pays more to pollute more. The REDD+ system also puts biodiversity at risk and causes land grabbing, endangering indigenous peoples.  This report is only a first step in carrying out this fight as it leaves out important issues such as the modification of the productive and agri-food system. The Paris Agreement does not even remotely mention agriculture. Industrial agriculture is among the main leaders of anthropogenic climate change, while climate change is one of the biggest problems related to food security.

name: Theresa GRIFFIN
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the resolution, as it aims to define the position of the European Parliament in view of the COP22 Climate Conference this November in Marrakesh, Morocco. The draft resolution addresses issues such as the urgency to ratify and implement the Paris Agreement, the pre-2020 ambition and the Kyoto Protocol, the priority negotiation points in COP22, the role of non-state actors, the comprehensive effort of all sectors, the reduction of non-CO2 emissions, climate finance, climate resilience through adaptation, climate diplomacy, etc.

name: Françoise GROSSETÊTE
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this resolution. COP22 must be as ambitious as the previous COP! It should provide an update on the progress of the ratifications of the Paris Agreement and on concrete steps that can facilitate and accelerate its implementation.  Efforts from all sectors will be required in each country that has ratified the agreement and, as such, international negotiations in the air and maritime sectors are essential, so that the same rule applies to all. The European Union must apply appropriate and proportionate measures to ensure the competitiveness of its industry until a level playing field is achieved and prevent carbon leakage where appropriate. That is why it is urgent that the Paris Agreement be respected by all. Our European climate diplomacy must continue in this direction!

name: Jytte GUTELAND
text: Written. "For us, there is no doubt that climate change is the fate of our time. We therefore wholeheartedly support the Paris Agreement and its objective of limiting the increase in the global average temperature to below 2 °C, with further efforts to limit the increase to 1.5 °C.  The objective is absolutely necessary and an investment in the future of humanity and nature. The EU's commitments under the Paris Agreement may mean that the financial resources for climate action may increase in the short term, which is why we welcome the Fact that the Commission is carrying out a comprehensive assessment of the possible impact of the agreement on the EU budget. However, we believe that there is uncertainty about the wording of an automatic financing mechanism at EU level and have therefore refrained from supporting such a proposal.

name: Marian HARKIN
text: in writing. ‒ Given that, according to scientific evidence, warming of the climate system is unequivocal, I support the implementation of the Paris Agreement. I agree that global emissions of carbon dioxide should be phased out by 2050 or shortly thereafter. Member States are urged to implement their national decarbonisation targets and strategies by prioritising the phasing-out of emissions from coal, which is the most polluting source of energy. It is a cause for concern that 166 million people were forced to leave their homes because of floods, windstorms, earthquakes or other disasters between 2008 and 2015 and I believe that the issue of climate refugees should be recognised by the EU. That being said, I welcome the EU’s continued focus on climate diplomacy, and that the EU has committed itself to ratification of the Paris Agreement as soon as possible and to using its international role to seek progress towards the quick ratification and implementation of the Paris Agreement.

name: Hans-Olaf HENKEL
text: Writing. This report addresses the European Parliament's priorities for preparing for the COP22 conference in Marrakesh in November 2016. It contains welcome aspects, such as linking the European emissions trading system with other markets or measures to limit carbon leakages – the shift in European emissions by emigrating production to other regions of the world. ALFA supports these points. However, the report also advocates a financial transaction tax or an increase in the climate and efficiency targets that have already been set. That is why I chose to abstain in the final vote. Incidentally, I believe that the single euro must be abolished, because it leads to strife and discord.

name: Cătălin Sorin IVAN
text: in writing. ‒ I have voted for this resolution which concerns the need and urgency to ratify and implement the Paris Agreement before the COP 22 in Marrakesh.

name: Ivan JAKOVČIĆ
text: Written. ‒ I voted for the motion for a resolution submitted following a question for oral response B8-0718/2016 in accordance with Article 128(5) of the EIA. Rules of Procedure on the implementation of the Paris Agreement and the UN Climate Change Conference to be held in 2016 in Marrakech, Morocco (COP22) (2016/2814 (RSP)), as this is practically the last step towards the ratification and subsequent implementation of the Paris Agreement.  Developed countries need to be urged to drastically reduce their greenhouse gas emissions even more than their commitments. The Paris Agreement is ambitious, balanced, fair and legally binding and its adoption marked a decisive turn towards comprehensive and joint global action. On a positive note, the EU is well on track to exceed its 2020 greenhouse gas emission reduction targets and meet the 2020 renewable energy target.  The EU has the experience, capacity and global reach to be at the forefront of building the smarter, cleaner and more resilient infrastructure needed to deliver the global transition driven by the Paris Agreement. The importance of energy efficiency and renewable energy sources for reducing emissions and achieving economic savings, energy security and preventing and alleviating energy poverty is of utmost importance. Further efforts are needed to mobilise $100 billion in climate change funding by 2020.

name: Jean-François JALKH
text: In writing. The Paris Agreements, which the resolution requires us to sign as soon as possible, are not in the interests of European countries. I do not intend to support a contradictory project to gradually de-industrialize us by increasing our efforts in favour of green funds or the circular economy, all in favour of imports resulting in more polluting production and ever-increasing immigration linked to climate change. So I voted against it.

name: Diane JAMES
text: in writing. – We in UKIP are against this resolution because we object to the Paris Agreement and the climate change alarmism supported by green lobbies. They are the cause of our current damaging and counter-productive energy policy.

name: Benedek JÁVOR
text: in writing. ‒ The European Union adopted the resolution for the next UN Climate Conference. This will be a follow-up to last year’s Paris Agreement. I welcome the decision of the European Parliament on the ratification of the Paris Agreement. We Greens call on the EU to commit to further emissions reductions for 2030. Now we will need action and implementation, but it is a good sign that the European Union will be able to stand firmly in Marrakesh and will stay a key player in fighting climate change.

name: Dennis de JONG
text: Written. 'With regard to paragraph 62: The SP supports the introduction of a financial transaction tax, but wants the proceeds to be fully benefited from the Member States that levy the tax and are not added to the EU budget.

name: Marc JOULAUD
text: In writing. I voted in favour of my colleague Giovanni La Via's report on COP 22 to be held in Marrakech. This report was an opportunity to underline our commitment to the goals set out in the Paris Agreement and to work fully for the climate. The negotiations to be held next November will focus on the details of the global balance sheet, the establishment of a transparency framework but also on the financing of the fight against climate change.  I am pleased that this text has been adopted by a large majority.

name: Philippe JUVIN
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this text in order to underline the European Parliament's commitment to climate change issues. The approval of COP 21 and now the adoption of a common position for COP 22 will send a strong signal to the international community, while inviting it to act.

name: Krišjānis KARIŅŠ
text: Writing. \u2012 At the European Parliament plenary session in Strasbourg, I voted in favour of the resolution on the implementation of the Paris Agreement and the 2016 UN Climate Change Conference in Marrakesh, Morocco. Mitigating climate change is not only a European but a global challenge. It is therefore important to be aware that climate change and the rise in average air temperatures are the responsibility of the whole world. However much Europe reduces, for example, the same CO2 emissions, it may not reduce CO2 emissions globally, because at the same time in another region of the world, these emissions will have doubled. I therefore believe that a global agreement on climate change mitigation is a very welcome initiative. However, in this resolution, I voted against the paragraph, which states that even more funding is needed to prevent climate change by introducing a financial transaction tax in the EU.

name: Afzal KHAN
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the resolution, as it aims to define the position of the European Parliament in view of the COP22 Climate Conference this November in Marrakesh, Morocco. The draft resolution addresses issues such as the urgency to ratify and implement the Paris Agreement, the pre-2020 ambition and the Kyoto Protocol, the priority negotiation points in COP22, the role of non-state actors, the comprehensive effort of all sectors, the reduction of non-CO2 emissions, climate finance, climate resilience through adaptation, climate diplomacy, etc.

name: Bernd KÖLMEL
text: Writing. This report addresses the European Parliament's priorities for preparing for the COP 22 conference in Marrakesh in November 2016. It contains welcome aspects, such as linking the European emissions trading system with other markets or measures to limit carbon leakages – the shift in European emissions by emigrating production to other regions of the world. ALFA supports these points. However, the report also advocates a financial transaction tax or an increase in the climate and efficiency targets that have already been set. That is why I chose to abstain in the final vote.

name: Kateřina KONEČNÁ
text: Writing. \u2012 On 6 December 2016, we voted in plenary on the resolution on the implementation of the Paris Agreement and on the 2016 UN Climate Change Conference in Marrakesh, Morocco. Unfortunately, the European Parliament delegation is not directly involved in the COP negotiations. In these, the EU is represented only by the current Presidency and the Commission, i.e. uneased representatives, which has long been criticised by Parliament. Moreover, the text presented reiterates the role of the ETS in combating CO2 emissions. According to the latest OECD report, 90% of CO2 emissions are under-priced. This means that public budgets practically take less money from CO2 emitters than they have to spend to repair the damage they cause. The report argues that the price of an allowance below EUR 30/tonne is wholly inadequate, implying that the current system is absolutely failing. Given that I am shadow rapporteur on its reform and in future changes, which I think will also not be enough, I see, I do not understand the constant adoration of this system. In my opinion, a better way is to set precise, legally binding limits, to enforce them consistently and to combine them, e.g. with a carbon tax. The motion for a resolution tabled is slightly more favourable than other years, but it still contains a number of nonsense that I cannot identify with.

name: Ilhan KYUCHYUK
text: in writing. – It is pleasing that the EP is ratifying the UNFCC Paris Agreement (COP21) on fighting climate change, the first ever universal, legally binding global climate deal. Thus, the EU will join the US, China and India, other global players and major greenhouse gas emitters at 2016 UN Climate change Conference in Marrakesh, Morocco (COP22). The climate change is a key priority for the EU. In fact, the EU is working hard to cut greenhouse gas emissions substantially while encouraging other nations and regions to do likewise. The EU’s continued focus on climate diplomacy shows the EU’s capacity to support the implementation of COP21 commitments, but also emphasises EU’s ability to influence COP22. In this regard, on 2016 UN Climate change Conference in Marrakesh the EU should push the international community (parties to the Paris Agreement) to adopt without delay concrete measures, including a timetable, environmentally or economically harmful subsidies, for reduction of fossil fuels. In this context, the EU should insist from the international community an increase in the contribution of renewable energy to all energy consumption.

name: Giovanni LA VIA
text: in writing. COP21 in Paris was an historic moment and next November, in Marrakech, we will go with the same determination and leadership ambition that we had in Paris. This report is the mandate for our delegation, during the negotiations that will be launched on the key elements of the Paris Agreement, including: a strengthened framework for transparency, details of the overall budget, some additional guidelines on INDCs, an understanding of differentiation, losses and damage, climate finance, inclusive multi-level governance, as well as a mechanism to facilitate implementation and promote compliance.  The resolution highlights the EU's good progress in meeting the 2020 targets for reducing greenhouse gas emissions, and in achieving the 2020 renewable energy targets. Parliament also stresses the need to implement a number of strategies to reduce emissions in the transport, air and sea sectors as well, and the parties to the UNFCCC must intervene, including through the ICAO and the IMO, to develop a comprehensive policy framework that will enable an effective and rapid response to be provided.

name: Gilles LEBRETON
text: In writing. I voted against this resolution because I disagree with many of its provisions. Not least because it requires considerable effort from the EU Member States when the other states do not want to commit to doing the same. And also because it highlights the reception of climate refugees. Finally, because it is calling for agricultural subsidies to be used for non-agricultural purposes...

name: Constance LE GRIP
text: In writing. I supported this resolution which affirms our wish to continue our efforts for the 2016 United Nations Climate Change Conference (COP 22) in Marrakech: funding the fight against climate change, establishing mechanisms to reduce the risk of carbon leakage, reducing non-CO2 gas emissions, needing to include non-state actors in discussions and better sharing efforts... A clear and responsible roadmap for the next climate negotiations!

name: Philippe LOISEAU
text: In writing. This resolution is part of COP 22, which will take place in Marrakech in November 2016. The European Parliament is sending an official delegation there, which will not participate in the negotiations. Barbara Kappel will represent the ENL group. This resolution must express the wishes conveyed to the Commission's negotiators.  Unsurprisingly, the resolution calls for urgent ratification of the Paris Agreements. It calls on the EU to work harder: more budget for green funds, more constraints on businesses... There is also reference to the reception of 'climate migrants'. I have therefore opposed the incoherent constraints imposed on us by the EU, which result in the massive deindustrialisation of our countries and, at the same time, more polluting production elsewhere than we import.

name: Javi LÓPEZ
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the resolution which aims to define the position of the European Parliament with a view to the COP22 Conference of the Parties on climate in November in Marrakech, Morocco. The proposal addresses issues such as the urgency of ratifying and implementing the Paris Agreement, pre-2020 ambition and the Kyoto Protocol, priority negotiating points at COP22, the role of non-State actors, the overall effort of all sectors, the reduction of non-CO2 emissions, climate finance, climate resilience through climate adaptation and diplomacy , among others. In general, the resolution welcomes the Paris Agreement as a historic achievement for the fight against climate change and multilateralism, representing an ambitious, balanced, equitable and legally binding agreement. On the other hand, the resolution welcomes the commitment of all countries to keep the increase in global average temperature below 2oC relative to pre-industrial levels and to continue efforts to limit temperature rise to 1.5oC.

name: Antonio LÓPEZ-ISTÚRIZ WHITE
text: in writing. This motion for a Resolution encourages countries to accelerate the transition to zero greenhouse gas emissions to avoid the worst consequences of global warming. In this regard, it encourages the countries that signed the Paris Agreement to ratify it as soon as possible, so that it enters into force as soon as possible and the emission limit targets can be achieved faster.  The European Union, as a leader in the fight against climate change, even if it is well aimed at going beyond its 2020 greenhouse emission reduction targets and meeting its renewable energy target by 2020, must adapt to the demands of the Paris Agreement and continue its efforts to achieve safe emissions limits in the most disadvantaged countries , who will feel the most about climate change because they do not have enough resources to prepare for and adapt to the changes that are taking place.  I am voting in favour because we are facing a global challenge which requires effective and concrete action, and the Union must set an example by immediately working towards the above objectives.

name: Mairead McGUINNESS
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this motion for a resolution. The Paris Agreement commits all countries to hold the increase in the global average temperature to well below 2°C above pre-industrial levels and its objectives are to be upheld in COP22.

name: Petr MACH
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted against. I do not agree with the call 'for developed countries, especially the EU, to significantly reduce their greenhouse gas emissions below existing commitments'. I do not agree with the call for 'decarbonisation' by 2050, because I believe that natural gas, for example, is still an important commodity for us, e.g. for heating. I do not agree with the call for a $100 billion fund to subsidise projects.

name: Andrejs MAMIKINS
text: in writing. ‒ It is very important for the EU not just to criticize others, but to demonstrate adherence to the Paris Agreement, especially through revisiting its own mid- and long-term goals and policy instruments, and to start this process as early as possible to allow for a comprehensive debate in which Parliament should play a crucial role, in partnership with representatives from national, regional and local authorities, civil society and the business sector.

name: Vladimír MAŇKA
text: Writing. \u2012 By ratifying the Paris Agreement, the European Parliament has sent a clear signal on the importance of climate change. It aims to limit global temperature growth to a maximum of two degrees Celsius by the end of the century compared to the pre-industrial period. The Agreement shall enter into force 30 days after its ratification by at least 55 States whose share of world emissions totals at least 55 %. To date, 62 countries have signed it, with 52% of emissions. The Marrakesh Conference should contribute to finding a way to implement the Paris Agreement commitments in individual countries. Addressing the need for climate change affects all spheres of the economy, with profound impacts on the quality of the environment and the protection of health and life on our planet at all.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: Writing. \u2012 I am voting against the motion for a resolution on the implementation of the Paris Agreement and the 2016 UN Climate Change Conference in Marrakech, Morocco, for the reasons I mentioned in detail in my speech to the plenary of the European Parliament in Strasbourg on 5/10/2016 but also because I believe that this motion for a resolution is neither complete nor substantiated.

name: Dominique MARTIN
text: In writing. I voted against this resolution. There are several problems with this solution. First of all, she is very enthusiastic about the Paris Agreements and calls for their ratification. However, we abstained on this text, in particular because of the deindustrialization measures it foresees.  Moreover, its initiators seek to give the European Parliament powers that it does not have. The authors want to send a delegation from Parliament to the COP 22 conference to be held in Marrakech. A delegation that can only be symbolic! In addition, the resolution makes unreasonable vows. Indeed, it calls on Member States to make ever more efforts: to increase budgets for green energy, to put even more constraints on businesses, and finally to welcome more migrants because of climate change! We therefore find this motion for a resolution unacceptable.

name: Costas MAVRIDES
text: Writing. \u2012 I am voting in favour of the resolution on the implementation of the Paris Agreement and the UN Conference on Climate Change because, first of all, climate change can act as a boost to competition for resources but can also exacerbate economic difficulties and political instability. I underline the very important role that developing countries can play in the efforts to implement and achieve the Paris Agreement and that is why the EU should support developing countries' efforts to transition to low-carbon societies that are more socially and environmentally sustainable. Finally, I hope that the EU will focus on climate diplomacy to ensure stability and practical implementation of the Paris Agreement.

name: Georg MAYER
text: Writing. Climate and environmental protection is an important concern for me. Here, however, CO2 emissions have been identified as an essential pillar of this agreement. As this indirectly supports those countries that rely on nuclear energy, I voted against.

name: Valentinas MAZURONIS
text: Writing. \u2012 I support the European Parliament resolution and its provisions that all countries inevitably need to take climate change adaptation action if they want to reduce its negative impact on the environment and make full use of the potential for climate-resilient growth and sustainable development.

name: Jean-Luc MÉLENCHON
text: In writing. After COP 21 in Paris, the next UN Framework Convention on Climate Change will be held next November in Marrakech. This report calls for going further than the Paris Agreement, since the sum of national contributions does not allow us to approach the 2oC target of limiting global warming. An "undeniable" disorder and mainly caused by human activity, all supported by many of the IPCC's work now recognized by all. It proposes some concrete targets to reduce carbon emissions by 2030, such as the phasing out of fossil fuel subsidies. But beyond a few measures, the logic of green capitalism has not changed. It advocates the establishment of this global emissions trading system while this "carbon market" functions as a subsidy system for polluters. In the end, the fight against global warming is just the "leverage in favour of growth" a little green. I'm voting against it.

name: Joëlle MÉLIN
text: In writing. This resolution is part of COP 22, which will take place in Marrakech in November 2016. The European Parliament is sending an official delegation there, which will not participate in the negotiations. Barbara Kappel will represent the ENL group. This resolution must express the wishes conveyed to the Commission's negotiators.  Unsurprisingly, the resolution calls for urgent ratification of the Paris Agreements. It calls on the EU to work harder: more budget for green funds, more constraints on businesses... There is also reference to the reception of 'climate migrants'. I have therefore opposed the incoherent constraints imposed on us by the EU which result in the massive deindustrialisation of our countries and, at the same time, more polluting production elsewhere than we import.

name: Nuno MELO
text: in writing. \u2012 After the EU's ratification of the Paris Agreement, the EP should use its international influence and its participation as a member in international parliamentary networks to make a firm and swift move forward the ratification and implementation of the Paris Agreement by all concerned. Hence my vote in favour.

name: Roberta METSOLA
text: in writing. ‒ While I fully stand behind the UN’s efforts to combat and curtail climate change, I could not support this resolution as the final version of the text called for the introduction of a financial transaction tax, which would have a disproportionate negative effect on the Union’s smaller economies such as Malta and would infringe the principle of subsidiarity.

name: Louis MICHEL
text: Written. – In this resolution, the European Parliament sets out its position for the Climate Conference in Marrakesh in November. Following the ratification of the Paris Agreement, it is now a priority to implement the climate plan. This means that the binding aspects of the agreement, such as the ambition to reduce greenhouse gases to zero in the long term, the switch to a carbon-free economy, and the limiting of the temperature rise to 1.5°C, will be implemented effectively. The Commission is asked about a long-term strategy for a carbon-free economy. The transition to a climate-friendly economy also creates a support base for new and sustainable employment. This resolution rightly highlights the importance of forests and their capacity to mitigate climate change. The EP rightly urges all countries to take seriously the issue of climate refugees and the social consequences of climate change and to support developing countries in their efforts to achieve climate resilience. In order to continue to finance these ambitious climate plans, the EP wants concrete commitments at European and international level to provide additional sources of funding by setting aside some of the allowances and also looking at the introduction of a financial transaction tax.

name: Miroslav MIKOLÁŠIK
text: Writing. – From 7 to 18 November 2016, the Moroccan Marrakesh will take place on 22 November 2016. Conference of the Parties to the United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change (COP22). The main points of the negotiations will be: the role of non-state actors, the need for comprehensive efforts in all sectors, the reduction of CO2 emissions, resilience to climate change through adaptation, climate diplomacy, etc. The Paris Climate Agreement is a successful milestone in the fight against climate change, and it is also significant in its multilateral nature. Parliament's approval of the ratification of this agreement on 4 October 2016 will help speed up its entry into force. However, many areas remain unresolved. There is a need to establish a global framework of policies to regulate air and maritime transport in order to reduce emissions from international aviation and maritime transport, which was absent from the Paris Agreement. The Union and its Member States should continue to be actively involved in the so-called High Ambition Coalition, including by supporting the Moroccan Presidency in its focus on the contribution of renewable energy sources and adaptation measures in the global fight against the negative phenomena of climate change. Ambitious energy efficiency targets in the EU can help achieve an ambitious climate target while reducing the risk of carbon leakage. Finally, energy efficiency and renewables are among the main objectives of the EU's Energy Union.

name: Anne-Marie MINEUR
text: Written. 'On paragraph 62: The SP supports the introduction of a financial transaction tax, but wants the proceeds to be fully benefited from the Member States that levy the tax and are not added to the EU budget.

name: Marlene MIZZI
text: in writing. ‒ I have voted in favour of the resolution because it is vital that the EU as a whole ratifies the Paris Agreement before COP22 in Marrakesh in order to ensure the agreement enters into force, and to ensure that the EU is round the table at Marrakesh.

name: Csaba MOLNÁR
text: Writing. \u2012 The fight against global warming has previously been designed to limit global average temperatures to levels 2°C above pre-industrial levels. However, all parties to the Kyoto Protocol have shown a commitment to limit this to a much lower level and to make further efforts to limit the temperature increase to 1,5°C. Another objective is to balance human emissions from different sources and the removal of greenhouse gases by sinks in the second half of the century. The report of the Committee on the Environment, Public Health and Food Safety considers the global efforts to achieve these objectives and the Opportunities of the European Union to contribute as much as possible to them. I supported the adoption of the draft.

name: Cláudia MONTEIRO DE AGUIAR
text: in writing. Climate change is ongoing and human action has been the main cause of climate warming since the middle of the 20th century. The Paris Climate Agreement was a historic achievement in the fight against climate change and a commitment to reduce global emissions to zero net emissions during the second half of the century is healthy. The EU must endeave to exert pressure on parties that are not yet in line with the one outlined by the Paris Agreement. I support the need for further efforts to ensure the mobilisation of financial resources to combat climate change in order to reach the us$100 billion target by 2020.

name: Sophie MONTEL
text: In writing. Unsurprisingly, the resolution is enthusiastic and calls for urgent ratification of the Paris Agreements. It calls on the Union to make ever more efforts: more budget for green funds, more constraints on businesses (but by supporting economic development with the lips), more circular economy... And more migrants to welcome because of climate change! So I'm voting against it.

name: Nadine MORANO
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this text on the implementation of the Paris Agreement and the conference of the parties to the 2016 United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change (COP 22), to be held in Marrakech. The mobilization of the international community in the fight against global warming is necessary and must not stop. In this context, the European Union must retain its major and driving role in keeping temperature rises and polluting emissions limited.

name: Alessia Maria MOSCA
text: in writing. \u2012 Considering the importance of a rapid implementation of the Paris Agreement, the correlation between economic growth and the war on global warming; weighed up the need for a global response to climate change and recognised the need for a strengthening of the multilateral system; We are voting in favour of the resolution. The text, recognising, among others, the causal relationship between migration and climate change, the proportionality of which is constantly increasing, is welcomed. We also share the wish that the Member States will also ratify the agreement as quickly as possible. In this regard, in view of the Marrakesh Summit, we call on the representatives of the European Union to continue to participate in the so-called coalition of high ambition and to actively encourage other partners to follow the example of rapid approval of the text.  We also agree with the commission's call for European environmental objectives to be aligned with the commitments made in Paris. In order to achieve the targets set for 2020 and those set by the Kyoto Protocol, we recognise that the EU is on track to achieve them but, given the need for immediate action, we call for equal commitment on all sides of COP21.

name: Victor NEGRESCU
text: in writing. ‒ Human activities represent the main cause for global warming, with widespread and substantial change occurring in natural and human systems all over the world. I have voted for this motion for a resolution that urges countries to reduce their greenhouse gases, which are the main cause of the greenhouse effect.

name: Momchil NEKOV
text: in writing. – In 2014, several severe floods reached my country – Bulgaria. More than 207,000 acres of farmland have suffered, with the production of hundreds of farmers destroyed. And while there was financial compensation for that, I believe that's not the long-term solution. This painful example from my country and the thousands of others around the world shows that global warming is and is high time for measures and actions that will prevent or at least reduce climate change.  The EU's target of reducing emissions by 80-95% by 2050 from 1990 levels is ambitious, but should not become a filter for even tougher requirements for the European farmer and producer. I have supported this resolution, but I strongly believe that the sector providing livelihoods for all and livelihoods for many cannot be a bargaining chip in shaping the goals facing the world.  I therefore also call on the Council, on the eve of the Marrakesh Conference and the mid-term review of the CAP, to ensure that negotiations and the roadmap to achieving global objectives will not be detrimental to the European farmer. The vicious practice of farmers paying the bill for EU geopolitical solutions must be put to an end.

name: Dan NICA
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted for the European Parliament resolution on the implementation of the Paris Agreement and the 2016 UN Conference in Marrakesh, Morocco, on climate change (COP 22). As a member of the delegation that will participate in COP22 and as shadow rapporteur for the COP22 resolution in the ITRE Committee, I stress that we must at the same time ensure energy security, sustainable economic growth and the creation of sustainable jobs, alongside the fight against climate change. Climate investment requires a stable and predictable legal framework, as well as clear policy signals. Until a level playing field is ensured, the EU should maintain appropriate and proportionate measures to ensure the competitiveness of its own industries and prevent, where necessary, carbon leakage, bearing in mind that coherence must be consistent between energy, industry and climate policies. A more ambitious energy efficiency target in the European Union can help achieve an ambitious climate target, while at the same time reducing the risk of carbon leakage. I also stress the need to prevent and alleviate energy poverty in order to protect and help vulnerable and poor households.

name: Luděk NIEDERMAYER
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported the resolution, which stresses, among other things, the need to make greater efforts to ensure that climate finance funds are mobilised in order to meet the USD 100 billion target by 2020. This is a relatively high amount, which is intended to be directed mainly to emerging economies. So far, however, for the most part, this is money that is only on paper. Therefore, we need to focus on adopting specific EU and international commitments to help raise additional funding to finance climate action, such as projects to promote technological innovation. One way to do this could be to introduce a financial transaction tax on a global scale, possibly on the OECD platform.

name: Rolandas PAKSAS
text: Writing. – I voted in favour of this resolution.  First of all, it is necessary to ratify and implement the Paris Agreement. In order to achieve the objectives set, a firmly scientifically sound climate policy must be pursued. It is essential that the Commission carry out a comprehensive assessment of the possible consequences of the Paris Agreement for the EU budget and establish a separate automatic EU financial mechanism. Particular attention must be paid to the contribution of renewable energy sources and adaptation measures to the global fight against climate change. I believe that the proposal to introduce a legally binding instrument for the human rights approach of multinational corporations and other businesses should be considered and should be considered for regulating the activities of multinational corporations and other businesses under the international human rights legal framework. In addition, all sectors need to step up their efforts to combat climate change. Industry and competitiveness, energy policy, research, innovation and digital technologies play a particular role in this area.

name: Demetris PAPADAKIS
text: Writing. \u2012 The relevant motion for a resolution aims to define the position of the European Parliament in view of the COP22 Climate Conference in Marrakech, Morocco. The draft resolution addresses issues such as the urgent need to implement the Paris Agreement (COP21), the drastic reduction of greenhouse gas emissions, the implementation of the EU's renewable energy target by 2020. At the same time, further efforts are needed to ensure that funding is mobilised to tackle climate change. Overall, the draft resolution welcomes the Paris Agreement as an achievement in the fight against climate change and as an ambitious, balanced, fair and legally binding agreement. It also welcomes the commitment of all countries to limit the increase in average global temperature to levels well below 2°C and to continue efforts to limit its increase to 1.5°C. For all these reasons, I voted in favour of this motion for a resolution.

name: Gilles PARGNEAUX
text: In writing. As the European Parliament's rapporteur on COP 21, I would like to begin by welcoming the ratification by the European Union of the Paris Agreement, which was formalised yesterday by our vote in plenary. Our challenge is met! The Paris Agreement will enter into force at the 22nd Un Climate Change Conference. This is a first victory! Of course, much remains to be done in the fight against climate change.  If COP 21 were the decision-making, COP 22 will be the one of action. COP 22 will have to implement the Paris Agreement in practice, including the creation of innovative financing to combat climate change, such as the adoption of a financial transaction tax, the setting of a floor price per tonne of carbon and the reform of the European Emissions Trading System (ETS).

name: Margot PARKER
text: in writing. ‒ We in UKIP are against this resolution because we object to the Paris Agreement and the climate change alarmism supported by green lobbies. They are the cause of our current damaging and counter-productive energy policy.

name: Aldo PATRICIELLO
text: in writing. \u2012 There is no doubt that the commitment to mitigate global warming is a priority, but it is important that this objective is pursued not by hindering economic growth, but on the contrary by acting as a catalyst by creating new jobs in a sustainable way. Therefore, I do not feel able to support it and I would vote against it.

name: Eva MAYDELL
text: in writing. – I voted in favour of this resolution as it aims to define the position of the European Parliament in view of the COP22 Climate Conference in November 2016 in Marrakesh. The resolution addresses important issues such as the urgency to ratify and implement the Paris Agreement, the pre-2020 ambition and the Kyoto Protocol, the priority negotiation points in COP22, the role of non-state actors, the comprehensive effort of all sectors, the reduction of non-CO2 emissions, climate finance, climate resilience through adaptation, and climate diplomacy, among other issues  Overall, the resolution welcomes the Paris Climate Agreement as a landmark achievement for combating climate change and for multilateralism.

name: Marijana PETIR
text: Written. ‒ I welcome the European Parliament's resolution on the occasion of the UN Climate Change Conference, which will be held in 2016 in Marrakech, Morocco. The consequences of recent climate change are visible in all parts of the world and we all feel them today. The urgent need to ratify and implement the Paris Agreement is a clear commitment made by all countries to limit the growth in global average temperatures that have been emerging since the mid-20th century as a result of human activity. It is our responsibility and duty to future generations to significantly start reducing greenhouse gas emissions today. Early decarbonisation is needed to limit the increase in global average temperature below 2°C, but at the same time it is necessary to continue efforts to limit this increase to 1.5°C.  At the same time, these efforts must also involve the development of carbon-free technologies and energy, and in the development of these technologies, the European Union must maintain its leadership position. They will only hold this position if they set sufficiently challenging goals in front of them with clear deadlines for achieving them.  I support this resolution and stress that the European Parliament must play a role in the formation and implementation of The European Climate Change Policy, which is why I expect the EP to have guaranteed access to all preparatory documents for the upcoming Marrakesh conference from the outset.

name: Tonino PICULA
text: Written. ‒in 2012, the EP cited as priorities outlined in the Resolution: a comprehensive effort by all sectors (the EP warns of emissions related to land use for agricultural purposes, for livestock farming, forestry and the problem of emissions in the transport sector); reducing non-CO2 emissions (the EP also warns of the importance of mitigating emissions of so-called short-lived pollutants such as black carbon, hydro fluorocarbon and methane, in order to slow short-term warming); the role of non-state actors (underlines the importance of dialogue between governments, the business community, cities, regions, international organisations, civil society and academic institutions in order to foster strong global action); climate finance (EP notes that further efforts are needed to ensure the mobilisation of climate finance to meet the 100 billion USD target by 2020); climate diplomacy (THE EP underlines the importance of the EU's focus on climate diplomacy to this day, and welcomes the continuation of such action and sees the EU as a leader in climate-related forums); resilience to climate change through adaptation.  For all of the above, I support the adoption of the aforementioned resolution.

name: João PIMENTA LOPES
text: in writing. \u2012 This resolution addresses the preparation of the 22nd UN Conference of the Parties on Climate Change, to be held later this year in Marrakesh. Inevitably, the Conference will take place under the sign of the Paris Conference and the agreement reached there. This resolution also reflects that. We do not follow the laudatory tone regarding the Paris Agreement. In fact, there are several problems with this agreement. In addition to not having agreed concrete limits on GHG emissions, the agreement maintains and legitimises a market approach to the problem of climate change, of which carbon trading is the main (but not only) instrument. The Agreement abandoned the principle of "common but differentiated responsibility", between developing and industrialised countries, opting for a single system that could deepen injustices between the countries that have contributed the most to the accumulation of carbon in the atmosphere and developing countries. The Agreement also includes a funding dimension of projects by large transnational groups in developing countries, enhancing the imperialist domination of the resources of these countries. These are views and options which are also shaped and defended in this resolution, which we are of course opposed to and to which we oppose an alternative vision, based on a normative approach and a common but necessarily differentiated responsibility.

name: Franck PROUST
text: In writing. Ahead of the United Nations Conference of the Parties on Climate Change (COP 22) in Marrakech in November 2016, I voted in favour of this resolution, which reiterates the need to implement the commitments of states set out at the signing of the historic COP 21 agreement in Paris.  The upcoming debates will focus on the tools to be implemented to ensure that the goal of a 2-degree reduction is truly achievable. States parties to the COP must move from words to deeds. The European Union will also need to continue to play its role as an international leader in the fight against global warming by adopting new emissions targets by 2050.

name: Julia REID
text: in writing. ‒ We in UKIP are against this resolution because we object to the Paris Agreement and the climate change alarmism supported by green lobbies. They are the cause of our current damaging and counter-productive energy policy.

name: Sofia RIBEIRO
text: in writing. \u2012 Whereas the Paris Agreement will enter into force on the 30th day after the date on which at least 55 Parties to the Convention and about 55 % of the total global greenhouse gas emissions have deposited their instruments of ratification, acceptance, approval or un-entry, Parliament refers to a number of issues such as climate action based on a sound scientific basis; the urgency of ratifying and implementing the Paris Agreement; the Conference of the Parties (COP) 22 in Marrakesh; ambition pre-2020 and the Kyoto Protocol; the comprehensive effort of all sectors; reducing greenhouse gas emissions, industry and competitiveness; energy policy; research, innovation and digital technologies; the role of non-state actors; resistance to climate change through adaptation; among others. The EP undertakes to ratify the Paris Agreement as soon as possible, as well as to use its influence at international level and its participation as a member in international parliamentary networks to advance firmly and swiftly the ratification and implementation of the Paris Agreement. In view of the above in this report, I voted in favour.

name: Frédérique RIES
text: In writing. Two days after the solemn session that saw the European Parliament ratify the Paris climate agreement, the climate issue was back on the agenda this afternoon with the vote on the resolution on the Marrakech conference (COP 22). The task that awaits the parties that will meet from 7 to 18 November 2016 is immense if they are to achieve the goal of containing the rise in global temperatures below 2oC compared to the pre-industrial era. Six eminent climate scientists have written an opinion piece, published by the NGO Universal Ecological Fund, to express concern about the acceleration of global warming and the practical impossibility of meeting the Paris commitment, without doubling efforts. And that is the whole problem in the absence of a binding mechanism provided for by this international treaty and without further elaboration on how to mobilize $100 billion annually for climate action by 2020.  That is to say if COP 22 has "bread on the board". The era of carbon-free is still wishful thinking, 82% of all the world's energy still comes from the burning of oil, coal and natural gas!

name: Inma RODRÍGUEZ-PIÑERO
text: in writing. The historic Paris Agreement reached in December 2015 was a historic achievement for the fight against climate change and multilateralism, representing an ambitious, balanced, equitable and legally binding agreement. The adoption of the Agreement and the submission of the planned contributions determined at the national level by 187 States Parties has marked a decisive turning point towards comprehensive and collective global action, and, once implemented, will be a major step in the transition to a resilient climate and a climate-neutral global economy. The next Climate Conference in Marrakesh will need to address the urgency of ratifying and implementing the Paris Agreement, pre-2020 ambition and the Kyoto Protocol; the details of a global inventory; further guidance on planned contributions determined at the national level; a mechanism to facilitate implementation and promote compliance; shape the 2018 facilitation dialogue, which will be a key opportunity to close the mitigation gap, given current national contributions; and to expand the mobilization of climate funds in order to achieve the common target of $100 billion per year by 2020, issues set out in this resolution in which I voted in favour.

name: Claude ROLIN
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the European Parliament's resolution of 6 October 2016 on the implementation of the Paris Agreement and on the conference of the parties to the 2016 United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change (COP22), to be held in Marrakech, Morocco.  Through this resolution, the European Parliament pledges on the one hand to ratify the Paris Agreement as soon as possible and to work towards its implementation, and, on the other hand, advocates being an integral part of the European Union's delegation to COP 22. Indeed, the Marrakesh negotiations aim to make progress on the key elements of the Paris agreement and the european Parliament should therefore attend these coordination meetings.

name: Bronis ROPĖ
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this resolution. This resolution commits itself to ratifying the Paris Agreement as soon as possible, to use its international role and membership of international parliamentary networks in order to make consistent efforts to make progress towards the swift ratification and implementation of the Paris Agreement. This resolution shows that the European Parliament remains ready to pursue an ambitious plan to reduce climate change.

name: Fernando RUAS
text: in writing. The Paris Climate Agreement is an unparalleled historic achievement in the fight against climate change and in favour of multilateralism. This is an ambitious, balanced, equitable and legally binding agreement and its adoption of the agreement marks a decisive turning point for more comprehensive and collective action at global level in combating climate change. Despite the positive commitment made by all countries to limit global average warming, this does not in itself guarantee that important negative repercussions on the climate can be avoided and the concrete political implications of limiting global warming to 1.5 °C can be avoided.   The EU has actively promoted the implementation of this Agreement and should therefore prove to respect it, including by reviewing its own long-term policy objectives and instruments- and initiating this process as early as possible.  The EU's tireless commitment to "climate diplomacy" is essential to improving the perception of the importance of this fight, especially among global public opinion and in third countries where such perception is small or non-existent. I also believe that a sound architecture for the implementation of this Agreement is fundamental - ideas also expressed in this report which I voted in favour of.

name: Tokia SAÏFI
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this resolution, which sets out the European Parliament's position for the holding of COP 22 next November in Marrakech. COP 22 should focus on the progress of ratification and implementation of the Paris Agreement. The European Union will have to ensure that it maintains its leadership in the fight against climate change.  Much remains to be done in this area and all stakeholders, both in the public and private domains, must contribute to this global action.

name: Lola SÁNCHEZ CALDENTEY
text: in writing. I voted to abstain since, although I believe that the ratification of the Paris Agreement by each member state is paramount to ensuring the fight against climate change, I understand that this report is only a first step. The Paris Agreement is wholly insufficient to achieve the very long-term objective set: not to exceed 2oC in temperature rise at the end of this century. The report is based on false solutions such as the Emission Trading System (ETS) whose exchange of emissions bonds contributes to the financing of nature and allows the one who pays more to pollute more. The REDD+ system also puts biodiversity at risk and causes land grabbing, endangering indigenous peoples.  This report is only a first step in carrying out this fight as it leaves out important issues such as the modification of the productive and agri-food system. The Paris Agreement does not even remotely mention agriculture. Industrial agriculture is among the main leaders of anthropogenic climate change, while climate change is one of the biggest problems related to food security.

name: Daciana Octavia SÂRBU
text: in writing. ‒ I supported this resolution and I am in favour of a rapid ratification of the Paris agreement by all parties. It is critical for the environment, and for the European industries working hard to reduce their emissions, that there is a global framework in place. A binding agreement which includes all major emitters should reduce unfair competition for European producers and help limit temperature increases to less than 2° above pre-industrial levels. Failure to reach this 2° target would be likely to cause significant environmental, economic and social pressures in the medium and long term.

name: Sven SCHULZE
text: Writing. I voted in favour of the resolution on the implementation of the Paris Agreement and for the next UN climate change conference in Marrakesh (Morocco). In doing so, the EU is paving the way for the Global Climate Treaty as the first binding agreement to combat global warming.  The aim of the Paris Agreement is to ensure that, from 2050, no more carbon dioxide is emitted worldwide than is absorbed at the same time (CO2 neutrality). With the treaty, the world community commits to limiting global warming to "well below two degrees Celsius" compared to pre-industrial times. The historic Paris climate agreement can now enter into force at the beginning of November.

name: Maria Lidia SENRA RODRÍGUEZ
text: in writing. After the Paris Agreement, the purposes of combating climate change are primarily based on voluntary commitments and market mechanisms. This resolution, even more ambitious, continues on the same path, so I abstained.

name: Siôn SIMON
text: in writing. ‒ Today, I voted in favour of the European Parliament resolution on the implementation of the Paris Agreement and the 2016 UN Climate Change Conference in Marrakesh, Morocco (COP22). Parliament believes that negotiations should advance on the key elements of the Paris Agreement such as the enhanced transparency framework and stresses the urgency of ratifying and implementing the Paris Agreement.

name: Davor ŠKRLEC
text: Written. ‒ I voted positively for this report, but this explanation of the vote is a criticism of the existing system of evaluation of the work of MEMBERS of the European Parliament solely on the basis of the statistical number of parliamentary activities potentiated in Croatia, which does not really reflect the actual quality and quantity of work, efficiency and most of all the success of parliamentary action.

name: Monika SMOLKOVÁ
text: Writing. \u2012 According to scientific evidence from 2014, the warming of the climate system is indisputable, climate change is taking place and human activity has been the main reason for observed warming since the mid-20th century. The large and significant consequences of climate change are already clear in natural and human systems on all continents and in the oceans. The UN Climate Change Conference in Marrakesh should build on the Paris Agreement, in particular in the area of climate finance and capacity support. The EU has the capacity, but also the obligation to to lead by example and start working immediately to align climate and energy targets with the agreed international objective of limiting the increase in the global average temperature to below 2 ⁰C, while at the same time seeking to limit its increase to 1.5 ⁰C.

name: Igor ŠOLTES
text: Writing. The resolution contains the views of the European Parliament for the next conference of the parties to the so-called the Paris Agreement to combat climate change, which will take place from 7 to 18 November 2016. The resolution outlines ambitious positions and calls on the Member States to take an even more active stand to combat climate change. Among other things, the resolution calls on developed countries to further accelerate dialogue to reduce greenhouse gas emissions more extensively and to implement the Paris Agreement as soon as possible. Parliament expresses its disappointment at the international civil aviation organisation's current proposal for the current legislation. I consider it very important that the resolution also contains serious recognition of the existence of so-called climate refugees. Population migration due to a changed climate is a real problem of today, so we must not turn a blind eye to the problems associated with such migration. At the same time, it is also important that the resolution calls on countries to increase the creation of leverage, which will only be used to combat climate change. I voted in favour of the resolution because of the extremely important thesae.

name: Joachim STARBATTY
text: Writing. This report addresses the European Parliament's priorities for preparing for the COP 22 conference in Marrakesh in November 2016. It contains welcome aspects, such as linking the European emissions trading system with other markets or measures to limit carbon leakages – the shift in European emissions by emigrating production to other regions of the world. ALFA supports these points. However, the report also advocates a financial transaction tax. That is why I chose to abstain in the final vote.

name: Ivan ŠTEFANEC
text: Writing. \u2012 The European Union is coming to COP22 with concrete proposals that represent a balance between the need to slow global warming and the need not to jeopardise industrial production and jobs. Modernisation and digitalisation in industry, motorism and agriculture are instruments that will play a key role in combating planetary pollution.

name: Dubravka ŠUICA
text: Written. ‒The existence of climate change is unquestionable today. They are a consequence of human activity and are already clearly discerned in both developing countries and less developed countries. They are causing difficulties in the economy and political disagreements, and could also lead to population migration. The Paris Agreement is seen as an extremely important tool for preventing climate change, which aims to highlight the importance of energy efficiency, the use of renewable energy sources and the reduction of emissions of harmful substances, all with the aim of reducing potential climate-induced poverty and increasing economic growth. I support the proposal for a resolution on the implementation of the Paris Agreement and the UN Climate Change Conference to be held in 2016 in Marrakech. The ratification of the Paris Agreement plays parliament's role in addressing this problem, as Parliament has the power to adopt concrete measures.

name: Eleftherios SYNADINOS
text: Writing. \u2012 The environment must be protected from human polluting and harmful interference.

name: Tibor SZANYI
text: Writing. \u2012 The motion for a resolution aims to summarise the Positions of the European Parliament for the Marrakesh Climate Conference in November. It raises specific issues such as the urgency to ratify the Paris Climate Agreement, pre-2020 efforts and the Kyoto protocol, the priority points of COP22 negotiations, the role of non-state actors, a comprehensive effort in all sectors, reducing non-CO2 emissions, climate finances, climate resilience and adaptation, and climate diplomacy. I share the finding that scientific evidence confirms the warming and change of the climate system and that the main reason for this is the accelerated human activity since the mid-20th century.  In cooperation with the proposal, I urge all countries to accelerate the transition to near-zero greenhouse gas emissions and climate change resistance, as agreed in the Paris Agreement, in order to avoid the worst effects of global warming. The agreement therefore encourages a shift in investment from fossil fuel investments to low-carbon and safe investments. The European Union must also take the lead in the conciliation process, so I voted in favour of this motion. I am pleased that the relevant EU institutions have also ratified the Paris Climate Agreement, so that the Moroccan climate summit can rightly be called a 'party'.

name: Adam SZEJNFELD
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 On the 21st. The Conference of the Parties (COP 21) on climate change in Paris in December 2015 adopted an agreement on global climate action. The aim of the agreement is to keep the increase in the global average temperature well below 2°C above pre-industrial levels and to continue to seek to limit the increase to 1.5°C. In the run-up to COP 22, to be held in Marrakesh on 7-18 November 2016, consideration should be made on what action the European Union and individual Member States should take to ensure that key elements of the Paris Agreement are met without harming the competitiveness of European industry. The imposition of increasing climate requirements and subsequent obligations on industrial companies in the European Union lead to a reduction in their competitive advantage in the global market. Some companies will move their operations out of the EU in saving their profitability. Others, on the other hand, will go bankrupt or severely restrict their activities in Europe. The European Union should therefore play a leading role in the fight against climate change in this process, provided, however, that this process is global and not limited to Europe.

name: Hannu TAKKULA
text: Written. \u2012 I voted against the motion for a resolution because it does not take sufficient account of the specific characteristics of active and sustainable forest management in the Nordic countries as part of the implementation of the Paris Agreement on climate change, in particular on land use, land use change and forests.

name: Claudia ȚAPARDEL
text: in writing. \u2012 The adoption of the Paris Agreement was a decisive moment in the international community's fight against climate change. Its implementation will determine how our children will live in the coming decades. The European Union and the Member States were among the main supporters of the adoption of the agreement, which has 187 signatory parties and which is a balanced, ambitious and fair document. Setting a global average temperature increase ceiling of 1.5 degrees Celsius compared to the pre-industrial era is an important commitment of the signatory states. In the context of the 2016 UN Conference on Climate Change (COP22), the current resolution draws attention to the need for ratification and immediate implementation of the Paris Agreement by EU Member States, assesses the state of implementation of the Kyoto Protocol, highlights the role of non-state actors in reducing polluting emissions, the importance of climate finance and diplomatic dialogue with other international actors. It also mentions the importance for this area of adapting industrial production, energy policies, research, innovation and digital technologies, support for developing countries. I support the adoption of this resolution which is so relevant to achieving the objectives of halting climate warming in the period ahead.

name: Marc TARABELLA
text: In writing. We welcome the Paris climate agreement, voted this week by the European Parliament, a historic event in the fight against climate change and for multilateralism. We believe that this is an ambitious, balanced agreement, fair and legally binding, that its adoption, in addition to the announcement by 187 parties before the end of COP21 of planned contributions determined at the national level (CPDN), marks a decisive turning point on the path to global, global and collective action and that, once implemented, this agreement and these contributions will permanently and irreversibly accelerate the transition to a global economy that is resilient to climate change and climate change. Neutral. We intend to work tirelessly in the same way for COP22

name: Pavel TELIČKA
text: in writing. ‒ The 22nd United Nations Conference of the Parties (COP 22), which will be held in Marrakesh, Morocco in November 2016, is of particular importance because it will bring into force the Paris Climate Change Agreement adopted last year, a landmark achievement in combating climate change. The quick implementation of the Paris Agreement by all parties, including the EU, is of the utmost importance. While the Paris Agreement gave clear pathways and a final destination in respect of decisive action on climate change, many of the details regarding how to move forward as one global community in that common direction still need to be resolved. This meeting is therefore incredibly important. I voted in favour of the resolution, supporting the EU ambition that is in line with the objectives of the Agreement. COP22 in Marrakesh will take the first concrete steps to implement the Paris Agreement, which sets the objective of holding the increase in the global average temperature to well below 2° and pursues efforts to limit the increase to 1.5°.

name: Isabelle THOMAS
text: In writing. The European Parliament has just voted to ratify the Paris Agreement, which Member States must take up immediately. It is time to take action at COP 22 in Marrakech. I supported this resolution because now COP 22 must implement all the measures adopted in the Paris Agreement to reduce greenhouse gas emissions.  Through this resolution, we reaffirm and recall the decisive role of non-state actors in the transition to a decarbonised economy. All economic sectors must also make an immediate commitment to reducing greenhouse gases.  Consequently, the issue of financing the ecological transition is at the heart of this resolution and I welcome the adoption of the amendments of the Group of Socialists and Democrats, in particular those aimed at financing the transition to a sustainable development model.  The resolution also reaffirms the necessary respect for human rights in the fight against climate change.

name: Ruža TOMAŠIĆ
text: Written. ‒ The European Parliament's resolution on the United Nations Climate Change Conference to be held in Marrakech in November 2016 supports the International Climate Agreement in Paris and proposes more ambitious climate change targets.  My position is that in order to protect people, living conditions and ecosystems, we must face the global challenge posed by climate change and strengthen resilience and reduce vulnerability to climate change.  However, I believe that Member States and other participating countries cannot achieve the proposed increased targets, and I believe that increasing funding to fight climate change would only create an additional burden on Member States without any long-term progress at local, national, regional and international level. Therefore, I did not support this resolution.

name: Romana TOMC
text: Writing. I voted in favour of the European Parliament resolution on the implementation of the Paris Agreement and the 2016 UN Climate Change Conference in Marrakesh, Morocco (COP 22). The Paris Agreement on climate change is an important milestone in the fight against climate change. The agreement is ambitious, balanced, fair and legally binding. The adoption of the agreement and the joint proclamation of the planned, nationally determined contributions from the 187 Parties before the end of COP 21 constitute an important turning point for comprehensive and joint global action, and the agreement, once it is made, will accelerate the transition to a climate-resilient climate-resilient global economy once it has been completed. The EU is on track to exceed its greenhouse gas emission reduction targets by 2020 and meet its 2020 renewable energy target.

name: Estefanía TORRES MARTÍNEZ
text: in writing. I have decided to abstain in this vote because, while I believe that the ratification of the Paris Agreement by each Member State is paramount to ensuring the fight against climate change, I understand that this report is only a first step. The Paris Agreement is wholly insufficient to achieve the very long-term objective set: not to exceed 2oC in temperature rise at the end of this century. The report is based on false solutions such as the Emission Trading System (ETS) whose exchange of emissions bonds contributes to the financing of nature and allows the one who pays more to pollute more. The REDD+ system also puts biodiversity at risk and causes land grabbing, endangering indigenous peoples.  This report is only a first step in carrying out this fight as it leaves out important issues such as the modification of the productive and agri-food system. The Paris Agreement does not even remotely mention agriculture. Industrial agriculture is among the main leaders of anthropogenic climate change, while climate change is one of the biggest problems related to food security.

name: Ulrike TREBESIUS
text: Writing. This report addresses the European Parliament's priorities for preparing for the COP 22 conference in Marrakesh in November 2016. It contains welcome aspects, such as linking the European emissions trading system with other markets or measures to limit carbon leakages – the shift in European emissions by emigrating production to other regions of the world. ALFA supports these points. However, the report also advocates a financial transaction tax or an increase in the climate and efficiency targets that have already been set. That is why I chose to abstain in the final vote.

name: Mylène TROSZCZYNSKI
text: In writing. This resolution is part of COP 22, which will take place in Marrakech in November 2016. The European Parliament sends an official delegation, which is included and does not participate in the negotiations. Barbara Kappel will represent the ENL group. This resolution must express the wishes conveyed to the Commission's negotiators.  Unsurprisingly, the resolution is enthusiastic and calls for urgent ratification of the Paris Agreements. It calls on the EU to make ever more efforts: more budget for green funds, more constraints for businesses (but by supporting economic development with the lips), more circular economy, and calls on EU countries to take in more "climatic" migrants.  I voted against this resolution.

name: Kazimierz Michał UJAZDOWSKI
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 The resolution sets out Parliament's main priorities ahead of the Conference of the Parties to the United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change. Parliament's agreement to ratify this agreement will bring it into force at COP22 in Marakesh in November 2016, which is a welcome reason. The resolution addresses important m.in the need to reduce greenhouse gas emissions, the need to reduce aviation and maritime emissions and reaffirms the growing importance of climate diplomacy. However, amendments have been made to the original motion for a resolution calling for even more ambitious climate policy targets by 2030, thereby raising even more resources to combat climate change. I voted in favour of the ratification of the Paris Agreement, and I believe that it sets ambitious targets and there is no need to set ourselves even higher, excessive aspirations and to allocate an additional pot of money for this purpose. I voted against the resolution.

name: Miguel URBÁN CRESPO
text: in writing. I have decided to abstain in this vote because, while I believe that the ratification of the Paris Agreement by each member state is paramount to ensuring the fight against climate change, I understand that this report is only a first step. The Paris Agreement is wholly insufficient to achieve the very long-term objective set: not to exceed 2oC in temperature rise at the end of this century. The report is based on false solutions such as the Emission Trading System (ETS) whose exchange of emissions bonds contributes to the financing of nature and allows the one who pays more to pollute more. The REDD+ system also puts biodiversity at risk and causes land grabbing, endangering indigenous peoples.  This report is only a first step in carrying out this fight as it leaves out important issues such as the modification of the productive and agri-food system. The Paris Agreement does not even remotely mention agriculture. Industrial agriculture is among the main leaders of anthropogenic climate change, while climate change is one of the biggest problems related to food security.

name: Ernest URTASUN
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this resolution as it sets the European Parliament's position at the next conference in Marrakesh to combat climate change while maintaining Parliament's ambitious position, although I regret that the Union did not want to set more ambitious targets.

name: Viktor USPASKICH
