text: Writing. – I welcome the commitment of the Paris Agreement to reduce global carbon emissions to zero in the second half of the century, as well as the development of emission trading systems (ETS) worldwide, including 17 ETS, which cover four continents and cover 40% of world GDP and contribute to economically efficient global emissions reductions.

name: Ivo VAJGL
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the motion for a resolution on the implementation of the Paris Agreement and the 2016 UN Climate Change Conference in Marrakesh, Morocco. The Paris Agreement is to enter into force on the thirtieth day after the date on which at least 55 Parties to the Convention, accounting in total for at least an estimated 55% of the total global GHG emissions, have deposited their instruments of ratification, acceptance, approval or accession to the UN. The most serious effects of climate change will be felt in developing countries, particularly in those least developed countries and developing small island states that have insufficient resources to prepare for and adjust to the changes. The resolution underlines that the EU has both the capacity and responsibility to lead by example and to start work immediately on aligning its climate and energy targets with the agreed international goal of limiting the increase in global average temperature to below 2°C, while pursuing efforts to limit that increase to 1.5°C. I voted in favour because I believe that combating climate change is the priority and should be pursued worldwide while ensuring energy security and the development of sustainable economic growth and jobs.

name: Ramón Luis VALCÁRCEL SISO
text: in writing. The Paris Agreement represents a before and after in the fight against climate change globally, designing the path to a low-greenhouse gas development model. The implementation of the Agreement should be promoted at this stage, ensuring the presence of climate change on the political agendas of world leaders beyond COP21. In this regard, COP22 will be erected as a reference point that will allow the integration of what was agreed in Paris with the implementation of concrete actions for the fight against climate change. The union's leadership in Paris must be maintained, and early ratification of the Agreement is key in the first place. I have thus supported with my vote the resolution setting out the position of the European Parliament in view of the conference to be held in Marrakesh and invites the Council to adopt without further resignation, on behalf of the Union, the Paris Agreement. Rapid ratification by its Member States will consolidate the Union as a leading player in the fight against climate change.

name: Ángela VALLINA
text: in writing. After the Paris Agreement, the purposes of combating climate change are primarily based on voluntary commitments and market mechanisms. This resolution, even more ambitious, continues on the same path, so I abstained.

name: Hilde VAUTMANS
text: Written. 'Global climate action must be carried out on a sound scientific basis. The report urges developed countries, and in particular the EU, to drastically and more reduce their greenhouse gas emissions than has been promised so far. I voted in favour of this report because there is an urgent need to ratify and implement the Paris Agreement.

name: Marie-Christine VERGIAT
text: In writing. This resolution affirms that the Paris Agreement is "ambitious, balanced, fair and legally binding" when we know that most of the provisions are non-binding and that the historical issues that needed to be addressed were largely missed. The resolution also admits that the sum of "nationally determined contributions" at the global level "does not even allow us to approach the goal" of limiting global warming to a maximum of 2oC, and that this limit, which is unattainable as it stands, "does not guarantee that serious impacts on the climate will be avoided". It would be almost laughable if the stakes were not so high. The text also makes the "carbon market" the alpha and omega of the fight against climate change, while emissions trading systems have largely demonstrated their inefficiency and dangerousness. And what about the vain request addressed "to the developed countries, especially those of the Union, to reduce their greenhouse gas emissions in a draconian way, beyond the current commitments", when we know that in practice they are doing exactly the opposite as we see in France with the government's stubbornness to maintain the Notre Dame des Landes project. So I chose to abstain.

name: Miguel VIEGAS
text: in writing. The Paris Agreement has been called historic. The big problem is that COP-21 has not set goals or set ways to achieve the objectives presented. And postponed the problem to 2030. In this sense, the Marrakesh conference (COP 22) should not bring any news. The rich countries will continue to beat their chests, hoping that this alone can reduce emissions and match the pious promises and agreements signed. They will continue to propose market solutions to solve a problem whose root lies precisely in the market economy and capitalism with its profit accumulation logic. For us Communists, the resolution of this environmental urgency is inseparable from the struggle to overcome capitalism and the emergence of a new society and a new model of social production in which the state has control of the fundamental levers of the economy. Everything else will be more palliative.

name: Harald VILIMSKY
text: Writing. The motion for a resolution welcomes the Paris Agreement (COP 21), which I have already rejected for several serious reasons, as a 'milestone in the fight against climate change'. It also calls for the Paris Agreement to enter into force quickly. I have therefore rejected this request.

name: Daniele VIOTTI
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the motion for a resolution which aims to define the European Parliament's position on the implementation of the Paris Agreement and the 2016 Un climate change conference in Marrakech.  The resolution urges developed countries, in particular the EU, to drastically reduce greenhouse gas emissions beyond the commitments already made to prevent the large-scale occurrence of negative emissions. It welcomes the Paris Climate Agreement as an historic achievement in the fight against climate change as an ambitious, balanced agreement which represents a decisive turning point towards global and collective action at world level to protect the environment.  The motion for a resolution also stresses the importance of research and innovation in combating climate change in an economically effective manner and stresses the need to promote universal access to sustainable energy in developing countries.

name: Julie WARD
text: in writing. ‒ We must build on the momentum built up at COP21, and work towards implementation and ever more ambitious targets. This is extremely important given recent reports that the world has now passed the threshold of 400 ppm of carbon dioxide in the atmosphere. EU Member States must do all they can to drastically reduce their greenhouse gas emissions.

name: Jana ŽITŇANSKÁ
text: Writing. \u2012 This resolution aims to set out the European Parliament's priorities for the forthcoming 22nd Conference of the Parties to the UN Convention on Climate Change, which will be held in Morocco in November. Like the Paris Conference, the 22nd Conference will address the need to keep global warming below 2°C and ideally below 1.5°C.  It is for this very purpose that the resolution proposes a number of ways to achieve this ambitious objective, from decarbonisation to preventing forest degradation. Overall, it calls on the Commission and the Member States to step up efforts to achieve the objectives, as well as to encourage partner countries to participate in their implementation. The report also addresses the need for adaptation measures for the population in the context of climate change. However, as the report also contained a number of articles that I could not support, such as the introduction of a financial transaction tax, I voted against it in the final vote.

name: Carlos ZORRINHO
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the resolution on the 2016 United Nations Climate Change Conference in Marrakesh, Morocco for advocating the need to tackle the global challenge of climate change through international cooperation. I would stress the presentation of several amendments to the text of the resolution, including the call for concerted action by the EU and other major global emitters to bring together the "planned contributions determined at national level" to the 2°C target. In this context, I would recall the historic ratification of the Paris Agreement by the European Parliament on 4 October, which will allow it to enter into force as early as 4 November 2016 by setting in motion the first conference of the parties in Marrakesh under the new Agreement.

name: Marco ZULLO
text: in writing. The resolution, which I voted in favour of, takes account of the issue of climate change outright, starting from considering the positive effects, including from an economic and innovation point of view, that have resulted from the policies to reduce emissions and promote renewables by 2020. We must continue negotiations on the key elements of the Paris Agreement. This resolution urges the Commission and the Member States to honour their commitments under the Paris Agreement. In addition, they are encouraged to make efforts to speed up the progress of the negotiations and to support the Moroccan Presidency in promoting the contribution of renewable energies and adaptation measures to the global fight against climate change. I believe that joint timing and efforts are essential to combat climate change. The EU can play an ambitious and central role in this issue by taking responsibility for leading by example on an issue as important as climate change. Europe must immediately start work on climate and energy in order to bring its objectives into line with the agreed international target of limiting the increase in the world average temperature below 2 °C.

name: Milan ZVER
text: Writing. I voted in favour of the European Parliament resolution on the implementation of the Paris Agreement and the 2016 UN Climate Change Conference in Marrakesh, Morocco (COP 22). The resolution notes that the emission reduction plan is not ambitious enough to achieve the Paris Agreement targets, therefore, calls on EU Member States to reduce emissions below current commitments and encourages politically and financially coordinated efforts for sustainable development. I believe that the calls are justified, as the consequences of climate change are often irreversible and cause economic, ecological and social losses. It is important that the EU maintains its leading role in preventing climate change and actively participates in climate for a, such as the upcoming Marrakech, in order to achieve the global success of the Paris Agreement commitments with partner countries.

name: Krisztina MORVAI
text: - Mr President, I would like to thank the European A fashionable term is konteo, conspiracy theory, conspiracy theory. But more and more conspiracy theories are becoming true, so it was a shame to laugh so much at the people who spread them. It's also the fact that our food, the food we eat, what we're forced to eat, and what we eat on a daily basis, is potentially life-threatening. As in this report, the Schaldemose report, the substances in contact with food, reveal that what we eat can cause cancer, cause fertility problems, cause chronic diseases, for example, because of hormones that get into food, or because of packaging that infects food for too long. Of course it's too long when food comes from the other side of the world. I feel very tragic that the European Parliament is constantly negotiating these free trade agreements on one line and trying to reduce the damage and catastrophe that they cause on the other. The funds should be abolished.

name: Isabella ADINOLFI
text: in writing. \u2012 Nowadays there are many materials that come into contact with food: packaging, kitchen utensils, dishes and so on. These materials coming into contact with food can transfer their components to them. That is why it is clear that there is a need for greater harmonisation at EU level for non-harmonised materials. For example, specific measures based on scientific data could be implemented, giving priority to those materials that pose a particular risk to human health. That is why I voted in favour.

name: Tim AKER
text: in writing. – We in UKIP believe that the safety of food contact materials must be seriously evaluated as chemicals can easily migrate from the materials into food. However, Member States should be free to adopt specific measures at national level so that FCMs can comply with good manufacturing practices.

name: Marina ALBIOL GUZMÁN
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report as the Union should seek adequate regulation for all types of materials and objects intended to come into contact with food, including a ban on the use of endocrine disruptors and other substances of high concern. Current Union legislation on MCF allows chemicals that are prohibited under other Union laws. Not much of the substances present in materials and objects intended to come into contact with food are being evaluated. This is the case with so-called 'unintendedly added substances' ('NIAS') which are impurities of intentionally added substances or substances resulting from chemical reactions (such as decomposition products or by-products formed during the production process), which are present in the finished material. It should also be noted that, in its risk assessment procedure, the European Food Safety Agency (EFSA) does not take into account the so-called 'cocktail effect' and multiple exposures (resulting from chemicals - even at low doses - from different sources). All of this should be addressed by EFSA as soon as possible.

name: Martina ANDERSON
text: in writing. – I voted in favour of this report dealing with food contact materials, which mainly means food packaging (but can also refer to food utensils or factories where food is made), and EU regulation or lack thereof covering these products.  Currently only 4 out of 17 of the FCMs identified for measures are actually regulated, which means there are a lot of packaging substances, e.g. printing ink, paper, metal, adhesives and varnishes, which are not covered. There is increasing concern regarding the migration of chemicals from food contact materials into the food we eat. This can be exacerbated by various factors including the length of time packaging has contact with the food, the ratio of surface area of food to the material, whether the product is heated, and whether the foods are surrounded by liquids or high-fat substances. This report calls on the Commission to close the gaps and bring in measures to cover the 13 untouched FCMs and points out that the current system of authorisation does not take into account the effects of low-dose exposure to chemicals migrating from FCMs. This is particularly of concern for vulnerable groups such as babies or infants.

name: Eric ANDRIEU
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report on materials that come into contact with our food supply. In this report, we have won a battle: that of the total ban, following the example of France, of bisphenol A. This is a victory that we welcome, proof that Europe can protect Europeans, especially their health.  Europe in recent years has often struggled to cope with the challenges of the beginning of the 21st century. But on many issues it also allows for great progress, especially in the area of health protection. A concrete Europe, which meets the expectations of citizens, is what we would like to see more often!

name: Laima Liucija ANDRIKIENĖ
text: in writing. ‒ I have voted in favour of the Report on the implementation of the Food Contact Materials (FCM) Regulation. FCMs are largely used in everyday life as food packaging, kitchen utensils, tableware, etc. When put in contact with food, different materials may behave differently, transferring their constituents to the food. In such cases, chemicals emanating from FCMs may endanger human health. FCMs are subject to legally binding rules at EU level, which are currently laid down in Framework Regulation (EC) No 1935/2004. This sets out general safety requirements that are applicable to all possible food contact materials. It also foresees the possibility to adopt specific measures for the 17 materials listed in the regulation, but so far specific EU measures have only been adopted for four FCMs: plastic, ceramics, regenerated cellulose and active and intelligent materials. I welcome the recommendations of this report to adopt the specific EU measures for the remaining 13 materials, giving priority to those that constitute a particular risk to human health, and to urgently tackle shortcomings in the implementation and enforcement of the legislation in place. In this respect, the focus should be on four major areas: risk assessment, traceability, enforcement and controls of compliance.

name: Nikos ANDROULAKIS
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report on the implementation of the regulation on materials in contact with foodstuffs, because the existing legislation needs to be revised. It is imperative to pay more attention to issues relating to the protection of human health through risk assessment, traceability and enforcement.

name: Pascal ARIMONT
text: Writing. Every day, food comes into contact with other materials, such as packaging, kitchen appliances, cutlery, ... Depending on the ingredients, these contact materials can transmit harmful elements to the diet. These elements can be harmful not only to the individual ingredients (such as .B bisphenol), but also to their interaction with other substances. Currently, only four out of 17 substances are subject to common EU rules. As a result, the majority of food contact materials are regulated inconsistently, with some states being very strict and others not at all. This report is to be welcomed because it advocates a harmonised approach. In my view, only a uniform standard guarantees a high standard of human health. In addition, I fully supported the call for a complete EU-wide ban on bisphenol.

name: Marie-Christine ARNAUTU
text: In writing. We are opposed to further harmonisation at European level of legislation on materials and objects intended to come into contact with food. In addition to the principled position, it should be remembered that the opinions and recommendations of the European Food Safety Authority do not reach consensus in the scientific community or among consumer associations. This is evidenced by its erroneous recommendations for bisphenol A.  Thus, Member States should be encouraged to develop their own legislation, in accordance with the precautionary principle. I voted against this report.

name: Jonathan ARNOTT
text: in writing. ‒ I believe that Member States must be free to adopt specific measures at national level for all kinds of food contact materials.

name: Jean ARTHUIS
text: In writing. I have decided to vote in favour of this resolution because I believe that decisions are needed to remedy the lack of specific EU measures for certain materials to come into contact with food.  The current regulatory framework needs to be redesigned to better achieve consumer health protection objectives while ensuring the proper functioning of the internal market.

name: Nicolas BAY
text: In writing. "Food contact materials" (FCM) are materials that come into contact with food at all stages of the production and consumption chain: containers, packaging, tableware, etc. I am in favour of this report against EFSA and the Commission.  On the other hand, the recommendations for revision of regulation 1935/2004, and in particular the consideration of the cocktail effect, the protection of pregnant women and technical measures on bisphenol seem to me to make common sense.

name: Hugues BAYET
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report of initiative by the Danish socialist Christel Schaldemose on the implementation of the regulation on materials intended to come into contact with food (plastic packaging, regenerated cellulose, cardboard, printing inks, etc.), as it is obvious that an assessment of the dangerousness of these materials is essential for the health of citizens. Members of the Committee on the Environment, Public Health and Food Safety recognise that the framework regulation in question provides a solid legal basis, the objectives of which remain relevant. However, they believe that measures at EU level are needed to address the lack of specific EU measures and the shortcomings in risk assessment, traceability, compliance and control. More specifically, and in view of the predominance of the materials cited in the EU market and the risk they pose to human health, MEPs believe that the Commission should immediately give priority to the development of specific EU measures for paper and cardboard, varnishes and coatings, metals and alloys, printing inks and glues.

name: Beatriz BECERRA BASTERRECHEA
text: in writing. •u2012 Materials in contact with food may behave differently and transfer their components to food. In such cases, chemicals emanating from these materials may endanger human health or negatively modify the composition of foodstuffs. Action at Union level is therefore necessary to address the lack of Specific Union measures and the shortcomings of risk assessment, traceability, compliance and control. The rapporteur asks the Commission to review the current regulatory framework on the basis of political recommendations. That is why I voted in favour of this report.

name: Brando BENIFEI
text: in writing. \u2012 Annex I to the Framework Regulation on materials and articles intended to come into contact with foodstuffs lists 17 materials which could be subject to specific discipline. To date, only 4 of them are: plastics (including recycled ones), ceramics, regenerated cellulose and active and intelligent materials.  The resolution voted on today by Parliament calls on the Commission to develop the necessary measures with regard to the 13 materials not yet regulated at EU level, taking into account the assessment carried out by the European Parliament's Research Service and the existing and ongoing national measures being prepared. review existing legislation. There is broad agreement that the lack of uniform measures at Community level in this area could jeopardise public health, environmental protection and the proper functioning of the internal market.  The European Union therefore has the task of responding to this regulatory vacuum, which can pose a risk to its citizens.

name: Xabier BENITO ZILUAGA
text: in writing. U2012 I vote in favour of this report. I think it is important that the Union gradually creates legislation on this subject. This is a first step and although I believe that this is not enough, it proposes specific measures at European level on materials and objects intended to come into contact with foods such as plastic, ceramics, cellulose, etc. which I think are paramount. The report also mentions the importance of Member States taking specific measures in the event that European legislation does not mention certain materials that may be considered toxic.

name: Izaskun BILBAO BARANDICA
text: in writing. I would like to thank the rapporteur for her work in this report on the implementation of the Regulation on materials and objects intended to come into contact with food. In this case, I have also voted in favour of an amendment which states that EFSA's numerous re-evaluations over the past decade have not effectively addressed all health problems, and that EFSA will reassess the risks of BPA in 2017, following the publication of a report showing that existing tolerable daily intake does not protect fetuses or infants from the effects of BPA in the immune system and it is recommended that consumers be advised to reduce their exposure to BPA from food and other sources, as well as to urge BPA to be prohibited in all food contact materials.

name: Dominique BILDE
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this regulation, which calls for even more draconian new rules at European level to harmonize legislation on "materials and objects intended to come into contact with material foodstuffs", referred to by the acronym FCM for food contact material in English. These rules must be the responsibility of the Member States. Nevertheless, some recommendations for revisions are moving in the right direction, including consideration of the cocktail effect, protection of pregnant women and technical measures on bisphenol.

name: Mara BIZZOTTO
text: in writing. \u2012 The report on the implementation of the Regulation on materials intended to come into contact with foodstuffs is the final step in the attempt to make food legislation more harmonised at EU level. I believe that the protection of the health of our citizens is essential, and this text moves in exactly this direction, which is why I wanted to support it with my vote.

name: Vilija BLINKEVIČIŪTĖ
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report, which deals with the Regulation on materials and articles intended to come into contact with food. Food contact materials are often used in everyday life as packaging, kitchen utensils, edible utensils and others. When contacting food and depending on their composition and properties, different substances can react differently by separating their ingredients into food. In such cases, substances released by food contact materials may endanger human health or adversely affect the composition of foodstuffs. As food is considered to be one of the most important routes through which chemicals affect humans, food contact materials are subject to legally binding RULES at EU level, which are currently laid down in the Framework Regulation. The legislation aims to maintain a high level of consumer protection while ensuring the effective functioning of the internal market for food contact materials. This Regulation establishes common safety requirements for all possible food contact materials and articles. To date, specific measures at EU level have only been adopted for four food contact materials, i.e. plastics (including recycled plastics), ceramics, regenerated cellulose and active and intelligent materials. For other food contact materials, Member States may adopt specific measures at national level.

name: Franc BOGOVIČ
text: Writing. I also supported my colleague Schaldema's report on the implementation of the Regulation on food contact materials. This report is a response to a survey by the European Parliament's research department and a study by the European Food Safety Authority which found that many substances present in food contact materials are not evaluated. This applies in particular to so-called inadvertently added substances, such as impurities in intentionally added substances, or substances resulting from chemical reactions present in the final material. It is therefore of the utmost importance that the manufacturers of these materials provide complete information and that scientific institutions and laboratories cooperate well in all Member States. The report notes that traceability needs to be improved in legislation in this area, along the entire supply chain. In particular, it is important that the same traceability and compliance standards apply to food contact materials imported from third countries.

name: Biljana BORZAN
text: Written. —Food contact materials are an issue that concerns each of the half a billion EU citizens because they are in daily contact with them. Many citizens buy organic food to avoid pesticides, and the contamination potential of chemicals from food packaging can be a thousand times higher. The current directive is from 2004, and in the meantime science and toxicology have progressed. That is why I think it is necessary to revise existing rules and procedures to strengthen the common market and better protect public health.   It is necessary to seriously take into account the interaction of compounds and chemicals that can be harmless separately, but together can provoke a reaction of the human organism. Furthermore, regulations for paper, cardboard, coatings, inks, metals and adhesives should be harmonized. In conclusion, I would like to thank the Rapporteur for her efforts and call on the Commission to take the steps proposed in the report as soon as possible.

name: Mercedes BRESSO
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the resolution on the implementation of Food Contact Material Regulation because I believe it is a solid legal basis for preventing risks to human health. Moreover, this resolution strategically asks the Commission to prioritise the drawing-up of specific EU measures for paper and board, varnishes and coatings, metals and alloys, printing inks and adhesives, and calls for further scientific research into the integration between different chemicals.

name: Renata BRIANO
text: in writing. \u2012 Food contact materials (MCAs), depending on their composition and properties, behave differently when they come into contact with food, transferring their components to them. In these circumstances, the chemicals released can harm human health. The Regulation lays down the general safety requirements applicable to all possible materials and articles intended to come into contact with foodstuffs. At EU level, specific measures have been taken for four MCAs: plastic, ceramics, regenerated cellulose and active and intelligent materials. For other MCAs, Member States take specific measures at national level, but having to comply with different national standards is neither efficient nor effective. In addition, this creates problems for different national product safety standards. It is also necessary to improve and strengthen existing legislation and the monitoring of consumer health protection and enforcement.

name: Steeve BRIOIS
text: In writing. This report contains proposals for the regulation of materials and objects to come into contact with food at all stages of the production and/or consumption chain: containers, packaging, table covers. In particular, it aims to better harmonize national regulations (in accordance with French standards) and to broaden the scope of the Food Contact Material (FCM) to better protect pregnant women and better protect themselves from bisphenol. In this, it contains evidence against the European Commission and EFSA.  That is why I voted for this report.

name: Nicola CAPUTO
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour today on the report on food contact materials (MCAs), which are used daily to pack food, because we must prevent them from releasing chemicals into dangerous foods or altering the composition of food, seriously harming human health. Materials in contact with food are subject to legally binding European standards, as laid down in Framework Regulation (EC) No 1935/2004.  The Regulation defines the general safety requirements applicable to all possible materials and articles intended to come into contact with foodstuffs and also provides for the possibility of adopting specific measures for the materials listed in Annex I to the Framework Regulation.  To date, specific measures have been taken for only four MCAs: plastic, ceramics, regenerated cellulose and active and intelligent materials. The absence of specific measures within the EU for most food contact materials listed in Annex I to Regulation (EC) No 1935/2004 creates real barriers to the internal market. Greater harmonisation in this area, through the adoption of specific measures based on scientific data, could be a step in the right direction, an important step towards protecting the health of citizens.

name: Matt CARTHY
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report on the implementation of the Food Contact Materials Regulation. This report deals with food contact materials, which mainly means food packaging (but can also refer to food utensils or factories where food is made), and EU regulation or lack thereof covering these products. Currently only 4 out of 17 of the FCMs identified for measures are actually regulated, which means there is are a lot of packaging substances, e.g. printing ink, paper, metal, adhesives and varnishes, which are not covered. There is increasing concern regarding the migration of chemicals from food contact materials into the food we eat. This can be exacerbated by various factors, including the length of time packaging has contact with the food, the ratio of surface area of food to the material, whether the product is heated, and whether the foods are surrounded by liquids or high-fat substances. For these reasons I voted in favour.

name: David CASA
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report, which concerns food contact materials which are largely used in everyday life such as food packaging, kitchen utensils, tableware and so on. When in contact with food, these materials could transfer their constituents to the food and may endanger human health or adversely change the composition of the foodstuffs. I agree amongst others with the recommendation to adopt a specific EU measure for non-harmonised material, starting off with those materials that constitute a particular risk to human health and are in bigger demand in the EU, namely paper and board, including recycled paper and board, coatings, inks and adhesives.

name: Fabio Massimo CASTALDO
text: in writing. \u2012 Food contact materials (MCAs) are widely used in daily life in the form of food packaging, kitchen utensils, dishes, and so on. When they come into contact with food, and depending on their composition and properties, the various materials can behave differently, transferring their components to food at the risk of harming human health or altering the composition of food.  It is worth remembering that only some of these materials, such as plastics and ceramics, have been completely tested for safety and public health. Others such as paints, enamels, inks and adhesives are not covered by EU rules and have yet to be tested. I voted in favour of this resolution calling for stricter EU safety standards.

name: Nessa CHILDERS
text: in writing. ‒ The consumption of junk food might not be unsafe in the short term, but healthy food may also present long-term risks if carried in packaging which itself contains unsafe substances. There is a range of items that come into contact with the food we eat every day, in the form of wrapping, packages or utensils used to prepare and consume our meals.  Food is indeed one the most significant sources of human exposure to chemicals, and we estimate the number of substances coming into contact with it at around 15 000. So this was a timely assessment of the state of the applicable legislation. We need more EU-level measures to better protect all consumers in the European markets from risks posed by such substances. The impact of inks, glues and coatings, as well as substances present in recycled paper and cardboard, has been underestimated, and the combined effect of various substances present in the same item remains absent from the European Food Safety Authority’s risk assessments. The presence of endocrine disruptors in food contact materials is a particularly sensitive issue, given the serious risk to human health that chemicals such as Bisphenol A can pose. A full ban is in order.

name: Caterina CHINNICI
text: in writing. \u2012 Although Regulation (EC) No 1935/2004 establishing general safety requirements applicable to all possible materials and articles intended to come into contact with foodstuffs has been in force for more than ten years, Major shortcomings still persist in the implementation and application of existing legislation, particularly with regard to specific measures, some of which have been defined at European level, which have so far only covered certain materials listed in Annex I to the Regulation such as: plastic (including recycled plastic), ceramics, regenerated cellulose and active and intelligent materials.  There are still other materials, such as wood or printing inks, for which the Member States, in the absence of specific European measures, have regulated on their own. We are faced with a clear disparity in safety standards which can only be bridged by action taken at EU level, both to improve the implementation of legislation and to avoid barriers to the internal market and, above all, to protect the health of consumers. For these reasons, I voted in favour.

name: Lefteris CHRISTOFOROU
text: Writing. \u2012 We are in favour of the report because the legislation seeks to ensure a high level of consumer protection and at the same time ensures the effective functioning of the internal market for all materials in contact with foodstuffs.

name: Kostas CHRYSOGONOS
text: Writing. \u2012 We voted on the report on the implementation of the Regulation on materials in contact with foodstuffs. This is a technical issue with particular implications for the everyday life of citizens. We are called upon to improve the rules regulating the food production process. I believe that the report contains positive elements and I have therefore decided to vote in favour.

name: Alberto CIRIO
text: in writing. \u2012 In view of the need for gaps in Regulation (EC) No 1935/2004 on materials and articles intended to come into contact with foodstuffs, I welcome the report. Indeed, it should be pointed out that of the 17 materials covered by the 2004 regulation, there are only four harmonised at European level, while national legislation dominates the rest and creates problems. These difficulties give cause a great inconsistency in the application of laws and sanctions: just think of the presence of states that do not even force companies producing these materials to register their activities. Unfortunately, these behaviours not only create competitive disadvantages, but also health risks.  In view of the above, it is essential to define specific measures to be taken where they are lacking and, at the same time, to ensure the full implementation of what is already in force. It is therefore necessary to implement the funds available to the European Food Safety Authority in order to deepen and update the information on the materials to be regulated, as well as to study the substances used in the production of the same and those added unintentionally (NIAS). It is also necessary to clarify and assess the risk posed by the so-called cocktail effect and multiple exposures.

name: Deirdre CLUNE
text: in writing. ‒ I supported the report on the implementation of the Food Contact Materials Regulation and noted no objections.

name: Carlos COELHO
text: in writing. \u2012 The regulation of materials intended to come into contact with food contributes to the protection of public health and consumer protection. The adoption of legally binding standards for four of the seventeen materials referred to in Annex I to Regulation (EC) No 1935/2004 (plastics, ceramics, regenerated cellulose and active and intelligent materials), a framework regulation of this matter, has resulted in legislative harmonisation defending competitiveness and innovation in the internal market, because it subjects all operators to equal rules. I therefore call for a harmonisation of the regulation of the other thirteen materials intended to come into contact with food, especially those that pose the greatest risk to the health of consumers and which have greater demand on the market, namely paper and cardboard, metals and alloys, glass, silicones and rubbers. The absence of common rules undermines the internal market and often transfers compliance costs to consumers. I share the concern with the implementation and implementation of current legislation, in particular in the areas of risk assessment, traceability, enforcement and compliance control. To this end, I believe that support (including financial) for the European Food Safety Authority (EFSA) should be increased. I support this report.

name: Jane COLLINS
text: in writing. – We in UKIP believe that the safety of food contact materials must be seriously evaluated as chemicals can easily migrate from the materials into food. However, Member States should be free to adopt specific measures at national level so that FCMs can comply with good manufacturing practices.

name: Lara COMI
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour because the regulation defines the general safety requirements applicable to all possible materials and articles intended to come into contact with foodstuffs and also provides for the possibility of adopting specific measures for additional materials in addition to those already standardled at European level. I believe that action at EU level is important to fill the gaps in risk assessment, traceability, compliance and controls so that the health of European consumers is increasingly guaranteed in a functional and effective internal market.

name: Anna Maria CORAZZA BILDT
text: Written. 'Harmonising legislation on food contact materials is of great importance for the internal market and for european consumers to feel safe in the safety of the food they eat; That is why we voted in favour of the report. However, we do not share the unfounded criticism of the European Food Safety Authority (EFSA) contained in the text. Nor can we support the calls to ban or phase out substances without scientific support.

name: Javier COUSO PERMUY
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report as the Union should seek adequate regulation for all types of materials and objects intended to come into contact with food, including a ban on the use of endocrine disruptors and other substances of high concern. Current Union legislation on MCF allows chemicals that are prohibited under other Union laws. Not much of the substances present in materials and objects intended to come into contact with food are being evaluated. This is the case with so-called 'unintendedly added substances' ('NIAS') which are impurities of intentionally added substances or substances resulting from chemical reactions (such as decomposition products or by-products formed during the production process), which are present in the finished material. It should also be noted that, in its risk assessment procedure, the European Food Safety Agency (EFSA) does not take into account the so-called 'cocktail effect' and multiple exposures (resulting from chemicals - even at low doses - from different sources). All of this should be addressed by EFSA as soon as possible.

name: Andrea COZZOLINO
text: in writing. \u2012 The current food contact materials regulation provides for the adoption of specific measures on 17 substances. To date, only 4 are harmonised at EU level, while, for all others, Member States retain the possibility of adopting national provisions. This lack of harmonised measures at EU level creates different safety standards and a consequential loss of competitiveness and innovation in the internal market.  On the other hand, materials not covered by specific EU measures can pose a risk to public health and lead to a loss of consumer confidence, legal uncertainty and higher compliance costs for operators. For these reasons, I consider it a priority to draw up specific Community measures, which can strengthen and harmonise the regulatory framework, ensuring the creation of a level playing field and better controls in the Member States, so that materials in direct contact with our food are safe.

name: Pál CSÁKY
text: Writing. \u2012 Regulation (EC) No 1935/2004 is for substances which come into contact with food during everyday use. It is essential that these substances are not harmful to health on their own and that they do not come into contact with foodstuffs in reactions which may be dangerous to health or have a negative impact on the composition of foodstuffs. There is no generally accepted regulation at EU level for most food contact materials. Materials must meet certain criteria, there are currently four that are subject to EU standards: ceramics, plastics, regenerated pulp and active and intelligent materials. The other substances are subject to different specifications from one Member State to another. A study on the subject was carried out courtesy of the European Parliament's Research Service. In the light of the data, preparations for the Regulation have been started, identifying four main areas: risk assessment, traceability and compliance enforcement and monitoring. Risk assessment of harmonised substances is a matter for the European Food Safety Authority (EFSA), but there are no adequate financial resources to do so. It is therefore proposed to finance these EFSA activities. However, for non-harmonised substances, EFSA is not competent. This is why a single set of rules is needed, to which those involved in the field can ass themselves. I supported the report.

name: Edward CZESAK
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 I supported the report on the implementation of the Regulation on food contact materials. My decision is motivated by the fact that I see giving Parliament a greater role in resolving the discrepancies between the different chemicals regulations as a good move. I support the general tone of the report on endocrine disruptors and bisphenol. For these reasons, I voted in favour.

name: Miriam DALLI
text: in writing. ‒ The current legislation on FCMs needs to be urgently revised in order to provide a better level of health protection. To ensure that substances coming into contact with foodstuffs do not present health risks, specific EU measures for non-harmonised materials should also be adopted to have better control standards across Member States. These materials are widely used in everyday life including in food packaging and tableware, and when put in contact with food, and depending on their composition and properties, the materials may behave differently, transferring constituents to food. I am in favour of this report as I believe that the main focus should be our citizens’ health and this is why I believe that we need to adopt specific EU measures to identify and prevent the use of substances which are endocrine disrupters. This would also enhance reuse and recycling properties in such materials to improve uptake in the circular economy.

name: Viorica DĂNCILĂ
text: in writing. \u2012 I believe that there needs to be more effective cooperation and coordination between the Member States and the Commission on the early warning system for food and feed in order to be able to quickly and effectively address risks to public health.

name: Michel DANTIN
text: In writing. This initiative report focuses on everyday materials in contact with foodstuffs, such as packaging, kitchen utensils and dishes. The European Commission has identified 17 groups of products that may be in contact with food, but it finds that only 4 groups are subject to harmonised measures at European level. At the same time, there are discrepancies between national rules that hinder food security and the protection of citizens in the Union. This report therefore proposes a harmonisation of national legislation for all the product groups concerned. Considering that this report aims to strengthen food security in the internal market, I supported this report.

name: Rachida DATI
text: In writing. Sharing the concerns of European citizens about the safety of food products, I voted in favour of the report on the implementation of the regulation on materials intended to come into contact with food. The absence of specific European measures establishes different levels of security within the Union, which is contrary to European values and the principles of the internal market.  It is also in the interest of consumer protection that I have spoken in favour of banning bisphenol A in all materials intended to come into contact with food, given doubts about the potential dangers of this product, particularly for fetuses and young children.

name: Angélique DELAHAYE
text: In writing. This report is a clear signal sent to the European Commission but also to consumers! Chemicals in materials intended to come into contact with foodstuffs, including packaging, kitchen utensils, dishes, etc., can endanger human health or significantly alter the composition of the products consumed, and it is essential that the European Commission address this issue.  I voted for this report because it is important to harmonise at European level the various measures taken by the Member States, but also to reflect on the gaps in the current legislation. We need to work on better legislation in this area, legislation that will aim to properly inform and protect the citizen.  Finally, I am particularly pleased with the adoption of the amendment on the ban on bisphenol A (BPA) in all materials intended to come into contact with food. It is a chemical considered an endocrine disruptor, toxic to reproductive organs, found in many consumer products.

name: Mark DEMESMAEKER
text: Written. The N-VA has strongly supported the resolution on the implementation of the legislation on materials that come into contact with food.  Food very often comes into contact with certain materials such as cutlery, crockery, utensils and packaging. These materials are carefully examined is essential to prevent contamination of food and to protect public health. The implementation of existing European legislation from 2004 can and must be improved. All the opportunities provided for in the legislation must be taken advantage of: there is a strong support for further harmonisation of the rules in question. The legislation provides for the possibility of establishing European rules for 17 materials. For the time being, this was only done for 4 materials. Member States also have the option of setting their own rules in the absence of European measures, but this threatens to fragment the internal market. There is a need for a level playing field. This is a win-win for producers and consumers as well: companies producing FCMs can compete fairly and consumers are protected equally across the EU.  The federal government in Belgium is pulling the rug for this and recently sent a letter to the Commission, together with some like-minded Member States, calling for further harmonisation.

name: Isabella DE MONTE
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report because I believe that food safety is an area of absolute importance for the health of citizens. The need to ensure the control and traceability of packaging, kitchen utensils and tableware, with appropriate 'declarations of conformity' certifying the satisfaction of the required standards, requires a joint effort by all EU Member States to fill gaps in the safety and public health testing of materials such as paints, enamels and inks. For these reasons, I voted in favour of the report.

name: Jean-Paul DENANOT
text: In writing. We have adopted this report on materials that come into contact with our food (packaging, kitchen utensils, crockery). It includes a key step forward in the fight against endocrine disruptors.  These, present in our daily lives, have a negative impact on human health. In this case, the total ban, as in France, of bisphenol A is a real victory.

name: Gérard DEPREZ
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this resolution because it is clear that the EU should further harmonize safety requirements for materials that are widely used in everyday life in the form of food packaging, kitchen utensils and crockery.  Current legislation provides for 17 substances to be regulated, but only four of them are currently being harmonized at European level and are therefore sufficiently controlled as to their impact on human health. The rest are left to the discretion of the Member States.  The lack of harmonized criteria therefore poses a number of problems. Some countries have high levels of protection, others do not. However, we now know, thanks to various studies, that depending on their composition and properties, certain substances in the packaging can transfer their components once put in contact with food. These substances are therefore potentially dangerous to health. That is why the EU should review the current legislation, so that food security means the same thing across Europe.

name: Marielle DE SARNEZ
text: In writing. Materials in contact with food are found in the everyday life of Europeans, whether in the form of food packaging, kitchen utensils or crockery. However, these materials have chemical properties that, if not controlled, can sometimes be dangerous to health. Only four of these products (including plastics and ceramics) are currently subject to specific safety measures at European level, with the control of the other 13 materials listed leaving it to the discretion of the Member States.  In view of the risks to public health and the environment, the Union needs to further harmonise its controls. In addition, the total ban on bisphenol A, limited to a few Member States such as France or Sweden, should be extended to the whole of the Union.

name: Georgios EPITIDEIOS
text: Writing. \u2012 I am voting in favour because I believe that no one can undermine public health at all. Furthermore, I believe that the solution to such problems is to return, as far as possible, to the use of traditional ways of packaging and processing food and not to develop new and unknown substances as to their end result.

name: Fredrick FEDERLEY
text: Written. \u2012 I have previously voted according to EFSA's recommendations regarding FCM and BPA; this time I chose to take into account the very clear line that the Center Party has taken on the issue – and wish to pursue at European level as well – namely a total ban on BPA in materials intended to come into contact with food. Otherwise, a very good text that highlights the need for increased research on synergies and unknown substances, among other things, and which interms sharper requirements around FCM in general.

name: José Manuel FERNANDES
text: in writing. \u2012 Materials intended to come into contact with food are widely used in everyday life in the form of food packaging, kitchenware, crockery, etc. When put in contact with food, depending on their composition and properties, the different materials may exhibit different behaviors, transferring their constituents to food. Further harmonisation in the field of food-related materials (in particular non-harmonised ones) is one of the paths to be followed because it would be a step forward in the right direction, giving priority to materials that pose a specific risk to human health and which have increased demand on the EU market. Action is needed at EU level to address the lack of specific measures and gaps in risk assessment, traceability, compliance and control.

name: Edouard FERRAND
text: In writing. Vote for: the report contains the following main proposals: coverage of 13 materials not covered by current legislation by European measures; consideration by legislation of the "cocktail" effect of materials intended to come into contact with foodstuffs (i.e. the result of their interactions) as well as substances resulting from chemical reactions of materials intended to come into contact with foodstuffs ("non intentionally added substances"); harmonized guidelines on testing and control procedures.

name: Laura FERRARA
text: in writing. \u2012 Materials in contact with food are widely used in daily life, and can sometimes be harmful or otherwise dangerous to human health. From this point of view, we are in favour of greater harmonisation at EU level through specific measures concerning the most commonly used materials based on demonstrable scientific data. This report examines the various issues posed by this type of material and is a welcome political initiative of the European Parliament.

name: João FERREIRA
text: in writing. This report addresses the need to revise the Regulation on food contact materials (MFTs), widely used in everyday life in the form of food packaging, kitchenware, cutlery, etc. When put in contact with food these different materials may behave differently by transferring some of their constituents to food – a phenomenon called migration – and some may endanger human health by infecting or adversely altering the composition of foodstuffs. So far, specific measures have been adopted at EU level for only four FCMs: plastic (including recycled plastic), ceramics, regenerated cellulose and active and intelligent materials. For other MFSs, Member States may adopt specific measures at national level. These measures may differ from Member State to Member State, with different product safety standards depending on where it is used and marketed. Current EU legislation on FCMs allows the use of chemicals that are prohibited for other purposes. On the other hand, it ignores the effect of endocrine disrupting, carcinogenic, mutagenic or toxic effects on reproduction, bioaccumulation effects or other harmful properties. It is therefore important to deal with the lack of specific measures and gaps in risk assessment, application, traceability, compliance and control of FCMs.

name: Christofer FJELLNER
text: Written. 'Harmonising legislation on food contact materials is of great importance for the internal market and for european consumers to feel safe in the safety of the food they eat; That is why we voted in favour of the report. However, we do not share the unfounded criticism of the European Food Safety Authority (EFSA) contained in the text. Nor can we support the calls to ban or phase out substances without scientific support.

name: Luke Ming FLANAGAN
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of amendment no 1 after recital F as it makes sense that the opinions of national governments should take precedence.

name: Monika BEŇOVÁ
text: Writing. \u2012 Furthermore, evidence gathered in recent months shows that there is an urgent need to address the current shortcomings in the implementation and enforcement of existing legislation. That Regulation lays down general safety requirements applicable to all possible materials and articles in contact with food. Until now, specific measures at EU level have only been taken for four food contact materials. In particular, plastic including recycled plastic, ceramics, regenerated cellulose and active and intelligent materials. That Regulation should extend this number to up to 17 materials. Action needs to be taken at European Union level to address the absence of specific European Union measures and deficiencies in risk assessment, traceability, compliance and control.

name: Lorenzo FONTANA
text: in writing. \u2012 I am voting in favour of the report in order to achieve greater harmonisation within the MCAs by the majority of stakeholders.

name: Lampros FOUNTOULIS
text: Writing. \u2012 I am voting in favour of the report on the implementation of the Regulation on materials in contact with foodstuffs (EC) No 1935/2004) because no one can undermine public health at all. Furthermore, I believe that the solution to such problems is to return, as far as possible, to the use of traditional ways of packaging and processing food and not to the development of new substances, unknown as to their ultimate consequences.

name: Francisco de Paula GAMBUS MILLET
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the report. Materials in contact with food are continuously used in daily life in the form of packaging, cooking utensils, crockery, etc. When they come into contact with food, and depending on its composition and properties, different materials can behave differently and transfer their components to food. In such cases, they may endanger human health or negatively modify the composition of foodstuffs. The legislation aims to maintain a high level of consumer protection while ensuring the effective functioning of the internal market of products including materials intended to come into contact with food. One of the main challenges we must face is the need for greater harmonization in the field of food contact materials (especially non-harmonised ones) by most stakeholders in all sectors. It is also necessary to strengthen and improve current traceability legislation to ensure traceability of all materials in contact with food.

name: Elena GENTILE
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the European Parliament resolution on the implementation of the regulation on materials and articles intended to come into contact with foodstuffs Regulation (EC) No 1935/2004, as I believe that although the framework regulation also constitutes a solid legal basis, the objectives of which continue to be relevant; however, the adoption of new specific measures at EU level would encourage operators in the sector to develop safe, reusable and recycled MCAs, thereby contributing to the Union's efforts towards the objective of a better circular economy; stresses that this would require better traceability and phasing out of substances in MCAs that could pose a danger to human health. I believe that EFSA carries out a risk assessment of the substances to be used in MCAs governed by specific measures; is aware of the costs of assessing the risk of a specific substance and EFSA's limited resources; I therefore hope that the Commission will increase the amount of funding provided to EFSA, given the additional work resulting from the increased need for risk assessments on new contaminants.

name: Jens GIESEKE
text: Writing. We are living longer and longer. The average life expectancy in Germany at birth is over 81 years. In 1990, it was 75. We owe this development to the advances of science and medicine.  We also want to further develop health protection for items and materials that come into contact with food. Here we must ensure uniform safety standards in Europe. In this way, innovations from one Member State can easily be transferred to other Member States, on the principle that the wheel is not always reinventable.  Of course, these substances must be safe. However, this is not possible by listing again and again the potential dangers of some substances in this own-initiative report. Instead, we should rely on the findings and risk analyses of scientists.  This principle has proved its worth in the past in increasing our life expectancy, and we should stick to it.

name: Nathan GILL
text: in writing. ‒ I believe that the safety of food contact materials must be seriously evaluated as chemicals can easily migrate from the materials into food. However, Member States should be free to adopt specific measures at national level so that FCMs can comply with good manufacturing practices.

name: Tania GONZÁLEZ PEÑAS
text: in writing. U2012 I vote in favour of this report. I think it is important that the Union gradually creates legislation on this subject. This is a first step and although I believe that this is not enough, it proposes specific measures at European level on materials and objects intended to come into contact with foods such as plastic, ceramics, cellulose, etc. which I think are paramount. The report also mentions the importance of Member States taking specific measures in the event that European legislation does not mention certain materials that may be considered toxic.

name: Maria GRAPINI
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted for this report because I believe that it is important for consumers to be protected by admitting only products that do not affect their health on the domestic market. Food is one of the main ways of human exposure to chemicals through the materials with which they come into contact. In the current context, it is important to guarantee a high level of consumer protection in order to ensure the effective functioning of the internal market for THE goods of the MCA. There is a need for better harmonisation at EU level, the development of uniform safety standards and better coordination in terms of risk assessment, traceability, implementation and compliance controls on compliance with existing legislation. With regard to the marketing of MCA materials in the EU, it is necessary to facilitate the criteria for documentation and official registration of business activity in order to avoid gaps in risk assessment. I believe that this report is an important step towards achieving extremely important objectives such as guaranteeing and protecting human health in the EU, ensuring the effective functioning of the internal market and facilitating the implementation of legislation.

name: Theresa GRIFFIN
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report as it calls for stronger rules to protect consumers from harmful substances in food packaging.

name: Françoise GROSSETÊTE
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report, because it aims to better regulate the composition of materials that come into contact with food (various packaging, cans, plastic bottles, etc.), in order to prevent any health risks to consumers. This report focuses in particular on the application and implementation of the current legislation that governs these materials, and highlights serious shortcomings in some Member States with regard to control and traceability.  I also supported an amendment calling for a total ban in Europe on bisphenol A, which is already banned in France. This chemical, widely used in the industrial manufacture of plastics or varnish, is a proven endocrine disruptor, toxic to reproductive organs.

name: Sylvie GUILLAUME
text: In writing. There is no shortage of cases of food contamination by chemicals that can endanger human health. Food packaging, kitchen utensils, crockery, all materials widely used in everyday life and whose composition deserves to be scrutinized. It is in this context that I voted in favour of the report by my Danish colleague SCHALDEMOSE calling for a revision of the European legislative framework, which has so far proved ineffective.  Several gaps are identified in EFSA's risk assessment, with regard to the traceability and control of these materials. We stress the risks of endocrine disruptors and bisphenol A, support the ban on the latter in particular, and call on the European Commission to propose alternatives to this extremely worrying substance.

name: Marian HARKIN
text: in writing. ‒ I supported this report and I am happy that it got the support of the Parliament. Food contact materials (FCMs) are largely used in everyday life in the form of food packaging, kitchen utensils, tableware, etc. However, when in contact with food, and depending on their composition and properties, the different materials may behave differently, transferring their constituents to the food. In such cases, chemicals emanating from FCMs may endanger human health or adversely change the composition of the foodstuffs. The report points to the fact that the level of enforcement of the legislation on FCMs differs widely throughout the EU and highlights the importance of developing EU guidelines for FCMs which would facilitate a more uniform implementation and better enforcement in the Member States. Thankfully, the report also calls on the Commission to ensure better coordination between REACH and FCM legislation, especially as regards substances classified as Substances of Very High Concern (SVHCs) under REACH, and to ensure that harmful substances already phased out under REACH are also phased out in FCMs.

name: Brian HAYES
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour since I have no objections

name: Hans-Olaf HENKEL
text: Writing. The report aims to create individual measures at EU level for all food contact materials, which I believe is useful and has positive effects for all stakeholders. Unfortunately, the report also provides for massive regulation of bisphenol A (BPA) contained in some food contact materials. BPA is used for the production of many plastics and therefore has an enormous technical and economic significance. The plastics themselves are generally completely harmless biologically, but can release the BPA they contain to food. BPA is known to have a negative effect similar to the female sex hormone estrogen. However, what the rapporteur has concealed in his very detailed report is the reassessment carried out by the European Food Safety Authority (EFSA) in January 2015. EFSA's findings show that the amount of BPA that the consumer is exposed to is well below the safe limit, even with combined contact with both food and cosmetics. According to EFSA 2015, BPA does not pose a health risk to any age group. The strong regulation of the economically relevant BPA cannot therefore be proven from a scientific perspective. Consequently, I rejected the report. Incidentally, I believe that the single euro must be abolished, because it leads to strife and discord.

name: György HÖLVÉNYI
text: Writing. \u2012 Wrapping paper, kitchenware and cutlery used in everyday life are regularly in contact with food. During contact, their ingredients are transmitted to food. These chemicals can harm human health and alter the composition of food. The European Union has established general safety regulations and has introduced specific safety rules in four areas: plastics, ceramics, regenerated pulp and active and intelligent materials. Member States have the possibility to introduce similar specific legislation in several areas. However, this leads to different product safety regulations, which may create internal market barriers. The European Union aims to harmonise regulations and develop additional specific EU regulations. It is also important to overcome the shortcomings in the implementation of existing legislation. The European Union aims to preserve and protect the health of consumers and to ensure the effective functioning of the internal market. To this end, the European Parliament calls for a review of the existing framework regulation. Against this view, I voted in favour of this report.

name: Cătălin Sorin IVAN
text: in writing. ‒ It is of great importance for the current EU legislation regarding food contact materials to be revised and updated in order to provide for a paramount need of EU citizens, health protection.

name: Ivan JAKOVČIĆ
text: Written. ‒ I voted for the Report on the Implementation of the Regulation on Materials and Objects That Come into Contact with Food, as I consider food-related caution to be a very relevant topic. Food contact materials (FCMs) are widely used daily, and when brought into contact with food, depending on their composition and properties, some materials transfer their component parts to food. In these cases, chemicals released by such materials may endanger human health or have a detrimental impact on food composition. These materials are subject to legally binding rules at EU level, which are currently laid down in Framework Regulation (EC) No 1000/2013. 1935/2004 But there is certainly room for progress and further harmonisation, given that Member States may adopt specific measures at national level for these materials, and these measures vary from Member To Member State. Also, there remain many materials that are not regulated, and pose a risk to human health.  I support this Report, but I am aware that action is needed at EU level to deliver an even better and more strict solution.

name: Jean-François JALKH
text: In writing. We support this report, in passing the Commission and the European Food Safety Authority, which we believe is moving in the right direction, in that it claims to be better protection for pregnant women, better consideration of the cocktail effect of FCM and technical measures on bisphenol.   I therefore voted in favour of this text.

name: Diane JAMES
text: in writing. – We in UKIP believe that the safety of food contact materials must be seriously evaluated as chemicals can easily migrate from the materials into food. However, Member States should be free to adopt specific measures at national level so that FCMs can comply with good manufacturing practices.

name: Petr JEŽEK
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported the motion for a resolution on a regulation on the use of food contact materials due to the lack of concrete EU action in this area. The European Union dominates the global rankings with its high demands on food quality and consumer protection. The emphasis on compliance with eu citizens' health standards is one of its priorities and the proposal for this regulation will contribute to ensuring increased food safety. With a view to protecting consumer health, the regulatory framework needs to be reconsidered in order to facilitate the implementation of legislation.

name: Marc JOULAUD
text: In writing. I voted in favour of my colleague Christel Schaldemose's report on the application of legislation on materials to come into contact with food.  It was important for me to support this regulation to protect public health and the interests of consumers. This report is therefore an opportunity to call on the Commission to review the current framework to facilitate risk assessment, traceability, compliance and control of its materials.  I supported the European ban on bisphenol A in materials in contact with food, a provision already in force in France since January 2015. I welcome the adoption of this report, which helps to strengthen European public health policies.

name: Eva KAILI
text: Writing. \u2012 Food contact materials (FCM) are widely used in everyday life taking the form of food packaging, cooking utensils, tableware, etc. The Regulation lays down the general safety requirements applicable to all possible materials and articles in contact with foodstuffs; it also provides for the possibility of adopting specific measures for the seventeen materials listed in Annex 1 to the Framework Regulation. So far, specific measures have been taken adopted at EU level for only four FCM: plastic (including recycled plastic), ceramics, regenerated cellulose and active and intelligent materials. Action at EU level is necessary to address the problems posed by both the absence of concrete EU measures and gaps in risk assessment, traceability, compliance and control. I therefore voted in favour of the report.

name: Jarosław KALINOWSKI
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 Each of us has to deal with materials that come into direct contact with food: the dishes in which we eat meals, the accessories we use to transport them, or the packaging in which finished products are sold. We also often think about their composition and properties, choosing such articles, which we believe are safe for the food we eat and thus do not have a harmful effect on our health. As food safety is a priority issue of EU policy, food contact materials are subject to strict EU rules currently contained in Regulation (EC) No 1935/2004. The safety requirements set out there in it concern seventeen different materials for which specific measures may be adopted. However, at EU level, exceptional measures have only been adopted for four types: ceramics, cellulose, plastics and so-called smart materials. For other materials, Member States may adopt special provisions at their discretion.  Unfortunately, this situation leads to different product safety standards, disturbances in the internal market, loss of competitiveness and increased food prices. It is therefore necessary to harmonise the rules, both as regards production standards and regular food controls (including feed, which seems particularly important in the era of the ASF epidemic). In this way, we will protect the health of consumers and improve the functioning of our market.

name: Barbara KAPPEL
text: Writing. I am voting in favour of this own-initiative report. Consumers today are exposed to many of the chemicals of concern, including perfluorinated compounds and endocrine disruptors that can cause chronic diseases. Consumer protection is an important concern for me, which is why I support the demands that have been made here.

name: Afzal KHAN
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report as it calls for stronger rules to protect consumers from harmful substances in food packaging.

name: Bernd KÖLMEL
text: Writing. The report aims to create individual measures at EU level for all food contact materials, which I believe is appropriate and has positive effects for all stakeholders. Unfortunately, the report also provides for massive regulation of bisphenol A (BPA) contained in some food contact materials.  BPA is used for the production of many plastics and therefore has an enormous technical and economic significance. The plastics themselves are generally completely harmless biologically, but can release the BPA they contain to food. BPA is known to have a negative effect similar to the female sex hormone estrogen.  However, what the rapporteur has concealed in his very detailed report is the reassessment carried out by the European Food Safety Authority (EFSA) in January 2015. EFSA's findings show that the amount of BPA that the consumer is exposed to is well below the safe limit, even with combined contact with both food and cosmetics. According to EFSA 2015, BPA does not pose a health risk to any age group.  The strong regulation of the economically relevant BPA cannot therefore be proven from a scientific perspective. Consequently, I rejected the report.

name: Kateřina KONEČNÁ
text: Writing. \u2012 On 6 December 2016, in plenary of the European Parliament in Strasbourg, we voted on a resolution on the application of the Regulation on food contact materials. Materials intended for contact with food are widely used in our daily lives, most often in the form of food packaging, kitchen utensils, dishes, etc. Different materials, when in contact with food, can behave very differently, often transmiting their ingredients directly to the food. In such cases, these chemicals may endanger human health by adversely altering the composition of the food. As I have been working for a long time on the issue of endocrine disruptors, with which packaging materials are also closely related, it is necessary to monitor very carefully which chemicals are being planted by manufacturers in our food and the environment. The current situation is that European legislation regulates only certain selected materials and the source regulation is already quite obsolete. For example, it does not at all reflect fundamental scientific findings regarding the harmfulness of the already mentioned endocrine disruptors. That is why the rapporteur is right to call on the European Commission to revise it. I tabled an amendment with my colleagues on the prohibition of bisphenol A (BPA). I was happy to support the document because, in my opinion, it is going in the right direction.

name: Stelios KOULOGLOU
text: in writing. ‒ Food contact materials are used in everyday life in food packaging, kitchen utensils, tableware, etc. In some case, chemicals can emanate from these materials and endanger human health. It is essential to provide at EU level specific measures to address the gap in assessment, enforcement, traceability and control of food contact materials.
