For GUE/NGL, the EU should seek to achieve proper regulation for all types of food contact materials. I voted in favour of this report since it can address the main gap and implement proper EU regulation.

name: Giovanni LA VIA
text: in writing. I am voting in favour of the implementation of the regulation on materials and articles intended to come into contact with foodstuffs. Food contact materials (MCAs) are utensils, dishes and food packaging, and other tools that are used daily. These, each depending on their training, when in contact with food, could transfer chemicals that could have effects on human health.  There is a European standard governing the composition and use of MCAs for consumer protection. This regulation, which is now in place, has been adopted for plastics, ceramics, regenerated cellulose and active and intelligent materials. It is necessary to initiate greater harmonisation at European level, and to review the regulatory framework by implementing the recommendations presented in this report, supporting its implementation towards achieving the objectives and towards protecting the health of citizens.

name: Gilles LEBRETON
text: In writing. I voted for this report because it seeks to protect public health from hazardous substances in contact with food, including bisphenol A. It also has the merit of denouncing the missteps of the Brussels Commission and the European Food Safety Authority (EFSA).

name: Philippe LOISEAU
text: In writing. "Food Contact Materials" (FCM) consist of materials that come into contact with food at all stages of the production and consumption chain: containers, packaging, tableware, etc.  We are in favour of this report against the Commission and EFSA. The report and recommendations for revision of Regulation 1935/2004 go in the right direction: the coverage of 13 materials not affected by current legislation by European measures, the consideration of the cocktail effect, the protection of pregnant women and technical measures on bisphenol. In addition, the text calls for harmonization of the "REACH" regulation (1907/2006) in that it contains provisions that conflict with the FCM directives. I therefore voted in favour of this report.

name: Javi LÓPEZ
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report because the Regulation lays down general safety requirements which apply to all possible materials and objects in contact with food. Member States may take specific measures at national level, and some have already done so in relation to commonly used materials such as paper and cardboard, metals and alloys, glass, coatings, silicones, rubbers, and printing inks. Howwise, in the case of some specific materials, the specific measures taken by one Member State may be different from those of another Member State, i.e. different rules have been created for product safety. However, the report stresses that it is essential to take Union-specific measures for the remaining non-harmonised materials, and to improve the reuse and recycling properties of these materials in order to improve their absorption into the circular economy.  As regards testing, they should be based on uniform standards and the overall "cocktail effect" of the materials should be examined, which would help identify and prevent the use of substances that are endocrine disruptors. In general, there is an emphasis on the need to greatly improve traceability measures as well as the implementation and strengthening of controls.

name: Paloma LÓPEZ BERMEJO
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report as the Union should seek adequate regulation for all types of materials and objects intended to come into contact with food, including a ban on the use of endocrine disruptors and other substances of high concern. Current Union legislation on MCF allows chemicals that are prohibited under other Union laws. Not much of the substances present in materials and objects intended to come into contact with food are being evaluated. This is the case with so-called 'unintendedly added substances' ('NIAS') which are impurities of intentionally added substances or substances resulting from chemical reactions (such as decomposition products or by-products formed during the production process), which are present in the finished material. It should also be noted that, in its risk assessment procedure, the European Food Safety Agency (EFSA) does not take into account the so-called 'cocktail effect' and multiple exposures (resulting from chemicals - even at low doses - from different sources). All of this should be addressed by EFSA as soon as possible.

name: Antonio LÓPEZ-ISTÚRIZ WHITE
text: in writing. This report recalls that Regulation No 1935/2004 lays down general requirements to prevent certain materials, when coming into contact with food, from transferring substances in quantities such as to cause problems in human health or cause a change in the composition of food or a deterioration in the organoleptic characteristics of foodstos. For this purpose, it establishes a list of seventeen materials and objects in contact with food that may be subject to specific measures. The problem identified in the report is that, from that list, only four materials or objects are subject to specific european Union measures, while the rest are subject to the possibility for Member States to adopt national provisions. Thus, the legislation on these national measures is disparate and the principle of mutual recognition does not work, so neither the effective functioning of the internal market nor a significant level of consumer protection can be guaranteed. I am voting in favour of the report, because greater harmonisation in the European Union, as stated in the European Union, is necessary to address the shortcomings in the implementation of Regulation No 1935/2004.

name: Elżbieta Katarzyna ŁUKACIJEWSKA
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 I believe that there must be clear and consistent procedures at European Union level for materials intended to come into contact with food, especially as food can be one of the most important ways of exposing people to chemicals. We know that materials that come into contact with food, depending on their composition and properties, can behave differently. Some toxins are released under the influence of heat, others at low temperatures and even in the refrigerator, toxins can penetrate into food products. Therefore, the procedures for the control of such materials must be subject to continuous verification, as health should be a priority for all of us. In support of these provisions, I voted in favour of the Christel Schaldemose report on the implementation of the Regulation on materials intended to come into contact with food.

name: Mairead McGUINNESS
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report, which seeks to harmonise law regarding food contact materials, incorporating paper, cardboard and other such materials.

name: Petr MACH
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted against. While it is important that food packaging does not endanger packaged food, I do not agree with the Commission's call to 'prepare standards for paper and cardboard' as a matter of priority, this will only lead to unnecessary regulation.

name: Ivana MALETIĆ
text: Written. \u2012 Monitoring and control measures related to food contact materials (FCMs) on the European Union market are essential for maintaining safety and managing the potential risk of human exposure to hazardous chemicals. Consequently, further harmonisation of FCM-related rules in the areas of risk assessment and conformity implementation and control is necessary. Some institutions, such as the European Food Safety Agency, deal with issues of materials that come into contact with food, but their actions are limited. Controls to be carried out by states under the Regulation on official controls on food and feed are rarely regular. Control practices vary across EU Member States and the documentation that comes with this control is often unavailable or incomplete.  In order to ensure effective oversight of FCMs within the EU, risk assessment gaps need to be filled, materials in every part of the supply chain should be followed and controls should be carried out successfully. The current framework of measures needs to be adapted to better achieve the objectives of preserving and protecting consumer health and better efficiency of the existing internal food market.  As a result of the forthcoming claims, I have supported this report, as I believe that standards for product safety features in the EU must ensure and protect consumer health and facilitate controls in the Member States.

name: Andrejs MAMIKINS
text: in writing. ‒ I support report author’s suggestion to continue with further scientific research into non-intentionally added substances as, in contrast to known hazardous substances, their identity and structure, especially in plastics, are often unknown and extend the concept of vulnerable groups to pregnant and breastfeeding women and to include the potential effects of low-dose exposure and non-monotonic dose responses in the risk assessment criteria.

name: Vladimír MAŇKA
text: Writing. \u2012 Food security is a fundamental human right. It also includes the safety of food contact materials. The regulation in force on these materials lays down general safety requirements and provides for the possibility of taking specific measures for the seventeen materials listed in the Annex to the Framework Regulation. So far, only four materials have been taken such measures: plastic (including recycled plastic), ceramics, regenerated cellulose and active and intelligent materials. Assessments of the implementation of the Regulation at EU level have highlighted the inadequacy in the implementation of the legislation and the need for further binding harmonisation in the area of food contact materials. I support the proposal asking the Commission to step up research and risk assessment of materials by effective cooperation and coordination with the Member States and the organisations concerned, and using new modern procedures and knowledge. It is necessary to introduce a declaration of conformity and to increase the traceability of materials from third countries so as to ensure a uniform high level of health protection.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: Writing. \u2012 I am voting in favour of the report on the implementation of the regulation on materials in contact with foodstuffs for the reasons I mentioned in detail in my speech to the plenary of the European Parliament in Strasbourg on 5/10/2016, and because this report is complete and documented.

name: Dominique MARTIN
text: In writing. I voted for this text. There is now a European legislation on Food Contact Material (FCM), i.e. "materials and objects intended to come into contact with food". The purpose of these regulations is to set standards on the limits that FCM may have on the taste of food and on the alteration of the composition or texture of foodstuffs. The voted text proposes to cover more materials, to take into account the cocktail effect (the result of the interaction of several CMFs), and finally to harmonize conflicting regulations, which we agree.

name: Costas MAVRIDES
text: Writing. \u2012 I am voting in favour of the report on the application of the Regulation on materials that come into contact with food, because when they come into contact with food and depending on its composition and properties, the different materials behave differently and can transfer their ingredients to food. Member States often adopt specific measures at national level but these measures may differ from other States and thus different product safety standards arise. For these reasons, it is necessary for the EU to take action to address both the lack of concrete measures and the gaps in risk assessment, compliance with the rules and control.

name: Georg MAYER
text: Writing. This report is concerned with improving the control and regulation of food contact materials. As consumers have so far been exposed to many chemicals of concern, their regulation needs to be stepped up. That is why I voted in favour of the report.

name: Valentinas MAZURONIS
text: Writing. \u2012 I support the EP's report on the Regulation on materials and articles intended to come into contact with food. The legislation aims to maintain a high level of consumer protection while ensuring the effective functioning of the internal market for food contact materials.

name: Jean-Luc MÉLENCHON
text: In writing. Materials intended to come into contact with food are commonly used in everyday life: food packaging, kitchen utensils, crockery, etc. Depending on their composition and properties, these different materials can transfer their constituents to food. For example, chemicals from materials can endanger human health or negatively alter the composition of food products.  An EU regulation adopted in 2004 aims to ensure a high level of consumer protection for products containing materials intended to come into contact with food. The report details the shortcomings of this regulation. As a result, it notes that "a number of substances in materials intended to come into contact with food are not currently being assessed". It also calls for "the adoption of specific measures for the 13 materials (glue, silicone,...) which are not yet regulated at EU level." It also criticises the evaluation procedures applied by the European Agency (EFSA), which takes into account "neither the cocktail effect nor that of multiple, concomitant and cumulative exposures".  I vote for this text.

name: Joëlle MÉLIN
text: In writing. "Food Contact Materials" (FCM) consist of materials that come into contact with food at all stages of the production and consumption chain: containers, packaging, tableware, etc.  We are in favour of this report against the Commission and EFSA. The report and recommendations for revision of Regulation 1935/2004 go in the right direction: the coverage of 13 materials not affected by current legislation by European measures, the consideration of the cocktail effect, the protection of pregnant women and technical measures on bisphenol. In addition, the text calls for harmonization of the "REACH" regulation (1907/2006) in that it contains provisions that conflict with the FCM directives. I therefore voted in favour of this report.

name: Nuno MELO
text: in writing. \u2012 Materials intended to come into contact with food are widely used in everyday life in the form of food packaging, kitchenware, crockery, etc. When put in contact with food, depending on their composition and properties, the different materials may exhibit different behaviors, transferring their constituents to food. In such cases, chemicals emanating from materials intended to come into contact with food may endanger human life or adversely alter the composition of foodstuffs. This legislation aims to safeguard a high level of consumer protection while ensuring the effective functioning of the internal market for food contact materials. Hence my vote in favour.

name: Roberta METSOLA
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report as further harmonisation across the Union and implementation of existing measures are steps in the right direction to increase citizens’ protection against the harmful effects caused by certain materials used in food packaging.

name: Louis MICHEL
text: Written. – The European Parliament gives the highest priority to food safety. And rightly so, because safe food is not only about what you get on your plate, but also about the materials in which food is prepared, served, stored or packaged. Potentially toxic ingredients in packaging can contaminate the food, creating additional health risks for the user. A number of these substances are associated with chronic diseases, metabolic disorders, allergies and neurological defects. By eliminating the use of these substances from products that are in contact with nutrition, you are not only doing targeted prevention, you are also saving on health care spending. In a single European market, it is extremely important to create a level playing field and to guarantee the same safe products to consumers wherever they live. If the recommendations in this report are implemented, important steps will have been taken to ensure food safety, a higher level of consumer protection and the proper functioning of the internal market for FCM. In addition, better cooperation and coordination between Member States on the rapid alert system for foodstuffs should help to ensure that health risks are avoided more quickly and effectively.

name: Miroslav MIKOLÁŠIK
text: Writing. – FCMs are used on a daily basis and are subject to legally binding rules at EU level (Regulation (EC) No 1935/2004). So far, only 4 FCMs have been covered by specific measures at EU level: plastic (including recycled plastic), ceramics, regenerated cellulose and active and intelligent materials. For other FCMS, Member States may take specific measures at national level. This leads to the development of different product safety standards, as specific measures taken by one Member State may differ from those of another Member State. Furthermore, the absence of specific EU measures for other FCMs creates barriers in the internal market, the increased costs associated with this are often borne by the consumer, thereby losing competitiveness and innovation. Further harmonisation of non-harmonised materials would be a positive step. Priority should be given to materials that pose a particular risk to human health and for which there is greater demand on the EU market (such as paper and cardboard, including recycled paper and cardboard, coatings, inks and adhesives). In the interests of greater efficiency, it is also necessary to address shortcomings in the implementation of existing legislation and to strengthen funding for the European Food Safety Authority (EFSA), which plays a key role in the fcms risk assessment.

name: Marlene MIZZI
text: in writing. ‒ I have voted in favour of the report because the current legislation on Food Contact Materials (FCMs) needs to be revised with some urgency in order to provide a better level of health protection. It is essential to ensure that substances coming in contact with foodstuffs do not present health risks, specific EU measures for non-harmonised materials should also be adopted to create a level playing field and better control standards across Member States. The focus should, in particular, be on risk assessment, traceability as well as enforcement and controls.

name: Csaba MOLNÁR
text: Writing. \u2012 Food contact materials are widely used in everyday food packaging and in the form of kitchen utensils, cutlery, etc. These substances are subject to legally binding rules at EU level, as defined in Framework Regulation (EC) No 1935/2004. The Regulation lays down general safety requirements applicable to all substances and products which may come into contact with food, but also provides for the possibility of adopting specific measures for the seventeen substances listed in Annex I to the Framework Regulation. However, only four specific measures have been adopted at EU level so far: plastics, ceramics, regenerated pulp and active and intelligent materials. Member States may adopt specific measures at national level for other materials in contact with food (e.g. paper and cardboard, metals and alloys, glass, coating materials, silicones, rubbers and printing inks). The absence of specific UNION measures for most of the substances listed in Annex I has led to internal market restrictions and loss of competitiveness and innovation. The draft resolution of the Committee on the Environment, Public Health and Food Safety cautiously calls for further harmonisation of the 13 non-harmonised substances at EU level, giving priority to substances that pose a particular threat to human health or for which there is greater demand on the EU market. I voted in favour of this report.

name: Sophie MONTEL
text: In writing. I am in favour of this report against the Commission and EFSA. On the other hand, the recommendations for revision of regulation (EC) No. 1935/2004, and in particular the consideration of the cocktail effect, the protection of pregnant women and the technical measures on bisphenol, seem to me to be common sense. So I'm voting for it.

name: Nadine MORANO
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report on materials intended to come into contact with food through packaging, cooking utensils, dishes... It is necessary to put in place at European level a harmonisation of the various measures taken by the Member States to ensure that citizens do not find elements harmful to their health in their diet. That is the purpose of this text.

name: Momchil NEKOV
text: in writing. – I supported Mrs Shaldemose's report on the application of the Food Contact Materials Regulation, as I believe that materials not regulated by specific EU measures can pose a risk to public health and lead to a loss of consumer confidence. Taking common measures on food quality will help to protect the environment and the proper functioning of the internal market.  There is uncertainty as to the identification of all materials intended to come into contact with food and may pose a risk to the quality of the products. Material traceability must be ensured at all stages of the supply chain in order to facilitate the control, recall of defective products, informing consumers and determining liability.  I share the idea of building single EU standards for analytical testing of certain categories of food contact materials and products. This system would facilitate the implementation of the legal framework by all Member States and would also help to promote the free movement of products already controlled between Member States.

name: József NAGY
text: Writing. \u2012 Conscious eating is becoming increasingly popular in our society. People are starting to pay more attention to what the products they buy are made of, but many people have no idea how much chemicals they come into contact with. We must assure customers that, when they come into contact with packaging, different products do not contain substances that may be harmful to human health. The European Union already has such a register, and with today's vote I supported the addition of new material to the list. In addition, we must ensure that the topicality of the register is monitored and that we provide easy access for all.

name: Victor NEGRESCU
text: in writing. ‒ Before its consumption, food comes into contact with many materials during its production, processing, storage, preparation and serving. These materials are known as food contact materials (FCMs). I have voted in favour of this report that will set out general safety requirements applicable to all FCMs.

name: Luděk NIEDERMAYER
text: Writing. \u2012 One of the areas that the EU should focus on in relation to food contact materials is to improve the traceability and compliance of those imported from third countries with the rules by requiring the production of proper and complete identification documents and declarations of conformity. Imported food contact materials must comply with EU standards in such a way as to protect public health and ensure fair competition. With regard to products originating in the EU, I do not think that we need new or stricter regulation at EU level. It is sufficient if we are able to harmonise the level of enforcement of legislation regulating food contact materials within the EU, where there are often significant differences between countries. Better data exchange between Member States is a prerequisite.

name: Franz OBERMAYR
text: Writing. I voted in favour of this report as consumers are exposed to a wide range of chemicals of concern, including perfluorinated compounds and endocrine-disrupting chemicals such as bisphenols and phthalates. These chemicals can lead to chronic diseases or developmental disorders. I am in favour of the Member States being allowed to take measures on their own if the European Union no longer pursues the precautionary principle.

name: Urmas PAET
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported. EU action is necessary to better protect consumer health and the more efficient functioning of the internal market.

name: Demetris PAPADAKIS
text: Writing. \u2012 Food, before its final consumption, comes into contact with many materials and articles during the various stages of their production, processing, storage, manufacture and disposal. These materials must be sufficiently inert to ensure that their ingredients do not adversely affect either consumer health or food quality. As food is one of the most important routes of human exposure to chemicals, materials that come into contact with food are subject to legally binding rules at EU level. I therefore voted in favour of the report on the implementation of the Regulation on materials in contact with foodstuffs because it seeks to ensure a high level of consumer protection while ensuring the effective functioning of the internal market in relation to products in contact with foodstuffs.

name: Margot PARKER
text: in writing. ‒ We in UKIP believe that the safety of food contact materials must be seriously evaluated as chemicals can easily migrate from the materials into food. However, Member States should be free to adopt specific measures at national level so that FCMs can comply with good manufacturing practices.

name: Eva MAYDELL
text: in writing. – I voted in favour of this report as I believe it will benefit the EU citizens by making food contact materials safer. The report points out the need to urgently tackle current shortcomings in the implementation and enforcement of the legislation in place. According to the report, the focus should, in particular, be on risk assessment and traceability as well as enforcement and controls.

name: Alojz PETERLE
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported the report, the key contribution of which is to encourage the necessary measures at EU level to fill gaps resulting from the lack of specific measures for certain materials and shortcomings in compliance and control. The hearing in Parliament has shown that the materials used in food packaging are a subject that undoubtedly deserves more attention. We have checked the implementation of the relevant regulation, ing about the worrying facts. Our aim is to promote the development of materials and products that are safe, fit for reuse and recycled, thereby also contributing to the Union's efforts to build a more efficient circular economy.

name: Marijana PETIR
text: Written. ‒ I support the resolution on the implementation of the Regulation on materials and objects that come into contact with food. In my view, we need to put in place eu-wide common measures for most food contact materials, as action in line with the requirements of different national rules is neither effective nor effective for achieving the objectives.  It is also important that manufacturers and processors provide complete information and that there is a good level of cooperation between scientific authorities and laboratories in all Member States to ensure food health correctness, but also to enable technological innovation in the future based on clear and uniform rules.  In line with one of the main objectives of the Regulation, namely the protection of human health, the Commission should also examine the consequences of the impact of interaction and multiple exposures to such materials when setting migration limits from materials considered safe for human health.  The conclusion is that action is needed at EU level to address the lack of specific EU measures and gaps in risk assessment, compliance and control enforcement.

name: Pina PICIERNO
text: in writing. \u2012 Protecting citizens' health is, as it should be, at the top of our concerns. The current legislation on materials and articles intended to come into contact with foodstuffs needs to be reviewed as soon as possible, to ensure that these materials do not present any health risks. Particular attention should be paid to risk assessment, traceability, regulatory effectiveness and controls. These materials are widely used, every day, for the packaging of food products, for their storage, for kitchen utensils and so on. Depending on their chemical use and composition, they can alter the properties of food and release toxic substances or that interfere with the endocrine system. It is therefore necessary to develop analytical and toxicological tests to be subjected to these materials, in order to ensure the highest degree of safety for consumers and, where possible, to provide for the use of safer alternative materials. At the same time, reuse and recycling must be encouraged in the context of the development of the circular economy. I therefore fully support the measures proposed in the report, and I hope that the Commission will implement them as soon as possible.

name: Tonino PICULA
text: Written. ‒As regards national measures, the principle of mutual recognition does not apply, so it is not possible to ensure effective internal market action and a high level of health protection. I recommend introducing uniform EU standards for analytical testing of categories of materials that come into contact with food. Further measures at EU level would encourage businesses to develop safe FCMs that can be recycled and reused, contribute to the EU's efforts to create a more efficient circular economy. Full attention should be paid to the adoption of specific measures for 13 materials that are not yet regulated at EU level.  In particular, I support additional research into nanomaterials, as scientifically their impact on human health has not yet been scientifically established. Nanomaterials should be subject to the authorisation procedure for use. A revision of the regulation of ceramics is also required. I call on the Commission to increase the level of EFSA funding given the additional work needed due to the increased need to carry out a risk assessment. The absence of specific measures encourages the emergence of barriers in the internal market, with increased costs often shifting to the burden on consumers. Member States must ensure the necessary personnel and equipment to carry out uniform, robust and systematic controls, as well as to establish a system of dissuasive penalties in case of non-compliance.

name: João PIMENTA LOPES
text: in writing. This report addresses the need to revise the Regulation on food contact materials (MFTs), widely used in everyday life in the form of food packaging, kitchenware, cutlery, etc. When put in contact with food these different materials may behave differently by transferring some of their constituents to food – a phenomenon called migration – and some may endanger human health by infecting or adversely altering the composition of foodstuffs. So far, specific measures have been adopted at EU level for only four FCMs: plastic (including recycled plastic), ceramics, regenerated cellulose and active and intelligent materials. For other MFSs, Member States may adopt specific measures at national level. These measures may differ from Member State to Member State, with different product safety standards depending on where it is used and marketed. Current EU legislation on FCMs allows the use of chemicals that are prohibited for other purposes. On the other hand, it ignores the effect of endocrine disrupting, carcinogenic, mutagenic or toxic effects on reproduction, bioaccumulation effects or other harmful properties. It is therefore important to deal with the lack of specific measures and gaps in risk assessment, application, traceability, compliance and control of FCMs.

name: Salvatore Domenico POGLIESE
text: in writing. \u2012 The rapporteur calls on the Commission to review the current regulatory framework in order to facilitate the implementation of the legislation and to better achieve its objectives, namely the protection and protection of consumer health and the guarantee of the effective functioning of the internal market. Regulation (EC) No 1935/2004 lays down the general safety requirements applicable to all possible materials and articles intended to come into contact with foodstuffs (MCAs); it also provides for the possibility of adopting specific measures for the seventeen materials listed in Annex I to the Framework Regulation.  This report analyses and develops the following issues on the substance in order to be able to urgently address the current shortcomings in the implementation and application of current legislation: risk assessment, traceability, enforcement and compliance checks. A further finding concerns the fact that some Member States do not oblige undertakings producing or importing MCA to officially register their economic activity, which is a major obstacle to carrying out the appropriate controls.  In conclusion, I believe that action is needed at EU level to remedy the lack of common specific measures and to fill the gaps in risk assessment, traceability of compliance and controls. I voted in favour of its approval.

name: Franck PROUST
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report on the implementation of the regulation on materials for contact with food. It must be noted that chemicals can sometimes come from materials that we all use in everyday life: packaging, crockery, kitchen equipment... The aim of this text is therefore to promote the harmonisation, at European level, of measures taken by the Member States. Existing gaps must be identified to continue to protect against risks, which is why I also voted to bring bisphenol A (BPA) ban on European level in all materials intended to be in contact with food.

name: Julia REID
text: in writing. ‒ We in UKIP believe that the safety of food contact materials must be seriously evaluated as chemicals can easily migrate from the materials into food. However, Member States should be free to adopt specific measures at national level so that FCMs can comply with good manufacturing practices.

name: Sofia RIBEIRO
text: in writing. The Regulation defines safety requirements for all possible materials intended to come into contact with food, providing for the possibility of adopting specific measures for the 17 materials.  Specific measures adopted by a Member State at national level may differ from those in another Member State by creating different standards for product safety. It also leads to barriers in the internal market, with increased compliance costs and loss of competitiveness and innovation.  According to the study by the Pe Studies Service, a major challenge is that several substances present in materials intended to come into contact with food are not currently evaluated. This is the case of so-called 'unintentionally added substances' ('SNIA') which are impurities of intentionally added substances or substances resulting from chemical reactions, which are present in the finished material.  Action needs to be taken at EU level to address the lack of specific measures in the EU and gaps in risk assessment, traceability, compliance and control.  According to the foregoing, I voted in favour of this report.

name: Liliana RODRIGUES
text: in writing. \u2012 Materials intended to come into contact with food are widely used in everyday life in the form of food packaging, kitchenware, crockery, etc. When put in contact with food, depending on their composition and properties, the different materials may exhibit different behaviors, transferring their constituents to food. In such cases, chemicals emanating from such materials may endanger human life or negatively alter the composition of foodstuffs. The legislation aims to safeguard a high level of consumer protection while ensuring the effective functioning of the internal market for such materials. To date, specific measures have been adopted at EU level for only four materials intended to come into contact with food: plastics, ceramics, regenerated cellulose and active and intelligent materials. For other materials intended to come into contact with food, Member States may adopt specific measures at national level. This creates a situation where the specific measures adopted by an MS at national level may differ from those in another MS, creating different standards for product safety and barriers to the internal market. Further harmonisation at EU level is a step in the right direction.

name: Inma RODRÍGUEZ-PIÑERO
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the application of the Regulation on materials and objects intended to come into contact with food, since sometimes the chemicals emanating from them may endanger health and adversely modify the composition of food. Regulation (EC) No 1935/2004 lays down safety requirements in this regard. Annex 1 lists seventeen materials for which Member States must take specific measures, and such measures need to be harmonised in order to avoid obstacles to the internal market. Uniform standards should also be established as regards the tests to be carried out on such materials.

name: Claude ROLIN
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the motion for a resolution on the implementation of the regulation (EC 1935/2004) on materials for contact with food. This subject concerns the daily lives of European citizens since there are many materials for contact with food. The report calls on the Commission to revise the current regulatory framework. Indeed, it is important to strengthen the assessment of substances in these materials and to ensure their traceability in order to protect the health of European consumers. Furthermore, I am pleased that the text contains a specific amendment calling for the banning of bisphenol A in materials in contact with food.

name: Bronis ROPĖ
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report. I think it's very relevant. Every day we use food packaging, tools that come into direct contact with food. It is often not even thought that these substances can affect food and then our health. It is therefore necessary to have legislation aimed at maintaining a high level of consumer protection. The report also calls for the development of safe, reusable and recyclable food-contact raw materials and products, thus contributing to the EU's efforts to create a more efficient circular economy.

name: Virginie ROZIÈRE
text: In writing. Regulation 1935/2004 establishes general safety requirements for materials and objects intended to come into contact with food. However, it does not guarantee sufficient consumer protection, as many materials are not subject to specific measures at European level and the provisions adopted by some Member States are insufficiently protective.  The purpose of this report is to improve existing regulations and fill gaps. It urges the Commission and relevant agencies to raise the level of consumer protection, including by extending the concept of vulnerable groups to pregnant or lactating women. This report proposes a ban on bisphenol A in all materials intended to come into contact with food and better traceability of nanomaterials, and calls for an obligation to submit complete identification documents and declarations of compliance. Finally, the report calls for a drastic increase in the effectiveness and frequency of regulatory compliance checks.  To the extent that it helps to better protect consumers, especially pregnant women and children, I voted in favour of this report.

name: Fernando RUAS
text: in writing. \u2012 Materials and objects in contact with food are widely used in everyday life (e.g. food packaging, cooking utensils). When put in contact with food and depending on their composition and properties, the materials behave differently, transmitting parts of their constituents to them. However, the chemicals that these objects emanat, can alter the composition of foodstuffs endangering human health. Although these products are subject to Community rules (to which they are legally bound), the existing Regulation lays down only the general safety requirements and also provides for the possibility of specific measures in accordance with the legislation of each Member State.  So far, only common specific measures have been adopted within the EU for four materials/objects.  The specific measures adopted by one Member State may be different from those taken into account by the other, so that the absence of common European measures not only hinders the internal market, but also leads to increased compliance costs (often transferred to consumers) and also result in a loss of competitiveness and innovation/development capacity. Because I consider this uniformity in the area of food security to be important, I voted in favour of this own-initiative report.

name: Tokia SAÏFI
text: In writing. Materials in contact with food, such as packaging or plastic bottles, contain chemicals that can endanger human health. It is therefore urgent and essential that the European Commission act on this issue and harmonize the measures taken by each Member State in this regard.  This harmonization must also be accompanied by solutions to current gaps in order to improve legislation and protect consumer health.  In addition, I voted to ban bisphenol A in any material that may come into contact with food. Bisphenol A is a dangerous, endocrine disrupting and toxic chemical. This substance is already banned in France but it is urgent that it be banned at European level.

name: Massimiliano SALINI
text: in writing. \u2012 With the regulation approved today we wanted to define the general safety requirements applicable to all objects that come into contact with food products and we have also adopted specific measures to be implemented when it comes to contact between food and 17 specific materials. On food safety, we cannot lower our guard, which is why I fully supported the text.

name: Lola SÁNCHEZ CALDENTEY
text: in writing. U2012 I vote in favour of this report. I think it is important that the Union gradually creates legislation on this subject. This is a first step and although I believe that this is not enough, it proposes specific measures at European level on materials and objects intended to come into contact with foods such as plastic, ceramics, cellulose, etc. which I think are paramount. The report also mentions the importance of Member States taking specific measures in the event that European legislation does not mention certain materials that may be considered toxic.

name: Daciana Octavia SÂRBU
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report which highlights many of the concerns related to food contact materials. I particularly support the emphasis on safer alternatives to endocrine disrupting chemicals. Once again, I urge the European Commission to provide the necessary support to reduce and prevent our exposure to the potentially harmful effects of endocrine disruptors. Whilst human health is the overriding priority, this report also contains constructive approaches for reducing costs to industry. Savings could be passed on to consumers if EU-wide standards replaced the current patchwork of varied rules and different standards.

name: Sven SCHULZE
text: Writing. I voted in favour of implementing the regulation on food contact materials as it is a useful preventive measure for our health. Materials or objects that come into contact with food are widely used in our everyday lives in the form of packaging, kitchen utensils or dishes. A whole list of these materials, such as .B plastic or ceramics, must now meet certain criteria. The aim is to reduce the health risk associated with food intake.

name: Olga SEHNALOVÁ
text: Writing. \u2012 In the case of contact with foodstuffs, different materials may behave differently depending on their composition and properties and their components may be released into food. This can threaten human health or adversely alter the composition of food. For this reason, I supported My colleague Schaldemos's report and her call for the current EU legislation on food contact materials to be arrangements in order to provide a higher level of health protection. In my opinion, emphasis should be placed, for example, on risk assessment and on the enforcement and control of compliance with the rules in question.

name: Maria Lidia SENRA RODRÍGUEZ
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report as the Union should seek adequate regulation for all types of materials and objects intended to come into contact with food, including a ban on the use of endocrine disruptors and other substances of high concern. Current Union legislation on MCF allows chemicals that are prohibited under other Union laws. Not much of the substances present in materials and objects intended to come into contact with food are being evaluated. This is the case with so-called 'unintendedly added substances' ('NIAS') which are impurities of intentionally added substances or substances resulting from chemical reactions (such as decomposition products or by-products formed during the production process), which are present in the finished material. It should also be noted that, in its risk assessment procedure, the European Food Safety Agency (EFSA) does not take into account the so-called 'cocktail effect' and multiple exposures (resulting from chemicals - even at low doses - from different sources). All of this should be addressed by EFSA as soon as possible.

name: Siôn SIMON
text: in writing. ‒ Today, I voted for the implementation of the Food Contact Materials Regulation, the regulation sets out general safety requirements that are applicable to all possible food contact materials. Depending on their composition and properties, different materials may behave differently and potentially transfer chemicals which may endanger human health.

name: Davor ŠKRLEC
text: Written. \u2012 Food comes into contact with a number of materials and objects (FCMs) during storage, processing, serving and end consumption. Although they should be inert with their structure and do not affect food quality or consumer health, there are materials that behave unexpectedly and transfer their component parts to food.  These are primarily endocrine disruptors – chemicals that disrupt the functioning of hormones, present in a wide range of commonly used products such as pesticides and biocides, food packaging materials, dishes, etc. They have a very negative effect on health by causing cancer, fertility problems, obesity, neurobihevioral disorders such as hyperactivity, etc.  Also among these chemicals is certainly the most famous bisphenol And to which we are exposed through plastic packaging of food products, plastic bottles and bottles for feeding infants.  I supported the European Parliament's resolution on the implementation of the regulation on materials that come into contact with food so that, in light of the EU's focus on the transition to a circular economy, they develop better synergies between the FCM Framework Regulation and the circular economy, which should include uniform methods of testing the harmfulness of these materials, banning their use, and adopting specific measures to regulate them across the European Union.

name: Monika SMOLKOVÁ
text: Writing. \u2012 The Food Contact Materials Regulation (MPSP) lays down general safety conditions for all materials in contact with food. I supported the resolution because it comes with proposals that should encourage businesses to develop safe, reusable and recyclable (IPC), thereby underlining the european Union (EU's) efforts to create a more efficient circular economy. As stated in the report, we have 13 materials that are not regulated at EU level and which may be subject to specific measures. I believe that, in view of the large presence of these materials on the EU market and the risk they pose to human health, and in order to maintain a single market for IPC and food products, the Commission should start giving immediate priority to the development of specific EU measures for materials such as paper, cardboard, varnishes and coatings, metals and alloys, inks and adhesives. It regrets that, in general, the role of food contact materials in food contamination and the lack of information on human exposure to chemicals are underestimated. I therefore expect member states to involve all relevant stakeholders in the process when proposing specific safety requirements for IPC and to increase the frequency and effectiveness of official controls.

name: Michaela ŠOJDROVÁ
text: Writing. \u2012 The European Parliament voted today on an own-initiative report on the application of the Regulation on food contact materials, which I have decided to support. I consider the EP's initiative to revise the existing Framework Regulation (EC) No 1935/2004 on the issue of food contact materials, particularly in the context of the protection of human health. In materials intended for contact with food (food packaging, kitchen utensils, tableware, etc.), there are a number of harmful chemicals released from these materials into food. When consuming food, EU citizens are thus at high risk of endangering their health. I therefore welcome this recommendation, which seeks to maintain a high level of consumer protection while ensuring the effective functioning of the internal market for these materials.  The recommendations rightly emphasise the appeal to support further research in this area, to ensure sufficient control of goods and compliance and enforcement of the rules. At the same time, the text also ed the need to comply with the established standards for goods imported from third countries.

name: Igor ŠOLTES
text: Writing. \u2012 We meet with materials intended to come into contact with food on a daily basis. They can be found in food packaging, kitchen utensils and the like. Different materials can behave very differently when in contact with food, leaving traces or particles in food. That is why it is important that the rules on the main standards are regulated at European Union level. In particular, the report recommends the adoption of measures at EU level on materials regulated in each country. These materials are mainly paper (also recycled), cardboard, various coatings, inks and accessories. The main point of this report is the need to address quickly the current shortcomings in the implementation of the regulation of food contact materials. I believe that, in the case of exposed materials, risk assessment, traceability and enforcement of rules and controls are of great importance. I supported the report because food security is crucial for our health and a healthy environment.

name: Bart STAES
text: Written. 'Food and food often come into contact with other materials, such as kitchen and tableware or packaging. In view of the possible 'interaction' with food, general safety rules apply in Europe and specific measures can be taken for 17 materials listed in the Annex.  To date, there are only regulations for 4 materials, namely plastic, ceramics, regenerated cellulose and active and intelligent materials. Member States may set their own rules for the other 13 materials. For example, in some countries strict regulations apply to paper, cardboard, metal and alloys, glass, coatings, silicone, rubber and printing inks, which are less stringent in others.  The implementation report nicely exposes how, because of this lack of harmonisation between Europe and the Member States, public health enjoys little protection and the interests of consumers are secondary. It calls for the creation of specific rules for the food contact materials that are most harmful and in high demand (paper, cardboard, coatings, ink and adhesives). The Greens provided a link with hormone disruptors, Reach, the cocktail effects and nanomaterials. And with circular economy. We ask for better control and uniform testing. And we call for a total ban on the use of bisphenol A.

name: Joachim STARBATTY
text: Writing. The report aims to create individual measures at EU level for all food contact materials, which I believe is useful and has positive effects for all stakeholders. Unfortunately, the report also provides for massive regulation of bisphenol A (BPA) contained in some food contact materials.  BPA is used for the production of many plastics and therefore has an enormous technical and economic significance. The plastics themselves are generally completely harmless biologically, but can release the BPA they contain to food. BPA is known to have a negative effect similar to the female sex hormone estrogen.  However, what the rapporteur has concealed in his very detailed report is the reassessment carried out by the European Food Safety Authority (EFSA) in January 2015. EFSA's findings show that the amount of BPA that the consumer is exposed to is well below the safe limit, even with combined contact with both food and cosmetics. According to EFSA 2015, BPA does not pose a health risk to any age group.  The strong regulation of the economically relevant BPA cannot therefore be proven from a scientific perspective. Consequently, I rejected the report.

name: Ivan ŠTEFANEC
text: Writing. \u2012 The quality and wholeness of food is affected not only by its composition, but also by substances, including packaging, which come into contact with them in the process of their supply to the market. In cooperation with EFSA and ECHA, we want to identify these substances, assess the potential risk to the consumer and take measures to eliminate any undesirable consequences of their use.

name: Neoklis SYLIKIOTIS
text: Writing. \u2012 The report provides for eu committees to examine food-in-contact materials imported from third countries, although it does so without strong and clear language. Although we are not satisfied with the verbal part, we are in favour of the report.

name: Eleftherios SYNADINOS
text: Writing. \u2012 No one can undermine public health at all. Furthermore, we believe that the solution to such problems is to return, as far as possible, to the use of traditional ways of packaging and processing food and not to develop new and unknown substances in terms of their final effects.

name: Tibor SZANYI
text: Writing. \u2012 Materials in contact with food are, for example, kitchen utensils and cutlery, in addition to food packaging. In contact with foodstuffs, depending on their composition and properties, these substances may transmit their ingredients to food and the ingredients may harm human health or alter the composition of foodstuffs. This process is known and therefore food contact materials are already regulated at EU level by a framework regulation (1935/2004/EC). This sets general safety requirements for seventeen substances and a separate eu-wide measure (plastics, ceramics, regenerated cellulose and active and intelligent substances) exists for a further four substances. Member States can currently adopt specific measures at national level for other substances in contact with food, so there are still many gaps and differences in standards hindering innovation.  I therefore agree that the current legislation needs to be amended, not only by widening the material scale, but also in instalments such as risk assessment, traceability, conformity and control. I also agree with the report that common measures are also needed for substances that do not pose health risks in order to improve control. I believe that the supply of healthy food is in our common interest, so I voted in favour of this report.

name: Adam SZEJNFELD
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 Food is considered one of the most important sources of human exposure to chemicals. The safety of food contact materials should therefore be carefully assessed, as these substances may enter the products we consume. Food contact materials include products such as packaging and containers, processing machines, kitchen appliances, cutlery and utensils. It is estimated that there are around 15 000 different substances in food contact materials.  Experts draw attention to the need to urgently correct shortcomings in the implementation and enforcement of existing European Union legislation, as the degree of enforcement varies greatly. Further harmonisation of the law on materials and articles intended to come into contact with food could help to ensure a uniform, high level of protection of public health.

name: Claudia ȚAPARDEL
text: in writing. \u2012 The European Union is the guarantor of the defence of the health of the citizens of the Member States and of the marketing of products that comply with food safety standards. Materials coming into contact with food (MACs), including food packaging, kitchen utensils, crockery, must have an appropriate chemical composition to avoid the transfer of harmful substances into food. In this respect, the EU adopted, in 2004, Regulation No 17. 1935, intended to ensure the safe management of plastic, ceramic, cellulose or intelligent compounds, in accordance with specialised studies in this field. For the remaining ESA, standards are set at national level, which creates real difficulties at Community level, in particular on the free movement of goods. With a view to harmonising these standards, this resolution proposes a common approach to the recycling and use process, in line with the concept of the circular economy, to carry out more complex joint tests at European level in order to avoid endocrine disruptors, in-depth research into nanomaterials, to revise the Ceramic products Regulation and to carry out more rigorous controls. This is a resolution aimed at eliminating the health risks of the MPA, which is why I support its adoption.

name: Marc TARABELLA
text: In writing. Packaging and containers, kitchen utensils, dishes: all materials in contact with your food but on which there is doubt about health safety. According to the European Parliament's report voted this lunchtime, 15,000 different substances are present in these materials, most of which are not known. Toxicity, traceability, lack of control and harmonisation: the European Parliament is sounding the alarm and believes that the danger to human health is real from a transfer of the chemicals contained in these materials to food. Some countries have rules in place but there is no real coherence between member states. In addition to the health risk, the situation is economically damaging. We also see gaps in the traceability of the various components and a lack of official controls: this is not acceptable, we do not mess with the health of citizens!

name: Pavel TELIČKA
text: in writing. ‒ Food contact materials (FCMs) are largely used in everyday life in the form of food packaging, kitchen utensils, tableware, etc. When in contact with food, and depending on their composition and properties, the different materials may behave differently, transferring their constituents to the food. In such cases, chemicals emanating from FCMs may endanger human health or adversely change the composition of the foodstuffs. The most pressing issue is the need to adopt EU specific measures for food contact materials that are widely used in Europe, such as paper and board, both virgin and recycled, and for materials that may pose a significant risk to human health, such as inks, metals or coatings. I voted in favour of the report and I fully support the call for the revision of current EU rules on food contact materials. Many substances are currently not harmonized at EU level, a goal that is in the interest of both consumers and operators. Consumers would benefit from the higher EU-wide standards of consumer protection and operators from the legal certainty that uniform rules bring.

name: Isabelle THOMAS
text: In writing. Materials intended to come into contact with food are widely used in everyday life: food packaging, kitchen utensils, crockery... Putting these materials in contact with food can endanger human health because they contain harmful chemicals.  EC Regulation 1935/2004 proved ineffective, and its revision is therefore essential.  More needs to be done to protect consumers and their health, including banning bisphenol A, which many scientists consider an endocrine disruptor. The European Commission's consideration of the dangerous nature of this substance is a step forward and I welcome Parliament's vote on its ban.  The Commission must now propose alternative solutions to this substance, and review the regulation to ensure the health of Europeans.

name: Ruža TOMAŠIĆ
text: Written. ‒ Although there has been significant progress in improving global food safety, the overall number of chronically malnourished people remains unacceptable. This is why I think it is right that eradicating hunger has become one of the priorities under the SDGs of the 2030 Agenda for Sustainable Development.  I also believe that among the most important items of the fight of the Agricultural Action Plan is to encourage responsible private sector involvement and learning from inclusive business models.  This resolution encourages increased productivity of small businesses and the achievement of sustainable agricultural and food systems, and recognises rural transformation as a key process for job creation, increasing incomes and achieving long-term food security and nutrition.  I believe that through the proposed integration of countries most affected by hunger into global trade and by maintaining food security and nutrition at the heart of global and national policies, progress will be made in the fight against malnutrition. Therefore, I supported this resolution.

name: Romana TOMC
text: Writing. The proposal for a regulation on food contact materials (Regulation (EC) No 1935/2004) was supported. Food contact materials are widely used in everyday life in the form of food packaging, kitchen utensils, tableware and utensils, etc. Chemicals made from food contact materials endanger human health or adversely alter the composition of foodstuffs. As food is considered one of the main routes of human exposure to chemicals, these materials are subject to legally binding rules at EU level, which are currently laid down in the Framework Regulation. The Regulation lays down general safety requirements applicable to all possible materials and articles intended to come into contact with foodstuffs.

name: Estefanía TORRES MARTÍNEZ
text: in writing. U2012 I vote in favour of this report. I think it is important that the Union gradually creates legislation on this subject. This is a first step and although I believe that this is not enough, it proposes specific measures at European level on materials and objects intended to come into contact with foods such as plastic, ceramics, cellulose, etc. which I think are paramount. The report also mentions the importance of Member States taking specific measures in the event that European legislation does not mention certain materials that may be considered toxic.

name: Ulrike TREBESIUS
text: Writing. The report aims to create individual measures at EU level for all food contact materials, which is a useful approach. Unfortunately, the report also provides for massive regulation of bisphenol A (BPA) contained in some food contact materials.  BPA is used for the production of many plastics and therefore has great technical and economic importance. The plastics themselves are generally completely harmless biologically, but can release the BPA they contain to food. BPA is known to have an effect similar to the female sex hormone estrogen and can have a negative effect on the organism.  However, what the rapporteur has concealed in his very detailed report is the reassessment carried out by the European Food Safety Authority (EFSA) in January 2015. EFSA's findings show that the amount of BPA that the consumer is exposed to is well below the safe limit, even with combined contact with both food and cosmetics. According to EFSA 2015, BPA does not pose a health risk to any age group.  The strong regulation of the economically relevant BPA cannot therefore be proven from a scientific perspective. Consequently, I rejected the report.

name: Ramon TREMOSA i BALCELLS
text: in writing. ‒ I agree to take any action that serves to protect the food safety. In this case, specific measures for 13 materials still unregulated, although it is also important to claim that shortcomings exist in the implementation on current legislation, since it seems that there are deficiencies in implementing the regulations in force. I call on the competent authorities to take the necessary measures to protect, in this sense, food consumers in European area.

name: Mylène TROSZCZYNSKI
text: In writing. "Food contact materials" (FCM) are materials that come into contact with food at all stages of the production and consumption chain: containers, packaging, table cutlery, etc. The report contains the following main proposals: - coverage of 13 materials not currently covered by European measures - taken into account by legislation the "cocktail" effect of FCM (i.e. the result of their interactions) as well as substances resulting from chemical reactions of FCM - publication of harmonised guidelines on testing and control procedures. In addition, the text calls for harmonization of the "REACH" regulation (1907/2006) in that it contains provisions that conflict with the FCM directives.  Furthermore, the recommendations on taking into account the cocktail effect, the protection of pregnant women and the technical measures on bisphenol seem to me to be common sense. I voted for it.

name: Kazimierz Michał UJAZDOWSKI
text: I would like to write to the Commission. "We use food packaging, kitchen equipment and dishes every day. Some materials intended to come into contact with food and used in large quantities may be harmful. They are therefore subject to legally binding provisions contained in Regulation (EC) No 1935/2004. That legislation provides that more specific safety requirements may be adopted for individual materials. To date, such rules have been developed for only 4 of the 17 types of materials. I also agree that we should improve existing legislation on risk assessments and ensure better enforcement. I voted in favour of the resolution.

name: Miguel URBÁN CRESPO
text: in writing. U2012 I vote in favour of this report. I think it is important that the Union gradually creates legislation on this subject. This is a first step and although I believe that this is not enough, it proposes specific measures at European level on materials and objects intended to come into contact with foods such as plastic, ceramics, cellulose, etc. which I think are paramount. The report also mentions the importance of Member States taking specific measures in the event that European legislation does not mention certain materials that may be considered toxic.

name: Ernest URTASUN
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report on the implementation of the Regulation on materials and objects intended to come into contact with food, as it reviews the implementation of the rules on these materials and includes important points on endocrine disruptors, on the needs of uniform standards and greater control among others.

name: Viktor USPASKICH
text: Writing. – I welcome research and innovation initiatives aimed at developing new materials that are used in FCMs and which have been proven safe for human health. I believe that further specific measures at EU level would encourage business operators to develop safe, reusable and recyclable FCMs, thus contributing to the EU's efforts to create a more efficient circular economy.

name: Ivo VAJGL
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report on the implementation of the Food Contact Materials Regulation ((EC) No 1935/2004). Food contact materials (FCMs) are largely used in everyday life in the form of food packaging, kitchen utensils, tableware, etc. When put in contact with food, and depending on their composition and properties, the different materials may behave differently, transferring their constituents to the food. In such cases, chemicals emanating from FCMs may endanger human health or adversely change the composition of the foodstuffs. The regulation sets out general safety requirements that are applicable to all possible food contact materials and articles. I voted in favour because I believe that further harmonisation at EU level for non-harmonised materials through specific measures based on scientific evidence would be a step in the right direction, giving priority to those materials that constitute a particular risk to human health and are in bigger demand on the EU market.

name: Ángela VALLINA
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report as the Union should seek adequate regulation for all types of materials and objects intended to come into contact with food, including a ban on the use of endocrine disruptors and other substances of high concern. Current Union legislation on MCF allows chemicals that are prohibited under other Union laws. Not much of the substances present in materials and objects intended to come into contact with food are being evaluated. This is the case with so-called 'unintendedly added substances' ('NIAS') which are impurities of intentionally added substances or substances resulting from chemical reactions (such as decomposition products or by-products formed during the production process), which are present in the finished material. It should also be noted that, in its risk assessment procedure, the European Food Safety Agency (EFSA) does not take into account the so-called 'cocktail effect' and multiple exposures (resulting from chemicals - even at low doses - from different sources). All of this should be addressed by EFSA as soon as possible.

name: Hilde VAUTMANS
text: Written. \u2012 Materials and articles intended to come into contact with foodstuffs (FCMs) are mainly used in everyday life in the form of food packaging, kitchen utensils, dishes, etc. When they come into contact with food, and depending on their composition and properties, the different materials can react differently. In such cases, chemicals derived from FCMs may endanger human health or lead to adverse changes in the composition of the food. The legislation is intended to ensure a high level of protection for consumers while ensuring the proper functioning of the internal market for FCM products. That is why I voted in favour of this report.

name: Marie-Christine VERGIAT
text: In writing. If there is one area where European legislation should be effective, it is to ensure the protection of health by implementing harmonised rules that are faithful to the precautionary principle. This report highlights the shortcomings in the implementation of EU legislation in this area despite the predominance of the materials concerned in the European Union market and the risk they pose to human health. It calls for the regulation to be implemented as a priority for materials that pose a proven risk. I particularly welcome the adoption of the amendment, which includes the ban on bisphenol A, the danger of which is known to all. I am surprised that 239 MEPs (41 ALDE, 41 ECR, 1EFDD, 3 ENF, 4 NI, 154 EPP) have chosen to vote against a request that goes beyond the application of the most basic precautionary principle by switching off a product deemed dangerous.

name: Miguel VIEGAS
text: in writing. \u2012 This report refers to EP recommendations for the revision of the Regulation on Food Contact Materials (MFTs), which are widely used in everyday life in the form of food packaging. This report says it is a voice to the request of a number of stakeholders, including NGOs and universities, saying that action at EU level is urgently and clearly needed to address the lack of specific measures and gaps in risk assessment, implementation, traceability, compliance and control of MFSs. , through specific measures based on scientific evidence, giving priority to materials that pose a particular risk to human health.

name: Harald VILIMSKY
text: Writing. The report contains some good proposals to improve the control and regulation of food contact materials. Consumers are still exposed to many chemicals of concern, which is why strict regulation, in line with the needs of the internal market, is essential to ensure the high level of health protection provided for in the framework regulation and the treaties. That is why I voted in favour.

name: Julie WARD
text: in writing. ‒ The EU’s common internal market rules allow us to trade easily and freely across borders, while keeping consumers safe, and setting common standards to protect our health. This report is one such example. In this report, Labour MEPs join their colleagues in calling for stronger rules to protect consumers from harmful substances in food packaging.

name: Lieve WIERINCK
text: in writing. – I voted in favour of this resolution because the health of European consumers is important to me. The food that we eat on a daily basis comes into contact with many different materials that can have a variety of chemical compositions. The regulation that this resolution concerns ensures that the safety of our food is not affected by these products. I also welcome the important role of EFSA which is recognised in it and the call for increased cooperation between EFSA and the European Chemicals Agency. It also correctly points out the importance of clarity on the use of the relevant substances for our companies, especially for our SMEs. This will also make it easier for them to produce the relevant safety assessments. Finally, with regard to the future, we should not only regard the effects of substances in an isolated form, but further scientific research should be done on the effects of their combinations.

name: Jana ŽITŇANSKÁ
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported Mrs Schaldemose's report on the implementation of the Regulation on food contact materials. The regulation deals with the materials that we come into contact with every day without even realising their possible effects. These are mainly kitchen utensils, food packaging or cutlery. In doing so, these materials can react differently in contact with food and transmit their ingredients to them. That is why such materials need to be subject to strict safety requirements. Strikingly, however, the possible effects of different combinations of these materials on human health have not yet been properly investigated. In the report on the implementation of the Regulation, we therefore invited the Commission to consider imposing special safety requirements on all 17 categories of materials and on Member States to properly check compliance with these requirements. At the same time, in the report, we looked at how best to assess risks and to improve current legislation in the light of the results. And while this regulation will mean, in practice, a slight additional harmonisation of European Union legislation, I believe that the protection of human health is an incalculable consideration.

name: Carlos ZORRINHO
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the Schaldemose report because I consider it necessary to adopt minimum harmonisation rules for materials and objects intended to come into contact with food. Currently the EU already has common standards on plastics, ceramics and cellulose, but there are still 13 types of materials where Member States continue to be able to adopt national provisions, such as paper, cardboard, certain types of metals, glass, silicone and some paints. I point out that within these materials, bisphenol is a particularly controversial endocrine disruptor. Portugal has already come forward to the European Union by banning the use of bisphenol in baby bottles. I believe that in situations where substances with a potentially harmful impact on health are concerned, the precautionary principle should prevail. At the same time, I support the need for scientific research with solid results on the safety of materials and objects intended to come into contact with food for the benefit of consumers, the environment and manufacturers.

name: Marco ZULLO
text: in writing. Food contact materials (MCAs) are widely used in daily life in the form of food packaging, kitchen utensils, dishes, and so on. When they come into contact with food, and depending on their composition and properties, the various materials can behave differently, transferring their components to food. We in the M5S have fought for our amendment to be included in the report calling for a ban on the use of bisphenol A, an endocrine disruptor, in all materials in contact with food. There is now extensive scientific literature which has shown damage to health resulting from the intake of these substances. The current regulation allows agreements on 17 substances, but only four of them are currently harmonised at EU level. The rest is a matter for the Member States. The lack of harmonised rules causes problems for consumers, businesses and authorities. For us in the M5S, this means that the single market is not a single market: some countries have high standards, others have low standards. Food safety must have the same meaning throughout the EU, and I therefore voted in favour of this resolution.

name: Milan ZVER
text: Writing. \u2012 Individual food contact materials and articles may pose risks to public health and the environment due to their specific composition. It is therefore important to monitor effectively the safety requirements for all materials and articles intended for direct or indirect contact with foodstuffs in order to prevent the transfer of substances into foodstuffs in quantities which could endanger human health or cause unacceptable changes in the composition of foodstuffs. I believe that the Report on the implementation of the Food Contact Materials Regulation (Regulation (EC) No 1935/2004) exhaustively presents shortcomings in the implementation of the regulation in force and provides appropriate measures to remedy the situation, which is why I supported it.

name: Krisztina MORVAI
text: - Mr President, I would like to thank the European I would like to briefly describe stage 10 of the report on the monitoring of the application of EU law, which may particularly affect Hungarians. It says it 'emphasises that Member States should avoid unnecessarily burdening EU rules when applying EU legislation, as this leads to a misinterpretation of the EU's legislative activities and increases unjustified EU skepticism among citizens'. We Hungarians would very much like to make sure that there is no unjustified EU skepticism, so that we interpret restrictively all the EU standards that want to extend the powers of Brussels and the Union to determine with which we must live on our own land, how many migrants we have to take in, and how many migrants the UNION intends to take into hungary. So we're trying perfectly to live up to expectations.

name: Danuta JAZŁOWIECKA
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by It is worrying that the internal market is among the areas where we can see the greatest number of complaints and infringements of EU law. In 2014, more than 600 complaints were received and more than 160 infringement cases were opened in this area. Of course, not all of them need to be well-known, but they point to an existing problem.
