Union citizens and businesses very often face a situation which, in their view, constitutes a breach of Union law. I therefore agree with the rapporteur that an easily accessible online complaint form should be created. It will effectively capture situations of violations of EU law. Another very important issue is whether, within the internal market, law should be governed by directives or regulations. I think the answer is not clear. On the one hand, regulations guarantee a more uniform implementation of legal provisions, which can prevent voluntary implementation of EU legislation, which often leads to protectionism. On the other hand, the directives allow for greater account to be taken of the specificities of individual Member States. The European Commission should carry out an even more thorough analysis of both aspects before deciding what legal form it will use. This approach will certainly improve the application of European Union law.

name: Seán KELLY
text: – Mr President, my friend and colleague, Mrs Morvai, made an interesting point when she said that we had too many European regulations. In some respects she reflects what Commission President Mr Juncker has said, because he said that henceforth we will only regulate from Europe where absolutely necessary. But, at the same time, there is no point in having European Union law if it is not applied. Obviously there have been cases where that has not happened and indeed there have been widespread examples of fraud. That is certainly something that has to be combated. I am very pleased that in the recent analysis my own country came out very well in regard to the application of European law. That is something that should apply everywhere. I think it is absolutely vital that we continue to monitor the application of European law and only regulate when necessary. But, when we do so, it has to be applied fairly and evenly across all Member States with no exceptions.

name: Monica MACOVEI
text: – Mr President, responsibility for the correct application of EU law, which means Union law, directives, regulations, but also the Treaty of the Union is shared between the Member States and the Commission. The Commission is the guarantor, the guardian of the Treaties, and must take on this role more firmly. In 2014, the Commission received around four thousand complaints of potential infringements of Union law and launched around nine hundred new procedures for Member States not applying UNION law in the areas of the environment, health, consumer protection, the internal market and so on.  What do I want to point out now? Two things: 1) Member States must transpose their Union legislation on time lye and correctly, they must do so through clear and not complicated laws because things only work with clear laws; 2) here in Parliament, let us no longer stumble in resolutions and complicated declarations with "more", "and", "especially", "if" from which people do not understand, but to adopt clear laws .

name: Isabella ADINOLFI
text: in writing. \u2012 The report takes stock of the situation on the system of infringement procedures within the European Union. Specifically, it focuses on the effectiveness of 'EU PILOT', a project drawn up by the Commission with the aim of preventing possible infringement procedures through a constant exchange of information with the Member States, but this does not seem to have been as effective as it should have been. Furthermore, there is some criticism in the report that the Commission has not yet implemented many proposals from the European Parliament, in particular a rule governing European administrative law. For the reasons listed above, I have chosen to vote in favour.

name: Tim AKER
text: in writing. – The recommendation was to vote against this. The report did not go as far as we would like in identifying enough effort being demonstrated to increase transparency, but it was heading in the right direction.  One of UKIP’s missions is to ensure that transparency is at the forefront of the operations of the EU institutions. Furthermore this report calls for more implementation of EU law.

name: Marina ALBIOL GUZMÁN
text: in writing. The resolution contains many positive elements, such as the reference to the Charter of Fundamental Rights of the European Union in the application of EU law or the recognition of civil society organised in the legislative process. Nevertheless, I abstained, in considering that the application of EU law is not a technical debate, but also a political debate: not in vain, it is legislation linked to the protection of social and civil rights that is systematically breached, where while its application is immediate when it undermines the interests of the people's classes.

name: Lucy ANDERSON
text: in writing. ‒ I was particularly pleased to vote in favour of this resolution because this year it puts renewed pressure on the Commission to fulfil its obligations to help ensure that European Union law is correctly implemented. Vital citizens’ rights in the areas of environment, transport, health and consumer protection, which I have prioritised in my work, are again the subject of the majority of new infringement cases. Members of the public, businesses and campaigning organisations have reported even more concerns about the application of EU law than in previous years, and it is extremely important for justice and democracy that action is taken to address their complaints.

name: Martina ANDERSON
text: in writing. – I voted in favour of this report which sets out the application of EU law in the Member States for the year 2014. The main focus of the report is the fact that there has been a general decrease in the number of formal infringement proceedings, due to the new Pilot Procedure which allows the Commission to open dialogue with Member States before taking official proceedings. This is a good process, which allows Member States to explain or rationalise legislative choices they make when transposing EU law. It means there are fewer instances of the Commission imposing on countries’ sovereign right to choose how to implement new rules.

name: Laima Liucija ANDRIKIENĖ
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report on monitoring the application of Union law, concerning the 2014 Annual Report. This, the Commission’s 32nd annual report on the subject, contains information on the actual implementation and practical application of EU law. While environment, transport and the internal market and services remained the policy areas in which most infringement cases were open in 2014, the number of formal infringement procedures has decreased in the last five years. Despite the positive change, which in Commission’s view reflects the effectiveness of dialogue with Member States, it is clear from the Annual Report that the enforcement of EU law is still not sufficiently transparent. I supported the report as it not only notes that but also calls on the Commission to make compliance with EU law a real political priority. I also appreciate the position that the European Parliament should play a more structured role in the analysis of how accession countries and countries with association agreements with the European Union comply with EU law, as well as in developing appropriate support in relation to those countries.

name: Nikos ANDROULAKIS
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report on monitoring the implementation of UNION law (Annual Report for 2014) because I believe that the adoption of a regulation governing the administrative procedure of the Union's administrative services is imperative.

name: Marie-Christine ARNAUTU
text: In writing. This report recalls or recommends a number of points that we are combating, including the equal value of the treaties in the EU Charter of Fundamental Rights, compliance with EU law as a political priority, the suggestion of greater parliamentary involvement in the exact transposition of EU legislation, particularly in each Member State, as well as for the candidate countries. , the link between the effective application of EU law and the strengthening of the credibility of the Union's institutions.  The report stresses that 'Member States, when applying EU legislation, should avoid adding unnecessary constraints to EU legislation, as this leads to a misguided view of THE Union's legislative activity and promotes unjustified Euroscepticism among citizens' (sic). There is also a demand for greater parliamentary access to information on EU Pilot files. I therefore objected to this report.

name: Jonathan ARNOTT
text: in writing. ‒ I abstained on the grounds that, whilst I do not support the European Union, I do support transparency.

name: Jean ARTHUIS
text: In writing. I voted for this report because I agree with the conclusion that the application of EU law is not yet sufficiently transparent. I also support the idea that the European Parliament must have a proactive role on this issue.

name: Zoltán BALCZÓ
text: Writing. \u2012 The proposal assesses the Commission's 2014 report on the application of EU law. According to the report, Member States are unable to meet unrealistic implementation deadlines for legislation, leading to tacit adoption of delayed application; calls on the European institutions to agree on a better timetable for the implementation of regulations and directives. It is proposed that the Commission should be more active in combating the incorrect transposition of directives.  The proposal to force integration is being pushed through with concern about the weakening of the effectiveness of EU law, which the reporter says "systemically undermines the poor use of it by Member States and insufficient monitoring activities by the Commission." The main point of the report is that EU law needs to be made more effective in the Member States, so it has a strongly pro-integration approach and is therefore not accepted from a Eurorealist point of view. At least in the previous report there were systemic elements, which is essentially missing. In view of these, I did not support the proposal.

name: Nicolas BAY
text: In writing. The text advocating a number of points that we are fighting, namely, the equal value of the treaties in the Charter of Fundamental Rights of the Union, compliance with EU law as a political priority, the suggestion of greater involvement by Parliament in the exact transposition of EU legislation, particularly in each Member State.  The report stresses that 'Member States, when applying EU legislation, should avoid adding unnecessary constraints to EU legislation, as this leads to a misguided view of THE Union's legislative activity and promotes unjustified Euroscepticism among citizens' (sic). There is also a demand for greater parliamentary access to information on EU Pilot files. I naturally voted against it.

name: Hugues BAYET
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report because I agree with the findings and proposals made by the members of the Committee on Legal Affairs.  While stressing the essential role that the Commission plays in monitoring and assessing the implementation of EU legislation, MEPs recognise that Parliament also plays a key role in exercising political oversight of the Commission's enforcement measures and suggests that it should contribute even more.  They also call on the EU institutions to agree on more realistic deadlines for the implementation of regulations and directives and to increase transparency in the application of EU law. The Commission is invited to present a legislative proposal on a European law of administrative procedure and to make compliance with EU law a real political priority, which it will have to implement in close collaboration with Parliament.

name: Xabier BENITO ZILUAGA
text: in writing. U2012 I am voting in favour of this resolution because it contains very positive elements. The resolution calls for strengthening EU law for the protection of consumer rights, and in health, environment, mobility and transport. There are many cases of infringements initiated by the Commission that are still open, so this report calls for Parliament to be able to adequately access this information to make the processes more transparent.

name: Izaskun BILBAO BARANDICA
text: in writing. I would like to thank the rapporteur for her work in this report on monitoring the application of EU law. The responsibility for correctly applying and implementing EU law lies mainly with the Member States, but that fact cannot relieve the European institutions of their duty to respect primary EU law when drawing up rules of secondary law.

name: Dominique BILDE
text: In writing. I voted against this report which recalls or advocates equal value to the treaties of the EU Charter of Fundamental Rights, compliance with EU law as a political priority, the suggestion of greater parliamentary involvement in the exact transposition of EU legislation, particularly in each Member State, as well as for candidate countries. , the link between the effective application of EU law and the strengthening of the credibility of the Union's institutions. Sovereignists, we fight European law which subjects our standards to those of illegitimate supranational institutions.

name: Mara BIZZOTTO
text: in writing. \u2012 The report analyses the regular report on member states' application of EU rules. I do not agree with what it says: I believe that it does not take into account the real problem facing the EU, namely excessive standardisation and the continuous attitude of censorship with regard to national parliaments that are transposing legislation that often strongly and negatively affects the socio-economic fabric of their territories. We need only think of the damage caused in Italy by the directive on services to the bathing and itinerant trade sectors. For all these reasons, I voted against this text.

name: Malin BJÖRK
text: Written. \u2012 The report deals with the Commission's annual report on the control of the application of EU law. It shows, among other things, that the environment, transport, the internal market and services remained the policy areas where the largest number of infringement procedures were in progress in 2014.  The report is critical of the fact that the work on enforcing EU law is still not sufficiently transparent. The desire for parliament's greater transparency is emphasised, greater transparency in monitoring the application of EU law; the application of EU law lies with the Member States, and it stresses that, when implementing EU law, Member States must also fully respect the fundamental values and rights of the Treaties and the CHARTER of Fundamental Rights. These are good points with which I agree.  Other points highlighted include the importance of reducing Euroscepticism among citizens, without any reflection on why it exists. The main issue of the report, as the title describes, is the basic functions of the European Union, which are deeply undemocratic but which are not sufficiently criticised. That is why I have chosen to abstain.

name: Vilija BLINKEVIČIŪTĖ
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report, which discusses the Commission's report on the monitoring of the application of European Union law. The report shows that the environment, transport and the internal market and services were the policy areas where the largest number of infringement procedures were initiated in 2014. The report also highlights the decrease in the number of formal infringement procedures over the last five years. According to the Commission, this demonstrates the effectiveness of the dialogue between Member States under the EU Pilot procedure. However, given that Parliament still has limited access to information on eu pilot and pending cases, it is difficult to assess the extent to which the reduction in the number of formal infringement procedures actually reflects the fact that Member States are more in compliance with EU law than by the fact that the Commission and the Member State that infringed EU law have found a compromise solution. Thus, the report concludes that enforcement of EU law is still not sufficiently transparent. Thus, the proposals of a new working group on administrative law set up by the Committee on Legal Affairs could be a valuable source of inspiration for the Commission, as they show that a regulation on the EU administrative process would be useful and that it could be adopted.

name: Andrea BOCSKOR
text: Writing. \u2012 The motion for a resolution summarises professionally and comprehensively the current state, results and problems of the application of EU law, and I therefore voted in favour of the adoption of this report.

name: Franc BOGOVIČ
text: Writing. \u2012 I also supported the annual report on monitoring the application of EU law for 2014, which contains a number of interesting information on the actual implementation and practical application of EU law. The report shows that it is the areas of the environment, transport and the internal market and services where infringement procedures were the most open in 2014. If I map this to the national level of the country I come from, the situation is similar. I am very pleased that the number of procedures is decreasing, which shows an improvement in the dialogue between the Commission and the Member States.

name: Simona BONAFÈ
text: in writing. \u2012 The Commission's 2014 annual report on monitoring the application of European Union law contains valuable indications. The European Union is founded on the rule of law and its institutions must ensure that Community policies and priorities are applied uniformly on European territory. The report shows that, in 2014, the environment, transport, the internal market and services sectors were the sectors with the highest number of infringements.  However, the number of formal infringement procedures has decreased over the last five years: this improvement is due to the implementation of the 'EU Pilot' procedure, which opens a constructive dialogue between the Commission, the 'guarantor of the Treaties', and the Member States caught in breach of European rules, before a formal opening of infringement proceedings. The report, which I support, emphasises the need for greater transparency in the application of Community law and greater inclusion of the European Parliament.  Transparency and information on infringement procedures can and must help to strengthen the confidence of EU citizens in the European Union.

name: Biljana BORZAN
text: Written. \u2012 I support this Report.  The Commission's annual report shows that the environment, transport and internal market and services remained at 2014 levels in most cases. According to the report, the number of formal infringement procedures has been reduced as a result of the effectiveness of the informal "EU pilot procedure".  However, the rapporteur also points out that, given that Parliament still has only limited access to information on this process and ongoing cases, it is difficult to assess the extent to which the reduction of the formal procedure actually reflects better compliance with EU laws.

name: Marie-Christine BOUTONNET
text: In writing. This report recalls or recommends a number of points that I am fighting, namely, the equal value of the treaties in the Eu's Charter of Fundamental Rights, compliance with EU law as a political priority, the suggestion of greater parliamentary involvement in the exact transposition of EU legislation, particularly in each Member State, as well as for the candidate countries, and the link between the effective application of EU law and the strengthening the credibility of the Union's institutions. So I voted against it.

name: Mercedes BRESSO
text: in writing. ‒ I endorsed the resolution on monitoring the application of Union law because we are aware that it is the timely and correct transposition of EU law into national legislation which enables the intended benefits of EU law to be delivered to individuals. I believe that Parliament can support the work of the national parliaments by sharing its expertise in the legislative decision-making process.

name: Renata BRIANO
text: in writing. \u2012 Monitoring the application of European Union law shows that there are still many cases where infringement proceedings are opened regarding the effective implementation and practical application of EU law. It can therefore be said that the application of Eu ropean Union law is not yet sufficiently transparent and that its effectiveness is systematically undermined by its unsatisfactory application by the Member States and by unsatisfactory verification by the Commission. Many of the EU directives, particularly those in the economic and financial field, have not been transposed by many of the Member States. It is often the imposition of unrealistic deadlines for the implementation of legislation that causes Member States to be unable to comply with them. Financial penalties for non-compliance with Union law should be effective, proportionate and dissuasive and take into account the repetition of the omission in the same area. Delays in transposition are an obstacle to the proper functioning of the internal market and run counter to the interests of citizens and businesses, depriving them of some of their rights.

name: Steeve BRIOIS
text: In writing. This report takes stock of the infringement procedures brought against Member States by the European Commission. It also recalls that the Brussels Commission is the guardian of the treaties (Article 17 of the EU Treaty) and that as such it has the opportunity to refer the matter to the Court of Justice of the Union in order to incriminate a Member State for mistrans transposing a directive into national law or misapsiting an EU regulation. As such, the Court has issued five judgments in which it has imposed the payment of penalties on Italy, Greece, Portugal, Spain and Sweden.  Above all, it extols two constitutive aspects of the positive law of the Union that I have always fought: the equal legal value between the treaties and the Charter of Fundamental Rights and the institution as a political priority for the compliance of national laws with EU law. That is why I voted against this report in order to defend the legislative and legal sovereignty of France.

name: Enrique CALVET CHAMBON
text: in writing. In the text put to the vote, it is stated that, together with the elections, the main expression of democracy is the referendum. In view of the serious attacks that representative democracy is suffering at the hands of the so-called 'direct democracy' or 'acclamative to the Carl Schmitt' which are undermining the very concept of democracy, with the obvious recent evidence of the Brexit referendums in Colombia or California, I was clearly not able to vote positively on the call to a method that is helping the delicuescence of the European project.

name: Matt CARTHY
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report which sets out the application of EU law in the Member States for the year 2014. The main focus of the report is the fact that there has been a general decrease in the number of formal infringement proceedings, due to the new Pilot Procedure which allows the Commission to open dialogue with Member States before taking official proceedings. This is a good process, which allows Member States to explain or rationalise legislative choices they make when transposing EU law. It means there are fewer instances of the Commission imposing on countries’ sovereign right to choose how to implement new rules.

name: David CASA
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report and I agree with the proposals made by Parliament’s Working Group on Administrative Law, which could provide valuable insight to the Commission, as they show that a regulation on the administrative procedure of the EU’s own administration would be useful and feasible to enact. The Commission’s Annual Report contains interesting information on the actual implementation and practical application of EU law. It also stresses, inter alia, that the number of formal infringement procedures has decreased in the past five years, which is a reflection of dialogue with Member States in the context of the EU Pilot procedure. It questionable though whether this is due to better compliance with EU law by Member States or to more compromise solutions between the Commission and the infringing Member States.

name: Fabio Massimo CASTALDO
text: in writing. \u2012 This year's report focuses on the effectiveness of the EU Pilot system, which provides for a continuous exchange of information between the Commission and Member States in order to prevent possible infringement procedures. The rapporteur, in particular, points out that the decrease in the number of infringement proceedings could be linked to the constant decrease in complaints lodged by the Commission and not to the actual effectiveness of the EU Pilot programme. The report also criticises the Commission for not implementing many proposals from the European Parliament, including the drafting of rules to regulate European administrative law.

name: Caterina CHINNICI
text: in writing. \u2012 The effective and timely application of Eu ropean Union law is a prerequisite for having a clear legislative framework and for strengthening the credibility of the European institutions.  It is clear from the report that the number of formal infringement procedures has decreased over the last five years, but I believe that we need to analyse the origins of this outcome. It is difficult, in fact, to assess the extent to which a reduction in the number of infringement procedures really represents greater respect for the law and better transposition of European rules or rather an increase in compromise solutions between the European Commission and the Member States.  I believe that Parliament can play a significant role in assessing the application of the law, but that its access to information on procedures is still too limited to allow for thorough monitoring, especially with regard to the EU Pilot procedure. Therefore, in voting in favour, I agree with the call made by the rapporteur, Heidi Hautala, for easier access for the European Parliament to files relating to cases of breaches of EU law, in order to ensure greater transparency and constructive interinstitutional dialogue.

name: Lefteris CHRISTOFOROU
text: Writing. \u2012 We support the report and agree with the rapporteur's position that the European Parliament can and should play a more structured role both in examining how the candidate countries and the countries with which the European Union has concluded association agreements comply with EU law and in providing appropriate support to these countries.

name: Kostas CHRYSOGONOS
text: Writing. \u2012 The annual report on monitoring the application of Union law monitors the extent to which Member States and competent authorities apply and comply with Union law. The report records positive comments and points that need to be improved immediately. I believe that such reports contribute to the improvement of European construction and that is why I voted in favour.

name: Angelo CIOCCA
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted against this report analysing the 2014 report on member states' application of EU rules. The report is limited in terms of describing the reasons that often lead Member States to apply EU legislation beyond the deadline. I believe that late transposition is the result of European over-standardisation.

name: Alberto CIRIO
text: in writing. \u2012 I agree with the 2014 annual report on monitoring the application of European Union law. In particular, I consider it extremely important to encourage the clearer and more transparent national rules adopted through the transposition of EU law and to specify which national authorities are responsible for their proper implementation. It is, in fact, as the rapporteur has pointed out, a right that belongs to the citizens of the Union, as it is based on the rule of law and on the certainty and predictability of the laws. I also believe that greater clarity is also needed between relations between Parliament and the European Commission with regard to the 'EU Pilot' procedure. Finally, I am pleased to note that, compared with the statistics contained in that report, the infringements committed by Italy are falling.

name: Deirdre CLUNE
text: in writing. ‒ I supported the report on monitoring the application of Union law: 2014 Annual Report, and I noted no objections.

name: Carlos COELHO
text: in writing. \u2012 Parliament annually focuses on the state of implementation of Community legislation. An essential exercise for the legislator, but which is of particular relevance given the institutional architecture of the Union: for example, directives depend on member states' action to enter into force. Once again, this report makes a good diagnosis, identifying the areas where member states have most non-compliance. It also notes a decrease in actions for non-compliance, the result of a further dialogue between the Commission and the Member States in the "pre-litigation" phase. Although desirable, this dialogue - called "EU pilot" - is not very transparent, limiting public scrutiny and by the institutions, in particular this Parliament. I therefore support this report, underlining the need to improve the implementation of Community legislation and parliament's power of scrutiny.

name: Jane COLLINS
text: in writing. – The recommendation was to vote against this. The report did not go as far as we would like in identifying enough effort being demonstrated to increase transparency, but it was heading in the right direction. One of UKIP’s missions is to ensure that transparency is at the forefront of the operations of the EU institutions. Furthermore this report calls for more implementation of EU law.

name: Lara COMI
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report as it provides a comprehensive picture of the effective implementation and practical application of EU law. The three sectors most affected by infringement proceedings in 2014 were the environment, transport and the internal market-services, but in the last five years there has nonetheless been a general decrease in procedures thanks also to an effective policy of dialogue with the Member States.

name: Therese COMODINI CACHIA
text: in writing. ‒ EU legislation needs to facilitate social, judicial, environmental and economic processes and not be burdensome or increase bureaucracy. The contrary continues to feed unjustified EU scepticism among citizens. Consequently, the Commission should always strive to improve its practices in order to inform citizens in a timely and appropriate manner of any actions and steps taken in response to processing their complaints. This can be facilitated by a single gateway that will provide citizens with easy access to online complaint forms and user-friendly information on infringement procedures.  The annual report states that it is still frequent and widespread practice that late or incomplete transposition take place. A similar situation is found in relation to the misapplication of EU law, and therefore I support its call on Member States to implement and execute EU law effectively.

name: Javier COUSO PERMUY
text: in writing. The resolution contains many positive elements, such as the reference to the Charter of Fundamental Rights of the European Union in the application of EU law or the recognition of civil society organised in the legislative process. Nevertheless, I abstained, in considering that the application of EU law is not a technical debate, but also a political debate: not in vain, it is legislation linked to the protection of social and civil rights that is systematically breached, where while its application is immediate when it undermines the interests of the people's classes.

name: Andrea COZZOLINO
text: in writing. \u2012 The primary responsibility for the proper implementation and application of EU law lies with the Member States. However, the Commission has an essential role to play in monitoring the application of EU law and in presenting its annual report to Parliament and the Council. The European Parliament has a decisive role to play in political control over the Commission's implementing actions. In view of this, I believe it is essential to increase the use of certain existing instruments at European level to contribute to a better application and verification of the application of EU law in the Member States, in line with the new Interinstitutional Agreement on Better Lawmaking. In particular, the informal 'EU Pilot' mechanism, which promotes closer and more coherent cooperation between the Commission and the Member States in order to remedy infringements of EU law at an early stage, so as not to have to resort to the formal infringement procedure. I believe that monitoring the effective transposition of EUROPEAN Union law within the national legislative framework is a way not only to prevent infringements, but also to bring citizens the expected benefits and to give credibility to the European legal system and its institutions.

name: Pál CSÁKY
text: Writing. \u2012 The European Commission prepares its annual report on the application of EU law for the 32nd time this year. The report under discussion relates to 2014. Several commissions in Parliament, including the Committee on Petitions (PETI), have commented on the 2014 report. In addition to infringement procedures, a number of cases are explored and resolved in the FRAMEWORK of THE EU Pilot. The latter involves less formalities and provides for a faster settlement in the event of a breach of EU law, which can benefit both the Member State concerned and, above all, those involved in the legislation, EU citizens and businesses. As the People's Party's responsibility within PETI, I pointed out that petitions also have a role to play in the application of EU law in the Member States, with a significant number of submissions helping Member States to monitor and identify shortcomings in the transposition and application of EU law. The petitions data show that the alleged infringements of EU legislation in particular in the following areas predominate: fundamental rights, including the rights of persons belonging to minorities and persons with disabilities, discrimination, in particular on the basis of nationality, the internal market, free movement, transport, the environment, education, employment and health. It is important that complaints concerning fundamental rights are also treated equally by the Commission.

name: Edward CZESAK
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 I have decided to abstain on the 2014 Annual Report on the review of the application of EU law. By being part of a political faction for which the sovereignty of each Member State is crucial, I have an ambivalent attitude to giving Parliament a greater role in analysing legal changes in both the acceding countries and the countries with which the Association Agreements have been signed. I also abstained because the amendments proposed by my faction were rejected, and they addressed key issues for me: the principles of subsidiarity and proportionality in the application of EU law.

name: Miriam DALLI
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report since I believe that it is important to monitor Member States’ legislation and to verify that it complies with EU law. It is important that Member States adopt EU legislation and EU institutions should ensure an effective monitoring system.

name: Viorica DĂNCILĂ
text: in writing. \u2012 Given that the primary responsibility for the proper implementation and application of EU law lies with the Member States, but also taking into account the important role played by the social partners, civil society organisations and other stakeholders in the drafting of legislation and in the monitoring and reporting of shortcomings in the transposition and application of EU law by the Member States, I believe that existing EU legislation must be supplemented when there are shortcomings or problems related to interpretation that will lead to more accessibility, clarity and consistency in the interpretation of existing rules for the benefit of citizens and businesses, as well as its administration and officials.

name: Michel DANTIN
text: In writing. This initiative report covers the 32nd annual report on the monitoring of the application of European law as well as the effective implementation and practical application of EU law. In this report, MEPs point out that the environment, transport and internal services are now the areas where most infringement cases were opened in 2014. Considering that the full and compliant application of European law is an essential component of the effectiveness of European policies, I supported this report.

name: Rachida DATI
text: In writing. I supported this report on the 2014 annual report on the monitoring of the application of EU law. European citizens can only have confidence in the European Commission's control of the application of EU law by Member States if they are satisfied with the degree of transparency. In this regard, an informal consultation process between the Commission and Member States on matters relating to the conformity of national legislation with European law or the proper application of EU law, known as eu-Pilot, is particularly opaque. It is therefore essential to make the content of these consultations more accessible by revising the framework agreement on relations between the European Parliament and the European Commission and by including informal EU Pilot-type processes. Once this review is carried out, the Commission will be obliged to keep Parliament informed of the progress of its informal consultations with the Member States.

name: Isabella DE MONTE
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the Commission's annual report to promote the effective implementation of EU law by both candidate and non-member countries, as well as countries with association agreements with the EU, and to improve transparency and cooperation. I also supported the report so that Parliament plays a more structured role in the analysis of compliance with EU law.

name: Angel DZHAMBAZKI
text: Angel Dzhambazki (ECR), in writing. \u2012 I abstained on the 2014 annual report on monitoring the application of Union law. Despite some positive aspects contained therein, proposals for the application of the principles of subsidiarity and proportionality were not taken into account. I believe that they are among the fundamental principles of European legislation and the assessment of their application is an integral part of the application of EU law.

name: Georgios EPITIDEIOS
text: Writing. \u2012 I consider the text negative in its entirety because, in a very artful and insidious way, the EU and its legislators have constructed laws and rules that also remove a nation's last right to sovereignty. These are laws which cannot have the same force in the States of Europe, since the situation is different. By covering the supposedly sensitive issues, in the view of the loan sharks, they are stepping on the wreckage of the Europe of Nations and Peoples.

name: Rosa ESTARÀS FERRAGUT
text: in writing. This report presents the European Parliament's position on the Commission's thirty-second annual report on monitoring the application of EU law. The report notes that the correct and time-limit transposition of Union legislation into national legislation and a clearly defined national legislative framework should be a priority for Member States. This line highlights the importance of improving transposition and the need for Member States to communicate and clearly indicate the national measures supplementing European directives. It is emphasized that, in applying EU law, Member States should refrain from adding unnecessary obstacles to EU law. The correct implementation of the Union contributes to strengthening the credibility of the institutions.

name: José Manuel FERNANDES
text: in writing. The report shows that the environment, transport, the internal market and services are the areas where more infringement proceedings were still pending in 2014 but the number of formal infringement cases has decreased in the last five years. One conclusion that can be drawn from the report is therefore that the application of Community law is still not sufficiently transparent. I therefore agree that Parliament could and should play a more structured role in analysing how candidate countries and countries that have concluded association agreements with the European Union comply with EU law, as well as in developing adequate support in this regard for those countries.

name: Edouard FERRAND
text: In writing. Vote against: this report recommends a number of points that we are fighting, including the equal value of the treaties in the EU Charter of Fundamental Rights, compliance with EU law as a political priority, the suggestion of greater parliamentary involvement in the exact transposition of EU legislation, particularly in each Member State, as well as for candidate countries. , the link between the effective application of EU law and the strengthening of the credibility of the Union's institutions.

name: João FERREIRA
text: in writing. \u2012 This annual report monitors the application of EU law by its institutions.  The general sense is not different from that of previous years. Some curiosities stand out. For example, it refers in the recitals that there were 3715 complaints, in significant numbers those relating to Spain (553), Italy (475) and Germany (276). But already when we move from complaints to cases (initiated by the European Commission) the figures change, with a total of 893 appearing in the following countries: Greece (89), Italy (89) and Spain ( 86). Obvious question: so what happened to Germany? What about Greece? Informative... We are opposed to the supervisory view, which is the part of the report and is part of the treaties, which gives the European Commission the power to bring infringement proceedings "in order to ensure compliance with EU law" and supports that the Court of Justice may impose sanctions on Member States for late transposition of EU law. And not only because of the discriminatory nature on which the evaluations are based, assessments which are never cease to be political evaluations, as is clear. Furthermore, we reject the possibility of financial sanctions, as advocated in the report, which Portugal is now facing. Obviously we voted against it.

name: Luke Ming FLANAGAN
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour.

name: Monika BEŇOVÁ
text: Writing. \u2012 The European Commission's annual report on monitoring the application of European Union law has once again yielded some interesting findings and insights. As in the past, most cases where Member States have failed to fulfil their obligations fall within the fields of the environment, transport and the internal market and services. It is also to be welcomed that the results of the report show that the number of formal infringement procedures has decreased in the last 5 years, which may point to the progress made under the EU Pilot project. However, the European Parliament still has very limited access to the information processed under the project in question, and it is therefore very difficult to determine to what extent the reduction in the number of formal infringement procedures actually reflects better compliance with Union law by the Member States and not compromise solutions between the Commission and the Member States. Despite the many positive results that have undoubtedly been achieved in the area of the application of European Union law by the Member States, it remains clear that we must continue to take further measures in order to achieve an even higher level of transparency.

name: Lorenzo FONTANA
text: in writing. \u2012 I am voting against the report, which focuses little on the flaws in EU over-standardisation and continues to prefer an attitude of censure towards national parliaments.

name: Lampros FOUNTOULIS
text: Writing. \u2012 I am voting against the 2014 annual report on monitoring the implementation of EU law because, in a very artful and insidious way, the EU and its legislators have constructed laws and rules that also remove a nation's last sovereign rights. These are laws that cannot have the same force in the states of Europe, since the situations are different. By covering the supposedly sensitive issues, in the view of the loan sharks, they are stepping on the wreckage of the Europe of Nations and Peoples.

name: Francisco de Paula GAMBUS MILLET
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the report on monitoring the application of EU law, which contains information of great importance on the effective transposition and practical application of EU law. The annual report also stresses that the number of formal infringement procedures has decreased over the past five years. However, the report points to Spain as one of the Member States that are most in breach of European legislation. It should be noted that the European Commission has received 533 complaints about possible violations of European regulation in the case of Spain. We must therefore urge the Spanish Government to faithfully comply with European legislation in order to defend the interests of all citizens and collectives.

name: Enrico GASBARRA
text: in writing. \u2012 After the vote in the JURI Committee, we also adopt in plenary a report that makes an important point on the application of European Union law. I welcome the work of Mrs Hautala, who highlights in particular the cases of infringements for failure to transpose EU directives and regulations in the fields of the environment, transport and the internal market, which touch on issues that are crucial to the lives of so many of our citizens. I think it would be useful for the report to also highlight Parliament's difficulty in being informed of the various infringements and to ask for a fundamental review of the right of access to all the various cases, it is a crucial point of transparency and democracy.

name: Jens GIESEKE
text: Writing. I support the 2014 Annual Report on the Application of EU Law. Only through regular revision can we improve the implementation of EU law.

name: Nathan GILL
text: in writing. ‒ The report did not go as far as I would have liked in identifying enough effort being demonstrated to increase transparency, but it was heading in the right direction. One of UKIP’s missions is to ensure that transparency is at the forefront of the operations of the EU institutions. Furthermore this report calls for more implementation of EU law.

name: Sylvie GODDYN
text: In writing. The purpose of this report is to verify the proper application of EU directives in the Member States and to take stock of the measures taken against those who have applied them poorly. It therefore accredits a large number of negative observations that we make against the European Union: a desire to put the internal law of each State in step, obvious interference, retaliatory measures in the event of insubordination. This report comes from the Commission on the Control of the Application of EU Law, for which the sovereignty of nations is not a concern. For these reasons, I objected to this report.

name: Tania GONZÁLEZ PEÑAS
text: in writing. U2012 I am voting in favour of this resolution because it contains very positive elements. The resolution calls for strengthening EU law for the protection of consumer rights, and in health, environment, mobility and transport. There are many cases of infringements initiated by the Commission that are still open, so this report calls for Parliament to be able to adequately access this information to make the processes more transparent.

name: Maria GRAPINI
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted by drawing Commissioner Jurova's attention to the fact that there is no need for overregulation, but there needs to be better monitoring of the application of European regulations, such as, for example, respect for the waiting time for the response to appeals. I consider it important to monitor and to inform information on the effective implementation and practical application of EU law. The report shows that areas such as the environment, transport, the internal market and services continue to be the developing political business, in most cases due to default in 2014. The number of formal infringement procedures has decreased over the past five years and this reflects the effectiveness of dialogue with Member States in the context of the EU Pilot procedure. I believe that the European Parliament could and should play a more structured role in carrying out the analysis on how candidate countries and countries with association agreements with the European Union comply with EU law, as well as in providing appropriate assistance to those countries.

name: Theresa GRIFFIN
text: in writing. ‒ I voted for the 2014 annual report on monitoring the application of EU law. The report expresses concern about the Commission’s democratic deficit and stresses the importance of parliamentary involvement and democratic oversight. It also calls for better oversight of the Commission’s infringement and pre-infringement procedures.

name: Marian HARKIN
text: in writing. ‒ The European Parliament plays a crucial role in the application of European Union law. It has a major role in overseeing the application of Union law to ensure that it is enforced correctly and fairly. I believe that Parliament itself should play a stronger role in the analysis of how accession countries and countries with association agreements with the European Union comply with EU law, and should provide those countries with suitable assistance. I support the suggestion that Parliament should draft proper reports, not simply resolutions, on all candidate countries in response to the annual progress reports released by the Commission. Sincere cooperation between the Commission and Parliament is essential for the smooth application of European law and is something I strongly support.

name: Brian HAYES
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour since I have no objections

name: Hans-Olaf HENKEL
text: Writing. This report clearly shows that there are difficulties in implementing Union law in the EU. More than 3700 infringement cases submitted to the Commission speak for themselves. The problem is made even clearer by the reform proposals submitted to the nation states in the context of the European Semester. According to the Committee on Economic and Monetary Affairs, only 10 of the 157 main proposals have been implemented. While Members of the European Parliament make every effort to emphasise the rule of law, the EU as a whole is not credible. In the course of the so-called euro rescue policy, too many laws from the highest level are simply being violated or violations are tolerated. The statement by Juncker, who asked whether the EU would launch infringement proceedings against France, replied: "No, because it is France." Because of this double standard, I voted against the report. If, on a large scale, the EU no longer wants to establish the rule of law, it cannot work on a small scale. Incidentally, I believe that the single euro must be abolished, because it leads to strife and discord.

name: Filiz HYUSMENOVA
text: in writing. \u2012 I support the annual report on monitoring the application of Union law. I am pleased that the report's findings indicate that there has been a decline in criminal procedures as a consequence of the introduction of the EU Pilot initiative. I join the call in the report for more transparency regarding the application of EU law.  I call on the Commission, as guardian of the Treaties, to continue to monitor impartially the compliance, proper and timely implementation of European legislation, as this creates reassurance to European citizens about the effective functioning of institutions in the protection of their interests.  However, I would also like to express my concern and call on the Commission to pay particular attention to the administrative and legislative obstacles still existing to the full exercise of minority languages in some Member States, as EU language policies aim to protect the linguistic diversity that is enshrined among EU values in the provisions of the EU Charter of Fundamental Rights.

name: Cătălin Sorin IVAN
text: in writing. ‒ The number of formal infringement procedures in 2014 decreased due to the effectiveness of the EU Pilot procedure. This is great news, but much remains to be done. One deplorable fact is that Parliament still has only limited access to vital information and thus cannot play the role of ‘monitoring the monitor’ efficiently and effectively.

name: Ivan JAKOVČIĆ
text: Written. ‒ I voted for the Monitoring report on the application of Union legislation: the 2014 annual report, as I think the effective application of EU legislation has an impact on strengthening the credibility of the Institutions of the European Union. In its annual reports, the Commission has given importance to petitions from citizens, businesses and civil society organisations as a fundamental right enshmined in the Lisbon Treaty and an important element of European citizenship and an important secondary means of monitoring the application of EU legislation and identifying possible loopholes through direct expression of citizens' views and experiences, in addition to elections and referendums, which remain the primary means of their democratic way of expressing themselves. 32. The annual monitoring report on the application of EU law has shown that the process of implementing EU law is still not transparent enough, but there is certainly room for progress, so changes and a different approach are expected in the new period, leading to even greater transparency.

name: Jean-François JALKH
text: In writing. This report raises a number of points on which I disagree with the EU's ambition, including the political priority of respect for Community law, the excessive value given to the Charter of Fundamental Rights, or any strengthening of any kind of European institutions. So I voted against it.

name: Diane JAMES
text: in writing. – The recommendation was to vote against this.  The report did not go as far as we would like in identifying enough effort being demonstrated to increase transparency, but it was heading in the right direction.  One of UKIP’s missions is to ensure that transparency is at the forefront of the operations of the EU institutions. Furthermore this report calls for more implementation of EU law.

name: Petr JEŽEK
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the 2014 Annual Report on monitoring the application of Union law because it contains interesting information on the current implementation and practical application of EU law. It is a large-scale analysis reflecting also the effectiveness of the dialogue with Member States, with the conclusion that the enforcement of EU law is still not sufficiently transparent. Not least, it turns the spotlight on the regulation on the administrative procedure of the Union’s own administration.

name: Marc JOULAUD
text: In writing. I voted in favour of my colleague Heidi Hautala's report on the application of EU law. The aim of this text is to highlight how EU law has been applied by Member States. The 2014 report mentioning some shortcomings, I welcome the Commission's initiative to strengthen its partnership with States to remedy the violations found and to improve the handling of complaints from European citizens and businesses. This report is part of the determination of all European institutions to ensure that European legislation serves citizens better.

name: Josu JUARISTI ABAUNZ
text: in writing. ‒ EH Bildu voted in favour of the annual report on monitoring the application of Union law, including a separate vote on paragraph 10. Despite being a paragraph that EH Bildu does not consider completely convincing, our vote was based on the following sentence: ‘stresses the importance of enhancing transposition and the need for Member States to provide notification of, and clearly indicate, national measures that supplement European directives.’ The Spanish State has often been warned or punished for not implementing EU law correctly.  More specifically, the Spanish government tried to hide the notification of Framework Decision 2008/675/JAI, after having transposed it more than four years late. Thanks to a parliamentary question addressed by Josu Juaristi MEP, we were informed that the Spanish government was one year and a half late notifying the transposition law. We have no doubt there is an intentional delay in the notification aiming to avoid the European Commission´s analysis of the national law.  EH Bildu wishes to recall that if the national law complied with this Framework Decision seven prisoners should be immediately released. EU law is often our only safeguard when dealing with Basque politically motivated prisoners and thus we voted in favour of paragraph 10.

name: Philippe JUVIN
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report, which responds to the report that the European Commission publishes every year, to present the main trends relating to the EU Pilot procedure as well as infringement procedures against Member States. In particular, the 2014 report highlights that the environment, transport and the internal market for services are the areas of public policy where offences are the most numerous. The report shows a decrease in infringements over the last five years, demonstrating the quality of dialogue with Member States.

name: Barbara KAPPEL
text: Writing. I am abstaining from this report. While calls for improved channels of democratic expression of will at EU level are worthy of support, there are also sections aimed at obliging Member States to implement EU law in order to prevent misconceptions about the Union's legislative activity and EU scepticism.

name: Tunne KELAM
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report. Scrutiny and monitoring on how efficiently Member States incorporate Union law to their legislation is a cornerstone of well-functioning EU and by that closing the gaps between Member States in various aspects – economic, environmental, regional, and social and so on. I fully support the report, which points out that the EU is founded on the rule of law, and on the certainty and predictability of laws. The EU citizens must be the first to learn, in a clear, accessible, transparent and timely manner of whether and which national laws have been adopted through the transposition of EU laws, and of which national authorities are responsible for ensuring that they are correctly implemented. I welcome the efforts under the Interinstitutional Agreement regarding better law-making. Structured cooperation, better coordination and streamlining are key elements in ensuring better compliance today and in the future. The report also proposes establishing a new working group on Administrative Law that would enable the EP have a closer and more timely insight in the proceedings and provide a better basis to assess the actual situation on complying with Union law.

name: Afzal KHAN
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report, as it expresses concern about the democratic deficit of the Commission, pointing out the importance of parliamentary involvement and democratic oversight.

name: Bernd KÖLMEL
text: Writing. This report clearly shows that there are difficulties in implementing Union law in the EU. More than 3700 infringement cases submitted to the Commission speak for themselves. The problem is made even clearer by the reform proposals given to the nation states in the context of the European Semester. According to the Committee on Economic and Monetary Affairs, only 10 of the 157 main proposals have been implemented. While Members of the European Parliament make every effort to emphasise the rule of law, the EU as a whole is not credible. In the course of the so-called euro rescue policy, too many laws from the highest level are simply being violated or violations are tolerated. The statement by Juncker, who asked whether the EU would launch infringement proceedings against France, replied: "No, because it is France." Because of this double standard, I voted against the report. If, on a large scale, the EU no longer wants to establish the rule of law, it cannot work on a small scale.

name: Stelios KOULOGLOU
text: in writing. ‒ An effective application of EU law is essential given that the European Union wishes to meet the objectives set in the treaties and to enhance its credibility. The Commission monitors the application of EU law and ensures that the legislation complies with EU law. This resolution aims to review the implementation of EU law for the year 2014. I voted in favour of the resolution, since it highlights improvements but notes that the sectors of the environment, health, consumer rights, mobility and transport were the policy areas in which most infringement cases remained.

name: Béla KOVÁCS
text: Writing. – The Greek MEMBER who produced the previous report had a much better sense of democracy and was more critical of the system himself, for understandable reasons. This report cannot be accepted on the ground of European realism because it blindly relies on the Commission. His financial and economic outlook is also on the ground of repeatedly failed neoliberalism. The fact that Parliament still has very little access to information on the EU Pilot procedure and ongoing cases is severely limited. Thus, it is very difficult to assess to what extent the reduction in the number of formal infringement procedures is due to compromise solutions between the Commission and the Member States, or rather to the better compliance of EU law by The Member States.

name: Andrey KOVATCHEV
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the 32-year-old report on monitoring the application of Union law, containing important information on the current implementation and practical application of EU law.  The report shows that the environment, transport and the internal market and services are the policy areas for which the most infringement proceedings were initiated in 2014. It is also underlined that the number of formal infringement proceedings has decreased over the past five years. This reflects the effectiveness of the dialogue with Member States in the context of the EU Pilot procedure.  However, the European Parliament must have better access to information on procedures for preliminary procedures and pending files. The proposal made by the new Working Party on Administrative Law, composed of the Committee on Legal Affairs, shows that the Regulation on the Administrative Process of the European Union would be both useful and feasible.  The European Parliament can and should play a more structured role in analysing how acceding countries and countries that have concluded association agreements with the European Union comply with EU law, as well as in developing appropriate support for those countries in this regard.

name: Agnieszka KOZŁOWSKA
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 The European Commission's annual report on transposing European law into the legal order of the Member States is an important element in building a harmonised legal area in the European Union. I supported the report because it contains a clear analysis of the situation and concrete recommendations, taking into account the subsidiarity aspect. The timeliness and relevance of transposition are important for the cohesion of the internal market and are in the interest of the citizens of the European Union. Delays or other irregularities in the implementation of European law may trigger an implementation infringement procedure, which includes a support and negotiation phase, but is gradually becoming more restrictive and, in the event of evasion of implementation obligations, may result in a judgment of the European Court of Justice and financial penalties for a Member State.  In the last 5 years, the number of infringements has been reduced thanks to the EU Pilot early warning system and a number of decisions have been taken to strengthen this direction of increasing the efficiency of implementations, setting up dedicated websites with a database of initiated procedures and special forms for reporting complaints by individual companies and citizens. Access to information for all Europeans and broad consultation of the law being created in its early stages is the key to creating a law that facilitates, rather than hinders, the lives of citizens in all Member States and, as such, will be implemented more efficiently and better than less consulted ones.

name: Giovanni LA VIA
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the 2014 annual report on monitoring the application of EU law. This is how we have arrived at the 32nd Commission report, which once again provides useful information on the effective implementation of eu law practices. According to the report, it is the environment, transport, and the internal market and services sectors where there are the most infringement procedures in 2014. At the same time, however, the report shows that there has been a decrease in the number of formal infringement procedures over the last five years. None the less, the report concludes that we should take into account the new proposals made by the working group on administrative law in order to improve the application of EU law. It is also recommended that Parliament should play a more precise role when analysing the procedures for respecting the EU law of the candidate countries and those with association agreements with the Union, and that it should implement support plans for the countries involved in this area.

name: Gilles LEBRETON
text: In writing. I voted against this report because it defends measures that we are fighting, including the equal value of the treaties of the Charter of Fundamental Rights of the Union, or compliance with EU law as a political priority.

name: Constance LE GRIP
text: In writing. This initiative responds to the report that the European Commission publishes annually, under Articles 16 and 17 of the FUE Treaty, to present the main trends relating to the EU Pilot procedure and infringement procedures against Member States. In particular, the 2014 report highlights that the environment, transport and the internal market for services are the areas of public policy where infringements are still the most numerous. The JURI committee's report also s lengthyly highlighted the work done in its working group on administrative law, suggesting that a regulation on administrative procedure within institutions could contribute to a better application of EU law. For these reasons, I voted in favour of this report.

name: Philippe LOISEAU
text: In writing. The report recalls or advocates a number of points that we are opposed to, including the EU Charter of Fundamental Rights of equal value to that of the Treaties, compliance with EU law as a political priority and the suggestion of greater parliamentary involvement in the exact transposition of EU legislation in each Member State as well as for candidate countries.  The report stresses that 'Member States, when applying EU legislation, should avoid adding unnecessary constraints to EU legislation, as this leads to a misguided view of THE Union's legislative activity and promotes unjustified Euroscepticism among citizens' (sic). I therefore objected to this report.

name: Javi LÓPEZ
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report which aims to 'monitor monitoring' the Commission, from a political point of view, and the interest in ensuring that the legislation adopted in the Union actually becomes a reality applied in the Member States.  The Commission's Annual Report shows that the environment, transport and the internal market and services remain the areas where there were the highest number of infringements in 2014. According to the report, the number of formally infringing procedures has decreased thanks to the effectiveness of the informal EU Pilot Procedure. However, the report also points out that, since Parliament still has limited access to information in this procedure and to pending cases, it is difficult to assess the extent to which the reduction of formal procedural infringements reflects the true degree of compliance by the Member States.  Thanks to the Socialists, the report underlines the joint responsibility of the Commission and the Member States in the event of inappropriate or incomplete implementation of European legislation.

name: Paloma LÓPEZ BERMEJO
text: in writing. The resolution contains many positive elements, such as the reference to the Charter of Fundamental Rights of the European Union in the application of EU law or the recognition of civil society organised in the legislative process. Nevertheless, I abstained, in considering that the application of EU law is not a technical debate, but also a political debate: not in vain, it is legislation linked to the protection of social and civil rights that is systematically breached, where while its application is immediate when it undermines the interests of the people's classes.

name: Antonio LÓPEZ-ISTÚRIZ WHITE
text: in writing. This annual report presents, once again, interesting information on the effective transposition and practical application of EU law. The report concludes that compliance with EU law is not yet sufficiently transparent. In this regard, Parliament considers that the Commission should propose, provided that it is possible and proportionate, more regulations and fewer directives to ensure a level playing field between Member States as regards legislation, especially in the case of Union legislation relating to the single market, bearing in mind also that the form of the legal texts must correspond to the objectives and purposes of the proposals. As the single market is the engine of the Union, I vote in favour of this report for agreeing with the proposals it submits in this area.

name: Mairead McGUINNESS
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in support of this report that recommends a regulation on European administrative procedure.

name: Petr MACH
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted against. In essence, the report calls for the application of EU law to be transferred from the Member States to the Commission in the form of direct regulations. On the contrary, I am in support of the Member States have maximum control over the legislation that applies on their territory.

name: Ivana MALETIĆ
text: Written. ‒ The successful application of legislation is a key tool for achieving the EU's objectives. By incompletely implementing the directives, Member States can create an imbalance in the single market. While the proper implementation of legislation depends mainly on the Member States itself, some factors, such as unrealistic timings for implementation, make it prevent certain directives from being implemented in the Member States. Also, the process of implementing EUROPEAN Union legislation in the Member States is still not transparent enough, and a multitude of complaints to the Commission indicate a frequent delay in the implementation and infringement of EU directives.  Monitoring the application of EU legislation would be facilitated by more systematic reporting and by improving access to information to Parliament, Member States and EU citizens. In addition, Member States should be left with room for manoeuvre in the implementation of directives, in order to ensure timely application and avoid delayed transposition into national legislation. The European Parliament should play a greater role in overseeing the enforcement of EU law, as its participation would allow individual cases to be monitored and thereby use the already existing knowledge within its relevant committees. In order to make this possible, Parliament should be given access to information on pending cases and other issues relating to the implementation of EU law.  I supported this report, as I believe that the effective application of EU law is one of the most important factors in strengthening the credibility of the Institutions of the European Union and in achieving its objectives.

name: Andrejs MAMIKINS
text: in writing. ‒ I share the rapporteur’s position that the rising number of infringements relating to late transposition shows that prompt transposition continues to be a challenge in numerous Member States and requires an effective response by the Commission. Timely and correct transposition of EU law into national legislation and a clear domestic legislative framework should be a priority for the Member States.

name: Vladimír MAŇKA
text: Writing. \u2012 The Commission's scrutiny of the actual application of Union law has highlighted shortcomings, in particular in the fields of the environment, transport, the internal market and services. In 2008, the 'EU Pilot' project was introduced in the Union as a method to improve assistance to citizens and businesses in the application of EU law. It aims to reduce the number of infringement procedures. However, the number of proceedings cannot reflect genuine respect for and application of the law, for example because of the persistent lack of awareness of the possibilities for citizens and legal persons to lodge complaints. I agree with the proposal that the EP should establish a separate process to monitor the application of Union law, which will also use the work and knowledge of Parliament's standing committees operating in the relevant areas.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: Writing. \u2012 I am voting in favour of the report on the 2014 annual report on monitoring the application of Union law, for the reasons I mentioned in detail in my speech to the plenary of the European Parliament in Strasbourg on 6/10/2016, and because this report is complete and documented.

name: Dominique MARTIN
text: In writing. I voted against this text. The 2014 annual report of the Committee on the Control of the Application of EU Law takes stock of the infringement procedures brought against the Member States. The voted text recalls or advocates several concepts on which we oppose: equal value to the treaties of the Charter of Fundamental Rights of the Union, compliance with EU law as a political priority, etc.  The report stresses that 'Member States, when applying EU legislation, should avoid adding unnecessary constraints to EU legislation, as this leads to a misguided view of THE Union's legislative activity and promotes unjustified Euroscepticism among citizens'. We are, of course, opposed to this concept.

name: Costas MAVRIDES
text: Writing. \u2012 I am voting in favour of the report. What is undoubtedly apparent from this is that the environment, transport, the internal market and services remain policy areas where most cases of breach of treaties remain pending since 2014. The report also shows that enforcement of EU law is characterised by reduced transparency.

name: Georg MAYER
text: Writing. The report criticises the inadequate implementation of EU law by Member States and calls for the introduction of an EU administrative procedure. The European Parliament complied with this request with a resolution back in 2013, but the Commission subsequently failed to act. While the idea of a single EU procedural law is worthy of support in principle, the report goes in the wrong direction on a number of other points (such as calling on the Commission to initiate infringement proceedings against those Member States that reject a system of mandatory reception quotas for refugees). I have therefore abstained from voting.

name: Valentinas MAZURONIS
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the EP report, which discusses the Commission's report on the monitoring of the application of European Union law. The report shows that enforcement of EU law is still not sufficiently transparent and therefore the report provides guidance and measures to address these problems.

name: Jean-Luc MÉLENCHON
text: In writing. Every year, the Commission takes stock of the application of the treaties: the transposition into national law of European legislation as well as infringement procedures against recalcitrant states. The environment is the most concerned subject. France has been in the red several times for its level of fine particulate air pollution for example. The impact of German coal mines is not incriminated. Is.  The report notes that there are fewer offences, supports petitions and complaints from citizens, or denounces the setting of often unrealistic deadlines. I welcome the fact that he recalls the possibility of setting 'higher social and ecological standards in the States than at EU level'. Above all, however, it calls on the Commission to apply more 'deterrent financial sanctions' to 'credible' the Union and thus combat 'unjustified Euroscepticism among citizens'.  Thus, the Commission seeks to bring into the marble of the treaties the sanctions of the European Semester, the famous golden rules. I'm voting against it.

name: Joëlle MÉLIN
text: In writing. The report recalls or advocates a number of points that we are opposed to, including the EU Charter of Fundamental Rights of equal value to that of the Treaties, compliance with EU law as a political priority and the suggestion of greater parliamentary involvement in the exact transposition of EU legislation in each Member State as well as for candidate countries.  The report stresses that 'Member States, when applying EU legislation, should avoid adding unnecessary constraints to EU legislation, as this leads to a misguided view of THE Union's legislative activity and promotes unjustified Euroscepticism among citizens' (sic). I therefore objected to this report.

name: Nuno MELO
text: in writing. \u2012 The Commission's 32nd annual report on monitoring the application of EU law contains, once again, interesting information on the effective transposition and practical application of EU law.  The report therefore shows that the environment, transport, the internal market and services are the areas where more infringement proceedings were still pending in 2014. The annual report also points out that the number of formal infringement cases has decreased in the last five years.  We must therefore continue to work to minimise existing impacts. Hence my vote in favour.

name: Roberta METSOLA
text: in writing. ‒ I chose to support this report as it calls for the creation of a single gateway for citizens to easily access complaint forms and user-friendly information on infringement proceedings. This would bring existing access points and information sites together into a single access point, thus incentivising citizen involvement and increasing transparency.

name: Louis MICHEL
text: In writing. Under Article 17 of the Treaty on european Union, the Commission is the 'guardian of the treaties' and, under the supervision of the European Court of Justice (ECJ), ensures the proper implementation of European treaties and decisions. However, as in 2013, we see that the areas most affected by the offences are those relating to the environment, health, consumer protection, mobility and transport.
