Justice is one of the pillars of our societal model and Community law must be respected. I therefore welcome the 32nd annual report on the monitoring of the application of EU law and would like the Commission to refer the matter to the ECJ so that appeals for breaches can be brought.

name: Miroslav MIKOLÁŠIK
text: Writing. – This year's annual report on the application of EU law in individual Member States of the Union highlighted shortcomings, particularly in the fields of the environment, transport and the internal market. According to the European Commission, if there is a lack of application of European law on the territory of individual Member States, the so-called EU Pilot is activated to initiate a dialogue between the Commission and the country concerned. It has a duty to explain why the conflict occurs and to make a subsequent correction. As it is an exchange of messages between a given Member State and the Commission, it is quite difficult for the European Parliament to have a sufficient overview of how many EU 'pilots' have actually started and what is the de facto state of application of Union law. For this reason, I believe that it would be appropriate for the Commission to give the European Parliament sufficient access to transparent information, including in this context. I support the report.

name: Marlene MIZZI
text: in writing. ‒ I have voted in favour of the report, which shows that the environment, transport and the internal market and services remained the policy areas in which most infringement cases were open in 2014. According to the report the number of formal infringement procedures has decreased as a result of the effectiveness of the informal ‘EU Pilot procedure’. However, the rapporteur also points out that, given that Parliament still has only limited access to information on that procedure and on pending cases, it is difficult to evaluate to what extent the reduction in formal infringement procedures actually reflects better compliance with EU law by Member States.

name: Cláudia MONTEIRO DE AGUIAR
text: in writing. \u2012 This Commission report deals with monitoring the application of EU law and contains data on the effective transposition and practical application of EU law. According to the Commission, the number of formal infringement cases has decreased in the last five years, and this decrease reflects the effectiveness of the dialogue with Member States in the context of the EU Pilot procedure.  However, it is regrettable that the European Parliament has had limited access to information on this procedure and on ongoing procedures. I advocate extending the deadlines for the implementation of legislation to ensure the ability of Member States to comply with them. To this end, more appropriate timetables should be set up for the implementation of the regulations and directives, taking due account of the necessary periods of monitoring and consultation. The new Interinstitutional Agreement on Better Regulation contains provisions aimed at improving the implementation and implementation of EU law. It is vital to improve the transposition process and the need for Member States to identify, and notify, national measures supplementing European directives.

name: Sophie MONTEL
text: In writing. This report recalls or recommends a number of points that we are combating, including the equal value of the treaties in the EU Charter of Fundamental Rights, compliance with EU law as a political priority, the suggestion of greater parliamentary involvement in the exact transposition of EU legislation, particularly in each Member State, as well as for the candidate countries. , the link between the effective application of EU law and the strengthening of the credibility of the Union's institutions. So I have no choice but to vote against it.

name: József NAGY
text: Writing. \u2012 I am voting in favour of this report. One of the basic conditions for the proper functioning of the European Union is that all Member States are subject to the same rules. It is also very important that citizens have transparency and clarity in the EU code.

name: Victor NEGRESCU
text: in writing. ‒ In response to the request from the European Parliament and Member States, the Commission draws up an annual report regarding the monitoring of the application of EU law. I have voted in favour of this report, which states that the environment, transport and the internal market and services were the policy areas with the most infringement cases in 2014.

name: Momchil NEKOV
text: in writing. – I supported Mrs Hautala's European Parliament motion for a resolution, as I believe that the European Parliament needs to be better informed about the application of EU law in order to better fulfil its role as co-legislator and to ensure that its legislative work improves.  The establishment of a procedure within Parliament reflecting the implementation of EU legislation in individual Member States would be an appropriate way to analyse non-compliance in a specific way for each country.  While the number of proceedings in 2014 decreased, underlining the effectiveness of the EU Pilot procedure, the areas where the application of EU law remains problematic remain the environment, transport and the internal market and services.  Parliament still has limited access to information on this procedure, so it cannot realistically establish whether the reduced number of proceedings actually reflects a better application of EU law or is some kind of arrangement between defaulting countries and the Commission.  The implementation of EU law is not yet transparent enough, which is why I support the idea of drafting a regulation on the administrative process that would be useful and facilitate the practical application of EU law.

name: Dan NICA
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted for the resolution on monitoring the application of Union law: the 2014 annual report. The new Interinstitutional Agreement on Better Regulation contains provisions aimed at improving the implementation and application of EU law and encouraging more structured cooperation in this regard.  We support the call for better identification of national measures that are not strictly related to Union law (a practice called 'overregulation'). We stress the importance of stepping up transposition and the need for Member States to notify and clearly indicate national measures supplementing the provisions of Union directives. When applying EU law, Member States should avoid adding unnecessary burdens to EU law, as this leads to a misconception about EU legislative activity and increases unjustified scepticism towards the EU among citizens. We draw attention, however, to the fact that this does not in any way affect the prerogatives of the Member States to adopt, at national level, stricter social and environmental standards than those agreed at EU level.

name: Luděk NIEDERMAYER
text: Writing. \u2012 The Annual Report points to a reduction in the number of formal infringement procedures in the last five years, which the Commission says has been the result of an effective structured dialogue with Member States within the EU Pilot project. This can certainly be agreed, but with the statement that the decline in recent years and the decline expected in the coming years is also due to a steady reduction in the number of new Commission legislative proposals.  This is then responded to by an increase in the number of own-initiative reports, which are non-legislative in nature. Unfortunately, these often reach a great breadth, do not correspond to the assignment, contain inconsistent or unrealistic attitudes and, from my point of view, reduce the ep's creditability. An objection may also be raised to the Commission relating to the non-implementation of EU Pilot procedures in cases where directives have been transpositioned by agreed deadlines. The Commission should also focus more on improvements in these cases in the future.

name: Franz OBERMAYR
text: Writing. I voted against this report because it calls on Member States to add as little as possible to the implementation of EU law in the report. In my opinion, a democratic expression of will must not be ruled out.

name: Urmas PAET
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported. It is an annual report providing information on the actual implementation and practical application of EU law. The report shows that the enforcement of EU law is still not sufficiently transparent, so efforts should be made to improve the situation.

name: Maite PAGAZAURTUNDÚA
text: in writing. One of the major problems of European legislation is its relationship with the laws of the Member States. For several years now, the European Parliament has been pointing out that one of the biggest problems in implementing Community legislation is 'gold-plating', a practice which often holds back the goals that this legislation wants to achieve. In this report, and in the reports of the coming years, on the application of EU law, we will follow this path of denouncing and trying to end this practice by the Member States. On the other hand, we mention some useful instruments (such as the EU Pilot programme), but I do not think we can forget that there are still many obstacles to remove for the implementation of European legislation to be precise and effective.

name: Rolandas PAKSAS
text: Writing. – I support the report tabled.  It should be noted that it is essential that Member States properly comply with the requirements of EU law and better implement them in national policies and improve compliance and ensure that infringements are swiftly eliminated for the benefit of citizens and businesses. The environment, transport and the internal market and services still remain the areas where most infringement procedures have been initiated. Attention should be paid to the importance of structured dialogue, which should be carried out before the start of the infringement procedure.  Confidence in the EU institutions needs to be increased. Particular attention must be paid to petitions, as this is a fundamental right enshrined in the Treaty of Lisbon, and at the same time an important secondary instrument for monitoring the application of EU law and identifying possible gaps in citizens' direct expression.

name: Margot PARKER
text: in writing. ‒ The recommendation was to vote against this. The report did not go as far as we would like in identifying enough effort being demonstrated to increase transparency, but it was heading in the right direction. One of UKIP’s missions is to ensure that transparency is at the forefront of the operations of the EU institutions. Furthermore this report calls for more implementation of EU law.

name: Eva MAYDELL
text: in writing. – The annual report stresses that the number of formal infringement procedures has decreased in the last five years, which reflects the effectiveness of the dialogue with Member States in the context of the EU pilot procedure. However, since the European Parliament still has rather little access to information about the EU pilot procedure and pending cases, it is difficult to evaluate to what extent the reduction in formal infringement procedures actually reflects better compliance with EU law by Member States. For this reason I voted in favour of this report, which could provide valuable inspiration for the Commission as it shows that a regulation on the administrative procedure of the Union’s own administration would be both useful and feasible to enact.

name: Marijana PETIR
text: Written. ‒ The Commission's 32nd Annual Monitoring Report on the Application of EU Legislation provides information on the actual implementation and practical application of EU law. Most infringement cases in 2014 were in the fields of environmental, transport and internal market protection. The number of formal infringement procedures has decreased in the last five years and I see this as a good improvement in the amount of EU rules in force in the Member States. According to the European Commission, this reflects the effectiveness of the dialogue with Member States in the context of the infringement procedure (EU pilot). However, given that Parliament still has little access to information on the implementation of these procedures and pending cases, it is difficult to assess the extent to which the reduction in formal infringement procedures actually reflects better compliance with EU laws by Member States rather than compromise solutions between the Commission and the Member States.  The European Parliament could and should play a structural role in the analysis of EU law of both accession countries and countries with an association agreement with the European Union and in developing appropriate support in this regard. I supported the report because it points to real problems and I expect that during the following reports the Commission will also pay attention to the requests of the European Parliament just made.

name: Pina PICIERNO
text: in writing. \u2012 Respect for Eu ropean Union law must be a priority for the Commission, the European institutions in general and, above all, for the Member States. Making this happen as transparently as possible would increase citizens' confidence in the EU, avoiding misunderstandings and exploitations that end up fomenting unjustified Eurosceptic sentiments. The Commission has a responsibility to monitor the measures taken by the Member States and to ensure that their legislation respectses Community law. The European Parliament, on the other hand, has a responsibility to monitor the Commission's monitoring activity and the interest in ensuring that the legislation it produces is actually transposed by the Member States. The Commission's annual report on monitoring the application of Eu ropean Union law reports that the number of formal infringement procedures has decreased over the last five years, thanks to the effectiveness of the structured dialogue between the Commission and the Member States under 'EU Pilot'. While the EU Pilot system has proved its worth, it is not transparent enough. I therefore share the report's regret that, despite repeated requests, the Commission has not yet ensured adequate access to information on the EU Pilot procedure and on cases pending before the relevant parliamentary committees.

name: Tonino PICULA
text: Written. ‒ The main responsibility for the correct implementation and application of EU law lies with the Member States, but this does not deprive the EU institutions of their duty to respect EU primary law in the development of secondary EU law. EU Pilot aims to make cooperation between the Commission and Member States closer to correct breaches of EU law at an early stage, avoid the need to initiate formal infringement proceedings. Unrealistic deadlines for the implementation of legislation may result in Member States being unable to meet them, thereby withering the postponement of applications – more realistic deadlines are needed for the application of regulations and directives.  In my view, fines for non-compliance with EU law should be effective, proportionate and dissuasive and should take into account repeated non-compliance with the law and respect the legal rights of the Member States. Unsatisfactory application and implementation play an important role in a number of European crises and create an uneven playing field in the single market. Parliament should make an additional contribution by sharing its expertise on the legislative process with national parliaments.  It could also, in response to the Commission's annual progress reports, draw up its own reports, not just resolutions, and help to review the implementation of legislation by supervising the Commission.

name: João PIMENTA LOPES
text: in writing. – The document reflects the usual "assessment" of the application of European Union law by the European institutions. A hymn to interference, which does not cease to reveal the duality with regard to compliance with the "rules" depending on the countries.  The major powers will serve well the so-called closer cooperation and a more structured dialogue with the Commission, which the report values, which in practice will be nothing more than a procedure in which they escape the rules they impose, and which they use to ensure the centralisation of power and control small and medium-sized countries, coerced under the cunning and unacceptable process of blackmail and threat of sanctions , such as those to which Portugal has been subject. Financial sanctions which, moreover, the text sanctions, requiring its application effectively and in a deterrent manner. A fiscal and penalising view which is an attack on the sovereignty of the Member States and which we reject head-on. In addition, pressure and interference on MSs in defining what their priorities and legislative framework should be, with the Better Regulation Institutional Agreement, the instrument for harmonising the legal and legislative framework, or the proposal to create a European administrative law. Reasons that could only justify voting against.

name: Salvatore Domenico POGLIESE
text: in writing. \u2012 The European Commission, in the proper performance of its functions, is called upon to play an active role in the development of various instruments aimed at improving the implementation, application and respect of Union law in the Member States. To this end, in a Union based on the rule of law and the certainty and predictability of laws, EU citizens must be able to know in a clear, accessible, transparent and timely manner whether and which national rules have been adopted through the transposition of EU law and which national authorities are responsible for their proper implementation. It is therefore considered appropriate to make effective financial penalties for non-compliance with Community law. The rapporteur believes that the proposals made by the new working group on administrative law, set up by the Committee on Legal Affairs, could be a valuable source of inspiration for the Commission. I think it should be emphasised that the European Parliament should play a more structured role in the analysis of how the candidate countries, and the countries with association agreements with the European Union, respect EU law. I voted in favour of approving this annual report.

name: Franck PROUST
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report, which refers to the European Commission's annual publication on the application of EU law within the Member States. Unfortunately, the areas related to the internal market or the transport and environment sectors are the areas of public action where infringements are the most important. For EU-wide policies to be consistent and effective, they must be implemented and respected in all European territories.

name: Julia REID
text: in writing. ‒ The recommendation was to vote against this.  The report did not go as far as we would like in identifying enough effort being demonstrated to increase transparency, but it was heading in the right direction.  One of UKIP’s missions is to ensure that transparency is at the forefront of the operations of the EU institutions. Furthermore this report calls for more implementation of EU law.

name: Sofia RIBEIRO
text: in writing. \u2012 The annual report shows that the environment, transport, the internal market and services are the areas where more infringement proceedings remain pending in 2014. Given that the European Parliament still has relatively little access to information on the EU Pilot procedure – a dialogue with Member States – and on ongoing procedures, it is difficult to assess to what extent the reduction of formal infringement procedures better reflects in practice member states' compliance with EU law than consensus solutions between the Commission and the Member States.  As can be seen, the application of Community law is still not sufficiently transparent. The rapporteur therefore considers that a regulation on the administrative procedure of the Union administration could be useful and easy to promulgate.  It also considers that Parliament could and should play a more structured role in analysing how candidate countries and countries that have concluded association agreements with the European Union comply with EU law, as well as in developing adequate support in this area for those countries. In view of the foregoing, I voted in favour of this report.

name: Liliana RODRIGUES
text: in writing. \u2012 This report shows that the environment, transport, the internal market and services are the areas where more infringement proceedings were still pending in 2014.  It also points out that the number of formal infringement proceedings has decreased in the last five years. According to the Commission, this decrease reflects the effectiveness of the dialogue with Member States in the context of the EU Pilot procedure.  However, the European Parliament still has relatively little access to information on this procedure and on ongoing procedures.  One conclusion that can be drawn from the report is that the application of Community law is still not sufficiently transparent. Parliament could and should play a more structured role in analysing how candidate countries and countries that have concluded association agreements with the EU comply with EU law, as well as in developing adequate support in this area for those countries.

name: Inma RODRÍGUEZ-PIÑERO
text: in writing. In accordance with Article 17 OF THET, the Commission monitors the actions of the Member States and ensures that their legislation complies with European law. Articles 258 to 260 TFEU authorise the Commission to bring actions against an offending Member State. The European Parliament, in turn, 'monitors monitoring' the Commission and must ensure that the legislation adopted in the EU effectively becomes an applied reality in the Member States.  This Annual Report on the Implementation of EU Law shows that the environment, transport, internal market and services remain the areas where the greatest number of infringements occur. The number of procedures has decreased thanks to the effectiveness of the EU Pilot Procedure. However, since Parliament has limited access to information on this procedure and pending cases, it is difficult to assess the extent to which the reduction of formal infringements reflects the true degree of compliance by the Member States.  I voted in favour of this report.

name: Claude ROLIN
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this motion for a resolution on the monitoring of the application of EU law (annual report of 2014). It contains important information on the actual transposition and practical application of EU law. In particular, the resolution stresses that the European Parliament has little access to information on formal infringement procedures. This text contains a series of recommendations and proposals aimed at addressing these shortcomings.

name: Bronis ROPĖ
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report, which discusses the annual report on the monitoring of the application of Union law in 2014. The report shows that the environment, transport and the internal market and services were the policy areas where the largest number of infringement procedures were initiated in 2014. It should be stressed that the European Parliament still has limited access to information on the EU Pilot procedure and the incomplete examination of infringements – all the more so because a significant number of infringements are not visible – after a Member State has found a compromise with the Commission.  Thus, the report concludes that enforcement of EU law is still not sufficiently transparent.

name: Fernando RUAS
text: in writing. \u2012 This is the 32nd Annual Report produced by the Commission on the monitoring of the application of EU law.  The report shows that sectors such as the environment, transport, the internal market and services are the ones with the most pending infringement proceedings, despite the increase in procedural volume in the last five years. This may be due to the effectiveness of the EU Pilot procedure – an informal pre-litigation phase – although there is some difficulty in confirming whether its use has an effective impact on greater and better compliance with EU law by Member States.  This means that there is still a lack of transparency in the application of Community law and, to that extent, I endorse the proposed solution within the JURI Committee to create a regulation on the administrative process of the Union administration as a means of promoting a better and more effective transposition and practical application of European law. Because I agree with the content of the report, I voted in favour.

name: Tokia SAÏFI
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report, which takes stock of the 2014 review of the application of EU law. This text underlines the essential role that the European Commission plays in monitoring the application of EU law, while recalling the crucial role of the European Parliament, which exercises political oversight over the Commission's enforcement measures. The report points out that the application of EU law is not transparent enough and that the environment, transport and the internal market for services are the areas of public policy where infringements are still the most numerous.

name: Massimiliano SALINI
text: in writing. \u2012 The text voted on is the thirty-second annual report (for 2014) that the European Parliament draws up after carrying out specific checks on the application of European law among the 28 Member States. The analysis carried out shows that the sectors in which serious gaps persist are those of the environment, transport of the internal market and services. At the same time, however, infringement procedures have decreased, which shows that the European Commission's decision to follow the line of dialogue before sanctions is working.

name: Lola SÁNCHEZ CALDENTEY
text: in writing. U2012 I am voting in favour of this resolution because it contains very positive elements. The resolution calls for strengthening EU law for the protection of consumer rights, and in health, environment, mobility and transport. There are many cases of infringements initiated by the Commission that are still open, so this report calls for Parliament to be able to adequately access this information to make the processes more transparent.

name: Sven SCHULZE
text: Writing. I voted in favour of the Commission's 32nd Annual Report on the Control and Application of EU Law.  In this report, the EP reviews the actual implementation and practical application of EU directives.

name: Olga SEHNALOVÁ
text: Writing. \u2012 The Commission's 2014 Annual Report on Monitoring the Application of Union Law shows that the most infringement cases have been repeatedly opened in the areas of environmental, transport and internal market policies and services, including consumer protection. A fair internal market, including consumer protection policy, cannot be built without timely and correct transposition of EU legislation, a clear legal framework, as well as oversight of compliance. The Commission's report highlights that the number of formal infringement procedures has decreased in the last five years, and this reduction is the result of an effective dialogue with Member States within the framework of the so-called EU Pilot. However, the JURI report notes that enforcement of EU law is not yet sufficiently transparent and asks whether the declared reduction actually corresponds to better compliance by Member States with EU law.   I therefore support the idea of ing a procedure within parliament's relevant committees to monitor the application of EU law in the Member States, which would be able to analyse the issue of non-compliance in a factual way, but also to pass this knowledge on to national parliaments. From this point of view, I welcome the commission's call for information sharing also in the context of the informal EU Pilot procedure.

name: Maria Lidia SENRA RODRÍGUEZ
text: in writing. The resolution contains many positive elements, such as the reference to the Charter of Fundamental Rights of the European Union in the application of EU law or the recognition of civil society organised in the legislative process. Nevertheless, I abstained, in considering that the application of EU law is not a technical debate, but also a political debate: not in vain, it is legislation linked to the protection of social and civil rights that is systematically breached, where while its application is immediate when it undermines the interests of the people's classes.

name: Siôn SIMON
text: in writing. ‒ Today, I voted in favour of the 2014 Annual Report on monitoring the application of EU law. The report expresses concern about the democratic deficit of the Commission and stresses the importance of parliamentary involvement and democratic oversight. It also calls for better oversight of the Commission’s infringement and pre-infringement procedures.

name: Branislav ŠKRIPEK
text: in writing. ‒ This annual report concerns infringement cases in the EU in the areas of the environment, transport, the single market and services.  I was not able to support this report as it contained many measures which would reduce Slovak national sovereignty and impair our competitiveness, so I abstained in the final vote.

name: Davor ŠKRLEC
text: Written. The 2014 Annual Report contains interesting information on the implementation and actual application of legislation and the importance of the role of CITIZENS of the European Union in the overall process.  The report can read the reduction of human rights violations, but also stresses that violations of them remain, not primarily in the case of minorities' rights, persons with disabilities, foreign nationals, transport rights, education and healthcare. One of the most effective sources of pointing out this problem is certainly individual complaints from citizens. Accordingly, there must be a legal obligation for CITIZENS of the European Union to be informed in a clear and accessible manner about which national legal standards have been adopted in EU law. It is also proposed to draw up its own reports by Parliament, not just resolutions to allow all committees concerned to express relevant opinions and to monitor how Member States comply with EU law.   The conclusion drawn from this report points to still a lack of transparency, therefore, as the European Union is based on the rule of law, legal certainty and predictability of the law, it is essential to strengthen its credibility and meet citizens' expectations of the benefits they can have as citizens of the European Union.

name: Monika SMOLKOVÁ
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported the EP motion for a resolution on monitoring the application of Union law – the 2014 annual report. The report states that the environment, transport and the internal market and services remained policy areas where the most infringement cases were opened in 2014. The report therefore shows that the enforcement of Union law is not sufficiently transparent. The correct implementation and application of Union law are primarily the responsibility of the Member States, which must fully respect the fundamental values and principles enshrined in the Treaties and the EU Charter of Fundamental Rights when implementing Union law. Only timely and correct transposition of Union law into national law and a clear national legal framework should become a priority for Member States in order to prevent infringements of Union law, while at the same time bringing the necessary benefits to individuals and businesses through the effective and effective application of Union law. Social partners and civil society organisations have an important role to play in monitoring and reporting shortcomings in the transposition and application of Union law by Member States.

name: Igor ŠOLTES
text: Writing. -u2012 European Union law is of paramount importance for the very functioning of this common union of States. It is therefore important that its implementation and application be monitored. The 2014 Annual Report on monitoring the application of Union law states that enforcement of EU law is still not sufficiently transparent and open. It calls for respect for the principle of legal clarity, transparency and openness and for the correct and timely application of EU law. Although the enforcement of EU law is one of the priorities of the current European Commission, this objective is far from achieved. I believe that the Commission should be more active in this area, but at the same time the European Parliament could also play a greater role in its analysis on the enforcement of EU law. Finally, members who joined the EU and members who are yet to become members should also provide wider support to the EU itself in implementing and enforcing EU law. I support the efforts to improve in this area, which is why I supported the report.

name: Joachim STARBATTY
text: Writing. This report clearly shows that there are difficulties in implementing Union law in the EU. More than 3700 infringement cases submitted to the Commission speak for themselves. The problem is made even clearer by the reform proposals submitted to the nation states in the context of the European Semester. According to the Committee on Economic and Monetary Affairs, only 10 of the 157 main proposals have been implemented. While Members of the European Parliament make every effort to emphasise the rule of law, the EU as a whole is not credible. In the course of the so-called euro rescue policy, too many laws from the highest level are simply being violated or violations are tolerated. The statement by Juncker, who asked whether the EU would launch infringement proceedings against France, replied: "No, because it is France." Because of this double standard, I voted against the report. If, on a large scale, the EU no longer wants to establish the rule of law, it cannot work on a small scale.

name: Ivan ŠTEFANEC
text: Writing. \u2012 When implementing European legislation into the legal system of the Member States, we are still encountering the problem of lengthy mechanisms. We need to unify, speed up and make these processes more transparent. As the only European institution elected directly by citizens, the European Parliament must also play a more active role in the political oversight of the European Commission's actions.

name: Helga STEVENS
text: Written. The N-VA abstained in the vote on this report. N-VA, for example, had wanted to see a clearer rejection of 'goldplating', also regretted that any scepticism towards the EU was dismissed as 'unjustified', and believes that referendums are not blissful. The biggest stumbling block in this report, however, is what it does not write or even conceal. A reference to the principle of subsidiarity and proportionality should not have been missing from this report (but was deliberately avoided during the negotiations). The same applies to the demand for better implementation of the Services Directive. Furthermore, N-VA wishes to stress that the EU must also respect its own rules. This seems obvious, but is not always the case. Consider, for example, the Dublin rules which determine which Member State is responsible for applying for asylum, but where the Commission appears to be turning a blind eye. Another example is the treaty-law-enshrined no-bailout rule, which has also been flossed by the EU on several occasions.

name: Dubravka ŠUICA
text: Written. One of the Commission's competences also includes oversight of the application of EU law. Accordingly, it is authorised to take action against Member States in breach of treaty obligations. Due to a more efficient exercise of supervision, the EU Pilot procedure is envisaged, which aims to reduce the initiation of formal infringement procedures through cooperation between the Commission and the Member State.  The Commission's 32nd annual report on monitoring the application of law shows a decrease in the number of official procedures attributed by the Commission to previous cooperation with Member States. However, due to Parliament's incomplete insight into the EU Pilot procedure, it cannot be assessed whether this is less likely to breach its obligations due to cooperation with Member States or member states. The Commission and Parliament have an obligation to cooperate with each other. A process should be developed to allow for better cooperation between the two institutions, with a way of achieving oversight of the application of EU legislation. For this reason, I support the monitoring report on the application of Union legislation: the annual report for 2014.

name: Neoklis SYLIKIOTIS
text: Writing. \u2012 We voted in favour of the report because it contains good assessments of the transposition and practical application of EU law. As stated in it, the environment, health, transport, the internal market and services continue to be the policy areas where most cases of treaty infringement remained pending in 2014. Bearing in mind that Parliament still has limited access to information on the EU Pilot procedure as well as to pending cases, it cannot be easily assessed to what extent the reduction in official infringement procedures actually reflects Member States' compliance with Union law rather than compromises between the Commission and Member States that violate Union law. The report therefore shows that the enforcement of Union law continues to be characterised by reduced transparency.

name: Eleftherios SYNADINOS
text: Writing. \u2012 In an artful way, the EU and its legislators have introduced laws and rules that also remove a nation's last right to sovereignty. These are laws which cannot have the same force in the states of Europe, since the situations are different.

name: Tibor SZANYI
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported the adoption of this report because it gives an accurate picture and makes remarkable findings and suggestions on the experience of implementing EU law two years ago. It points to the Commission's key role in the audit, but also recalls that the ultimate responsibility for implementing EU law lies with the Member States. I was pleased to see in the report that the situation in this respect improved somewhat in 2014, in particular in the light of the decrease in the number of infringement procedures. I also agree with the specific proposal that, in future, in the case of associated and candidate countries, the Commission will examine compliance with EU law more rigorously in a similar way to that of the Member States. As a Hungarian MEP, I also considered it particularly appropriate to consider this report in order to draw appropriate future lessons from the recent fact that the Government of the EU Member State has recently launched Hungary direct, provocative challenge to the EU's legal order, principles and practices in relation to an important EU policy or Community decision (migration regulation): in a referendum campaign, it called on its people to reject the primacy of Community law and to demand that national decision-making be exercised. On this basis, in the future I will be more of a representative of my view that European law needs urgent protection, and that such a legal-political effort must be nipped in the bud before it has a disruptive effect on EU law.

name: Adam SZEJNFELD
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 In 2014, the European Commission received almost 4 000 complaints of alleged breaches of European Union law by taking action on a quarter of them. This means that many countries still do not fulfil their Treaty obligations and either do not implement European Union legislation or implement it incorrectly. Timely and correct transposition of Community legislation into national legislation and a clear national legislative framework should be a priority for Member States in order to strengthen citizens' confidence in the legal system. Unfortunately, it is also the fault of the EU institutions for breaches of EU law, which often introduce unrealistic deadlines for the implementation of legislation, leading to member states not being able to comply with them. Furthermore, the European Commission, as indicated in the document, should monitor effectively and in a timely way how EU law is applied and implemented at an early stage.

name: Claudia ȚAPARDEL
text: in writing. ‒ The Commission’s 32nd ‘Annual Report on Monitoring the Application of EU Law’ shows that the number of formal infringement procedures has decreased in the last five years, although environment, transport and internal market and services remained the policy areas in which most infringement cases were open in 2014. According to the Commission, the decrease in infringement procedures reflects the effectiveness of their dialogue with Member States. However, the European Parliament has little access to this type of information, and it is difficult for us to evaluate to what extent this reduction is due to a more effective dialogue with Member States. Consequently, I support this report as I strongly believe that the European Parliament could play a more prominent role in the analysis of how accession countries comply with EU law. Furthermore, I agree with the rapporteur`s conclusion that the enforcement of EU law is still not sufficiently transparent and I believe that measures should be taken to increase transparency.

name: Marc TARABELLA
text: In writing. We have decided to follow the rapporteur on this issue. The Commission's 32nd annual report on the monitoring of the application of EU law contains, as usual, interesting information on the actual transposition and practical application of European law. The report thus shows that the environment, transport, the internal market and services are the areas where the most infringement cases remained pending in 2014.  However, bearing in mind that Parliament still has little access to information on this procedure and on the current cases, it seems difficult to assess the extent to which the reduction in infringement procedures is really a sign of better compliance of Member States with EU law, rather than compromise solutions between the Commission and the offending States.  We are convinced that the European Parliament could and should itself play a more structured role in analysing how candidate countries comply with EU law, as well as in developing appropriate support for these countries on this issue.

name: Pavel TELIČKA
text: in writing. ‒ European Union law is a system of rules operating within the Member States of the European Union. EU law, which has equal force with national law, confers rights and obligations on the authorities in each member country, as well as individuals and businesses. The Commission’s 32nd Annual Report on Monitoring the Application of EU Law contains interesting information on the implementation and practical application of EU law. The report on the application of Union law, a pilot procedure aimed at increasing effectiveness in the application of Union law, expresses doubt that the enforcement of EU law is sufficiently transparent. I voted in favour of the proposed amendments, which would see the European Parliament play a more structured role in the analysis of how both countries in the EU and accession countries comply with EU law and aid in developing appropriate support in this respect for those countries.

name: Ruža TOMAŠIĆ
text: Written. ‒ This report on its own initiative to monitor the application of EUROPEAN Union legislation for 2014 underlines that the number of cases where legislation has been breached has declined.  As Parliament has only limited information regarding this procedure, it is difficult to assess the reasons for the fall in infringements, and it is particularly difficult to assess whether this is generally due to better coherence between national legislative systems and those of the European Union. I certainly believe that, in general, one of the fundamental reasons for the infringement lies in the unrealistically set implementation deadlines imposed on individual Member States of the Union. Member States should certainly be given more time to examine and consult. While I support the parts of the report that call on the Commission to take this into account, I voted with restraint, as the report unfortunately does not incorporate amendments calling for compliance with the principle of subsidiarity and proportionality in the application of Union legislation.

name: Romana TOMC
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported the proposal on monitoring the application of Union law - Annual report 2014. The Commission's 32th Annual Report on Monitoring the Application of EU Law shows that the areas of environment, transport and the internal market and services are the ones where infringement procedures were the most open in 2014. It also points out that the number of formal infringement procedures has decreased over the last five years. Parliament still has quite limited access to information on procedures and open matters in the EU Pilot system. The report therefore concludes that the enforcement of EU law is still not sufficiently transparent.

name: Estefanía TORRES MARTÍNEZ
text: in writing. U2012 I am voting in favour of this resolution because it contains very positive elements. The resolution calls for strengthening EU law for the protection of consumer rights, and in health, environment, mobility and transport. There are many cases of infringements initiated by the Commission that are still open, so this report calls for Parliament to be able to adequately access this information to make the processes more transparent.

name: Ulrike TREBESIUS
text: Writing. This report clearly shows that there are difficulties in implementing Union law in the EU. More than 3700 infringement cases submitted to the Commission speak for themselves. The problem is made even clearer by the reform proposals submitted to the nation states in the context of the European Semester. According to the Committee on Economic and Monetary Affairs, only 10 of the 157 main proposals have been implemented. While Members of the European Parliament make every effort to emphasise the rule of law, the EU as a whole is not credible. In the course of the so-called euro rescue policy, too many laws from the highest level are simply being violated or violations are tolerated. The statement by Juncker, who asked whether the EU would launch infringement proceedings against France, replied: "No, because it is France." Because of this double standard, I voted against the report. If, on a large scale, the EU no longer wants to establish the rule of law, it cannot work on a small scale.

name: Mylène TROSZCZYNSKI
text: In writing. The Commission's 2014 annual report on the monitoring of the application of EU law takes stock of the infringement procedures brought against Member States for delaying the transposition or mistrans transposition of EU directives by the Commission, under its mission as a 'treaty guardian'. The most problematic areas were health, the environment, consumer protection and transport. In 2014, the EU Court of Justice issued 38 judgments to the detriment of the Member States. It imposed the payment of penalties on Italy, Greece, Portugal, Spain and Sweden. This report recalls or recommends a number of points that we are fighting, including the equal value of the treaties in the Union's Charter of Fundamental Rights, compliance with EU law as a political priority, the suggestion of greater parliamentary involvement in the exact transposition of EU legislation, particularly in each Member State and for the candidate countries. I am voting against this text.

name: Kazimierz Michał UJAZDOWSKI
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 The report notes a decrease in the number of infringement proceedings against Member States. The European Parliament does not have full information on this procedure and outstanding cases. I believe that more committees should be involved in matters relating to the application of the law in order to improve scrutiny.  Given the limited knowledge of MePs in this procedure, it is difficult to assess whether the lower number of infringement procedures reflects better compliance with EU law by Member States. However, I certainly support the aim of setting realistic deadlines for transposing EU legislation into national systems. Member States should have the necessary time to carry out checks and consultations before implementing the Directives. On the other hand, the principles of subsidiarity and proportionality must be respected in the application of EU law. These amendments were rejected during the work on the report. In my opinion, the problem of the impact of EU law on competitiveness has also not been duly address. For these reasons, I abstained.

name: Miguel URBÁN CRESPO
text: in writing. U2012 I am voting in favour of this resolution because it contains very positive elements. The resolution calls for strengthening EU law for the protection of consumer rights, and in health, environment, mobility and transport. There are many cases of infringements initiated by the Commission that are still open, so this report calls for Parliament to be able to adequately access this information to make the processes more transparent.

name: Ernest URTASUN
text: in writing. – I voted in favour of this report because the report concludes that the enforcement of EU law is still not sufficiently transparent and open and that the discretionary power conferred by the Treaty upon the Commission in dealing with infringement procedures must respect the rule of law, the principle of legal clarity and the requirements of transparency and openness and that nothing must jeopardise the basic purpose of that power, which is to guarantee the timely and correct application of Union law. Absolute discretion coupled with an absolute lack of transparency is fundamentally contrary to the rule of law. The enforcement of EU law is proclaimed as a priority by this Commission, but it is far from being achieved.

name: Viktor USPASKICH
text: Writing. – I believe that financial sanctions for non-compliance with EU law should be effective, proportionate and dissuasive, taking into account repeated cases of non-compliance in the same area and the respect of the rights of The Member States enshrined in the legislation.

name: Ivo VAJGL
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report on monitoring the application of Union law: 2014 Annual Report. The Commission’s 32nd Annual Report on Monitoring the Application of EU Law shows that environment, transport and internal market and services remained the policy areas in which most infringement cases were open in 2014. The Annual report also stresses that the number of formal infringement procedures has decreased in the last five years. I voted in favour because I believe that the European Parliament should play a more structured role in the analysis of how accession countries and countries with association agreements with the European Union comply with EU law and in developing appropriate support in this respect to those countries.

name: Ramón Luis VALCÁRCEL SISO
text: in writing. The new Working Group on Administrative Law established within the framework of the European Parliament's Committee on Legal Affairs has drawn up proposals which, as advocated in this report, can serve as valuable inspiration to the Commission in monitoring the application of Community legislation in the different countries of the Union. The report notes, on the basis of the conclusions drawn from the 32nd Annual Report on the Control of the Implementation of EU Law drawn up by the Commission, that an initiative to regulate the administration of the Union's own administrative procedures would be both useful and feasible for their enactment. I have cast an affirmative vote with the desire to give the European Parliament (the only Community institution directly elected by citizens through its vote) greater access to the infringement procedures which the Commission opens up against the Member States, with the aim of assessing the extent to which better compliance with the acquis communautaire is being made by the 28 or whether , on the contrary, agreements are being reached with them once the rule has been violated.

name: Ángela VALLINA
text: in writing. The resolution contains many positive elements, such as the reference to the Charter of Fundamental Rights of the European Union in the application of EU law or the recognition of civil society organised in the legislative process. Nevertheless, I abstained, in considering that the application of EU law is not a technical debate, but also a political debate: not in vain, it is legislation linked to the protection of social and civil rights that is systematically breached, where while its application is immediate when it undermines the interests of the people's classes.

name: Hilde VAUTMANS
text: Written. \u2012 Every year, the European Parliament draws up a report on the control of the application of European law. It cites the pain points and highlights the Commission's possible improvements. I voted in favour of this report because it explicitly calls for all applications of European law to be better followed in all Member States and also in the candidate countries so that European law is applied equally everywhere.

name: Miguel VIEGAS
text: in writing. \u2012 This annual report monitors the application of EU law by the European institutions. It is the Responsibility of the Commission, as guardian of the Treaties, Article 17 TUE, to supervise whether or not States apply treaties and Union law.  We do not recognize financial sanctions against states. See what's happening now with Portugal. We are against the Commission's supervisory role and the discriminatory nature in which it makes its assessments of what community law is or is not properly enapply. That they never cease to be political evaluations, as is well seen.

name: Harald VILIMSKY
text: Writing. The report criticises the inadequate implementation of EU law by Member States and calls for the introduction of an EU administrative procedure. The European Parliament complied with this request with a resolution back in 2013, but the Commission subsequently failed to act. While the idea of a single EU procedural law is worthy of support in principle, the report goes in the wrong direction on a number of other points (such as calling on the Commission to initiate infringement proceedings against those Member States that reject a system of mandatory reception quotas for refugees). I have therefore abstained from voting.

name: Daniele VIOTTI
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the 2014 annual report on monitoring the application of Eu ropean Union law. The report indicates that the environment, transport, the internal market and services remain the three areas in which the most infringement proceedings were opened in 2014, despite the fact that the number of cases has decreased over the past five years. In the Commission's view, this decrease is due to a more effective dialogue with Member States in the context of the EU Pilot procedure, but the report stresses that Parliament still has limited access to information on this procedure and pending cases. It is therefore difficult to understand whether the reduction in the number of formal procedures really reflects greater compliance with EU law by Member States and not an increase in compromise solutions between the Commission and non-compliant countries. The aim of this report is therefore to ensure greater transparency in the application of EU law by Member States.

name: Tomáš ZDECHOVSKÝ
text: Writing. \u2012 I support with my vote this 32nd Annual Report of the Commission on monitoring the application of EU law. In my opinion, the report contains a lot of interesting and inspiring information on the current state of compliance with European legislation. For example, it is pointed out that the environment, transport and the internal market and services remained the sectors where the most infringement cases were opened in 2014. On the other hand, it is interesting to see that the total number of formal infringements of the Treaty has been steadily decreasing over the last five years. Nevertheless, I stress that the Commission must continue to play an active role in monitoring respect for the law and develop tools to help better implement European legislation at national level. Parliament's role, on the other hand, should be primarily political oversight of the Commission's law enforcement activities. Personally, I therefore consider the proposals on administrative procedure put forward by the working group set up by the Committee on Legal Affairs to be particularly beneficial in the report, because I think they can inspire the Commission for the future.

name: Jana ŽITŇANSKÁ
text: Writing. \u2012 The 2014 Annual Report concerns the monitoring of the application of Union law. It contains, in particular, statistics relating to cases of infringement of Union law. The report notes that the number of these infringement complaints has fallen, while also proposing a possible solution to the persistent number of complaints concerning the environment, transport or the single market, which could be a longer implementation period. According to the report, it is unrealistic time limits for the implementation of legislation that may give the Member States the cause of the infringement. The report also deals with the benefits of the Interinstitutional Agreement on Better Law-Making and condemns the practice of so-called 'redelacation'. On the other hand, however, the report also intervened in areas such as calls on the Commission to submit a legislative proposal on European administrative procedural law. Although I do not share these challenges, I have decided to support the report as a whole.

name: Milan ZVER
text: Writing. In the European Union, based on the rule of law and legal certainty and predictability, monitoring the application of EU law in the Member States is essential for the credibility of the institutions and citizens' confidence in the effective functioning of the EU. The report on monitoring the application of Union law rightly calls on the Commission to better draft legislation, to set more realistic deadlines for transposition and enforcement of legislation in the Member States and to effectively control the timely and correct transposition of EU law into national law, which is why I supported it.

name: Isabella ADINOLFI
text: in writing. \u2012 The Commission has asked EFSA to assess whether new evidence has emerged that would change the conclusions and recommendations of EFSA's scientific advice on the cultivation of genetically modified Bt11 maize. This resolution, considered that EFSA's cultivation risk assessment is incomplete and that the risk management recommendations proposed by the Commission are inadequate, calls on EFSA to withdraw the draft implementing decision. I voted in favour.

name: Tim AKER
text: in writing. – We in UKIP are concerned about the safety of GMOs for health and the environment, but we would prefer our national Parliament to legislate on this delicate issue rather than the European Parliament.

name: Marina ALBIOL GUZMÁN
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this objection to the marketing of seeds of Bt11 genetically modified maize (tolerant to toxic herbicide ammonium glufosinate), because I am totally against genetically modified organisms and, therefore, new authorisations thereof. Moreover, it is clear that the current procedure for the authorisation of genetically modified food and feed is not working properly. That is why I am in favour of this and any objections raised in relation to the authorisation of GMOs, and I voted accordingly.

name: Martina ANDERSON
text: in writing. – I voted in favour of this GMO authorisation objection. It is absurd that the European Commission continues to propose authorisations of GMOs under a system which they themselves have admitted is flawed. It is essential that Mr Juncker listens to the European Parliament’s call for a new proposal and that the EU GMO authorisation procedure is overhauled completely.

name: Eric ANDRIEU
text: In writing. We oppose the authorisation to grow this transgenic maize. BT11 corn is tolerant to the herbicide glufosinate-ammonium. Moreover, it should be remembered once again that the rules on the authorisation of GMOs are not democratic, according to Jean-Claude Juncker's own admissions. And that as such it is up to Parliament to play its part in promoting transparency and democracy. No new proposals for rules on the importation of GMOs appear to be proposed by the Commission.  It should be remembered that a majority of Parliament voted on an amendment asking the Commission to review its copy of the GMO marketing process. Our objective therefore remains the same: no genetically modified food will be validated by the European Parliament in committee until the Commission has proposed a new framework for the importation of GMOs in order to take into account the majority fact in Europe.  It is a question of democracy and also a way of enforcing the choices of the European Parliament in the institutional game.

name: Laima Liucija ANDRIKIENĖ
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the motion for a resolution on the draft Commission implementing decision concerning the placing on the market for cultivation of genetically modified maize Bt11 seeds. Pursuant to Directive 2001/18/EC, the cultivation of genetically modified maize Bt11 is prohibited in states of the European Union such as Bulgaria, Denmark, Greece, France, Croatia, Italy, Cyprus, Latvia, Lithuania, etc. The draft Commission implementing decision is not consistent with Union law as it is not compatible with the objective of Directive 2001/18/EC, which is to approximate the laws, regulations and administrative provisions of the Member States and to protect human health and the environment when carrying out the deliberate release into the environment of genetically modified organisms for any other purposes than placing on the market within the Community and placing on the market genetically modified organisms as or in products within the Community. Having in mind also that the risk management recommendations proposed by the Commission are inadequate, I supported resolution’s call on the Commission to withdraw its draft implementing decision.

name: Nikos ANDROULAKIS
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the objection under Rule 106 of the Rules of Procedure concerning the placing on the market of genetically modified maize seed in the Bt11 series, because the assessment of the risks of cultivation was incomplete and the risk management recommendations proposed by the Commission were inadequate.

name: Marie-Christine ARNAUTU
text: In writing. Five objections are made by Parliament on permits to grow or import GMOs for maize or wheat.  Despite systematic objections, the Commission continues to issue permits for cultivation or import of GMOs. Parliament persists in objecting, to no avail, since the Commission does not take this into account. These objections help to unmask the hypocrisy of the majority parliamentarians (who maintain the Commission) in the face of EU totalitarianism. So I voted for these new objections.

name: Jonathan ARNOTT
text: in writing. ‒ Given that I have no specialist knowledge of the seeds concerned, and having concerns about the use of delegated acts, I felt it appropriate to follow the advice of officials and abstain on this matter.

name: Jean ARTHUIS
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this objection to prohibiting the importation and marketing of herbicide-resistant maize. Its use could have adverse effects on users and consumers.

name: Zoltán BALCZÓ
text: Writing. \u2012 The objections are due to the fact that the Commission has submitted, for the five GMO maize and cotton crops in question, a draft implementing act in which it does not impose restrictions on the marketing and use of these GMOs. Parliament and the ENVI Committee believe that the Commission has exceeded its powers by these acts and would authorise the import and marketing of these products in the European Union, without taking into account the precautionary principle. Unfortunately, the Impact Assessments of the European Food Safety Authority do not contain sufficient data and information on the harmless nature of these plants to human health. I supported the adoption of the proposals in order for the European Commission to withdraw its draft authorisations.

name: Gerard BATTEN
text: in writing. ‒ We in UKIP are concerned about the safety of GMOs for health and the environment, but we would prefer our national Parliament to legislate on this delicate issue rather than the European Parliament.

name: Nicolas BAY
text: In writing. Five objections are presented by Parliament on permits for cultivation or imports of GMOs with different properties. The herbicide-tolerant GMO or two that will soon be banned is of little interest and, more importantly, is dangerous for biodiversity. Monitoring of the effects on nature is insufficient, the EFSA assessment is still as minimal and as contrary to food sovereignty. In this case, I voted in favour of this objection to the marketing of genetically modified Bt11 maize seeds.

name: Hugues BAYET
text: In writing. The European Parliament, which I fully agree with on this issue, considers that this draft commission enforcement decision exceeds the enforcement powers set out in Directive 2001/18/EC. EFSA's crop risk analysis is incomplete and the Commission's risk management recommendations are inadequate. Moreover, the Commission's draft enforcement decision is not in line with EU law. We therefore reject this request.

name: Beatriz BECERRA BASTERRECHEA
text: in writing. I am not positioned for or against GMOs. I'm in favor of science. In the Union we have set up an agency for this type of task: the EFSA (EFSA) where the opinion of independent scientists who ensure and guarantee food security in the Union is reflected. Just a few months ago, more than a hundred Nobel laureates encouraged recognizing the findings of the relevant scientific institutions and abandoning campaigns against genetically modified organisms without sufficient scientific support.  Different products need to be analyzed on a case-by-case basis, and the debate should not be generalized or simplified.

name: Brando BENIFEI
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted today in favour of objections to the placing on the market for the cultivation of two types of genetically modified maize seeds, including Bt11. I believe that the current regulatory framework does not allow the Commission and EFSA to provide adequate assessments of the impact of GMOs. In the case of Bt11 maize, in particular, concern concerns the presence of the Cry1Ab protein which gives resistance to European maize pyralid and Mediterranean maize pyralid. There is a risk of harming certain species of butterflies and moths, questioning efsa's concept of 'acceptable local mortality' of certain species of lepidoptite., I therefore decided to vote in favour of the objection, reaffirming the need for the Commission to draw up a comprehensive proposal on GMOs as soon as possible in order to carefully assess the environmental and health impact of these technologies and establishing a new procedure for their authorisation.

name: Xabier BENITO ZILUAGA
text: in writing. The use of transgenic seeds is part of a more substantive debate, which can be addressed from three angles: health, environmental and socio-economic impact. I voted in favour of the objection, because when we talk about allowing the marketing of transgenic seeds we talk about deepening this unsustainable model, abuses, royalties, dependence on agrochemicals; and socially perverse. We know that GENETICally modified seeds will not be marketed for the benefit of farmers, consumers, society, the environment but for the profit of a giant like Monsanto. A giant whose merger with Bayer will entail the creation of a monster whose consequences for the global agri-food system we are not even able to foresee.

name: Izaskun BILBAO BARANDICA
text: in writing. I would like to thank the rapporteurs of this report on the marketing of seeds of GM maize Bt11 for their work. This report, as well as the other four that we voted on today on various objections, does not leave anyone indifferent. I have been consistent with my previous votes in this area and supported the European Parliament's report which considers that the Commission's draft Implementing Decision exceeds the implementing powers con assigned to it by Directive 2001/18/EC.

name: Dominique BILDE
text: In writing. Despite systematic objections, the Commission persists in issuing permits for gmOS crops or imports. The aim here is to object to the marketing of genetically modified Bt11 maize seeds for cultivation by the manufacturer Syngenta. The problems raised concern Glufosinate, which is to be banned in 2017 (ownership is therefore useless) and the destruction of biodiversity. So I voted for it.

name: Mara BIZZOTTO
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted against the marketing authorisation for the cultivation of genetically modified maize seeds Bt11.

name: Vilija BLINKEVIČIŪTĖ
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this resolution, in which the European Parliament considers that the draft Commission implementing decision is not in line with European Union law because it is incompatible with the objective of Directive 2001/18/EC of the European Parliament and of the Council, according to which the precautionary principle seeks to appease the laws, regulations and administrative provisions of the Member States and to protect human health and the environment when genetically modified organisms are intentionally released into the environment for any purpose other than placing on the market in the territory of the European Community and genetically modified organisms are placed on the market in the Community as products in their own form or in other products. Parliament also considers that the cultivation risk assessment carried out by the European Food Safety Authority is not comprehensive and that the risk management recommendations proposed by the Commission are not appropriate.

name: Andrea BOCSKOR
text: Writing. \u2012 In accordance with the Hungarian Basic Law and the precautionary principle, I am opposed to the authorisation of GMO products, and I believe that the Commission's draft implementing decision does not comply with EU law, Whereas it is incompatible with the objective of Regulation (EC) No 1829/2003, which, in accordance with the general principles laid down in Regulation (EC) No 178/2002, is to serve as a basis for a high level of protection of human life and health, animal health and well-being, the environment and consumer interests in genetically modified food and feed, while ensuring the effective functioning of the internal market; The report calls on the Commission to withdraw its draft implementing decision, and I therefore voted in favour of the adoption of this report.

name: Franc BOGOVIČ
text: Writing. As with all objections to the placing on the market for the cultivation of seeds produced by genetic engineering, I also supported this objection, which is related to GS Maize Bt11. I myself am a supporter of the precautionary principle in GMOs, so I find it completely unnecessary for such a sensitive topic, such as the registration of MAHs, to be moved through the process quickly. We are at a sensitive moment when the institutions should have greater respect among themselves, and above all we must respect the will of the people, who are majority against the use of GMOs in Europe. I also personally wonder very much whether we really need this kind of GN-seed of maize. The genetically modified Maize bt11 under consideration contains a PAT protein that causes resistance to the herbicide glufosinate-ammonium, the use of which is only allowed in the EU until 2017. That herbicide is toxic to reproduction and the use of genetically modified maize would lead to an increase in its use and thus an increase in the risk to human health.

name: Biljana BORZAN
text: Written. ‒I support this report because it is a political message to the Commission that Parliament will not support any new approval until the gm food licensing process is reformed.

name: Mercedes BRESSO
text: in writing. ‒ I supported the resolution on the decision concerning the placing on the market for cultivation of genetically modified maize Bt11 seeds because in that resolution we criticise the draft by the Commission and we consider its risk management recommendations inadequate. Thus, with this vote I called on the Commission to withdraw its draft implementing decision.

name: Renata BRIANO
text: in writing. \u2012 Genetically modified Bt11 maize expresses the Cry1Ab protein, which is a Bt protein that gives resistance to European maize pyralid and Mediterranean maize pyralid; and the Pat protein that gives tolerance to the herbicide glufosinate ammonium. It should be borne in mind that glufosinate is classified as toxic for breeding purposes and therefore the cultivation of genetically modified Bt11 maize is prohibited in the various territories. Efsa's cultivation risk assessment is considered to be incomplete and the commission's proposed risk management recommendations are inadequate. Furthermore, the Commission's draft implementing decision is not consistent with EU law because it is not compatible with the objective of protecting human health and the environment when genetically modified organisms are deliberately released into the environment for purposes other than placing on the market within the Community and genetically modified organisms as such or contained in products are placed on the market within the Community. The Commission should therefore withse the draft implementing decision.

name: Steeve BRIOIS
text: In writing. This report proposes to adopt five objections to GMO cultivation or import authorizations, including from Monsanto. These objections highlight, in particular, the hypocrisy and dual discourse of the European parliamentarians of the majority groups who vote the opposite of what they promise their constituents. I voted in favour of these objections.

name: Nicola CAPUTO
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this objection today because I believe that EFSA's cultivation risk assessment is incomplete and that the risk management recommendations proposed by the Commission are inadequate. To date, the safety of BT11 genetically modified maize seeds has not been proven. Serious gaps in the data continue to persist. The Commission's draft implementing decision is not consistent with EU law as it is not compatible with the objective of Directive 2001/18/EC, which aims, in accordance with the precautionary principle, to approximate the laws, regulations and administrative provisions of the Member States and to protect human health and the environment when genetically modified organisms are deliberately evolved into the environment. I therefore call on the Commission to withdraw the draft implementing decision.

name: Matt CARTHY
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of these objections to GMO authorisations. The European Commission has yet to propose a new authorisation procedure since its very weak proposal was rejected earlier this year.  In spite of the fact that the EP called for a new proposal, the Commission continues to authorise GMOs under a flawed procedure which they themselves have admitted does not work. For these reasons I voted in favour of the objection.

name: David CASA
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this resolution as I consider that the risk assessment of cultivation of genetically modified maize Bt11 conducted by EFSA is incomplete and the risk management recommendations proposed by the Commission are inadequate. The draft Commission implementing decision is not consistent with Union law in line with the precautionary principle, which is to approximate the laws, regulations and administrative provisions of the Member States and to protect human health and the environment when carrying out the deliberate release into the environment of genetically modified organisms for any other purposes than placing on the market within the Community and placing on the market genetically modified organisms as or in products within the Community. I therefore call on the Commission to withdraw its draft implementing decision.

name: Fabio Massimo CASTALDO
text: in writing. \u2012 The European Commission has asked the European Food Safety Authority (EFSA) to assess whether new evidence has emerged that would change the recommendations of EFSA's scientific advice on the placing on the market for the cultivation of genetically modified Bt11 maize seeds. The European Parliament resolution on the European Commission's draft implementing decision considers efsa's cultivation risk assessment to be incomplete and that the risk management recommendations proposed by the European Commission are inadequate and therefore calls for the draft implementing decision to be withdrawn. Together with the M5S delegation, I voted in favour of the resolution.

name: Lefteris CHRISTOFOROU
text: Writing. \u2012 The issue of Genetically Modified Organisms (GMOs) is particularly important and has occupied the European Union since the 1990s. We believe that the objective of the competent authorities of the Member States of the European Union should be to control and limit any negative effects of GMOs, while leaving room for research action in the new scientific field of biotechnology or even for use on the market, if the products prove useful and harmless.

name: Kostas CHRYSOGONOS
text: Writing. \u2012 The vote on the objection to the placing on the market of genetically modified maize seed in the Bt11 series is a positive move for the benefit of the health of European citizens. As stated in the resolution, we consider that the assessment of the risks of cultivation is incomplete and that the risk management recommendations proposed by the Commission are inadequate. I therefore voted in favour.

name: Deirdre CLUNE
text: in writing. ‒ I rejected this objection as I support the EFSA and the European Commission's scientific GMO authorisation procedure.

name: Jane COLLINS
text: in writing. – We in UKIP are concerned about the safety of GMOs for health and the environment, but we would prefer our national Parliament to legislate on this delicate issue rather than the European Parliament.

name: Therese COMODINI CACHIA
text: in writing. ‒ It transpires that the risk assessment of cultivation conducted by EFSA is incomplete and the risk management recommendations proposed by the Commission are inadequate; therefore, I agree that we should withdraw the Commission’s draft implementing decision. I have consistently voted against placing on the market genetically modified organisms within the Community in line with the precautionary principle, which I believe should be followed in issues related to human health and the environment of our citizens.

name: Javier COUSO PERMUY
text: in writing.
