I voted in favour of this objection to the marketing of seeds of Bt11 genetically modified maize (tolerant to toxic herbicide ammonium glufosinate), because I am totally against genetically modified organisms and, therefore, new authorisations thereof. Moreover, it is clear that the current procedure for the authorisation of genetically modified food and feed is not working properly. That is why I am in favour of this and any objections raised in relation to the authorisation of GMOs, and I voted accordingly.

name: Andrea COZZOLINO
text: in writing. \u2012 I consider that the risk assessment of the placing on the market of genetically modified maize seed Bt11 is not complete and that the Commission's recommendations are not adequate. To date, EFSA's analysis still lacks some data on possible contamination that could cause serious harm to farmers. It should be remembered that GMOs are currently authorised in the EU by the Commission without the support of member states' committees and that, in particular, BT11 is still banned in many EU countries. For these reasons, I believe that the current proposal does not comply with ensuring a high level of protection of human life and health, animal health and welfare and the environment.

name: Edward CZESAK
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 I supported the opposition to the placing on the market of grains of genetically modified maize Bt11. This framework is one of the most restrictive in the world when it comes to assessing the risk to GMO crops and food, which makes me happy. I believe that this should remain the same, which is why I voted in favour.

name: Miriam DALLI
text: in writing. ‒ Maize Bt11 is an insect resistant seed. It allows the use of glufosinate ammonium as weed control but the EU has restricted it as a herbicide. Herbicide-resistant crops could encourage the more liberal use of these chemicals which can have knock-on environmental and health effects, especially in the third countries in which they are grown. This problem is inextricably linked to the wider debate around the safety of plant protection products, and especially the current controversies around the herbicide glyphosate. I have voted in favour of this objection as I support the idea of a strict system of authorisation of GMOs.

name: Michel DANTIN
text: In writing. This objection is aimed at opposing the marketing of the GMO Bt11. I am against this objection insofar as the European Commission has complied with its mandate as part of its enforcement power granted by the European Parliament and the Council. I regret that this ideologically motivated resolution does not take into account the numerous precautionary measures voted by the European legislator on the authorisation to market new products, as well as the positive scientific opinion granted by the European Food Safety Authority. For these reasons, I voted against this objection.

name: Angélique DELAHAYE
text: In writing. I voted against this objection to refusing to market genetically modified maize seed for cultivation purposes. This objection is based on an accusation made to the Commission: by this authorization it would exceed the enforcement powers assigned to it.  However, the Commission has complied with the existing GMO authorisation procedure. It has previously requested an analysis by the European Food Safety Authority (EASA) to verify that this maize seed is not dangerous to human and animal health, and to the environment.  This objection, in my view, therefore does not have to be and merely reflects a desire to systematically ban all GMOs, even though it is the responsibility of the Member States.

name: Mark DEMESMAEKER
text: Written. 'The N-VA delegation did not support the objections to the approval of a number of GMOs for the following reasons: The authors of the objections do not agree with the current legislative framework for GMOs and therefore refuse any further approval. What is before us today is a de facto moratorium on GMOs. The Commission has not exceeded its mandate: if member states do not achieve a qualified majority, the Commission is authorised to approve GMOs on the basis of the EFSA opinion. Moreover, the European approval procedure for GMOs is particularly strict. The EFSA risk assessment plays a crucial role in this. The N-VA strongly believes in a science-based and evidence-based policy.  Biotechnology is also an important sector for innovation, research and development. Flanders, and ghent in particular, is also a leader in such research. The objections send a signal that Europe wants to put a brake on this research, which I think is wrong and wrong.  It remains, of course, always important to distinguish between GMO technology and application. It is also clear that the (possible) use of GMOs should always take place within an agricultural policy that integrates the protection of public health, the environment and biodiversity, with integrated pest control essential for the sustainable use of pesticides and non-chemical alternatives.

name: Marielle DE SARNEZ
text: In writing. Currently, genetically modified organisms (GMOs) can be grown on the territory of the European Union after the seed companies holding the GMO have obtained a marketing authorization in accordance with European regulations.  The European Parliament has chosen to use its power of objection to ask the European Commission to withdraw its authorisations on the use of genetically modified Bt11 maize seeds tolerating glyphosate, a herbicide classified as a "probable carcinogen" by the World Health Organization (WHO).  In the future, the GMO authorisation process should not be reviewed without the support of a qualified majority of Member States and with the opinion of Parliament.

name: Angel DZHAMBAZKI
text: in writing. \u2012 I supported this objection as I am against the use of GMOs and the placing on the market of genetically modified goods. Furthermore, there is no robust data on risk assessment and impact assessment methods that calls their safety into question in the relevant case.

name: Georgios EPITIDEIOS
text: Writing. \u2012 We are voting in favour because we are against any attempt to liberalise GMOs and we are even calling on the European Parliament to take an even tougher stance and to block the Commission's attempts to allow, by side means, their cultivation within the Union.

name: Norbert ERDŐS
text: Writing. – Bt11 maize produces Cry1Ab toxin, which, like mon 810 toxin, is a Bt protein. This allows it to protect itself against various Lepidoptera species. It also expresses PAT protein, which provides tolerance to gluphosine ammonium herbicide. The available scientific knowledge provide sufficient reasons to believe that inbred lines and hybrids from the maize line containing the Bt11 gene design pose a risk to the environment. In view of all this, in accordance with the Hungarian Basic Law and the precautionary principle, I do not support the authorisation of GM products.

name: Jill EVANS
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this objection to the authorisation of genetically modified maize Bt11 seeds because the current legal framework for authorising GMOs is not democratic. Decisions are made by the Commission without the agreement of the Member States. I represent Wales, which has declared itself GM-free, and I want that decision to be respected.

name: Eleonora EVI
text: in writing. \u2012 As a signatory to the objection resolution, I voted in favour, as I believe that until democratic control of the European Commission's decisions has been strengthened and correctly reflects the opinion of the majority of Member States, MEPs and European citizens, no GMOs should be authorised. In addition, with regard to the three GMO maize, there is still a lack of data and incompleteness of the risk assessment, complete analyses of non-target species, such as aquatic insects, risk mitigation measures are inadequate and impractical, as demonstrated in the case of the definition of "safe haven areas" or "isolation distances from protected habitats" measures that have proved ineffective, or finally there remains a strong threat to GMO or organic-free crops , endangered by possible contamination.

name: José Manuel FERNANDES
text: in writing. \u2012 The Commission's draft implementing decision exceeds the implementing powers provided for in Directive 2001/18/EC and the efsa cultivation risk assessment is incomplete, and the risk management recommendations proposed by the Commission are inadequate.  The Commission's draft implementing decision is not in line with Union law in the protection of human health and the environment when deliberate releases are made into the environment of genetically modified organisms for any purpose other than placing on the market. I agree with the withdrawal of the draft implementing decision.

name: Edouard FERRAND
text: In writing. Vote for: despite systematic objections, the Commission persists in issuing permits for GMO crops or imports. Parliament persists in objecting, to no avail, since the Commission does not take this into account. These objections help to unmask the hypocrisy of the majority parliamentarians (who maintain the Commission) in the face of the totalitarianism of the European Union.

name: João FERREIRA
text: in writing. \u2012 Once again, as regards the procedures for that authorisation decision, the exception has become the rule. The corn from the genetically modified event Bt11 expresses the Cry1Ab protein, which is a protein (derived from Bacillus thuringiensis subsp. Kurstaki) which confers resistance to the European corn bit (Ostrinia nubilalis) and the Mediterranean corn drill (Sesamia nonagrioides), and pat protein, which confers tolerance to the herbicide glufosinate-ammonia. There was no consensus among the Member States, so according to the perverse legislative framework in force, the decision falls into the hands of the European Commission – which invariably has a pro-GMO stance, even in the face of a lack of long-term studies of food toxicity and insufficient risk assessment. Reasons underthe basis of the position of refusal (or abstention) taken by several Member States. This resolution objects to the authorisation of this Genetically Modified Organism (GMO). We voted in favour. It is necessary and urgent to amend the current legislative framework in order to respect the right of each Member State not to want GMOs on its territory, for food and/or cultivation, for reasons of protection of food sovereignty, the environment, biodiversity and public health.

name: Luke Ming FLANAGAN
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour as I believe GMO crops are a threat to our existence.

name: Lorenzo FONTANA
text: in writing. \u2012 I am voting in favour of the resolution containing an objection to the commission's authorisation of a GMO.

name: Lampros FOUNTOULIS
text: Writing. \u2012 I am voting in favour of the objection raised, in accordance with Rule 106 of the Rules of Procedure, to the placing on the market of seeds of genetically modified maize of the Bt11 series because I am against any attempt to liberalise the circulation of GMOs. I even call on the European Parliament to take an even tougher stance and to block all attempts by the Commission to allow them to grow sideways within the Union.

name: Kinga GÁL
text: Writing. \u2012 The available scientific knowledge provide sufficient reasons to believe that inbred lines and hybrids from the maize line containing the Bt11 gene design pose a risk to the environment. In view of all this, in accordance with the Hungarian Basic Law and the precautionary principle, I do not support the authorisation of GM products.

name: Ildikó GÁLL-PELCZ
text: Writing. – Bt11 maize produces Cry1Ab toxin, which, like mon 810 toxin, is a Bt protein. This allows it to protect itself against various Lepidoptera species. It also expresses PAT protein, which provides tolerance to gluphosine ammonium herbicide. The available scientific knowledge provide sufficient reasons to believe that inbred lines and hybrids from the maize line containing the Bt11 gene design pose a risk to the environment. In view of all this, in accordance with the Hungarian Basic Law and the precautionary principle, I do not support the authorisation of GM products.

name: Francisco de Paula GAMBUS MILLET
text: in writing. I voted against the objection concerning the marketing of seeds of GM maize Bt11. After studying the objection, I believe that there are sufficient controls and guarantees regarding risk management to limit the unwanted exposure of lepidoptera being conserved in protected habitats. It is always necessary to keep in mind that we must ensure maximum food security for European citizens but without falling into an exaggeration which can have serious economic consequences for the sector.

name: Nathan GILL
text: in writing. ‒ I am concerned about the safety of GMOs and their impact on health and the environment, but I would prefer the UK Government to legislate on this delicate issue, rather than the European Parliament.

name: Tania GONZÁLEZ PEÑAS
text: in writing. The use of transgenic seeds is part of a more substantive debate, which can be addressed from three angles: health, environmental and socio-economic impact. I voted in favour of the objection, because when we talk about allowing the marketing of transgenic seeds we talk about deepening this unsustainable model, abuses, royalties, dependence on agrochemicals; and socially perverse. We know that GENETICally modified seeds will not be marketed for the benefit of farmers, consumers, society, the environment but for the profit of a giant like Monsanto. A giant whose merger with Bayer will entail the creation of a monster whose consequences for the global agri-food system we are not even able to foresee.

name: Theresa GRIFFIN
text: in writing. ‒  Today, I voted against the objection pursuant to Rule 106 against the placing on the market of genetically modified maize Bt11 seeds, as the risk assessment conducted by the European Food Safety Agency (EFSA) concluded that the cultivation of these GM crops is unlikely to a pose danger to human and animal health or to the environment.

name: András GYÜRK
text: Writing. \u2012 Bt11 maize produces Cry1Ab toxin, which, like mon 810 toxin, is a Bt protein. This allows it to protect itself against various Lepidoptera species. It also expresses PAT protein, which provides tolerance to gluphosine ammonium herbicide. The available scientific knowledge provide sufficient reasons to believe that inbred lines and hybrids from the maize line containing the Bt11 gene design pose a risk to the environment. In view of all this, in accordance with the Hungarian Basic Law and the precautionary principle, I do not support the authorisation of GM products.

name: Marian HARKIN
text: in writing. ‒ I supported this objection because there are concerns that the implementing decision by the Commission is not compatible with Union law and there are concerns over the EFSA risk management process. More specifically, the Commission bases its argument for authorisation on the concept of a level of ‘acceptable local mortality’ of non-target lepidopteran species (butterflies and moths), which is considered by some to be a flawed interpretation of EFSA advice. In addition, there is the possibility of cross-contamination with an ancient maize variety that carries major risks for farmers and the environment. For all of the above reasons I voted in favour of the objection, plus the fact that I do not support the introduction of GMOs into the European Union.

name: György HÖLVÉNYI
text: Writing. \u2012 Bt11 maize produces Cry1Ab toxin, which, like mon 810 toxin, is a Bt protein. This allows it to protect itself against various Lepidoptera species. It also expresses PAT protein, which provides tolerance to gluphosine ammonium herbicide. The available scientific knowledge provide sufficient reasons to believe that inbred lines and hybrids from the maize line containing the Bt11 gene design pose a risk to the environment. In view of all this, in accordance with the Hungarian Basic Law and the precautionary principle, I do not support the authorisation of GM products.

name: Ivan JAKOVČIĆ
text: Written. ‒ I voted to object in accordance with Article 106. Rules of Procedure: placing on the market seeds of GM maize Bt11 because I do not support the use of genetically modified organisms on agricultural lands.

name: Jean-François JALKH
text: In writing. We are witnessing a balancing act: the Commission persists in encouraging the cultivation and importation of GMOs into our countries with its authorisations, and in sweeping away parliament's equally stubborn opposition. All this is indeed of little use, and is not enough to absolve parliamentarians of their responsibility, which maintain the Commission by the Band in its omnipotence. I remain convinced that the marketing of Bt11 seeds is harmful. True to my convictions, I voted for it.

name: Diane JAMES
text: in writing. – We in UKIP are concerned about the safety of GMOs for health and the environment, but we would prefer our national Parliament to legislate on this delicate issue rather than the European Parliament.

name: Marc JOULAUD
text: In writing. I voted against this objection to the renewal of the European Commission's approval of genetically modified maize seeds. By authorising marketing for cultivation or marketing purposes, the European Commission has duly complied with the procedure, taking into account the analysis of the European Food Safety Authority.  It is also important to remember that genetically modified products found in French shelves or crops are approved by the French state and not by the European Union.

name: Barbara KAPPEL
text: Writing. I am voting in favour of this report. It rejects the Commission's proposal to allow a variety of genetically modified maize and forces the Commission to reconsider its proposal. The implementing decision is incompatible with Union law, the recommendation on risk management is deficient and genetically modified foods must be generally rejected from an Austrian point of view.

name: Krišjānis KARIŅŠ
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported a resolution at the European Parliament plenary session in Strasbourg calling for the withdrawal of the Commission's implementing decision on the placing on the market for cultivation of genetically modified maize seed. The European Commission has the power to come up with a better and clearer solution for the release and free trade of genetically modified products or products containing genetically modified raw materials on the European Union market. I believe that the European Commission has sufficient resources in its mandate to investigate and understand the impact of genetically modified products on the environment and human health.

name: Ádám KÓSA
text: Writing. \u2012 Bt11 maize produces Cry1Ab toxin, which, like mon 810 toxin, is a Bt protein. This allows it to protect itself against various Lepidoptera species. It also expresses PAT protein, which provides tolerance to gluphosine ammonium herbicide. The available scientific knowledge provide sufficient reasons to believe that inbred lines and hybrids from the maize line containing the Bt11 gene design pose a risk to the environment. In view of all this, in accordance with the Hungarian Basic Law and the precautionary principle, I do not support the authorisation of GM products.

name: Béla KOVÁCS
text: Writing. – The most basic human right is the right to health and healthy food. The resolution rightly points out that the Commission is ignoring EU law when it comes to placing various GMO seeds on the market. However, this cannot be done in accordance with the precautionary principle. The majority of Member States also prohibit the spread of GMOs by their national laws or basic laws. This approach by the Commission is worrying, with large crowds rightly protesting against the conclusion of CETA and TTIP.

name: Gilles LEBRETON
text: In writing. I voted for this objection because it opposes the use of a GMO that is dangerous to biodiversity. The European Parliament agreed to vote on it, demonstrating that the Commission's initiative was harmful. I want France to regain its food sovereignty.

name: Philippe LOISEAU
text: In writing. The Commission persists in issuing permits for the cultivation or importation of GMOs. Parliament persists in objecting, to no avail, since the Commission does not take this into account. I voted in favour of that objection.

name: Paloma LÓPEZ BERMEJO
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this objection to the marketing of seeds of Bt11 genetically modified maize (tolerant to toxic herbicide ammonium glufosinate), because I am totally against its authorisation. It is clear that the current procedure for the authorisation of genetically modified food and feed is not working with guarantees as to its impact on agricultural practices and food and I voted accordingly.

name: Petr MACH
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted against the Commission's decision authorising the distribution of GM maize seed.  I respect the right of states to ban seed on their territory, as about half of EU countries have done, but it is not right not to allow those states that do not mind this seed to be restricted.  I am thus behind the Commission's decision.

name: Svetoslav Hristov MALINOV
text: in writing. \u2012 Today in plenary I supported the objections against the placing on the market of genetically modified maize. The European Commission has requested a new legislative proposal to strengthen democratic control over authorisations for GMO products.  Decisions authorising GMOs are currently adopted by the European Commission without being supported by Member States' opinions. This was initially envisaged as an exception in the procedure, but, unfortunately, became the rule. Cultivation of genetically modified maize is prohibited on the territory of: Austria, Belgium (Wallonia), Bulgaria, Germany (except for research purposes), Greece, Denmark, Italy, Cyprus, Latvia, Lithuania, Luxembourg, Malta, united Kingdom (Northern Ireland, Wales, Scotland), Poland, Slovenia, France, the Netherlands and Croatia.  I join those of my colleagues who find that the European Commission's draft marketing of these GMO products exceeds its implementing powers and must be withdrawn.

name: Andrejs MAMIKINS
text: in writing. – I agree that the risk assessment of cultivation conducted by EFSA is incomplete and the risk management recommendations proposed by the Commission are inadequate and support calls on the Commission to withdraw its draft implementing decision.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: Writing. \u2012 I am voting in favour of the motion for a resolution calling on the European Commission to withdraw the draft of its implementing decision on the placing on the market for cultivation of genetically modified maize seed of the Bt11 series, because it is complete and documented.

name: Dominique MARTIN
text: In writing. I voted for this text. Five objections are presented by Parliament on authorisations for gmOS crops or imports. The different properties of these GMOs pose several problems: carcinogenic herbicides, insecticides causing the destruction of biodiversity, etc. We are therefore in favour of these objections and, in this case, in favour of the marketing of Bt11 genetically modified maize seeds.

name: Costas MAVRIDES
text: Writing. \u2012 I am voting in favour of the resolution on the draft Commission implementing decision concerning the placing on the market for cultivation of genetically modified maize seed in the Bt11 series because I believe that the Commission's draft implementing decision is not in accordance with UNION law, in the sense that it is not compatible with the objectives of Directive 2001/18/EC of the European Parliament and of the Council, which are, in accordance with the precautionary principle, the approximation of the laws, regulations and administrative provisions of the Member States and the protection of human health and the environment when genetically modified organisms are deliberately released into the environment for purposes other than the placing on the market within the Community and when genetically modified organisms are marketed as products or in products within the Community.

name: Georg MAYER
text: Writing. The resolution states that the Commission's draft implementing decision is incompatible with EU law and therefore calls on the Commission to withdraw its draft. As EFSA's risk assessment of cultivation is incomplete and the recommendations on risk management proposed by the Commission are deficient, I voted in favour of the resolution.

name: Valentinas MAZURONIS
text: Writing. \u2012 I support the EP resolution because it opposes the Commission's decision to authorise the marketing of genetically modified maize seed. I believe that, in accordance with the precautionary principle and the objective of protecting human health and the environment, decisions on the marketing of GMO seeds should only be taken once uncontested scientific evidence of their effects has been provided. Unfortunately, at present, risk assessments for GMOs production are not complete and unennutrs. For these reasons, I do not support the development, trade and cultivation of GMOs in the EU.

name: Jean-Luc MÉLENCHON
text: In writing. The report opposes the Commission's decision to allow the marketing of Bt11 genetically modified maize seeds. This variety is developed by Syngenta. It confers resistance to certain insects (corn borer). But of course also a tolerance to herbicides containing Phosphinotricin (PPT), such as ammonium Glufosinate, a substance classified as toxic for reproduction. And its use is also banned on maize in the EU.  The report criticises the assessment by the European Food Safety Authority (EFSA). In particular, it points to the arbitrary introduction of the concept of an "acceptable local mortality" level of non-target lepidoptera species. This maize destroys insects other than the corn borer it is supposed to be specialized in. I vote for this text.

name: Joëlle MÉLIN
text: In writing. The Commission persists in issuing permits for the cultivation or importation of GMOs. Parliament persists in objecting, to no avail, since the Commission does not take this into account. I voted in favour of this objection, as did the other four.

name: Nuno MELO
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this resolution because I believe that the risk assessment of cultivation carried out by EFSA is incomplete and that the risk management recommendations proposed by the Commission are inadequate with regard to the cultivation of genetically modified maize seeds Bt11.

name: Roberta METSOLA
text: in writing. ‒ I chose to support this objection to the placing on the market of genetically modified maize Bt11 seeds as a more thorough risk assessment of cultivation by EFSA is needed and the risk management recommendations proposed by the Commission are inadequate.

name: Louis MICHEL
text: Written. – At the beginning of 2016, there were some 7.4 billion people on our planet. In the most prudent scenario, the world's population will grow to 9 billion by 2050. Rapid growth of the world's population implies that demand for food and crops will also increase proportionately. Entrepreneurs in agriculture and food are facing important challenges. The existing agricultural area will have to be continued and better utilised. Innovation in agriculture will focus on sustainable and efficient agricultural techniques and plant technology will play a special role in ensuring food production. In that context, there are currently no convincing scientific arguments for objecting to a GM licence.

name: Marlene MIZZI
text: in writing. ‒ I have supported the decision to object to the placing on the market of genetically modified maize Bt11 seeds because the draft Commission implementing decision is not consistent with Union law. In accordance with the precautionary principle, to approximate the laws, regulations and administrative provisions of the Member States and to protect human health and the environment when carrying out the deliberate release into the environment of genetically modified organisms for any other purposes than placing on the market within the Community and placing on the market genetically modified organisms as or in products within the Community.

name: Sophie MONTEL
text: In writing. Despite systematic objections, the Commission persists in issuing permits for gmOS crops or imports. Parliament persists in objecting, to no avail, since the Commission does not take this into account. These objections help to unmask the hypocrisy of the majority parliamentarians (who maintain the Commission) in the face of the Union's totalitarianism. So I'm voting for it.

name: Nadine MORANO
text: In writing. I voted against this objection to the authorisation of GMO maize BT11, which is the responsibility of the Member States or not, because it is based on the false argument that the Commission has exceeded its powers by authorising this maize. Indeed, the Commission has fully complied with the procedure by asking the European Food Safety Authority for a study on the safety of the plant for human and animal health and for the environment. It then proposed this GMO authorization to the Council, which did not refuse it.

name: József NAGY
text: Writing. \u2012 I believe that until the cultivation of GM species and varieties proves to be of great environmental and economic benefit to European farmers, there is no point in taking even the slightest risk by authorising them. The greater part of the European public has not yet really accepted modern agricultural methods and their unprotused dangers, and I think we legismies should bear this in mind.

name: Victor NEGRESCU
text: in writing. ‒ I have abstained from voting on this motion for a resolution that authorises the placing on the market of products containing, consisting of, or produced from genetically modified maize Bt11 seeds following a risk evaluation to human health and biodiversity.

name: Momchil NEKOV
text: in writing. – I supported this resolution, initiated by the Committee on the Environment, Public Health and Food Safety, because I believe that without an effective control mechanism within the internal market which can ensure that products which are prohibited for cultivation in a Member State do not pose a danger or run counter to that prohibition or risk its infringement, it cannot and must not proceed to the authorisation of the placing on the market of seeds of that prohibited crop. For bt11 maize seeds in the territory of 19 Member States, there are effective prohibitions on its cultivation. One of these countries is mine – Bulgaria.  The Bulgarian public is strongly opposed to the use of such crops. The Single European Market can only function when its terms are accepted by all its participants, without the risk of violating their legal and moral laws. This culture does not meet these conditions.

name: Franz OBERMAYR
text: Writing. I voted in favour of this resolution because the Commission's implementing decision is incompatible with EU law. The Commission is invited to withdraw its draft implementing decision.

name: Urmas PAET
text: Writing. \u2012 Not supported. Regulation of genetically modified products individually is neither effective nor feasible.

name: Margot PARKER
text: in writing. ‒ We in UKIP are concerned about the safety of GMOs for health and the environment, but we would prefer our national Parliament to legislate on this delicate issue rather than the European Parliament.

name: Aldo PATRICIELLO
text: in writing. \u2012 With regard to the objection concerning the placing on the market for the cultivation of genetically modified maize seeds Bt11, while noting the importance of this argument, I do not believe that the objections raised are complete. I would therefore like to abstain.

name: Alojz PETERLE
text: Writing. \ i supported the objection because I believe that the Commission's draft implementing decision goes beyond the implementing powers laid down in Directive 2001/18/EC. The Commission should therefore withdraw the draft implementing decision authorising genetically modified maize. I also do not recognise GMO as part of the solution to the problems facing the agricultural and food sectors.

name: Marijana PETIR
text: Written. I supported this resolution as I consider that the Commission's draft implementing decision exceeds the powers provided for in Directive 2001/18/EC and is not even in line with its objective of protecting human health and the environment in certain cases where genetically modified organisms are deliberately introduced into the environment. It is the modifications of Bt11 that express genes for cry1Ab protein, and this is precisely the protein Bt (which comes from Bacillus thuringiensis subspecies Kurstaki) which allows resistance to the presence of corn moth (Ostrinia nubilalis) and Mediterranean corn moth (Sesamia nonagrioides), and for the protein Pat that allows tolerantness to herbicides with ammonia gluphosinate will not have its expected economic effect.  Glufosinate is classified as a substance that is toxic to reproductive health and therefore falls under the exclusion criteria set out in Regulation (EC) No 101/2013. 1107/2009 and the exclusion criteria apply to substances already authorised when the authorisation is to be renewed and the glufosinate authorisation expires in 2017 so that the use of glufosinates should in principle end in 2017. I see no reason why approval should be given for seeds that will only be used for a year, with the use of substances with a known negative effect on health.

name: Tonino PICULA
text: Written. In 2005, EFSA issued an opinion in which it considered that there were no compatible relatives in nature to interbreed with, and then considered that the cultivation and spread of this species did not provide for undesirable environmental effects. The Spanish authorities informed the Commission of the presence of the theosine in Spanish maize fields, including a very limited presence in GM maize fields, and that the available data indicate that theosinta was also found in France. Since theosine populations can become recipients of transgenic DNA derived from genetically modified maize MON 810, thereby producing the toxin Bt, allowing for greater survival capacity for maize hybrids and theosins compared to native teozinte plants. It is a scenario that carries a great risk to farmers and the environment.  In my view, this draft Commission decision exceeds the implementing powers provided for in Directive 2001/18/EC. Efsa's assessment of farming risks is not complete and the risk management recommendations put forward by the Commission are not adequate. The Commission's draft implementing decision does not comply with Union law, as it is incompatible with Regulation (EC) No 1009/2013. 1829/2003 and, in accordance with the precautionary principle, it is a rapprochement between the laws and other regulations of the Member States on the protection of human health and the environment when genetically modified organisms are deliberately introduced into the environment.

name: João PIMENTA LOPES
text: in writing. \u2012 Once again, as regards the procedures for that authorisation decision, the exception has become the rule. The corn from the genetically modified event Bt11 expresses the Cry1Ab protein, which is a protein (derived from Bacillus thuringiensis subsp. Kurstaki) which confers resistance to the European corn bit (Ostrinia nubilalis) and the Mediterranean corn drill (Sesamia nonagrioides), and pat protein, which confers tolerance to the herbicide glufosinate-ammonia. There was no consensus among the Member States, so according to the perverse legislative framework in force, the decision falls into the hands of the European Commission – which invariably has a pro-GMO stance, even in the face of a lack of long-term studies of food toxicity and insufficient risk assessment. Reasons underthe basis of the position of refusal (or abstention) taken by several Member States. This resolution objects to the authorisation of this Genetically Modified Organism (GMO). We voted in favour. It is necessary and urgent to amend the current legislative framework in order to respect the right of each Member State not to want GMOs on its territory, for food and/or cultivation, for reasons of protection of food sovereignty, the environment, biodiversity and public health.

name: Franck PROUST
text: In writing. I voted against this objection. Indeed, the European Commission has not exceeded its powers and has complied well with the procedure for authorising GMOs, thanks in particular to the opinion of the European Food Safety Authority. As a reminder, this proposal for market authorization was forwarded to the Commission, which did not reject it.  Also, these objections used by political groups such as the Greens have no real effect because they relate to acts of execution. More generally, I would like to point out that France bans the cultivation of GMOs, even though it imports them.

name: Julia REID
text: in writing. ‒ We in UKIP are concerned about the safety of GMOs for health and the environment, but we would prefer our national Parliament to legislate on this delicate issue rather than the European Parliament.

name: Sofia RIBEIRO
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted against, as glufosinate is classified as toxic to reproduction and is therefore covered by the exclusion criteria set out in Regulation (EC) No 1107/2009.  For substances that have already been approved, the exclusion criteria apply when approval needs to be renewed, and glufosinate approval expires in 2017. The use of glufosinate should, in principle, cease to be allowed in 2017.

name: Frédérique RIES
text: In writing. It is an eminently political signal that MEPs gave this afternoon by rejecting, by a large majority, 5 new permits to grow GMO maize 1507, Bt11, MON810 and GM cotton 281-24-236. Eighteen months after the legislation came into force (on 2 April 2015) giving Member States a new opportunity to ban the cultivation of GMOs on their territory, of which I was rapporteur, nothing has changed. The Commission is working hard to make a move in the absence of both scientific and political consensus. This is in stark contradiction to the commitments made by President Juncker in July 2014 to change the procedure for authorising GMOs at European level.  The European Parliament therefore reminds the Commission of the respect of the word given. Although the cultivation of MON810, which is the only GMO grown in Europe, mainly in Spain and since 1998, represents less than 0.10% of agricultural land, it is a matter of principle. Any decision authorising the marketing of GMOs should be suspended until democratic control of the Commission's decisions has been strengthened and they do not reflect the majority opinion of Member States and citizens.

name: Bronis ROPĖ
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this resolution in which Parliament rejects the Commission's decision to renew the authorisation for the renewal of the authorisation of Genetically Modified Maize for Syngenta Seeds S.A.S. for access to the EU market. Parliament considers that the draft Commission decision is not compatible with Union law because it is incompatible with the objective of Directive 2001/18/EC of the European Parliament and of the Council, which aims to harmonise the laws, regulations and administrative provisions of the Member States and to protect human health and the environment.

name: Fernando RUAS
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted against this report, following the indication of my political group, which defended the opposition to the Commission's decision on the placing on the market for cultivation of genetically modified maize seeds designated by Bt11 (SYN BTØ11-1) (D046173/01).  In its scientific opinion adopted in May 2015, the European Food Safety Authority (ESA) stated that existing data are insufficient so that bt maize-linked larvae mortality can be framed in the context of overall mortality. However, in July 2016, the Commission asked ESA to assess, by the end of September 2016, whether, on the basis of existing scientific literature and other relevant information, new data were tabled to modify the findings and recommendations set out in the scientific advice on the planting of genetically modified maize varieties. Since no consideration has been given by EFSA to go in the sense of what had been previously reported, I do not consider there to be any reason for the Commission's decision to be rejected, a position subject, taking into account the principle of prudence, obviously the appropriate amendments, if new evidence sprucing up.

name: Lola SÁNCHEZ CALDENTEY
text: in writing. The use of transgenic seeds is part of a more substantive debate, which can be addressed from three angles: health, environmental and socio-economic impact. I voted in favour of the objection, because when we talk about allowing the marketing of transgenic seeds we talk about deepening this unsustainable model, abuses, royalties, dependence on agrochemicals; and socially perverse. We know that GENETICally modified seeds will not be marketed for the benefit of farmers, consumers, society, the environment but for the profit of a giant like Monsanto. A giant whose merger with Bayer will entail the creation of a monster whose consequences for the global agri-food system we are not even able to foresee.

name: Maria Lidia SENRA RODRÍGUEZ
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this objection to the marketing of seeds of Bt11 genetically modified maize (tolerant to toxic herbicide ammonium glufosinate), because I am totally against genetically modified organisms and, therefore, new authorisations thereof. Moreover, it is clear that the current procedure for the authorisation of genetically modified food and feed is not working properly. That is why I am in favour of this and any objections raised in relation to the authorisation of GMOs, and I voted accordingly.

name: Siôn SIMON
text: in writing. ‒ Today, I voted against the objection pursuant to Rule 106 on the placing on the market of genetically modified maize Bt11 seeds, as the risk assessment conducted by the European Food Safety Agency (EFSA) concluded that the cultivation of these GM crops is unlikely to a pose danger to human and animal health or to the environment.

name: Branislav ŠKRIPEK
text: Writing. \u2012 I agree that the European Parliament is asking the Commission to withdraw its draft implementing decision on the placing on the market of genetically modified maize Bt11 for cultivation purposes. I consider that the Commission's implementing decision does not comply with EU law, Since it is incompatible with the objectives of Directive 2001/18/EC of the European Parliament and of the Council, which complies with the precautionary principle, with a view to approxibling the laws, regulations and administrative provisions of the Member States and protecting human health and the environment in the event of the deliberate release into the environment of genetically modified organisms for any purpose other than placing on the market within the Community and the placing on the market of genetically modified organisms as or in products within the Community. For this reason, I voted in favour of adopting this resolution.

name: Davor ŠKRLEC
text: Written. ‒ I voted positively for this report, but this explanation of the vote is a criticism of the existing system of evaluation of the work of MEMBERS of the European Parliament solely on the basis of the statistical number of parliamentary activities potentiated in Croatia, which does not really reflect the actual quality and quantity of work, efficiency and most of all the success of parliamentary action.

name: Monika SMOLKOVÁ
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported the objection to the Commission implementing decision extending the authorisation for the cultivation of BT11 GM maize. An application for the cultivation of this type of maize was lodged in France in 1996. However, Bt11 maize contains a protein guaranteeing tolerance to the herbicide glufosinate-ammonium, which is classified as toxic for reproduction and its authorisation expires in 2017. In addition, the cultivation of this maize is prohibited in many countries. As scientific evidence suggests that released pollen may spread across borders, we should maintain the precautionary principle. Should such GMOs cross and spread, biological diversity may be compromised and may also pose risks to farmers. Since, on the basis of current methods of controlling the planting of GMOs of maize, we cannot guarantee a sufficient level of protection of human life and health, the Commission should not issue such GMO decisions. I am therefore of the opinion that the Commission should withdraw its implementing decision and submit a new legislative proposal that takes better account of the specificities of gmo crop cultivation.

name: Igor ŠOLTES
text: Writing. The European Parliament has successfully expressed its disagreement with the authorisation of five food and feed products from genetically modified organisms. These include the seeds of genetically modified Bt11 maize, which is being dealt with by this resolution. At the same time, the European Commission has rejected the call for a change in the authorisation procedure for the use of individual GMOs, as the European Parliament considers that the procedure is currently not democratic, as decisions are now being taken by the Commission. There is also a certain lack of data on the use and import of GMOs, as the Commission rarely shares data with the European Parliament in such cases. The European Food Safety Authority is currently carrying out a review in relation to gmOs which the Commission wishes to approve for the use of the research. As I believe that our food should be kept safe and healthy, I voted in favour of Parliament's resolution which seeks to ensure that the authorisation to use the mentioned GM seeds of Bt11 maize is not accepted.

name: Dubravka ŠUICA
text: Written. —Having regard to the draft European Commission on the implementing decision to market gm maize seeds Bt11 (SYN-BTØ11-1) for cultivation, and since, according to Article 26.c(2) of the Regulation, Directive 2001/18/EC the cultivation of BT11 GM maize prohibited on the territories of certain Member States, including Croatia, the draft European Commission goes beyond its executive powers achieved by Directive 2001/18/EC. In addition, the Assessment of the Farming Risks of the European Food Safety Authority is incomplete and the Commission's draft on the implementation of the decision is insufficiently aligned with the legislation, regulations and administrative provisions of the Member States that would protect human health and the environment when intentionally introducing GENETICally modified organisms for any purpose other than placing on the Union market. I therefore support the European Parliament's objection and resolution on the Commission's draft decision on the implementing decision to market GM maize seeds Bt11 (SYN-BTØ11-1) for cultivation.

name: Eleftherios SYNADINOS
text: Writing. We are against any attempt to liberalise GMOs;

name: Tibor SZANYI
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the European Parliament's motion for a resolution on the draft Commission implementing decision on the placing on the market of genetically modified Maize grains Bt11 (SYN-BTØ11-1) for cultivation. Syngenta Seeds SAS (formerly Novartis Seeds) submitted a marketing notice for Bt11 maize to the competent French authorities in 1996 (and again in 2003). This corn contains Cry1Ab protein and Pat protein, which provides resistance to herbicides containing glufosineate ammonium. This herbicide, on the other hand, is considered a reproductive agent and should be discontinued at the end of 2017.  According to the European Food Safety Authority (EFSA), vertical wind movement or gusts during pollen spraying can spread pollen up to several kilometres away. In its draft implementing decision, the Commission provided for an isolation distance of at least 5 metres between the Bt11 maize fields and protected habitats, despite efsa's clear finding that an isolation distance of 20 metres around a protected habitat would be proposed. EFSA also stated that the risk assessment for cultivation was incomplete. I therefore agree that the draft Commission implementing decision goes beyond competences and that the EFSA recommendations are therefore inadequate.

name: Marc TARABELLA
text: In writing. The European Parliament, which I fully agree with on this issue, considers that this draft commission enforcement decision exceeds the enforcement powers set out in Directive 2001/18/EC. EFSA's crop risk analysis is incomplete and the Commission's risk management recommendations are inadequate. Moreover, the Commission's draft enforcement decision is not in line with EU law. We therefore reject this request!

name: Pavel TELIČKA
text: in writing. ‒ The objection proposed by the Environment, Public Health and Food Safety committee against the Commission’s proposal for placing genetically modified maize Bt11 seeds on the European market is part of a larger theme of systematically opposing GM authorisations on mainly procedural grounds and is not the right way to force the Commission to change the EU-level authorisation regime. I voted against the motion to object the proposal, as I believe that as long as there are no convincing scientific reasons to object to a GM authorisation, I will continue to follow the advice given by the European Food and Safety Authority.

name: Ruža TOMAŠIĆ
text: Written. ‒I supported the objection to the Commission's decision to authorize the marketing of the GM maize variety Bt11 (SYN-BTØ11-1), as some Member States of the European Union oppose the introduction of GM products on their market.  Given that this is about human health and environmental impact, I believe that each Member State has the right to impose conditions or restrictions on the marketing of GM products, as well as their cultivation, regardless of whether they are genetically modified food intended directly for humans or feed.  With human health, protecting our traditional agricultural production and environment must come first, so we need to take all possible measures so that genetically modified maize is not dispersed by air.

name: Romana TOMC
text: Writing. I supported the objection under Rule 106 of the Rules of Procedure: Placing on the market for the cultivation of seeds of genetically modified maize Bt11. In 1996, Syngenta Seeds SAS (formerly Novartis Seeds) ('notifier') submitted a notification to the competent authority of France in accordance with Council Directive 90/220/EEC(8) of placing genetically modified Maize Bt11 on the market. The draft implementing decision is not compatible with Union law and the objective of Directive 2001/18/EC of the European Parliament and of the Council, i.e. in accordance with the precautionary principle, to approximate the laws, regulations and administrative provisions of the Member States and to protect human health and the environment when the deliberate release into the environment of genetically modified organisms is carried out for any other reason, such as placing on the market in the Community, or when genetically modified organisms are placed on the market as products or in products in the Community.

name: Estefanía TORRES MARTÍNEZ
text: in writing. The use of transgenic seeds is part of a more substantive debate, which can be addressed from three angles: health, environmental and socio-economic impact. I voted in favour of the objection, because when we talk about allowing the marketing of transgenic seeds we talk about deepening this unsustainable model, abuses, royalties, dependence on agrochemicals; and socially perverse. We know that GENETICally modified seeds will not be marketed for the benefit of farmers, consumers, society, the environment but for the profit of a giant like Monsanto. A giant whose merger with Bayer will entail the creation of a monster whose consequences for the global agri-food system we are not even able to foresee.

name: Mylène TROSZCZYNSKI
text: In writing. Despite systematic objections, the Commission persists in issuing permits for cultivation or import of GMOs. Parliament persists in objecting, to no avail, since the Commission does not take this into account. These objections help to unmask the hypocrisy of the majority parliamentarians (who maintain the Commission) in the face of the totalitarianism of the European Union. I'm voting for that objection.

name: Kazimierz Michał UJAZDOWSKI
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 Genetically modified food can have a negative impact on humans, animals and the environment and should be controlled in detail in these respects. I doubt whether the Commission should allow further types of genetically modified food and feed to be placed on the market. That is why I voted against the introduction of Bt11 maize seeds and voted against it.

name: Miguel URBÁN CRESPO
text: in writing. The use of transgenic seeds is part of a more substantive debate, which can be addressed from three angles: health, environmental and socio-economic impact. I voted in favour of the objection, because when we talk about allowing the marketing of transgenic seeds we talk about deepening this unsustainable model, abuses, royalties, dependence on agrochemicals; and socially perverse. We know that GENETICally modified seeds will not be marketed for the benefit of farmers, consumers, society, the environment but for the profit of a giant like Monsanto. A giant whose merger with Bayer will entail the creation of a monster whose consequences for the global agri-food system we are not even able to foresee.

name: Ernest URTASUN
text: in writing. – I voted in favour of the GMO import objection as I have decided to object systematically to any GM import authorisation. This was following the EP rejection of the Commission’s proposal to renationalise instead of democratise the authorisation procedure. In relation to the GMO cultivation, I also decided to object as all three maizes are Bt maizes: they all themselves produce the Bt toxin that enables them to be ‘pest-resistant’, meaning they are themselves toxic to the targeted pests – but also the non-targeted, even if those ones are protected or pollinate.

name: Ivo VAJGL
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the objection pursuant to Rule 106(2) and (3) of the Rules of Procedure on the draft Commission implementing decision concerning the placing on the market for cultivation of genetically modified maize Bt11 (SYN-BTØ11-1) seeds (D046173/01 – 2016/2919(RSP)). I voted in favour of the objection because I believe that maize Bt11 seeds could harm ‘non-target’ species of butterflies and moths. Moreover, I find that the concept introduced by the European Food Safety Authority (EFSA) of an ‘acceptable local mortality’ of non-target lepidopteran species should be revised.

name: Ángela VALLINA
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this objection to the marketing of seeds of Bt11 genetically modified maize (tolerant to toxic herbicide ammonium glufosinate), because I am totally against genetically modified organisms and, therefore, new authorisations thereof. Moreover, it is clear that the current procedure for the authorisation of genetically modified food and feed is not working properly. That is why I am in favour of this and any objections raised in relation to the authorisation of GMOs, and I voted accordingly.

name: Marie-Christine VERGIAT
text: In writing. The proof of the safety of GMOs is far from being made. On the other hand, the danger to many of them, both on the environment and on consumers, is proven. The precautionary principle should therefore prevail. However, the European Commission regularly allows them. The current procedure does not block the marketing authorizations for GMOs granted by the European Commission. As far as the cultivation of GMOs is authorised by the Commission is concerned, it can only be blocked by Member States on their own territory. However, everyone knows that pollen does not stop at borders, nor do insects that have become resistant. Together with a large majority of my colleagues, we have therefore just questioned the authorisation and renewal of authorisation for five GMOs, including the famous GMO maize Monsanto. I welcome this vote, even though it is essentially a political position to put pressure on the Commission to propose new legislation. But I have little illusions about what the European Commission will do. That is why I urge our citizens to take this vote to put pressure on and impose respect for the precautionary principle in the EU.

name: Miguel VIEGAS
text: in writing. We are in favour of this opposition, and any future objection to the authorisation of GMOs, as a matter of principle, but also with the purpose of showing the European Commission the need to amend the recently adopted legislation with a legislative proposal that will respect the right of an individual not to authorise GMOs for food on its territory.

name: Harald VILIMSKY
text: Writing. The resolution states that the Commission's draft implementing decision is incompatible with EU law and therefore calls on the Commission to withdraw its draft. As EFSA's risk assessment of cultivation is incomplete and the recommendations on risk management proposed by the Commission are deficient, I voted in favour of the resolution.

name: Udo VOIGT
text: Writing. The objections raised in the motion for a resolution to the placing on the market of the genetically modified products in question are well founded and necessarily suggest that the Commission rejects the relevant implementing decision. The motion for a resolution before us is therefore in favour.

name: Julie WARD
text: in writing. ‒ Labour MEPs voted against a ban on pest-resistant maize as we agree with EFSA's assessment that they are unlikely to pose risks to human, animal health or the environment, while limiting the need for use of pesticides. Moreover, the Commission attached stringent conditions for use of these GMOs in their authorisation decisions. I continue to take the issue of GMOs with the utmost seriousness, and will continue to oppose GMO use that is deemed harmful or potentially dangerous.

name: Lieve WIERINCK
text: in writing. – I voted against this motion for a resolution.  It is very important that Europe can ensure its own food supply. At the same time, this needs to be done in an efficient and sustainable manner. Science helps us in achieving this goal. It is important that those products that are developed in this regard are safe for both consumers and the environment. Such an assessment, research and consequent conclusions need to be based on scientific processes and empirical evidence. It is EFSA's task and responsibility to ensure that this is the case. This is the reason why it was established by the institutions of the European Union. In this case, EFSA has, upon request of the European Commission, duly assessed this GMO and concluded that it is safe. In my view, EFSA is the appropriate authority to give recommendations on these matters and likewise the Commission is the relevant authority to act on those.  Therefore I have voted against this proposal that would go against EFSA's judgement.

name: Jana ŽITŇANSKÁ
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported the European Parliament's objection to the Commission's implementing decision authorising the placing on the market of products containing genetically modified maize. My opinion on GMOs does not change, as there is not yet sufficient evidence regarding their wholesomeness. Likewise, we do not have sufficient information on their effects on the environment. That is why I agree with the view that, in the circumstances where the risk assessment is not thorough and complete, the European Commission has exceeded its powers in this implementing regulation, let alone acted in accordance with the precautionary principle, which is absolutely necessary in cases where human health may be at risk.

name: Marco ZULLO
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the resolution strongly calling on the European Commission not to authorise the placing on the market of genetically modified maize seed Bt11. It is a GMO designed to express the Bt protein that gives tolerance to the herbicide glufosinate ammonium. Glufosinate has been classified as toxic for reproduction, which is why it is one of the substances which meet the criteria for exclusion from placing on the market. We are dealing with a trade package designed to facilitate the greater use of this dangerous herbicide. The European Union Food Safety Authority (EFSA) has also recognised the toxicity of this GMO for non-target butterflies and moths, while ignoring impacts on other species such as ladybirds and aquatic insects. The cultivation of genetically modified Bt11 maize has already been banned in many Member States and must be banned throughout the EU in accordance with the precautionary principle. Since the beginning of my term of office, I have always fought to make Europe a GMO-free territory, and with this vote and with this resolution, I reiterate a dry no to the entry of gm products into European territory.

name: Carlos ZORRINHO
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of all objections under Rule 106 of the Rules of Procedure, because I agree with the opposition to genetically modified substances for which there are still no solid scientific results to allow them to be authorised without compromising public health.  Therefore, until the Commission proposes a new legislative framework for these substances, the European Socialist Group will continue in concert to support these objections.

name: Isabella ADINOLFI
text: in writing. \u2012 The Commission has asked EFSA to assess whether new evidence has emerged that would change the conclusions and recommendations of EFSA's scientific advice on the cultivation of genetically modified maize 1507. This resolution, considered that EFSA's cultivation risk assessment is incomplete and that the risk management recommendations proposed by the Commission are inadequate, calls on EFSA to withdraw the draft implementing decision. I voted in favour.

name: Tim AKER
text: in writing. – We in UKIP are concerned about the safety of GMOs for health and the environment, but we would prefer our national Parliament to legislate on this delicate issue rather than the European Parliament.

name: Marina ALBIOL GUZMÁN
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this objection to the marketing of seeds of GM maize 1507 (tolerant to the toxic herbicide glufosinate ammonium), because I am totally against genetically modified organisms and, therefore, new authorisations thereof. Moreover, it is clear that the current procedure for the authorisation of genetically modified food and feed is not working properly. That is why I am in favour of this and any objections raised in relation to the authorisation of GMOs, and I voted accordingly.

name: Martina ANDERSON
text: in writing. – I voted in favour of this GMO authorisation objection. It is absurd that the European Commission continues to propose authorisations of GMOs under a system which they themselves have admitted is flawed. It is essential that Mr Juncker listens to the European Parliament’s call for a new proposal and that the EU GMO authorisation procedure is overhauled completely.

name: Eric ANDRIEU
text: In writing. I am opposed to the cultivation of transgenic maize 1507, which has enabled EFSA to develop this interesting concept of "acceptable mortality" for polishing butterflies, precious species of lepidoptera. It is necessary to recall the immense risks to pollinators and our responsibility to protect them. Lepidoptera are the main nocturnal pollinators of flowers, they have an essential place in the cycle of nature.

name: Laima Liucija ANDRIKIENĖ
text: in writing. ‒ I have voted in favour of the motion for a resolution on the draft Commission implementing decision concerning the placing on the market for cultivation of genetically modified maize 1507 seeds. The European Food Safety Authority (EFSA) considered in 2005 that maize has no cross-compatible wild relatives in Europe and stated that no unintended environmental effects due to its establishment and spread are anticipated. However, situation has changed as teosintes, the ancestor of cultivated maize, has been present in Spain since 2009. Spanish authorities have informed the Commission about the presence of teosinte in Spanish maize fields, including very limited presence in GM maize fields. I supported this motion for a resolution as the risk assessment on the cultivation conducted by EFSA is incomplete and the risk management recommendations proposed by the Commission are inadequate. Having in mind also the fact that the draft Commission implementing decision exceeds the implementing powers provided for in Directive 2001/18/EC and that the draft Commission implementing decision is not consistent with Union law, in that it is not compatible with the objective of Directive 2001/18/EC of the EP and of the Council, I welcome the call on the Commission to withdraw its draft implementing decision.

name: Nikos ANDROULAKIS
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the objection pursuance to Rule 106 of the Rules of Procedure concerning the placing on the market of genetically modified maize seed in the 1507 series, because the assessment of the risks of cultivation was incomplete and the risk management recommendations proposed by the Commission were inadequate.

name: Marie-Christine ARNAUTU
text: In writing. Five objections are made by Parliament on permits to grow or import GMOs for maize or wheat.  Despite systematic objections, the Commission continues to issue permits for cultivation or import of GMOs. Parliament persists in objecting, to no avail, since the Commission does not take this into account. These objections help to unmask the hypocrisy of the majority parliamentarians (who maintain the Commission) in the face of EU totalitarianism. So I voted for these new objections.

name: Jonathan ARNOTT
text: in writing. ‒ Given that I have no specialist knowledge of the seeds concerned, and having concerns about the use of delegated acts, I felt it appropriate to follow the advice of officials and abstain on this matter.

name: Jean ARTHUIS
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this objection to prohibiting the importation and marketing of herbicide-resistant maize. Its use could have adverse effects on users and consumers.

name: Gerard BATTEN
text: in writing. ‒ We in UKIP are concerned about the safety of GMOs for health and the environment, but we would prefer our national Parliament to legislate on this delicate issue rather than the European Parliament.

name: Nicolas BAY
text: In writing. Five objections are presented by Parliament on permits for cultivation or imports of GMOs with different properties. The herbicide-tolerant GMO or two that will soon be banned is of little interest and, more importantly, is dangerous for biodiversity. Monitoring of the effects on nature is insufficient, the EFSA assessment is still as minimal and as contrary to food sovereignty. In this case, I voted for this objection to the marketing of genetically modified maize seeds 1507.

name: Hugues BAYET
text: In writing. The European Parliament, which I fully agree with on this issue, considers that this draft commission enforcement decision exceeds the enforcement powers set out in Directive 2001/18/EC. EFSA's crop risk analysis is incomplete and the Commission's risk management recommendations are inadequate. Moreover, the Commission's draft enforcement decision is not in line with EU law. We therefore reject this request.

name: Beatriz BECERRA BASTERRECHEA
text: in writing. I am not positioned for or against GMOs. I'm in favor of science. In the Union we have set up an agency for this type of task: the EFSA (EFSA) where the opinion of independent scientists who ensure and guarantee food security in the Union is reflected. Just a few months ago, more than a hundred Nobel laureates encouraged recognizing the findings of the relevant scientific institutions and abandoning campaigns against genetically modified organisms without sufficient scientific support.  Different products need to be analyzed on a case-by-case basis, and the debate should not be generalized or simplified.

name: Brando BENIFEI
text: in writing. \u2012 I have today voted in favour of objections to the placing on the market for the cultivation of two types of genetically modified maize seeds, including 1507. I believe that the current regulatory framework does not allow the Commission and EFSA to provide adequate assessments of the impact of GMOs. In the case of maize 1507, in particular, concern concerns the presence of the Cry1F protein which gives resistance to maize pyralid and some other parasites of the order of lepidoptes such as maize notation. There is a risk of damaging certain species of butterflies and moths by questioning efsa's concept of 'acceptable local mortality' of certain lepidopty species. I therefore decided to vote in favour of the objection, reaffirming the need for the Commission to draw up a comprehensive proposal on GMOs as soon as possible in order to carefully assess the environmental and health impact of these technologies and to establish a new procedure for their authorisation.

name: Xabier BENITO ZILUAGA
text: in writing. The use of transgenic seeds is part of a more substantive debate, which can be addressed from three angles: health, environmental and socio-economic impact. I voted in favour of the objection, because when we talk about allowing the marketing of transgenic seeds we talk about deepening this unsustainable model, abuses, royalties, dependence on agrochemicals; and socially perverse. We know that GENETICally modified seeds will not be marketed for the benefit of farmers, consumers, society, the environment but for the profit of a giant like Monsanto. A giant whose merger with Bayer will entail the creation of a monster whose consequences for the global agri-food system we are not even able to foresee.

name: Izaskun BILBAO BARANDICA
text: in writing. I would like to thank the rapporteurs of this report on the marketing of seeds of genetically modified maize 1507 for their work. This report, as well as the other four that we voted on today on various objections, does not leave anyone indifferent. I have been consistent with my previous votes in this area and supported the European Parliament's report which considers that the Commission's draft Implementing Decision exceeds the implementing powers con assigned to it by Directive 2001/18/EC.

name: Dominique BILDE
text: In writing. Despite systematic objections, the Commission persists in issuing permits for gmOS crops or imports. The aim here is to object to the marketing of genetically modified 1507 maize seeds for their cultivation by the manufacturer Dow Agro Sciences. The problems raised concern Glufosinate, which is to be banned in 2017 (ownership is therefore useless) and the destruction of biodiversity. So I voted for it.

name: Mara BIZZOTTO
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted against the objection to the marketing authorisation for the cultivation of genetically modified maize seeds 1507.

name: Vilija BLINKEVIČIŪTĖ
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this resolution, in which the European Parliament considers that the draft Commission implementing decision is not in line with European Union law because it is incompatible with the objective of Directive 2001/18/EC of the European Parliament and of the Council, according to which the precautionary principle seeks to appease the laws, regulations and administrative provisions of the Member States and to protect human health and the environment when genetically modified organisms are intentionally released into the environment for any purpose other than placing on the market in the territory of the European Community and genetically modified organisms are placed on the market in the Community as products in their own form or in other products. In its scientific opinion of 28 May 2015, which updated risk management recommendations to reduce the impact on non-target protected insects in the protected habitats of the lepidoptera group, the European Food Safety Authority said that sufficient data are currently available to assess larval mortality in relation to Bt maize in the context of overall mortality. Parliament considers that the cultivation risk assessment carried out by the European Food Safety Authority is not comprehensive and that the risk management recommendations proposed by the Commission are not appropriate.

name: Andrea BOCSKOR
text: Writing. \u2012 In accordance with the Hungarian Basic Law and the precautionary principle, I am opposed to the authorisation of GMO products, and I believe that the Commission's draft implementing decision does not comply with EU law, Whereas it is incompatible with the objective of Regulation (EC) No 1829/2003, which, in accordance with the general principles laid down in Regulation (EC) No 178/2002, is to serve as a basis for a high level of protection of human life and health, animal health and well-being, the environment and consumer interests in genetically modified food and feed, while ensuring the effective functioning of the internal market; The report calls on the Commission to withdraw its draft implementing decision, and I therefore voted in favour of the adoption of this report.

name: Franc BOGOVIČ
text: Writing. I also supported this objection against the use of genetically modified maize 1507, which, like genetically modified Bt11 maize, is resistant to maize moths (Ostrinia nubilalis) and Sesamia nonagrioides, and contains the PROTEIN PAT, which causes resistance to the herbicide glufosinate-ammonia. On the issue of GMOs, the profession also does not have a single opinion, so it is expected that Members and other publics should also share on these issues. I myself am a supporter of the precautionary principle in GMOs, so I find it completely unnecessary for such a sensitive topic as the registration of MAMs to be quickly passed through the process. We are at a sensitive moment when the institutions should have greater respect among themselves, and above all we must respect the will of the people, who are majority against the use of GMOs in Europe. I also personally wonder very much whether we really need this kind of GN-seed of maize. Glufosinate-ammonium, which is only authorised in the EU until 2017, is toxic for reproduction and the use of genetically modified maize 1507 would lead to an increase in its use and thus increase the risk to human health.

name: Biljana BORZAN
text: Written. ‒I support this report because it is a political message to the Commission that Parliament will not support any new approval of GMO cultures and products as long as the gm food licensing process is not reformed.

name: Mercedes BRESSO
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the resolution on the Commission's decision concerning the placing on the market for cultivation of genetically modified maize 1507 because by doing that I called on the Commission to withdraw its draft. Indeed, I believe that mostly the risk management recommendations proposed by the Commission were inadequate.

name: Renata BRIANO
text: in writing. \u2012 Genetically modified maize 1507 expresses the Cry1F protein, i.e. a Bt protein that gives resistance to maize pyralid and other parasites of the order of lepidoptes and american pyralid and also expresses the PAT protein, which gives tolerance to the herbicide glufosinate ammonium. Glufosinate is classified as toxic for reproduction and, therefore, the cultivation of genetically modified maize 1507 is prohibited in various territories. According to EFSA's GMO Expert Group, the possible evolution of Cry1F protein resistance is a cause for concern as the evolution of resistance could lead to changes in antiparasitic control practices, with potential harmful consequences for the environment. However, EFSA argues that the data currently available are not sufficient to frame the mortality of larvae related to the Bt toxin. However, EFSA's cultivation risk assessment is incomplete and the risk management recommendations proposed by the Commission are inadequate. Furthermore, the Commission's draft implementing decision is not in accordance with EU law because it is not compatible with the objective of protecting human health and the environment.

name: Steeve BRIOIS
text: In writing. This report proposes to adopt five objections to GMO cultivation or import authorizations, including from Monsanto. These objections highlight, in particular, the hypocrisy and dual discourse of the European parliamentarians of the majority groups who vote the opposite of what they promise their constituents. I voted in favour of these objections.

name: Nicola CAPUTO
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this objection today because I believe that EFSA's cultivation risk assessment is incomplete and that the risk management recommendations proposed by the Commission are inadequate. To date, the safety of genetically modified maize seeds 1507 has not been demonstrated. Serious gaps in the data continue to persist.  EFSA analysed possible negative impacts on non-target butterflies and moths, but ignored impacts on other species, such as ladybirds. The cultivation of this GMO would bring with it environmental threats that are difficult to manage and would undermine actions to improve environmental risk assessment for all GMOs, as unanimously requested by environment ministers in 2008. No GMOs should be authorised until democratic control of Commission decisions has been strengthened and correctly reflects the opinion of the majority of Member States, MEPs and European citizens. I therefore call on the Commission to withdraw the draft implementing decision.

name: Matt CARTHY
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of these objections to GMO authorisations. The European Commission has yet to propose a new authorisation procedure since its very weak proposal was rejected earlier this year.  In spite of the fact that the EP called for a new proposal, the Commission continues to authorise GMOs under a flawed procedure which they themselves have admitted does not work. For these reasons I voted in favour of the objection.

name: David CASA
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this resolution which calls on the Commission to withdraw its draft implementing decision concerning the placing on the market for cultivation of genetically modified maize 1507 (DAS-Ø15Ø7-1) seeds as the risk assessment on the cultivation conducted by EFSA is incomplete and the risk management recommendations proposed by the Commission are inadequate.

name: Fabio Massimo CASTALDO
