text: in writing. \u2012 The European Commission has asked the European Food Safety Authority (EFSA) to assess whether new evidence has emerged that would change the recommendations of EFSA's scientific advice on the placing on the market for the cultivation of genetically modified maize seeds 1507. The European Parliament resolution on the European Commission's draft implementing decision considers efsa's cultivation risk assessment to be incomplete and that the risk management recommendations proposed by the European Commission are inadequate and therefore calls for the draft implementing decision to be withdrawn. Together with the M5S delegation, I voted in favour of the resolution.

name: Lefteris CHRISTOFOROU
text: Writing. \u2012 The issue of Genetically Modified Organisms (GMOs) is particularly important and has occupied the European Union since the 1990s. We believe that the aim of the competent authorities of the Member States of the European Union should be to control and limit any negative effects of GMOs, while leaving room for research action in the new scientific field of biotechnology or even for use on the market, if the products prove useful and harmless.

name: Kostas CHRYSOGONOS
text: Writing. \u2012 The vote on the objection to the placing on the market of genetically modified maize seed of the 1507 series is a positive move for the benefit of the health of European citizens, since it concerns the strengthening of the procedures for monitoring the authorisation of genetically modified organisms. I therefore voted in favour.

name: Deirdre CLUNE
text: in writing. ‒ I rejected this objection as I support the EFSA and the European Commission's scientific GMO authorisation procedure.

name: Jane COLLINS
text: in writing. – We in UKIP are concerned about the safety of GMOs for health and the environment, but we would prefer our national Parliament to legislate on this delicate issue rather than the European Parliament.

name: Therese COMODINI CACHIA
text: in writing. ‒ It transpires that the risk assessment of cultivation conducted by EFSA is incomplete and the risk management recommendations proposed by the Commission are inadequate; therefore, I agree that we should withdraw the Commission’s draft implementing decision. I have consistently voted against placing on the market genetically modified organisms within the Community in line with the precautionary principle which I believe should be followed in issues related to human health and the environment of our citizens.

name: Javier COUSO PERMUY
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this objection to the marketing of seeds of GM maize 1507 (tolerant to the toxic herbicide glufosinate ammonium), because I am totally against genetically modified organisms and, therefore, new authorisations thereof. Moreover, it is clear that the current procedure for the authorisation of genetically modified food and feed is not working properly. That is why I am in favour of this and any objections raised in relation to the authorisation of GMOs, and I voted accordingly.

name: Andrea COZZOLINO
text: in writing. \u2012 Although EFSA has stated that the placing on the market of maize seed 1507 is not harmful to human health, food health, let alone biodiversity, I believe that the risk assessment is incomplete. It should be remembered that in the past the European Parliament has spoken out against a possible authorisation by the European Commission for the cultivation of transgenic maize and that GMOs are currently authorised in the EU by the Commission without the support of the opinions of the Committees of the Member States. In my opinion, it is a priority to take account of compliance with the precautionary principle, in bringing the laws, regulations and administrative provisions of the Member States closer together and in protecting human health and the environment, at least until the methods of risk assessment have been improved.

name: Edward CZESAK
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 I supported the opposition to the placing on the market of grains of genetically modified maize 1507. I believe that no novel food or genetically modified feed should be allowed under the current legal framework. This framework is one of the most restrictive in the world when it comes to assessing the risk to GMO crops and food, which makes me happy. I believe that this should remain unchanged, which is why I voted in favour.

name: Miriam DALLI
text: in writing. ‒ Parliament has also objected to the authorization of the placing on the market for cultivation of genetically modified Maize 1507 seeds. The European Food Safety Authority stated that 1507 maize has been developed for protection against specific lepidopteran pests such as the European corn borer. It also introduced the concept of a level of ‘acceptable local mortality’ of non-target lepidopteran species. My main concern is that the Commission needs to come forward immediately with a new legislative framework for GMOs. Voting in favour of this objection will ensure that the Commission commits to its work.

name: Michel DANTIN
text: In writing. This objection is intended to oppose the marketing of GMO 1507. I am against this objection insofar as the European Commission has complied with its mandate as part of its enforcement power granted by the European Parliament and the Council. I regret that this ideologically motivated resolution does not take into account the numerous precautionary measures voted by the European legislator on the authorisation to market new products, as well as the positive scientific opinion granted by the European Food Safety Authority. For these reasons, I voted against this objection.

name: Angélique DELAHAYE
text: In writing. I voted against this objection to refusing to market genetically modified maize seed for cultivation purposes. This objection is based on a charge made to the Commission: by this authorization it would exceed the enforcement powers assigned to it.  However, the Commission has complied with the existing GMO authorisation procedure. It has previously requested an analysis by the European Food Safety Authority (EASA) to verify that this maize seed is not dangerous to human and animal health, and to the environment.  This objection, in my view, therefore does not have to be and merely reflects a desire to systematically ban all GMOs, even though it is the responsibility of the Member States.

name: Marielle DE SARNEZ
text: In writing. Currently, genetically modified organisms (GMOs) can be grown on the territory of the European Union after the seed companies holding the GMO have obtained a marketing authorization in accordance with European regulations.  The European Parliament has chosen to use its power of objection to ask the European Commission to withdraw its authorisations on the use of genetically modified maize seeds 1507 tolerant of glyphosate, a herbicide classified as a "probable carcinogen" by the World Health Organization (WHO). In the future, the GMO authorisation process should not be reviewed without the support of a qualified majority of Member States and with the opinion of Parliament.

name: Angel DZHAMBAZKI
text: in writing. \u2012 I supported this objection as I am against the use of GMOs and the placing on the market of genetically modified goods. Furthermore, in the relevant case, there is no solid data on risk assessment and impact assessment methods that calls safety into question.

name: Georgios EPITIDEIOS
text: Writing. \u2012 We are voting in favour because we are against any attempt to liberalise GMOs and we even call on the European Parliament to take an even tougher stance and to block the Commission's attempts to allow them to be grown sideways within the Union.

name: Norbert ERDŐS
text: Writing. – Maize 1507 produces Cry1F protein, which, like the toxin MON 810, is a Bt protein. This allows it to protect itself against various Lepidoptera species. It also expresses PAT protein, which provides tolerance to gluphosine ammonium herbicide. The available scientific knowledge provide sufficient reasons to believe that inbred lines and hybrids from the maize line containing 1507 gene designs pose a risk to the environment. In view of all this, in accordance with the Hungarian Basic Law and the precautionary principle, I do not support the authorisation of GM products.

name: Jill EVANS
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this objection to the authorisation of genetically modified maize 1507 seeds because the current legal framework for authorising GMOs is not democratic. Decisions are made by the Commission without the agreement of the Member States. I represent Wales, which has declared itself GM-free, and I want that decision to be respected.

name: Eleonora EVI
text: in writing. \u2012 As a signatory to the objection resolution, I voted in favour, as I believe that until democratic control of the European Commission's decisions has been strengthened and correctly reflects the opinion of the majority of Member States, MEPs and European citizens, no GMOs should be authorised. In addition, with regard to the three GMO maize, there is still a lack of data and incompleteness of the risk assessment, complete analyses of non-target species, such as aquatic insects, risk mitigation measures are inadequate and impracticable, as demonstrated in the case of the definition of "safe haven areas" or "isolation distances from protected habitats" measures that have proved ineffective, or finally there remains a strong threat to GMO-free or organic crops. , endangered by possible contamination.

name: José Manuel FERNANDES
text: in writing. \u2012 The Commission's draft implementing decision exceeds the implementing powers provided for in Directive 2001/18/EC and the efsa cultivation risk assessment is incomplete, and the risk management recommendations proposed by the Commission are inadequate.  The Commission's draft implementing decision is not in line with UNION law on the protection of human health and the environment when deliberate releases are made into the environment of genetically modified organisms for any purpose other than placing on the market. I agree with the withdrawal of the draft implementing decision.

name: Edouard FERRAND
text: In writing. Vote for: despite systematic objections, the Commission persists in issuing permits for GMO crops or imports. Parliament persists in objecting, to no avail, since the Commission does not take this into account. These objections help to unmask the hypocrisy of the majority parliamentarians (who maintain the Commission) in the face of the totalitarianism of the European Union.

name: João FERREIRA
text: in writing. \u2012 Genetically modified corn of the 1507 sline expresses the protein Cry1F, which is a protein (derived from Bacillus thuringiensis subsp. Kurstaki) which confers resistance to the European corn drill (Ostrinia nubilalis) and some other lepidopteran pests, such as the pink drill (Sesamia spp.), cartridge caterpillar (Spodoptera frugiperda), black thread (Agrotis ipsilon) and southwest corn drill (Diatraea grandiosella), and pat protein, which confers tolerance to the herbicide ammonium glufosinate. The possible evolution of Cry1F protein resistance in lepidopteran target pests has been identified by the EFSA GMO panel as a concern associated with the cultivation of 1507 maize, as the acquisition of resistance may lead to altered pest control practices that can cause adverse environmental effects. There was no consensus among the Member States, so according to the perverse legislative framework in force, the decision falls into the hands of the European Commission – which invariably has a pro-GMO stance, even in the face of a lack of long-term studies of food toxicity and insufficient risk assessment. Reasons that were based on the position of refusal (or abstention) assumed by several Member States. This resolution objects to the authorisation of this Genetically Modified Organism (GMO). We voted in favour.

name: Luke Ming FLANAGAN
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour as I believe GMO crops are a threat to our existence.

name: Lorenzo FONTANA
text: in writing. \u2012 I am voting in favour of the resolution containing an objection to the commission's authorisation of a GMO.

name: Lampros FOUNTOULIS
text: Writing. \u2012 I am voting in favour of the objection raised in accordance with Rule 106 of the Rules of Procedure concerning the placing on the market of genetically modified maize seed in the 1507 series, because I am against any attempt to liberalise the movement of GMOs and I even call on the European Parliament to take an even tougher stance and to prevent any attempts by the Commission to allow their cultivation in the Union sideways.

name: Kinga GÁL
text: Writing. \u2012 The available scientific knowledge provide sufficient reasons to believe that inbred lines and hybrids from maize lines containing 1507 gene designs pose a risk to the environment. In view of all this, in accordance with the Hungarian Basic Law and the precautionary principle, I do not support the authorisation of GM products.

name: Ildikó GÁLL-PELCZ
text: Writing. – Maize 1507 produces Cry1F protein, which, like the toxin MON 810, is a Bt protein. This allows it to protect itself against various Lepidoptera species. It also expresses PAT protein, which provides tolerance to gluphosine ammonium herbicide. The available scientific knowledge provide sufficient reasons to believe that inbred lines and hybrids from the maize line containing 1507 gene designs pose a risk to the environment. In view of all this, in accordance with the Hungarian Basic Law and the precautionary principle, I do not support the authorisation of GM products.

name: Francisco de Paula GAMBUS MILLET
text: in writing. I voted against the objection concerning the risk management of insect-resistant 1507 genetically modified maize for cultivation purposes. Having considered the objection, I believe that there are sufficient checks and guarantees on the part of the European Commission as well as the Member States. We must always keep in mind that we must ensure maximum food security for European citizens but we must not be exaggerated which can have serious economic consequences for the sector.

name: Nathan GILL
text: in writing. ‒ I am concerned about the safety of GMOs and their impact on health and the environment, but I would prefer the UK Government to legislate on this delicate issue, rather than the European Parliament.

name: Tania GONZÁLEZ PEÑAS
text: in writing. The use of transgenic seeds is part of a more substantive debate, which can be addressed from three angles: health, environmental and socio-economic impact. I voted in favour of the objection, because when we talk about allowing the marketing of transgenic seeds we talk about deepening this unsustainable model, abuses, royalties, dependence on agrochemicals; and socially perverse. We know that GENETICally modified seeds will not be marketed for the benefit of farmers, consumers, society, the environment but for the profit of a giant like Monsanto. A giant whose merger with Bayer will entail the creation of a monster whose consequences for the global agri-food system we are not even able to foresee.

name: Theresa GRIFFIN
text: in writing. ‒ Today I voted against the objection pursuant to Rule 106 on the placing on the market of genetically modified maize 1507 seeds, as the risk assessment conducted by the European Food Safety Agency (EFSA) concluded that the cultivation of these GM crops is unlikely to pose a danger to human and animal health or to the environment.

name: András GYÜRK
text: Writing. \u2012 Corn 1507 produces Cry1F protein, which, like the toxin MON 810, is a Bt protein. This allows it to protect itself against various Lepidoptera species. It also expresses PAT protein, which provides tolerance to gluphosine ammonium herbicide. The available scientific knowledge provide sufficient reasons to believe that inbred lines and hybrids from the maize line containing 1507 gene designs pose a risk to the environment. In view of all this, in accordance with the Hungarian Basic Law and the precautionary principle, I do not support the authorisation of GM products.

name: Marian HARKIN
text: in writing. ‒ I supported this objection for a number of reasons. Firstly, I have concerns with the implementing decision by the Commission as it is may not be compatible with Union law, while there are concerns over the EFSA risk management procedure. More specifically, the achieved genetic modification of the maize seed can lead to a resistance to glyphosate. The Commission bases its argument for authorisation on the concept of a level of ‘acceptable local mortality’ of non-target lepidopteran species (butterflies and moths) which is considered by some to be a flawed interpretation of EFSA advice. In addition, there is the possibility of cross-contamination with an ancient maize variety that carries major risks for farmers and the environment. For all of the above reasons I voted in favour of the objection, plus the fact that I do not support the introduction of GMOs into the European Union.

name: György HÖLVÉNYI
text: Writing. \u2012 Corn 1507 produces Cry1F protein, which, like the toxin MON 810, is a Bt protein. This allows it to protect itself against various Lepidoptera species. It also expresses PAT protein, which provides tolerance to gluphosine ammonium herbicide. The available scientific knowledge provide sufficient reasons to believe that inbred lines and hybrids from the maize line containing 1507 gene designs pose a risk to the environment. In view of all this, in accordance with the Hungarian Basic Law and the precautionary principle, I do not support the authorisation of GM products.

name: Ivan JAKOVČIĆ
text: Written. ‒ I voted to object in accordance with Article 106. Rules of Procedure: placing on the market seeds of genetically modified maize 1507 because I do not support the use of genetically modified organisms on agricultural lands.

name: Jean-François JALKH
text: In writing. We are witnessing a balancing act: the Commission persists in encouraging the cultivation and importation of GMOs into our countries with its authorisations, and in sweeping away parliament's equally stubborn opposition.  All this is indeed of little use, and is not enough to absolve parliamentarians of their responsibility, which maintain the Commission by the Band in its omnipotence. Opposition to genetically modified maize seeds 1507 must be unanimous. True to my convictions, I voted for it.

name: Diane JAMES
text: in writing. – We in UKIP are concerned about the safety of GMOs for health and the environment, but we would prefer our national Parliament to legislate on this delicate issue rather than the European Parliament.

name: Marc JOULAUD
text: In writing. I voted against this objection to the renewal of the European Commission's approval of genetically modified maize seeds. By authorising marketing for cultivation or marketing purposes, the European Commission has duly complied with the procedure, taking into account the analysis of the European Food Safety Authority. It is also important to remember that genetically modified products found in French shelves or crops are approved by the French state and not by the European Union.

name: Barbara KAPPEL
text: Writing. I am voting in favour of this report. It rejects the Commission's proposal to allow a variety of genetically modified maize and forces the Commission to reconsider its proposal. The implementing decision is incompatible with Union law, the recommendation on risk management is deficient and genetically modified foods must be rejected in general from an Austrian point of view.

name: Krišjānis KARIŅŠ
text: Writing. \u2012 At the European Parliament plenary session in Strasbourg, I voted in favour of a resolution calling for the withdrawal of the Commission's implementing decision on the placing on the market for cultivation of genetically modified maize seed. I believe that the European Commission has sufficient resources in its mandate to investigate and understand the impact of genetically modified products on the environment and human health. Consequently, the European Commission has the power to come up with a better and clearer solution for the release and free trade on the European Market of genetically modified products or products containing genetically modified raw materials. The impact of these products on human health and the environment must be clearly investigated.

name: Ádám KÓSA
text: Writing. \u2012 Corn 1507 produces Cry1F protein, which, like the toxin MON 810, is a Bt protein. This allows it to protect itself against various Lepidoptera species. It also expresses PAT protein, which provides tolerance to gluphosine ammonium herbicide. The available scientific knowledge provide sufficient reasons to believe that inbred lines and hybrids from the maize line containing 1507 gene designs pose a risk to the environment. In view of all this, in accordance with the Hungarian Basic Law and the precautionary principle, I do not support the authorisation of GM products.

name: Gilles LEBRETON
text: In writing. I voted for this objection because it opposes the use of a GMO that is dangerous to biodiversity. The European Parliament agreed to vote on it, demonstrating that the Commission's initiative was harmful. I want France to regain its food sovereignty.

name: Philippe LOISEAU
text: In writing. The Commission persists in issuing permits for the cultivation or importation of GMOs. Parliament persists in objecting, to no avail, since the Commission does not take this into account. I voted for that objection.

name: Paloma LÓPEZ BERMEJO
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this objection to the marketing of seeds of GM maize 1507 (tolerant to toxic herbicide ammonium glufosinate), because I am totally against its authorisation. It is clear that the current procedure for the authorisation of genetically modified food and feed is not working with guarantees as to its impact on agricultural practices and food and I voted accordingly.

name: Petr MACH
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted against the Commission's decision authorising the distribution of GM maize seed.  I respect the right of states to ban seed on their territory, as about half of EU countries have done, but it is not right not to allow those states that do not mind this seed to be restricted.  I am thus behind the Commission's decision.

name: Andrejs MAMIKINS
text: in writing. ‒ I agree that the risk assessment of cultivation conducted by EFSA is incomplete and the risk management recommendations proposed by the Commission are inadequate and support calls on the Commission to withdraw its draft implementing decision.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: Writing. \u2012 I am voting in favour of the motion for a resolution calling on the European Commission to withdraw the draft of its implementing decision on the placing on the market for cultivation of genetically modified maize seed of the 1507 series, because it is complete and documented.

name: Dominique MARTIN
text: In writing. I voted for this text. Five objections are presented by Parliament on authorisations for gmOS crops or imports. The different properties of these GMOs pose several problems: carcinogenic herbicides, insecticides causing the destruction of biodiversity, etc. We are therefore in favour of these objections and, in this case, in favour of the marketing of genetically modified maize seeds 1507.

name: Georg MAYER
text: Writing. The resolution states that the Commission's draft implementing decision is incompatible with EU law and therefore calls on the Commission to withdraw its draft. As EFSA's risk assessment of cultivation is incomplete and the recommendations on risk management proposed by the Commission are deficient, I voted in favour of the resolution.

name: Valentinas MAZURONIS
text: Writing. \u2012 I support the EP resolution because it opposes the Commission's decision to authorise the marketing of genetically modified maize seed. I believe that, in accordance with the precautionary principle and the objective of protecting human health and the environment, decisions on the marketing of GMO seeds should only be taken once uncontested scientific evidence of their effects has been provided. Unfortunately, at present, risk assessments for GMOs production are not complete and unennutrs. For these reasons, I do not support the development, trade and cultivation of GMOs in the EU.

name: Jean-Luc MÉLENCHON
text: In writing. The report opposes the Commission's decision to allow the marketing of TC1507 genetically modified maize seeds. The TC1507 variety of the American group Pioneer confers resistance to certain insects (corn borer). But also a tolerance to herbicides containing ammonium Glufosinate, a substance classified as toxic for reproduction and whose use is banned on maize in the EU.  The report criticises the assessment by the European Food Safety Authority (EFSA). In particular, it points to the arbitrary introduction of the concept of an "acceptable local mortality" level of non-target lepidoptera species. This maize destroys insects other than the corn borer it is supposed to be specialized in. I vote for this text.

name: Joëlle MÉLIN
text: In writing. The Commission persists in issuing permits for the cultivation or importation of GMOs. Parliament persists in objecting, to no avail, since the Commission does not take this into account. I voted in favour of this objection, as did the other four.

name: Nuno MELO
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this resolution because I believe that the risk assessment of cultivation carried out by EFSA is incomplete and that the risk management recommendations proposed by the Commission are inadequate with regard to the cultivation of genetically modified maize seeds 1507.

name: Roberta METSOLA
text: in writing. ‒ I chose to support this objection on the placing on the market of genetically modified maize 1507 seeds as a more thorough risk assessment of cultivation by the EFSA is needed and the risk management recommendations proposed by the Commission are inadequate.

name: Louis MICHEL
text: Written. – At the beginning of 2016, there were some 7.4 billion people on our planet. In the most prudent scenario, the world's population will grow to 9 billion by 2050. Rapid growth of the world's population implies that demand for food and crops will also increase proportionately. Entrepreneurs in agriculture and food are facing important challenges. The existing agricultural area will have to be continued and better utilised. Innovation in agriculture will focus on sustainable and efficient agricultural techniques and plant technology will play a special role in ensuring food production. In that context, there are currently no convincing scientific arguments for objecting to a GM licence.

name: Miroslav MIKOLÁŠIK
text: Writing. – In 2003, Pioneer Overseas Corporation and Dow AgroSciences Europe Ltd submitted an updated notification to the competent authority of Spain on the placing on the market of genetically modified maize (GMO) 1507. However, this maize contains, among other things, the Pat protein, which guarantees its tolerance to the herbicide glufosinate-ammonium. However, glufosinate is classified as toxic for reproduction and is subject to exclusion conditions and should expire in 2017. In addition, the cultivation of GMOs of maize 1507 is prohibited in the territories of several Member States. According to a scientific study, it can have an adverse effect on the environment. I consider that efsa's assessment of cultivation risks is incomplete and the risk management recommendations proposed by the Commission are insufficient. The Commission Implementing Decision is not in conformity with Union law as it is incompatible with the objectives of Directive 2001/18/EC of the European Parliament and of the Council to protect human health and the environment in the event of the deliberate release into the environment of genetically modified organisms for any purpose other than placing on the market within the Community or the placing on the market of genetically modified organisms as or in products within the Community. I therefore support the resolution calling on the Commission to withdraw the draft implementing decision.

name: Marlene MIZZI
text: in writing. ‒ I have supported the decision to object to the placing on the market of genetically modified maize 1507 seeds because the draft Commission implementing decision is not consistent with Union law. In accordance with the precautionary principle, to approximate the laws, regulations and administrative provisions of the Member States and to protect human health and the environment when carrying out the deliberate release into the environment of genetically modified organisms for any other purposes than placing on the market within the Community and placing on the market genetically modified organisms as or in products within the Community.

name: Sophie MONTEL
text: In writing. Despite systematic objections, the Commission persists in issuing permits for gmOS crops or imports. Parliament persists in objecting, to no avail, since the Commission does not take this into account. These objections help to unmask the hypocrisy of the majority parliamentarians (who maintain the Commission) in the face of EU totalitarianism. So I'm voting for it.

name: Nadine MORANO
text: In writing. I voted against this objection to the authorisation of GMO maize 1507, which is the responsibility of the Member States or not, because it is based on the false argument that the Commission has exceeded its powers by authorising this maize.  Indeed, the Commission has fully complied with the procedure by asking the European Food Safety Authority for a study on the safety of the plant for human and animal health and for the environment. It then proposed this GMO authorization to the Council, which did not refuse it.

name: Momchil NEKOV
text: in writing. – I supported this resolution, initiated by the Committee on the Environment, Public Health and Food Safety, because I believe that without an effective control mechanism within the internal market which can ensure that products which are prohibited from growing in a Member State do not present a danger or conflict with that prohibition or risk its infringement, seed of that prohibited crop cannot and must not be proceeded with. For seeds of genetically modified maize 1507 (DAS-Ø15Ø7-1) there are effective prohibitions on its cultivation in the territory of 19 Member States. One of these countries is mine – Bulgaria.  The Bulgarian public is strongly opposed to the use of such crops. The Single European Market can only function when its terms are accepted by all its participants, without the risk of violating their legal and moral laws. This culture does not meet these conditions.

name: Franz OBERMAYR
text: Writing. I voted in favour of this resolution because the Commission's implementing decision is incompatible with EU law. The Commission is invited to withdraw its draft implementing decision.

name: Urmas PAET
text: Writing. \u2012 Not supported. Regulation of genetically modified products individually is neither effective nor feasible.

name: József NAGY
text: Writing. \u2012 I believe that until the cultivation of GM species and varieties proves to be of great environmental and economic benefit to European farmers, there is no point in taking even the slightest risk by authorising them. The greater part of the European public has not yet really accepted modern agricultural methods and their unprotused dangers, and I think we legismies should bear this in mind.

name: Victor NEGRESCU
text: in writing. ‒ I have abstained from voting on this motion for a resolution that authorises the placing on the market of products containing, consisting of, or produced from genetically modified maize 1507 seeds following a risk evaluation for human health and biodiversity.

name: Margot PARKER
text: in writing. ‒ We in UKIP are concerned about the safety of GMOs for health and the environment, but we would prefer our national Parliament to legislate on this delicate issue rather than the European Parliament.

name: Aldo PATRICIELLO
text: in writing. \u2012 With regard to the objection concerning the placing on the market for the cultivation of genetically modified maize seeds 1507, while noting the importance of this subject, I cannot fully support the proposal presented. I would therefore like to abstain.

name: Alojz PETERLE
text: Writing. \ i supported the objection because I believe that the Commission's draft implementing decision goes beyond the implementing powers laid down in Directive 2001/18/EC. The Commission should therefore withdraw the draft implementing decision authorising genetically modified maize. I also do not recognise GMO as part of the solution to the problems facing the agricultural and food sectors.

name: Marijana PETIR
text: Written. \u2012 Genetically modified maize containing the change 1507 expresses genes for cry1F protein, i.e. protein Bt, and the cultivation of Bt11 maize is already prohibited in Croatia and a whole host of other Member States. I am also concerned about the presence of the Pat protein, which can adversely affect reproductive health due to associated use with gluphosinate and may possibly adversely affect nature protection.  Namely, the theozinta, the ancestor of cultivated maize, has been present in Spain since 2009, which carries a high risk to farmers and the environment and is sufficient cause for concern. Theosine populations may become recipients of transgenic DNA derived from genetically modified maize MON 810, which is grown in Spain in some regions where theosin is spreading unbridled and genetic material may move to the theosine, which will therefore be able to produce the Bt toxin and allow greater survival capacity for maize hybrids and theosins compared to native plants. Therefore, as well as the fact that the Commission's draft implementing decision exceeds the powers provided for in Directive 2001/18/EC, nor does it comply with the objective of Regulation (EC) No 2001/18/EC. 1829/2003 for the protection of human health and the environment in cases where genetically modified organisms are intentionally introduced into the environment, I supported this resolution.

name: Tonino PICULA
text: Written. ‒ Glufosinate is classified as a substance toxic to reproductive health and is therefore subject to the exclusion criteria set out in Regulation (EC) No 2013/2013; 1107/2009, and approval for glufosinate expires in 2017. Therefore, the use of glufossants should in principle end in 2017.  The Spanish authorities informed the Commission of the presence of the theosine in Spanish maize fields, including a very limited presence in GM maize fields, and that the available data indicate that theosinta was also found in France. Theosine populations may become recipients of transgenic DNA derived from genetically modified MON 810 maize, thereby producing the bt toxin, allowing for greater survival capacity for maize hybrids and theosins compared to native teozinte plants. It is a scenario that carries a great risk to farmers and the environment.  In my view, this draft Commission decision exceeds the implementing powers provided for in Directive 2001/18/EC. Efsa's assessment of farming risks is not complete and the risk management recommendations put forward by the Commission are not adequate. The Commission's draft implementing decision does not comply with Union law, as it is incompatible with Regulation (EC) No 1009/2013. 1829/2003 and, in accordance with the precautionary principle, it is a rapprochement between the laws and other regulations of the Member States on the protection of human health and the environment when genetically modified organisms are deliberately introduced into the environment.

name: João PIMENTA LOPES
text: in writing. \u2012 Genetically modified corn of the 1507 sline expresses the protein Cry1F, which is a protein (derived from Bacillus thuringiensis subsp. Kurstaki) which confers resistance to the European corn bit (Ostrinia nubilalis) and some other lepidopteran pests, such as the pink drill (Sesamia spp.), the cartridge caterpillar (Spodoptera frugiperda), the black thread (Agrotis ipsilon) and the southwest corn drill (Diatraea grandiosella), and the PAT protein, which confers tolerance to the herbicide ammonium glufosinate. The possible evolution of Cry1F protein resistance in lepidopteran target pests has been identified by the EFSA GMO panel as a concern associated with the cultivation of 1507 maize, as the acquisition of resistance may lead to altered pest control practices that can cause adverse environmental effects. There was no consensus among the Member States, so according to the perverse legislative framework in force, the decision falls into the hands of the European Commission – which invariably has a pro-GMO stance, even in the face of a lack of long-term studies of food toxicity and insufficient risk assessment. Reasons that were based on the position of refusal (or abstention) assumed by several Member States. This resolution objects to the authorisation of this Genetically Modified Organism (GMO). We voted in favour.

name: Franck PROUST
text: In writing. I voted against this objection. Indeed, the European Commission has not exceeded its powers and has complied well with the procedure for authorising GMOs, thanks in particular to the opinion of the European Food Safety Authority. As a reminder, this proposal for market authorisation was forwarded to the Commission, which did not reject it.  Also, these objections used by political groups such as the Greens have no real effect because they relate to acts of execution. More generally, I would like to point out that France bans the cultivation of GMOs, even though it imports them.

name: Julia REID
text: in writing. ‒ We in UKIP are concerned about the safety of GMOs for health and the environment, but we would prefer our national Parliament to legislate on this delicate issue rather than the European Parliament.

name: Sofia RIBEIRO
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted against, since genetically modified corn 1507 expresses the Cry1F protein, which constitutes a Bt protein (derived from Bacillus thuringiensis subesp. Kurstaki), which confers resistance to the European variant of the corn drill (Ostrinia nubilalis) and other lepidopteran pests, such as Sesamia albiciliata, the caterpillar—american corn (Spodoptera frugiperda), Agrotis ipsilon and Diatraea grandiosella, as well as the PAT protein, which confers tolerance to the herbicide glufosinate-ammonium. Similarly, the development of possible resistance to CRy1F protein by the targeted lepidopterans is considered by the EFSA GMO Panel as a cause for concern associated with the cultivation of maize 1507, since the evolution of resistance may lead to a change in pest control practices which, in turn, may have adverse effects on the environment.

name: Frédérique RIES
text: In writing. It is an eminently political signal that MEPs gave this lunchtime by rejecting, by a large majority, 375 in and 193 against, the authorisation to market for the cultivation of genetically modified maize seeds 1507. This corn expresses the Cry1F protein, which confers resistance against corn borers and some other lepidopter parasites, as well as the PAT protein, which confers tolerance to the herbicide glufosinate, which is classified as toxic to reproduction. MEPs are also concerned about the risk of contamination with conventional crops or teosinte, the ancestor of cultivated maize. All these reasons justify that the cultivation of GM 1507 maize should be banned in twenty-one European states and regions: Wallonia (Belgium), Bulgaria, Denmark, Germany, Greece, France, Croatia, Italy, Cyprus, Latvia, Lithuania, Luxembourg, Hungary, Malta, the Netherlands, Austria, Poland, Slovenia, Northern Ireland, Scotland and Wales. Practically, this majority cannot win the decision. It is therefore the procedure for authorising GMOs at European level that must be reviewed, as commission president-elect Jean-Claude Juncker pledged to the European Parliament in July 2014. We're still waiting.

name: Bronis ROPĖ
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this resolution in which Parliament rejects the Commission's decision to authorise the import of 1507 seeds of genetically modified maize by Pioneer Overseas Corporation and Dow AgroSciences Europe Ltd. Parliament considers that the draft Commission decision is not compatible with Union law because it is incompatible with the objective of Directive 2001/18/EC of the European Parliament and of the Council, which aims to harmonise the laws, regulations and administrative provisions of the Member States and to protect human health and the environment.

name: Fernando RUAS
text: in writing. \u2012 As in the case of genetically modified Maize Bt11, in this report too I followed the indication of my group not to be opposed to the Commission's decision on the placing on the market for cultivation of genetically modified maize seeds designated by 1507 (DAS-Ø15Ø7-1) (D046172/00). Genetically modified maize 1507 expresses cry1f protein, which is a Bt protein, which gives resistance to the European variant of the maize drill and other pests. However, the May 2015 scientific opinion by the European Food Safety Authority (EESA) stated that currently the existing data are insufficient to prove that bt-linked larvae mortality cannot be framed in the context of overall mortality. Since ESA did not give any consideration contrary to the previously communicated, I considered that there was no reason for the Commission's decision to be rejected – a position subject to the necessary amendments in the event of new evidence so justifying it.

name: Lola SÁNCHEZ CALDENTEY
text: in writing. The use of transgenic seeds is part of a more substantive debate, which can be addressed from three angles: health, environmental and socio-economic impact. I voted in favour of the objection, because when we talk about allowing the marketing of transgenic seeds we talk about deepening this unsustainable model, abuses, royalties, dependence on agrochemicals; and socially perverse. We know that GENETICally modified seeds will not be marketed for the benefit of farmers, consumers, society, the environment but for the profit of a giant like Monsanto. A giant whose merger with Bayer will entail the creation of a monster whose consequences for the global agri-food system we are not even able to foresee.

name: Maria Lidia SENRA RODRÍGUEZ
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this objection to the marketing of seeds of GM maize 1507 (tolerant to the toxic herbicide glufosinate ammonium), because I am totally against genetically modified organisms and, therefore, new authorisations thereof. Moreover, it is clear that the current procedure for the authorisation of genetically modified food and feed is not working properly. That is why I am in favour of this and any objections raised in relation to the authorisation of GMOs, and I voted accordingly.

name: Siôn SIMON
text: in writing. ‒ Today, I voted against the objection pursuant to Rule 106 on the placing on the market of genetically modified maize 1507 seeds, as the risk assessment conducted by the European Food Safety Agency (EFSA) concluded that the cultivation of these GM crops is unlikely to pose a danger to human and animal health or to the environment.

name: Branislav ŠKRIPEK
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this resolution. I agree that the European Parliament is asking the Commission to withdraw its draft implementing decision on the placing on the market of GENETICALLY MODIFIED MAIZE 1507 for cultivation purposes. I consider that the Commission's implementing decision does not comply with EU law, since it is incompatible with the objectives of Directive 2001/18/EC of the European Parliament and of the Council, which complies with the precautionary principle with a view to approxibling the laws, regulations and administrative provisions of the Member States and protecting human health and the environment in the event of the deliberate release into the environment of genetically modified organisms for any purpose other than placing on the market within the Community or the placing on the market of genetically modified organisms as products or in products within the Community.

name: Davor ŠKRLEC
text: Written. ‒ I voted positively for this report, but this explanation of the vote is a criticism of the existing system of evaluation of the work of MEMBERS of the European Parliament solely on the basis of the statistical number of parliamentary activities potentiated in Croatia, which does not really reflect the actual quality and quantity of work, efficiency and most of all the success of parliamentary action.

name: Monika SMOLKOVÁ
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported the objection to the Commission implementing decision extending the authorisation for the cultivation of genetically modified maize 1507. However, maize 1507 contains a protein guaranteeing tolerance to the herbicide glufosinate-ammonium, which is classified as toxic for reproduction and its authorisation expires in 2017. In addition, the cultivation of this maize is prohibited in many countries. As scientific evidence suggests that released pollen may spread across borders, we should maintain the precautionary principle. Should such GMOs cross and spread, biological diversity may be compromised and may also pose risks to farmers. Since, on the basis of current methods of controlling the planting of GMOs of maize, we cannot guarantee a sufficient level of protection of human life and health, the Commission should not issue such GMO decisions. I am therefore of the opinion that the Commission should withdraw its implementing decision and submit a new legislative proposal that takes better account of the specificities of gmo crop cultivation.

name: Igor ŠOLTES
text: Writing. The European Parliament has successfully expressed its disagreement with the authorisation of five food and feed products from genetically modified organisms. These include the seeds of genetically modified maize 1507, which this resolution deals with. At the same time, the European Commission has rejected the call for a change in the authorisation procedure for the use of individual GMOs, as the European Parliament considers that the procedure is currently not democratic, as decisions are now being taken by the Commission. There is also a certain lack of data on the use and import of GMOs, as the Commission rarely shares data with the European Parliament in such cases. In relation to GMOs, which the Commission wishes to approve for use, research is currently being carried out by the European Food Safety Authority. As I believe that our food must be kept safe and healthy, I voted in favour of the Parliament resolution which seeks to ensure that the authorisation for use is not accepted.

name: Dubravka ŠUICA
text: Written. ‒2012 Taking into account the Draft European Commission on the implementing decision to market GM maize seeds 1507 (DAS-Ø15Ø7-1) for cultivation and since, according to Article 26.c(2) (2) of the EIZE, Directive 2001/18/EC the cultivation of GM maize Bt11 prohibited on the territories of certain Member States, including Croatia, the draft European Commission goes beyond its executive powers achieved by Directive 2001/18/EC. In addition, the Assessment of the Farming Risks of the European Food Safety Authority is incomplete and the Commission's draft on the implementation of the decision is insufficiently aligned with the legislation, regulations and administrative provisions of the Member States that would protect human health and the environment when intentionally introducing GENETICally modified organisms for any purpose other than placing on the Union market. I therefore support the European Parliament's objection and resolution on the Commission's draft decision on the implementing decision to market GM maize seeds 1507 (DAS-Ø15Ø7-1) for cultivation.

name: Eleftherios SYNADINOS
text: Writing. We are against any attempt to liberalise GMOs;

name: Tibor SZANYI
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the motion for a commission implementing decision on the placing on the market of genetically modified seed 1507 (DAS-Ø15Ø7-1) for cultivation. The resolution describes that Pioneer Overseas Corporation and Dow AgroSciences Europe notified the competent Spanish authorities in 2001 of the placing on the market of genetically modified maize 1507. This corn contains cry1F protein obtained from germs against pests and produces PAT protein, which provides tolerance to herbicides containing glufosineate ammonium. Since gluphosine is considered to be a toxic substance for reproduction, the exclusion criteria for substances already authorised should be applied when authorisation is to be renewed.  In addition, the scientific panel of EFSA genetically modified organisms identified the potential development of cry1F protein resistance to target moths as a concern for the cultivation of 1507 maize, because the development of resistance could lead to a change in pest control, which could have a detrimental environmental impact. In the draft Commission implementing decision, it sets out less isolation distance than EFSA clearly establishes as proven. For these reasons, I agree that the draft Commission implementing decision goes beyond the specific implementing powers and that efsa's risk assessment of cultivation is incomplete.

name: Marc TARABELLA
text: In writing. The European Parliament, which I fully agree with on this issue, considers that this draft commission enforcement decision exceeds the enforcement powers set out in Directive 2001/18/EC. EFSA's crop risk analysis is incomplete and the Commission's risk management recommendations are inadequate. Moreover, the Commission's draft enforcement decision is not in line with EU law. We therefore reject this request!

name: Pavel TELIČKA
text: in writing. ‒ The objection proposed by the Committee on the Environment, Public Health and Food Safety against the Commission´s proposal to place genetically modified maize 1507 seeds on the European market is part of a larger theme of systematically opposing GM authorisations on mainly procedural grounds and is not the right way to force the Commission to change the EU level authorisation regime. I voted against the motion to object to the proposal, as I believe that as long as there are no convincing scientific reasons to object to a GM authorisation, I will continue to follow the advice given by the European Food and Safety Agency.

name: Ruža TOMAŠIĆ
text: Written. ‒ I voted in favour of this objection to the placing on the market of GM maize seeds 1507 (DAS-Ø15Ø7-1). As I have already pointed out, some Member States have prohibited the cultivation of this GM maize, and since this decision may affect human health, the environment and agriculture in the Member States, I believe that each Country must have the right to choose whether to allow GM seeds to be placed on its market.  The effect of genetically modified products has been a subject of debate for many years, as various scientific studies show a high potential for a bad impact on human health and on the environment.  In my view, the Commission should withdraw its decision and that future decisions should be taken primarily in line with the provision of high protection of human and animal health and welfare and the environment, and that it is borne in mind that the European Parliament has never given authorisation to market GM products.

name: Romana TOMC
text: Writing. I supported the placing on the market for the cultivation of seeds of genetically modified maize 1507. In 2001, Pioneer Overseas Corporation and Dow AgroSciences Europe Ltd submitted a notification to the competent authority of Spain on the placing on the market of genetically modified maize in accordance with Council Directive 90/220/EC(9). The draft implementing decision is not compatible with Union law and the objective of Directive 2001/18/EC of the European Parliament and of the Council, i.e. in accordance with the precautionary principle, to approximate the laws, regulations and administrative provisions of the Member States and to protect human health and the environment when the deliberate release into the environment of genetically modified organisms is carried out for any other reason, such as placing on the market in the Community, or when genetically modified organisms are placed on the market as products or in products in the Community.

name: Estefanía TORRES MARTÍNEZ
text: in writing. The use of transgenic seeds is part of a more substantive debate, which can be addressed from three angles: health, environmental and socio-economic impact. I voted in favour of the objection, because when we talk about allowing the marketing of transgenic seeds we talk about deepening this unsustainable model, abuses, royalties, dependence on agrochemicals; and socially perverse. We know that GENETICally modified seeds will not be marketed for the benefit of farmers, consumers, society, the environment but for the profit of a giant like Monsanto. A giant whose merger with Bayer will entail the creation of a monster whose consequences for the global agri-food system we are not even able to foresee.

name: Mylène TROSZCZYNSKI
text: In writing. Despite systematic objections, the Commission persists in issuing permits for cultivation or import of GMOs. Parliament persists in objecting, to no avail, since the Commission does not take this into account. These objections help to unmask the hypocrisy of the majority parliamentarians (who maintain the Commission) in the face of totalitarianism in the European Union. I'm voting for that objection.

name: Kazimierz Michał UJAZDOWSKI
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 Genetically modified food can have a negative impact on humans, animals and the environment and should be controlled in detail in these respects.  I doubt whether the Commission should allow further types of genetically modified food and feed to be placed on the market. That is why I voted against the introduction of maize seeds in 1507 and voted against it.

name: Miguel URBÁN CRESPO
text: in writing. The use of transgenic seeds is part of a more substantive debate, which can be addressed from three angles: health, environmental and socio-economic impact. I voted in favour of the objection, because when we talk about allowing the marketing of transgenic seeds we talk about deepening this unsustainable model, abuses, royalties, dependence on agrochemicals; and socially perverse. We know that GENETICally modified seeds will not be marketed for the benefit of farmers, consumers, society, the environment but for the profit of a giant like Monsanto. A giant whose merger with Bayer will entail the creation of a monster whose consequences for the global agri-food system we are not even able to foresee.

name: Ernest URTASUN
text: in writing. – I voted in favour of the GMO import objection as I have decided to object systematically to any GM import authorisation. This was following the EP rejection of the EC proposal to renationalise instead of democratise the authorisation procedure. In relation of the GMO cultivation I also decided to object as all three maizes are Bt maizes: they all themselves produce the Bt toxin that enables them to be ‘pest-resistant’, meaning they are themselves toxic to the targeted pests – but also the non-targeted, even if those ones are protected or pollinate.

name: Ivo VAJGL
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the objection pursuant to Rule 106(2) and (3) of the Rules of Procedure on the draft Commission implementing decision concerning the placing on the market for cultivation of genetically modified maize 1507 (DAS-Ø15Ø7-1) seeds (D046172/00 – 2016/2920(RSP)). I voted in favour of the objection because I believe that maize 1507 seeds could harm ‘non-target’ species of butterflies and moths. Moreover, I find that the concept introduced by the European Food Safety Authority (EFSA) of an ‘acceptable local mortality’ of non-target lepidopteran species should be revised.

name: Ángela VALLINA
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this objection to the marketing of seeds of GM maize 1507 (tolerant to the toxic herbicide glufosinate ammonium), because I am totally against genetically modified organisms and, therefore, new authorisations thereof. Moreover, it is clear that the current procedure for the authorisation of genetically modified food and feed is not working properly. That is why I am in favour of this and any objections raised in relation to the authorisation of GMOs, and I voted accordingly.

name: Miguel VIEGAS
text: in writing. We are in favour of this opposition, and any future objection to the authorisation of GMOs, as a matter of principle, but also for the purpose of showing the European Commission the need to amend the recently adopted legislation with a legislative proposal that will respect an individual's right not to authorise GMOs for food on its territory.

name: Harald VILIMSKY
text: Writing. The resolution states that the Commission's draft implementing decision is incompatible with EU law and therefore calls on the Commission to withdraw its draft. As EFSA's risk assessment of cultivation is incomplete and the recommendations on risk management proposed by the Commission are deficient, I voted in favour of the resolution.

name: Udo VOIGT
text: Writing. The objections raised in the motion for a resolution to the placing on the market of the genetically modified products in question are well founded and necessarily suggest that the Commission rejects the relevant implementing decision. The motion for a resolution before us is therefore in favour.

name: Julie WARD
text: in writing. ‒ Labour MEPs voted against a ban on pest-resistant maize as we agree with EFSA's assessment that they are unlikely to pose risks to human, animal health or the environment, while limiting the need for use of pesticides. Moreover, the Commission attached stringent conditions for use of these GMOs in their authorisation decisions. I continue to take the issue of GMOs with the utmost seriousness, and will continue to oppose GMO use that is deemed harmful or potentially dangerous.

name: Lieve WIERINCK
text: in writing. – I voted against this motion for a resolution.  It is very important that Europe can ensure its own food supply. At the same time, this needs to be done in an efficient and sustainable manner. Science helps us in achieving this goal. It is important that those products that are developed in this regard are safe for both consumers and the environment. Such an assessment, research and consequent conclusions need to be based on scientific processes and empirical evidence. It is EFSA's task and responsibility to ensure that this is the case. This is the reason why it was established by the institutions of the European Union. In this case, EFSA has, at the request of the European Commission, duly assessed this GMO and concluded that it is safe. In my view, EFSA is the appropriate authority to give recommendations on these matters and likewise the Commission is the relevant authority to act on them.  I therefore voted against this proposal that would go against EFSA's judgement.

name: Jana ŽITŇANSKÁ
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported the European Parliament's objection to the Commission's implementing decision authorising the placing on the market of products containing genetically modified maize. My opinion on GMOs does not change, as there is not yet sufficient evidence regarding their wholesomeness. Likewise, we do not have sufficient information on their effects on the environment. That is why I agree with the view that, in the circumstances where the risk assessment is not thorough and complete, the European Commission has exceeded its powers in this implementing regulation, let alone acted in accordance with the precautionary principle, which is absolutely necessary in cases where human health may be at risk.

name: Carlos ZORRINHO
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of all objections under Rule 106 of the Rules of Procedure, because I agree with the opposition to genetically modified substances for which there are still no solid scientific results to allow them to be authorised without compromising public health.  Therefore, until the Commission proposes a new legislative framework for these substances, the European Socialist Group will continue in concert to support these objections.

name: Marco ZULLO
text: in writing. Parliament's resolution, which I voted in favour of, calls on the European Commission not to authorise the placing on the market of genetically modified maize 1507. Corn 1507 has been genetically manipulated to produce the Bt toxin, which is lethal to some parasites. EFSA, the European Union Food Safety Authority, recognised the toxicity of this GMO for butterflies and moths and warned of possible deficiencies in tests on malys 1507. The negative consequences of the introduction of such organisms into the wild, both for the ecosystem and for people's health, are unpredictable. If that is not enough, those who grow genetically modified maize can easily contaminate not only their neighbours, but also fields miles away, causing enormous economic damage to other farmers. The only way to eliminate the problem of GMO contamination is to ban GMOs. As spokesman for the 5-Star Movement, I believe in a Europe free from genetically modified organisms, which really protects agri-food biodiversity. It is right to aim for ambitious objectives when it comes to environmental, food and agricultural protection.

name: Isabella ADINOLFI
text: in writing. \u2012 The Commission has asked EFSA to assess whether new evidence has emerged that would change the conclusions and recommendations of EFSA's scientific advice on the cultivation of GM MAize MON 810. This resolution, considered that EFSA's cultivation risk assessment is incomplete and that the risk management recommendations proposed by the Commission are inadequate, calls on EFSA to withdraw the draft implementing decision. I voted in favour.

name: Tim AKER
text: in writing. – We in UKIP are concerned about the safety of GMOs for health and the environment, but we would prefer our national Parliament to legislate on this delicate issue rather than the European Parliament.

name: Marina ALBIOL GUZMÁN
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this objection to the renewal of the authorisation of seeds of MON 810 genetically modified maize because I am totally against genetically modified organisms and, therefore, new authorisations thereof. EFSA's assessment underscores the lack of data and the renewal of the authorisation to grow its seeds are based on a legal act that has proven dysfunctional (1829/2003). Moreover, it is clear that the current procedure for the authorisation of genetically modified food and feed is not working properly. That is why I am in favour of this and any objections raised in relation to the authorisation of GMOs, and I voted accordingly.

name: Martina ANDERSON
text: in writing. – I voted in favour of this GMO authorisation objection. It is absurd that the European Commission continues to propose authorisations of GMOs under a system which they themselves have admitted is flawed. It is essential that Mr Juncker listens to the European Parliament’s call for a new proposal and that the EU GMO authorisation procedure is overhauled completely.

name: Eric ANDRIEU
text: In writing. I object to the cultivation of the famous Monsanto 810 maize because it is in the process of allowing the mutation of a species of wild maize, teocinte, the ancestor of maize grown in Europe, present in Spain since 2009, which the Spanish authorities have found in both GMO fields and so-called conventional fields. We are in a typical cross-contamination situation.

name: Laima Liucija ANDRIKIENĖ
text: in writing. ‒ I have voted in favour of the motion for a resolution on the draft Commission implementing decision renewing the authorisation for the placing on the market for cultivation of genetically modified maize MON 810 seeds. As is stated in the resolution, both risk assessment on the cultivation and risk management recommendations are either incomplete or inadequate. What is more, the draft implementing decision itself is not consistent with Union law, as it is not compatible with the objective of Regulation (EC) No 1829/2003, which is, in accordance with the general principles laid down in Regulation (EC) No 178/2002, to provide the basis for ensuring a high level of protection of human life and health, animal health and welfare, the environment and consumer interests in relation to genetically modified food and feed, whilst ensuring the effective functioning of the internal market. For these reasons and also considering that the draft Commission implementing decision exceeds the implementing powers provided for in Regulation (EC) No 1829/2003, I welcome the call on the Commission to withdraw its draft implementing decision.

name: Nikos ANDROULAKIS
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the objection pursuance to Rule 106 of the Rules of Procedure concerning the renewal of the authorisation for genetically modified maize seed in the MON 810 series, because the assessment of the risks of cultivation was incomplete and the risk management recommendations proposed by the Commission were inadequate.

name: Marie-Christine ARNAUTU
text: In writing. Five objections are made by Parliament on permits to grow or import GMOs for maize or wheat.  Despite systematic objections, the Commission continues to issue permits for cultivation or import of GMOs. Parliament persists in objecting, to no avail, since the Commission does not take this into account. These objections help to unmask the hypocrisy of the majority parliamentarians (who maintain the Commission) in the face of EU totalitarianism. So I voted for these new objections.

name: Jonathan ARNOTT
text: in writing. ‒ Given that I have no specialist knowledge of the seeds concerned, and having concerns about the use of delegated acts, I felt it appropriate to follow the advice of officials and abstain on this matter.

name: Jean ARTHUIS
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this objection not to renew the authorization to import and market herbicide-resistant maize. Its use could have adverse effects on users and consumers.

name: Gerard BATTEN
text: in writing. ‒ We in UKIP are concerned about the safety of GMOs for health and the environment, but we would prefer our national Parliament to legislate on this delicate issue rather than the European Parliament.

name: Nicolas BAY
text: In writing. Five objections are presented by Parliament on permits for cultivation or imports of GMOs with different properties. The herbicide-tolerant GMO or two that will soon be banned is of little interest and, more importantly, is dangerous for biodiversity. Monitoring of the effects on nature is insufficient, the EFSA assessment is still as minimal and as contrary to food sovereignty. In this case, I voted in favour of this objection to the marketing of genetically modified maize seeds MON 810.

name: Hugues BAYET
text: In writing. The European Parliament, which I fully agree with on this issue, considers that this draft commission enforcement decision exceeds the enforcement powers set out in Directive 2001/18/EC. EFSA's crop risk analysis is incomplete and the Commission's risk management recommendations are inadequate. Moreover, the Commission's draft enforcement decision is not in line with EU law. We therefore reject this request.

name: Beatriz BECERRA BASTERRECHEA
text: in writing. I am not positioned for or against GMOs. I'm in favor of science. In the Union we have set up an agency for this type of task: the EFSA (EFSA) where the opinion of independent scientists who ensure and guarantee food security in the Union is reflected. Just a few months ago, more than a hundred Nobel laureates encouraged recognizing the findings of the relevant scientific institutions and abandoning campaigns against genetically modified organisms without sufficient scientific support.  Different products need to be analyzed on a case-by-case basis, and the debate should not be generalized or simplified.

name: Brando BENIFEI
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted today in favour of the objection to the renewal of the authorisation for MON 810 genetically modified maize seeds. I believe that the current regulatory framework does not allow the Commission and EFSA to provide adequate assessments of the impact of GMOs. In the case of MON 810 maize, in particular, EFSA's assessment of the seeds of this type of maize lacks some data leading to some doubts about the possible cross-contamination of an invasive plant carrying the Bacillus thuringiensis (Bt) toxin, used as a pesticide. In view of the possible great risks to farmers and the environment, I have chosen to vote in favour of the objection, reaffirming the need for the Commission to draw up a comprehensive proposal on GMOs as soon as possible in order to carefully assess the environmental and health impact of these technologies and to establish a new procedure for their authorisation.

name: Xabier BENITO ZILUAGA
text: in writing. The use of transgenic seeds is part of a more substantive debate, which can be addressed from three angles: health, environmental and socio-economic impact. I voted in favour of the objection because when we talk about allowing the marketing of transgenic seeds we talk about deepening this unsustainable model, abuses, royalties, dependence on agrochemicals; and socially perverse. We know that GENETICally modified seeds will not be marketed for the benefit of farmers, consumers, society, the environment but for the profit of a giant like Monsanto. A giant whose merger with Bayer will entail the creation of a monster whose consequences for the global agri-food system we are not even able to foresee.

name: Izaskun BILBAO BARANDICA
text: in writing. I would like to thank the rapporteurs of this report on the authorisation of seeds of MON 810 genetically modified maize for their work. This report, as well as the other four that we voted on today on various objections, does not leave anyone indifferent. I have been consistent with my previous votes in this area and supported the report of the European Parliament where the draft Commission Implementing Decision is considered to exceed the implementing powers provided for in Regulation (EC) No 1829/2003.

name: Dominique BILDE
text: In writing. Despite systematic objections, the Commission persists in issuing permits for gmOS crops or imports. The aim here is to object to the renewal of the approval of genetically modified maize seeds MON810 by the manufacturer Monsanto. The problem raised is the destruction of biodiversity, so I voted for it.

name: Mara BIZZOTTO
text: in writing. \u2012 I supported with my vote the objection to the authorisation to renew the authorisation for genetically modified maize seeds MON 810.

name: Vilija BLINKEVIČIŪTĖ
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this resolution, in which the European Parliament considers that the draft Commission implementing decision is not in line with Union law because it is incompatible with the objective of Regulation (EC) No 1829/2003, which, in accordance with the general principles laid down in Regulation (EC) No 178/2002, aims to develop a framework to ensure a high level of protection of human life and health, animal health and consumer interests with regard to genetically modified food and feed, while ensuring effective functioning of the internal market. The European Food Safety Authority and the Expert Group on Genetically Modified Organisms (GMOs) strongly reiterate their recommendations on post-market monitoring of the effects of MON 810 maize on the market, i.e. recommendations for more detailed information on sampling methods, to reduce the possibility of bias in the selection of questionnaires for farmers and to ensure that all relevant scientific publications are identified. In order to improve the list of samples of the farmers survey, the GMO Panel continues to reiterate the importance of national GMO cultivation registers and reiterates its recommendations to authorisation holders to consider how they can make the best use of the information contained in national registers and to maintain a dialogue on the production zones of MON 810 maize with the persons administering these registers.

name: Andrea BOCSKOR
text: Writing. \u2012 In accordance with the Hungarian Basic Law and the precautionary principle, I am opposed to the authorisation of GMO products, and I believe that the Commission's draft implementing decision does not comply with EU law, Whereas it is incompatible with the objective of Regulation (EC) No 1829/2003, which, in accordance with the general principles laid down in Regulation (EC) No 178/2002, is to serve as a basis for a high level of protection of human life and health, animal health and well-being, the environment and consumer interests in genetically modified food and feed, while ensuring the effective functioning of the internal market; The report calls on the Commission to withdraw its draft implementing decision, and I therefore voted in favour of the adoption of this report.

name: Franc BOGOVIČ
text: Writing. I also supported this objection. That genetically modified MON 810 maize provides protection against certain lepidoptera pests, including maize moths (Ostrinia nubilalis) and sesamia spp butterflies, but the EFSA's impact assessment on MON 810 maize does not contain cross-pollination of maize, which increases the risk to biodiversity. On the issue of GMOs, the profession also does not have a single opinion, so it is expected that Members and other publics should also share on these issues. I am a supporter of the precautionary principle in GMOs, so I find it completely unnecessary for such a sensitive topic, such as the registration of MAMs, to be brought through the process quickly. We are at a sensitive moment when the institutions should have greater respect among themselves, and above all we must respect the will of the people, who are majority against the use of GMOs in Europe. I also personally very much wonder whether we really need such GHG seeds of maize that will be resistant to glyphosate and glyphosinate. I understand that, for various reasons, we are not able to produce enough soy bee in the EU and we are obliged to import soy from countries where gms are mostly used. But I can't understand why we need GSO corns. I firmly believe that we can grow enough maize without this GMO seed. I therefore supported the proposed objection of a peaceful conscience.

name: Biljana BORZAN
text: Written. ‒I support this report because it is a political message to the Commission that Parliament will not support any new approval of GMO cultures and products as long as the gm food licensing process is not reformed.

name: Mercedes BRESSO
text: in writing. ‒ I endorsed this resolution on the Commission's decision renewing the authorisation for the placing on the market for cultivation of genetically modified maize MON 810 seeds because we have called on the Commission to withdraw it. I believe that the Commission’s draft was not consistent with Union law that ensures a high level of protection of human life and health.

name: Renata BRIANO
text: in writing. \u2012 Genetically modified maize MON 810 expresses the Cry1Ab protein, derived from Bacillus thuringiensis, which gives protection from certain species of parasitic lepidoptera, including maize pyralid and corn nottua. The placing on the market for the cultivation of mon 810 genetically modified maize seeds was initially authorised by commission decision. Unfortunately, there are still constant shortcomings in the implementation of post-marketing environmental monitoring; and EFSA is obliged to continuously reiterate its recommendations for monitoring, in particular the need to provide more detailed information on the sampling methodology, to reduce the risk of partiality in the selection of questionnaires for farmers, and to ensure the identification of all relevant scientific publications. However, EFSA's cultivation risk assessment is incomplete and the risk management recommendations proposed by the Commission are inadequate. Furthermore, the Commission's draft implementing decision is not in accordance with UNION law, since it is not compatible with the objective of ensuring a high level of protection of human life and health, animal health and welfare, the environment and consumer interests, while ensuring the effective functioning of the internal market.

name: Steeve BRIOIS
text: In writing. This report proposes to adopt five objections to GMO cultivation or import authorizations, including from Monsanto. These objections highlight, in particular, the hypocrisy and dual discourse of the European parliamentarians of the majority groups who vote the opposite of what they promise their constituents. I voted in favour of these objections.

name: Nicola CAPUTO
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this objection today because I believe efsa's cultivation risk assessment is incomplete. In addition, the renewal of the authorisation for MON810 genetically modified maize seeds threatens European organic and conventional non-GM farming. Under the new European rules on the use of GMOs, once a GMO is authorised for use in Europe as food or feed, Member States have the opportunity to decide whether or not to allow a given GMO to be used in their food chain (opt-out measures).  Unfortunately, Member States that have not chosen to use opt-out measures to ban the cultivation of specific GMOs on their territory have generally not implemented effective measures to prevent contamination of non-GMO or organic ma corn. Spain, for example, where most GMO ma corn is grown in Europe, has no specific rules regarding isolation distances, buffer zones or information required for adjacent authorities or growers. Experience shows that it is almost impossible for organic and conventional farmers to grow corn in areas where MON810 GMO ma corn is produced. I therefore call on the Commission to withdraw the draft implementing decision.

name: Matt CARTHY
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of these objections to GMO authorisations. The European Commission has yet to propose a new authorisation procedure since its very weak proposal was rejected earlier this year.  In spite of the fact that the EP called for a new proposal, the Commission continues to authorise GMOs under a flawed procedure which they themselves have admitted does not work. For these reasons I voted in favour of the objection.

name: David CASA
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this resolution which calls on the Commission to withdraw is draft implementing decision renewing the authorisation for the placing on the market for cultivation of genetically modified maize MON 810 (MON-ØØ81Ø-6) seeds.
