Whereas the EFSA GMO Panel strongly reiterates in vain each year its recommendations to provide more detailed information on the sampling methodology, the importance of national GMO cultivation registers and its recommendations to consent holders to consider how they may make best use of the information recorded in national registers and foster dialogue with those responsible for the administration of these registers where MON 810 maize is cultivated, I consider the risk assessment on the cultivation conducted by EFSA to be incomplete and the risk management recommendations proposed by the Commission to be inadequate.

name: Fabio Massimo CASTALDO
text: in writing. \u2012 The European Commission has asked the European Food Safety Authority (EFSA) to assess whether new evidence has emerged that would change the recommendations of EFSA's scientific advice on placing mon 810 on the market for the cultivation of genetically modified maize seeds. The European Parliament resolution on the European Commission's draft implementing decision considers efsa's cultivation risk assessment to be incomplete and that the risk management recommendations proposed by the European Commission are inadequate and therefore calls for the draft implementing decision to be withdrawn. Together with the M5S delegation, I voted in favour of the resolution.

name: Lefteris CHRISTOFOROU
text: Writing. \u2012 The issue of Genetically Modified Organisms (GMOs) is particularly important and has occupied the European Union since the 1990s. We believe that the aim of the competent authorities of the Member States of the European Union should be to control and limit any negative effects of GMOs, while at the same time remaining room for research action in the new scientific field of biotechnology or even for use on the market, if the products prove useful and harmless.

name: Kostas CHRYSOGONOS
text: Writing. \u2012 The vote on the objection to the renewal of the authorisation for genetically modified maize seed in the MON 810 series is a positive move for the benefit of the health of European citizens, since it concerns the strengthening of the procedures for monitoring the authorisation of genetically modified organisms. I therefore voted in favour.

name: Deirdre CLUNE
text: in writing. ‒ I rejected this objection as I support the EFSA and the European Commission's scientific GMO authorisation procedure.

name: Jane COLLINS
text: in writing. – We in UKIP are concerned about the safety of GMOs for health and the environment, but we would prefer our national Parliament to legislate on this delicate issue rather than the European Parliament.

name: Therese COMODINI CACHIA
text: in writing. ‒ It transpires that the risk assessment of cultivation conducted by EFSA is incomplete and the risk management recommendations proposed by the Commission are inadequate; therefore, I agree that we should withdraw the Commission’s draft implementing decision. I have consistently voted against placing on the market genetically modified organisms within the Community in line with the precautionary principle, which I believe should be followed in issues related to human health and the environment of our citizens.

name: Javier COUSO PERMUY
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this objection to the renewal of the authorisation of seeds of MON 810 genetically modified maize because I am totally against genetically modified organisms and, therefore, new authorisations thereof. EFSA's assessment underscores the lack of data and the renewal of the authorisation to grow its seeds are based on a legal act that has proven dysfunctional (1829/2003). Moreover, it is clear that the current procedure for the authorisation of genetically modified food and feed is not working properly. That is why I am in favour of this and any objections raised in relation to the authorisation of GMOs, and I voted accordingly.

name: Andrea COZZOLINO
text: in writing. \u2012 EFSA's analysis to date still lacks some data on possible contamination that could cause serious harm to farmers. I therefore believe that the risk assessment of the placing on the market of mon 810 genetically modified maize seeds is not complete and that the Commission's recommendations are not adequate. It should be remembered that GMOs are currently authorised in the EU by the Commission without the support of member states' committees and that MON 810 in particular is still banned in many EU countries. For these reasons, I believe that the current proposal is not capable of guaranteeing a high level of protection of human life and health, animal health and welfare and the environment.

name: Edward CZESAK
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 I supported the opposition to the placing on the market of GM maize grains MON 810. I believe that no novel food or genetically modified feed should be allowed under the current legal framework. This framework is one of the most restrictive in the world when it comes to assessing the risk to GMO crops and food, which makes me happy. I believe that this should remain the same, which is why I voted in favour.

name: Miriam DALLI
text: in writing. ‒ The renewal of authorization for maize MON 810 seeds is being objected to. The Commission approved MON 810 in 1998, but it has been controversial ever since. In the case of maize MON 810 seeds, cross-contamination of an invasive plant with Bt toxin has been found on EU territory. This might contribute to a decline in bio-diversity with specific risks to butterflies and moths. The cultivation authorisation renewal of seeds is based on a legal act that has proved to be dysfunctional. I have voted in favour because further knowledge and research is still needed to fully understand the extent of these GMOs.

name: Michel DANTIN
text: In writing. This objection is intended to oppose the marketing of the GMO MON 810. I am against this objection insofar as the European Commission has complied with its mandate as part of its enforcement power granted by the European Parliament and the Council. I regret that this ideologically motivated resolution does not take into account the numerous precautionary measures voted by the European legislator on the authorisation to market new products, as well as the positive scientific opinion granted by the European Food Safety Authority. For these reasons, I voted against this objection.

name: Angélique DELAHAYE
text: In writing. I voted against this objection to refusing to market genetically modified maize seeds for cultivation purposes. This objection is based on a charge made to the Commission: by this authorization it would exceed the enforcement powers assigned to it.  However, the Commission has complied with the existing GMO authorisation procedure. It has previously requested an analysis by the European Food Safety Authority (EASA) to verify that this maize seed is not dangerous to human and animal health, and to the environment.  This objection, in my view, therefore does not have to be and merely reflects a desire to systematically ban all GMOs, even though it is the responsibility of the Member States.

name: Marielle DE SARNEZ
text: In writing. Currently, genetically modified organisms (GMOs) can be grown on the territory of the European Union after the seed companies holding the GMO have obtained a marketing authorization in accordance with European regulations.  The European Parliament has chosen to use its power of objection to ask the European Commission to withdraw its authorisations on the use of genetically modified maize seeds MON 810 tolerant of glyphosate, a herbicide classified as a "probable carcinogen" by the World Health Organization (WHO). In the future, the GMO authorisation process should not be reviewed without the support of a qualified majority of Member States and with the opinion of Parliament.

name: Angel DZHAMBAZKI
text: in writing. \u2012 I supported this objection as I am against the use of GMOs and the placing on the market of genetically modified goods. Furthermore, there is no solid data on risk assessment and impact assessment methods in the relevant case, which calls safety into question.

name: Georgios EPITIDEIOS
text: Writing. \u2012 We are voting in favour because we are against any attempt to liberalise GMOs. We call on the European Parliament to take an even tougher stance and to block the Commission's attempts to allow them to be grown in the Union on the other side.

name: Norbert ERDŐS
text: Writing. – Domestic scientific evidence has shown that the persistent presence of MON810 maize in the ecosystem under investigation may have adverse effects. It produces 1500-2000 times more Bt-toxin than is released from dipel, a plant protection product containing Bt-toxin, during conventional plant protection during single treatment. Furthermore, the remnants of Bt plants decomposed more slowly than their non-toxin-producing lines. After harvesting, 8% of the toxin produced by the plant remained in the area and a significant part of this active toxin could still be detected in the soil 11 months later. In our view, the available scientific knowledge is sufficient reason to believe that inbred lines and hybrids from the maize line containing the MON 810 gene design pose a risk to the environment. In view of all this, in accordance with the Hungarian Basic Law and the precautionary principle, I do not support the authorisation of GM products.

name: Jill EVANS
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this objection to the authorisation of Monsanto GMO maize MON810 seeds because the current legal framework for authorising GMOs is not democratic. Decisions are made by the Commission without the agreement of the Member States. I represent Wales, which has declared itself GM-free, and I want that decision to be respected.

name: Eleonora EVI
text: in writing. \u2012 As a signatory to the objection resolution, I voted in favour, as I believe that until democratic control of the European Commission's decisions has been strengthened and correctly reflects the opinion of the majority of Member States, MEPs and European citizens, no GMOs should be authorised. In addition, with regard to the three GMO maize, there is still a lack of data and incompleteness of the risk assessment, complete analyses of non-target species, such as aquatic insects, risk mitigation measures are inadequate and impractical, as demonstrated in the case of the definition of "safe haven areas" or "isolation distances from protected habitats" measures that have proved ineffective, or finally there remains a strong threat to GMO or organic-free crops , endangered by possible contamination.

name: José Manuel FERNANDES
text: in writing. \u2012 The commission's draft implementing decision exceeds the implementing powers laid down in Regulation (EC) No 1829/2003 and is not in line with EU law, to the extent that it is not compatible with the purpose of Regulation (EC) No 1829/2003, which is to provide the basis for ensuring, as far as genetically modified food and feed is concerned, a high level of protection of human life and health, animal health and health, the environment and consumer interests, while ensuring the functioning of the internal market. I agree with the withdrawal of the draft implementing decision and the presentation of a new legislative proposal amending the Regulation in question.

name: Edouard FERRAND
text: In writing. Vote for: despite systematic objections, the Commission persists in issuing permits for GMO crops or imports. Parliament persists in objecting, to no avail, since the Commission does not take this into account. These objections help to unmask the hypocrisy of the majority parliamentarians (who maintain the Commission) in the face of EU totalitarianism.

name: João FERREIRA
text: in writing. The cultivation of MON810 GMO maize is prohibited in Belgium (Wallonia), Bulgaria, Denmark, Germany (with the exception of research cultivation), Greece, France, Croatia, Italy, Cyprus, Latvia, Lithuania, Luxembourg, Hungary, Malta, the Netherlands, Austria, Poland, Slovenia, Northern Ireland, Scotland and Wales. There is a lack of environmental monitoring after marketing, as the European Food Safety Authority (ESSA) notes in the 2014 Post-market Environmental Monitoring (PMEM) report, which refers to non-compliance with, for example, the implementation of bt-free refuges in Spain, as noted in previous years, with methodological limitations similar to those found in previous annual MPM reports on MON810 maize. In addition, ESA has arbitrarily excluded cross-pollination of maize from the scope of its scientific advice, thus not looking at all the potential risks to biodiversity arising from the cultivation of this GMO. It therefore considers this resolution that the risk assessment of cultivation carried out by ESA is incomplete and the risk management recommendations proposed by the European Commission are inadequate. We voted in favour.

name: Luke Ming FLANAGAN
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour as I believe GMO crops are a threat to our existence.

name: Lorenzo FONTANA
text: in writing. \u2012 I am voting in favour of the resolution containing an objection to the commission's authorisation of a GMO.

name: Lampros FOUNTOULIS
text: Writing. \u2012 I am voting in favour of the objection raised in accordance with Rule 106 of the Rules of Procedure on the renewal of the authorisation for genetically modified maize seed in the MON 810 series because I am against any attempt to liberalise GMOs and because I call on the European Parliament to take an even tougher stance and to prevent any attempt by the Commission to allow the cultivation of GMOs within the Union by side.

name: Kinga GÁL
text: Writing. \u2012 Domestic scientific evidence has shown that the persistent presence of MON810 maize in the ecosystem under investigation may have adverse effects. It produces 1500-2000 times more Bt-toxin than is released from dipel, a plant protection product containing Bt-toxin, during conventional plant protection during single treatment. Furthermore, the remnants of Bt plants decomposed more slowly than their non-toxin-producing lines. After harvesting, 8% of the toxin produced by the plant remained in the area and a significant part of this active toxin could still be detected in the soil 11 months later. In our view, the available scientific knowledge is sufficient reason to believe that inbred lines and hybrids from the maize line containing the MON 810 gene design pose a risk to the environment. In view of all this, in accordance with the Hungarian Basic Law and the precautionary principle, I do not support the authorisation of GM products.

name: Ildikó GÁLL-PELCZ
text: Writing. – Domestic scientific evidence has shown that the persistent presence of MON810 maize in the ecosystem under investigation may have adverse effects. It produces 1500-2000 times more Bt-toxin than is released from dipel, a plant protection product containing Bt-toxin, during conventional plant protection during single treatment. Furthermore, the remnants of Bt plants decomposed more slowly than their non-toxin-producing lines. After harvesting, 8% of the toxin produced by the plant remained in the area and a significant part of this active toxin could still be detected in the soil 11 months later. In our view, the available scientific knowledge is sufficient reason to believe that inbred lines and hybrids from the maize line containing the MON 810 gene design pose a risk to the environment. In view of all this, in accordance with the Hungarian Basic Law and the precautionary principle, I do not support the authorisation of GM products.

name: Francisco de Paula GAMBUS MILLET
text: in writing. I voted against the objection concerning the renewal of the authorisation of seeds of GM maize MON 810. Having considered the objection raised, I believe that there are sufficient checks and guarantees on the part of the European Commission as well as on the Member States. We must always require maximum post-marketing environmental surveillance, as it is necessary to always keep in mind that we must ensure maximum food security for European citizens but without seriously harming the producer sector.

name: Nathan GILL
text: in writing. ‒ I am concerned about the safety of GMOs and their impact on health and the environment, but I would prefer the UK Government to legislate on this delicate issue, rather than the European Parliament.

name: Tania GONZÁLEZ PEÑAS
text: in writing. The use of transgenic seeds is part of a more substantive debate, which can be addressed from three angles: health, environmental and socio-economic impact. I voted in favour of the objection because when we talk about allowing the marketing of transgenic seeds we talk about deepening this unsustainable model, abuses, royalties, dependence on agrochemicals; and socially perverse. We know that GENETICally modified seeds will not be marketed for the benefit of farmers, consumers, society, the environment but for the profit of a giant like Monsanto. A giant whose merger with Bayer will entail the creation of a monster whose consequences for the global agri-food system we are not even able to foresee.

name: Theresa GRIFFIN
text: in writing. ‒ Today, I voted against the objection pursuant to Rule 106 on the placing on the market of genetically modified maize MON 810 seeds, as the risk assessment conducted by the European Food Safety Agency (EFSA) concluded that the cultivation of these GM crops is unlikely to pose a danger to human and animal health or to the environment.

name: András GYÜRK
text: Writing. \u2012 Domestic scientific evidence has shown that the persistent presence of MON810 maize in the ecosystem under investigation may have adverse effects. It produces 1500-2000 times more Bt-toxin than is released from dipel, a plant protection product containing Bt-toxin, during conventional plant protection during single treatment. Furthermore, the remnants of Bt plants decomposed more slowly than their non-toxin-producing lines. After harvesting, 8% of the toxin produced by the plant remained in the area and a significant part of this active toxin could still be detected in the soil 11 months later. In our view, the available scientific knowledge is sufficient reason to believe that inbred lines and hybrids from the maize line containing the MON 810 gene design pose a risk to the environment. In view of all this, in accordance with the Hungarian Basic Law and the precautionary principle, I do not support the authorisation of GM products.

name: Marian HARKIN
text: in writing. ‒ I, along with the majority of the Parliament, supported this objection. I have concerns with the implementing decision by the Commission as it is may not be compatible with Union law, while there are concerns over the EFSA risk management procedure. More specifically, the achieved genetic modification of the maize seed can lead to a resistance to glyphosate. The Commission bases its argument for authorisation on the concept of a level of ‘acceptable local mortality’ of non-target lepidopteran species (butterflies and moths) which is considered by some to be a flawed interpretation of EFSA advice. In addition, there is the possibility of cross-contamination with an ancient maize variety that carries major risks for farmers and the environment. For all of the above reasons I voted in favour of the objection, plus the fact that I do not support the introduction of GMOs into the European Union.

name: György HÖLVÉNYI
text: Writing. \u2012 Domestic scientific evidence has shown that the persistent presence of MON810 maize in the ecosystem under investigation may have adverse effects. It produces 1500-2000 times more Bt-toxin than is released from dipel, a plant protection product containing Bt-toxin, during conventional plant protection during single treatment. Furthermore, the remnants of Bt plants decomposed more slowly than their non-toxin-producing lines. After harvesting, 8% of the toxin produced by the plant remained in the area and a significant part of this active toxin could still be detected in the soil 11 months later. In our view, the available scientific knowledge is sufficient reason to believe that inbred lines and hybrids from the maize line containing the MON 810 gene design pose a risk to the environment. In view of all this, in accordance with the Hungarian Basic Law and the precautionary principle, I do not support the authorisation of GM products.

name: Ivan JAKOVČIĆ
text: Written. ‒ I voted to object in accordance with Article 106. Rules of Procedure: extending the authorisation for GM maize MON 810 seeds because I do not support the use of genetically modified organisms on agricultural lands.

name: Jean-François JALKH
text: In writing. We are witnessing a balancing act: the Commission persists in encouraging the cultivation and importation of GMOs into our countries with its authorisations, and in sweeping away parliament's equally stubborn opposition. All this is indeed of little use, and is not enough to absolve parliamentarians of their responsibility, which maintain the Commission by the Band in its omnipotence.  It seems obvious to me to oppose any renewal of the MON 810 seed authorization. True to my convictions, I voted for it.

name: Diane JAMES
text: in writing. – We in UKIP are concerned about the safety of GMOs for health and the environment, but we would prefer our national Parliament to legislate on this delicate issue rather than the European Parliament.

name: Marc JOULAUD
text: In writing. I voted against this objection to the renewal of the European Commission's approval of genetically modified maize seeds. By authorising marketing for cultivation or marketing purposes, the European Commission has duly complied with the procedure, taking into account the analysis of the European Food Safety Authority. It is also important to remember that genetically modified products found in French shelves or crops are approved by the French state and not by the European Union.

name: Barbara KAPPEL
text: Writing. I am voting in favour of this report. It rejects the Commission's proposal to allow a variety of genetically modified maize and forces the Commission to reconsider its proposal. The implementing decision is incompatible with Union law, the recommendation on risk management is deficient and genetically modified foods must be rejected in general from an Austrian point of view.

name: Krišjānis KARIŅŠ
text: Writing. \u2012 Like I supported other resolutions calling for the withdrawal of the European Commission's implementing decisions on the placing on the market of genetically modified products or products containing genetically modified raw materials, I also supported this. I believe that the European Commission has more resources in its mandate to investigate and understand the impact of genetically modified products on the environment and human health. Consequently, the European Commission has the power to come up with a better and clearer solution for the release and free trade on the European Market of genetically modified products or products containing genetically modified raw materials. It must be clearly investigated whether these products are indeed harmful, do not damage human health or have an impact on the environment, and until the possible consequences are identified, these implementing acts are not acceptable. That is why I voted in favour of the resolution in Strasbourg at the European Parliament plenary session, which calls for the commission's implementing decision on the placing of genetically modified maize seed on the market for cultivation purposes.

name: Ádám KÓSA
text: Writing. \u2012 The MON810 corn line carries the cry1A gene, from which Bt-toxin - an insecticide protein - is re-written, making MON810 maize capable of controlling certain Lepidoptera species. Studies on the health safety of the product were not satisfactory. Longer-term studies would also be necessary to detect the possible toxicological and allergenic effects of MON810. In my view, GM products that have not been thoroughly tested in terms of health and environmental safety should not be authorised in the European Union. Scientific studies to identify risks are inadequate and I therefore do not support the authorisation of GM products in accordance with the Hungarian Basic Law and the precautionary principle.

name: Gilles LEBRETON
text: In writing. I voted for this objection because it opposes the use of a GMO that is dangerous to biodiversity. The European Parliament agreed to vote on it, demonstrating that the Commission's initiative was harmful. I want France to regain its food sovereignty.

name: Philippe LOISEAU
text: In writing. The Commission persists in issuing permits for the cultivation or importation of GMOs. Parliament persists in objecting, to no avail, since the Commission does not take this into account. I voted in favour of that objection.

name: Paloma LÓPEZ BERMEJO
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this objection to the marketing of seeds of MON 810 genetically modified maize because I am totally against your authorisation. EFSA's assessment underscores the lack of data and the renewal of the authorisation to grow its seeds are based on a legal act that has proven dysfunctional (1829/2003). It is clear that the current procedure for the authorisation of genetically modified food and feed is not working with guarantees and I voted accordingly.

name: Petr MACH
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted against the Commission's decision authorising the distribution of GM maize seed.  I respect the right of states to ban seed on their territory, as about half of EU countries have done, but it is not right not to allow those states that do not mind this seed to be restricted.  I am thus behind the Commission's decision.

name: Andrejs MAMIKINS
text: in writing. ‒ I also consider that the draft Commission implementing decision exceeds the implementing powers provided for in Regulation (EC) No 1829/2003. I agree that the risk assessment of cultivation conducted by EFSA is incomplete and the risk management recommendations proposed by the Commission are inadequate and support calls on the Commission to withdraw its draft implementing decision.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: Writing. \u2012 I am voting in favour of the motion for a resolution calling on the European Commission to withdraw the draft of its implementing decision on the placing on the market for cultivation of genetically modified maize seed of the MON 810 series, because it is complete and documented.

name: Dominique MARTIN
text: In writing. I voted for this text.  Five objections are presented by Parliament regarding permits to grow or import GMOs. The different properties of these GMOs pose several problems: carcinogenic herbicides, insecticides causing the destruction of biodiversity, etc. We are therefore in favour of these objections and, in this case, in favour of the renewal of the mon 810 genetically modified maize seed licence.

name: Georg MAYER
text: Writing. The resolution states that the Commission's draft implementing decision is incompatible with EU law and therefore calls on the Commission to withdraw its draft. As EFSA's risk assessment of cultivation is incomplete and the recommendations on risk management proposed by the Commission are deficient, I voted in favour of the resolution.

name: Valentinas MAZURONIS
text: Writing. \u2012 I support the EP resolution because it opposes the Commission's decision to authorise the marketing of genetically modified maize seed. I believe that, in accordance with the precautionary principle and the objective of protecting human health and the environment, decisions on the marketing of GMO seeds should only be taken once uncontested scientific evidence of their effects has been provided. Unfortunately, at present, risk assessments for GMOs production are not complete and unennutrs. For these reasons, I do not support the development, trade and cultivation of GMOs in the EU.

name: Jean-Luc MÉLENCHON
text: In writing. The report opposes the Commission's decision to allow the marketing of genetically modified maize seeds MON 810. The MON 810 variety developed by the American group Monsanto has an added gene - cry1Ab - that confers resistance to the pests that target this cereal - including the corn borer. And because of its use we observe the appearance of pyral, developing resistance to cry1Ab, which requires the use of products with more aggressive chemical formulas and in larger quantities. In addition, cross-contamination of an invasive plant with bt toxin has been found in the EU, demonstrating its danger to the ecosystem. I vote for this text.

name: Joëlle MÉLIN
text: In writing. The Commission persists in issuing permits for the cultivation or importation of GMOs. Parliament persists in objecting, to no avail, since the Commission does not take this into account. I voted in favour of this objection, as did the other four.

name: Nuno MELO
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this resolution because I believe that the risk assessment of cultivation carried out by EFSA is incomplete and that the risk management recommendations proposed by the Commission are inadequate with regard to the cultivation of genetically modified maize MON 810.

name: Roberta METSOLA
text: in writing. ‒ I chose to support this objection on the placing on the market of genetically modified maize MON 810 seeds as a more thorough risk assessment of cultivation by the EFSA is needed and the risk management recommendations proposed by the Commission are inadequate.

name: Louis MICHEL
text: Written. – At the beginning of 2016, there were some 7.4 billion people on our planet. In the most prudent scenario, the world's population will grow to 9 billion by 2050. Rapid growth of the world's population implies that demand for food and crops will also increase proportionately. Entrepreneurs in agriculture and food are facing important challenges. The existing agricultural area will have to be continued and better utilised. Innovation in agriculture will focus on sustainable and efficient agricultural techniques and plant technology will play a special role in ensuring food production. In that context, there are currently no convincing scientific arguments for objecting to a GM licence.

name: Marlene MIZZI
text: in writing. ‒ I have supported the decision to object to the placing on the market of genetically modified maize MON 810 seeds because the draft Commission implementing decision is not consistent with Union law. In accordance with the precautionary principle, to approximate the laws, regulations and administrative provisions of the Member States and to protect human health and the environment when carrying out the deliberate release into the environment of genetically modified organisms for any other purposes than placing on the market within the Community and placing on the market genetically modified organisms as or in products within the Community.

name: Sophie MONTEL
text: In writing. Despite systematic objections, the Commission persists in issuing permits for gmOS crops or imports. Parliament persists in objecting, to no avail, since the Commission does not take this into account. These objections help to unmask the hypocrisy of the majority parliamentarians (who maintain the Commission) in the face of EU totalitarianism. So I'm voting for it.

name: Nadine MORANO
text: In writing. I voted against this objection to the renewal of the authorisation of GMO maize MON 810, which or does not have the responsibility of the Member States, because it is based on the false argument that the Commission has exceeded its powers by authorising this maize. Indeed, the Commission has fully complied with the procedure by asking the European Food Safety Authority for a study on the safety of the plant for human and animal health and for the environment. It then proposed this GMO authorization to the Council, which did not refuse it.

name: József NAGY
text: Writing. \u2012 I believe that until the cultivation of GM species and varieties proves to be of great environmental and economic benefit to European farmers, there is no point in taking even the slightest risk by authorising them. The greater part of the European public has not yet really accepted modern agricultural methods and their unprotused dangers, and I think we legismies should bear this in mind.

name: Victor NEGRESCU
text: in writing. ‒ I have abstained from voting on this motion for a resolution that authorises the placing on the market of products containing, consisting of, or produced from genetically modified maize MON 810 seeds following a risk evaluation to human health and biodiversity.

name: Momchil NEKOV
text: in writing. – I supported this resolution, initiated by the Committee on the Environment, Public Health and Food Safety, because I believe that without an effective control mechanism within the internal market which can ensure that products which are prohibited from growing in a Member State do not present a danger or conflict with that prohibition or risk its infringement, seed of that prohibited crop cannot and must not be proceeded with. Cultivation of genetically modified maize MON 810 is prohibited in 19 EU Member States. One of these countries is mine - Bulgaria.  The Bulgarian public is strongly opposed to the use of such crops. The Single European Market can only function when its terms are accepted by all its participants, without the risk of violating their legal and moral laws. This culture does not meet these conditions.

name: Franz OBERMAYR
text: Writing. I voted in favour of this resolution because EFSA's risk assessment of cultivation is incomplete and the recommendations on risk management proposed by the Commission are deficient. The Commission is invited to withdraw the implementing decision.

name: Urmas PAET
text: Writing. \u2012 Not supported. Regulation of genetically modified products individually is neither effective nor feasible.

name: Margot PARKER
text: in writing. ‒ We in UKIP are concerned about the safety of GMOs for health and the environment, but we would prefer our national Parliament to legislate on this delicate issue rather than the European Parliament.

name: Aldo PATRICIELLO
text: in writing. \u2012 While taking into account the aspects contained in the objection tabled concerning the renewal of the authorisation for MON 810 genetically modified maize seeds, I do not feel able to fully support the proposal. I would therefore like to abstain.

name: Alojz PETERLE
text: Writing. \ i supported the objection because I believe that the Commission's draft implementing decision goes beyond the implementing powers laid down in Regulation (EC) No 1829/2003. The Commission should withdraw the draft implementing decision authorising genetically modified maize as there is no basis for ensuring a high level of protection of human life and health, animal health and welfare, the environment and consumer interests with regard to genetically modified food and feed, while ensuring the unso tmable functioning of the internal market. I also do not recognise GMO as part of the solution to the problems facing the agricultural and food sectors.

name: Marijana PETIR
text: Written. ‒ I supported this resolution since I believe that the draft implementing decision exceeds the powers provided for in Regulation (EC) No 2012/2013. 1829/2003 and is not even linked to its objectives of anticipating the basis for a high level of protection of human health and life, animal health and welfare, the environment and consumer interests in relation to genetically modified food and feed and at the same time the effective functioning of the internal market.  Recall, the EFSA GMO Commission reiterates its recommendations for monitoring the environmental impact on the marketing of MON 810 maize every year, and it should be borne in mind that EFSA itself has exempted cross-pollination in maize in its scientific opinion, thus overlooking potential risks to biodiversity.

name: Tonino PICULA
text: Written. ‒EFSA arbitrarily exempted cross-pollination in maize in its scientific opinion on MON 810 maize, thereby overlooking potential biodiversity risks. Theosine populations may become recipients of transgenic DNA derived from MON 810, which is grown in Spain in some regions where theosination is spreading rampantly, thereby producing bt toxin, and allowing greater survival capacity for maize hybrids and teozinte hybrids compared to native teozinte plants – such a scenario has serious risks to farmers and the environment. Every year, the EFSA GMO Commission reiterates in vain its recommendations for monitoring the environmental impact following the marketing of MON 810 maize and the importance of national GMO farming registers.  I believe that the Commission's draft implementing decision exceeds the implementing powers provided for in the Regulation. Efsa's assessment of farming risks is not complete and the risk management recommendations put forward by the Commission are not appropriate. The Commission's draft implementing decision is incompatible with Union law, as it is incompatible with the objective of the Regulation – to provide for a high level of protection of human health and life, animal health and welfare, the environment and consumer interests with regard to GENETICally modified food and feed, while ensuring the effective functioning of the internal market.

name: João PIMENTA LOPES
text: in writing. The cultivation of MON810 GMO maize is prohibited in Belgium (Wallonia), Bulgaria, Denmark, Germany (with the exception of research cultivation), Greece, France, Croatia, Italy, Cyprus, Latvia, Lithuania, Luxembourg, Hungary, Malta, the Netherlands, Austria, Poland, Slovenia, Northern Ireland, Scotland and Wales. There is a lack of environmental monitoring after marketing, as the European Food Safety Authority (ESSA) notes in the 2014 Post-market Environmental Monitoring (PMEM) report, which refers to non-compliance with, for example, the implementation of bt-free refuges in Spain, as noted in previous years, with methodological limitations similar to those found in previous annual MPM reports on MON810 maize. In addition, ESA has arbitrarily excluded cross-pollination of maize from the scope of its scientific advice, thus not looking at all the potential risks to biodiversity arising from the cultivation of this GMO. It therefore considers that the risk assessment on cultivation carried out by ESA is incomplete and the risk management recommendations proposed by the European Commission are inadequate. We voted in favour.

name: Franck PROUST
text: In writing. I voted against this objection. Indeed, the European Commission has not exceeded its powers and has complied well with the procedure for authorising GMOs, thanks in particular to the opinion of the European Food Safety Authority. As a reminder, this proposal for marketing authorization was forwarded to the Commission, which did not reject it. Also, these objections used by political groups such as the Greens have no real effect because they relate to acts of execution. More generally, I would like to point out that France bans the cultivation of GMOs, even though it imports them.

name: Julia REID
text: in writing. ‒ We in UKIP are concerned about the safety of GMOs for health and the environment, but we would prefer our national Parliament to legislate on this delicate issue rather than the European Parliament.

name: Sofia RIBEIRO
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted against, since genetically modified maize MON 810, as described in the application, expresses the Cry1Ab protein, derived from Bacillus thuringiensis subsp. kurstaki, which provides protection against certain pests of lepidopteran insects, including the European variant of the corn drill (Ostrinia nubilalis ) (ECB) and Sesamia spp. Taking into account the terms of Article 26c(2) of Directive 2001/18/EC, the cultivation of genetically modified maize MON 810 is prohibited in the following territories: Wallonia Region (Belgium); Bulgaria; Denmark; Germany (except for research purposes); Greece; France; Croatia; Italy; Cyprus; Latvia; Lithuania; Luxembourg; Hungary; The people of the Netherlands; Austria; Poland; Slovenia; Northern Ireland (United Kingdom); Scotland (United Kingdom); Wales (United Kingdom). In its scientific opinion adopted on 28 May 2015, updating risk management recommendations to limit exposure of non-target lepidopterans with conservation problems in protected habitats, ESA indicated that 'currently available data are not sufficient to allow bt-related larvae mortality to be inserted into the context of overall mortality'.

name: Frédérique RIES
text: In writing. Like 45 other MEPs, I abstained on the renewal of GMO maize MON810. I obviously share the concerns expressed by the majority of the plenary about the shortcomings of the current GMO authorisation procedure at EU level. This is why I supported the other three objections to the authorisation of the cultivation of new GMOs (two maize and one cotton) without any real scientific assessment of so-called "stacked" GMOs containing several transgenes. But MON810 maize is an exception. The only GMO grown in Europe since 1998, it represents less than 0.10% of agricultural land, and I felt that it was not necessary for the European Parliament to deliver a negative 'at this point' message with regard to a technique that is certainly imperfect, but whose negative impact on health has never been demonstrated.  On the other hand, there are real concerns about the lack of concrete measures taken by Spain, where most GM maize is grown, in relation to protection distances, buffer zones or mandatory information for neighbouring authorities or farms. A matter of first and foremost a national one.

name: Bronis ROPĖ
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report, which opposes the decision by the European Commission to renew the authorisation to grow genetically modified maize MON 810 by Monsanto Europe S. A. The European Parliament considers that the draft Commission implementing decision is not compatible with Union law because it is incompatible with the objective of Regulation (EC) No 1829/2003, which, in accordance with the general principles laid down in Regulation (EC) No 178/2002, aims to develop a framework to ensure a high level of protection of human life and health, animal health and consumer interests with regard to genetically modified food and feed, while ensuring effective functioning of the internal market.

name: Fernando RUAS
text: in writing. \u2012 The case of genetically modified maize called MON 810 (MON-ØØ81Ø-6) (D046170/00) is a case similar to those described in the previously voted reports (Bt11 and 1507 seeds). In this vote too, I followed my group's statement that it was not opposed to the Commission's decision. This type of genetically modified maize expresses the Cry1Ab protein, which provides protection against certain pests of lepidopteran insects, including the European variant of the corn drill (Ostrinia nubilalis).  In July 2016, the Commission asked the European Food Safety Authority (ESA) to assess, by the end of September 2016, whether, on the basis of existing scientific literature and any other relevant information, new elements have emerged that could alter the findings and recommendations of ESA scientific advice on the cultivation of genetically modified maizes MON 810, Bt11, 1507 and GA21. ESA has not made statements contrary to those submitted so far, so I do not believe there is any reason for the Commission's decision, as regards the renewal of the authorisation, to be rejected. My position is, of course, subject to the amendments which it deems appropriate if new scientific evidence emerges to justify it.

name: Lola SÁNCHEZ CALDENTEY
text: in writing. The use of transgenic seeds is part of a more substantive debate, which can be addressed from three angles: health, environmental and socio-economic impact. I voted in favour of the objection because when we talk about allowing the marketing of transgenic seeds we talk about deepening this unsustainable model, abuses, royalties, dependence on agrochemicals; and socially perverse. We know that GENETICally modified seeds will not be marketed for the benefit of farmers, consumers, society, the environment but for the profit of a giant like Monsanto. A giant whose merger with Bayer will entail the creation of a monster whose consequences for the global agri-food system we are not even able to foresee.

name: Maria Lidia SENRA RODRÍGUEZ
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this objection to the renewal of the authorisation of seeds of MON 810 genetically modified maize because I am totally against genetically modified organisms and, therefore, new authorisations thereof. EFSA's assessment underscores the lack of data and the renewal of the authorisation to grow its seeds are based on a legal act that has proven dysfunctional (1829/2003). Moreover, it is clear that the current procedure for the authorisation of genetically modified food and feed is not working properly. That is why I am in favour of this and any objections raised in relation to the authorisation of GMOs, and I voted accordingly.

name: Siôn SIMON
text: in writing. ‒ Today, I voted against the objection pursuant to Rule 106 on the placing on the market of genetically modified maize MON 810 seeds, as the risk assessment conducted by the European Food Safety Agency (EFSA) concluded that the cultivation of these GM crops is unlikely to pose a danger to human and animal health or to the environment.

name: Branislav ŠKRIPEK
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of adopting this resolution. I agree that the European Parliament is asking the Commission to withdraw its draft implementing decision on the renewal of the marketing authorisation for genetically modified maize MON 810 for cultivation purposes. I agree with the position that the Commission's draft implementing decision does not comply with Union law, whereas it is incompatible with the objective of Regulation (EC) No 1829/2003, which, according to the general principles laid down in Regulation (EC) No 178/2002, is to provide the basis for ensuring a high level of protection of human life and health, animal health and welfare, the environment and the interests of consumers with regard to genetically modified food and feed, while ensuring the effective functioning of the internal market.

name: Davor ŠKRLEC
text: Written. ‒ I voted positively for this report, but this explanation of the vote is a criticism of the existing system of evaluation of the work of MEMBERS of the European Parliament solely on the basis of the statistical number of parliamentary activities potentiated in Croatia, which does not really reflect the actual quality and quantity of work, efficiency and most of all the success of parliamentary action.

name: Monika SMOLKOVÁ
text: Writing. \u2012 I agreed to oppose the Commission's implementing decision to re-authorise the cultivation of GM maize. In fact, I believe that we should stick to the principle that, until we have sufficient information on the effects of such crops on human health or the environment, they should not be grown at all on the territory of Europe. In the present case, Monsanto Europe has submitted three applications for renewal of the authorisation of existing food, food ingredients and feed produced from genetically modified maize. The cultivation of this particular GENETICALLY MODIFIED MAIZE MON 810 is prohibited in several territories of EU Member States, including Austria, Hungary or Poland. France, on the other hand, authorised this type of maize as early as 1998. However, it turns out that pollen of plants can spread to large distances, and spontaneous crossing with other plants can occur. Should such cross-crossing and spread occur, biological diversity may be compromised and may also pose risks to farmers. Since, on the basis of current methods of controlling the planting of GMOs of maize, we cannot guarantee a sufficient level of protection of human life and health, the Commission should not issue such GMO decisions. I am therefore of the opinion that the Commission should withdraw its implementing decision and submit a new legislative proposal that takes better account of the specificities of gmo crop cultivation.

name: Igor ŠOLTES
text: Writing. The European Parliament has successfully expressed its disagreement with the authorisation of five food and feed products from genetically modified organisms. These include the seeds of genetically modified MON 810 maize, which is being dealt with by this resolution. At the same time, the European Commission has rejected the call for a change in the authorisation procedure for the use of individual GMOs, as the European Parliament considers that the procedure is currently not democratic, as decisions are now being taken by the Commission. There is also a certain lack of data on the use and import of GMOs, as the Commission rarely shares data with the European Parliament in such cases. In relation to GMOs, which the Commission wishes to approve for use, research is currently being carried out by the European Food Safety Authority. As I believe that our food must be kept safe and healthy, I voted in favour of the Parliament resolution which seeks to ensure that the authorisation for use is not accepted.

name: Dubravka ŠUICA
text: Written. ‒2012 Taking into account the Draft Commission on the implementing decision on the renewal of authorisations for the marketing of GM maize seeds MON 810 (MON-ØØ81Ø-6) for cultivation and, under Article 26(2) of the TSR.c Directive 2001/18/EC the cultivation of GM maize MON 810 will be prohibited in the territories of certain Member States, including Croatia, the draft Commission goes beyond the implementing powers achieved by Regulation (EC) No 100/2013. 1829/2003 Furthermore, the European Food Safety Authority's assessment of the farming risks is incomplete and the Commission's draft implementation decision is not in line with the objectives of Regulation (EC) No 1029/2003. 1829/2003 which would ensure the high protection of human health and life, animals, the environment and consumers related to GM foods while ensuring the efficient functioning of the internal market. I therefore support the European Parliament's objection and resolution on the Commission's draft decision on renewing the authorisation to market GM maize seeds MON 810 (MON-ØØ81Ø-6) for cultivation.

name: Eleftherios SYNADINOS
text: Writing. \u2012 We are against any attempt to liberalise GMOs and we even call on the European Parliament to take an even tougher stance and to block the Commission's attempts to allow them to be grown sideways within the Union.

name: Tibor SZANYI
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the European Parliament's motion for a resolution on the draft Commission implementing decision renewing the commission's decision to renew the authorisation to place genetically modified MAIZE GRAINS ON THE MARKET FOR CULTIVATION. The motion states that, on 11 and 18 April 2007, Monsanto Europe S.A. submitted three applications to the Commission for the renewal of the marketing authorisation for foods, food ingredients and feedingstuffs currently produced from MON 810 maize. On 9 March 2016, Monsanto Europe S.A. sent a letter to the Commission requesting that the part of the application relating to cultivation be treated separately from the rest of the application. This genetically modified maize contains the Cry1Ab protein from the subspecies Bacillus thuringiensis kurstaki, which provides resistance to certain pests in the order butterflies.  According to the European Food Safety Authority (EFSA), evidence shows that between 95% and 99% of the pollen emitted are uneating up to 50 metres from the source of pollen, while vertical wind movements or gusts of wind can cause dispersed pollen to enter the atmosphere and travel a significant distance of several kilometres. I agree that the draft Commission implementing decision goes beyond the implementing powers laid down in Regulation (EC) No 1829/2003 and that the efsa assessment of cultivation is incomplete. For these reasons, the resolution calls on the Commission to withdraw its implementing regulation.

name: Marc TARABELLA
text: In writing. The European Parliament, which I fully agree with on this issue, considers that this draft commission enforcement decision exceeds the enforcement powers set out in Directive 2001/18/EC. EFSA's crop risk analysis is incomplete and the Commission's risk management recommendations are inadequate. Moreover, the Commission's draft enforcement decision is not in line with EU law. We therefore reject this request!

name: Pavel TELIČKA
text: in writing. ‒ The objection proposed by the Environment, Public Health and Food Safety committee against the renewing of authorisation for the use of genetically modified maize MON 810 seeds in the European market is part of a larger theme of systematically opposing GM authorisations on mainly procedural grounds, and is not the right way to force the Commission to change the EU-level authorisation regime. I voted against the motion to object the proposal, as I believe that as long as there are no convincing scientific reasons to object to a GM authorisation, I will continue to follow the advice given by the European Food and Safety Agency.

name: Ruža TOMAŠIĆ
text: Written. ‒I supported the objection to the extension of the authorisation for GM maize MON 810 seeds, as that seed is registered in the Community register of genetically modified food and feed. Some Member States of the European Union have prohibited the cultivation and use of GM crops and food and I believe that the Commission must respect their decision.  In addition, I believe that all institutions of the European Union, including the Commission, should be primarily at a high level of protection of the lives and health of citizens, the preservation and protection of the environment and the protection of consumers. While the European Union has one of the strictest rules on GM products in the world, I believe that Member States must, with the help of experts, decide for themselves whether they want these products on their market.

name: Romana TOMC
text: Writing. I supported the objection under Rule 106 of the Rules of Procedure: renewal of the authorisation to place on the market the cultivation of seeds of genetically modified maize MON 810. In accordance with Articles 11 and 23 of Regulation (EC) No 1829/2007 on 11 and 18 April 2007, Monsanto Europe SA submitted three applications to the Commission for the renewal of the authorisation of existing foods, food ingredients and feed produced from MON 810 maize. The commission's draft implementing decision is not in line with Union law, as it is not consistent with the objective of Regulation (EC) No 1829/2003, which is in line with the general principles laid down in Regulation (EC) No 178/2002 , to provide the basis for ensuring a high level of protection of human life and health, animal health and welfare, the environment and the interests of consumers with regard to genetically modified food and feed, while ensuring the proper functioning of the internal market.

name: Estefanía TORRES MARTÍNEZ
text: in writing. The use of transgenic seeds is part of a more substantive debate, which can be addressed from three angles: health, environmental and socio-economic impact. I voted in favour of the objection because when we talk about allowing the marketing of transgenic seeds we talk about deepening this unsustainable model, abuses, royalties, dependence on agrochemicals; and socially perverse. We know that GENETICally modified seeds will not be marketed for the benefit of farmers, consumers, society, the environment but for the profit of a giant like Monsanto. A giant whose merger with Bayer will entail the creation of a monster whose consequences for the global agri-food system we are not even able to foresee.

name: Mylène TROSZCZYNSKI
text: In writing. Despite systematic objections, the Commission persists in issuing permits for the cultivation or import of GMOs.  Parliament persists in objecting, to no avail, since the Commission does not take this into account. These objections help to unmask the hypocrisy of the majority parliamentarians (who maintain the Commission) in the face of totalitarianism in the European Union.  I vote FOR this objection.

name: Kazimierz Michał UJAZDOWSKI
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 Genetically modified food can have a negative impact on humans, animals and the environment and should be controlled in detail in these respects.  I doubt whether the Commission should allow further types of genetically modified food and feed to be placed on the market. That is why I voted against the introduction of MON 810 maize seeds and voted against it.

name: Miguel URBÁN CRESPO
text: in writing. The use of transgenic seeds is part of a more substantive debate, which can be addressed from three angles: health, environmental and socio-economic impact. I voted in favour of the objection because when we talk about allowing the marketing of transgenic seeds we talk about deepening this unsustainable model, abuses, royalties, dependence on agrochemicals; and socially perverse. We know that GENETICally modified seeds will not be marketed for the benefit of farmers, consumers, society, the environment but for the profit of a giant like Monsanto. A giant whose merger with Bayer will entail the creation of a monster whose consequences for the global agri-food system we are not even able to foresee.

name: Ernest URTASUN
text: in writing. – I voted in favour of the GMO import objection as I have decided to object systematically to any GM import authorisation. This was following the EP rejection of the EC proposal to renationalise instead of democratise the authorisation procedure. In relation to the GMO cultivation I also decided to object as all three maizes are Bt maizes: they all themselves produce the Bt toxin that enables them to be ‘pest-resistant’, meaning they are themselves toxic to the targeted pests – but also the non-targeted, even if those ones are protected or pollinate.

name: Ivo VAJGL
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the objection pursuant to Rule 106(2) and (3) of the Rules of Procedure on the draft Commission implementing decision renewing the authorisation for the placing on the market for cultivation of genetically modified maize MON 810 (MON-ØØ81Ø-6) seeds (D046170/00 – 2016/2921(RSP)). I voted in favour of the objection because I believe that the EFSA assessment of maize MON 810 seeds lacks data. In addition, possible cross-contamination by an invasive plant carrying Bacillus thuringiensis (Bt) toxin, used as a pesticide, poses major risks for farmers and the environment.

name: Ángela VALLINA
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this objection to the renewal of the authorisation of seeds of MON 810 genetically modified maize because I am totally against genetically modified organisms and, therefore, new authorisations thereof. EFSA's assessment underscores the lack of data and the renewal of the authorisation to grow its seeds are based on a legal act that has proven dysfunctional (1829/2003). Moreover, it is clear that the current procedure for the authorisation of genetically modified food and feed is not working properly. That is why I am in favour of this and any objections raised in relation to the authorisation of GMOs, and I voted accordingly.

name: Miguel VIEGAS
text: in writing. We are in favour of this opposition, and any future objection to the authorisation of GMOs, as a matter of principle, but also with the purpose of showing the European Commission the need to amend the recently adopted legislation with a legislative proposal that will respect the right of an individual not to authorise GMOs for food on its territory.

name: Udo VOIGT
text: Writing. The objections raised in the motion for a resolution to the placing on the market of the genetically modified products in question are well founded and necessarily suggest that the Commission rejects the relevant implementing decision. The motion for a resolution before us is therefore in favour.

name: Julie WARD
text: in writing. ‒ Labour MEPs voted against a ban on pest-resistant maize as we agree with EFSA's assessment that they are unlikely to pose risks to human, animal health or the environment, while limiting the need for use of pesticides. Moreover, the Commission attached stringent conditions for use of these GMOs in their authorisation decisions. I continue to take the issue of GMOs with the utmost seriousness, and will continue to oppose GMO use that is deemed harmful or potentially dangerous.

name: Lieve WIERINCK
text: in writing. – I voted against this motion for a resolution.  It is very important that Europe can ensure its own food supply. At the same time, this needs to be done in an efficient and sustainable manner. Science helps us in achieving this goal. It is important that those products that are developed in this regard are safe for both consumers and the environment. Such an assessment, research and consequent conclusions need to be based on scientific processes and empirical evidence. It is EFSA's task and responsibility to ensure that this is the case. This is the reason why it was established by the institutions of the European Union. In this case, EFSA has, at the request of the European Commission, duly assessed this GMO and concluded that it is safe. In my view, EFSA is the appropriate authority to give recommendations on these matters and likewise the Commission is the relevant authority to act on them.  Therefore I have voted against this proposal that would go against EFSA's judgement.

name: Jana ŽITŇANSKÁ
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported the European Parliament's objection to the Commission implementing decision renewing the authorisation for seeds of GENETICALLY MODIFIED MAIZE. My opinion on GMOs does not change, as there is not yet sufficient evidence regarding their wholesomeness. Likewise, we do not have sufficient information on their effects on the environment. That is why I agree with the view that, in the circumstances where the risk assessment is not thorough and complete, the European Commission has exceeded its powers in this implementing regulation, let alone acted in accordance with the precautionary principle, which is absolutely necessary in cases where human health may be at risk.

name: Carlos ZORRINHO
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of all objections under Rule 106 of the Rules of Procedure, because I agree with the opposition to genetically modified substances for which there are still no solid scientific results to allow them to be authorised without compromising public health.  Therefore, until the Commission proposes a new legislative framework for these substances, the European Socialist Group will continue in concert to support these objections.

name: Marco ZULLO
text: in writing. Once again, we must fight to prevent the marketing of genetically modified maize seed MON 810. It is a genetically modified maize tolerant to the herbicide glufosinate ammonium. Herbicide which has been classified as toxic for reproduction purposes and therefore meets the criteria that should lead to the exclusion of the renewal of marketing authorisation in 2017. The consequences are so unpredictable and potentially disastrous that they have already been banned in many of the Member States. GMOs are an interest of the few, it is the large biotech companies against small local farmers. Those who grow genetically modified maize can easily contaminate not only their neighbours, but also fields miles away, causing enormous economic damage to other farmers. I am fighting for an agriculture that safeguards local excellence by creating economic return for farmers and the territory, and with my vote in favour of this resolution, promoted together with my colleagues in the M5S, I reiterate a dry no to genetically modified organisms in Europe.

name: Isabella ADINOLFI
text: in writing. \u2012 The legislative proposal of 22 April 2015 amending Regulation (EC) No Regulation (EC) No 1829/2003 was rejected by Parliament on 28 October 2015 on the ground that, while the cultivation of GMOs necessarily takes place on the territory of a Member State, their trade crosses borders, which means that a national 'sale and use' ban proposed by the Commission would be impossible to apply without reintroducing border controls on imports. The motion for a resolution therefore calls for the Commission's draft implementing decision to be withdrawn, as it does not comply with EU law, as it is incompatible with ensuring a high level of protection of human life and health, animal health and welfare, the environment and consumer interests in relation to genetically modified food and feed. For these reasons, I voted in favour.

name: Tim AKER
text: in writing. – We in UKIP are concerned about the safety of GMOs for health and the environment, but we would prefer our national Parliament to legislate on this delicate issue rather than the European Parliament.

name: Marina ALBIOL GUZMÁN
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this objection to the renewal of the authorisation of THE products of MON 810 genetically modified maize because I am totally against genetically modified organisms and, therefore, new authorisations thereof. EFSA's assessment underscores the lack of data and renewal of import authorization for its products based on a legal act that has proven dysfunctional (1829/2003). Moreover, it is clear that the current procedure for the authorisation of genetically modified food and feed is not working properly. That is why I am in favour of this and any objections raised in relation to the authorisation of GMOs, and I voted accordingly.

name: Martina ANDERSON
text: in writing. – I voted in favour of this GMO authorisation objection. It is absurd that the European Commission continues to propose authorisations of GMOs under a system which they themselves have admitted is flawed. It is essential that Mr Juncker listens to the European Parliament’s call for a new proposal and that the EU GMO authorisation procedure is overhauled completely.

name: Eric ANDRIEU
text: In writing. I object to the importation of MON 810 maize, as I object to its marketing authorization, for the risks mentioned of cross-contamination with the Bt toxin. Bt maize is a variety that is modified by a gene and is resistant to major corn pests, such as pyral.

name: Laima Liucija ANDRIKIENĖ
text: in writing. ‒ I have voted in favour of the motion for a resolution objecting to the draft Commission implementing decision authorising the placing on the market of genetically modified maize MON 810 products. In 2015 the Commission, in the explanatory memorandum to its legislative proposal amending Regulation (EC) No 1829/2003, deplored the fact that since the entry into force of the Regulation, authorisation decisions had been adopted by the Commission without the support of opinions of Member State committees. However, the Commission’s legislative proposal amending the Regulation was rejected by the European Parliament on the grounds that, while cultivation necessarily takes place on a Member State’s territory, GMO trade crosses borders, which means that a national sales and use ban proposed by the Commission could be impossible to enforce without reintroducing border checks on imports. I supported this motion for a resolution considering that the draft Commission implementing decision is not consistent with Union law and also exceeds the implementing powers provided for in Regulation (EC) No 1829/2003. I welcome the call on the Commission to withdraw its draft implementing decision and to submit a new legislative proposal which takes into account frequently expressed national concerns.

name: Nikos ANDROULAKIS
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the objection pursuance to Rule 106 of the Rules of Procedure concerning the renewal of the authorisation for genetically modified maize products of the MON 810 series, because the assessment of the risks of cultivation was incomplete and the risk management recommendations proposed by the Commission were inadequate.

name: Marie-Christine ARNAUTU
text: In writing. Five objections are made by Parliament on permits to grow or import GMOs for maize or wheat.  Despite systematic objections, the Commission continues to issue permits for the cultivation or import of GMOs. Parliament persists in objecting, to no avail, since the Commission does not take this into account. These objections help to unmask the hypocrisy of the majority parliamentarians (who maintain the Commission) in the face of the totalitarianism of the European Union. So I voted for these new objections.

name: Jonathan ARNOTT
text: in writing. ‒ Given that I have no specialist knowledge of the seeds concerned, and having concerns about the use of delegated acts, I felt it appropriate to follow the advice of officials and abstain on this matter.

name: Jean ARTHUIS
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this objection not to renew the authorization to import and market herbicide-resistant maize. Its use could have adverse effects on users and consumers.

name: Gerard BATTEN
text: in writing. ‒ We in UKIP are concerned about the safety of GMOs for health and the environment, but we would prefer our national Parliament to legislate on this delicate issue rather than the European Parliament.

name: Nicolas BAY
text: In writing. Five objections are presented by Parliament on permits for cultivation or imports of GMOs with different properties. The herbicide-tolerant GMO or two that will soon be banned is of little interest and, more importantly, is dangerous for biodiversity. Monitoring of the effects on nature is insufficient, EFSA's assessment is still as minimal and as contrary to food sovereignty. In this case, I voted in favour of this objection to the renewal of the authorization of genetically modified maize products MON 810.

name: Hugues BAYET
text: In writing. The European Parliament, which I fully agree with on this issue, considers that this draft commission enforcement decision exceeds the enforcement powers set out in Directive 2001/18/EC. EFSA's crop risk analysis is incomplete and the Commission's risk management recommendations are inadequate. Moreover, the Commission's draft enforcement decision is not in line with EU law. We therefore reject this request!

name: Beatriz BECERRA BASTERRECHEA
text: in writing. I am not positioned for or against GMOs. I'm in favor of science. In the Union we have set up an agency for this type of task: the EFSA (EFSA) where the opinion of independent scientists who ensure and guarantee food security in the Union is reflected. Just a few months ago, more than a hundred Nobel laureates encouraged recognizing the findings of the relevant scientific institutions and abandoning campaigns against genetically modified organisms without sufficient scientific support.  Different products need to be analyzed on a case-by-case basis, and the debate should not be generalized or simplified.

name: Brando BENIFEI
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted today in favour of the objection to the renewal of the authorisation for genetically modified maize MON 810. I believe that the current regulatory framework does not allow the Commission and EFSA to provide adequate assessments of the impact of GMOs. In the case of MON 810 maize, in particular, the problem is the presence of the Cry1Ab protein, derived from Bacillus thuringiensis, which gives protection from predation of certain parasites of the order of lepidoptera. The lack of long-term studies on nutrition and toxicity and insufficient risk assessment led me to vote in favour of the objection, reaffirming the need for the Commission to draw up a comprehensive proposal on GMOs as soon as possible in order to carefully assess the environmental and health impact of these technologies and to establish a new procedure for their authorisation.

name: Xabier BENITO ZILUAGA
text: in writing. The use of transgenic seeds is part of a more substantive debate, which can be addressed from three angles: health, environmental and socio-economic impact. I voted in favour of the objection because when we talk about allowing the marketing of transgenic seeds we talk about deepening this unsustainable model, abuses, royalties, dependence on agrochemicals; and socially perverse. We know that GENETICally modified seeds will not be marketed for the benefit of farmers, consumers, society, the environment but for the profit of a giant like Monsanto. A giant whose merger with Bayer will entail the creation of a monster whose consequences for the global agri-food system we are not even able to foresee.

name: Izaskun BILBAO BARANDICA
text: in writing. I would like to thank the rapporteurs of this report on the renewal of the authorisation of products of MON 810 genetically modified maize for their work. This report, as well as the other four that we voted on today on various objections, does not leave anyone indifferent. I have been consistent with my previous votes in this area and supported the report of the European Parliament where the draft Commission Implementing Decision is considered to exceed the implementing powers provided for in Regulation (EC) No 1829/2003.

name: Dominique BILDE
text: In writing. Despite systematic objections, the Commission persists in issuing permits for gmOS crops or imports. The aim here is to object to the renewal of the approval of genetically modified maize products MON810 by the manufacturer Monsanto. The problem raised is the destruction of biodiversity, so I voted for it.

name: Mara BIZZOTTO
text: in writing. \u2012 I supported with my vote the objection to the authorisation to renew the authorisation for genetically modified maize seeds MON 810.

name: Vilija BLINKEVIČIŪTĖ
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this resolution, in which the European Parliament that the Commission implementing decision is not compatible with Union law because it is incompatible with the objective of Regulation (EC) No 1829/2003, which, in accordance with the general principles laid down in Regulation (EC) No 178/2002, aims to develop a legal framework to ensure a high level of protection of human life and health, animal health and consumer interests with regard to genetically modified food and feed, while ensuring effective functioning of the internal market. Parliament calls on the Commission, in accordance with the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union, to submit a new legislative proposal amending Regulation (EC) No 1829/2003 and taking into account the frequently expressed concerns expressed by national authorities on issues that concern not only the health and environmental safety of genetically modified organisms (GMOs).

name: Andrea BOCSKOR
text: Writing. \u2012 In accordance with the Hungarian Basic Law and the precautionary principle, I am opposed to the authorisation of GMO products, and I believe that the Commission's draft implementing decision does not comply with EU law, Whereas it is incompatible with the objective of Regulation (EC) No 1829/2003, which, in accordance with the general principles laid down in Regulation (EC) No 178/2002, is to serve as a basis for a high level of protection of human life and health, animal health and well-being, the environment and consumer interests in genetically modified food and feed, while ensuring the effective functioning of the internal market; The report calls on the Commission to withdraw its draft implementing decision, and I therefore voted in favour of the adoption of this report.

name: Franc BOGOVIČ
text: Writing. I also supported the objection to renewing the authorisation to place on the market products from genetically modified maize MON 810. That maize provides protection against certain lepidoptera pests, including maize moths (Ostrinia nubilalis) and butterflies of sesamia spp, but the EFSA's impact assessment on MON 810 maize does not contain cross-pollination of maize, which increases the risk to biodiversity. On the issue of GMOs, the profession also does not have a single opinion, so it is expected that Members and other publics should also share on these issues. I am a supporter of the precautionary principle in GMOs, so I find it completely unnecessary for such a sensitive topic, such as the registration of MAM products, to be brought through the process quickly.

name: Biljana BORZAN
text: Written. ‒I support this report because it is a political message to the Commission that Parliament will not support any new approval of GMO cultures and products as long as the gm food licensing process is not reformed.

name: Mercedes BRESSO
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the resolution on the Commission's decision renewing the authorisation for genetically modified maize MON 810 products because I stand for the protection of human life and health and the Commission's draft does not ensure the respect of those values and therefore does not respect Union law.

name: Renata BRIANO
text: in writing. \u2012 Genetically modified maize MON 810 produces the Cry1Ab protein, derived from Bacillus thuringiensis, which gives protection from predation of certain parasites of the order of lepidoptera, including maize pyralid and corn nottua. The commission's draft implementing decision was adopted in the Standing Committee without any opinion being delivered. The same was true of the Appeal Committee, where 12 Member States were in favour, 11 Member States against, 4 Member States abstained and 1 Member State was absent. The two main reasons why the Member States voted against or abstained were the lack of long-term studies on nutrition and toxicity and insufficient risk assessment. Furthermore, the Commission's draft implementing decision is not in accordance with UNION law, since it is not compatible with the objective of ensuring a high level of protection of human life and health, animal health and welfare, the environment and consumer interests. Therefore, the Commission is asked to withdraw the draft implementing decision and to present a new legislative proposal to take account of the concerns frequently expressed at national level.

name: Steeve BRIOIS
text: In writing. This report proposes to adopt five objections to GMO cultivation or import authorizations, including from Monsanto. These objections highlight, in particular, the hypocrisy and dual discourse of the European parliamentarians of the majority groups who vote the opposite of what they promise their constituents. I voted in favour of these objections.

name: Nicola CAPUTO
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this objection today because I believe efsa's cultivation risk assessment is incomplete. In addition, the renewal of the authorisation for GM MAize MON810 threatens European organic and conventional non-GM farming. Under the new European rules on the use of GMOs, once a GMO is authorised for use in Europe as food or feed, Member States have the opportunity to decide whether or not to allow a given GMO to be used in their food chain (opt-out measures).
