Unfortunately, Member States that have not chosen to use opt-out measures to ban the cultivation of specific GMOs on their territory have generally not implemented effective measures to prevent contamination of non-GMO or organic ma corn. Spain, for example, where most GMO ma corn is grown in Europe, has no specific rules regarding isolation distances, buffer zones or information required for adjacent authorities or growers. Experience shows that it is almost impossible for organic and conventional farmers to grow corn in areas where MON810 GMO ma corn is produced. I therefore call on the Commission to withdraw the draft implementing decision.

name: Matt CARTHY
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of these objections to GMO authorisations. The European Commission has yet to propose a new authorisation procedure since its very weak proposal was rejected earlier this year.  In spite of the fact that the EP called for a new proposal, the Commission continues to authorise GMOs under a flawed procedure which they themselves have admitted does not work. For these reasons I voted in favour of the objection.

name: David CASA
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the resolution calling on the Commission to withdraw the draft implementing decision authorising the placing on the market of genetically modified maize MON 810 (MON-ØØ81Ø-6) products. The draft Commission implementing decision was voted on in the Standing Committee on 8 July 2016, with no opinion being delivered and two major reasons for a negative vote or abstention by the Member States were the lack of long-term feeding and toxicity studies and insufficient risk assessment.  I call on the Commission to withdraw its proposal and to submit a new one.

name: Fabio Massimo CASTALDO
text: in writing. \u2012 The European Commission has asked the European Food Safety Authority (EFSA) to assess whether new evidence has emerged that would change the recommendations of EFSA's scientific advice on renewing the marketing authorisation for the cultivation of GM MON 810 maize seeds. The European Parliament resolution on the European Commission's draft implementing decision considers efsa's cultivation risk assessment to be incomplete and that the risk management recommendations proposed by the European Commission are inadequate and therefore calls for the draft implementing decision to be withdrawn. Together with the M5S delegation, I voted in favour of the resolution.

name: Lefteris CHRISTOFOROU
text: Writing. \u2012 The issue of Genetically Modified Organisms (GMOs) is particularly important and has occupied the European Union since the 1990s. We believe that the aim of the competent authorities of the Member States of the European Union should be to control and limit any negative effects of GMOs, while leaving room for research action in the new scientific field of biotechnology or even for use on the market, if the products prove useful and harmless.

name: Kostas CHRYSOGONOS
text: Writing. \u2012 The vote on the objection to the renewal of the authorisation for genetically modified maize products of the MON 810 series is a positive move for the benefit of the health of European citizens, since it concerns the strengthening of the procedures for monitoring the authorisation of genetically modified organisms. I therefore voted in favour.

name: Deirdre CLUNE
text: in writing. ‒ I rejected this objection as I support the EFSA and the European Commission's scientific GMO authorisation procedure.

name: Jane COLLINS
text: in writing. – We in UKIP are concerned about the safety of GMOs for health and the environment, but we would prefer our national Parliament to legislate on this delicate issue rather than the European Parliament.

name: Therese COMODINI CACHIA
text: in writing. ‒ It transpires that the risk assessment of cultivation conducted by EFSA is incomplete and the risk management recommendations proposed by the Commission are inadequate; therefore, I agree that we should withdraw the Commission’s draft implementing decision. I have consistently voted against placing on the market genetically modified organisms within the Community in line with the precautionary principle, which I believe should be followed in issues related to human health and the environment for our citizens.

name: Javier COUSO PERMUY
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this objection to the renewal of the authorisation of THE products of MON 810 genetically modified maize because I am totally against genetically modified organisms and, therefore, new authorisations thereof. EFSA's assessment underscores the lack of data and renewal of import authorization for its products based on a legal act that has proven dysfunctional (1829/2003). Moreover, it is clear that the current procedure for the authorisation of genetically modified food and feed is not working properly. That is why I am in favour of this and any objections raised in relation to the authorisation of GMOs, and I voted accordingly.

name: Andrea COZZOLINO
text: in writing. \u2012 I believe that the Commission's recommendations are not adequate and that a new legislative proposal should be presented which takes greater account of the concerns frequently expressed at national level and which do not only relate to issues relating to the safety of GMOs for health or the environment. I therefore voted against the authorisation of existing food, food ingredients and feed from MON 810 maize on the placing on the market of maize products. It should be remembered that MON 810 maize is still banned in many COUNTRIES of the European Union due to the lack of long-term studies on nutrition and toxicity and insufficient risk assessment.

name: Edward CZESAK
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 I supported the objection to the renewal of the authorisation of products from genetically modified maize MON 810. I believe that no novel food or genetically modified feed should be allowed under the current legal framework. This framework is one of the most restrictive in the world when it comes to assessing the risk to GMO crops and food, which makes me happy. I believe that this should remain unchanged, which is why I voted in favour.

name: Miriam DALLI
text: in writing. ‒ The import authorisation renewal of products with maize MON 810 is being objected to. The assessment made by EFSA underlines the lack of data since herbicide tolerance is not assessed. MON 810's legal act has also proved to be weak. I believe that consumers should have the right to make informed decisions about what they are eating. I have voted in favour of this objection so as to reach public conclusions on maize MON 810 products' effects.

name: Michel DANTIN
text: In writing. This objection is intended to oppose the marketing of the GMO MON 810. I am against this objection insofar as the European Commission has complied with its mandate as part of its enforcement power granted by the European Parliament and the Council. I regret that this ideologically motivated resolution does not take into account the numerous precautionary measures voted by the European legislator on the authorisation to market new products, as well as the positive scientific opinion granted by the European Food Safety Authority. For these reasons, I voted against this objection.

name: Angélique DELAHAYE
text: In writing. I voted against this objection to refusing to market genetically modified maize seeds for cultivation purposes. This objection is based on a charge made to the Commission: by this authorization it would exceed the enforcement powers assigned to it. However, the Commission has complied with the existing procedure for authorising GMOs. It has previously requested an analysis by the European Food Safety Authority (EFSA) to verify that this maize seed is not dangerous to human and animal health, and to the environment. This objection, in my view, therefore does not have to be and merely reflects a desire to systematically ban all GMOs, even though it is the responsibility of the Member States.

name: Angel DZHAMBAZKI
text: in writing. \u2012 I supported this objection as I am against the use of GMOs and the placing on the market of genetically modified goods. Furthermore, there is no solid data on risk assessment and impact assessment methods in the relevant case, which calls safety into question.

name: Georgios EPITIDEIOS
text: Writing. \u2012 We are voting in favour because we are against any attempt to liberalise GMOs. We also call on the European Parliament to take an even tougher stance and to block the Commission's attempts to allow them to grow sideways within the Union.

name: Norbert ERDŐS
text: Writing. – The MON810 corn line carries the cry1A gene, from which Bt-toxin – insecticide protein – is re-written, which enables MON810 maize to be protected against certain Lepidoptera species. Studies on the health safety of the product were not satisfactory. Longer-term studies would also be necessary to detect the possible toxicological and allergenic effects of MON810. In my view, GM products that have not been thoroughly tested in terms of health and environmental safety should not be authorised in the European Union. Scientific studies to identify risks are inadequate and I therefore do not support the authorisation of GM products in accordance with the Hungarian Basic Law and the precautionary principle.

name: Jill EVANS
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this objection to the authorisation of Monsanto GMO maize MON810 products because the current legal framework for authorising GMOs is not democratic. Decisions are made by the Commission without the agreement of the Member States. I represent Wales, which has declared itself GM-free, and I want that decision to be respected.

name: Eleonora EVI
text: in writing. \u2012 As a signatory to the objection resolution, I voted in favour, as I believe that until democratic control of the European Commission's decisions has been strengthened and correctly reflects the opinion of the majority of Member States, MEPs and European citizens, no GMOs should be authorised. In addition, with regard to the three GMO maize, there is still a lack of data and incompleteness of the risk assessment, complete analyses of non-target species, such as aquatic insects, risk mitigation measures are inadequate and impractical, as demonstrated in the case of the definition of "safe haven areas" or "isolation distances from protected habitats" measures that have proved ineffective, or finally there remains a strong threat to GMO or organic-free crops , endangered by possible contamination.

name: José Manuel FERNANDES
text: in writing. \u2012 The commission's draft implementing decision exceeds the implementing powers laid down in Regulation (EC) No 1829/2003 and is not in line with EU law, to the extent that it is not compatible with the purpose of Regulation (EC) No 1829/2003, which is to provide the basis for ensuring, as far as genetically modified food and feed is concerned, a high level of protection of human life and health, animal health and health, the environment and consumer interests, while ensuring the functioning of the internal market.  I agree with the withdrawal of the draft implementing decision and the presentation of a new legislative proposal amending the Regulation in question.

name: Edouard FERRAND
text: In writing. Vote for: despite systematic objections, the Commission persists in issuing permits for GMO crops or imports. Parliament persists in objecting, to no avail, since the Commission does not take this into account. These objections help to unmask the hypocrisy of the majority parliamentarians (who maintain the Commission) in the face of EU totalitarianism.

name: João FERREIRA
text: in writing. We are looking at proposals for renewal of authorisation, submitted by Monsanto Europe SA, for existing foods, food ingredients and feed produced from MON810 maize, including cultivation. Once again, as regards the procedures for this authorisation decision, the exception has become a rule. There was no consensus among the Member States, so according to the perverse legislative framework in force, the decision falls into the hands of the European Commission – which invariably has a pro-GMO stance, even in the face of a lack of long-term studies on food toxicity and an insufficient risk assessment, reasons which underlie the position of refusal (or abstention) taken by several Member States. This resolution objects to the authorisation of this Genetically Modified Organism (GMO). We voted in favour. It is necessary and urgent to amend the current legislative framework in order to respect the right of each Member State not to want GMOs on its territory, for food and/or cultivation, for reasons of protection of food sovereignty, the environment, biodiversity and public health.

name: Luke Ming FLANAGAN
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour as I believe GM crops are a threat to our existence.

name: Lorenzo FONTANA
text: in writing. \u2012 I am voting in favour of the resolution containing an objection to the authorisation of a GMO by the Commission.

name: Lampros FOUNTOULIS
text: Writing. \u2012 I am voting in favour of the objection raised in accordance with Rule 106 of the Rules of Procedure concerning the renewal of the authorisation for genetically modified maize products of the MON 810 series because I am against any attempt to liberalise the use of GMOs. I even call on the European Parliament to take an even tougher stance and to block all attempts by the Commission to allow them to grow sideways within the Union.

name: Kinga GÁL
text: Writing. \u2012 The MON810 corn line carries the cry1A gene, from which Bt-toxin - an insecticide protein - is re-written, making MON810 maize capable of controlling certain Lepidoptera species. Studies on the health safety of the product were not satisfactory. Longer-term studies would also be necessary to detect the possible toxicological and allergenic effects of MON810. In my view, GM products that have not been thoroughly tested in terms of health and environmental safety should not be authorised in the European Union. Scientific studies to identify risks are inadequate and I therefore do not support the authorisation of GM products in accordance with the Hungarian Basic Law and the precautionary principle.

name: Ildikó GÁLL-PELCZ
text: Writing. – The MON810 corn line carries the cry1A gene, from which Bt-toxin – insecticide protein – is re-written, which enables MON810 maize to be protected against certain Lepidoptera species. Studies on the health safety of the product were not satisfactory. Longer-term studies would also be necessary to detect the possible toxicological and allergenic effects of MON810. In my view, GM products that have not been thoroughly tested in terms of health and environmental safety should not be authorised in the European Union. Scientific studies to identify risks are inadequate and I therefore do not support the authorisation of GM products in accordance with the Hungarian Basic Law and the precautionary principle.

name: Francisco de Paula GAMBUS MILLET
text: in writing. I voted against the objection concerning the renewal of the authorisation of products of MON 810 GENETICally modified maize. Having considered the objection raised, I believe that there are sufficient checks and guarantees on the part of the European Commission as well as on the Member States. It is necessary to maintain a high level of protection of human life and health, animal health and welfare, the environment and the interests of consumers in relation to genetically modified food and feed, while ensuring the effective functioning of the internal market.

name: Nathan GILL
text: in writing. ‒ I am concerned about the safety of GMOs and their impact on health and the environment, but I would prefer the UK Government to legislate on this delicate issue, rather than the European Parliament.

name: Tania GONZÁLEZ PEÑAS
text: in writing. The use of transgenic seeds is part of a more substantive debate, which can be addressed from three angles: health, environmental and socio-economic impact. I voted in favour of the objection because when we talk about allowing the marketing of transgenic seeds we talk about deepening this unsustainable model, abuses, royalties, dependence on agrochemicals; and socially perverse. We know that GENETICally modified seeds will not be marketed for the benefit of farmers, consumers, society, the environment but for the profit of a giant like Monsanto. A giant whose merger with Bayer will entail the creation of a monster whose consequences for the global agri-food system we are not even able to foresee.

name: András GYÜRK
text: Writing. \u2012 The MON810 corn line carries the cry1A gene, from which Bt-toxin - an insecticide protein - is re-written, making MON810 maize capable of controlling certain Lepidoptera species. Studies on the health safety of the product were not satisfactory. Longer-term studies would also be necessary to detect the possible toxicological and allergenic effects of MON810. In my view, GM products that have not been thoroughly tested in terms of health and environmental safety should not be authorised in the European Union. Scientific studies to identify risks are inadequate and I therefore do not support the authorisation of GM products in accordance with the Hungarian Basic Law and the precautionary principle.

name: Marian HARKIN
text: in writing. ‒ I supported the objection because, as with the other votes on GMO maize, I believe that the Commission’s implementing decision is not compatible with Union law. As well as that, there was no agreement among Member States in the Standing Committee to approve this product, mainly due to the lack of long-term feeding and toxicity studies and to insufficient risk assessment studies. Finally, considering the Parliament had already rejected the Commission proposal of 22 April 2015 for a new GMO sales and use policy and asked them to come forward with a new policy, I believe that it does not make sense to authorise GMO products. For all of the above reasons I voted in favour of the objection, plus the fact that I do not support the introduction of GMOs into the European Union.

name: György HÖLVÉNYI
text: Writing. \u2012 The MON810 corn line carries the cry1A gene, from which Bt-toxin - an insecticide protein - is re-written, making MON810 maize capable of controlling certain Lepidoptera species. Studies on the health safety of the product were not satisfactory. Longer-term studies would also be necessary to detect the possible toxicological and allergenic effects of MON810. In my view, GM products that have not been thoroughly tested in terms of health and environmental safety should not be authorised in the European Union. Scientific studies to identify risks are inadequate and I therefore do not support the authorisation of GM products in accordance with the Hungarian Basic Law and the precautionary principle.

name: Ivan JAKOVČIĆ
text: Written. ‒ I voted to object in accordance with Article 106. Rules of Procedure: renewing approval for GM maize MON 810 products because I do not support the use of genetically modified organisms on agricultural lands.

name: Jean-François JALKH
text: In writing. We are witnessing a balancing act: the Commission persists in encouraging the cultivation and importation of GMOs into our countries with its authorisations, and in sweeping away parliament's equally stubborn opposition. All this is indeed of little use, and is not enough to absolve parliamentarians of their responsibility, which maintain the Commission by the Band in its omnipotence. It is up to us to fight the authorisation of genetically modified maize products MON 810. True to my convictions, I voted for it.

name: Diane JAMES
text: in writing. – We in UKIP are concerned about the safety of GMOs for health and the environment, but we would prefer our national Parliament to legislate on this delicate issue rather than the European Parliament.

name: Marc JOULAUD
text: In writing. I voted against this objection to the renewal of the European Commission's product authorisation for genetically modified maize. By authorising marketing for cultivation or marketing purposes, the European Commission has duly complied with the procedure, taking into account the analysis of the European Food Safety Authority. It is also important to remember that genetically modified products found in French shelves or crops are approved by the French state and not by the European Union.

name: Barbara KAPPEL
text: Writing. I am voting in favour of this report. It rejects the Commission's proposal to allow a variety of genetically modified maize and forces the Commission to reconsider its proposal. The implementing decision is incompatible with Union law, the recommendation on risk management is deficient and genetically modified foods must be rejected in general from an Austrian point of view.

name: Krišjānis KARIŅŠ
text: Writing. \u2012 Like I supported other resolutions calling for the withdrawal of the European Commission's implementing decisions on the placing on the market of genetically modified products or products containing genetically modified raw materials, I also supported this. I believe that the European Commission has more resources in its mandate to investigate and understand the impact of genetically modified products on the environment and human health. Consequently, the European Commission has the power to come up with a better and clearer solution for the release and free trade on the European Market of genetically modified products or products containing genetically modified raw materials. It must be clearly investigated whether these products are indeed harmful, do not damage human health or have an impact on the environment, and until the possible consequences are identified, these implementing acts are not acceptable. That is why I voted in favour of the resolution in Strasbourg at the European Parliament plenary session, which calls for the commission's implementing decision on the placing of genetically modified maize seed on the market for cultivation purposes.

name: Ádám KÓSA
text: Writing. \u2012 Domestic scientific evidence has shown that the persistent presence of MON810 maize in the ecosystem under investigation may have adverse effects. It produces 1500-2000 times more Bt-toxin than is released from dipel, a plant protection product containing Bt-toxin, during conventional plant protection during single treatment. Furthermore, the remnants of Bt plants decomposed more slowly than their non-toxin-producing lines. After harvesting, 8% of the toxin produced by the plant remained in the area and a significant part of this active toxin could still be detected in the soil 11 months later. In our view, the available scientific knowledge is sufficient reason to believe that inbred lines and hybrids from the maize line containing the MON 810 gene design pose a risk to the environment. In view of all this, in accordance with the Hungarian Basic Law and the precautionary principle, I do not support the authorisation of GM products.

name: Gilles LEBRETON
text: In writing. I voted for this objection because it opposes the use of a GMO that is dangerous to biodiversity. The European Parliament agreed to vote on it, demonstrating that the Commission's initiative was harmful. I want France to regain its food sovereignty.

name: Philippe LOISEAU
text: In writing. The Commission persists in issuing permits for the cultivation or importation of GMOs. Parliament persists in objecting, to no avail, since the Commission does not take this into account. So I SUPPORTED this objection.

name: Paloma LÓPEZ BERMEJO
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this objection to the marketing of PRODUCTS of MON 810 genetically modified maize because I am totally against their authorisation. EFSA's assessment underscores the lack of data and the renewal of the authorisation to grow its seeds are based on a legal act that has proven dysfunctional (1829/2003). It is clear that the current procedure for the authorisation of genetically modified food and feed is not working with guarantees and I voted accordingly.

name: Andrejs MAMIKINS
text: in writing. ‒ I agree that Commission should withdraw its draft implementing decision and to submit a new legislative proposal on the basis of the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union, amending Regulation (EC) No 1829/2003 to take into account frequently expressed national concerns which do not relate only to issues associated with the safety of GMOs for health or the environment.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: Writing. \u2012 I am voting in favour of the motion for a resolution calling on the European Commission to withdraw the draft of its implementing decision approving the placing on the market of genetically modified maize products of the MON 810 series, because it is complete and documented.

name: Dominique MARTIN
text: In writing. I voted for this text.  Five objections are presented by Parliament regarding authorisations for gmOS crops or imports. The different properties of these GMOs pose several problems: carcinogenic herbicides, insecticides causing the destruction of biodiversity, etc. We are therefore in favour of these objections and, in this case, in favour of the renewal of the authorization of genetically modified maize products MON 810.

name: Georg MAYER
text: Writing. The resolution states that the Commission's draft implementing decision is incompatible with EU law and therefore calls on the Commission to withdraw its draft. As EFSA's risk assessment of cultivation is incomplete and the recommendations on risk management proposed by the Commission are deficient, I voted in favour of the resolution.

name: Valentinas MAZURONIS
text: Writing. \u2012 I support the EP resolution because it opposes the Commission's decision to authorise the renewal of genetically modified maize products. I believe that, in accordance with the precautionary principle and the objective of protecting human health and the environment, decisions on GMOs should only be taken once uncontested scientific evidence on their effects has been provided. Unfortunately, at present, the risk assessments of GMOs are not complete and unennutrs. For these reasons, I do not support the development, trade and cultivation of GMOs in the EU.

name: Jean-Luc MÉLENCHON
text: In writing. The report opposes the Commission's decision to allow the marketing of genetically modified maize products MON 810. The MON 810 variety developed by the American group Monsanto has an added gene - cry1Ab - that confers resistance to the pests that target this cereal - including the corn borer. And, because of its use, we observe the appearance of pyral, developing resistance to cry1 Ab, which requires the use of products with more aggressive chemical formulas and in larger quantities. In addition, cross-contamination of an invasive plant with Bt toxin has been found in the EU. I vote for this text.

name: Joëlle MÉLIN
text: In writing. The Commission persists in issuing permits for the cultivation or importation of GMOs. Parliament persists in objecting, to no avail, since the Commission does not take this into account. I voted in favour of this objection, as did the other four.

name: Nuno MELO
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this resolution because I believe that the Commission's draft implementing decision exceeds the implementing powers laid down in Regulation (EC) No 1829/2003 in the case of the renewal of the marketing authorisation for genetically modified maize products MON 810.

name: Roberta METSOLA
text: in writing. ‒ I chose to support this objection to the placing on the market of genetically modified maize MON 810 products as the Commission’s draft implementing decision risks endangering health, the ecosystem and consumer interests.

name: Louis MICHEL
text: Written. – At the beginning of 2016, there were some 7.4 billion people on our planet. In the most prudent scenario, the world's population will grow to 9 billion by 2050. Rapid growth of the world's population implies that demand for food and crops will also increase proportionately. Entrepreneurs in agriculture and food are facing important challenges. The existing agricultural area will have to be continued and better utilised. Innovation in agriculture will focus on sustainable and efficient agricultural techniques and plant technology will play a special role in ensuring food production. In that context, there are currently no convincing scientific arguments for objecting to a GM licence.

name: Marlene MIZZI
text: in writing. ‒ I have supported the decision to object to the placing on the market of genetically modified maize MON 810 products because the draft Commission implementing decision is not consistent with Union law. In accordance with the precautionary principle, to approximate the laws, regulations and administrative provisions of the Member States and to protect human health and the environment when carrying out the deliberate release into the environment of genetically modified organisms for any other purposes than placing on the market within the Community and placing on the market genetically modified organisms as or in products within the Community.

name: Sophie MONTEL
text: In writing. Despite systematic objections, the Commission persists in issuing permits for gmOS crops or imports. Parliament persists in objecting, to no avail, since the Commission does not take this into account. These objections help to unmask the hypocrisy of the majority parliamentarians (who maintain the Commission) in the face of EU totalitarianism. So I'm voting for it.

name: Nadine MORANO
text: In writing. I voted against this objection to the renewal of the authorisation of GMO maize MON 810, which or does not have the responsibility of the Member States, because it is based on the false argument that the Commission has exceeded its powers by authorising this maize. Indeed, the Commission has fully complied with the procedure by asking the European Food Safety Authority for a study on the safety of the plant for human and animal health and for the environment. It then proposed this GMO authorization to the Council, which did not refuse it.

name: József NAGY
text: Writing. \u2012 I believe that until the cultivation of GM species and varieties proves to be of great environmental and economic benefit to European farmers, there is no point in taking even the slightest risk by authorising them. The greater part of the European public has not yet really accepted modern agricultural methods and their unprotused dangers, and I think we legismies should bear this in mind.

name: Victor NEGRESCU
text: in writing. ‒ I have abstained from voting on this motion for a resolution that authorises the placing on the market of products containing, consisting of, or produced from genetically modified maize MON 810 products following a risk evaluation to human health and biodiversity.

name: Momchil NEKOV
text: in writing. – I supported this resolution, initiated by the Committee on the Environment, Public Health and Food Safety, because I believe that without an effective control mechanism within the internal market which can ensure that products which are prohibited from growing in a Member State do not present a danger or conflict with that prohibition or risk its infringement, seed of that prohibited crop cannot and must not be proceeded with. The Bulgarian public is strongly opposed to the use of genetically modified crops, such as GMO maize MON 810. The Single European Market can only function when its terms are accepted by all its participants, without the risk of violating their legal and moral laws. The impact of genetically modified organisms and their products on human health remains under-examined and investigated, so I am of the opinion that it is not appropriate to market such products in the European single market.

name: Franz OBERMAYR
text: Writing. I voted in favour of this resolution because EFSA's risk assessment of cultivation is incomplete and the recommendations on risk management proposed by the Commission are deficient. The Commission is invited to withdraw the implementing decision.

name: Urmas PAET
text: Writing. \u2012 Not supported. Regulation of genetically modified products individually is neither effective nor feasible.

name: Margot PARKER
text: in writing. ‒ We in UKIP are concerned about the safety of GMOs for health and the environment, but we would prefer our national Parliament to legislate on this delicate issue rather than the European Parliament.

name: Aldo PATRICIELLO
text: in writing. \u2012 While taking into account the aspects contained in the objection tabled concerning the renewal of the authorisation for genetically modified maize MON 810, I do not feel able to fully support the proposal. I would therefore like to abstain.

name: Alojz PETERLE
text: Writing. \ u2012 I supported the objection because I believe that the Commission's draft implementing decision goes beyond the implementing powers laid down in Regulation (EC) No 1829/2003. The Commission should withdraw the draft implementing decision authorising genetically modified maize as there is no basis for ensuring a high level of protection of human life and health, animal health and welfare, the environment and consumer interests with regard to genetically modified food and feed, while ensuring the unso tmable functioning of the internal market. I also do not recognise GMO as part of the solution to the problems facing the agricultural and food sectors.

name: Marijana PETIR
text: Written. ‒Insufficient risk assessment and lack of long-term consumption and toxicity studies are likely reasons why no opinion has been issued on this draft Commission implementing decision in either the Standing Or The Board of Appeal. For these reasons, but also since I consider that the Commission's draft implementing decision exceeds the implementing powers of Regulation (EC) No 2013/2013. 1829/2003 and opposes its objective of a high level of protection of human health and life, animal health and welfare, the environment and consumer interests in relation to GM food and feed and at the same time the effective functioning of the internal market, I have decided to support this resolution.  I would like to recall that on 28 October 2015 the European Parliament rejected a legislative proposal of 22 April 2015 amending Regulation (EC) No 22/2016. 1829/2003, because, despite the fact that farming necessarily takes place on the territory of one Member State, trade in GENETICally modified organisms takes place outside national borders and, on the basis of that proposal, it was not possible to carry out successful monitoring of the implementation of the Regulation. As Parliament has proposed to the Commission to submit a new proposal that would take into account member states' concerns, which are not exclusively related to the safety issues of GMOs for health or the environment, to date this has not been done.

name: Tonino PICULA
text: Written. ‒ Parliament rejected a legislative proposal to amend Regulation No 2012. 1829/2003 of April 2015, as trade in genetically modified organisms takes place outside national borders, irrespective of the fact that the cultivation takes place on the territory of one Member State.  This means that the Commission's proposed national ban on 'sale and use' could be unenforceable without reintroducing border controls on imports. The Commission's draft implementing decision exceeds the implementing powers provided for in the Regulation. It is incompatible with Union law, it is incompatible with the objective of the Regulation – to provide for a high level of protection of human health and life, animal health and welfare, the environment and consumer interests with regard to genetically modified food and feed, and of course to ensure the effective functioning of the internal market. I call on the Commission to take into account issues that are often raised at national level.  The two main reasons why Member States voted against or abstained were the lack of studies on long-term consumption and toxicity and insufficient risk assessment. However, I expect from the Commission a new legislative proposal amending Regulation (EC) No 1009/2013. 1829/2003 which will also take into account the concerns expressed by Member States on issues not necessarily related to the safety of GMOs for health or the environment.

name: João PIMENTA LOPES
text: in writing. We are looking at proposals for renewal of authorisation, submitted by Monsanto Europe SA, for existing foods, food ingredients and feed produced from MON810 maize, including cultivation. Once again, as regards the procedures for this authorisation decision, the exception has become a rule. There was no consensus among the Member States, so according to the perverse legislative framework in force, the decision falls into the hands of the European Commission – which invariably has a pro-GMO stance, even in the face of a lack of long-term studies on food toxicity and an insufficient risk assessment, reasons which underlie the position of refusal (or abstention) taken by several Member States. This resolution objects to the authorisation of this Genetically Modified Organism (GMO). We voted in favour. It is necessary and urgent to amend the current legislative framework in order to respect the right of each Member State not to want GMOs on its territory, for food and/or cultivation, for reasons of protection of food sovereignty, the environment, biodiversity and public health.

name: Franck PROUST
text: In writing. I voted against this objection. Indeed, the European Commission has not exceeded its powers and has complied well with the procedure for authorising GMOs, thanks in particular to the opinion of the European Food Safety Authority. As a reminder, this proposal for market authorization was forwarded to the Commission, which did not reject it. Also, these objections used by political groups such as the Greens have no real effect because they relate to acts of execution. More generally, I would like to point out that France bans the cultivation of GMOs, even though it imports them.

name: Laurenţiu REBEGA
text: in writing. \u2012 Studies carried out on genetically modified maize MON 810 have shown that its composition contains the Cry1 Ab protein, known for its property that confers protection against pests represented by certain lepidopteran insects. Thus, by using it in the EU, it can protect insect plantations such as the European spredelitor Ostrinia nubiladis and the pink sesamia spp, insects that endanger maize plantations throughout the EU.

name: Julia REID
text: in writing. ‒ We in UKIP are concerned about the safety of GMOs for health and the environment, but we would prefer our national Parliament to legislate on this delicate issue rather than the European Parliament.

name: Sofia RIBEIRO
text: in writing. \u2012 Whereas, in 2007, Monsanto Europe S.A. submitted three applications to the Commission for the renewal of the authorisation of existing food, food and feed products produced from MON 810 maize or containing MON 810 maize and the authorisation of MON 810 maize in products it contains, it is stated that the Commission's draft implementing decision exceeds the implementing powers laid down in the Regulation. The Commission's draft implementing decision shall be considered not to be in line with UNION law, as it is not compatible with the purpose of the Regulation in question, and the Commission is requested to withdraw its draft implementing decision and to submit, on the basis of the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union, a new legislative proposal amending the Regulation , to take into account concerns often expressed at national level that do not concern only issues relating to the safety of GMOs for health or the environment. In view of what was presented in this report, I voted against it.

name: Bronis ROPĖ
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report, which opposes the decision by the European Commission to renew the authorisation to cultivate MONSanto Europe S.A. genetically modified maize MON-ØØ81Ø-6. The European Parliament considers that the draft Commission implementing decision is not compatible with Union law because it is incompatible with the objective of Regulation (EC) No 1829/2003, which, in accordance with the general principles laid down in Regulation (EC) No 178/2002, aims to develop a framework to ensure a high level of protection of human life and health, animal health and consumer interests with regard to genetically modified food and feed, while ensuring effective functioning of the internal market.

name: Fernando RUAS
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted against this report, following the indication of my political group, not to be opposed to the Commission's decision on the placing on the market of genetically modified maize called MON 810 (MON-ØØ81Ø-6). Since there is no scientific advice from the European Food Safety Authority (EFSA) or another homologous, which understake the prohibition on the marketing of this type of genetically modified maize, I do not consider there to be sufficient reasons that may give rise to a ban on the placing on the market of these products, and I therefore voted against this report.  However, today's position is subject to review if there are new scientific evidence to justify it.

name: Lola SÁNCHEZ CALDENTEY
text: in writing. The use of transgenic seeds is part of a more substantive debate, which can be addressed from three angles: health, environmental and socio-economic impact. I voted in favour of the objection because when we talk about allowing the marketing of transgenic seeds we talk about deepening this unsustainable model, abuses, royalties, dependence on agrochemicals; and socially perverse. We know that GENETICally modified seeds will not be marketed for the benefit of farmers, consumers, society, the environment but for the profit of a giant like Monsanto. A giant whose merger with Bayer will entail the creation of a monster whose consequences for the global agri-food system we are not even able to foresee.

name: Maria Lidia SENRA RODRÍGUEZ
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this objection to the renewal of the authorisation of THE products of MON 810 genetically modified maize because I am totally against genetically modified organisms and, therefore, new authorisations thereof. EFSA's assessment underscores the lack of data and renewal of import authorization for its products based on a legal act that has proven dysfunctional (1829/2003). Moreover, it is clear that the current procedure for the authorisation of genetically modified food and feed is not working properly. That is why I am in favour of this and any objections raised in relation to the authorisation of GMOs, and I voted accordingly.

name: Siôn SIMON
text: in writing. ‒ Today, I voted against the objection pursuant to Rule 106 on the placing on the market of genetically modified maize MON 810 products, as the risk assessment conducted by the European Food Safety Agency (EFSA) concluded that the cultivation of these GM crops is unlikely to pose a danger to human and animal health or to the environment.

name: Branislav ŠKRIPEK
text: Writing. \u2012 I agree that the European Parliament is asking the Commission to withdraw its draft implementing decision authorising the marketing of products derived from genetically modified maize MON 810. I consider that the Commission's draft implementing decision does not comply with Union law, whereas it is incompatible with the objective of Regulation (EC) No 1829/2003, which, according to the general principles laid down in Regulation (EC) No 178/2002, is to provide the basis for ensuring a high level of protection of human life and health, as well as animal welfare, the environment and the interests of consumers in relation to genetically modified food and feed, while ensuring the effective functioning of the internal market. I therefore voted in favour of this resolution.

name: Davor ŠKRLEC
text: Written. ‒ I voted positively for this report, but this explanation of the vote is a criticism of the existing system of evaluation of the work of MEMBERS of the European Parliament solely on the basis of the statistical number of parliamentary activities potentiated in Croatia, which does not really reflect the actual quality and quantity of work, efficiency and most of all the success of parliamentary action.

name: Monika SMOLKOVÁ
text: Writing. \u2012 I agreed with the objection to the Commission's implementing decision to re-authorise the cultivation of GENETICALLY MODIFIED MAIZE. In fact, I believe that we should stick to the principle that, until we have sufficient information on the effects of such crops on human health or the environment, they should not be grown at all on the territory of Europe. In the present case, Monsanto Europe has submitted three applications for renewal of the authorisation of existing food, food ingredients and feed produced from genetically modified maize. In the case of gmo approval, the Commission should consult the competent committees of the Member States on its procedure. However, it has become common practice for committees not to issue an opinion. The main reason why they did not vote or abstain on this request was the lack of long-term studies on feeding and toxicity and the lack of risk assessment. If we cannot guarantee a sufficient level of protection of human life and health, the Commission should not issue such GMO decisions. I am therefore of the opinion that the Commission should withdraw its implementing decision and submit a new legislative proposal that complies with European regulations.

name: Igor ŠOLTES
text: Writing. The European Parliament has successfully expressed its disagreement with the authorisation of five food and feed products from genetically modified organisms. These include products from genetically modified MAM MON 810, which is being dealt with in this resolution. At the same time, the European Commission has rejected the call for a change in the authorisation procedure for the use of individual GMOs, as the European Parliament considers that the procedure is currently not democratic, as decisions are now being taken by the Commission. There is also a certain lack of data on the use and import of GMOs, as the Commission rarely shares data with the European Parliament in such cases. In relation to gmOs, which the Commission wishes to approve for use, research is also carried out by the European Food Safety Authority. As I believe that our food must be kept safe and healthy, I voted in favour of the Parliament resolution which seeks to ensure that the authorisation for use is not accepted.

name: Dubravka ŠUICA
text: Written. ‒ The Commission's draft decision on authorising the marketing of GM maize and products containing it, consisting of or manufactured from it is controversial for a number of reasons. The draft was not voted in line with the EU legislation envisaged. No opinion has been issued on the draft implementing decision and the majority that voted on the draft does not represent the will of most Member States. This did not achieve the commission's envisaged decision control mechanism. Studies conducted on the harmfulness and risks of the use of these products are incomplete. Human health, animal health and the environment need to be protected.  The Commission's proposal on the possibility of a national ban on the cultivation of these products on its territory is contrary to EU principles when it is extended to ban their sale. In the event of a ban on sales in a Member State, there would be a need to verify imports. I therefore support the European Parliament's objection and resolution on the Draft European Commission on the implementing decision on the marketing of GM maize MON 810 (MON-ØØ81Ø-6) and products.

name: Eleftherios SYNADINOS
text: Writing. \u2012 We are against any attempt to liberalise GMOs and we also call on the European Parliament to take an even tougher stance and to block the Commission's attempts to allow, through the use of side-by-side means, their cultivation within the Union.

name: Tibor SZANYI
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the motion for a resolution on the placing on the market of genetically modified MON 810 maize (MON-ØØ81Ø-6). The motion states that, on 11 and 18 April 2007, Monsanto Europe S.A. submitted three applications to the Commission for the renewal of the marketing authorisation for foods, food ingredients and feedingstuffs currently produced from MON 810 maize. This maize contains a cry1ab protein from a germ, which provides resistance to certain pests in the order of butterflies. Member States have expressed concern that there are no long-term studies on nutrition and toxicity and that the risk assessment is not resmissionary. In the case of genetically modified (GM) food and feed, it has also become commonplace for exceptional decision-making practices to return the dossier to the Commission for final approval.  However, a fundamental problem is that, while production necessarily takes place on the territory of a Member State, trade in GMOs crosses borders, which means that the national 'sales and use' ban proposed by the Commission could not be enforced without the reintroducing of import border controls. I therefore agree that the Commission's draft implementing decision does not comply with EU law and does not serve as a basis for a high level of protection of human life and health, animal health and well-being, the environment and consumer interests in genetically modified food and feed.

name: Marc TARABELLA
text: In writing. The European Parliament, which I fully agree with on this issue, considers that this draft commission enforcement decision exceeds the enforcement powers set out in Directive 2001/18/EC. EFSA's crop risk analysis is incomplete and the Commission's risk management recommendations are inadequate. Moreover, the Commission's draft enforcement decision is not in line with EU law. We therefore reject this request!

name: Pavel TELIČKA
text: in writing. ‒ The objection proposed by the Committee on the Environment, Public Health and Food Safety against the renewing of authorisation for the use of genetically modified maize MON 810 products in the European market is part of a larger theme of systematically opposing GM authorisations on mainly procedural grounds and is not the right way to force the Commission to change the EU-level authorisation regime. I voted against the motion to object to the proposal as I believe that as long as there are no convincing scientific reasons to object to a GM authorisation, I will continue to follow the advice given by the European Food and Safety Agency.

name: Ruža TOMAŠIĆ
text: Written. ‒ I voted to object to the renewal of authorisations for GM maize PRODUCTS MON 810, as some Member States of the European Union oppose the introduction of GM products on their market and the European Parliament has not authorised the introduction of GM products on the market either.  Since there are still various doubts about the effect of genetically modified products, both on human health and on the environment and animal health, I think it is irresponsible to renew the approval for a product that we cannot safely claim has no adverse effects. A flawed legal framework and incomplete research results must not be an excuse or justification for potentially compromising people's living standards. Each country should decide for itself whether it wants to introduce genetically modified products on its market, and the same applies to MON 810 maize.

name: Romana TOMC
text: Writing. I supported the objection under Rule 106 of the Rules of Procedure: renewal of the authorisation to place on the market products from genetically modified maize MON 810. In accordance with Articles 11 and 23 of Regulation (EC) No 1829/2007 on 11 and 18 April 2007, Monsanto Europe SA submitted three applications to the Commission for the renewal of the authorisation of existing foods, food ingredients and feed produced from MON 810 maize. The commission's draft implementing decision is not in line with Union law, as it is not consistent with the objective of Regulation (EC) No 1829/2003, which is in line with the general principles laid down in Regulation (EC) No 178/2002 , to provide the basis for ensuring a high level of protection of human life and health, animal health and welfare, the environment and the interests of consumers with regard to genetically modified food and feed, while ensuring the proper functioning of the internal market.

name: Estefanía TORRES MARTÍNEZ
text: in writing. The use of transgenic seeds is part of a more substantive debate, which can be addressed from three angles: health, environmental and socio-economic impact. I voted in favour of the objection because when we talk about allowing the marketing of transgenic seeds we talk about deepening this unsustainable model, abuses, royalties, dependence on agrochemicals; and socially perverse. We know that GENETICally modified seeds will not be marketed for the benefit of farmers, consumers, society, the environment but for the profit of a giant like Monsanto. A giant whose merger with Bayer will entail the creation of a monster whose consequences for the global agri-food system we are not even able to foresee.

name: Mylène TROSZCZYNSKI
text: In writing. Despite systematic objections, the Commission persists in issuing permits for the cultivation or importation of GMOs.  Parliament persists in objecting, to no avail, since the Commission does not take this into account. These objections help to unmask the hypocrisy of the majority parliamentarians (who maintain the Commission) in the face of the totalitarianism of the European Union.  I vote FOR this objection.

name: Kazimierz Michał UJAZDOWSKI
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 Committee on the Environment, Public Health and Food Safety Genetically modified foods can have a negative impact on humans, animals and the environment and should be scrutiny in detail in these respects.  I doubt whether the Commission should allow further types of genetically modified food and feed to be placed on the market. I voted against the renewal of the MON 810 maize seed authorisation and supported the opposition.

name: Miguel URBÁN CRESPO
text: in writing. The use of transgenic seeds is part of a more substantive debate, which can be addressed from three angles: health, environmental and socio-economic impact. I voted in favour of the objection because when we talk about allowing the marketing of transgenic seeds we talk about deepening this unsustainable model, abuses, royalties, dependence on agrochemicals; and socially perverse. We know that GENETICally modified seeds will not be marketed for the benefit of farmers, consumers, society, the environment but for the profit of a giant like Monsanto. A giant whose merger with Bayer will entail the creation of a monster whose consequences for the global agri-food system we are not even able to foresee.

name: Ernest URTASUN
text: in writing. – I voted in favour of the GMO import objection as I have decided to object systematically to any GM import authorisations. This was following the EP rejection of the EC proposal to renationalise instead of democratise the authorisation procedure. In relation of the GMO cultivation I also decided to object as all three maizes are Bt maizes: they all themselves produce the Bt toxin that enables them to be ‘pest-resistant’, meaning they are themselves toxic to the targeted pests – but also the non-targeted, even if those ones are protected or pollinate.

name: Ivo VAJGL
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the  objection pursuant to Rule 106(2) and (3) of the Rules of Procedure on the draft Commission implementing decision authorising the placing on the market of genetically modified maize MON 810 (MON-ØØ81Ø-6) products pursuant to Regulation (EC) No 1829/2003 of the European Parliament and of the Council (D046169/00 – 2016/2922(RSP)). I voted in favour of the objection because I believe that GMOs are now being authorised in the EU by the Commission, without the support of opinions of Member State committees. I find that the Commission goes beyond its powers. Although this was supposed to be an exception to the usual decision-making procedure, it has in fact become the norm.

name: Ángela VALLINA
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this objection to the renewal of the authorisation of THE products of MON 810 genetically modified maize because I am totally against genetically modified organisms and, therefore, new authorisations thereof. EFSA's assessment underscores the lack of data and renewal of import authorization for its products based on a legal act that has proven dysfunctional (1829/2003). Moreover, it is clear that the current procedure for the authorisation of genetically modified food and feed is not working properly. That is why I am in favour of this and any objections raised in relation to the authorisation of GMOs, and I voted accordingly.

name: Miguel VIEGAS
text: in writing. We are in favour of this opposition, and any future objection to the authorisation of GMOs, as a matter of principle, but also with the purpose of showing the European Commission the need to amend the recently adopted legislation with a legislative proposal that will respect the right of an individual not to authorise GMOs for food on its territory.

name: Harald VILIMSKY
text: Writing. The resolution states that the Commission's draft implementing decision is incompatible with EU law and therefore calls on the Commission to withdraw its draft. As EFSA's risk assessment of cultivation is incomplete and the recommendations on risk management proposed by the Commission are deficient, I voted in favour of the resolution.

name: Udo VOIGT
text: Writing. The objections raised in the motion for a resolution to the placing on the market of the genetically modified products in question are well founded and necessarily suggest that the Commission rejects the relevant implementing decision. The motion for a resolution before us is therefore in favour.

name: Julie WARD
text: in writing. ‒ Labour MEPs voted against a ban on pest-resistant maize as we agree with EFSA's assessment that they are unlikely to pose risks to human, animal health or the environment, while limiting the need for use of pesticides. Moreover, the Commission attached stringent conditions for use of these GMOs in their authorisation decisions. I continue to take the issue of GMOs with the utmost seriousness, and will continue to oppose GMO use that is deemed harmful or potentially dangerous.

name: Jana ŽITŇANSKÁ
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported the European Parliament's objection to the Commission's implementing decision renewing the authorisation for genetically modified maize products. My opinion on GMOs does not change, as there is not yet sufficient evidence regarding their wholesomeness. Likewise, we do not have sufficient information on their effects on the environment. That is why I agree with the view that, in the circumstances where the risk assessment is not thorough and complete, the European Commission has exceeded its powers in this implementing regulation, let alone acted in accordance with the precautionary principle, which is absolutely necessary in cases where human health may be at risk.

name: Carlos ZORRINHO
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of all objections under Rule 106 of the Rules of Procedure, because I agree with the opposition to genetically modified substances for which there are still no solid scientific results to allow them to be authorised without compromising public health.  Therefore, until the Commission proposes a new legislative framework for these substances, the European Socialist Group will continue to support these objections in concert.

name: Marco ZULLO
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the resolution strongly calling on the European Commission not to authorise the placing on the market of gm maize products MON 810. Since the beginning of my term of office, I have always fought to make Europe a GMO-free territory, without ifs and buts. Gm food and feed must not enter European territory without ifs and buts. The lack of long-term studies on the nutrition and toxicity of GMOs and insufficient risk assessment have led many Member States to ban even the cultivation of these organisms on their national territory. But if cultivation necessarily takes place on the territory of a Member State, their trade crosses borders, which means that a national 'sale and use' ban proposed by the Commission would be impossible to apply without reintroducing border controls on imports. If the authorisation were renewed, millions of tonnes of transgenic feed would circulate in Europe, feeding our animals and indirectly us too. Together with my colleagues in the M5S, I fought, by promoting this resolution, for a GMO-free Europe.

name: Isabella ADINOLFI
text: in writing. \u2012 The legislative proposal of 22 April 2015 amending Regulation (EC) No Regulation (EC) No 1829/2003 was rejected by Parliament on 28 October 2015 on the ground that, while the cultivation of GMOs necessarily takes place on the territory of a Member State, their trade crosses borders, which means that a national 'sale and use' ban proposed by the Commission would be impossible to apply without reintroducing border controls on imports. The motion for a resolution therefore calls for the Commission's draft implementing decision to be withdrawn, as it does not comply with EU law, as it is incompatible with ensuring a high level of protection of human life and health, animal health and welfare, the environment and consumer interests in relation to genetically modified food and feed. For these reasons, I voted in favour.

name: Tim AKER
text: in writing. – We in UKIP are concerned about the safety of GMOs for health and the environment, but we would prefer our national Parliament to legislate on this delicate issue rather than the European Parliament.

name: Marina ALBIOL GUZMÁN
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this objection to the marketing of genetically modified cotton 281-24-236 × 3006-210-23 × MON 88913 (this cotton is resistant to glyphosate and ammonium glufosinate) because I am totally against genetically modified organisms and, therefore, of new authorizations thereof. Moreover, it is clear that the current procedure for the authorisation of genetically modified food and feed is not working properly. That is why I am in favour of this and any objections raised in relation to the authorisation of GMOs, and I voted accordingly.

name: Martina ANDERSON
text: in writing. – I voted in favour of this GMO authorisation objection. It is absurd that the European Commission continues to propose authorisations of GMOs under a system which they themselves have admitted is flawed. It is essential that Mr Juncker listens to the European Parliament’s call for a new proposal and that the EU GMO authorisation procedure is overhauled completely.

name: Eric ANDRIEU
text: In writing. I am opposed to the importation of cotton 281—24—236. It should be remembered once again that the rules on the authorisation of GMOs are not democratic, according to Jean-Claude Juncker's own admissions. And that as such it is up to Parliament to play its part in promoting transparency and democracy. No new proposals for rules on the importation of GMOs appear to be proposed by the Commission. It should be remembered that a majority of Parliament voted on an amendment asking the Commission to review its copy of the GMO marketing process. Our objective therefore remains the same: no genetically modified food will be validated by the European Parliament in committee, until the Commission has proposed a new framework for the importation of GMOs in order to take into account the majority fact in Europe. It is a question of democracy and also a way of enforcing the choices of the European Parliament in the institutional game.

name: Laima Liucija ANDRIKIENĖ
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the motion for a resolution on the draft Commission implementing decision authorising the placing on the market of products containing, consisting of, or produced from genetically modified cotton. In 2015 the European Parliament rejected the legislative proposal amending Regulation (EC) No 1829/2003 on the grounds that a national sales and use ban proposed by the Commission could be impossible to enforce without reintroducing border checks on imports, and called on the Commission to withdraw its proposal and to submit a new one. Furthermore, the specialised cancer agency of the World Health Organisation, the International Agency for Research on Cancer, classified glyphosate – associated with the cultivation of genetically modified cotton – as probably carcinogenic to humans. Also, as it is stated in the resolution, the draft Commission implementing decision exceeds the implementing powers and is not compatible with the objective provided for in Regulation (EC) No 1829/2003. I therefore support the call to the Commission to withdraw its draft implementing decision and to submit a new legislative proposal on the basis of the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union.

name: Nikos ANDROULAKIS
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the objection pursuance to Rule 106 of the Rules of Procedure concerning the placing on the market of genetically modified cotton 281-24-236 × 3006-210-23 × MON 88913, because the assessment of the risks of cultivation was incomplete and the risk management recommendations proposed by the Commission were inadequate.

name: Marie-Christine ARNAUTU
text: In writing. Five objections are presented by Parliament regarding permits for the cultivation or import of GMOs of maize or wheat.  Despite systematic objections, the Commission persists in issuing authorisations for the cultivation or importation of GMOs. Parliament persists in objecting, to no avail, since the Commission does not take this into account. These objections help to unmask the hypocrisy of the majority parliamentarians (who maintain the Commission) in the face of EU totalitarianism. So I voted for these new objections.

name: Jonathan ARNOTT
text: in writing. ‒ Given that I have no specialist knowledge of the seeds concerned, and having concerns about the use of delegated acts, I felt it appropriate to follow the advice of officials and abstain on this matter.

name: Jean ARTHUIS
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this objection to prohibiting the importation and marketing of herbicide-resistant cotton. Its use could have adverse effects on users and consumers.

name: Gerard BATTEN
text: in writing. ‒ We in UKIP are concerned about the safety of GMOs for health and the environment, but we would prefer our national Parliament to legislate on this delicate issue rather than the European Parliament.

name: Nicolas BAY
text: In writing. Five objections are presented by Parliament on permits for cultivation or imports of GMOs with different properties. The herbicide-tolerant GMO or two that will soon be banned is of little interest and, more importantly, is dangerous for biodiversity. Monitoring of the effects on nature is insufficient, EFSA's assessment is still as minimal and as contrary to food sovereignty. In this case, I voted in favour of this objection to the marketing of genetically modified cotton 281-24-236 × 3006-210-23 × MON 88913.

name: Hugues BAYET
text: In writing. The European Parliament, which I fully agree with on this issue, considers that this draft commission enforcement decision exceeds the enforcement powers set out in Directive 2001/18/EC. EFSA's crop risk analysis is incomplete and the Commission's risk management recommendations are inadequate. Moreover, the Commission's draft enforcement decision is not in line with EU law. We therefore reject this request!

name: Beatriz BECERRA BASTERRECHEA
text: in writing. I am not positioned for or against GMOs. I'm in favor of science. In the Union we have set up an agency for this type of task: the EFSA (EFSA) where the opinion of independent scientists who ensure and guarantee food security in the Union is reflected. Just a few months ago, more than a hundred Nobel laureates encouraged recognizing the findings of the relevant scientific institutions and abandoning campaigns against genetically modified organisms without sufficient scientific support.  Different products need to be analyzed on a case-by-case basis, and the debate should not be generalized or simplified.

name: Brando BENIFEI
text: in writing. \u2012 Today I voted in favour of the objection to the placing on the market of products containing, consisting or obtained from genetically modified cotton 281-24-236 × 3006-210-23 × MON 88913. I believe that the current regulatory framework does not allow the Commission and EFSA to provide adequate assessments of the impact of GMOs. In the case of cotton 281-24-236 × 3006-210-23 × MON 88913, in particular, the problem is the presence of the CP4 protein 5-enolpiruvil-shikimato-3-phosphate modified synthase (CP4 EPSPS), which gives tolerance to herbicides based on glyphosate, a substance that the International Agency for Research on Cancer has included in the list of probable carcinogens for humans. In view of the possible health risks, I therefore voted in favour of the objection, reaffirming the need for the Commission to draw up a comprehensive proposal on GMOs as soon as possible in order to carefully assess the environmental and health impact of these technologies and to establish a new procedure for their authorisation.

name: Xabier BENITO ZILUAGA
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the objection since genetically modified organisms (GMOs) are not managing to control pests and weeds, and instead have led to the appearance of superpestes and superhighds. The cap's new objectives include ensuring food security, protecting the environment and ensuring the economic and social dynamism of rural areas. It is difficult to justify that monsanto's transgenic seed approval meets one of these three objectives.

name: Izaskun BILBAO BARANDICA
text: in writing. I would like to thank the rapporteurs of this report on the marketing of genetically modified cotton 281-24-236 x 3006-210-23 x MON 88913 for their work. This report, as well as the other four that we voted on today on various objections, does not leave anyone indifferent. I have been consistent with my previous votes in this area and supported the report of the European Parliament where the draft Commission Implementing Decision is considered to exceed the implementing powers provided for in Regulation (EC) No 1829/2003.

name: Dominique BILDE
text: In writing. Despite systematic objections, the Commission persists in issuing permits for GMO crops or imports. The aim here is to object to the marketing of genetically modified cotton 281-24-236 × 3006-210-23 × MON 88913 by the manufacturer Down Agro Sciences. The problems raised concern Glufosinate, which is to be banned in 2017 (property is therefore useless), glyphosate which is carcinogenic and the destruction of biodiversity. So I voted for it.

name: Mara BIZZOTTO
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted against the objection to the marketing authorisation of genetically modified cotton 281-24-236 × 3006-210-23 × MON 88913.

name: Vilija BLINKEVIČIŪTĖ
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this resolution, in which the European Parliament that the Commission implementing decision is not compatible with Union law because it is incompatible with the objective of Regulation (EC) No 1829/2003, which, in accordance with the general principles laid down in Regulation (EC) No 178/2002, aims to establish a legal framework to ensure a high level of protection of human life and health, animal health and consumer interests with regard to genetically modified food and feed, while ensuring the effective functioning of the internal market. Parliament rejected on 28 October 2015 on 22 April 2015. The Commission proposal amending Regulation (EC) No 1829/2003 on the grounds that, although crops are inevitably grown in the territory of a Member State, trade in genetically modified organisms (GMOs) is cross-border, which means that it may not be possible to implement the national prohibition on marketing and use proposed by the Commission if imports are not reintroduced under border controls.

name: Andrea BOCSKOR
text: Writing. \u2012 In accordance with the Hungarian Basic Law and the precautionary principle, I am opposed to the authorisation of GMO products, and I believe that that the draft Commission implementing decision does not comply with EU law as it is incompatible with the objective of Regulation (EC) No 1829/2003, which, in accordance with the general principles laid down in Regulation (EC) No 178/2002, is to serve as a basis for a high level of protection of human life and health, animal health and well-being, the environment and consumer interests in genetically modified food and feed, while ensuring the efficient functioning of the internal market. The report calls on the Commission to withdraw its draft implementing decision, and I therefore voted in favour of the adoption of this report.

name: Franc BOGOVIČ
text: Writing. I also supported the latest objection to the placing on the market of GM products for GM cotton. In order to further avoid continuing objections to the Commission's conclusions on GMOs issues, the latter should take more account of frequently expressed national concerns, which do not only concern health or environmental safety issues. As I am a supporter of the precautionary principle in GMO, I believe that the placing on the market of such products must be extremely conservative, as we do not yet know at present all the consequences for human health that may result from the consumption of products produced from GMOs. We must also take into account the will of people, who mostly do not want to grow GMOs in Europe.

name: Biljana BORZAN
text: Written. ‒I support this report because it is a political message to the Commission that Parliament will not support any new approval of GMO cultures and products as long as the gm food licensing process is not reformed.

name: Mercedes BRESSO
text: in writing. ‒ I supported the resolution on the option of placing genetically modified cotton on the market, rejecting the Commission’s draft. Following this vote I hope the Commission will submit a new legislative proposal that will address other national concerns not related only to the safety of GMOs for health or the environment.

name: Renata BRIANO
text: in writing. \u2012 Genetically modified cotton expresses the PAT protein, which gives tolerance to herbicides based on ammonium glufosinate; the CP4 EPSPS protein, which gives tolerance to glyphosate-based herbicides; and Cry1F and Cry1Ac proteins, which give protection from some lepidoptes. In addition, in 2015, the International Agency for Research on Cancer put glyphosate on the list of likely carcinogens for humans. The commission's draft implementing decision was adopted in the Standing Committee without any opinion being delivered and the same was done in the Appeal Committee. Parliament also rejected the legislative proposal because GMOs are grown on the territory of a Member State but trade crosses borders, so a national 'sale and use' ban proposed by the Commission would be impossible to apply without reintroducing border controls. The Commission's draft implementing decision is not in accordance with Union law because it is not compatible with the objective of ensuring a high level of protection of human life and health, animal health and welfare, the environment and consumer interests. The Commission is therefore asked to present a new legislative proposal.

name: Steeve BRIOIS
text: In writing. This report proposes to adopt five objections to GMO cultivation or import authorizations, including from Monsanto. These objections highlight, in particular, the hypocrisy and dual discourse of the European parliamentarians of the majority groups, who vote the opposite of what they promise their constituents. I voted in favour of these objections.

name: Nicola CAPUTO
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this objection today because I believe that EFSA's cultivation risk assessment is incomplete and that the risk management recommendations proposed by the Commission are inadequate. Various studies on the cultivation of GMO cotton have given rise to serious concerns about the safety of this type of cotton. A recent report found that thousands of sheep and goats died in New Zealand after grazing on land where GMO cotton had been grown. What is more, GMO cotton crops have failed in India. I would also point out that, on 16 December 2015, the European Parliament declared the GMO approval system 'not working' and added that 'any implementing decision authorizing the placing on the market of products containing, consisting of or obtained from genetically modified organisms ... should be suspended." No GMOs should be authorised until democratic control of Commission decisions has been strengthened and correctly reflects the opinion of the majority of Member States, MEPs and European citizens. I therefore call on the Commission to withdraw the draft implementing decision.

name: Matt CARTHY
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of these objections to GMO authorisations. The European Commission has yet to propose a new authorisation procedure since its very weak proposal was rejected earlier this year.  In spite of the fact that the EP called for a new proposal, the Commission continues to authorise GMOs under a flawed procedure which they themselves have admitted does not work. For these reasons I voted in favour of the objection.

name: David CASA
text: in writing. ‒ I believe that this draft Commission implementing decision is not consistent with Union law, in that it is not compatible with the objective of Regulation (EC) No 1829/2003, which is, in accordance with the general principles laid down in Regulation (EC) No 178/2002, to provide the basis for ensuring a high level of protection of human life and health, animal health and welfare, environment and consumer interests in relation to genetically modified food and feed, whilst ensuring the effective functioning of the internal market. The motion for a resolution calls on the Commission to withdraw its draft implementing decision.

name: Fabio Massimo CASTALDO
text: in writing. \u2012 The European Commission has asked the European Food Safety Authority (EFSA) to assess whether new evidence has emerged that would change the recommendations of EFSA's scientific advice on the placing on the market of products containing, consisted or obtained from genetically modified cotton 281-24-236 × 3006-210-23 × MON 88913. The European Parliament resolution on the European Commission's draft implementing decision considers efsa's cultivation risk assessment to be incomplete and that the risk management recommendations proposed by the European Commission are inadequate and therefore calls for the draft implementing decision to be withdrawn.
