Together with the M5S delegation, I voted in favour of the resolution.

name: Lefteris CHRISTOFOROU
text: Writing. \u2012 The issue of Genetically Modified Organisms (GMOs) is particularly important and has been of concern to the European Union since the 1990s. We believe that the objective of the competent authorities of the Member States of the European Union should be to control and limit any negative effects of GMOs, while leaving room for research action in the new scientific field of biotechnology or even for use on the market, if the products prove useful and harmless.

name: Kostas CHRYSOGONOS
text: Writing. \u2012 We voted on the objection to the placing on the market of certain types of genetically modified cotton. I believe that the objections raised are reasonable and legitimate as the scope for controlling the impact of these agencies has not been exhausted. I therefore voted in favour.

name: Deirdre CLUNE
text: in writing. ‒ I rejected this objection as I support the EFSA and the European Commission's scientific GMO authorisation procedure.

name: Jane COLLINS
text: in writing. – We in UKIP are concerned about the safety of GMOs for health and the environment, but we would prefer our national Parliament to legislate on this delicate issue rather than the European Parliament.

name: Therese COMODINI CACHIA
text: in writing. ‒ It transpires that the risk assessment of cultivation conducted by EFSA is incomplete and the risk management recommendations proposed by the Commission are inadequate; therefore, I agree that we should withdraw the Commission’s draft implementing decision. I have consistently voted against placing on the market genetically modified organisms within the Community in line with the precautionary principle, which I believe should be followed in issues related to human health and the environment of our citizens

name: Javier COUSO PERMUY
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this objection to the marketing of genetically modified cotton 281-24-236 × 3006-210-23 × MON 88913 (this cotton is resistant to glyphosate and ammonium glufosinate) because I am totally against genetically modified organisms and, therefore, of new authorizations thereof. Moreover, it is clear that the current procedure for the authorisation of genetically modified food and feed is not working properly. That is why I am in favour of this and any objections raised in relation to the authorisation of GMOs, and I voted accordingly.

name: Andrea COZZOLINO
text: in writing. \u2012 I believe that the Commission's recommendations are not adequate and that a new legislative proposal should be presented which takes greater account of the concerns frequently expressed at national level and which do not only relate to issues relating to the safety of GMOs for health or the environment. To date, the risk assessment of the placing on the market of genetically modified cotton seeds of genetically modified maize 281-24-236X 3006-210-23X MON 88913 does not appear to be complete and the Commission's recommendations do not seem adequate. In my opinion, it is a priority to take account of compliance with the precautionary principle, in bringing the laws, regulations and administrative provisions of the Member States closer together and in protecting human health and the environment, at least until the methods of risk assessment have been improved.

name: Edward CZESAK
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 I supported the opposition to the placing on the market of gm cotton grains 281-24-236 × 3006-210-23 × MON 88913. I believe that no novel food or genetically modified feed should be allowed under the current legal framework. This framework is one of the most restrictive in the world when it comes to assessing the risk to GMO crops and food, which makes me happy. I believe that this should remain unchanged, which is why I voted in favour.

name: Miriam DALLI
text: in writing. ‒ Authorising the placing on the market of products containing, consisting of or produced from genetically modified cotton 281-24-236 × 3006-210-23 × MON 88913 was also voted on. This cotton is glyphosate-resistant and the import authorisation is based on a legal act that has proved to be dysfunctional. Doubts about this cotton’s safety for human health and the environment are still being debated. This has led me to vote in favour of this objection until further information is issued.

name: Michel DANTIN
text: In writing. This objection is intended to oppose the marketing of GMO MON 88913. I am against this objection insofar as the European Commission has complied with its mandate as part of its enforcement power granted by the European Parliament and the Council. I regret that this ideologically motivated resolution does not take into account the numerous precautionary measures voted by the European legislator on the authorisation to market new products, as well as the positive scientific opinion granted by the European Food Safety Authority. For these reasons, I voted against this objection.

name: Angélique DELAHAYE
text: In writing. I voted against this objection to refusing to market products containing genetically modified cotton for marketing purposes. This objection is based on a charge made to the Commission: by this authorization it would exceed the enforcement powers assigned to it. However, the Commission has complied with the existing procedure for authorising GMOs. It has previously requested an analysis by the European Food Safety Authority (EFSA) to verify that the plant is not dangerous to human and animal health, and to the environment. This objection, in my view, therefore does not have to be and merely reflects a desire to systematically ban all GMOs, even though it is the responsibility of the Member States.

name: Marielle DE SARNEZ
text: In writing. Currently, genetically modified organisms (GMOs) can be grown on the territory of the European Union after obtaining a marketing licence from GMO seed companies in accordance with European regulations. The European Parliament has chosen to use its power of objection to ask the Commission to withdraw its authorisations for the use of genetically modified maize seeds tolerant of glyphosate, a herbicide classified as a "probable carcinogen" by the World Health Organization (WHO). In the future, the GMO authorisation process, which should not be possible, should be reviewed without the support of a qualified majority of Member States and the approval of Parliament.

name: Angel DZHAMBAZKI
text: in writing. \u2012 I supported this objection as I am against the use of GMOs and the placing on the market of genetically modified goods. Furthermore, there is no solid data on risk assessment and impact assessment methods in the relevant case, which calls safety into question.

name: Georgios EPITIDEIOS
text: Writing. We are voting in favour because we are against any attempt to liberalise GMOs and we are even calling on the European Parliament to take an even tougher stance and to block the Commission's attempts to allow them to be grown sideways within the Union.

name: Norbert ERDŐS
text: Writing. – Cotton 281-24-236x3006-210-23xMON88913 produces two types of protein: pat protein, which makes it resistant to glyphosate ammonium pesticides, and cp4 EPSPS protein modified to make it glyphosate-tolerant. It also produces Cry1F and Cry1Ac proteins, which enable it to protect against certain Lepidoptera species. Studies on the health safety of the product were not satisfactory. Longer-term feeding trials should also have been carried out in order to determine whether this product does not pose a risk to human or animal health. In my view, GM products that have not been thoroughly tested in terms of health and environmental safety should not be authorised in the European Union. Scientific studies to identify risks are inadequate and I therefore do not support the authorisation of GM products in accordance with the Hungarian Basic Law and the precautionary principle.

name: Jill EVANS
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this objection to the authorisation of genetically modified cotton because the current legal framework for authorising GMOs is not democratic. Decisions are made by the Commission without the agreement of the Member States. I represent Wales, which has declared itself GM-free, and I want that decision to be respected.

name: José Manuel FERNANDES
text: in writing. \u2012 The commission's draft implementing decision exceeds the implementing powers laid down in Regulation (EC) No 1829/2003 and is not in line with EU law, to the extent that it is not compatible with the purpose of Regulation (EC) No 1829/2003, which is to provide the basis for ensuring, as far as genetically modified food and feed is concerned, a high level of protection of human life and health, animal health and health, the environment and consumer interests, while ensuring the functioning of the internal market.  I agree with the withdrawal of the draft implementing decision and the presentation of a new legislative proposal amending the Regulation in question.

name: Edouard FERRAND
text: In writing. Vote for: despite systematic objections, the Commission persists in issuing permits for GMO crops or imports. Parliament persists in objecting, to no avail, since the Commission does not take this into account. These objections help to unmask the hypocrisy of the majority parliamentarians (who maintain the Commission) in the face of EU totalitarianism.

name: João FERREIRA
text: in writing. \u2012 Genetically modified cotton referred to in this objection expresses phosphotricinprotein acetyltransferase (PAT) and modified protein CP4EPSPS, which confer tolerance to herbicides containing ammonia glufosinate and glyphosate, as well as Cry1F and Cry1 Ac proteins, which provide protection against some lepidopteran phees. Once again, as regards the procedures for this authorisation decision, the exception has become a rule. There was no consensus among the Member States, so according to the perverse legislative framework in force, the decision falls into the hands of the European Commission – which invariably has a pro-GMO stance, even in the face of a lack of long-term studies on food toxicity and an insufficient risk assessment, reasons which underlie the position of refusal (or abstention) taken by several Member States. This resolution objects to the authorisation of this Genetically Modified Organism (GMO). We voted in favour. It is necessary and urgent to amend the current legislative framework in order to respect the right of each Member State not to want GMOs on its territory, for food and/or cultivation, for reasons of protection of food sovereignty, the environment, biodiversity and public health.

name: Luke Ming FLANAGAN
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour as I believe GM crops are a threat to our existence.

name: Lorenzo FONTANA
text: in writing. \u2012 I am voting in favour of the resolution proposing an objection to the authorisation of a GMO by the Commission.

name: Lampros FOUNTOULIS
text: Writing. \u2012 I am voting in favour of the objection raised in accordance with Article 106 concerning the placing on the market of genetically modified cotton 281-24-236 × 3006-210-23 × MON 88913, because I am against any attempt to liberalise the use of GMOs. I also call on the European Parliament to take an even tougher stance and to prevent any attempts by the Commission to allow their cultivation within the Union by the way.

name: Kinga GÁL
text: Writing. \u2012 Studies on the health safety of genetically modified cotton have not been satisfactory. Longer-term feeding trials should also have been carried out in order to determine whether this product does not pose a risk to human or animal health. In my view, GM products that have not been thoroughly tested in terms of health and environmental safety should not be authorised in the European Union. Scientific studies to identify risks are inadequate and I therefore do not support the authorisation of GM products in accordance with the Hungarian Basic Law and the precautionary principle.

name: Ildikó GÁLL-PELCZ
text: Writing. – Cotton 281-24-236x3006-210-23xMON88913 produces two types of protein: pat protein, which makes it resistant to glyphosate ammonium pesticides, and cp4 EPSPS protein modified to make it glyphosate-tolerant. It also produces Cry1F and Cry1Ac proteins, which enable it to protect against certain Lepidoptera species. Studies on the health safety of the product were not satisfactory. Longer-term feeding trials should also have been carried out in order to determine whether this product does not pose a risk to human or animal health. In my view, GM products that have not been thoroughly tested in terms of health and environmental safety should not be authorised in the European Union. Scientific studies to identify risks are inadequate and I therefore do not support the authorisation of GM products in accordance with the Hungarian Basic Law and the precautionary principle.

name: Francisco de Paula GAMBUS MILLET
text: in writing. I voted against the objection concerning the marketing of genetically modified cotton 281-24-236 × 3006-210-23 × MON 88913. Having considered the objection raised, I believe that there are sufficient checks and guarantees on the part of the European Commission as well as on the Member States. It is necessary to maintain a high level of protection of human life and health, animal health and welfare, the environment and the interests of consumers in relation to genetically modified food and feed, while ensuring the effective functioning of the internal market.

name: Elena GENTILE
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the EP resolution on the objection to the Commission's draft implementing decision authorising the placing on the market of products made up of or obtained from genetically modified cotton and on as many resolutions on the placing on the market or renewal of authorisations for genetically modified seeds and maize, on the basis of as many requests for objections made by the EP's ENVI Committee, because I believe that the relevant proposals for authorisation decisions made by the European Commission are not, firstly, consistent with EU legislation and, secondly, not compatible with the objectives of Regulation No 1829/2003 on genetically modified food and feed. I therefore wholefully supported the withdrawal of these decisions and the request to the European Commission to submit new legislative proposals on the basis of the TFEI.

name: Nathan GILL
text: in writing. ‒ I am concerned about the safety of GMOs and their impact on health and the environment, but I would prefer the UK Government to legislate on this delicate issue, rather than the European Parliament.

name: Tania GONZÁLEZ PEÑAS
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the objection since genetically modified organisms (GMOs) are not managing to control pests and weeds, and instead have led to the appearance of superpestes and superhighds. The cap's new objectives include ensuring food security, protecting the environment and ensuring the economic and social dynamism of rural areas. It is difficult to justify that monsanto's transgenic seed approval meets one of these three objectives.

name: Theresa GRIFFIN
text: in writing. ‒ Today, I voted in favour of the objection pursuant to Rule 106 on the placing on the market of genetically modified cotton 281-24-236 × 3006-210-23 × MON 88913 as the authorisation of GMOs resistant to herbicides is likely to result in excessive herbicide spraying. It is important to ensure that the EU regulatory framework with regards to GMOs is further improved, particularly in terms of assessing GMOs’ impacts on the wider environment as well as on human health

name: András GYÜRK
text: Writing. \u2012 Cotton 281-24-236x3006-210-23xMON88913 produces two types of protein: pat protein, which makes it resistant to glyphosine ammonium pesticides, and cp4 EPSPS protein modified to make it glyphosate-tolerant. It also produces Cry1F and Cry1Ac proteins that enable it to protect against certain Lepidoptera species. Studies on the health safety of the product were not satisfactory. Longer-term feeding trials should also have been carried out in order to determine whether this product does not pose a risk to human or animal health. In my view, GM products that have not been thoroughly tested in terms of health and environmental safety should not be authorised in the European Union. Scientific studies to identify risks are inadequate and I therefore do not support the authorisation of GM products in accordance with the Hungarian Basic Law and the precautionary principle.

name: Marian HARKIN
text: in writing. ‒ I supported the objection because I believe the Commission’s implementing decision is not compatible with Union law. As well as that, there was no agreement among Member States in the Standing Committee to approve this product, mainly due to the lack of long-term feeding and toxicity studies and insufficient risk assessment studies. I would also like to stress there are still important data gaps in the risk assessment of these GM maize crops and authorising their release in the environment would contradict the precautionary principle. For all of the above reasons I voted in favour of the objection, plus the fact that I do not support the introduction of GMOs into the European Union.

name: György HÖLVÉNYI
text: Writing. \u2012 Cotton 281-24-236x3006-210-23xMON88913 produces two types of protein: pat protein, which makes it resistant to glyphosine ammonium pesticides, and cp4 EPSPS protein modified to make it glyphosate-tolerant. It also produces Cry1F and Cry1Ac proteins that enable it to protect against certain Lepidoptera species. Studies on the health safety of the product were not satisfactory. Longer-term feeding trials should also have been carried out in order to determine whether this product does not pose a risk to human or animal health. In my view, GM products that have not been thoroughly tested in terms of health and environmental safety should not be authorised in the European Union. Scientific studies to identify risks are inadequate and I therefore do not support the authorisation of GM products in accordance with the Hungarian Basic Law and the precautionary principle.

name: Ivan JAKOVČIĆ
text: Written. ‒ 91 - I voted to object in accordance with Article 106. Rules of Procedure: placing on the market genetically modified cotton 281-24-236 x 3006-210-23 x MON 88913 because I do not support the use of genetically modified organisms on agricultural lands.

name: Jean-François JALKH
text: In writing. We are witnessing a balancing act: the Commission persists in encouraging the cultivation and importation of GMOs into our countries with its authorisations, and in sweeping away parliament's equally stubborn opposition. All this is indeed of little use, and is not enough to absolve parliamentarians of their responsibility, which maintain the Commission by the Band in its omnipotence. I reiterate my refusal to market genetically modified cotton 281-24-236 x 3006-210-23 x MON 88913. True to my convictions, I voted for it.

name: Diane JAMES
text: in writing. – We in UKIP are concerned about the safety of GMOs for health and the environment, but we would prefer our national Parliament to legislate on this delicate issue rather than the European Parliament.

name: Marc JOULAUD
text: In writing. I voted against this objection to the European Commission's introduction of genetically modified cotton. By authorising marketing for cultivation or marketing purposes, the Commission has duly complied with the procedure, taking into account the analysis of the European Food Safety Authority. It is also important to remember that genetically modified products found on french shelves or in French cultures are approved by the French state, not the European Union.

name: Barbara KAPPEL
text: Writing. I am voting in favour of this report. It rejects the Commission's proposal to allow a cotton variety and forces the Commission to reconsider its proposal. The implementing decision is incompatible with Union law, the recommendation on risk management is deficient and genetically modified foods must be rejected in general from an Austrian point of view.

name: Krišjānis KARIŅŠ
text: Writing. \u2012 Like I supported other resolutions calling for the withdrawal of the European Commission's implementing decisions on the placing on the market of genetically modified products or products containing genetically modified raw materials, I also supported this. I believe that the European Commission has more resources in its mandate to investigate and understand the impact of genetically modified products on the environment and human health. Consequently, the European Commission has the power to come up with a better and clearer solution for the release and free trade on the European Market of genetically modified products or products containing genetically modified raw materials. It must be clearly investigated whether these products are indeed harmful, do not damage human health or have an impact on the environment, and until the possible consequences are identified, these implementing acts are not acceptable. That is why I voted in favour of the resolution in Strasbourg at the European Parliament plenary session, which calls for the commission's implementing decision on the placing of genetically modified maize seed on the market for cultivation purposes.

name: Ádám KÓSA
text: Writing. \u2012 Cotton 281-24-236x3006-210-23xMON88913 produces two types of protein: pat protein, which makes it resistant to glyphosine ammonium pesticides, and cp4 EPSPS protein modified to make it glyphosate-tolerant. It also produces Cry1F and Cry1Ac proteins that enable it to protect against certain Lepidoptera species. Studies on the health safety of the product were not satisfactory. Longer-term feeding trials should also have been carried out in order to determine whether this product does not pose a risk to human or animal health. In my view, GM products that have not been thoroughly tested in terms of health and environmental safety should not be authorised in the European Union. Scientific studies to identify risks are inadequate and I therefore do not support the authorisation of GM products in accordance with the Hungarian Basic Law and the precautionary principle.

name: Gilles LEBRETON
text: In writing. I voted for this objection because it opposes the use of a GMO that is dangerous to biodiversity. The European Parliament agreed to vote on it, demonstrating that the Commission's initiative was harmful. I want France to regain its food sovereignty.

name: Philippe LOISEAU
text: In writing. The Commission persists in issuing permits for the cultivation or importation of GMOs. Parliament persists in objecting, to no avail, since the Commission does not take this into account. I voted in favour of that objection.

name: Paloma LÓPEZ BERMEJO
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this objection to the marketing of genetically modified cotton 281-24-236 × 3006-210-23 × MON 88913 (this cotton is resistant to glyphosate and ammonium glufosinate) because I am totally against its authorisation. It is clear that the current procedure for the authorisation of genetically modified food and feed is not working with guarantees and I voted accordingly.

name: Petr MACH
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted against the Commission's decision authorising the distribution of products containing genetically modified cotton. I respect the right of individual Member States, where appropriate, to prohibit such products in their territory, but I do not consider it right not to restrict those States which do not mind such products. I am thus behind the Commission's decision.

name: Andrejs MAMIKINS
text: in writing. ‒ I agree that the Commission should  withdraw its draft implementing decision and submit a new legislative proposal on the basis of the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union, amending Regulation (EC) No 1829/2003 to take into account frequently expressed national concerns which do not relate only to issues associated with the safety of GMOs for health or the environment.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: Writing. \u2012 I am voting in favour of the motion for a resolution calling on the European Commission to withdraw its draft implementing decision approving the placing on the market of products containing, consisting of or produced from genetically modified cotton 281-24-236 × 3006-210-23 × MON 88913, because it is complete and documented.

name: Dominique MARTIN
text: In writing. I voted for this text.  Five objections are presented by Parliament regarding permits to grow or import GMOs. The different properties of these GMOs pose several problems: carcinogenic herbicides, insecticides causing the destruction of biodiversity, etc. We are therefore in favour of these objections and, in this case, in favour of the marketing of genetically modified cotton, technically called 281-24-236 x 3006-210-23 x MON 88913.

name: Georg MAYER
text: Writing. The resolution states that the Commission's draft implementing decision is incompatible with EU law and therefore calls on the Commission to withdraw its draft. As EFSA's risk assessment of cultivation is incomplete and the recommendations on risk management proposed by the Commission are deficient, I voted in favour of the resolution.

name: Valentinas MAZURONIS
text: Writing. \u2012 I support the EP resolution because it opposes the Commission's decision to authorise the marketing of foodstuffs, food ingredients and feed containing genetically modified cotton. I believe that, in accordance with the precautionary principle and the objective of protecting human health and the environment, decisions on trade in GMO products should only be taken once uncontested scientific evidence of their effects has been provided. Unfortunately, at present, risk assessments for GMOs production are not complete and unennutrs. For these reasons, I do not support the development, trade and cultivation of GMOs in the EU.

name: Jean-Luc MÉLENCHON
text: In writing. The report opposes the Commission's decision to allow genetically modified cotton to be put on the market 281-24-236 × 3006-210-23 × MON 88913. These cotton varieties developed by Dowagroscience and Monsanto are tolerant to glyphosate, a toxic and possibly carcinogenic substance, as well as to repretoxic ammonium glufosinate. These cottons are also resistant to lepidoptera through the addition of the Cry1 F and Cry 1 Ac genes. This has the long-term effect of increasing lepidopteran tolerance to these proteins and leads to the use of increasingly potent plant protection products in ever-increasing quantities. I'm voting for this report.

name: Joëlle MÉLIN
text: In writing. The Commission persists in issuing permits for the cultivation or importation of GMOs. Parliament persists in objecting, to no avail, since the Commission does not take this into account. I voted in favour of this objection, as did the other four.

name: Nuno MELO
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this resolution because I believe that the Commission's draft implementing decision exceeds the implementing powers laid down in Regulation (EC) No 829/2003 in the case of the placing on the market of genetically modified cotton 281-24-236 × 3006-210-23 × MON 88913.

name: Roberta METSOLA
text: in writing. ‒ I chose to support this objection on the placing on the market of genetically modified cotton 281-24-236 × 3006-210-23 × MON 88913 as the Commission’s draft implementing decision risks endangering health, the ecosystem and consumer interests.

name: Louis MICHEL
text: Written. – At the beginning of 2016, there were some 7.4 billion people on our planet. In the most prudent scenario, the world's population will grow to 9 billion by 2050. Rapid growth of the world's population implies that demand for food and crops will also increase proportionately. Entrepreneurs in agriculture and food are facing important challenges. The existing agricultural area will have to be continued and better utilised. Innovation in agriculture will focus on sustainable and efficient agricultural techniques and plant technology will play a special role in ensuring food production. In that context, there are currently no convincing scientific arguments for objecting to a GM licence.

name: Miroslav MIKOLÁŠIK
text: Writing. – Dow AgroSciences Europe submitted a request to the competent authority of the Netherlands in 2009 to place on the market food, food ingredients and feed containing cotton 281-24-236 × 3006-210-23 × and MON 88913. This genetically modified cotton ensures, inter alia, tolerance to glyphosate-based herbicides. However, glyphosate was classified as a probable cancer-forming agent in 2015 by the World Health Organisation for Research on Cancer (WHO, a specialised agency). Under EU law, all authorised GMOs must meet traceability and labelling requirements. The aim is to provide consumers with information and freedom of choice and the possibility for Member States to take appropriate measures if an unforeseen adverse effect is shown. In this case, even if the cultivation of GMOs takes place in the territory of a Member State, trade in gmos is of a cross-border nature, so that a national ban on sale and use, as proposed by the Commission, could not be enforced without the reintroduction of border controls on imported goods. Proposal for a Commission Implementing Decision authorising the placing on the market of products containing genetically modified cotton under Regulation (EC) No 1829/2003 of the European Parliament and of the Council goes beyond the implementing powers provided for in this Regulation. Therefore, the Commission should withdraw its implementing decision and submit a new proposal to amend that Regulation.

name: Marlene MIZZI
text: in writing. ‒ I have supported the decision to object to the placing on the market of genetically modified cotton 281-24-236 × 3006-210-23 × MON 88913 because the draft Commission implementing decision is not consistent with Union law. In accordance with the precautionary principle, to approximate the laws, regulations and administrative provisions of the Member States and to protect human health and the environment when carrying out the deliberate release into the environment of genetically modified organisms for any other purposes than placing on the market within the Community and placing on the market genetically modified organisms as or in products within the Community.

name: Sophie MONTEL
text: In writing. Despite systematic objections, the Commission persists in issuing permits for gmOS crops or imports. Parliament persists in objecting, to no avail, since the Commission does not take this into account. These objections help to unmask the hypocrisy of the majority parliamentarians (who maintain the Commission) in the face of the Union's totalitarianism. So I'm voting for it.

name: Nadine MORANO
text: In writing. I voted against this objection to the authorisation of GMO cotton 281-24-236 x 3006-210-23 x MON 88913, which is under the jurisdiction of the Member States or not, because it is based on the false argument that the Commission exceeded its powers by authorising this maize. Indeed, the Commission has fully complied with the procedure by asking the European Food Safety Authority for a study on the safety of the plant for human and animal health and for the environment. It then proposed this GMO authorization to the Council, which did not refuse it.

name: József NAGY
text: Writing. \u2012 I believe that until the cultivation of GM species and varieties proves to be of great environmental and economic benefit to European farmers, there is no point in taking even the slightest risk by authorising them. The greater part of the European public has not yet really accepted modern agricultural methods and their unprotused dangers, and I think we legismies should bear this in mind.

name: Victor NEGRESCU
text: in writing. ‒ I have abstained in voting this motion for a resolution that authorises the placing on the market of products containing, consisting of, or produced from genetically modified cotton 281-24-236 × 3006-210-23 × MON 88913 following a risk evaluation to human health and biodiversity.

name: Momchil NEKOV
text: in writing. – I supported this resolution, initiated by the Committee on the Environment, Public Health and Food Safety, because I believe that without an effective control mechanism within the internal market which can ensure that products which are prohibited from growing in a Member State do not present a danger or conflict with that prohibition or risk its infringement, seed of that prohibited crop cannot and must not be proceeded with. The Bulgarian public is strongly opposed to the use of genetically modified crops, products containing, consisting of or produced from genetically modified cotton 281-24-236 × 3006-210-23 × MON 88913 (DAS-24236-5×DAS-21Ø23-5×MON-88913-8). The Single European Market can only function when its terms are accepted by all its participants, without the risk of violating their legal and moral laws. The impact of genetically modified organisms and their products on human health remains under-examined and investigated, so I am of the opinion that it is not appropriate to market such products in the European single market.

name: Franz OBERMAYR
text: Writing. I voted in favour of this resolution because EFSA's risk assessment of cultivation is incomplete and the recommendations on risk management proposed by the Commission are deficient. The Commission is invited to withdraw the implementing decision.

name: Urmas PAET
text: Writing. \u2012 Not supported. Regulation of genetically modified products individually is neither effective nor feasible.

name: Margot PARKER
text: in writing. ‒ We in UKIP are concerned about the safety of GMOs for health and the environment but we would prefer our national Parliament to legislate on this delicate issue rather than the European Parliament.

name: Aldo PATRICIELLO
text: in writing. \u2012 With reference to the objection concerning the placing on the market of genetically modified cotton 281-24-236 × 3006-210-23 × MON 88913, while noting the scope of this argument, I cannot fully support the proposal presented. I would therefore like to abstain.

name: Alojz PETERLE
text: Writing. \ i supported the objection because I believe that the Commission's draft implementing decision goes beyond the implementing powers laid down in Regulation (EC) No 1829/2003. The Commission should withdraw the draft implementing decision authorising genetically modified cotton as there is no basis for ensuring a high level of protection of human life and health, animal health and welfare, the environment and consumer interests with regard to genetically modified food and feed, while ensuring the unso t functioning of the internal market.

name: Marijana PETIR
text: Written. \u2012 Genetically modified cotton 281-24-236 × 3006-210-23 × MON 88913 expresses genes of phosphinotricin-acetyl-transferase protein (PAT) that allows tolerance to her her amonia glufosinate and modified protein GENE CP4 5-enolpiruvil-šikimat-3-phosphate synthase (CP4EPSPS) that allows tolerance to glyphosate herbicides, as well as protein genes Cry1F and Cry1Ac, which provide protection against certain pest insects from the order Lepidoptera. Tolerance to herbicides with active glyphosate means that the economic effect will be recognizable only with the application of herbicides with this active substance. However, glyphosate has been classified by the World Health Organization as carcinogenic to humans. For this reason, I consider that the draft implementing decision is incompatible with the objective of a high level of protection of human health and life, animal health and welfare, the environment and consumer interests in relation to GM food and feed on the simultaneous effective functioning of the internal market set by Regulation (EC) No 100/2013. 1829/2003, the draft exceeds both the implementing powers of that Regulation and I therefore support the Resolution and underline that the Regulation must be amended in such a way that the care of the wishes of the Member States is not limited to health and environmental impact issues.

name: Tonino PICULA
text: Written. ‒ In October last year, Parliament rejected a legislative proposal to amend Regulation No 2012. 1829/2003 of April of the same year, as trade in genetically modified organisms takes place outside national borders, irrespective of the fact that the cultivation takes place on the territory of one Member State. This means that the Commission's proposed national ban on 'sale and use' could be unenforceable without reintroducing border controls on imports. This draft Implementing Decision of the Commission exceeds the implementing powers provided for in the Regulation. It is incompatible with Union law, it is incompatible with the objective of the Regulation – to provide for a high level of protection of human health and life, animal health and welfare, the environment and consumer interests with regard to genetically modified food and feed, and of course to ensure the effective functioning of the internal market. I call on the Commission to take into account issues that are often raised at national level and do not only relate to safety concerns of genetically modified organisms for health and the environment.

name: João PIMENTA LOPES
text: in writing. \u2012 Genetically modified cotton referred to in this objection expresses phosphotricinprotein acetyltransferase (PAT) and modified protein CP4EPSPS, which confer tolerance to herbicides containing ammonia glufosinate and glyphosate, as well as Cry1F and Cry1 Ac proteins, which provide protection against some lepidopteran phees. Once again, as regards the procedures for this authorisation decision, the exception has become a rule. There was no consensus among the Member States, so according to the perverse legislative framework in force, the decision falls into the hands of the European Commission – which invariably has a pro-GMO stance, even in the face of a lack of long-term studies on food toxicity and an insufficient risk assessment, reasons which underlie the position of refusal (or abstention) taken by several Member States. This resolution objects to the authorisation of this Genetically Modified Organism (GMO). We voted in favour. It is necessary and urgent to amend the current legislative framework in order to respect the right of each Member State not to want GMOs on its territory, for food and/or cultivation, for reasons of protection of food sovereignty, the environment, biodiversity and public health.

name: Franck PROUST
text: In writing. I voted against this objection. Indeed, the European Commission has not exceeded its powers and has complied well with the procedure for authorising GMOs, thanks in particular to the opinion of the European Food Safety Authority. As a reminder, this proposal for market authorization was forwarded to the Commission, which did not reject it. Also, these objections used by political groups such as the Greens have no real effect because they relate to acts of execution. More generally, I would like to point out that France bans the cultivation of GMOs, even though it imports them.

name: Julia REID
text: in writing. ‒ We in UKIP are concerned about the safety of GMOs for health and the environment, but we would prefer our national Parliament to legislate on this delicate issue rather than the European Parliament.

name: Sofia RIBEIRO
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted against, since genetically modified cotton DAS-24236-5×DAS-21Ø23-5×MON-88913-8 expresses phosphotricinprotein acetyltransferase (PAT), which confers tolerance to glufosinate-ammonium herbicides, and the modified protein CP4 5-enolpiruvil-chiquimato-3-phosphate-synthase (CP4EPSPS), which confers tolerance to glyphosate-based herbicides, and cry1F and cry1ac proteins, which provide protection against certain lepidopteran pests, and whereas on March 20, 2015 , the International Cancer Research Centre – the WHO agency specialising in this disease – has classified glisophate as probably carcinogenic to humans. Although cultivation necessarily takes place on the territory of a Member State, trade in GMOs crosses borders, which means that it would be impossible to apply the national prohibition on sales and use proposed by the Commission without reintroducing border controls on imports.

name: Bronis ROPĖ
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report, which opposes the decision by the European Commission to allow market access for products, containing genetically modified cotton 281-24-236 × 3006-210-23 × MON 88913 (DAS-24236-5×DAS-21Ø23-5×MON-88913-8). The European Parliament considers that that the Commission implementing decision is not compatible with Union law because it is incompatible with the objective of Regulation (EC) No 1829/2003, which, in accordance with the general principles laid down in Regulation (EC) No 178/2002, aims to establish a legal framework to ensure a high level of protection of human life and health, animal health and consumer interests with regard to genetically modified food and feed, while ensuring the effective functioning of the internal market.

name: Fernando RUAS
text: in writing. \u2012 Genetically modified cotton designated DAS 24236 5×DAS 21Ø23 5×MON-88913-8 expresses phosphotricine protein acetyltransferase (PAT), which confers tolerance to glyphosate-based herbicides and protection against certain lepidoptera pests, and, in accordance with Regulation (EC) No 1829 of 2003, it may be marketed. However, on 20 March 2015, the International Cancer Research Centre – the WHO agency specialising in this disease – classified glisophate as probably carcinogenic to humans. In April this year, and in a similar vote, I took into account at the same time the assessments of the European Food Safety Authority (EFSA) which said that glyphosate was "unlikely to have a carcinogenic risk to humans" and the doubts expressed by the scientific community, so, in view of the precautionary principle, I also decided to abstain in this vote.

name: Lola SÁNCHEZ CALDENTEY
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the objection since genetically modified organisms (GMOs) are not managing to control pests and weeds, and instead have led to the appearance of superpestes and superhighds. The cap's new objectives include ensuring food security, protecting the environment and ensuring the economic and social dynamism of rural areas. It is difficult to justify that monsanto's transgenic seed approval meets one of these three objectives.

name: Maria Lidia SENRA RODRÍGUEZ
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this objection to the marketing of genetically modified cotton 281-24-236 × 3006-210-23 × MON 88913 (this cotton is resistant to glyphosate and ammonium glufosinate) because I am totally against genetically modified organisms and, therefore, of new authorizations thereof. Moreover, it is clear that the current procedure for the authorisation of genetically modified food and feed is not working properly. That is why I am in favour of this and any objections raised in relation to the authorisation of GMOs, and I voted accordingly.

name: Siôn SIMON
text: in writing. ‒ Today, I voted in favour of the objection pursuant to Rule 106 on the placing on the market of genetically modified cotton 281-24-236 × 3006-210-23 × MON 88913, as the authorisation of GMOs resistant to herbicides is likely to result in excessive herbicide spraying. It is important to ensure that the EU regulatory framework with regards to GMOs is further improved, particularly in terms of assessing GMOs’ impacts on the wider environment as well as on human health.

name: Branislav ŠKRIPEK
text: Writing. \u2012 I agree that the European Parliament is asking the Commission to withdraw its draft implementing decision authorising the placing on the market of products containing genetically modified cotton 281-24-236 × 3006-210-23 × MON 88913) as well as products composed of or produced from it. I consider that the Commission's draft implementing decision does not comply with Union law, whereas it is incompatible with the objective of Regulation (EC) No 1829/2003, which, according to the general principles laid down in Regulation (EC) No 178/2002, is to provide the basis for ensuring a high level of protection of human life and health, animal health and welfare, the environment and the interests of consumers with regard to genetically modified food and feed, while ensuring the effective functioning of the internal market. I voted in favour of this resolution.

name: Davor ŠKRLEC
text: Written. ‒ I voted positively for this report, but this explanation of the vote is a criticism of the existing system of evaluation of the work of MEMBERS of the European Parliament solely on the basis of the statistical number of parliamentary activities potentiated in Croatia, which does not really reflect the actual quality and quantity of work, efficiency and most of all the success of parliamentary action.

name: Monika SMOLKOVÁ
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported the objection to the location of GENETICALLY MODIFIED COTTON on the European market because I share the opinion of the Committee on the Environment that the Commission's implementing decision on this matter goes beyond the implementing powers. Doubts also remain as to the procedures that accompanied the adoption of the implementing decision, as neither the member states' committees nor the Board of Appeal adopted an opinion on the Commission's decision. As regards this genetically modified cotton, it is known to expressing, inter alia, a modified protein that ensures tolerance to glyphosate-based herbicides. However, the International Agency for Research on Cancer put glyphosate on the list of substances that can have a cancer-forming effect on humans last year. As the cultivation of GMO crops may take place on the territory of one Member State, but trade in these products is of a cross-border nature, I believe that the Commission should come up with a more precise proposal. As GM crops can have a negative impact on the human body, we should only proceed with their registration with caution if we remove all doubts.

name: Igor ŠOLTES
text: Writing. The European Parliament has successfully expressed its disagreement with the authorisation of five food and feed products from genetically modified organisms. These include products containing genetically modified cotton MON 88913, which this resolution deals with. At the same time, the European Commission has rejected the call for a change in the authorisation procedure for the use of individual GMOs, as the European Parliament considers that the procedure is currently not democratic, as decisions are now being taken by the Commission. There is also a certain lack of data on the use and import of GMOs, as the Commission rarely shares data with the European Parliament in such cases. In relation to gmOs, which the Commission wishes to approve for use, research is also carried out by the European Food Safety Authority. As I believe that our food must be kept safe and healthy, I voted in favour of the Parliament resolution which seeks to ensure that the authorisation for use is not accepted.

name: Dubravka ŠUICA
text: Written. ‒ The Commission's draft decision on the marketing of GM cotton was not voted in line with the EU legislation envisaged and the Commission exceeded its powers. No opinion has been issued on the draft implementing decision and the majority that voted on the draft does not represent the will of most Member States. This exceptional legislation procedure is unsuitable for decision-making essential for the protection of human health, animal health and the environment. It provides for the possibility of a Member State to prohibit the cultivation of those products on its territory. However, the problem arises when they are banned from being sold in a Member State – this would create the need to check imports, which is contrary to EU principles. I therefore support the European Parliament's objection and resolution on the European Commission's draft decision on the marketing of GM cotton 281-24-236 × 3006-210-23 × MON 88913.

name: Eleftherios SYNADINOS
text: Writing. We are against any attempt to liberalise GMOs;

name: Tibor SZANYI
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of genetically modified 281-24-236 × 3006-210-23 × MON 88913 cotton (DAS-24236-5×DAS-21Ø23-5×MON-88913-8), a motion for a resolution on the draft Commission implementing decision authorising the placing on the market of products consisting of or produced there from it. On 12 March 2009, Dow AgroSciences Europe submitted an application to the competent authority of the Netherlands for the placing on the market of foodstuffs, food ingredients and feedingstuffs containing, consisting of or produced from the abovementioned cotton. This cotton contains a protein called phosphinotricin acetyltransferase (PAT), which provides resistance to herbicides containing glufosinate ammonium. It also contains Cry1F and Cry1Ac proteins that protect against certain pests.  Glyphosate was classified as a substance likely to be carcinogenic to humans in 2015 and since the entry into force of Regulation (EC) No 1829/2003, authorisation decisions have been adopted by the Commission without the opinions of the Member States' committees in accordance with the applicable legislation. The legislative proposal amending Regulation (EC) No 1829/2003 was rejected by Parliament in 2015 on the ground that, while production necessarily occurs on the territory of a Member State, trade in GMOs crosses borders, which means that the national 'sales and use' ban proposed by the Commission could not be enforced without the restoration of import border controls. I agree that the draft Commission implementing decision goes beyond the implementing powers laid down in Regulation (EU) No 1829/2003 and I therefore voted in favour of the motion.

name: Marc TARABELLA
text: In writing. The European Parliament, which I fully agree with on this issue, considers that this draft commission enforcement decision exceeds the enforcement powers set out in Directive 2001/18/EC. EFSA's crop risk analysis is incomplete and the Commission's risk management recommendations are inadequate. Moreover, the Commission's draft enforcement decision is not in line with EU law. We therefore reject this request!

name: Pavel TELIČKA
text: in writing. ‒ The objection proposed by the Committee on the Environment, Public Health and Food Safety against the proposal to place on the market genetically modified cotton 281-24-236 x 3006-210-23 x MON 88913 is part of a larger theme of systematically opposing GM authorisations on mainly procedural grounds and is not the right way to force the Commission to change the EU level authorisation regime. I voted against the motion to object the proposal, as I believe that as long as there are no convincing scientific reasons to object to a GM authorisation, I will continue to follow the advice given by the European Food and Safety Agency.

name: Ruža TOMAŠIĆ
text: Written. ‒ I voted to object to the Commission's implementing decision to authorising the marketing of certain products containing, consisting of or manufactured from genetically modified types of cotton.  The Commission should take such decisions primarily on the basis of the protection of human health and the environment and should be guided by the fact that the European Parliament, as a representative body of EU citizens, has never given its consent to the placing on the market of GM products. In addition, some Member States have declared that they do not wish to introduce GENETICally modified products on their market, be they human food, feed or other products. I therefore believe that each country should decide for itself whether it wants to introduce GM products into its market, even though the European Union's risk assessment process on GM products is probably one of the strictest in the world.

name: Romana TOMC
text: Writing. - Objection under Article 106: placing on the market of products containing genetically modified cotton 281-24-236 × 3006-210-23 × MON 88913. On 12 October 2008, Dow AgroSciences Europe submitted to the Competent Authority of the United In accordance with Articles 5 and 17 of Regulation (EC) No 1829/2003, the Commission submitted an application to the competent authority of the Netherlands for the placing on the market × of foods, food ingredients and feedingstuffs containing cotton 281-24-236 × and 3006-210-23 and MON 88913. The commission's draft implementing decision is not in line with Union law, as it is not consistent with the objective of Regulation (EC) No 1829/2003, which is in line with the general principles laid down in Regulation (EC) No 178/2002 – to provide a basis for ensuring a high level of protection of human life and health, animal health and welfare, the environment and the interests of the consumer in relation to genetically modified food and feed, while ensuring the proper functioning of the internal market.

name: Estefanía TORRES MARTÍNEZ
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the objection since genetically modified organisms (GMOs) are not managing to control pests and weeds, and instead have led to the appearance of superpestes and superhighds. The cap's new objectives include ensuring food security, protecting the environment and ensuring the economic and social dynamism of rural areas. It is difficult to justify that monsanto's transgenic seed approval meets one of these three objectives.

name: Mylène TROSZCZYNSKI
text: In writing. Despite systematic objections, the Commission persists in issuing permits for the cultivation or import of GMOs.  Parliament persists in objecting, to no avail, since the Commission does not take this into account. These objections help to unmask the hypocrisy of the majority parliamentarians (who maintain the Commission) in the face of the totalitarianism of the European Union.  I vote FOR this objection.

name: Kazimierz Michał UJAZDOWSKI
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 Genetically modified food can have a negative impact on humans, animals and the environment and should be controlled in detail in these respects.  I have doubts as to whether the Commission should allow further types of such food and genetically modified feed to be placed on the market. This also applies to certain products containing, consisting of or produced from a genetically modified cotton variety. I therefore supported the opposition.

name: Miguel URBÁN CRESPO
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the objection since genetically modified organisms (GMOs) are not managing to control pests and weeds, and instead have led to the appearance of superpestes and superhighds. The cap's new objectives include ensuring food security, protecting the environment and ensuring the economic and social dynamism of rural areas. It is difficult to justify that monsanto's transgenic seed approval meets one of these three objectives.

name: Ernest URTASUN
text: in writing. – I voted in favour of the GMO import objection as I have decided to object systematically to any GM import authorisation. This was following the EP rejection of the EC proposal to renationalise instead of democratise the authorisation procedure. In relation of the GMO cultivation I also decided to object as all three maizes are Bt maizes: they all themselves produce the Bt toxin that enables them to be ‘pest-resistant’, meaning they are themselves toxic to the targeted pests – but also the non-targeted, even if those ones are protected or pollinate.

name: Ivo VAJGL
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the objection pursuant to Rule 106(2) and (3) of the Rules of Procedure on the draft Commission implementing decision authorising the placing on the market of products containing, consisting of, or produced from genetically modified cotton 281-24-236 × 3006-210-23 × MON 88913 (DAS-24236-5×DAS-21Ø23-5×MON-88913-8) pursuant to Regulation (EC) No 1829/2003 of the European Parliament and of the Council (D046168/00 – 2016/2923(RSP)). I voted in favour of the objection because I believe that GMOs are now being authorised in the EU by the Commission without the support of opinions of Member State committees. I find that the Commission goes beyond its powers. Although this was supposed to be an exception to the usual decision-making procedure, it has in fact become the norm.

name: Ángela VALLINA
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this objection to the marketing of genetically modified cotton 281-24-236 × 3006-210-23 × MON 88913 (this cotton is resistant to glyphosate and ammonium glufosinate) because I am totally against genetically modified organisms and, therefore, of new authorizations thereof. Moreover, it is clear that the current procedure for the authorisation of genetically modified food and feed is not working properly. That is why I am in favour of this and any objections raised in relation to the authorisation of GMOs, and I voted accordingly.

name: Miguel VIEGAS
text: in writing. We are in favour of this opposition, and any future objection to the authorisation of GMOs, as a matter of principle, but also with the purpose of showing the European Commission the need to amend the recently adopted legislation with a legislative proposal that will respect the right of an individual not to authorise GMOs for food on its territory.

name: Harald VILIMSKY
text: Writing. The resolution states that the Commission's draft implementing decision is incompatible with EU law and therefore calls on the Commission to withdraw its draft. As EFSA's risk assessment of cultivation is incomplete and the recommendations on risk management proposed by the Commission are deficient, I voted in favour of the resolution.

name: Udo VOIGT
text: Writing. The objections raised in the motion for a resolution to the placing on the market of the genetically modified products in question are well founded and necessarily suggest that the Commission rejects the relevant implementing decision. The motion for a resolution before us is therefore in favour.

name: Julie WARD
text: in writing. ‒ In these votes on GMO objection motions, Labour MEPs have exemplified their case-by-case approach to GM technology, while adhering strictly to the principles of robust risk assessment, the precautionary principle and the authority of EFSA, and acting pragmatically with regard to biotechnology which is already strongly present in our food chain. My colleagues and I thus vote against the introduction of GMOs resistant to herbicides.

name: Lieve WIERINCK
text: in writing. – I voted against this motion for a resolution. It is very important that Europe can ensure its own food supply. At the same time, this needs to be done in an efficient and sustainable manner. Science helps us in achieving this goal. It is important that products developed in this regard are safe for both consumers and the environment. Such an assessment, research and consequent conclusions need to be based on scientific processes and empiric evidence. It is the task and the responsibility of the European Food Safety Agency (EFSA) to ensure that this is the case: that is why the agency was established by the institutions of the European Union. In this case, EFSA has, at the request of the Commission, duly assessed this product and concluded that it is safe. In my view, EFSA is the appropriate authority to give recommendations on these matters and likewise is the Commission the relevant authority to act on those. Therefore I voted against this proposal which would go against EFSA’s judgment.

name: Jana ŽITŇANSKÁ
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported the European Parliament's objection to the Commission's implementing decision authorising the placing on the market of genetically modified cotton. My opinion on GMOs does not change, as there is not yet sufficient evidence regarding their wholesomeness. Likewise, we do not have sufficient information on their effects on the environment. That is why I agree with the view that, in the circumstances where the risk assessment is not thorough and complete, the European Commission has exceeded its powers in this implementing regulation, let alone acted in accordance with the precautionary principle, which is absolutely necessary in cases where human health may be at risk.

name: Carlos ZORRINHO
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of all objections under Rule 106 of the Rules of Procedure, because I agree with the opposition to genetically modified substances for which there are still no solid scientific results to allow them to be authorised without compromising public health. Therefore, until the Commission proposes a new legislative framework for these substances, the European Socialist Group will continue to support these objections in concert.

name: Marco ZULLO
text: in writing. By voting in favour of this resolution, I wanted to express a dry no to the placing on the market of products containing, consisting of or obtained from genetically modified cotton. The genetically modified cotton under discussion is designed to express certain proteins that give tolerance to herbicides based on ammonium glufosinate and glyphosate. The International Agency for Research on Cancer (agency of the World Health Organization specializing in oncology) has included glyphosate in the list of probable carcinogens for humans. It is clear that this is a trade package designed to facilitate the greater use of these dangerous herbicides. GMOs are an interest of the few and an unnecessary and unacceptable risk that offers significant benefits only to companies that patent them. I believe in a GMO-free Europe, which protects people's health and not the interests of biotech multinationals, and I voted for it.

name: Rainer WIELAND
text: The next item on the agenda is the debate on the Commission statement on sustainable finances (2016/2896(RSP)).

name: Rainer WIELAND
text: Vice-President of the Commission. – Mr President, honourable Members, let me first thank you for introducing this very important topic of sustainable finance. Vice-President Dombrovskis and I are jointly responsible for the Capital Markets Union and this obviously has a close link to the sustainable finance issue. Last year we witnessed some landmark international agreements with the adoption of the Sustainable Development Goals (SDG) and the Paris Climate Agreement (COP21). Implementing a transition towards a more sustainable world requires determined efforts in many policy areas. In terms of public finance, the EU is leading the way due to its commitment to spend at least 20% of its 2014-2020 budget on climate-related projects and policies. Work is ongoing to increase the availability of green funds through the European Fund for Strategic Investments (EFSI). But we need to move beyond public finance and to further reach out to private investors. The financial sector has a role to play. The Capital Markets Union initiative addresses the importance of long-term and sustainable investments. In the most recent CMU Communication, the Commission has indicated a need for a broader strategy on sustainable finance. This is necessary to support investment in clean technologies and ensure that the financial system can finance growth in a sustainable manner over the long term. The Commission also monitors developments in the green bond market. A study on the potential of the bond market to finance resource-efficient investments is under preparation. The final report will be ready in November. The Commission has also adopted initiatives to increase company transparency, such as the Directive on non-financial reporting that will be transposed by the end of 2016, and the related non-binding guidelines, currently under preparation. Last July, a political agreement on IORP2 was achieved that will require occupational pension funds to consider taking into account environmental, social and governance factors in their investment decisions. The Commission is also assessing the follow-up to the recent public consultation on long-term and sustainable investment which emphasised the importance of environmental, social and governance issues for the long-term performance of companies and investors, and the challenges institutional investors faced in this area. Since sustainable finance has no boundaries, work must also be done at global level. The Commission supports the work of the FSB industry-led Task Force which will provide recommendations on climate-related financial disclosures early next year. We will take these into account as much as possible when preparing the upcoming EU guidelines on non-financial reporting. At the same time, the Commission is a member of the G20 Green Finance Study Group (GFSG), which recently identified options on how to mobilise private green investment; we will also continue this work under the German Presidency. Beyond relying on public finance and mobilising the private sector, the Commission is also looking at how, and to what extent, climate change implications could affect the financial sector or even be a source of systemic risk to it. Some EU institutions and central banks of EU Member States have already begun analysing this. Last February, the European Systemic Risk Board proposed enhanced disclosures and the incorporation of climate-related prudential risks into stress tests as policy responses to mitigate risks for the financial system. This may be a suitable trigger to integrate considerations about long-term environmental risks and opportunities into the mindset of private investors. Undoubtedly more needs to be done at EU level, and in a comprehensive manner. That is why the Commission will establish an expert group on green finance that will help formulate the EU strategy. This group will provide advice on how to mobilise private capital for sustainable and green investments; and to better understand and deal with the financial risks related to the transition to a low-carbon economy. The expert group will be composed of senior experts representing various stakeholders of the green and sustainable finance spectrum.  Honourable Members, I am interested to hear your views on the ongoing work streams and also I am expecting some input from your side for future work streams.

name: Theodor Dumitru STOLOJAN
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. – Mr President, there is no doubt that we are all experiencing the effects of climate change and no country is without these effects. Even in a country like my country, which is far from the oceans, we have climate change that simply cannot be explained. That is why all the efforts that are being made to mobilise the funding needed to change the structure of economies, from economies that consume a lot of fuel that generate greenhouse gas emissions, to economies that substantially reduce these greenhouse gas emissions are welcomed. I note, from the word of the Vice-President of the European Commission, Katainen, a number of initiatives that the European Commission has in this area. Indeed, there is a fundamental problem to which we must give an answer: how do we attract private capital in this financing? We know very well: private equity will not go into this financing unless it sees a favourable return for investors. That is why the efforts we are making to achieve the Single Capital Market in the European Union and the other efforts are welcome. Let us not forget that there was a commitment, made several years ago, by all the countries of the world, to make a fund of about a hundred billion to finance the transition to an economy that responds to the challenges of climate change, and practically little has been achieved from this commitment, at the time, of the countries. Within the European Union we have a lot of funds that can also be used from the European Union budget, but also from the resources of the Member States, which can be used to encourage this shift to a green energy economy. I would, however, like to mention here that the populations, the population, the citizens, however, have had a negative reaction to certain incentive schemes that we have made, especially for those who invested in green energy (wind and so on), where there were simply too many incentives to what was normal. So I think that here we need to act very clearly, to all think about what the optimal size of incentives must be for those who invest in green energy.

name: Bernd KÖLMEL
text: Mr President, I would like to like to take back from the ECR Group. Mr President, I would like to thank the Commissioner Katainen, thank you for your report. I would like to start this debate in such a way that I would like to stress that environmental aspects do not override basic arithmetic. This means that when we talk about sustainable finances, we should first of all look at the situation of the EU and its Member States. A large proportion of EU countries are over-indebted. Not only that, but also the private sector and the citizens of these countries have accumulated large mountains of debt. However, if the economy and the citizens are heavily indebted, these countries end up with low tax revenues, and as the tip of the iceberg, we see that states such as Greece or Italy have long since ceased to be able to finance themselves on the capital market. Sustainable finances mean that you can only spend as much as you have. If you want to spend more, you can take out a loan – but that can only be done as long as you can pay the interest and the repayments due for it. This simple truth has been disregarded by some states for a long time.  There are always reasons to take on debt for this. But we have almost never seen states repay their debts. When the debt has reached a certain size – some speak of a limit of 90 percent debt in terms of gross domestic product – then in the long run there is hardly any escape from this spiral. And the behaviour of the euro area countries is a deterrent example of unsustainable, unsolidarity. The euro is based on the Maastricht Treaty, and its core elements are debt ceilings and a so-called 'no bail out' clause. In the past 15 years, the provisions of this treaty have been broken well over 100 times – without consequences! Only seven euro Member States currently meet the debt ceiling, and if you add up the payments and guarantees from the euro area countries, including the ECB's Target II balances, you get tens of billions of euros that are on fire here. And denying this amounts to a gigantic irresponsibility. The European Commission also has a responsibility to do so, Commissioner: it is the guardian of the European Treaties, and it must ensure that it is respected. Then we would have sound finances, and then we could talk on a completely different basis about whether we could open up new instruments and finance so-called green projects. However, the European Commission is not complying with its obligation. Instead, the ECB has taken on the task of keeping the euro countries afloat. To prevent reasonable interest rates, it is pumping billions into this financial system through a government bond-buying program. But the ECB has made itself a prisoner of its own policy here. The zero interest rate policy removes the pressure of reform from the crisis states, with the result that the debt continues. So what do we have to do to get out of this dilemma? We need, first of all, an honest, analytical approach to this sovereign funding crisis. And that includes countries that do not meet the Maastricht criteria having to leave the euro area. Of course, we must not leave these countries alone with their problems. This requires aid and also debt cuts. We must share them. But it is true: "better an end with terror than a terror without end". In addition, we really need to be sustainable. This means that there will no longer be pump-funded election gifts. These must be as taboo as investments in which the state cannot afford to repay depreciation. We must not continue on a path towards even more state investment, even more redistribution, even more governance of the economy and also of the citizens. That is the wrong way to go! Instead, we must finally free the forces of the economy from their shackles. In other words, we need fewer regulations, we need to take the citizens more with us in all the projects that we are planning – as good as they may be. But it is not acceptable to be able to steer a European Union in one direction from any headquarters where we are pretending what to do and what is not. I therefore appeal to you and the Commission to make a commitment! Ensure that the existing contracts are respected. Otherwise, we cannot assume that the EU states will comply with new treaties.

name: Ivan JAKOVČIĆ
text: on behalf of the ALDE Club. – Dear President, when my friends from my student days see that I was talking about sustainable finances, they will probably laugh because I used to be editor-in-chief of a magazine called Bankruptcy during my studies. A magazine that came out only in zero numbers because it was immediately banned afterwards, because during communism there was no talk of bankruptcy. It could not be said in what was then Yugoslavia, which was at least a little more open than other eastern states.  However, today we can talk about bankruptcy, today we can also talk about that, as we know, some countries and even eurozone countries are close to bankruptcy or have been close to bankruptcy, that some cities, some local self-government units have come into a situation to go bankrupt and that some regions have come into serious financial trouble. We really need to talk about these and such sustainable finances here. And that is why I support this initiative that we are hearing about today from the Commission, but I want to add something, as my small contribution. I think in any case we need to talk about the synergy of financing many projects that are important to us especially when we talk about climate change and green projects that simply cannot be seriously financed without having in mind the need for various types of subsidies.  So, if we are talking about this synergy that we can produce, I see this synergy between what the Commission is doing and what the Commission can finance through, in particular, cohesion policy, but of course all that can be done by the European Investment Bank, what member states can do and what they can do, I insist on it, and regional and local authorities in areas where some projects are done because we know very well that both regional and local authorities have subsidy options and can help in the realization of various projects.  When we talk specifically about energy, I am more than satisfied that finally one project in Croatia, called Plomin 3, is no longer in operation because it was the idea to use coal and to re-ruin the next twenty, thirty years one area. However, to invest in wind farms and solar energy, as we have a number of examples in Croatia, we know that it is looking for the right kind of subsidies and in this context I seriously think that the Commission has to come out with concrete proposals where we really need to use solar energy in Europe because it is not logical for me that on many parallels where the sun has very little we often see solar power plants or attempts to use the cost-effectiveness of the sun for energy purposes.  And finally, I would add that, I am convinced that all these aspects of funding that are available can create sustainable financing, not bankrupt us.

name: Molly SCOTT CATO
text: on behalf of the Verts/ALE Group. – Mr President, now that EU has ratified the Paris Agreement, we have a tremendous challenge to decarbonise our economy, but also a tremendous opportunity. Humanity’s journey into the fossil fuel era was marked by the enclosure of common resources, monopoly control and the growth in inequality. Finding ways to develop and invest in renewable resources offers a wonderful opportunity to do things differently. This is why, as Greens, we believe that sustainable finance must also be equitable finance. The overwhelming majority of finance for the green transition so far is private finance. Through the creation of green bonds, bankers can make use of what financiers like to call ‘the magic of money’ to multiply an initial stock of capital many times over, with the value of this multiplication staying with the shareholders and employees of the bank.  So the need to invest in a sustainable future could be used to swell bank profits, exacerbating inequality. How much better it would be if the magic of money could be used for the benefit of the citizens of the world, if we funded the transition through public banking and through community ownership. Then the value of money creation could be invested for public good and the value of renewable energy could accrue to local communities. The German KfW Bank provides an excellent model of such a method of capturing the power of banking for public good and I think such a model should be at the heart of sustainable finance.  I have also championed the idea of green quantitative easing to ensure that some of the vast amount of money being created by the European Central Bank should be channelled towards green investments. I believe the Commission and Parliament need to work together to undertake a critical review of the impact of the current QE programme and find ways to ensure that it is redesigned to play a central role in the financing of the green economy in Europe.  For some time Greens in this House have been ringing the alarm bell about the systemic risk to financial services, products and companies from assets which are grossly overvalued in the context of the EU’s policies to tackle climate change. Since at least 75% of fossil fuel reserves have to be kept in the ground if we are to keep within the 2° global warming limit agreed in Paris, companies, banks and pension funds that have significant fossil—related assets on their books are vastly overvalued, a phenomenon known as the carbon bubble. McKinsey and others have estimated that 30% to 40% of fossil fuel companies’ value could be threatened by this carbon bubble. Mark Carney, Governor of the Bank of England, has responded to this alert, as has Mario Draghi, as evidenced in the report produced by the European Systemic Risk Board. We have taken an important first step to tackle the carbon bubble in the specific case of pensions, as was mentioned by the Commissioner. The Parliament has voted that the extent of these stranded assets must be notified to the regulatory authorities, but we should not stop there. It is not only pensions that are at risk. Insurance companies are also holding large quantities of stranded assets. Both the European Systemic Risk Board (ESRB) and the Ecofin Council have discussed the idea of undertaking carbon stress tests for banks and we need to make urgent progress on that front.
